DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, May 31, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1594: Tintoretto, originally Jacopo Robusti, Italian painter of religious, mythological and historical subjects as well as portraits, dies at the age of 76. His works include "Saint George and the Dragon," "The Last Judgment" and "The Last Supper."
1859: Big Ben, the clock tower of the House of Parliament in London, goes into operation.
1923: Rainier III, Prince of Monaco, is born. He married the American actress Grace Kelly in 1956 and transformed Monaco from a gambling paradise into a booming international business center.
1924: The Republic of China signs the Peking agreement with the Soviet Union, recognizing the Soviet government.
1930: Clint Eastwood, American actor and director, is born. He hit the big time in movies known as spaghetti westerns, such as "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" and "High Plains Drifter," before turning to detective roles in the "Dirty Harry" series.
1933: The Sino-Japanese Tangku Armistice Agreement is signed, ending hostilities in Northern China.
1940: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt asks Congress for a US$1.3 billion defense spending program.
1945: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who remains as president of the Republic of China, resigns as premier and is succeeded by Dr. T. V. Soong.
1958: The Soviet Union agrees to talk with the United States on an atmospheric test ban treaty.
1961: South Africa declares itself a republic independent of the British Commonwealth.
1970: A strong earthquake rocks northern Peru, killing more than 60,000 people and injuring at least 200,000 others.
1973: The China Youth Corps elects Lee Huan as its director.
1973: Vice Foreign Minister H. K. Yang leaves on a 45-day tour of Africa as the special envoy of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: The Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development under the Executive Yuan is reorganized into the Council for Economic Planning and Development, with Chang Chi-cheng serving as its chairman.
1974: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Malaysia.
1976: The provisional government of East Timor declares the country's merger with Indonesia.
1976: ROC Economic Affairs Minister Y.S. Sun and Colombian Agriculture Minister Rafael Pardo Buelvas sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1984: The ruling Kuomintang approves the nomination of Chang Chi-cheng as governor of the Central Bank of China, Wang Chang-ching as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, and Chen Li-an as chairman of the National Science Council.
1989: Jim Wright, speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, resigns following investigations by the House Ethics Committee into financial improprieties, becoming the first speaker in U.S. history to be forced to resign.
1989: One million students participate in the "Hand in Hand, Heart to Heart" rally in support of the mainland democracy movement.
1992: The Mainland Affairs Council allows Chinese mainlanders to come to Taiwan to care for elderly or sick relatives.
1997: The Legislative Yuan passes the third reading of the Public Television Bill, which enables the nation's public television station to begin broadcasting in 1998.
1999: ROC Education Minister Lin Chin-jiang says that he has tendered his resignation so that he can concentrate on undergoing treatment for a brain tumor.
2000: The Council of Labor Affairs announces that a temporary ban on the importation of workers from the Philippines will become effective on June 1.
2001: Senior presidential adviser K.T. Li, who is credited as laying the foundation for Taiwan's econo;mic development in the 1970s and 980s and later helping foster the island's hi-tech industry, dies at the age of 92.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Friendship with insincere men, with men of insinuating manners, and with glib-tongued men: such friendships are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan wants to help preserve Guatemalan relics: president
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, May 30 (CNA) 05/31/09 16:07:47 (By Huang Juei-hung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Ma Ying-jeou told his host, Guatemalan President Alvaro Colom Caballeros, Saturday that Taiwan would like to help Guatemala conserve its historic relics.

"Conserving historic relics or sites is a mammoth engineering task that takes a long time to complete, " Ma said during a dinner party held in Guatemala City, adding that the ROC government would like to extend a helping hand if necessary.
Ma and his wife Chow Mei-ching hosted the dinner party to thank Colom for his nation's hospitality during their three-day visit to Guatemala -- one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.

Earlier in the day, the Taiwan first couple visited the Tikal area, where they viewed the country's most prominent Mayan ruins, which are a living testimony to a culture that flourished there between 700 BC and 900 AD.
Ma and Colom released a joint statement the previous day reiterating that they will continue efforts to promote bilateral ties and cooperation in a wide range of fields.
Ma and his 158-member entourage will depart Sunday for El Salvador, where they will attend the June 1 inauguration of President-elect Mauricia Funes.
El Salvador is the last leg of Ma's 10-day, three-nation diplomatic tour of Central America that also has taken him to Belize.
Ma and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taiwan June 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bird strike at Taoyuan airport in April caused by eagle: report

TEXT.P: The bird strike incident involving a China Airlines flight at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport April 16 was caused by a crested serpent eagle, according to a report released last week by the Flight Safety Foundation-Taiwan.

The report said that an examination of a small amount of flesh and feathers from what was left of the shredded bird showed that the CAL flight collided with the medium-large raptor known scientifically as Spilornis cheela, a reptile eater that hunts over woodland mainly for snakes and lizards.

Flight safety experts at the foundation noted that the airport authorities had launched a drive to eliminate rodents around the airport shortly before the incident. They said in the report that the eagle was probably attracted by rat carcasses or slow-moving rodents under the influence of rat poison.
A bird strike at the Taoyuan airport caused by a bird of prey of such a large size is a rare occurrence, as previous incidents involved only small birds, the report said.
The CAL jetliner involved in the strike was taxiing on the runway at the time and did not suffer serious damage, it added.
Bird strikes are a perennial problem for aircraft at Taiwan's 27 airports for civilian and military aircraft.

The Flight Safety Foundation recorded six such incidents in April and May at airports in Taoyuan, Taipei, Tainan, Chiayi, Gangshan and Hualien -- caused by a variety of birds, including red turtle doves, barn swallows and large Indian pratincoles.
The air force has lost four expensive jet fighters to bird strikes since 1991, but there have been not crashes of civilian aircraft attributed to bird strikes.

According to statistics compiled by the foundation, there were 841 bird strike incidents involving military and civilian aircraft in Taiwan between 2002 and 2005, 108 of which resulted in damage and causing 22 planes to abandon their scheduled takeoffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical students protest against academic credentials policy

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 students from Taiwan's major medical schools took it to the streets Sunday to protest a policy they claim favors Taiwanese doctors who have received medical education abroad.

The policy against which they were protesting allows foreign-trained Taiwanese doctors to practice in Taiwan once they pass a two-stage national medical exam, which is generally considered not very difficult.

Liu Tzu-hung, a senior at National Taiwan University School of Medicine who co- organized the protest, said they hope foreign-trained medical school graduates should also have to do internships at local hospitals before being allowed to sit national medical exams.

Liu said these people, some of whom received their medical education in eastern European countries such as Poland and Romania, may have received diplomas from abroad, but lack on-the-spot clinical experience in Taiwanese hospitals.

"Because they have not done internships and because of their lack of clinical experience in Taiwanese hospitals, critical conditions and emergencies occur as a result of their practices, often requiring their locally educated peers to scramble to correct their errors, " Liu elaborated.
The protesters also demanded that foreign medical school graduates should have their academic credentials certified by the Ministry of Education before being allowed to sit national exams.
The protesting students also opposed a "sunset bill" proposal that would exempt those who are now studying at medical schools in Eastern European countries from being subject to the new regulations.
The students said they want relevant draft amendments to be included on the agenda of the present legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12th swine flu case confirmed in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) confirmed another imported case of swine flu Sunday, bringing to 12 the number of people infected with the influenza A(H1N1) virus in the country.
"The 12th case is a 33-year-old Taiwanese businessman who flew back to Taiwan from the United States via Hong Kong May 27, " said CECC spokesman Shih Wen-yi.
The man suffered a fever aboard the flight that departed from New York, according to Shih.
"Since the businessman was traveling first class to Hong Kong, no other passengers came into close contact with him during the flight," Shih said.

However, he then boarded another flight from Hong Kong to Taiwan on which he traveled economy class. A total of 40 people were seated in the three rows in front of and behind him during that flight, Shih noted.
Once back in Taiwan, he went to a movie with his wife and two friends in Taipei City.

As a consequence, a total of 44 people have come into close contact with him over the past three days, all of whom have been notified and told to closely monitor their health and contact the CECC if any flu symptoms develop.

In order to avoid causing public panic, the CECC decided last week that it will no longer identify the flights taken by swine flu patients unless there is evidence to show that the virus was contracted during the flight.
Moreover, Shih said that as Taiwan has not reported any more indigenous case for seven days, the country's swine flu alert was downgraded to the second level Sunday as previously scheduled.
To date, 12 swine flu cases have been confirmed in Taiwan, with no deaths.

The CECC raised the level of the country's swine flu alert to the third stage of yellow May 25 -- which denotes a situation in which imported cases have already caused a second wave of infections -- after the first case of domestic infection was confirmed that same day.
As of 2 p.m. Friday, 53 countries had officially reported 15,510 cases of A(H1N1) infection, including 99 deaths, according to the latest World Health Organization report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Couple tie the knot again after six decades of separation

TEXT.P: A 92-year-old veteran and his "former" wife tied the knot again Sunday, after being separated for decades with one in Taiwan and the other in China as a result of the Chinese civil war more than 60 years ago.
Lee Fu-tang, dressed in a trim business suit, arrived in a limousine to marry Kuan Wen-ying, 85, at his home in Yuanlin township in the central county of Changhua that morning.

A wedding ceremony was held at the courtyard of Lee's home, where the couple has lived since 2007 after Kuan came to Taiwan from their hometown in China's northern province of Shandong, followed by a wedding banquet, also held in the courtyard.
The wedding was organized with the assistance of the Taichung City-based Hondao Senior Citizen's Welfare Foundation.
The foundation decided to help organize the wedding after hearing of Lee's long- held hope of being able to remarry his wife in a "more formal wedding ceremony."

Lee said that he and Kuan used to play together as children when they were neighbors back in Shandong. They were later wed through a marriage arranged by their parents, but only over a table at a small restaurant with just their parents attending.

Lee said he left home three years later to join the Nationalist army and fight against Japanese invading troops and the emerging Chinese communists. Their son was also born at around that time, he went on, adding that he did not see Kuan and their only son again until 1993, when he got in contact with them and they began exchanging photos.

He traveled to Shandong to bring Kuan to Taiwan to live with him in 2007 -- after nearly 60 years of separation across the strait, during which they both remarried and had families of their own. Both Lee's Taiwanese wife and Kuan's Chinese husband had died by the time Lee made the trip to Shandong.
Lee kissed a shy Kuan on the cheek during the wedding ceremony, in which the couple vowed to keep each other company for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$20 surcharge on cigarettes from June 1: DOH

TEXT.P: The health and welfare surcharge on tobacco products will be increased from the present NT$10 per pack to NT$20 per pack from June 1, a senior health official said Sunday.

Chao Kun-yu, director of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said retail stores are allowed to sell off their existing cigarette stocks without asking their customers to pay the extra NT$10 surcharge.
He urged consumers to examine the cigarettes they buy to make sure the pack carries a sticker certifying the imposition of a NT$20 health and welfare surcharge.
The 100 percent surcharge increase will raise the average per-pack price for cigarettes to between NT$55 and NT$70 (US$2.15) per pack, depending on the brand.
According to an estimate by Chao, the new measure is expected to boost annual revenues from the health and welfare surcharge from NT$20 billion to between NT$32 billion and NT$36 billion.

In accordance with the Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act and the regulations governing the distribution of the tobacco health and welfare surcharge, the DOH will use 4 percent, or NT$1.39 billion, of the revenues from the surcharge as subsidies to help 470,000 less privileged people obtain national health insurance, Chao said.

The Bureau of National Health Insurance will receive 70 percent of the surcharge revenues and will spend NT$10 billion to meet its financial shortfall and the rest in various areas, including 6 percent for cancer prevention, 5 percent on raising the standards of medical services, 3 percent in areas lacking medical resources, another 3 percent on tobacco hazards prevention and 2 percent on treatment of rare diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Reading replacing smoking' drive launched on World No Tobacco Day

TEXT.P: The Nantou county government in central Taiwan launched a new publicity campaign Sunday to encourage smokers to replace smoking with reading as part of the observance of the May 31 World No Tobacco Day.

Magistrate Lee Chao-ching and Nantou County Council Speaker Wu Chi-hsiang stubbed out a giant-size burning cigarette in a ceremony held on the county government plaza to signify their determination to prevent the hazards caused by tobacco and promote a smoke-free society.
Noting that the drugs and chemicals found in cigarettes are detrimental to health, Lee said he looks forward to seeing local smokers quit as soon as possible for the sake of public health.
"Smoking not only threatens the health of the smoker but also harms non-smokers through second-hand smoke," Lee said.
He urged smokers to take up reading as a replacement for their smoking habits, saying that reading benefits both physical and mental health and contributes to national development in the long run.
Similar ceremonies were also held in the county's 13 major townships and villages to inspire local smokers.

As of Friday, 101 infractions had been reported throughout the county since the newly revised Tobacco Hazards Prevention Act came into effect in January that bars smoking in indoor public areas and workplaces, a local public health official said.
Among the violators, 65 cases involved students younger than 18, the official said.

He further said that anti-smoking patrols will be intensified at the county's major scenic spots and recreational areas, as the county government frequently receives complaints about illegal smoking in such areas.
With beautiful mountain scenery, Nantou -- the only land-locked county in Taiwan -- has long played a significant role in Taiwan's tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese deckhand on Taiwanese fishing boat bitten by shark

TEXT.P: A Chinese deckhand on a Taiwanese fishing boat suffered serious shark bite injuries aboard the boat Sunday while trying to move the seemingly unconscious fish to a freezer.

Officials from the Coast Guard Administration's 15th flotilla said they received a radio request for help from the skipper of the Chin Sheng Fa 13 to help Zhang Sanqian, 46, a native from Fujian province who was bleeding profusely because of the shark bites.

Zhang was given first aid treatment by health workers at a clinic on Green Island to stop bleeding before a helicopter from the National Airborne Services Corps lifted him to the Taitung branch of Macay Memorial Hospital in southeastern Taiwan for further treatment.
CGA officials quoted other crew members of Chin Sheng Fa 13 as saying that the crew caught the 80-kilogram shark in waters near Green Island during an operation to catch hake.

After Zhang and five other deckhands pulled the shark onto the deck, they had the fish electrocuted. As Zhang tried to pull the seemingly unconscious shark toward the freezer, it suddenly attacked him twice with its razor-sharp teeth, wounding his knee and tearing off large chunks of flesh from the back of his left lower leg.

Doctors at Macay Hospital said that Zhang needed 54 stitches to close the wounds, and that he was "out of danger" by noon. However, the doctors decided that Zhang should remain in an intensive care unit for a few days to prevent wound infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese trade delegation arrives for procurement mission

TEXT.P: A 77-member trade delegation from China arrived in Taipei Sunday to procure a variety of products ranging from high-tech devices to traditional craftworks.

The delegation, headed by Li Shuilin, president of the Association for Trade and Economic Exchange Across the Taiwan Straits (ATEEATS) , is composed of senior executives of five major Chinese export-import trade associations and six leading industry associations.

Among the members are also top management officers from more than 40 flagship companies in China, including Haier Group and Hasee Computer Co. Most of them have won bids to provide products under China's "home appliances to the countryside" project as part of its massive economic stimulus package.

Noting that Taiwan is the ATEEATS' main engagement target, Li said many of Taiwan-produced goods are badly needed in China. Therefore, he added, his association plans to send more procurement missions to Taiwan later this year.
The cross-strait trade and economic exchange association is set up by China's Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges.

Chao Yung-chuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) who greeted the Chinese delegation at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, said the group will procure electric home appliances, information technology (IT) products, chemicals, craftworks, textiles, foodstuffs and many other items.

TAITRA will organize a presentation at the Taipei International Convention Center Monday for Chinese buyers to meet their potential Taiwanese suppliers, Chao said, adding that the council will help local manufacturers to grasp business opportunities generated by China's "home appliances going to the countryside" project.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma arrives in El Salvador for presidential inauguration
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, May 31 (CNA) 05/31/09 23:48:17 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Ma Ying-jeou arrived in San Salvador Sunday to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mauricio Funes the following day.
Ma received a red carpet welcome at the airport. Carlos Montes, vice minister of foreign affairs of El Salvador, presided over the welcoming ceremony on behalf of the Salvadoran government.

Ma was accorded full military honors at the ceremony which was attended by Salvadoran officials as well as ROC Embassy staff and members of the ROC technical mission stationed in the Central American country and Taiwanese expatriate community leaders.
More than 100 Taiwanese expatriates turned out to greet Ma at Radisson Plaza Hotel where he will stay during his three-day state visit.
Ma has a hectic schedule on the first day of his visit. He paid a courtesy call on outgoing El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca shortly after his arrival.
He then traveled to the country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to attend a plaque-unveiling ceremony to mark the completion of the ministry's new Taiwan- funded building.

After hosting a luncheon to entertain Taiwanese expatriates in El Salvador, Ma will meet with President-elect Funes. Later in the day, Ma will give interviews to Salvadoran and international news media. In the evening, he will attend a state dinner hosted by Saca.
Meanwhile, first lady Chow Mei-ching will visit the El Salvador chapter of World Vision, a Christian charity dedicated to helping disadvantaged children and families.
During the visit, Chow will meet with a young Salvadoran whom President Ma has been sponsoring under a World Vision sponsorship program.
Traveling at the head of a 158-member delegation, Ma left Taiwan May 26 for the 10-day, three-country diplomatic tour of Central America that has already taken him to Belize and Guatemala.
Ma is scheduled to depart San Salvador June 2 and return to Taipei June 4 after an overnight transit stop in Seattle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 1, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
El Salvador will maintain formal ties with ROC: president-elect
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, May 31 (CNA) 06/01/09 13:36:30 (By Huang Kwang-chun, Huang Jui-hung and Debora Kuo)

TEXT.P: Salvadoran President-elect Mauricio Funes said Sunday that El Salvador will continue to maintain formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan.

During a 30-minute discussion with visiting ROC President Ma Ying-jeou, Funes said that the decision was based on the long-standing friendship and long-term cooperation between the two countries, according to Tsai Chung-li, director- general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office.
However, Funes said his administration will simultaneously seek closer economic ties with China.
Funes also expressed the hope that Taiwan will help El Savador with its agricultural development in particular, according to Tsai.

For his part, Ma congratulated Funes on his imminent inauguration as president of El Salvador and expressed appreciation to the Salvadoran government for its staunch support of Taiwan in the international community, which he said helped Taiwan to join the World Health Assembly this year as an observer.
Ma told Funes that since he took office one year ago, his administration has adopted a "modus vivendi diplomacy" strategy aimed at easing tensions across the Taiwan Strait.
"The efforts have worked, and cross-Taiwan Strait relations have improved noticeably over the past year, " Ma was quoted as telling Funes.

"The two sides have been cooperating, even though they are competitors, " Ma said. "That is the reason why Taiwan is not opposed to its diplomatic allies also developing business and trade relations with China."

On agricultural cooperation between Taiwan and El Salvador, Ma said that Taiwan has rich experience in rice and fruit growing as well as in aquaculture, and is willing to share its expertise with El Salvador.
A Salvadoran daily newspaper reported recently that several "Chinese officials" will be attending Funes' inauguration.

But ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco Ou said as far as he knows, the "Chinese officials" will be representatives of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , rather than officials of Chinese government.
Ma received a red carpet welcome at the airport upon his arrival in San Salvador Sunday.
He also met with outgoing Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca later in the day.
During the day, he visited El Salvador's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to attend the formal unveiling of a plaque on a new Taiwan-funded building in the country.
The plaque states that the building symbolizes the unbroken friendship and cooperation between the two countries over the past 68 years.

Salvadoran Foreign Minister Marisol Argueta expressed appreciation on behalf of the Salvadoran government and people to Taiwan for its long-term assistance to his country, saying that Taiwan's aid has enabled El Salvador to flourish economically and socially over the past decades.
Argueta said that over the past five years Taiwan has granted over US$29 million to El Salvador to help finance various development projects under the leadership of President Saca.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's first lady Chow Mei-ching visited the El Salvador chapter of World Vision, a Christian charity dedicated to helping disadvantaged children and families.
During the visit, Chow met with a Salvadoran child whom President Ma has been sponsoring under a World Vision program.
Traveling at the head of a 158-member delegation, Ma left Taiwan May 26 for a 10-day, three-country diplomatic tour of Central America that has already taken him to Belize and Guatemala.
Ma is scheduled to depart San Salvador June 2 and return to Taipei June 4 after an overnight transit stop in Seattle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Head of Chinese trade mission says no cap on procurement of goods

TEXT.P: Li Shuilin, chairman of China's Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (ATEEATS), said Monday in Taipei that there is no limit on the volume of Taiwan goods his delegation intends to order on its current procurement mission.

"As long as Taiwanese companies manufacture the products we need, we intended to purchase them from Taiwan and nowhere else, " Li said at a news conference held by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to welcome him and a 77-member trade delegation from China.

"It is difficult to predict the total volume of the procurements, which will include information technology products, precision machinery, petroleum products, and handcraft. Let's just say that there will be no limit," he added.

The delegation, which arrived in Taipei the previous day, is composed of senior executives of five major Chinese export-import trade associations, six leading industry associations and top management officers from more than 40 flagship companies in China, including home appliances manufacturer Haier Group and computer giant Lenovo China.

Most of the companies have won bids to provide products under China's new subsidy program to expand consumer purchase of home appliances in rural areas, as part of a massive economic stimulus package.
During its 6-day stay in Taiwan, the delegation is looking to procure a variety of products, ranging from high-tech devices to traditional craft items.
Li said the much improved cross-strait relations over the past year has afforded companies on both sides to a great opportunity to work together and create a win-win situation.
His agency is seeking long-term cooperation between Chinese and Taiwanese companies, and hence bilateral business opportunities will be unlimited, he added.
TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang said on the same occasion that by combining Taiwan's technology and China's market, the two sides will be able create an IT industry that could dominate the world.

The ATEEATS' first procurement mission to Taiwan is a step toward boosting bilateral trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and China, he said. TAITRA has arranged 467 one-on-one sessions to help potential Taiwanese suppliers access the business opportunities generated by China's "home appliances in the countryside" project, he added.
TAITRA is a semi-official agency that deals with matters of trade promotion and international sales.

ATEEATS Secretary-General Sun Zhaolin said at the news conference that his agency is planning to organize two more procurement missions to Taiwan this year. The second group is scheduled arrive in Taiwan at the end of June, while the third will visit in July, he added.
The ATEEATS was set up by China's Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan companies dominate Computex Taipei design awards

TEXT.P: The second Computex Taipei design and innovation (d&i) awards were dominated Monday by Taiwanese companies, with five of them winning gold among the 20 short-listed entries.

"The surprise winners in this year's Computex Taipei d&i awards represent a fresh variety of creations," said the panel of judges at an award ceremony hosted by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and Taipei Computer Association (TCA).
"An amazing development has taken place and the future of Taiwanese design looks promising," the panel added.
Although this year the judges did not offer the Green Award to any of the entries, they urged companies to work toward advancement in this special field.

The second Computex Taipei d&I awards, organized jointly by the German iF International Forum Design and TAITRA, was open to all exhibitors at Computex Taipei 2009 and all registered information technology firms in Taiwan.

This year, a total of 147 entries were submitted by participants from the United States, South Korea, China and Taiwan, and the five winners were selected by judges Gerhard Seizer and Marc Nagel from Germany, Hiroaki Tanaka from Japan, Gideon Loewy from Denmark, and Lawrence Weng from Taiwan.

The five gold winners were Acer Aspire 3935 Notebook by Acer Inc., DHKS-10 Dual Tray LCD Console Drawer by Hoeya Technology, Inc., SI-24S Digital Signage System by IBASE Technology Inc., SpinQ CPU Cooler by Thermaltake Technology Co. Ltd., and ZEBEX Z-3130BT Handy Bluetooth CCD Barcode Scanner by ZEBEX Industries Inc.
Having won the Computex gold awards, these products have automatically earned the right to carry the "Taiwan Good Design" label.
Computex Taipei is Asia's biggest IT exhibition and the world's leading ICT procurement platform.

This year's exhibition, co-hosted by TAITRA and TCA, is scheduled for June 2-6 and is expected to attract some 35,000 international buyers and 1,700 exhibitors and to generate US$20 billion in business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will continue pursuing U.N. cause: president
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, May 31 (CNA) 06/01/09 17:17:10 (By Huang Kuan-chun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said in El Salvador Sunday that Taiwan will maintain its efforts to take part in U.N.-affiliated activities, backed by a strong public mandate and its participation in the recently concluded World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva.

Ma made the remarks while speaking with international media reporters at the Radisson Plaza Hotel where he was staying on the eve of the June 1 inauguration of El Salvador President-elect Mauricio Funes.

Ma said that Taiwan's success in participating in the WHA as an observer in mid- May was an indication that his administration's pragmatic policies have won support at home and abroad, and that this approach should be maintained.
The president attributed the positive development to improved Taiwan-China relations over the past year since he has been at the helm of the government.

"The incumbent administration's pragmatic and flexible diplomacy has led to improved ties between Taiwan and China and to the signing of nine accords in three rounds of bilateral talks, " he noted. "Warming cross-Taiwan Strait ties has made it possible for El Salvador not to have to take sides between Taiwan and China."
"El Salvador can continue maintaining formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan while developing closer trade and economic links with China," Ma said.

"As a diplomatic partner of El Salvador, Taiwan will continue its cooperation on a wide front and will provide necessary assistance, " Ma said, in response to recent remarks by Funes that El Salvador will seek better links with China when he takes office.
Earlier the same day, Ma was also interviewed by the international news media, including El Salvador's TCS and Prensa Grafica, EFE of Spain and Reuters.
Ma is leading a large delegation on the third leg of a three-country diplomatic tour of Central America that took him to Belize and Guatemala.
The president is slated to depart El Salvador June 2 and return to Taiwan June 4 via Seattle after an overnight stopover.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's diplomatic truce with China triggers war of words at home

TEXT.P: Prior to President Ma Ying-jeou's departure from Taipei May 26 for his Central America tour of Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, mainly to attend the June 1 inauguration of El Salvador president-elect Mauricio Funes, he said at the airport that the journey proves that his advocacy of pragmatic diplomacy is working.
Although he did not elaborate, observers knew Ma was referring to Taiwan's relations with El Salvador.
After Funes won the presidency, fears had mounted in Taiwan that he might follow through on hints during his election campaign that he would switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
The potential crisis was quickly defused, however, by China giving an apparent cold shoulder to Funes, paving the way for Ma's trip.
The pillar of Ma's pragmatic diplomacy, which he calls a "modus vivendi" strategy, is seeking a diplomatic truce with China.
Ma's administration has never actually disclosed how it plans to define the concept of a diplomatic truce with Beijing, much less strike an agreement on the issue.
The president has simply made public appeals that neither side should woo the allies of the other.

The war for diplomatic turf between Taiwan and China began as an extension of the civil war between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Chinese communists after the gunfire ended in 1949, with each side vying for recognition as the only legitimate regime governing China.
It raged even harder after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in Taiwan in 2000 after a half-century of KMT rule.
Alarmed by the DPP's support for Taiwan independence, Beijing stepped up its efforts to quash Taiwan's international presence and any hints alluding to the country's sovereignty.

In its eight years in power, the DPP administration under former President Chen Shui-bian lost nine allies to China while gaining three, resulting in an overall decline in the number of its allies from 29 in 2000 to 23 in 2008.

The fight for diplomatic allies provided shrewd politicians in small, mainly impoverished Third World states with a chance to play one side against the other, alternating their loyalties between the two countries to squeeze maximum gains for their countries or themselves.

This led to a bidding war, with both sides pitching for the other side's allies with open wallets -- the notorious "checkbook diplomacy" -- which only went to prove in a number of cases that money could not buy long-term friendship.

For example, the South Pacific island nation of Nauru switched its recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 2002 and then back to Taipei in 2005; Chad, a cash- strapped African state, restored official ties with Taiwan in 1997 and severed them in 2006.
Senegal, also in Africa, resumed ties with Taipei in 1996 and terminated them in 2005.

But the game grew increasingly costly. When Beijing persuaded Costa Rica to abandon Taipei in 2007, it pledged to purchase US$300 million-worth of the Central American country's bonds and to provide US$130 million in direct aid.
This diplomatic maneuvering involved a large amount of backroom deals and gave corrupt local and foreign politicians ample opportunity to grease their palms.
Notable examples include two middlemen who made away with US$30 million provided by Taiwan's Foreign Ministry after saying they could help the country forge ties with Papua New Guinea in 2006.

In another glaring example that came to light, former National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-ren was accused of seizing US$500,000 from a US$1.6 million secret fund set aside by the Foreign Ministry to win the friendship of World Trade Organization Director-General Supachai Panitchpakdi of Thailand in 2003.
Rather than enhancing the country's international profile, these secret diplomatic dealings tarnished Taiwan's global image.

Ma vowed to get rid of this practice. On May 28, during his visit to Belize, Ma lambasted Chen's administration for engaging in checkbook diplomacy and made a pitch for his own administration's pragmatic diplomacy.
He also said that any diplomatic breakthrough for Taiwan depends on a breakthrough in its ties with China.
Foreign Minister Francisco Ou believes Beijing will buy Ma's idea of a diplomatic truce -- if, that is, China puts a premium on its ties with Taiwan.
"With more than 170 allies around the world, Beijing can hardly increase its prestige by winning one or two of Taiwan's allies, but doing so would cost China goodwill from Taiwan," Ou said.
Beijing has not agreed to a truce with Taiwan, but it has refrained from luring away any of Taiwan's 23 remaining allies since Ma's inauguration in May 2008.

In addition to El Salvador, Paraguay and Panama have also flirted with the idea of changing their allegiances but have not followed through on their threats, possibly after also being given the brush-off by China.

In Ou's view, Beijing should not only forsake any attempt to lure away Taiwan's allies but should also reject any countries who approach Beijing seeking recognition, or it will inevitably harm Taipei's trust in Beijing.
Ma's diplomatic truce with Beijing has also given Taipei more leeway in dealing with its allies' requests for aid, according to Ou.
"Although Taiwan is willing to help its allies, our ambassadors are now capable of asking their host countries to come up with detailed plans and practical requests for grants," the minister said.
However, Jaushieh Joseph Wu, Taipei's representative to the United States in former President Chen Shui-bian's administration, dismissed Ma's vow to give up checkbook diplomacy as mere rhetoric.
According to Wu, the diplomatic budget of Ma's administration is no less than that of the preceding government, and in fact it has spent even more in some countries.

"Although Ma's administration hasn't lost any allies thus far, it is traveling on a dangerous path, as it has given up any efforts to win new friends out of deference to what it calls its `truce' with China," Wu said.
Meanwhile, Beijing is going to great lengths to improve its ties with Taiwan's allies, which could easily be converted into official ties, Wu warned.
"Forsaking efforts to foster friendship with non-allies and pinning all hopes on Beijing is very dangerous," he pointed out.

Taipei's "abrupt reconciliation" with Beijing has also embarrassed those of its allies that have spoken out for Taiwan in its struggle with China, and has baffled other countries that are friendly to Taiwan, Wu claimed.
"They don't know whether they should continue to extend their support to Taiwan," Wu further speculated.
Lo Chih-cheng, a political science professor at Soochow University in Taipei, said the success of Ma's diplomatic truce should not be judged simply by the number of allies the country can count.
"What matters is Taiwan's substantive ties with countries that do not officially recognize it," Lo said.

"By this measurement, President Ma can hardly claim any progress, because his leading ministers are still forbidden from setting foot in countries that are allies of Beijing -- which contrasts sharply with Ma's encouragement to Taiwan's allies to forge unofficial ties with Beijing," he said.
"It doesn't take a diplomat to see who gets the upper hand from the truce," he went on.
Lo took particular issue with Ma's criticism of his predecessor's checkbook diplomacy in Belize, describing his comments as unbecoming for a head of state.
"It is more a piece of campaign rhetoric than a diplomatic statement, suggesting that our allies have got a lot of mileage out of Taiwan's dispute with China, " he said.
It remains to be seen how long Ma's truce with China will last. What is obvious, however, is that the war of words surrounding it will not end any time soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: WiMAX, touch-screen technology expected to dominate IT fair

TEXT.P: WiMAX and touch-screen technology, as well as netbooks, will take the spotlight at this year's Computex Taipei, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and Taipei Computer Association (TCA) said Monday.

"Touch screen technology is focus of this year's exhibition, with the launch of many new products by international and local flagship companies expected," said Walter Yeh, executive vice president of the semi-official trade promotion body TAITRA at an international press conference on the eve of the opening of Computex Taipei 2009.

In addition to Intel and AMD, which will present new products at the Asia's biggest IT exhibition, companies such as HP, Dell and Hitachi will also take part and will hold seminars on ICT development trends, he added.

Li Chang, deputy secretary-general of the TCA, said at the news conference that he thinks netbooks smaller than 11 inches and long-life laptop batteries will also draw heavy attention at this year's exhibition.
"Everyone can foresee the growth of these products in the future," he said.

According to TAITRA, among the new products to be launched at Computex Taipei, those likely to attract the most attention include AMD Phenom X4 Quad-Core 9550, Intel 4G and 8G Fiber Channel SFP, IBM Thinkpad X41T Series, Notebook Intel N270 and Eee PC S101/S101H.

Meanwhile, TAITRA noted that the theme of this year's Computex Taipei is "WiMAX on the Move, " under which three features -- innovation, leap and launch -- will be presented. The products featured will be the WiMAX embedded notebook and netbook, the smallest and lightest WiMAX mobile Internet device, the unique WiMAX TV dongle, and other epochal WiMAX products, he added.

Visitors to Computex Taipei 2009 will have access to various WiMAX products on display at over 700 booths, TAITRA said. The four main Taiwan WiMAX operators -- VMAX, Vee Telecom, TATUNG InfoComm, and Global Mobile -- will demonstrate several WiMAX application services to the public for the first time, it added.

This year's exhibition, co-hosted by the TAITRA and TCA, is scheduled for June 2-6 and is expected to attract some 35,000 international buyers and 1,700 exhibitors and generate US$20 billion in business.

For the first time, the show will include a pavilion dedicated to some 100 companies from China, including big brands such as the IT company Tsinghua Tongfang and the consumer electronics manufacturer MALATA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan hopes to step up academic cooperation with Taiwan: envoy

TEXT.P: An official from Japan's representative office in Taipei expressed hope Monday that academic cooperation between Taiwan and Japan can be boosted in the latter part of the year.

Naohiro Tsutsumi, director-general of the Interchange Association's Taipei Office, also said the association, which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, will carefully plan on how to strengthen such cooperation with Taiwan's academic sector.
He cited several possible options, including the opening of classes on Japan studies, exchanges of students and invitations to Japanese professors to conduct classes in Taiwan.
"Through such academic cooperation, we hope Taiwanese undergrad or graduate students will be more interested in studying Japanese politics, history and culture," he said.
He noted that Taiwan and Japan have already made progress in a number of programs in the first part of this year.

They include an agreement earlier this year to open regular flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport, which Tsutsumi said will boost bilateral tourism revenues and facilitate exchanges after it is launched this winter.

He also noted that the Japanese government invited 100 senior high school students to visit Japan in February, while Taiwan in return will invite 100 Japanese senior high school students to visit Taiwan this December.
"We hope the two sides will continue to promote exchanges of youngsters based on this solid basis," he said.

In related news that same day, applications for working holiday visas for Japan kicked off Monday, which will offer a rare opportunity for young people from both sides to learn about the culture of their respective host countries, he said.
He noted that he himself made his first overseas trip to Taiwan at the age of 26. Although it was only a five-day stay, he went on, it left him with a "wonderful and impressive experience."
The Interchange Association is accepting applications for working holiday visas at its Taipei and Kaohsiung offices June 1-5 and Nov. 2-6.
Japan is the third country to reach such a working holiday agreement with Taiwan after Australia and New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City opens 1st walking trail to promote poetry appreciation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung has inaugurated a walking trail with poems inscribed on tablets for people to learn about and enjoy poetry while they are out taking a stroll, a local official said Monday.
The trail, inaugurated Sunday amid dance and music, is 517 meters in length and built along the west side of the famous scenic attraction Lotus Pond in the city's Zuoying District.
The 15 poems, all written by local poets, will be displayed on the trail, said Lin Mei-hsiou, an official in the city government's Bureau of Cultural Affairs, which is in charge of the trail project.
Altogether, 15 writers' poems will be displayed on the trail, which begins with four lines of late writer Yeh Shih-tao's prose titled "No Land, No Literature."
Born in Tainan City in 1925, Yeh was a pioneering Taiwanese writer who specialized in the literary history of Taiwan. Yeh moved to Kaohsiung in 1965 and died there in 2008.

According to Lin, other writers whose poems are exhibited on the trail all live in the city, including two prose writers and 12 poets, such as Wang Chi-chiang, Cheng Chiung-ming, Chung Shun-wen, Lee Chang-hsien, Chin Lien, Tzeng Kuei-hai, and Lu Han-hsiou.

Lin said the poems were selected by a committee convened by the city government, and are inscribed on tablets made of granite or steel in different shapes to fit in with the scenic views around the pond.

Inscriptions of all the poetic writings, as well as the words at the entrance and exit of the trail, are written in calligraphy by Chung Chao-cheng, an 84 -year-old writer well-known for his literary critiques. Like Yeh, Chung is also famous in Taiwan's literary circle.
The city government spent nearly two years on the project, Lin said.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said at the inauguration ceremony that the trail dedicated to literature is as meaningful as trails glorifying philosophers in foreign countries.

She expressed the hope that there will be more venues of this kind in the future to showcase Kaohsiung residents' love for literature and to present literature with vitality and power by local writers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled Chinese brothers to be cited in Taipei

TEXT.P: Two physically challenged brothers from a rural backwater in northern China were expected to arrive in Taipei Monday to be cited by a local charity for their "fervent love of life."

Twenty-nine-year-old Zhang Yunpeng, who paints using his mouth, and his younger brother Zhang Yuncheng, 28, a published author who types with just one finger, are scheduled to join 10 other recipients of the 2009 Fervent Global Love of Life Awards to be presented by the Chou Ta-Kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation June 4.

Zhang Yunpeng, who has suffered from incurable muscular dystrophy since the age of 3, is expected to do a Chinese brush painting at a gathering to be held Tuesday using his mouth, the only part of his body he can still control.
The painting will be presented to Terry Gou, CEO and founder of Taiwan's Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract maker of consumer electronics by revenue, according to the foundation.

Gou, who made the Zhangs acquaintance two years ago when he was invited to present the "10 Most Touching Figures in China" Award in Hangzhou, decided to invite the Zhangs for dinner Monday to his business empire's headquarters located in Tucheng, Taipei County.
Gou has also offered the brothers a suite he owns in Beijing so they can get away from their shabby home in China's remote Heilongjiang Province.

Paralyzed from the neck down, Yunpeng started to use his mouth to hold brushes to paint at 23. But even his mouth became dysfunctional a year later, and a year after that, the strength in his neck slipped away, while he also suffered analosis, causing his skeleton to deform.

With his weight dropping to less than 30 kg, Yunpeng found himself unable to move anything except his head, but this did not make him give up his dream of holding an exhibition of his work. He kept painting with a brush held in his mouth and finally held his first exhibition in May 2002.

Zhang Yuncheng, who also has suffered from muscular dystrophy since the age of 3, lost his ability to walk at 16 but in 2000, at the age of just 20, completed his 170,000-character book If I Were to Walk for Three Days after four years of painstaking work on the keyboard using only his two index fingers -- the only mobile parts of his body.

Unfortunately, one week after the book was published, both of his index fingers also became paralyzed. Even this setback, however, did not cause him to lose his faith in himself and he continued writing with his right middle finger -- now his only mobile part.

His story deeply moved Ma Yun, the founder of Alibaba.com -- the world's largest online B2B marketplace -- who in turn offered to help him open an online shop of his own, from which he now sells his books, as well as paintings done by his brother.
The income from the shop, which can reach up to 200,000 Chinese yuan (US$29,295) per year, is donated to other disadvantaged people.
The Chou Ta-Kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation selected 12 winners this year from among 1,929 candidates recommended from various sectors around the world for their excellence in their fields.

Cheng Mei-chu, a painter from Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu who was born with ichthyosis -- a severe genetic skin disorder -- was selected as a recipient for her pursuit of the arts with passion and dedication, despite her physical disability.

Another recipient was Daniel Gottlieb, an American practicing psychologist and family therapist who has been paralyzed from the neck down since an automobile accident in 1979. He was chosen for his devotion to family and his career while overcoming paralysis.
Also on the list is Wang Hung-yi, who founded a one-man band and now performs overseas using recycled musical instruments.

Another of the recipients is Mark Inglis, a New Zealand mountaineer who lost both legs after he was trapped in an ice cave for two weeks due to a storm in 1982. Inglis was recognized for his dedication to helping physically disadvantaged individuals. He also won a silver medal at the 2000 Paralympics in the 1,000 meter cycling individual time trial.
Wu Chung-yun, a third grader from an elementary school in Taichung who became completely blind as a result of a brain tumor, was honored for the 132 paintings he has completed.
The foundation was founded in 1997 by the parents of Chou Ta-kuan in memory of their son, who died of cancer. Ta-kuan was a young poet who is remembered today for his great enthusiasm for life.
Keen to promote Ta-kuan's love for life, his parents have sponsored various activities and programs via the foundation, including the presentation of the Fervent Global Love of Life awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price of red-label rice wine slashed significantly

TEXT.P: The state-operated Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTL) cut the price of its rice wine from NT$180 to NT$50 per 600 cc bottle, with immediate effect Monday.

TTL Chairman Wei Po-tao announced the price cut Monday at a news conference in Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, following the Legislature's revision of the Tobacco and Alcohol Tax Act in April to allow for the price adjustment.

The alcohol content of the rice wine will be reduced from 22 percent to 19.5 percent, which is what it was prior to 2002 when the government monopoly was lifted and the price was raised to comply with World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations, Wei said.

The popular red label wine, used mainly for cooking, will also be repackaged to let consumers know that it is the same product that was made by Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Board (TTWMB) , the predecessor of TTL, Wei added.

The name of the liquor will be changed back from "Tao Hsiang red-label rice wine" to "TTWMB red-label rice wine, " as it was labeled before TTWMB was converted into an enterprise to end the government's monopoly on liquor and tobacco products.
Wei said that with effect from Monday, consumers can either return unopened bottles of red-label wine or exchange them for the new product.

Each bottle of 22 percent proof rice wine that was bought for NT$180 can be exchanged for four bottles of the new product, once consumers pay the NT$20 price difference on the exchange, according to TTL.

TTWMB red-label rice wine was known to be an indispensable item in Taiwanese kitchens in the years before Taiwan was forced to impose a high tax on the locally distilled liquor to comply with WTO regulations.
The tax pushed the price of red-label rice wine up from NT$22 to NT$180 per bottle. The hike not only drew public protests, but also resulted in a slump in the sale of the liquor.
According to TTL statistics, when the rice wine was being sold at NT$22 per 600 cc bottle, the average sale volume was some 2.1 billion bottles a year.

After Taiwan joined the WTO in 2002 and was forced to impose the liquor tax on the wine, the sale volume fell to 7.5 million bottles a year. The latest price cut is expected to push up sales, TTL said.
Rice wine is a vital ingredient in Chinese dishes such as "sesame oil chicken" and "ginger duck."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices close higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 0.92 percent higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 63.66 points to close at 6,954.10.
Following Wall Street's gains of Friday, the local bourse opened at the day's highest of 7,033.33, also the highest figure so far this year. It later dropped to a low of 6,892.27.
A total of 7.42 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$201.85 billion (US$6.23 billion) , posting a drop of NT$21.69 billion from the previous trading day.

All eight major stock categories apart from construction issues gained ground, with textile stocks advancing the most at 3.3 percent. Cement shares rose 2.6 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 1.6 percent, foodstuff stocks surged 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 1.2 percent, banking and financial stocks moved up 0.8 percent, and machinery and electronics issues gained 0.6 percent.
Construction stocks dropped 1.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,128 to 1,096, with 127 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors bought NT$14.83 billion-worth of shares.

Automobile stocks outperformed the overall market, with Yulon Motor rising by its 7 percent daily maximum limit because of its development of an abandoned factory site into a residential and commercial complex expected to be finalized at the end of this year, according to an analyst.
Shares in electronics stocks were boosted by the upcoming WiMAX Taipei 2009 and the Computex Taipei 2009 and the visit to Taiwan by a 77-member trade delegation from China, the analyst said.
The analyst predicted selling pressure as the TAIEX hovers between 7,000 and 7,100 unless there is some good news to buoy the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, falling NT$0.275 to close at NT$32.375.
A total of US$2.367 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.650 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.228.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County farming plan kicks off

TEXT.P: Some 130 jobless and retired workers Monday signed up for an agriculture plan in Daliao township sponsored by the Kaohsiung county government and the local farmers association, with Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing wishing them good luck and prosperous business.

The county government kicked off the program by leasing 45 hectares of farmland from the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. -- 25 hectares in Daliao township and 20 hectares in Ciaotou township -- to be farmed by the program participants as part of the county's efforts to tackle unemployment.
Each of the 199 new farmers -- 127 from Daliao township and 72 from Ciaotou township -- was provided with 0.2-hectares of land and a start-up subsidy of NT$2,000 (US$62) per year from the county.
Seventy-seven of the new farmers in Daliao township and 54 in Ciaotou township have opted for organic farming, with the land in Ciaotou township set to be opened in late June.
The individuals chosen to participate in the farming initiative will also have their land rental fees paid for by the local government for three years.
In addition, the two townships' farmers associations will set up task forces to help them sell and market their produce.

The plan, originally aimed at drawing 90 jobless workers into farming, received greater interest than the county had expected, with 300 people applying to take part in the program when it was announced in March.
With more applicants than positions available, priority has been given to those who lost their jobs involuntarily, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Liquor opens its own convenience store franchise

TEXT.P: State-own Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTLC) formally entered the convenience store battle in Taiwan Monday by launching 13 stores islandwide simultaneously.
TTLC Chairman Wei Po-tao officiated a ceremony at a TTLC flagship convenience store located in the northern Hsinchu City to symbolize the opening of all the 13 stores.
Tending the store, Wei rolled up his sleeves to tout TTLC products -- cold draft beer in particular -- which is hotly welcome during summer time.

Wei said many people have said that they know the TTLC has a wide range of products, but do not know where to buy them, prompting his company to open its own convenience store franchise to build its own retailing networks, with long business hours from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m.

Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer offered his congratulations to Wei personally, expressing his wishes that TTLC's retailing business will continue to boom after it cut the price of the hotly-sought-after Red Label rice wine from the previous NT$180 per bottle to NT$50 from Monday and having launched a series of promotional campaigns in both Taiwan and mainland China.
TTLC management said that if business at the first 13 stores prove to be good, more stores will be opened in all 319 cities and townships around the country.

In addition to alcoholic and tobacco products, TTLC has also researched and produced health foods and cosmetics in recent years. Other lines of products that it has produced include soft drinks and cleansing products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number trying to quit smoking up after surcharge hike

TEXT.P: With the doubling of the health and welfare surcharge on tobacco products starting Monday, a northern Taiwan hospital under the Department of Health (DOH) reported that the number of outpatients seeking to quit smoking has increased by around one-third over the past two months.

Tsai Fu-hsun, director of the department of thoracic medicine at Keelung Hospital, also said that as of the end of May, the number of new patients wanting to quit had exceeded 100, which he said "represents a marked increase compared to the just-over 80 recorded for the whole of last year."

He pointed out that success in quitting depends largely on the individual's will, adding that only about 20 people in his hospital anti-smoking program have successfully kicked the habit over the past six months.
He urged smokers to "just say no" to cigarettes, especially now that the surcharge has increased from the previous NT$10 per pack to NT$20 per pack.
The 100 percent surcharge increase has raised the average per-pack price for cigarettes to between NT$55 and NT$70 per pack, depending on the brand.

Meanwhile, to encourage more people to join the quitters, the Mackay Memorial Hospital and the John Tung Foundation, a non-profit anti-tobacco organization, started a "quit smoking week" activity in which celebrities were invited to share their experiences of kicking the habit.

Entertainer-turned-lifetime anti-smoking volunteer Sun Yueh said he had his first puff at the age of 16 and was a smoker for 37 years before kicking the habit 25 years ago because he "didn't want to affect others."
Another spokesperson for the foundation, Chen Shu-li, said smoking is like a chronic disease and that "it is really hard to kick the habit by force of willpower alone without professional guidance."

DOC.HEADLINE: A king of the herring caught on seas off Taitung

TEXT.P: A king of the herring caused a small stir at a fishing port in Taitung County, southeastern Taiwan, Monday, with some local people fearing it was a sign of earthquake.

A local fishing boat, the "Sheng Fa Tsai, " caught the rarely-seen fish the previous night in waters off Chenggong Township. The Sheng Fa Tsai skipper, Tung Chin-hsing, said his crew spotted the fish at around 11 p.m. after seeing a long silver strip glittering on the water.

Before gathering it on to the boat, the crew did not recognize it is a king of the herring, a ribbon-shaped oarfish with a silver-gray glittery body and a red dorsal that can stretch up to 11 meters long.
It is known locally as the "king of dragons, " said to rule the sea in Taiwanese folks tales, Tung said.
"It was the first time I've seen the legendary king of dragons over the past 30 years," Tung said.
The 5-meter-long oarfish drew plenty of attention while on display at Singang fishing port, but no vendors dared to handle the fish due to the legends surrounding the obscure creature.
Some said it is an "earthquake fish" related to the occurrence of an earthquake. Some believed catching the "king of dragons" might trigger a disaster while others said it might bring good luck.
A vendor, nicknamed A Chin, rejected Tung's request to sell it as food, saying she "does not know whether the fish good or bad. It is better not to touch it."
Eventually, a buyer took it home for NT$2,000, saying he planned to prepare it for display in his home.

Ho Yuan-hsin, a researcher at the Eastern Marine Biology Research Center run by the Council of Agriculture, said the fish, also called a "messenger from the dragon palace" by local people, usually lives at a depth of between 50 meters and 250 meters.
It might have been sick, or something unusual had happened on the seabed that caused the fish to linger at the surface of the sea, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government agencies kick off anti-drug campaign

TEXT.P: Prior to a national anti-drug conference slated for Wednesday, representatives of several government agencies kicked off a joint anti-drug campaign at a news conference Monday.

Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng, Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng, Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Javier Ching-shan Hou, as well as pop star Jam Hsiao attended the news conference to mark the launch of the campaign.
Cheng urged young people not to take drugs because doing so will destroy their lives and families.
According to Wang, Taiwan's law enforcement authorities seized a total of 645 kilograms of illegal narcotics in the first quarter of 2009, up from 428.7 kgs nabbed during the same period last year.

A vast majority (94 percent) of the drugs seized in the first three months of this year were level-three or level-four controlled substances, such as ketamine, Wang noted, and she called on everybody to help fight the increased use of drugs in society.

In Wednesday's national meeting aimed at building public awareness of illicit drug abuse, experts and government officials will discuss measures to prevent, monitor and break the cycle of abuse as well as explore feasible means to forge closer cooperation.
They will also publish studies on the subject.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large haul of ketamine, Ecstasy pills seized

TEXT.P: Two suspects were arrested and 366 kilograms of ketamine and 14 kgs. of Ecstasy pills were seized in a raid on a fishing boat in southern Taiwan, agents from the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice said Monday.
The agents said they received a tip in February that drug traffickers in southern Taiwan would use a fishing boat to smuggle drugs to Taiwan from China
Since then, the agents have been busy verifying the information, and, with the assistance of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency, they targeted a fishing boat called the "Hsinfongli."
The ship left Anping Harbor, Tainan, on May 28, and the agents waited for its return to conduct the raid.
They found the drugs in tea bags hidden under the beds of the crew members, and the agents turned the two suspects over to the Kaohsiung Prosecutors Office for further questioning.
An agent said the 366 kgs of ketamine and over 2 million Ecstasy pills would be enough for the use of 6 million people, which they said could pose health risks if they were circulated in the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13th swine flu case confirmed in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan confirmed another imported case of swine flu Monday, bringing to 13 the total number of individuals who have been infected with the influenza A(H1N1) virus in the country.

The 13th patient was an 8-year-old Canadian girl of Asian descent who was sent to a local hospital for treatment and quarantine after arriving at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport early Sunday, the Central Epidemics Command Centers (CECC) said in a statement.
The girl showed flu symptoms, such as fever, coughing and vomiting, after arriving at the Vancouver airport May 29 from Montreal along with her parents.

The family of three were bound for Cambodia via Taiwan. The girl's parents informed flight attendants of her health condition after boarding the plane in Vancouver, and the three wore face masks throughout the flight to Taiwan.

Local quarantine officials conducted an on-board health check on the girl after the plane landed at the Taoyuan airport. The girl was then sent to Taoyuan General Hospital for treatment and quarantine.
Laboratory tests confirmed Monday that the girl was infected with the H1N1 virus, making her the 13th confirmed swine flu patient detected in Taiwan.
As the girl's mother also showed symptoms of coughing, she was also required to be tested, but it eventually confirmed she was free of the H1N1 virus, the CECC statement said.

Based on an investigation into the girl's case, she likely contracted the virus in Montreal. As she and her parents all wore masks throughout the flight, local quarantine officials said individuals sitting near them had a low probability of contracting the disease.

Thirty of the 54 passengers who were seated in the three rows in front of and behind the girl flew on to other destinations after a transit stop in Taiwan, the CECC said, adding that it has informed the World Health Organization (WHO) and other relevant countries of the case through the International Health Regulations-affiliated reporting system.
The center has also notified Canada's representative office of the case, the statement said.

As for the 24 passengers who have entered Taiwan, the statement said, they should contact local health bureaus or the epidemic center through the 1922 phone line to seek medical counseling if they develop flu-like symptoms in the coming week.
Taiwan has so far recorded only one indigenous swine flu case and the remaining are all imported patients. Most of the confirmed patients have since recovered.

As the country has not reported any new domestic infections since May 25, the epidemic center lowered the alert level to the second stage of yellow, which denotes that there are no community infections in Taiwan.
As of 2 p.m. Friday, 53 countries had officially reported 15,510 cases of A(H1N1) infection, including 99 deaths, according to the latest World Health Organization report.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADImmune receives seed viruses for H1N1 flu vaccine production

TEXT.P: ADImmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer, has received seed viruses for production of vaccines against the influenza A(H1N1) strain, the company said in a statement Monday.
Australia sent seed viruses to the company Sunday, the statement said, adding that Britain and the United States are expected to send samples to the company this week.

The company will cultivate the virus in its Biosafety Level 2 enhanced (BSL2+) and evaluate successive transfers over a one to two week period to choose which seed virus will be used for production of a vaccine against the new flu strain, the statement said.

The company completed its logistics preparation on schedule in late May and will continue to beef up its quality control and biological safety management mechanisms in order to ensure vaccine quality.

Department of Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said last month that the department plans to procure 10 million doses of new flu vaccines this year, with 2.5 million imported from abroad and the remaining bought domestically from ADImmune.
According to Yeh, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has promised to assist in quality control and certification of Taiwan-produced flu vaccines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 2, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's diplomatic truce with China triggers war of words at home

TEXT.P: Prior to President Ma Ying-jeou's departure from Taipei May 26 for his Central America tour of Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, mainly to attend the June 1 inauguration of El Salvador president-elect Mauricio Funes, he said at the airport that the journey proves that his advocacy of pragmatic diplomacy is working.
Although he did not elaborate, observers knew Ma was referring to Taiwan's relations with El Salvador.
After Funes won the presidency, fears had mounted in Taiwan that he might follow through on hints during his election campaign that he would switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
The potential crisis was quickly defused, however, by China giving an apparent cold shoulder to Funes, paving the way for Ma's trip.
The pillar of Ma's pragmatic diplomacy, which he calls a "modus vivendi" strategy, is seeking a diplomatic truce with China.
Ma's administration has never actually disclosed how it plans to define the concept of a diplomatic truce with Beijing, much less strike an agreement on the issue.
The president has simply made public appeals that neither side should woo the allies of the other.

The war for diplomatic turf between Taiwan and China began as an extension of the civil war between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Chinese communists after the gunfire ended in 1949, with each side vying for recognition as the only legitimate regime governing China.
It raged even harder after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in Taiwan in 2000 after a half-century of KMT rule.
Alarmed by the DPP's support for Taiwan independence, Beijing stepped up its efforts to quash Taiwan's international presence and any hints alluding to the country's sovereignty.

In its eight years in power, the DPP administration under former President Chen Shui-bian lost nine allies to China while gaining three, resulting in an overall decline in the number of its allies from 29 in 2000 to 23 in 2008.

The fight for diplomatic allies provided shrewd politicians in small, mainly impoverished Third World states with a chance to play one side against the other, alternating their loyalties between the two countries to squeeze maximum gains for their countries or themselves.

This led to a bidding war, with both sides pitching for the other side's allies with open wallets -- the notorious "checkbook diplomacy" -- which only went to prove in a number of cases that money could not buy long-term friendship.

For example, the South Pacific island nation of Nauru switched its recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 2002 and then back to Taipei in 2005; Chad, a cash- strapped African state, restored official ties with Taiwan in 1997 and severed them in 2006.
Senegal, also in Africa, resumed ties with Taipei in 1996 and terminated them in 2005.

But the game grew increasingly costly. When Beijing persuaded Costa Rica to abandon Taipei in 2007, it pledged to purchase US$300 million-worth of the Central American country's bonds and to provide US$130 million in direct aid.
This diplomatic maneuvering involved a large amount of backroom deals and gave corrupt local and foreign politicians ample opportunity to grease their palms.
