DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 2, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets U.S. secretary of state in El Salvador
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/09 12:47:32 (By Huang Jui-hung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou met U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton briefly in El Salvador Sunday in a rare informal encounter between high-level officials of the two countries.
The two met at a state banquet hosted by outgoing Salvadoran President Antonio Saca, during which Ma shared a table with Clinton.
Clinton took the initiative to greet and shake hands with Ma, and Ma addressed the secretary of state as "Mrs. Clinton" and introduced himself as "the president of Taiwan."

Ma told Clinton that Taiwan is very grateful to the United States for the assistance it has provided in improving relations between Taiwan and China and that Taiwan will try its best to maintain stability across the Taiwan Strait.
The governments of Taiwan and the United States have maintained no formal contact since diplomatic ties were severed in 1979.

A similar informal meeting took place in Panama in 2003 between then President Chen Shui-bian and then U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell during the Central American nation's 100th National Day celebration.

Ma is in El Salvador to attend the inauguration of Salvadoran President-elect Mauricio Funes. This is the final leg of his three-nation Central American tour that has also taken him to Belize and Guatemala.

Also in El Salvador Monday, Ma held talks with Honduras President Manuel Zelaya, during which the two leaders reached an agreement on a proposal for Taiwan to provide hydraulic power technology to Honduras.

The proposal, which was put forth by Zelaya, was intended as a substitude for a previous plan put forward by the state-owned Taiwan Power Company to invest more than US$360 million in helping Honduras build a hydraulic power plant, said Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi.
The investment project was canceled after Taiwan's legislature nixed its funding.
According to Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming, the power company, which lost more than NT$100 billion (US$3.09 billion) in 2008, cannot carry out the investment project without the budget.
Providing technical assistance to Honduras instead will be a good solution for the company, Yiin said.
During the meeting, Ma and Zelaya also reached consensus on proposals for Taiwan to help Honduras develop clean energy and boost community development.

Ma is expected to visit Honduras during his next Central American trip slated for late June, when he will also go to Panama to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Ricardo Martinelli.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's ICT industry in limelight as Computex Taipei opens

TEXT.P: Taiwanese high-tech companies once again became the focal point of the global ICT (information and communications technology) industry on Tuesday with the opening of the 29th Computex Taipei, and the show's strong participation indicated that the local ICT sector is as dynamic as ever.

With a total of 1,712 manufacturers from 21 countries and regions occupying 4,498 booths this year and tens of thousands of telecom professional and buyers expected to attend, the scope of this year's Computex maintained previous levels despite the global economic downturn.
Most of the big names in the industry are exhibiting at this week's show, including AMD, Arctic Cooling, Hitachi, Intel, Microsoft, Marvel, Acer, ASUS, and Gigabyte.

Computex Taipei is one of the world's most influential ICT exhibitions. The fact that it has remained unaffected by the current global economic downturn underscores the competitiveness of Taiwan's ICT industry, said Premier Liu Chao- shiuan at the opening ceremony hosted by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade and Development Council (TAITRA) and the Taipei Computer Association (TCA).

Noting that the global economic slump has shaken up industries, Liu said Taiwan's ICT can be expected to rebound strongly when the global economy recovers due to its technical experience, comprehensive global supply chain, and the core competitiveness and flexibility of its manufacturing sector.
TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang said on the same occasion that Taiwan's ICT industry occupies a position of competitiveness in the global supply chain that is irreplaceable.

To back his point, he cited a report published by the Economist in September 2008 that said the global competitiveness of Taiwan's IT industry had climbed to second in the world, trailing only that of the United States.

In addition, 18 Taiwanese companies were included in BusinessWeek's 2008 InfoTech 100 IT industry survey, the highest among all Asian countries, ahead of China (6), Japan (5), and South Korea (4), he added.
The harsher the economic conditions, the clearer one can witness the vitality and strong spirit of Taiwan's ICT industry, said TCA Chairman J.T. Wang.

According to Wang, this year, Computex Taipei will show the whole world the local sector's hard-earned accomplishments, with WiMAX, netbooks and lightweight energy-saving notebooks the year's three most notable innovations.

Building on last year's successful "Computex catch the WiMAX" theme, the theme of this year's show isWiMAX on the MOVE, which symbolizes the launch of commercial WiMAX operations in Taiwan, Wang said.

Moreover, with the full support of the Taipei City government and the Industrial Development Bureau, WiMAX services will be available on the Taipei MRT's Muzha Line, allowing the public to try out the world's first mobile broadband wireless access network on a rapid transit system, he added.

As for the new wave of super lightweight notebooks introduced by Taiwanese vendors, Wang said they have up to eight hours of battery power but are priced in the same price range as average notebooks, leading global notebook suppliers to follow this new standard.
Co-hosted by the TAITRA and TCA, Computex Taipei 2009 will run until June 6 and is expected to attract some 35,000 international buyers and generate US$20 billion in business.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-tech netbooks dominate Computex Taipei 2009

TEXT.P: Netbooks incorporated with advance features such as touch screens, long-life batteries and WiMAX compatibility are one of the biggest draws at this year's Computex Taipei, which opened Tuesday in Taipei.
Several flagship local and international companies such as ASUSTek Computer Inc., AMD, Microsoft, and Intel all showcased their latest products and applications of their innovations.

"Originated in Taiwan, the netbook started as an underdog product but has become a real phenomenon sweeping through the global market. It demonstrates Taiwan's ability to stake out a leading position and create product trends in the ICT industry," said J.T. Wang, chairman of the Taipei Computer Association, at the opening ceremony of the show.
WiMAX and super lightweight notebooks with long battery power will also dominate this year's show, he added.

Zing Chen, deputy director of Asus' second channel product planning and management department, told the Central News Agency that her company's latest Eee PC Seashell and Eee PC Touch netbooks illustrate the ability of local vendors to stay ahead of the innovation curve.

Launched two weeks ago, the Eee PC Seashell is the lightest and slimmest 10-inch netbook available on the market, weighing only 1.1 kilograms and measuring 1 inch in thickness, Chen said. The in-built battery can last for up to six hours or for 10.5 hours for its all-day-computing series.
"ASUS is also the first company to launch netbooks using touch-screen technology, with many innovative supporting software features developed by the company," she added.

The single-touch Eee PC Touch is scheduled to go onto the market at the end of June, but a new model with a multitouch-enabled tablet will also be introduced later this year to coincide with the launch of Microsoft's Windows 7, Chen said.

In line with this year's theme of "WiMAX on the MOVE" at Computex Taipei, Intel demonstrated its latest application of WiMAX modules in laptops, which enable swift access to the Internet wherever the computer is.

As to netbooks, Stanley Huang, director of Advanced Technical Sales and Services at Intel Asia Pacific, said in a press release that compactness and conserving power are the focal point for netbook development.
"Following the success of the Atom CPU that is specially designed for netbooks, Intel will introduce the next generation Atom CPU, featuring higher integration," he said.

Regarding the new generation notebook PC operation platform, Consumer Ultra Low Voltage or CULV, Huang stressed that it is for ultra slim notebooks equipped with full features, and highlights low power consumption and long battery life.

Computex Taipei 2009 -- Asia's biggest IT exhibition and the world's leading ICT procurement platform -- will run until June 6 and is expected to attract 35,000 international buyers and generate US$20 billion in business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to develop methods to test melamine tableware: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan's product supervisory authority said Tuesday it is studying Japan's methods of testing tableware made of melamine and it will collaborate with the Department of Health (DOH) to set standards for the maximum allowable amount of melamine that should be released from food containers.
Taiwan still has no established way of testing the amount of melamine released from utensils and tableware made from melamine resin.

However, in an experiment conducted by the Consumers' Foundation based on Japan's methods, it was found that 100 percent of the 20 melamine-resin tableware products tested released melamine when filled with anything hot.

The raw material used in melamine tableware is melamine formaldehyde resin and the quality of the finished product depends on the temperature and pressure used during the manufacturing process, said Wang Cheng-huei, deputy director of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection.
If the process is properly controlled, there should be no concerns over the release of melamine or formaldehyde from tableware made of thermosetting resin, he added.
Melamine is often used in the manufacture of kitchen utensils and tableware, but such containers are not safe for microwave use, as they absorb the oven's radiation and heat up.
Wang said the bureau will work to obtain more information about Japan's sanitary testing methods for the products.

Taiwan has a standard for the maximum amount of formaldehyde released from food containers, but not one for melamine tableware, Wang said. If the DOH, which regulates the food container industry, establishes a melamine standard, the bureau will make an effort to include it in the national standards, he added.
In the recent experiment, all tableware made of melamine resin tested positive for melamine release, Wang said, warning that consumers should not use such products for hot food or for microwaving.

Wang also urged melamine tableware manufacturers to clearly label their products with the warning that they "should not be used in microwave ovens, " and to remind consumers not to use them for hot food or drink.

The Consumers' Foundation on Monday released the results of the tests which showed that all 20 sample products contained excessive amounts of melamine. Eight of the tested samples, or 40 percent, carried no warning against microwave use, the foundation observed.

The tests found that the amount of melamine released from the 20 items varied from 0.04 mg per liter to 20 mg per liter. The foundation recommended that consumers use stainless steel and ceramics as alternatives to melamine resin tableware.
Melamine is a highly toxic substance commonly used in the manufacture of plastic resins for household use, such as counter tops, plates and bowls.

DOC.HEADLINE: 103 adult Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins remain in west coast:survey

TEXT.P: Only 103 adult Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins remained along the west coast of Taiwan, according to the results of a survey conducted between 2006 and 2008.

Chou Lien-siang, a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Life Science in northern Taiwan, released the survey results at a forum held by the Environmental Protection Administration Monday.
The forum was held to discuss the possible impact of development in western Taiwan on the population of humpback dolphins, which are also called Chinese white dolphins.

The survey covered an area in west-central Taiwan between Taichung County and Chiayi County and was commissioned by Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) , which is involved in several development projects in western Taiwan.

The dolphins, which are white in color and endemic to Taiwan, were discovered in 2002 off the west coast of the island and were listed last August as critically endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
Chou said that in 45 survey trips at sea, she observed 54 groups of 259 Chinese white dolphins, including babies, and in another 45 observation trips on land, she spotted 20 groups of 59 dolphins.

The dolphins seen from the land were only 20 to 800 meters from the shore, Chou said, adding that the dolphins prefer shallow coastal waters where biodiversity conservation is often threatened by economic development.

Chou said she also issued 51 questionnaires on Chinese white dolphin sightings to fishermen and vendors at three fishing ports in the survey area, and results showed that all the respondents had seen the dolphins, which usually appear in the area all year round.
Chou called on the public to pay attention to conservation of the dolphins, which have an extremely low birth rate and a life span of 30-40 years.
It takes 10-12 years for Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins to reach sexual maturity, and a female dolphin gives birth once every 3-4 years, Chou explained.
Chou said the noise level at construction sites should be measured and bubble screens should be used to protect the dolphins from noise hazards during such development projects.

The humpback dolphins are called "Matsu Fish" by local fishermen because they usually are seen most frequently between March and April off the western coast when the northeasterly monsoons weaken and the birthday of Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the Sea, is celebrated in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei department stores post strong sales over four-day holiday

TEXT.P: Most department stores in Taipei reported stronger sales during the just- concluded four-day Dragon Boat Festival holiday than during the same holiday last year, seen by retailers as a sign of improving consumer confidence.

Taiwan's biggest department store chain, Shin Kong Mitsukoshi, had sales of NT$960 million (US$29.7 million) around Taiwan from May 28 to May 31, an increase of 90 percent compared to the same period in 2008.

Shin Kong Mitsukoshi's biggest competitor, Sogo Co., said Tuesday that excluding its newly-opened department store in Taipei's Tianmu district, its other three stores in the city saw sales grow 20 percent compared to the June 5-8 Dragon Boat Festival period last year.
As for the Tianmu store that was opened May 22, sales over the four-day period exceeded the company's target by 60 percent, store executives said.
Other department stores in the upscale Tianmu neighborhood also performed well, according to analysis done by department store operators in the area.

Sales at Shin Kong Mitsukoshi's outlet over the last two days of the holiday (a weekend) rose 15 percent compared to average weekends, and the Dayeh Takashima department store saw sales rise by 5 percent.

The analysis found that the new Sogo department store did not have as big of a negative effect on the competition as had been anticipated because most people who shopped at the new store were consumers from outside the district.
The Miramar department store in Dazhi was the only major retailer to post lower numbers during the long holiday, with sales 2 percent lower over the holiday weekend than during an average weekend.

Industry insiders attributed the weak showing to its proximity to the Neihu Science Park, which has been hit hard by the global economic downturn. Its location outside the main part of the city also means it relies heavily on consumers in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-sponsored telescope project passes major milestone

TEXT.P: The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) , a major international telescope project, in which Taiwan is a participant, achieved a major milestone in late April when faint radio waves emitted by Mars were first collected by two 12- meter diameter ALMA antennas, Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) announced Tuesday.
The ALMA project is an international collaboration among East Asia, Europe, and North America in cooperation with Chile.

The ALMA Operations Support Facility, located 5,000 meters above sea level in the Chilean Atacama desert, is the highest site for ground-based astronomy, Liu Sheng-yuan, an NSC assistant research fellow and a scientist in the project, said at a briefing on the project.
The NSC, in conjunction with Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica, have injected US$32 million in the project, Liu added.

On April 30, the ALMA research team observed the first fringes--a regular pattern of alternating strong and weak signals-- by the two ALMA antennas as Mars moved across the sky. The signals were then processed by state- of-the-art electronics to turn the two antennas into a single, high- resolution telescope system, called an interferometer, according to Liu.

ALMA is the most ambitious project in millimeter and submillimeter astronomy which will comprise 66 antennas observing in unison as a single giant telescope when it is completed in 2012. However, scientific observations will start from 2011, Liu added.

The array is expected to resolve distant objects at least five to 10 times better than the Hubble Space Telescope, which can enable people in Taipei in the north to observe a one-dollar coin in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.159 to close at NT$32.534.
A total of US$2.13 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.525 and fluctuated between NT$32.269 and NT$32.750.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop slightly on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed lower slightly Tuesday due to selling pressure, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 5.02 points, or 0.07 percent, to close at 6,949.08.

Following Wall Street's gains overnight and buoyed by a strong showing of Asian markets and appreciation of the local currency, the local bourse opened at 7,058 and shot to the day's high of 7,084.83, which was also the highest figure so far this year. It later dropped to a low of 6,899. 98.
A total of 8.75 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$232.19 billion (US$7.14 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks advancing the most at 1.9 percent. Textile shares rose 1.1 percent, and machinery and electronics shares surged 0.1 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks dropping the most at 2.3 percent. Banking and financial shares lost 1.0 percent, machinery and electronics shares moved down 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares dropped 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals issues shed 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,255 to 959, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

Altogether, the three major institutional investors bought NT$11.44 billion- worth of shares -- NT$10.54 billion by foreign investors, NT$1.77 billion by investment trust firms and NT$877 million by securities firms.

Shares in electronics stocks made a strong showing, boosted by the opening of WiMAX Taipei 2009 and the Computex Taipei 2009 and the visit to Taiwan by a 77-member trade delegation from China, an analyst said.

The analyst predicted the market will face some technical resistance because of profit-taking pressure and the 27.89 percent increase in margin trading volume in May after the TAIEX index rose above 6,000 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan confirms 14th case of swine flu

TEXT.P: Another imported case of swine flu was confirmed in Taiwan Tuesday, bringing to 14 the total number of individuals who have been infected with the influenza A(H1N1) virus in the country, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.
Central Epidemics Command Centers spokesman Shih Wen-yi said the latest victim was an eight-year-old school boy who returned to Taiwan Sunday from the United States.
Shih said on May 29, the boy, who went to Texas last year, developed mild coughing at the Los Angeles airport on his way home.

The boy arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport early Sunday. He began to develop a fever the following day and sought emergency treatment. He was listed as a case that required investigation. He was confirmed to have been infected the same night and is still being quarantined for treatment.

Shih said the boy wore a surgical mask throughout the entire flight. Center officials estimated that passengers sitting on three rows in front of and behind the boy, as well as his uncle, who drove to the airport to pick him up, and his cousin, who had temporarily stayed with the boy, have little risks of being infected and they only need to monitor their own health.
But the boy's grandparents, aunt and children from two relatives, all of whom have stayed long with the boy, "have been given medicine as a preventive measure," Shih added.
It is estimated that 59 individuals have had close contact with the boy. Among the 59, eight -- including family members and relatives -- have shown no symptoms.

Of the 39 passengers who were on the same flight with the boy and transferred to other countries, Taiwan has notified related countries through the International Health Regulations (IHR), an international instrument that is legally binding on all World Health Organization (WHO) member states.
Taiwan has so far recorded only one indigenous swine flu case and the remaining are all imported patients. Most of the confirmed patients have since recovered.

As the country has not reported any new domestic infections since May 25, the epidemic center lowered the alert level to the second stage of yellow, which denotes that there are no community infections in Taiwan.
As of 2 p.m Monday, 62 countries have officially reported 17,410 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 115 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scheduled cross-strait flights to begin in July

TEXT.P: Regular flights between Taiwan and China are set to begin in July in response to strong market demand, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Lung-wen announced Tuesday.

Under an accord inked in April by Taiwan and China that will take effect on June 25, the two sides agreed to expand air links from the current 108 charters to 270 scheduled flights per week, with each side to operate 135, Lee noted.
Taiwan's two largest carriers, China Airlines and EVA Airways, will each operate 30 scheduled flights to and from destinations in China, according to Lee.

UNI Airways and Mandarin Airlines will provide 25 weekly two-way flights across the strait, while TransAsia Airways will operate 24, he said. The remaining one flight will serve the Taichung-Shenzhen route and will be run by UNI Airways and Mandarin alternately.
Among the 19 popular destinations in China, Shanghai will be most heavily served by the Taiwan carriers, with 28 flights scheduled every week for that Chinese city, Lee said.

Nine flights will depart from each of the two airports in northern Taiwan -- Taipei's Songshan Airport and the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport -- and there will also be two weekly flights from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to Shanghai, he added.
Other Chinese cities, such as Beijing, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Shenzhen, will also be served by 10 two-way cross-strait flights per week, or more, from July, Lee said.

In a related development, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced in late May that Chinese tour operators who organize charter flights that use airports other the main two in Taiwan are now eligible for subsidies from the bureau.

Under a revised tourism incentive program, Chinese travel agents will receive NT$160,000 (US$4,920) per charter as long as the flight does not use Taipei City's Songshan Airport or Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and is carrying at least 100 foreign passengers who are visiting Taiwan for a minimum of two days.

Tourism Bureau officials said that if the charters either take off or land at one of the two northern airports, or carry between 50 and 100 passengers, the charter operators will be eligible to smaller subsidies.
The incentive is designed to expose foreign tourists to parts of the country outside of the popular northern gateways, including Taiwan's outlying islands, bureau officials said.

The vast majority of the current 108 direct charter flights per week between Taiwan and China use one of the two northern airports, even though a total of eight local airports have been designated to handle the direct charters.
Of the 108 direct charters, only four serve the southern port city of Kaohsiung and two serve Taichung in central Taiwan.
The Tourism Bureau launched the incentive program in May 2005 to encourage travel agents, primarily in Hong Kong, Macau, Japan and South Korea, to organize large tour groups to Taiwan.

In light of the rising number of Chinese tourist arrivals since the beginning of the year, the bureau recently decided to include China in the incentive program to lure more Chinese visitors to other parts of Taiwan. Taiwan has a daily quota of 3,000 Chinese tourist arrivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: President downplays 'courtesy encounter' with U.S. secretary of state
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/09 18:46:26 (By Huang Jui-hung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Monday called his recent exchange with U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton a "courtesy encounter, " as he played down the significance of the informal chat.

The two, who were in El Salvador to attend the Salvadoran presidential inauguration, met Sunday at a state banquet hosted by outgoing President Antonio Saca, during which Ma shared a table with Clinton.

The encounter drew much media attention because the governments of Taiwan and the United States have had no formal contact since diplomatic ties were severed in 1979, which means that meetings between high-level officials of the two countries are rare.

A similar encounter in 2003 in Panama between then President Chen Shui-bian and then U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell was considered by Chen's administration as a breakthrough in Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Asked about the issue during a casual gathering with Taiwanese media at his hotel, Ma said he would not play up such "courtesy encounters" as they are very common in diplomatic settings.
According to the president, progress in relations between Taiwan and the United States is unlikely to be achieved through such occasional meetings.

As to his use of the designation "the president of Taiwan" to introduce himself to Clinton, Ma explained that the name "Taiwan" is commonly known to represent "the Republic of China" and is widely used when convenient.
He stressed that the reference does not change the country's official name or his status as "the president of the Republic of China."

On his current Central America visit, Ma said the success of his policy to improve relations between Taiwan and China and to adopt a moderate, flexible approach in promoting foreign relations over the past year was validated.
Ma said he discovered during the visit that Taiwan's allies in the region are in favor of such a policy, which he added has greatly increased his confidence.

According to Ma, while Taiwan is working to consolidate its relations with its diplomatic allies, it does not oppose their attempts to develop unofficial relations with China that are based mainly on economic and trade activities.

Pledging to continue Taiwan's aid to its diplomatic allies, Ma said such assistance will be provided in the form of technical assistance, instead of cash donations or loans, in order to produce the best results.
El Salvador is the final leg of Ma's three-nation Central America visit that has also taken him to Belize and Guatemala.
He is scheduled to depart El Salvador June 2 and return to Taiwan June 4 via Seattle after an overnight stopover there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Invisible sticker to help police return lost bikes to owners

TEXT.P: Police in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, released Tuesday an invisible sticker that carries a set of code numbers that would enable law enforcement officers to find the owners of lost bicycles.

The specially-designed sticker with a hidden code can only be revealed with the use of a special optical device, Yilan police said, adding that the stickers would not mar the appearance of stylish bicycles.

The hidden code would interface with the police's data bank where the personal information of bike owners would be stored, the police explained. If a bike carrying the invisible sticker is stolen and the police find it, they could easily identify the owner, based on the hidden code, they said.

With effect from Tuesday, cyclists with ID cards can ask for the free stickers at any police station around the county, and at the same time have their bikes registered as a precaution against theft, the Yilan police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham urges Taiwan to improve government efficiency

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) released its 2009 Taiwan White Paper Tuesday, in which it praised Taiwan on several breakthrough achievements of the past year, but cautioned that Taiwan needs to do more to bolster its competitiveness during a time of unprecedented economic challenges, especially in improving government efficiencies.

AmCham Chairman Alan Eusden noted at a news conference that the area where Taiwan consistently has been weakest is government efficiency, and said that Taiwan has been losing ground recently, mainly because competing economies are improving so rapidly.

"It is the experience of some of our committees that the regulatory bodies that they deal with often do more to obstruct than to facilitate," Eusden said, adding that the regulatory process needs to be made more transparent and to involve more effective consultation with industries.

"International practices should be adopted instead of inventing unique-to-Taiwan regulations. Retraining of civil servants to emphasize service mindedness would help improve the situation and enable Taiwan to emerge from the recession in better shape to compete," he added.

According to the AmCham, several examples of particular frustration were found in the telecom industry, which has found little opportunity to engage in meaningful two-way dialogue with commissioners of the National Communications Commission.

Also frustrating was the current move to legislate a cap on credit-card interest rates, which the business organization said would likely hurt rather than help lower-income consumers and small businesses by shrinking the credit supply.

Another area that the AmCham expressed concern over is pharmaceutical and medical devices. It said that given the reimbursement prices from Taiwan's National Health Insurance system are among the lowest in the world, it would discourage pharmaceutical companies from launching innovative products that would enhance Taiwan's healthcare treatment.

Despite the above, AmCham commended Taiwan for making "breakthrough accomplishments" over the past year that include the start of regular direct flights between Taiwan and China, the country's accession to the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement, and the legislative passage of the Internet Service Provider bill, which reinforced Taiwan's commitment to intellectual property rights protection and validating the U.S. decision earlier this year to remove Taiwan from the Special 301 Watch List.

Since it was first published in 1996, the AmCham White Paper has served to set the basic annual agenda for the chamber's meetings with government agencies on a wide spectrum of economic and business issues.
Established in 1951, AmCham, which consists of more than 900 individuals representing more than 500 companies, is the oldest, largest, and the most active foreign-business organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meal vouchers help underprivileged families

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government has used meal vouchers to help underprivileged families weather difficulties amid the global economic downturn, the city government's Department of Social Welfare said Tuesday.

Department officials said that under the voucher program, underprivileged families can receive vouchers worth between NT$60 and NT$80 each and use them in eateries or restaurants that have joined the program.
The officials said that since the program was launched on a trial basis in March, it has provided assistance to 639 individual cases, and distributed 5,225 meal vouchers.
Twenty-nine eateries, cafeterias, beef noodle shops, fast food chain stores, as well as 28 charity groups have taken part in the program.
Department commissioner Shih Yu-ling said that the program is made possible because of the generosity of these eateries and charity groups.

"The significance of the program is not only to meet the needs of the underprivileged families, but also to build a more comprehensive social safety network in the community to provide better care to the underprivileged families," Shih said.

A department official also said that with the good results of the program, the department expects it to last until the end of the year, and will not rule out the possibility of continuing it after that.
The official said that all 12 administrative districts in Taipei have social welfare service centers, and the centers will evaluate the situation of needy families to distribute the meal vouchers.

"Between six and eight meal vouchers will be distributed each time to these families," he said, adding that "to make the best use of the limited resources, families with minors will be given priority."

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham encourages Taiwan to sign trade pact with China

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) said Tuesday that Taiwan should sign the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to ensure the competitiveness of Taiwan's products in the regional economic bloc.

"AmCham welcomes the negotiation of trade agreements with China along the lines of the ECFA now being discussed. Without it, Taiwan products stand to be excluded from the China market, as the regional trade bloc centered on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations expands, " said AmCham Chairman Alan Eusden at a news conference to release the business organization's annual White Paper.
"The chamber regards such an agreement as an economic necessity that should not be overly politicized," he added.

Since it was first published in 1996, the AmCham White Paper has served to set the basic annual agenda for the chamber's meetings with government agencies on a wide range of economic and business issues.

President Ma Ying-jeou has said that an ECFA with China is vital for Taiwan to avoid marginalization in the region and to help regulate the trade and investment relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The proposed ECFA would be similar to a free trade agreement between the two sides.
Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, told a cross-strait forum in Xiamen May 17 that China is willing to start ECFA negotiations with Taiwan as soon as possible.

According to the White Paper, AmCham also hopes to see economic connections between Taiwan and the United States advance through the scheduling of talks soon under the bilateral trade and investment framework agreement and by working toward the start of formal negotiations on a bilateral investment agreement.
Established in 1951, AmCham, which consists of more than 900 individuals representing more than 500 companies, is the oldest, largest, and the most active foreign-business organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to stage 2011 World Junior Badminton Championships

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei Badminton Association (CTBA) has won the right to host the 2011 World Junior Badminton Championships in Taiwan, CTBA President Kuo Jeng- liang announced Tuesday.
It will be Taiwan's first opportunity to host an international badminton championship and this event is expected to boost the country's international visibility, Kuo said at a news conference.
The association won the bid at the annual general meeting of the Badminton World Federation (BWF) in late May, according to Kuo.
He also said that CTBA Vice President Wu Chun-yen became the first Taiwanese ever to be elected to the BWF Board of Directors, gaining 207 of the 231 valid votes cast during the meeting.

The international badminton event will attract the participation of a large number of athletes from 30-40 countries, Kuo said, adding that he will lobby for other international badminton competitions and BWF board meetings to be held in Taiwan.
Wu also exhorted Taiwan's young badminton players to practice hard in order to perform outstandingly when the country hosts the international event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singaporean students volunteer help with Nantou harvest

TEXT.P: A group of high school students from the Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) in Singapore helped farmers in central Taiwan's Nantou County to harvest their radishes Tuesday as part of an overseas volunteer service program organized by the school.

Led by their teachers and assisted by local farmers, the 49 Singaporean students, braving temperatures of more than 30 degrees Celsius, rolled up their sleeves and wielded sickles to reap the crop in Puli township.

Two of the students said the hard work they had to do in the fields made a strong impression on them -- the first time in their lives they had done such work -- but said they "had a lot of excitement and fun."
Living in a city state, Singapore's people seldom have the opportunity to step on the soil and work in the fields.

"We hope to help Singaporean teenagers to learn more about the hard work farmers have to do and to gain a better understanding of Taiwan through this voluntary service program, " said one of the teachers.
Later in the day, the group visited a tea factory in the county's Shinyi township to learn about the process of tea-making and everyday life in a Taiwanese rural village.
They were also slated to visit a residential community in Mingjian township the following day, where they were to help clean the streets and trim roadside trees.
It is the third year the Singaporean school has sent students to do community service in Nantou through a cooperation program with the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK official to visit Taiwan for talks on bilateral cooperation

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui- lung will visit Taiwan June 5-6 for talks on the formation of an organization to promote bilateral cooperation between Hong Kong and Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Tuesday.

The Hong Kong government announced earlier in the day Lam's acceptance of an invitation from the MAC to make the visit, which will be the first official visit to Taiwan by an official of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

MAC officials said that during his stay, Lam, who is the Hong Kong official in charge of Taiwan affairs, will also have talks with MAC Vice Chairman Fu Don- cheng on issues concerning efforts to boost mutual exchanges in the fields of economics, trade and culture.

Taiwan and Hong Kong have had frequent contact on the planned cooperation organization and Fu visited the former British colony in March at the invitation of the Hong Kong government for talks on the issue, the MAC noted.
Fu is scheduled to meet with Lam June 5 to hammer out an agreement on the planned organization and other relevant issues, the MAC said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong, Yang Chia-chun, told CNA that Lam's visit will boost the development of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations and he expressed hope that similar official visits by personnel from the two sides will continue after Lam's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Israeli medical treatment benefits Taiwanese patients

TEXT.P: Israel's representative to Taiwan said Tuesday that the introduction earlier this year of an Israeli non-invasive treatment for uterine fibroids by a local medical university hospital has been of great benefit for local women.

"This serves as a good example of high-tech cooperation between Taiwan and Israel that has made it possible for Taiwanese women to benefit from Israel's scientific achievements, " said Raphael Gamzou, head of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO), in a press release.
Taiwan has therefore joined Japan, the United States, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Singapore and Israel as advanced countries, according to Gamzou.

Taipei Medical University Hospital announced at a news conference the previous day that since the hospital introduced the new ExAblate magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) -guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) incisionless surgery system for the treatment of uterine fibroids in January, it has received very positive responses from the 12 patients who have undergone the procedure.

Manufactured by Israeli medical device company InSightec and approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 2004, the ExAblate combines MRI to visualize anatomy, aid in planning the treatment and monitor temperatures and thermal doses in real time during the treatment.

This thermal feedback allows the physician to control and adjust the treatment to ensure that the targeted tumor is fully treated and surrounding tissues spared. Focused ultrasound is capable of ablating tumors inside the body without the need for an incision.

According to the ISECO, the world leading Biomed Israel 2009 that is scheduled for June 15-17 in Tel-Aviv will feature experts from around to world who will share their latest research on future developments of the biopharma and medical device industries.
The office also noted that a Taiwanese delegation will leave for the exhibition later this month and said companies interested in participating can contact the ISECO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung plans more MRT lines, despite losses

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is planning two more lines for its mass rapid transit system, even though the system suffered a massive loss of NT$2.2 billion last year, a city government official said Tuesday.

The Department of Rapid Transit official said that in order to build the system into a comprehensive public transport network, the department is planning yellow and brown lines, which will pass through bustling business, leisure and scenic districts in the city to end at Chengching Lake in Kaohsiung County.
The official noted that the existing Red Line and Orange Line intersect each other at the Formosa Boulevard Station, and said the department believes this has not made it a comprehensive network.
It has therefore appropriated NT$16 million this year to commission a consultancy company to plan the routes of the two proposed lines to facilitate the government's efforts to promote the system.
Both lines will be above ground, in contrast to the two existing lines that mainly run underground, to save on construction costs.
The yellow line, which will start at a major shopping mall at the heart of the Kaohsiung, will be 14.3 km and will cost an estimated NT$11.5 billion.
The brown line will start from a wharf near Kaohsiung Harbor and end at Chengching Lake, a distance of 11.29 km. Its price tag is estimated at around NT$9 billion.
Meanwhile, expansion plans for the existing two lines have been completed and submitted to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications for review.
The Red Line will be extended 9.8 km to Kaohsiung Science Park, while the Orange Line will be extended 14.04 km to neighboring Pingtung City, for a combined projected cost of NT$49.9 billion.

The north-south Red Line and east-west Orange Line were inaugurated in March and September last year, respectively. Since their launch, system's finances have taken a heavy hit because of low passenger volume.
In an effort to reduce the financial shortfall, the company has planned to increase passenger volume by 30 percent to 150,000 and to cut operating costs by 10 percent.
The Kaohsiung MRT was constructed on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis at a total cost of NT$181.3 billion and covers a total of 42.7 km.

DOC.HEADLINE: 78% satisfied with quality of government services: poll

TEXT.P: A majority of respondents to a recent government survey expressed satisfaction with the quality of official services, but over 40 percent said they were dissatisfied with the services offered by the police authorities, a Cabinet- level agency said Tuesday.

The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) conducted the telephone poll May 25-26 to explore local adults' views on the quality of government services. A total of 1,140 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

According to the poll results, 78 percent were generally satisfied with the various government services about which they were questioned and 67.7 percent said they found the efficiency of government services to be adequate.
By service category, eight fields received an approval rating of over 85 percent, with identification card replacement topping the list at 92.9 percent.

Mass rapid transit services came second, winning acclaim from 88.7 percent of the respondents, followed by driver's license test and replacement services at 88.2 percent, firefighters' services at 87.9 percent, land registration services at 87.7 percent, public cultural services at 87.2 percent, garbage disposal and recycling services at 86.9 percent and visa applications and replacements at 86 percent.

On the negative side, the "113" telephone hotline service for children's and women's protection posted the highest disapproval rating of 53.7 percent, followed by police services at 40.2 percent and government job placement services at 32.5 percent.

Overall, the survey found that 72.9 percent of the respondents were satisfied with civil servants' professional expertise, while 77.3 percent gave the thumbs- up to civil servants' service attitudes and 71 percent said they felt they are treated fairly in the course of seeking government services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Girl with Down syndrome gets new home in U.S.

TEXT.P: After five years of efforts, the Pingtung county government in southern Taiwan has finally found a new home in the United States for a 7-year-old girl with Down syndrome who was born into a severely dysfunctional family, a local charity said Tuesday.

"The girl, identified as Sunny, will soon settle in the state of Massachusetts along with her adoptive American parents, " said an executive with the Pingtung chapter of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF).
The charity, which collaborated with the county government to arrange the child's adoption, organized a farewell party for Sunny Tuesday, the eve of her departure for her new life in America.
At the party, Sunny, who has spent most of her life in foster care, met with her new parents -- James Lindsay, a high school teacher, and his wife Kelly, a homemaker.

The couple has three birth children, but have wide experience with physically and mentally challenged people, including time spent caring for three other children with Down syndrome, so they were very willing to take Sunny into their family.

According to a TFCF executive, Sunny, a first grader at a local elementary school, has good academic records as she has received government-subsidized medical treatments over the past few years to increase her intelligence, health and ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 3, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

Taiwan's two largest carriers, China Airlines and EVA Airways, will each operate 30 scheduled flights to and from destinations in China, according to Lee.

UNI Airways and Mandarin Airlines will provide 25 weekly two-way flights across the strait, while TransAsia Airways will operate 24, he said. The remaining one flight will serve the Taichung-Shenzhen route and will be run by UNI Airways and Mandarin alternately.
Among the 19 popular destinations in China, Shanghai will be most heavily served by the Taiwan carriers, with 28 flights scheduled every week for that Chinese city, Lee said.

Nine flights will depart from each of the two airports in northern Taiwan -- Taipei's Songshan Airport and the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport -- and there will also be two weekly flights from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan to Shanghai, he added.
Other Chinese cities, such as Beijing, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Shenzhen, will also be served by 10 two-way cross-strait flights per week, or more, from July, Lee said.

In a related development, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced in late May that Chinese tour operators who organize charter flights that use airports other the main two in Taiwan are now eligible for subsidies from the bureau.

Under a revised tourism incentive program, Chinese travel agents will receive NT$160,000 (US$4,920) per charter as long as the flight does not use Taipei City's Songshan Airport or Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and is carrying at least 100 foreign passengers who are visiting Taiwan for a minimum of two days.

Tourism Bureau officials said that if the charters either take off or land at one of the two northern airports, or carry between 50 and 100 passengers, the charter operators will be eligible to smaller subsidies.
The incentive is designed to expose foreign tourists to parts of the country outside of the popular northern gateways, including Taiwan's outlying islands, bureau officials said.

The vast majority of the current 108 direct charter flights per week between Taiwan and China use one of the two northern airports, even though a total of eight local airports have been designated to handle the direct charters.
Of the 108 direct charters, only four serve the southern port city of Kaohsiung and two serve Taichung in central Taiwan.
The Tourism Bureau launched the incentive program in May 2005 to encourage travel agents, primarily in Hong Kong, Macau, Japan and South Korea, to organize large tour groups to Taiwan.

In light of the rising number of Chinese tourist arrivals since the beginning of the year, the bureau recently decided to include China in the incentive program to lure more Chinese visitors to other parts of Taiwan. Taiwan has a daily quota of 3,000 Chinese tourist arrivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: President downplays 'courtesy encounter' with U.S. secretary of state
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, June 1 (CNA) 06/02/09 18:46:26 (By Huang Jui-hung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Monday called his recent exchange with U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton a "courtesy encounter, " as he played down the significance of the informal chat.

The two, who were in El Salvador to attend the Salvadoran presidential inauguration, met Sunday at a state banquet hosted by outgoing President Antonio Saca, during which Ma shared a table with Clinton.

The encounter drew much media attention because the governments of Taiwan and the United States have had no formal contact since diplomatic ties were severed in 1979, which means that meetings between high-level officials of the two countries are rare.

A similar encounter in 2003 in Panama between then President Chen Shui-bian and then U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell was considered by Chen's administration as a breakthrough in Taiwan-U.S. relations.
Asked about the issue during a casual gathering with Taiwanese media at his hotel, Ma said he would not play up such "courtesy encounters" as they are very common in diplomatic settings.
According to the president, progress in relations between Taiwan and the United States is unlikely to be achieved through such occasional meetings.

As to his use of the designation "the president of Taiwan" to introduce himself to Clinton, Ma explained that the name "Taiwan" is commonly known to represent "the Republic of China" and is widely used when convenient.
He stressed that the reference does not change the country's official name or his status as "the president of the Republic of China."

On his current Central America visit, Ma said the success of his policy to improve relations between Taiwan and China and to adopt a moderate, flexible approach in promoting foreign relations over the past year was validated.
Ma said he discovered during the visit that Taiwan's allies in the region are in favor of such a policy, which he added has greatly increased his confidence.

According to Ma, while Taiwan is working to consolidate its relations with its diplomatic allies, it does not oppose their attempts to develop unofficial relations with China that are based mainly on economic and trade activities.

Pledging to continue Taiwan's aid to its diplomatic allies, Ma said such assistance will be provided in the form of technical assistance, instead of cash donations or loans, in order to produce the best results.
El Salvador is the final leg of Ma's three-nation Central America visit that has also taken him to Belize and Guatemala.
He is scheduled to depart El Salvador June 2 and return to Taiwan June 4 via Seattle after an overnight stopover there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Invisible sticker to help police return lost bikes to owners

TEXT.P: Police in Yilan County, northeastern Taiwan, released Tuesday an invisible sticker that carries a set of code numbers that would enable law enforcement officers to find the owners of lost bicycles.

The specially-designed sticker with a hidden code can only be revealed with the use of a special optical device, Yilan police said, adding that the stickers would not mar the appearance of stylish bicycles.

The hidden code would interface with the police's data bank where the personal information of bike owners would be stored, the police explained. If a bike carrying the invisible sticker is stolen and the police find it, they could easily identify the owner, based on the hidden code, they said.

With effect from Tuesday, cyclists with ID cards can ask for the free stickers at any police station around the county, and at the same time have their bikes registered as a precaution against theft, the Yilan police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham urges Taiwan to improve government efficiency

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) released its 2009 Taiwan White Paper Tuesday, in which it praised Taiwan on several breakthrough achievements of the past year, but cautioned that Taiwan needs to do more to bolster its competitiveness during a time of unprecedented economic challenges, especially in improving government efficiencies.

AmCham Chairman Alan Eusden noted at a news conference that the area where Taiwan consistently has been weakest is government efficiency, and said that Taiwan has been losing ground recently, mainly because competing economies are improving so rapidly.

"It is the experience of some of our committees that the regulatory bodies that they deal with often do more to obstruct than to facilitate," Eusden said, adding that the regulatory process needs to be made more transparent and to involve more effective consultation with industries.

"International practices should be adopted instead of inventing unique-to-Taiwan regulations. Retraining of civil servants to emphasize service mindedness would help improve the situation and enable Taiwan to emerge from the recession in better shape to compete," he added.

According to the AmCham, several examples of particular frustration were found in the telecom industry, which has found little opportunity to engage in meaningful two-way dialogue with commissioners of the National Communications Commission.

Also frustrating was the current move to legislate a cap on credit-card interest rates, which the business organization said would likely hurt rather than help lower-income consumers and small businesses by shrinking the credit supply.

Another area that the AmCham expressed concern over is pharmaceutical and medical devices. It said that given the reimbursement prices from Taiwan's National Health Insurance system are among the lowest in the world, it would discourage pharmaceutical companies from launching innovative products that would enhance Taiwan's healthcare treatment.

Despite the above, AmCham commended Taiwan for making "breakthrough accomplishments" over the past year that include the start of regular direct flights between Taiwan and China, the country's accession to the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement, and the legislative passage of the Internet Service Provider bill, which reinforced Taiwan's commitment to intellectual property rights protection and validating the U.S. decision earlier this year to remove Taiwan from the Special 301 Watch List.

Since it was first published in 1996, the AmCham White Paper has served to set the basic annual agenda for the chamber's meetings with government agencies on a wide spectrum of economic and business issues.
Established in 1951, AmCham, which consists of more than 900 individuals representing more than 500 companies, is the oldest, largest, and the most active foreign-business organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meal vouchers help underprivileged families

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government has used meal vouchers to help underprivileged families weather difficulties amid the global economic downturn, the city government's Department of Social Welfare said Tuesday.

Department officials said that under the voucher program, underprivileged families can receive vouchers worth between NT$60 and NT$80 each and use them in eateries or restaurants that have joined the program.
The officials said that since the program was launched on a trial basis in March, it has provided assistance to 639 individual cases, and distributed 5,225 meal vouchers.
Twenty-nine eateries, cafeterias, beef noodle shops, fast food chain stores, as well as 28 charity groups have taken part in the program.
Department commissioner Shih Yu-ling said that the program is made possible because of the generosity of these eateries and charity groups.

"The significance of the program is not only to meet the needs of the underprivileged families, but also to build a more comprehensive social safety network in the community to provide better care to the underprivileged families," Shih said.

A department official also said that with the good results of the program, the department expects it to last until the end of the year, and will not rule out the possibility of continuing it after that.
The official said that all 12 administrative districts in Taipei have social welfare service centers, and the centers will evaluate the situation of needy families to distribute the meal vouchers.

"Between six and eight meal vouchers will be distributed each time to these families," he said, adding that "to make the best use of the limited resources, families with minors will be given priority."

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham encourages Taiwan to sign trade pact with China

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) said Tuesday that Taiwan should sign the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to ensure the competitiveness of Taiwan's products in the regional economic bloc.

"AmCham welcomes the negotiation of trade agreements with China along the lines of the ECFA now being discussed. Without it, Taiwan products stand to be excluded from the China market, as the regional trade bloc centered on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations expands, " said AmCham Chairman Alan Eusden at a news conference to release the business organization's annual White Paper.
"The chamber regards such an agreement as an economic necessity that should not be overly politicized," he added.

Since it was first published in 1996, the AmCham White Paper has served to set the basic annual agenda for the chamber's meetings with government agencies on a wide range of economic and business issues.

President Ma Ying-jeou has said that an ECFA with China is vital for Taiwan to avoid marginalization in the region and to help regulate the trade and investment relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The proposed ECFA would be similar to a free trade agreement between the two sides.
Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, told a cross-strait forum in Xiamen May 17 that China is willing to start ECFA negotiations with Taiwan as soon as possible.

According to the White Paper, AmCham also hopes to see economic connections between Taiwan and the United States advance through the scheduling of talks soon under the bilateral trade and investment framework agreement and by working toward the start of formal negotiations on a bilateral investment agreement.
Established in 1951, AmCham, which consists of more than 900 individuals representing more than 500 companies, is the oldest, largest, and the most active foreign-business organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to stage 2011 World Junior Badminton Championships

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei Badminton Association (CTBA) has won the right to host the 2011 World Junior Badminton Championships in Taiwan, CTBA President Kuo Jeng- liang announced Tuesday.
It will be Taiwan's first opportunity to host an international badminton championship and this event is expected to boost the country's international visibility, Kuo said at a news conference.
The association won the bid at the annual general meeting of the Badminton World Federation (BWF) in late May, according to Kuo.
He also said that CTBA Vice President Wu Chun-yen became the first Taiwanese ever to be elected to the BWF Board of Directors, gaining 207 of the 231 valid votes cast during the meeting.

The international badminton event will attract the participation of a large number of athletes from 30-40 countries, Kuo said, adding that he will lobby for other international badminton competitions and BWF board meetings to be held in Taiwan.
Wu also exhorted Taiwan's young badminton players to practice hard in order to perform outstandingly when the country hosts the international event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Singaporean students volunteer help with Nantou harvest

TEXT.P: A group of high school students from the Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) in Singapore helped farmers in central Taiwan's Nantou County to harvest their radishes Tuesday as part of an overseas volunteer service program organized by the school.

Led by their teachers and assisted by local farmers, the 49 Singaporean students, braving temperatures of more than 30 degrees Celsius, rolled up their sleeves and wielded sickles to reap the crop in Puli township.

Two of the students said the hard work they had to do in the fields made a strong impression on them -- the first time in their lives they had done such work -- but said they "had a lot of excitement and fun."
Living in a city state, Singapore's people seldom have the opportunity to step on the soil and work in the fields.

"We hope to help Singaporean teenagers to learn more about the hard work farmers have to do and to gain a better understanding of Taiwan through this voluntary service program, " said one of the teachers.
Later in the day, the group visited a tea factory in the county's Shinyi township to learn about the process of tea-making and everyday life in a Taiwanese rural village.
They were also slated to visit a residential community in Mingjian township the following day, where they were to help clean the streets and trim roadside trees.
It is the third year the Singaporean school has sent students to do community service in Nantou through a cooperation program with the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK official to visit Taiwan for talks on bilateral cooperation

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui- lung will visit Taiwan June 5-6 for talks on the formation of an organization to promote bilateral cooperation between Hong Kong and Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Tuesday.

The Hong Kong government announced earlier in the day Lam's acceptance of an invitation from the MAC to make the visit, which will be the first official visit to Taiwan by an official of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

MAC officials said that during his stay, Lam, who is the Hong Kong official in charge of Taiwan affairs, will also have talks with MAC Vice Chairman Fu Don- cheng on issues concerning efforts to boost mutual exchanges in the fields of economics, trade and culture.

Taiwan and Hong Kong have had frequent contact on the planned cooperation organization and Fu visited the former British colony in March at the invitation of the Hong Kong government for talks on the issue, the MAC noted.
Fu is scheduled to meet with Lam June 5 to hammer out an agreement on the planned organization and other relevant issues, the MAC said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's representative to Hong Kong, Yang Chia-chun, told CNA that Lam's visit will boost the development of Taiwan-Hong Kong relations and he expressed hope that similar official visits by personnel from the two sides will continue after Lam's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Israeli medical treatment benefits Taiwanese patients

TEXT.P: Israel's representative to Taiwan said Tuesday that the introduction earlier this year of an Israeli non-invasive treatment for uterine fibroids by a local medical university hospital has been of great benefit for local women.

"This serves as a good example of high-tech cooperation between Taiwan and Israel that has made it possible for Taiwanese women to benefit from Israel's scientific achievements, " said Raphael Gamzou, head of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO), in a press release.
Taiwan has therefore joined Japan, the United States, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Singapore and Israel as advanced countries, according to Gamzou.

Taipei Medical University Hospital announced at a news conference the previous day that since the hospital introduced the new ExAblate magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) -guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) incisionless surgery system for the treatment of uterine fibroids in January, it has received very positive responses from the 12 patients who have undergone the procedure.

Manufactured by Israeli medical device company InSightec and approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 2004, the ExAblate combines MRI to visualize anatomy, aid in planning the treatment and monitor temperatures and thermal doses in real time during the treatment.

This thermal feedback allows the physician to control and adjust the treatment to ensure that the targeted tumor is fully treated and surrounding tissues spared. Focused ultrasound is capable of ablating tumors inside the body without the need for an incision.

According to the ISECO, the world leading Biomed Israel 2009 that is scheduled for June 15-17 in Tel-Aviv will feature experts from around to world who will share their latest research on future developments of the biopharma and medical device industries.
The office also noted that a Taiwanese delegation will leave for the exhibition later this month and said companies interested in participating can contact the ISECO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung plans more MRT lines, despite losses

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is planning two more lines for its mass rapid transit system, even though the system suffered a massive loss of NT$2.2 billion last year, a city government official said Tuesday.

The Department of Rapid Transit official said that in order to build the system into a comprehensive public transport network, the department is planning yellow and brown lines, which will pass through bustling business, leisure and scenic districts in the city to end at Chengching Lake in Kaohsiung County.
The official noted that the existing Red Line and Orange Line intersect each other at the Formosa Boulevard Station, and said the department believes this has not made it a comprehensive network.
It has therefore appropriated NT$16 million this year to commission a consultancy company to plan the routes of the two proposed lines to facilitate the government's efforts to promote the system.
Both lines will be above ground, in contrast to the two existing lines that mainly run underground, to save on construction costs.
The yellow line, which will start at a major shopping mall at the heart of the Kaohsiung, will be 14.3 km and will cost an estimated NT$11.5 billion.
The brown line will start from a wharf near Kaohsiung Harbor and end at Chengching Lake, a distance of 11.29 km. Its price tag is estimated at around NT$9 billion.
Meanwhile, expansion plans for the existing two lines have been completed and submitted to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications for review.
The Red Line will be extended 9.8 km to Kaohsiung Science Park, while the Orange Line will be extended 14.04 km to neighboring Pingtung City, for a combined projected cost of NT$49.9 billion.

The north-south Red Line and east-west Orange Line were inaugurated in March and September last year, respectively. Since their launch, system's finances have taken a heavy hit because of low passenger volume.
In an effort to reduce the financial shortfall, the company has planned to increase passenger volume by 30 percent to 150,000 and to cut operating costs by 10 percent.
The Kaohsiung MRT was constructed on a build-operate-transfer (BOT) basis at a total cost of NT$181.3 billion and covers a total of 42.7 km.

DOC.HEADLINE: 78% satisfied with quality of government services: poll

TEXT.P: A majority of respondents to a recent government survey expressed satisfaction with the quality of official services, but over 40 percent said they were dissatisfied with the services offered by the police authorities, a Cabinet- level agency said Tuesday.

The Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) conducted the telephone poll May 25-26 to explore local adults' views on the quality of government services. A total of 1,140 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

According to the poll results, 78 percent were generally satisfied with the various government services about which they were questioned and 67.7 percent said they found the efficiency of government services to be adequate.
By service category, eight fields received an approval rating of over 85 percent, with identification card replacement topping the list at 92.9 percent.

Mass rapid transit services came second, winning acclaim from 88.7 percent of the respondents, followed by driver's license test and replacement services at 88.2 percent, firefighters' services at 87.9 percent, land registration services at 87.7 percent, public cultural services at 87.2 percent, garbage disposal and recycling services at 86.9 percent and visa applications and replacements at 86 percent.

On the negative side, the "113" telephone hotline service for children's and women's protection posted the highest disapproval rating of 53.7 percent, followed by police services at 40.2 percent and government job placement services at 32.5 percent.

Overall, the survey found that 72.9 percent of the respondents were satisfied with civil servants' professional expertise, while 77.3 percent gave the thumbs- up to civil servants' service attitudes and 71 percent said they felt they are treated fairly in the course of seeking government services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Girl with Down syndrome gets new home in U.S.

TEXT.P: After five years of efforts, the Pingtung county government in southern Taiwan has finally found a new home in the United States for a 7-year-old girl with Down syndrome who was born into a severely dysfunctional family, a local charity said Tuesday.

"The girl, identified as Sunny, will soon settle in the state of Massachusetts along with her adoptive American parents, " said an executive with the Pingtung chapter of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF).
The charity, which collaborated with the county government to arrange the child's adoption, organized a farewell party for Sunny Tuesday, the eve of her departure for her new life in America.
At the party, Sunny, who has spent most of her life in foster care, met with her new parents -- James Lindsay, a high school teacher, and his wife Kelly, a homemaker.

The couple has three birth children, but have wide experience with physically and mentally challenged people, including time spent caring for three other children with Down syndrome, so they were very willing to take Sunny into their family.

According to a TFCF executive, Sunny, a first grader at a local elementary school, has good academic records as she has received government-subsidized medical treatments over the past few years to increase her intelligence, health and ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday, moving down 34.08 points at 6,915 on a turnover of NT$5.85 billion (US$179.81 million).
The weighted price index lost 5.02 points, or 0.07 percent, to close at 6,949.08 Tuesday.
