DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 3, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's peacefulness ranking rises to 37th worldwide
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 2 (CNA) 06/03/09 12:58:47 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the world's 37th most peaceful country in 2008 -- up six notches from the previous year -- despite a general decrease in world peacefulness amid the global economic recession, according to the 2009 Global Peace Index (GPI) released Tuesday.

Robin Bew, chief economist of the London-based Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) that calculated the index for the Institute for Economics and Peace, attributed Taiwan's "moderate progress" to the country's political stability and increased instability in other countries.

The improvement in relations between Taiwan and China is another important reason, Bew said, adding that it would help raise Taiwan's ranking further if cross-Taiwan Strait ties continued to warm and military tensions continued to temper.
Now in its third year, the index defines peace as "the absence of violence" and looks at 23 qualitative and quantitative indicators of external and internal measures of peacefulness.

The results of the 2009 GPI showed that Taiwan score was dragged down by a less satisfactory performance in the areas of military capability/sophistication, relations with neighboring countries, ease of access to weapons of minor destruction and level of organized conflict (internal).

Overall, the results revealed that as the global economy headed into recession in 2008, many of the indicators, such as the likelihood of violent demonstrations and political instability, increased, while others -- such as respect for human rights -- decreased.
One such example was Iceland, which lost its title as the world's most peaceful country after its economy collapsed.
New Zealand was rated the world's most peaceful country in 2008, followed by Denmark and Norway (tied for second) , Iceland and Austria.
Rounding out the top 20 were Sweden, Japan, Canada, Finland, Slovenia, Czech Republic, Ireland, Luxembourg, Portugal, Belgium, Germany, Qatar, Switzerland, Australia and Chile.
Iraq was again the world's least peaceful country in 2008, remaining in 144th place. Afghanistan, Somalia, Israel and Sudan were the next least peaceful, ranking from 143rd to 140th, respectively.
Three of the world's major military-diplomatic powers continued to register relatively low rankings, with China at 74th, the United States at 83rd and Russia at 136th.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Computex Taipei a benchmark for global economic recovery: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2009 is serving as a benchmark of global economic recovery and as a platform to showcase Taiwan's competitiveness to the world, the executive vice president of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Wednesday.

"Under the current global economic challenges, this year's Computex Taipei provides an opportunity to test the temperature of the global economy and serve as an indicator for its recovery, said TAITRA's Walter Yeh.

Noting that the number of visitors to Computex Taipei 2009 on its opening day grew one percent to 7,900 compared to the previous year, Yeh said the increase isvery positive and inspiringand of great importance given the global economic dislocations that have occurred.

Computex Taipei -- Asia's biggest IT exhibition and the world's leading ICT procurement platform -- opened June 2 and will run through June 6. It is expected to attract 35,000 international buyers and generate US$20 billion in business.

In addition to Computex Taipei, Yeh said Taiwan has many other information and communication technology (ICT) trade shows that have great potential and competitive advantages in the international arena.

They include the upcoming Display Taiwan, scheduled for June 10-12, Photovoltaic Taiwan 2009 from October 7-9, TAITRONICS 2009 and the Taiwan International RFID Application Show from October 8-11, and Broadband Taiwan 2009 from October 26-28.
This is why the TAITRA held an international news conference Wednesday along with industry association representatives to promote thefive starsof Taiwan's ICT sector to the world, he added.
"The recipe for success for Taiwan's trade shows over the years is the fact that TAITRA and industry associations work closely together,Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Artifacts solicited for museum commemorating Taiwan's spy pilots

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu City Bureau of Culture Affairs is soliciting artifacts for a museum scheduled to open at the end of November that will honor the Black Bats Squadron, a group that flew surveillance missions over China decades ago.
To enrich its collection, the bureau called a news conference Tuesday to appeal to former Black Bats crew members around the country to donate memorabilia to the museum.
Nine former Black Bats were present at the news conference, with some promising to donate their collection of records on the squadron to the museum.
Former pilot Lu Wei-heng, 81, who had just returned to Taiwan from Canada, recalls that at that time, every one in the squadron shared common ideals.
"It is a great honor to die for the country, " and "I will be either a martyr if I die, or a hero if I survive, " were typical sentiments reflecting their outlooks, Lu recalled.
The Black Bats Squadron, or the 34th Squadron of the ROC Air Force, refers to a corps of CIA reconnaissance plane pilots based in Taiwan's northern city of Hsinchu during the Cold War in the 1950s.
The squadron was established in 1953 for the purpose of assisting the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in gathering military intelligence about China's secretive military plans.

The operation was made possible through the collaboration between the then Chiang Kai-shek government and Western Enterprises Inc. in Taipei, which was set up by the CIA. Under the cooperation program, the CIA provided aircraft and necessary equipment, while Taiwan was responsible to provide the pilots.
The squadron became known as the Black Bats Squadron because it always entered Chinese air space at night to conduct reconnaissance and surveillance missions.

Until the squadron's missions came to an end in December 1967, it had conducted 838 reconnaissance flights over China, losing 15 aircraft and 148 crew members, or two-thirds of the total, in the process. Only 14 dead bodies were recovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stops over in Seattle

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou arrived Tuesday in Seattle for an overnight stopover on his way back to Taiwan, after wrapping up his latest Central America visit.
Ma will not take part in any public activities in the U.S. city but is expected to receive some members of the U.S. congress at his hotel.
He is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday evening.
The main purpose of Ma's Central America trip was to attend the inauguration of El Salvador's President-elect Mauricio Funes. The tour also took him to Belize and Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: World's first WiMAX-service MRT trains available in Taipei

TEXT.P: WiMAX services have recently been made available on Taipei's MRT, allowing the public to try out the world's first mobile broadband wireless access network on a rapid transit system.

In all, eight trains of the Taipei MRT's Muzha Line were equipped with laptops with built-in WiMAX modules -- which enable swift access to the Internet -- to be used by passengers while riding the MRT system, said Lin Yu-hui, a project manager with the Taipei Computer Association, Wednesday.
The WiMAX MRT services, in line with this year's theme of "WiMAX on the MOVE" at Computex Taipei, will be available free of charge for one year from Monday, when the services were launched, Lin said.

Meanwhile, a 23-inch LCD monitor is installed on the front and back wall of each car of the WiMAX service MRT trains to enable passengers to watch various programs, including some that feature the star residents of Taipei Zoo -- its two giant pandas and its Formosan black bears.
"The passengers will also be able to watch live broadcasts of the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009 after September," Lin added.
The WiMAX MRT services were made possible only with the full support of the Taipei City government, the Industrial Development Bureau, and private companies including Acer and MSI, Lin said.

WiMAX (Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access) , a big broadband wireless application, processes data at a speed three to four times faster than ADSL, allowing users to download a 2G film in only 20-30 seconds.
Addressing the opening of Computex Taipei 2009 Tuesday, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung- bin said it took the city government half a year to prepare for the WiMAX services on the Muzha Line.
"The services marked a giant step forward in infrastructure development efforts to make Taipei City a new wired city," Hau said.
"Taipei City will take part in the Expo 2010 Shanghai under the name of Wireless Broadband Model City," Hau noted.
Also speaking at the opening, Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said a new era of WiMAX commercial operations will soon arrive.
WiMAX, netbooks and lightweight energy-saving notebooks appear to be the three major draws at this year's Computex Taipei, which opened Tuesday in Taipei.

Asia's biggest IT exhibition and the world's leading ICT procurement platform, Computex Taipei will run until June 6 and is expected to attract 35,000 international buyers and generate US$20 billion in business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Have you 'solar paneled' yet?

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer

On Orchid Island, the latest greeting between hotel operators is "Have you solar paneled yet? " This is because more and more inns and hostels on the island have begun to install cost-saving and environmentally-friendly solar panel water heating systems, sparking a trend that environmentalists hope will spread across Taiwan.

Located off Taiwan's southeast coast in the Pacific Ocean, the island famous for its aboriginal culture and picturesque scenery now has a higher percentage of hotels with solar panel hot-water systems than any other area in Taiwan.
So far, 10 out of the 52 hotels and hostels there have installed solar water heaters.
Hoteliers on the remote island never imagined they could help limit greenhouse gases, or save the planet.
"We don't have much here, except sunshine and the wind, which are endlessly available," said Chen Tsung-yue, operator of Yueshiuan Hotel.

Taking advantage of the strong and long durations of sunshine on the island, Chen was one of the first hotel owners to install a solar hot water system on his hostel's roof, at a cost of about NT$60,000 (US$2,000). "I recouped the investment in just one year," he said.
Others on Orchid Island soon followed in his footsteps, and the trend is also catching on elsewhere in Taiwan.

Central Taiwan's Nantou County has the greatest number of solar-powered water heaters in the country and the highest percentage of households with solar water heaters, mainly because almost all the homes rebuilt after the devastating Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake were equipped with solar water heaters.
Nationwide, 5 percent of all households have installed the devices, ranking Taiwan third behind Israel and Cyprus, according to the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Part of the reason for Taiwan's relatively high installation rate is that in 2000 the Bureau of Energy initiated a generous program offering incentives and subsidies to households to install solar water heaters, and 440,000 homes around the country have put in the devices since then.

The 5 percent installation rate in Taiwan is equivalent to a savings of 5 million 20-kilogram containers of liquefied gas that are not consumed, or a reduction of 370,000 tons of carbon dioxide, according to Bureau chief Yeh Hui- ching.
"It is expected that there will be 20 percent coverage of all homes with water- heating solar panels by 2020, with subsidies rising by 50 percent from this year," Yeh said.
The subsidy now averages NT$10,800 for a heater capable of generating hot water for a family of 4-5 persons, or solar collectors of an area of 4.8 square meters, compared to NT$7,200 since 2000.
Besides hotels and homes, some businesses in Taiwan are also joining the trend.

The Fugi Educational Park located in south-central Yunlin County -- known for its exclusively Buddhist education of youths and its devotion to promoting organic diets and green life -- has been one of the major users of solar water heaters in Taiwan.

According to Chuang Chao-chin, the head of Fugi's construction engineering task force, the institution has had 11 solar water heating systems installed so far since the school's inception in 2003 at a total cost of NT$13.75 million.

"The hot water has been limitlessly available in dormitories for about 1,000 students, faculty and volunteers, " Chuang said. "Even during peak shower hours in winter time, there was a sufficient supply of hot water without ever hitting a snag."
"The investment in the installation was paid back in three years," a contented Chuang said.
The Bureau of Energy has encouraged the installation of solar water heaters in part because of geography.
Taiwan's latitude -- between 22XN and 25XN -- is ideal for transforming the sun's rays into electricity and has made solar thermal energy the most widely used form of renewable energy in the country.

The solar water heating industry has also matured, with every phase of the installation, from know-how to equipment and materials, developed and sourced locally, said K. C. Chang, a professor at National Cheng Kung University in the southern city of Tainan.

But whether solar water heaters can become more popular and widely used in Taiwan depends on climate conditions, population structure, urbanization, building types and the status of new construction, according to Chang, who is also the principal investigator of NCKU's Research and Development Foundation, which has been authorized by the bureau to oversee the application of solar water heaters in the country.

Chang and his investigative team found that solar water heating systems are popular in Taiwan's central and southwestern regions, mainly because sunshine duration there is longer, and there are many more individual bungalows or terraced houses with flat roofs in the regions than in northern Taiwan, which make installation easier.
Solar water heaters have gained less traction in the north because of the many high-rise residential buildings and relatively lower sunshine duration.

Taiwan's government has not done enough to promote the application of solar water heating systems on the island, said Chen Fu-yung, chairman of the Taiwan Solar Energy Development Association, a nonprofit group of solar water heater installers and dealers.

Compared to Israel, in which installation of solar water heaters is mandatory, Germany, where installations grew at an 84 percent rate in 2008, and Spain, where the installation rate was up 67 percent last year, Taiwan has lagged far behind, Chen said.

He said that during a national energy conference held in April, officials and specialists devoted a lot of time to the further expansion of wind power generation and the development of solar photovoltaic energy in Taiwan.
It is unrealistic, however, to talk about developing wind power generation at present with each wind turbine unit having to be imported at a cost of NT$100 million.
"It would only benefit the foreign suppliers and dealers, " he contended.

"Why doesn't the government pay greater attention to the solar water heating system sector, whose know-how is mature and related materials available domestically thanks to Taiwan's well-developed high-tech industries. Also, solar water heating systems are inexpensive compared with wind and photovoltalic energy, " Chen noted.
The administration should live up to its promise to have 140,000 more solar water heating systems installed nationwide in the next four years, Chen said.

"The installation plan should begin in public facilities, such as schools, prisons, fire departments, police stations, and military establishments -- places with vast spaces and flat roofs that are ideal for solar panels," he suggested.

To bolster the popularity of solar water heaters in northern Taiwan, particularly in the Taipei metropolitan area, the government will also need to develop new strategies. In eastern Taiwan, it needs to address the problem of typhoons, which can destroy the roof-top equipment, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president discharged from hospital after lung surgery

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew was discharged from the Taipei Veterans General Hospital Wednesday following recovery from lung cancer surgery, the Presidential Office said that day.
Siew was expected to return to work Thursday, according to a statement released by the office.
The hospital will continue to follow up on his health and will provide him with targeted preventive therapy, the office added.
Siew, who was diagnosed with lung adenocarcinoma, underwent surgery May 20 to have the tumors removed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior ministry to hold municipality review June 23

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will hold a meeting June 23 to evaluate all applications by local cities and counties for mergers or upgrades to special municipalities next year, and the Executive Yuan is expected to make a final decision by Aug. 4, Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Wednesday.

Cities and counties that applied for such changes in status will be invited to give a 20-minute presentation on their plans, Liao said during a meeting with Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair and Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih.

At the meeting, Su submitted to Liao a petition signed by Tainan County residents seeking the minister's support for a merger of Tainan city and country into a special municipality similar to the metropolises of Taipei and Kaohsiung.

Su said Tainan's application has been considered as least likely to succeed since President Ma Ying-jeou laid out his campaign vision last year to demarcate Taiwan into three metropolises and 15 counties.

However, he urged that the government reconsider its redistricting plan from a historical and cultural perspective, and pointed out that Tainan, the ancient cultural capital of Taiwan, has a wealth of cultural heritage and historical sites.

Su also warned that political conflict will arise if the government fails to support the planned merger between Tainan city and county but endorses Taipei County's application for an upgrade to a special municipality.

The magistrate further asked Liao to guarantee that the Executive Yuan will announce its decision on the applications before Aug. 4 so as to avoid an impact on the three-in-one local elections scheduled for Dec. 5.
In response, Liao gave the assurance that the announcement will be made before early August.
On Hsu's question of whether administrative districts will be granted autonomy even after merging or upgrading, Liao said that has yet to be decided.
In accordance with the recently amended Local Government Act, counties or cities seeking a status upgrade or a merger had to submit their applications to the MOI by the end of May.

The MOI has received applications from Taipei county, Taichung city and county, Taoyuan county, Changhua county, Kaohsiung city and county, Tainan city and county, and the counties of Yunlin and Chiayi.
The applications will be submitted to the Executive Yuan at the end of this month after an initial MOI review, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Another opposition DPP mayor to visit China

TEXT.P: Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, a prominent member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , is scheduled to visit China in late June, on the heels of Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu's ice-breaking visit to the mainland last month.

Hsu has filed applications with the National Immigration Agency for approval for his China visit, which will mainly be a trip to the southeastern Chinese port city of Xiamen to attend the opening ceremony of the First Strait Cup Sailing Boat Championship slated for June 28-29.
About 30 sailing boats of all sizes from both sides are expected to take part in the sailing competition, which will start at a port in Xiamen June 28 and end in Tainan City's Anping Port on June 29.

Chen Chu, in her capacity as president of the World Games 2009 Kaohsiung Organizing Committee, visited Beijing and Shanghai May 21-24 to promote the 2009 World Games, which will be held in Kaohsiung July 16-26, making her the highest- ranking incumbent DPP official to have set foot in China.
Speaking about his forthcoming and first visit to the Chinese mainland, Hsu said Taiwan and China should engage in normal exchanges under the principles of dignity and equality.

"The two sides should grasp this juncture of friendly atmosphere to create peace across the Taiwan Strait. We should be determined on 'good things, ' but should refrain from doing things that are not conducive to development of mutual trust," he said.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently expressed welcome to Chen Chu's visits to China, and said he hoped to see increased interaction between the DPP and the Chinese leadership. He said that such interaction will allow Beijing to more clearly hear voices from Taiwan other than those of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and is conducive to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

If the country intends to reach a consensus on major issues pertaining to the people's well-being and interests, it should not depend solely on the KMT's efforts, Ma said. The DPP must also do its share, said Ma.

In Beijing, the spokesman for the State Council Taiwan Affairs Office, Yang Yi, labeled Chen Chu's China visit as "irrelevant to politics, " and expressed welcome to other prominent DPP figures to visit the mainland in the future.
Yang reiterated that Beijing would "respond favorably" to future visits by DPP politicians as long as the DPP changes its pro-Taiwan independence stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed 0.8 percent lower Wednesday, following news reports that China Metal Products Group and Prince Housing and Development Corp. were raided a day earlier by prosecutors for allegedly siphoning off money from their companies through the purchase of non-performing loans (NPLs).
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 55.94 points, to close at 6,893.14.

Despite Wall Street's gains overnight, the local bourse opened at 6,915 before rising to the day's high of 6,931.29. It later dropped to the day's low of 6,847.76, as profit-taking selling emerged and investors turned cautious as the TAIEX hovered close to 7,000 points.
A total of 5.76 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$156.20 billion (US$4.80 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 5.7 percent on news that the two construction companies were suspected of insider trading, breach of trust and forgery.

Cement shares dropped 2.2 percent, textile issues shed 2.1 percent, foodstuff stocks lost 1.6 percent, banking and financial stocks fell 1.3 percent, paper and pulp stocks dropped 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals issues fell 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,4361 to 714, with 116 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$8.11 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.029 to close at NT$32.505.
A total of US$1.033 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.534 and fluctuated between NT$32.408 and NT$32.579.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of junior high and primary students in Taipei City drops

TEXT.P: The number of students at junior high and elementary schools in Taipei City for the 2008-2009 school year totalled 261,907, a decrease of 9,484 from the previous school year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the city government.
Of the total, 253,188 students were born to parents who are both local nationals.

Some 3.33 percent of the total, or 8,719 students, were born to a local citizen parent and a foreign national, of whom, 1,521 are junior high school students, and 7,198 are elementary school students, the statistics showed.
Of those ethnically diverse students, most were born to a parent from China, Macau and Hong Kong, accounting for 47 percent of the group, followed by those born to a parent from Southeast Asia.

Most of the students born to one non-Taiwanese parent live in the city's Wenshan district, where 1,123 of the students lived. Nangang district had the smallest number of students born to a non-Taiwanese parent, with only 414 such students residing there, according to the figures.
The sharpest decrease was seen in the number of students born to both local nationals, which decreased by 11,048.

Meanwhile, the number of students born to a foreign parent increased by 1,564, with those born to a parent from China, Macau and Hong Kong increasing by 709, and those born to a parent from Vietnam increasing by 611, the statistics revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Octogenarian student launches solo exhibit to mark graduation

TEXT.P: An octogenarian student opened a solo exhibition of his paintings Wednesday in the southern county of Tainan to mark his graduation from university.
The exhibit features more than 100 pieces of work by Shen Chien-yi, 84, and includes oil paintings, water colors, stereography and Chinese brush calligraphy.
The show is being held at Chang Jung Christian University in Tainan County's Gueiren township to mark Shen's graduation from the school's Department of Visual Art after four years of studies.
Shen, who fought in World War II as a career military officer, came to Taiwan from mainland China more than five decades ago to work as a public functionary.
He was chief of the Tainan City government's news department before he was transferred to the Kaohsiung City government where he worked in the secretariat until his retirement.

He told the Central News Agency that was fond of painting even as a child. But he had been living the life of a refugee since he was 10 because of the outbreak of WWII, and his dreams of becoming a painter or even gaining a college education were dashed, he said.
However, Shen said, he never lost his interest in painting and he applied to study at China Academy of Art in Hangzhou at the age of 73, years after his retirement.

He was accepted and began his program at the academy, but was forced to return in full to Taiwan less than two years later when his health began to decline due to age and fatigue from the frequent trips across the Taiwan Strait to attend school.

Determined not to give up his dream, Shen, at the age of 80, registered four years ago for classes in water color painting with professor Tsai Mau-sung, director of Chang Jung Christian University's Department of Visual Art.
In 2005, he took the department's entrance exams and began full- time studies there.
"Now my dreams have come true, " a gratified Shen said at the opening of his exhibition.
He said he wants to tell people of the younger generations not to waste precious time when they are young and have the opportunity to learn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boost foreign language proficiency of undergraduates

TEXT.P: The government will encourage local universities to list foreign language proficiency among the graduation criteria for students so as to strengthen the competitiveness of the country's labor force, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.
The measure is one of several strategies put forward by the CEPD to boost the development of Taiwan's service sector.

Other steps to be adopted by the government include providing foreign language courses for workers in the service sector, especially those in the medical and travel sectors, the CEPD said in a briefing to the Cabinet.
According to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Taiwan's business sector is undergoing a structural change in which services play a crucial role.
Therefore, the government should support the development of the service sector by promoting measures that take advantage of Taiwan's culture and human resources, Liu said.
According to the CEPD, the government's objective is to raise the service sector's contribution to the country's gross domestic product to NT$11 trillion by 2012.

To achieve this goal, the government will promote the export of replicable services, explore business opportunities in emerging markets such as China, and seek to internationalize Taiwanese food to boost food exports, the CEPD said.
In 2008, services exported by Taiwan were valued at US$33.59 billion, accounting for 0.9 percent of the world's total value and making Taiwan the world's 26th- largest services exporter.
The ranking, however, marked a significant decline from 2000, when Taiwan was in 18th place.

The CEPD said that in addition to weak export competitiveness, Taiwan's service sector is facing several other problems, such as insufficient investment in research, development and innovation, and low productivity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military personnel recruitment policy laid down

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has devised a new military recruitment policy under which Taiwan will adopt an all-volunteer military service system during peace time but will maintain areservist system to be used in time of war, a senior MND official said Wednesday.
Lt. Gen. Wang Chun-chiang, director of the MND Department of Manpower, made the announcement at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.
Wang said the MND will reach its goal of having an all-volunteer military force by the end of 2014.
Wang and Vice Defense Minister Chang Liang-jen were invited to attend the committee meeting to give briefings how the ministry will implement the new system.
Faced with a variety of legislators' opinions about the system, Chang said the ministry "will go all-out to reach the goal of building an all-volunteer military service system."

Asked how the ministry plans to cover the added expense of an all-volunteer military, Chang said the annual budget for personnel spending will be raised from 39 percent of the total national defense budget in 2009 to 45 percent once the system is fully implemented.
At the same time, the budget for arms procurement will be cut, he said.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang reminded the ministry that as it continues to reduce its intake of conscripts year by year, it will be faced with the problem that the number of people awaiting deferred conscription will have reached 92,000 by the end of 2013. According to the existing laws, these people must perform their national service.

Asked how the MND will handle the problem, Wang said it is planning to put such conscripts to work as alternative service draftees and will move to amend the relevant regulations to allow more people to serve in this capacity.

According to the MND report, under the all-volunteer system, conscripts after 2014 will still need to undergo military training for four months before being registered as military reserves, to be called up in the event of war.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft to launch Windows 7 Oct. 22

TEXT.P: Microsoft announced Wednesday in Taipei that its Windows 7 operating system will be released Oct. 22, bringing to its end-users and business customers what it called a much easier and more exciting Windows experience.

Steven Guggenheimer, corporate vice president of the Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) Division at Microsoft Corp. made the announcement in a keynote speech at Microsoft Forum 2009 during the ongoing Computex Taipei show.

In addition, details of the Windows 7 upgrade option will be released later this month, while Windows 7 Release to Manufacturing will be available at the end of July, Guggenheimer said in the speech, which included a demonstration of Windows 7 features.

"That date (Oct. 22) was chosen based on conversations with our hardware partners -- retail partners across the globe. We worked on Windows 7 from milestone to milestone and Oct. 22 popped out, " Guggenheimer said in a news conference after the forum.

As to why he chose to announce the release date at Computex Taipei, Guggenheimer said it was an obvious choice because Computex is a very important IT show at the core of the industry and some of Microsoft's best partners are there.
Asked about the likely penetration rate and sales volume of Windows 7, Guggenheimer said the company's goal is to let the product speak for itself.
He declined to disclose the retail price of the new product, saying that it is an intricate decision that Microsoft makes in conjunction with its partners and that the price will be announced later.

According to Microsoft, Windows 7 is meant to be more user-centric and to focus on improved performance. It includes a number of new features, such as advances in handwriting recognition, support for virtual hard disks, improved performance on multi-core processors, and the option to pin any program to the taskbar.
Guggehheimer, who has just taken over the helm of OEM, was making his second address at Computex Taipei, which will run until June 6.

He said that although the economic realities of the past year have created new challenges for customers, partners and the IT industry, the power of innovation will continue to benefit consumers, the industry and the economy at large.
To illustrate the point, Guggenheimer pointed to the evolution of small notebook PCs, or netbooks, and the ensuing emergence of a new class of consumer Internet devices.

Guggenheimer said that the broad adoption of small notebooks shows that they are answering a market need, especially given the economic situation. It also reflects that they have evolved quickly from their initial function as basic Web-surfing tools to become powerful personal computers, he added.
"Buyers are becoming increasingly cost-conscious and mobile, and laptop sales are soon expected to outstrip desktop PC sales in developed economies," he said.

Speaking of the future trend of the ICT industry, Guggenheimer forecast that consumer Internet devices, which fall somewhere between smartphones and full- featured small notebook PCs, will become more and more popular.
The next generation of smart, connected, service-oriented devices will give people mobile access to a rich set of media and information, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Olympic athletes to help promote Deaflympics

TEXT.P: Participants, including Taiwanese athletes who competed in the Olympics, will wear earplugs when they run in a June 7 race to promote the upcoming Taipei Deaflympics, according to aDeaflympics executive Wednesday.
The event, which will be held in Taiwan for the first time, will bring together thousands of athletes who are hearing impaired to compete in various sports.

Emile Chih-jen Sheng, CEO of the Taipei Deaflympics Organizing Committee (TDOC) , said the committee worked with the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee in designing the Olympic Day Run, which will precede the Deaflympics to encourage more people to understand and take part in the 2009 Deaflympics, which will be held in Taipei City from Sept. 5-15.

Tzeng Wen-hung, a Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee executive, said the race is an international movement in celebration of the creation of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and has been held annually for more than 20 years by IOC members around the world.
A total of 3,341 runners, including more than 20 people with hearing disabilities and 10 visually impaired people, will vie for medals in two groups-- the 4 km race and 8 km race.
They will each receive a pair of earplugs from the organizer on the day of the race, Tzeng said.

TDOC CEO Sheng said runners are invited to experience the silence in movement to understand the feelings and difficulties of hearing impaired athletes in the Deaflympics, which is limited to those who have a hearing loss of at least 55 decibels in the better ear.
The race will come after the release of Deaflympics' theme song in May, Sheng said.

Many other promotional activities will also be staged after the road race, including a grand opening of the Deaflympics main stadium on July 23 and an invitational track and field game from July 24-25.
There will also be a series of large-scale performances to drum up the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009, which is expected to draw 4,000 players from 81 countries to compete in 19 types of sports.

The performances include Taiwanese operas and shows by aboriginal singers, the world-famous creative organization Blue Man Group, and a folk music and dance troupe from China's Yunnan Province, Sheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to discuss revision of physician act

TEXT.P: A dozen medical students again called on the government Wednesday to address what they said were discrepancies in the requirements for Taiwanese medical school graduates to practice their profession in their home country.
The call came on the heels of a massive protest by medical students, which is rare in Taiwan, on the weekend.

The approximately 1,000 local medical students who took to the streets in Taipei Sunday said the process whereby Taiwanese graduates of Polish medical schools could begin to practice in Taiwan was "simple" and "unfair" compared to the requirements that apply to graduates of local schools.
In response, an Executive Yuan official said Monday that the Cabinet "has heard the voice of the public" and will discuss a draft revision of the physician act Thursday.

The draft bill seeks to introduce a requirement for Taiwan nationals who graduate from foreign medical schools to obtain accreditation of their academic qualifications before they could be allowed to sit the state medical doctor examination in Taiwan.

If the bill is passed, they will also be required to serve internships at local hospitals for a certain period of time and pass screening process before being allowed to take the state exam, an official said.

Under the current act, Taiwan students who graduate from medical schools in the United States, Japan, the European Union, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore or Hong Kong are not required to obtain accreditation of their academic credentials or serve internships at Taiwan hospitals before taking the state medical examination.

However, the Federation of Medical Students in Taiwan has been demanding a revision of the act, saying that Taiwanese graduates of foreign medical schools should be subject to the same requirements as those who studied in Taiwan.

The members of the federation noted that in order to enter medical schools, local applicants have to pass rigorous exams, and that only about 700 of the 100,000 senior high school students who took the entrance exams last year were admitted to medical schools in Taiwan.

In comparison, the threshold for entry to medical schools in Poland and elsewhere in Europe is lower and the tuition less, they said, noting that local recruiters have been arranging for relatively large numbers Taiwanese senior high school students to enter such institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group opposes plan to build tobacco plant in Miaoli township

TEXT.P: The non-profit, anti-smoking John Tung Foundation voiced its objection Wednesday to a foreign company's plan to build a tobacco plant in northern Taiwan's Miaoli County, and called for a central government investigation of the issue.

Speaking at a news conference, John Tung Foundation CEO Yao Shi-yuan harshly criticized the plan by the Imperial Tobacco Company Ltd. to build a plant in Miaoli's Chunan township, and criticized the local government for allowing the company to do so despite strong public disapproval.
The Miaoli county government announced recently that it has approved a project submitted by the Britain-based Imperial Tobacco to erect a plant at the Kuanyuan technology park in Chunan.
According to Yao, the tobacco plant would be the company's first in Southeast Asia and will serve as a base from which to explore other markets in the region.
Yao said that although the tobacco plant was projected to create some 250 job opportunities in Miaoli, "it would not be worthwhile compared to the possible hazards."

Allowing the tobacco plant would be tantamount to opening the door to a dangerous foe, Yao warned. He urged the Control Yuan, Taiwan's highest watchdog body, to investigate the planned project, given that it is "against international norms and could seriously tarnish Taiwan's international image."
In response, Blanchi Cheng, a board member of the Tobacco Institute of the Republic of China, said that Yao's arguments did not reflect the whole truth.
The project is a legal investment that could also help to boost local economic development, Cheng said.
However, a woman surnamed Lin who lives in Dali City in central Taiwan's Taichung County expressed support for Yao's call.

"A tobacco plant would not benefit the local community. Instead, it might damage the health of the local residents, " she said, pointing a finger at a cigarette factory run by the state-run Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. in her hometown.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan Science Park reports increasing turnover

TEXT.P: The accumulated turnover of the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) in March and April reached NT$65.31 billion (US$2 billion) -- a growth of 46.41 percent compared with the January-February figure, the park administration said in a statement Wednesday.
The March-April turnover, however, posted a drop of 37.18 percent from the same period in 2008, the STSP administration said.
Nonetheless, the decline was the smallest for the last six months, which was a sign that the local recession has bottomed out, according to the statement.

The accumulated turnover of the science park, which houses nearly 160 high-tech businesses, in the first four months of the year stood at NT$109.93 billion, which was a 46.07 percent decline from the same period last year, according to the statement.

The STSP is comprised of two separate parks -- the Tainan Science Park and the Kaohsiung Science Park. The industries operating in the parks include integrated circuits, optoelectronics, biotechnology, telecommunications, precision machinery, as well as computer and peripherals.

The STSP administration said that the optoelectronics industry generated a turnover of NT$44.33 billion in the March-April period, recording the largest two-month growth among all the business sectors in the park.
The STSP administration attributed the growth to increasing demand from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young fairy pittas begin to explore outside world

TEXT.P: A bird watcher urged bird lovers Wednesday to seize the opportunity to watch the beautiful fairy pittas and their young, which will leave Taiwan soon on their annual migration route.
Lai Wen-ho said he has been looking forward for nearly a month to seeing the young birds leaving their nests with their parents and that "the time has finally come."
Lai said that he had been waiting quietly in some low bushes near the birds' habitat since early Wednesday morning to take photographs of them.
Taitung, with its wide expanses of lush greenery, has been attractive to the birds, which migrate every year between March and June to Taiwan to breed and leave again after June, he said.
He noted that the birds usually chose damp bushes that are free of pesticides and other pollutants as their breeding ground.
The birds migrate not to escape harsh winters, but rather to take advantage of the long spring and summer days and to feed on the many insects in the higher latitudes, Lai said.

This bird species, with an estimated population of 2,500 to 10,000, is classified as "vulnerable" by BirdLife International. This infers that the population is rapidly declining due to deforestation in its breeding areas, principally for agriculture and logging purposes. The problem is compounded by trappers who catch the birds to sell them in the pet industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer than 200,000 babies born in 2008: interior ministry

TEXT.P: The number of babies born in Taiwan in 2008 was under 200,000, which was a new low, statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) showed.
According to the MOI statistics, 196,486 babies were born in 2008, which was a drop of 3.5 percent from 2007.
Some 9.6 percent of the mothers of newborns were non-Taiwan nationals, down 0.6 percentage points from 2007, which represented a sharp decline to fewer than 20,000.
Most of the women who gave birth in Taiwan last year were between 25 and 34 years old, which was an indication that the age of women giving birth was rising, with the average being 29.8 years.

The average age of mothers in Taiwan from Southeast Asian countries was 26.7, for those from China, Hong Kong and Macau it was 28.7 years, and for Taiwanese women it was 30.1, according to the statistics.
Along with a growing trend toward people getting married later in life, the average age of women having their first babies also rose to 28.9 years in 2008 from 26.4 in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor departs for Italy to attend Venice Biennale

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin headed for Italy Wednesday to attend the 53rd Venice Biennale, which has been an important arena for Taiwan to engage with the international arts community over the past 10-plus years.

In addition to presiding over the opening of the Taiwan Hall at the Venice Biennale, Hau will also meet with Rome and Venice city officials to discuss the promotion of urban cultural industries and services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of junior high and primary students in Taipei City drops

TEXT.P: The number of students at junior high and elementary schools in Taipei City for the 2008-2009 school year totalled 261,907, a decrease of 9,484 from the previous school year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the city government.
Of the total, 253,188 students were born to parents who are both local nationals.

Some 3.33 percent of the total, or 8,719 students, were born to a local citizen parent and a foreign national, of whom, 1,521 are junior high school students, and 7,198 are elementary school students, the statistics showed.
Of those ethnically diverse students, most were born to a parent from China, Macau and Hong Kong, accounting for 47 percent of the group, followed by those born to a parent from Southeast Asia.

Most of the students born to one non-Taiwanese parent live in the city's Wenshan district, where 1,123 of the students lived. Nangang district had the smallest number of students born to a non-Taiwanese parent, with only 414 such students residing there, according to the figures.
The sharpest decrease was seen in the number of students born to both local nationals, which decreased by 11,048.

Meanwhile, the number of students born to a foreign parent increased by 1,564, with those born to a parent from China, Macau and Hong Kong increasing by 709, and those born to a parent from Vietnam increasing by 611, the statistics revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Octogenarian student launches solo exhibit to mark graduation

TEXT.P: An octogenarian student opened a solo exhibition of his paintings Wednesday in the southern county of Tainan to mark his graduation from university.
The exhibit features more than 100 pieces of work by Shen Chien-yi, 84, and includes oil paintings, water colors, stereography and Chinese brush calligraphy.
The show is being held at Chang Jung Christian University in Tainan County's Gueiren township to mark Shen's graduation from the school's Department of Visual Art after four years of studies.
Shen, who fought in World War II as a career military officer, came to Taiwan from mainland China more than five decades ago to work as a public functionary.
He was chief of the Tainan City government's news department before he was transferred to the Kaohsiung City government where he worked in the secretariat until his retirement.

He told the Central News Agency that was fond of painting even as a child. But he had been living the life of a refugee since he was 10 because of the outbreak of WWII, and his dreams of becoming a painter or even gaining a college education were dashed, he said.
However, Shen said, he never lost his interest in painting and he applied to study at China Academy of Art in Hangzhou at the age of 73, years after his retirement.

He was accepted and began his program at the academy, but was forced to return in full to Taiwan less than two years later when his health began to decline due to age and fatigue from the frequent trips across the Taiwan Strait to attend school.

Determined not to give up his dream, Shen, at the age of 80, registered four years ago for classes in water color painting with professor Tsai Mau-sung, director of Chang Jung Christian University's Department of Visual Art.
In 2005, he took the department's entrance exams and began full- time studies there.
"Now my dreams have come true, " a gratified Shen said at the opening of his exhibition.
He said he wants to tell people of the younger generations not to waste precious time when they are young and have the opportunity to learn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to boost foreign language proficiency of undergraduates

TEXT.P: The government will encourage local universities to list foreign language proficiency among the graduation criteria for students so as to strengthen the competitiveness of the country's labor force, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.
The measure is one of several strategies put forward by the CEPD to boost the development of Taiwan's service sector.

Other steps to be adopted by the government include providing foreign language courses for workers in the service sector, especially those in the medical and travel sectors, the CEPD said in a briefing to the Cabinet.
According to Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Taiwan's business sector is undergoing a structural change in which services play a crucial role.
Therefore, the government should support the development of the service sector by promoting measures that take advantage of Taiwan's culture and human resources, Liu said.
According to the CEPD, the government's objective is to raise the service sector's contribution to the country's gross domestic product to NT$11 trillion by 2012.

To achieve this goal, the government will promote the export of replicable services, explore business opportunities in emerging markets such as China, and seek to internationalize Taiwanese food to boost food exports, the CEPD said.
In 2008, services exported by Taiwan were valued at US$33.59 billion, accounting for 0.9 percent of the world's total value and making Taiwan the world's 26th- largest services exporter.
The ranking, however, marked a significant decline from 2000, when Taiwan was in 18th place.

The CEPD said that in addition to weak export competitiveness, Taiwan's service sector is facing several other problems, such as insufficient investment in research, development and innovation, and low productivity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military personnel recruitment policy laid down

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has devised a new military recruitment policy under which Taiwan will adopt an all-volunteer military service system during peace time but will maintain areservist system to be used in time of war, a senior MND official said Wednesday.
Lt. Gen. Wang Chun-chiang, director of the MND Department of Manpower, made the announcement at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.
Wang said the MND will reach its goal of having an all-volunteer military force by the end of 2014.
Wang and Vice Defense Minister Chang Liang-jen were invited to attend the committee meeting to give briefings how the ministry will implement the new system.
Faced with a variety of legislators' opinions about the system, Chang said the ministry "will go all-out to reach the goal of building an all-volunteer military service system."

Asked how the ministry plans to cover the added expense of an all-volunteer military, Chang said the annual budget for personnel spending will be raised from 39 percent of the total national defense budget in 2009 to 45 percent once the system is fully implemented.
At the same time, the budget for arms procurement will be cut, he said.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the ruling Kuomintang reminded the ministry that as it continues to reduce its intake of conscripts year by year, it will be faced with the problem that the number of people awaiting deferred conscription will have reached 92,000 by the end of 2013. According to the existing laws, these people must perform their national service.

Asked how the MND will handle the problem, Wang said it is planning to put such conscripts to work as alternative service draftees and will move to amend the relevant regulations to allow more people to serve in this capacity.

According to the MND report, under the all-volunteer system, conscripts after 2014 will still need to undergo military training for four months before being registered as military reserves, to be called up in the event of war.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft to launch Windows 7 Oct. 22

TEXT.P: Microsoft announced Wednesday in Taipei that its Windows 7 operating system will be released Oct. 22, bringing to its end-users and business customers what it called a much easier and more exciting Windows experience.

Steven Guggenheimer, corporate vice president of the Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) Division at Microsoft Corp. made the announcement in a keynote speech at Microsoft Forum 2009 during the ongoing Computex Taipei show.

In addition, details of the Windows 7 upgrade option will be released later this month, while Windows 7 Release to Manufacturing will be available at the end of July, Guggenheimer said in the speech, which included a demonstration of Windows 7 features.

"That date (Oct. 22) was chosen based on conversations with our hardware partners -- retail partners across the globe. We worked on Windows 7 from milestone to milestone and Oct. 22 popped out, " Guggenheimer said in a news conference after the forum.

As to why he chose to announce the release date at Computex Taipei, Guggenheimer said it was an obvious choice because Computex is a very important IT show at the core of the industry and some of Microsoft's best partners are there.
Asked about the likely penetration rate and sales volume of Windows 7, Guggenheimer said the company's goal is to let the product speak for itself.
He declined to disclose the retail price of the new product, saying that it is an intricate decision that Microsoft makes in conjunction with its partners and that the price will be announced later.

According to Microsoft, Windows 7 is meant to be more user-centric and to focus on improved performance. It includes a number of new features, such as advances in handwriting recognition, support for virtual hard disks, improved performance on multi-core processors, and the option to pin any program to the taskbar.
Guggehheimer, who has just taken over the helm of OEM, was making his second address at Computex Taipei, which will run until June 6.

He said that although the economic realities of the past year have created new challenges for customers, partners and the IT industry, the power of innovation will continue to benefit consumers, the industry and the economy at large.
To illustrate the point, Guggenheimer pointed to the evolution of small notebook PCs, or netbooks, and the ensuing emergence of a new class of consumer Internet devices.

Guggenheimer said that the broad adoption of small notebooks shows that they are answering a market need, especially given the economic situation. It also reflects that they have evolved quickly from their initial function as basic Web-surfing tools to become powerful personal computers, he added.
"Buyers are becoming increasingly cost-conscious and mobile, and laptop sales are soon expected to outstrip desktop PC sales in developed economies," he said.

Speaking of the future trend of the ICT industry, Guggenheimer forecast that consumer Internet devices, which fall somewhere between smartphones and full- featured small notebook PCs, will become more and more popular.
The next generation of smart, connected, service-oriented devices will give people mobile access to a rich set of media and information, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Olympic athletes to help promote Deaflympics

TEXT.P: Participants, including Taiwanese athletes who competed in the Olympics, will wear earplugs when they run in a June 7 race to promote the upcoming Taipei Deaflympics, according to aDeaflympics executive Wednesday.
The event, which will be held in Taiwan for the first time, will bring together thousands of athletes who are hearing impaired to compete in various sports.

Emile Chih-jen Sheng, CEO of the Taipei Deaflympics Organizing Committee (TDOC) , said the committee worked with the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee in designing the Olympic Day Run, which will precede the Deaflympics to encourage more people to understand and take part in the 2009 Deaflympics, which will be held in Taipei City from Sept. 5-15.

Tzeng Wen-hung, a Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee executive, said the race is an international movement in celebration of the creation of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and has been held annually for more than 20 years by IOC members around the world.
A total of 3,341 runners, including more than 20 people with hearing disabilities and 10 visually impaired people, will vie for medals in two groups-- the 4 km race and 8 km race.
They will each receive a pair of earplugs from the organizer on the day of the race, Tzeng said.

TDOC CEO Sheng said runners are invited to experience the silence in movement to understand the feelings and difficulties of hearing impaired athletes in the Deaflympics, which is limited to those who have a hearing loss of at least 55 decibels in the better ear.
The race will come after the release of Deaflympics' theme song in May, Sheng said.

Many other promotional activities will also be staged after the road race, including a grand opening of the Deaflympics main stadium on July 23 and an invitational track and field game from July 24-25.
There will also be a series of large-scale performances to drum up the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009, which is expected to draw 4,000 players from 81 countries to compete in 19 types of sports.

The performances include Taiwanese operas and shows by aboriginal singers, the world-famous creative organization Blue Man Group, and a folk music and dance troupe from China's Yunnan Province, Sheng said.
Detailed information can be accessed via the Deaflympics' official Web site at http://www.2009deaflympics.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open little changed

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened little changed Thursday, moving down 5.26 points at 6,887.88 on a turnover of NT$4.15 billion (US$127.67 million).
The weighted price index lost 55.94 points, or 0.80 percent, to close at 6,893.14 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan Science Park reports increasing turnover

TEXT.P: The accumulated turnover of the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) in March and April reached NT$65.31 billion (US$2 billion) -- a growth of 46.41 percent compared with the January-February figure, the park administration said in a statement Wednesday.
The March-April turnover, however, posted a drop of 37.18 percent from the same period in 2008, the STSP administration said.
Nonetheless, the decline was the smallest for the last six months, which was a sign that the local recession has bottomed out, according to the statement.

The accumulated turnover of the science park, which houses nearly 160 high-tech businesses, in the first four months of the year stood at NT$109.93 billion, which was a 46.07 percent decline from the same period last year, according to the statement.

The STSP is comprised of two separate parks -- the Tainan Science Park and the Kaohsiung Science Park. The industries operating in the parks include integrated circuits, optoelectronics, biotechnology, telecommunications, precision machinery, as well as computer and peripherals.

The STSP administration said that the optoelectronics industry generated a turnover of NT$44.33 billion in the March-April period, recording the largest two-month growth among all the business sectors in the park.
The STSP administration attributed the growth to increasing demand from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young fairy pittas begin to explore outside world

TEXT.P: A bird watcher urged bird lovers Wednesday to seize the opportunity to watch the beautiful fairy pittas and their young, which will leave Taiwan soon on their annual migration route.
Lai Wen-ho said he has been looking forward for nearly a month to seeing the young birds leaving their nests with their parents and that "the time has finally come."
Lai said that he had been waiting quietly in some low bushes near the birds' habitat since early Wednesday morning to take photographs of them.
Taitung, with its wide expanses of lush greenery, has been attractive to the birds, which migrate every year between March and June to Taiwan to breed and leave again after June, he said.
He noted that the birds usually chose damp bushes that are free of pesticides and other pollutants as their breeding ground.
The birds migrate not to escape harsh winters, but rather to take advantage of the long spring and summer days and to feed on the many insects in the higher latitudes, Lai said.

This bird species, with an estimated population of 2,500 to 10,000, is classified as "vulnerable" by BirdLife International. This infers that the population is rapidly declining due to deforestation in its breeding areas, principally for agriculture and logging purposes. The problem is compounded by trappers who catch the birds to sell them in the pet industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer than 200,000 babies born in 2008: interior ministry

TEXT.P: The number of babies born in Taiwan in 2008 was under 200,000, which was a new low, statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) showed.
According to the MOI statistics, 196,486 babies were born in 2008, which was a drop of 3.5 percent from 2007.
Some 9.6 percent of the mothers of newborns were non-Taiwan nationals, down 0.6 percentage points from 2007, which represented a sharp decline to fewer than 20,000.
Most of the women who gave birth in Taiwan last year were between 25 and 34 years old, which was an indication that the age of women giving birth was rising, with the average being 29.8 years.

The average age of mothers in Taiwan from Southeast Asian countries was 26.7, for those from China, Hong Kong and Macau it was 28.7 years, and for Taiwanese women it was 30.1, according to the statistics.
Along with a growing trend toward people getting married later in life, the average age of women having their first babies also rose to 28.9 years in 2008 from 26.4 in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.602 at 10 a.m. Thursday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.097 from Wednesday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seattle's bright sunshine reflects solid Taiwan-U.S. ties: AIT head
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, June 3 (CNA) 06/04/09 10:42:17 (By Huang Jui-hung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Raymond Burghardt said Tuesday at a welcome dinner for President Ma Ying-jeou that the bright sunshine in Seattle that day symbolized the good relations between Taiwan and the United States.

The top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties made the remarks at a dinner with Taiwanese expatriates to welcome President Ma, who arrived in Seattle earlier in the day for an overnight transit stop en route home after a three-country Central American diplomatic tour.

Burghardt said in his opening remarks that Seattle has a reputation for frequent rain and that it was rainy during his two previous visits to the city. However, on his third visit Tuesday, it was sunny in Seattle, which was a reflection of Taiwan-U.S. relations, he added.
Traveling at the head of a large delegation, Ma arrived in Seattle Tuesday evening from El Salvador where he attended the inaugural of new Salvadoran President Mauricio Funes.
Hundreds of Taiwanese expatriates turned out to greet Ma at the hotel where he was staying.

Shortly after his arrival, Ma met separately with Burghardt and Seattle Mayor Greg Nickel for wide-ranging talks. He also had telephone conversations with Washington State Governor Christine Gregoire and several U.S. congressmen, including Lincoln Diaz-Balart, co-chair of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus.
Ma was quoted as having assured the American politicians that progress in relations across the Taiwan Strait will have a positive impact on Taiwan-U.S. ties.
He also expressed hopes that U.S. congressional members will support his proposal that the U.S. grant visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists.
Ma, who also visited Belize and Guatemala during his just-concluded Central America tour, is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday evening.
