DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 4, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2001: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicks off at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Check-in loophole lets woman into secure airport areas for 40 hours

TEXT.P: A check-in loophole at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport allowed a female Canadian citizen of Chinese descent to breach security and enter off-limits areas of the terminal for more than 40 hours earlier this week, the Aviation Police Office said Thursday.

The woman, identified only by her surname Chen, came to Taiwan late last month on a backpacking trip, but was deported Tuesday evening via a Hong Kong-bound flight after she was found to have used someone else's boarding pass to enter a controlled area the previous day.
"The Canadian passport holder had apparently violated our immigration law," said an aviation police officer who spoke on condition of anonymity.

According to the officer, initial investigations found that Chen was scheduled to depart Taiwan June 16, but went to the airport June 1 and managed to secure a boarding pass under someone else's name at a self-service check-in kiosk installed by an air carrier at the airport.
She then entered a controlled area and strolled around there, then later in the day checked into the airport's transit hotel for an overnight stay.
Chen was not located until after the air carrier discovered that she had not boarded the plane and reported the case to the aviation police.
Acting on the report, aviation police officers launched a large-scale search of the airport terminal and finally located her.

Chen was asked to explain how she had managed to acquire a boarding pass and proceed past the immigration counter. From her account of her actions, aviation police authorities learned of a loophole in the air carrier's self-service online check-in system.
According to the police officer, the automated system mistakenly Chen a boarding pass in the name of a passenger whose surname was the same as hers and who was to have taken the same flight as her.
As the carrier's self-service check-in system was not linked to its traditional check-in counter, two boarding passes were issued in the same passenger's name.

It was not clear why the woman moved up her scheduled departure date from June 16 to June 1 or why she entered the off-limits area after securing a boarding pass bearing someone else's name, the police officer said.

As to why she was able to remain in a controlled area for over 40 hours, the officer said most likely the immigration officers did not carefully check whether the name on the boarding pass was exactly the same as that of the passport holder.

According to the police officer, the self-service check-in systems are usually developed by the air carriers themselves. At the moment, Taiwan's China Airlines, Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways and U.S.-based United Airlines have such kiosks at the airport to allow e-ticket passengers bound for visa-free destinations to bypass the check-in counters and obtain a boarding pass in as little as 30 seconds.

Major local airlines associations have been informed of the incident, the officer said, adding that the Aviation Police Office has suggested that air carriers take steps to plug any possible loopholes in their online and self- service check-in systems.
Airport immigration officials also said they will tighten checks from now on to ensure that the names on boarding passes match those on the passports presented by passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan working holiday program draws flood of applications

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that applications have been flooding in for a reciprocal working holiday program between Taiwan and Japan that came into effect June 1.

Peter Tsai, secretary-general of the MOFA's Association of East Asian Relations, said at a regular press briefing that the Taipei-based Interchange Association, which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, received some 700 applications in the first three days since the program started.
The Japanese agency is expecting another 400-500 applications before it fills the first 1,000 openings at the end of the first phase of the process June 5, he added.
Taiwan and Japan are each offering 2,000 places in the first year of the program and will increase the number over the next few years depending on the popularity of the program.

The Interchange Association has 1,000 slots for Taiwanese applicants in each of the periods June 1-5 and Nov. 2-6, while Taiwan's representative offices in Japan are accepting applications from Japanese youth year round.
"I'm glad to see that so many young people are interested in taking this opportunity to go to Japan and to fulfill their dreams, using their own funds," Tsai said.
"I would like to remind them be on good behavior and pay attention to their actions while in Japan because that would be the best basis on which to ask Japan for more openings next year, " he added.

Under the program that opened June 1, Taiwanese aged 18-30 can apply to the Interchange Association for a working holiday visa that will allow them to work on a short-term basis while visiting Japan. The visas are valid for one year.
Japan was the third country to sign a working holiday agreement with Taiwan, with the other two being Australia and New Zealand in 2004.

Meanwhile, despite the flood of applications in Taiwan for the working holiday visas, the country's representative offices in Tokyo, Yokohama, Fukuoka, Osaka, Okinawa in Japan received a total of only five applications during the first three days, Tsai said.

However, the Foreign Ministry did not expect that there would many applications initially from Japan, as that country follows a different academic year, he added. Most Japanese students are likely still too busy with school work to be making any travel plans, as the first semester of the academic year started April 1, he said.
Also, Japanese students have the option of applying anytime during the year, while Taiwanese applicants have to meet the deadlines within the two designated periods, he added.

Tsai encouraged Japanese students to apply for the working holiday program, saying that many local universities, social groups, Japanese language schools and companies in Taiwan have all expressed interest in offering them jobs.

Asked when Taiwan's new representative office in Sapporo will officially begin operation, Tsai said that the ministry is working very hard toward the scheduled opening this summer, but it will depend on the administrative procedures.

As to whether former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to visit Taiwan this year, Tsai said that as much as the MOFA wants Abe to visit, his trip will depend on the date for the election of Japan's House of Representatives, which might fall in July or August.
If Abe makes the visit, he will be the fourth former Japanese prime minister to do so, with the other three being Nobusuke Kishi, Takeo Fukuda and Yoshiro Mori.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF to study feasibility of auctioning unclaimed shopping vouchers

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Thursday it will consider whether to auction the unclaimed shopping vouchers that were issued by the government earlier this year to stimulate domestic spending.
Hwang Ding-fang, director-general of the MOF's National Treasury Agency, made the remarks in a question-and-answer session at a legislative committee meeting.

Legislator Lu Shiow-yen of the ruling Kuomintang asked what the government is planning to do with the unclaimed shopping vouchers, noting that when the collection date expired at the end of April there were still around 130,000 sets of unclaimed vouchers.
Hwang said the appropriated sum of NT$500 million for these shopping vouchers will be returned to the national treasury, while the vouchers themselves will be destroyed in accordance with the law.

However, Lu mentioned the suggestion raised by some people that the vouchers should be auctioned because it would be "a pity" to destroy them, and pointed out that it had cost Central Engraving and Printing Plant around NT$10 to print each set.
Lu said this would also save the cost of destroying the vouchers, and the proceeds of the auction could be paid into the national coffers or used to take care of the underprivileged.
Hwang responded that the suggestion was a very "creative" one, although "it lacked a legal basis."
He promised to study the feasibility of the suggestion in collaboration with the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The NT$85.7 billion consumption voucher program was one of the measures the government initiated to prop up the sagging economy, and many businesses launched special promotions to encourage consumers to spend the vouchers at their stores.

All Taiwanese citizens -- with the exception of those living abroad without identity cards, household registration or residency rights -- and their foreign spouses were eligible to each receive NT$3,600 in vouchers.
Under the regulations, the vouchers must be exchanged for goods or services by Sept. 30, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges China to face up to Tiananmen massacre history

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called on China Thursday to face up to the history of the Tiananmen Square massacre, in a written statement issued to mark the 20th anniversary of the tragedy.
The military crackdown took place June 4, 1989 following months of pro-democracy demonstrations in and near Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

It remains unclear how many people were actually killed or injured, but some estimates put the fatalities at hundreds and others at thousands. The figure published by the Chinese government was 241 dead, including soldiers, and 7,000 wounded.

Ma said that while violent conflicts between governments and civilians were not uncommon in the history of China and other countries, the hatred and fear that result from such conflicts do not automatically fade with time.
"In any such conflict, it is the government that exercises public authority and therefore bears responsibility for critically examining its actions," Ma said.
According to Ma, it is essential to face up honestly to the history of unfortunate events and deal with the bereaved families with sympathy in order to prevent a repetition of similar tragedies.

In this regard, the efforts made by Taiwan over the past two decades to redress the miscarriage of justice in the 228 incident of 1947 and during a subsequent 38-year period of martial law hold positive lessons for not only Taiwan but also other countries around the world, the president said.
He noted that in the last 10 years, China has been paying greater attention to human rights than before.

Beijing's signing of the international Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1988, its ratification of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights in 2001, and its publication of the national human rights action plan in April this year all demonstrate that Beijing is now more willing to directly address the issue, Ma said.
He said such changes, which coincide with Taiwan's transformation from authoritarianism to a full-fledged democracy, are very gratifying.

According to Ma, with relations between Taiwan and China beginning to warm following 60 years of military conflicts and political confrontation, the two sides should end their arms race and diplomatic contention and instead compete to improve their respective rules of law and human rights records to create a free and democratic future for generations yet to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT invites local chefs to join U.S. food competition

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) invited professional and amateur Taiwanese chefs Thursday to participate in a food competition to showcase their creativity and skills using ingredients from the United States.

"The AIT's Agricultural Trade Office (ATO) , in cooperation with the Western United States Agricultural Trade Association (WUSATA) and the Formosa Chef's Association, is pleased to announce a 'U.S. Food Unlimited Creativity 2009' competition for both established chefs and aspiring artisans to demonstrate their skills using the highest quality American ingredients from the Western United States," the AIT stated in a press release.

According to the AIT, the first round of the competition will be held June 6 at Chung Hwa University in two divisions -- one for professional chefs over the age of 23 and the other for younger contestants.
Applicants are required to submit a photo of themselves and the recipes for the dishes they intend to prepare, the AIT said.
So far, the organizers have already received 60 applications, it added.

Eight two-person teams from each division will be selected for the preliminary competitions, and two teams from each division will go through to the finals, which will be held on June 26 at the American Kitchen at the Taipei International Food Show.

Competitors will be required to prepare an appetizer and an entree using ingredients from WUSATA member states, such as beef, natural pork, Alaskan spot pawns and black cod, the AIT said. The teams will receive extra points if they use other U.S.-made ingredients, including premium sauces, tortilla shells, potato products, natural salt, and other products that will be on display at the food fair.
WUSATA will sponsor a visit by Doug Fisher, a celebrity chef from Washington State, to give demonstrations at the American Kitchen and to serve as a judge in the finals of the competition.
Winners will be given the opportunity to demonstrate their recipes on a television cooking show or participate in Asia's first Culinary Cup 2009 in Thailand, the AIT said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister opposes plan to build tobacco plant in Miaoli

TEXT.P: Amid a row over a British company's plans to build a tobacco plant in a Miaoli township, Taiwan's Health Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Thursday that his agency is basically opposed to the project.
Yeh, minister of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) , made the remarks while fielding questions on the issue from lawmakers at a legislative committee meeting.
He said although the DOH is not the agency in charge of the matter, in principle it is opposed to the tobacco plant construction plan because it goes counter to global anti-smoking trends.
The negative complications, such as public health and pollution problems, could outweigh the plant's job creation benefits, the minister said.

The non-profit, anti-smoking John Tung Foundation voiced its objection a day earlier to the plan by the Britain-based Imperial Tobacco Company Ltd. to build a tobacco plant in northern Taiwan Miaoli County's Chunan township,

The foundation criticized the local government for allowing the company to do so despite strong public disapproval and called for the watchdog arm of the government, the Control Yuan, to conduct an investigation of the issue.
"The project is against international norms and could seriously tarnish Taiwan's international image," a foundation spokesman said.
The Miaoli county government announced recently that it has approved a project submitted by Imperial Tobacco to erect a plant at the Kuanyuan technology park in Chunan.
Blanchi Cheng, a board member of the Tobacco Institute of the Republic of China, argued Wednesday that as a legal investment, the plan could also help to boost local economic development.
The tobacco plant would be the company's first in Southeast Asia and would serve as a base from which to explore other markets in the region.
The tobacco plant is reportedly projected to create some 250 job opportunities in Miaoli.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tiananmen student leader vows to try again to return to China

TEXT.P: Leading Tiananmen political dissident Wu'er Kaixi, who tried in vain to enter Macau in hopes of going to China to see his aging parents, said after he was forced to return to Taiwan Thursday that his attempts to go home will not cease.

Wu'er Kaixi, now Taiwan citizen, said upon arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport around 3 p.m. that he had been detained at the Macau airport since Wednesday evening when immigration officials refused to let him enter.
He spent the night at the Macau customs office and was put aboard a flight for Taiwan around noon Thursday.

Wu'er Kaixi, one of the most well-known leaders of the 1989 pro-democracy student movement in Beijing and No. 2 on China's most wanted list of student leaders after its bloody crackdown against demonstrators on June 4, 1989, said that since he is a fugitive to Beijing, he chose Wednesday to turn himself in at China's liaison office in Macau.
But he was rejected by Chinese-ruled Macau, a former Portuguese colony which returned to Chinese sovereignty in 1999.
"Is China a 'big country' with confidence by ousting me irrationally when I tried to turn myself in? " Wu'er Kaixi asked Beijing when he arrived at Taoyuan airport and was interviewed by reporters.

He asked President Ma Ying-jeou, who has adopted a China-friendly policy since taking office a year ago: "Is now the time for him, as president of the Republic of China, to speak favorably for China?"
He also asked the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to take advantage of the dialogue platform it has with the Communist Party of China (CPC) and to do him a favor by asking Beijing to let him go home.
Noting that he had not returned to Beijing and seen his family for 20 years, he said "my homecoming effort will not cease as long as I live."

Wu'er Kaixi, who fled to the United States after the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, has been living in Taiwan for years, working as the manager of an overseas investment company's Taiwan office. He is married to his Taiwanese schoolmate from the Dominican University in California.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president returns to work after lung surgery

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew returned to work Thursday, after an absence of two weeks during which he had surgery for lung cancer, the Presidential Office said.
Siew began the day by listening to briefings by top officials and then proceeded with his usual routine, the office said in a statement.
Siew, who was diagnosed with lung adenocarcinoma, underwent surgery at Taipei Veterans General Hospital (TVGH) May 20 to have the tumors removed.
He was discharged from the hospital Wednesday after recuperation and is expected to have targeted therapy to fight recurrence of the cancer.

Asked by lawmakers in a legislative committee meeting Thursday about Siew's condition, TVGH superintendent Lin Fang-yue said the vice president's surgery was very successful because the tumors were discovered in the early stages.
Siew has recovered very well from the surgery and his physical strength will return fully later on, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice prices stable despite spring damage: agriculture council

TEXT.P: Rice prices will remain stable despite damage to the crop's spring harvest in eastern Taiwan, said an official at the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) Thursday.

According to Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, only about 39 percent of the crop in about 1,590 hectares of rice paddies in the country's eastern regions was affected by the low temperatures in early April.

This means that while about 620 hectares of rice paddies had no harvest, there has been no dent in the country's overall rice production or prices, Yu said. A total of 154,000 hectares of farm lands across the country were devoted to rice cultivation this spring, he added.
Rice grown in eastern Taiwan enjoys widespread popularity among consumers because of its high quality.

Meanwhile, Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen was planning to lead a group of local rice farmers to protest in front of the COA to ask for higher government subsidies in compensation for the losses they suffered because they had no crop this spring.
The COA has decided to pay these farmers compensation of NT$20,000 (US$617) per hectare of rice paddy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Broad dialogue on China relations needed in Taiwan: AIT director

TEXT.P: The top U.S. envoy to Taiwan said Thursday that it is important for Taiwan to have internal broad-based dialogue that would be as close as possible to consensus, as relations between Taipei and Beijing move into more difficult stages.

"The democracy which we celebrate today in Taiwan is an important tool and force for managing this very difficult process, " said Stephen Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), at a farewell luncheon hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
Young is scheduled to leave office later this year.

According to Young, while Taiwan and China have "spoken in fairly similar terms" over the past year and made significant process on improving bilateral economic and trade relations, it will take a long time for the two sides to deal with issues that involve Taiwan's international space and political and security difficulties.

"Sort of like those computer games that our kids play and maybe some of us play, where if you do well in the first stage, it gets harder as you go up to another stage," Young said, adding that the Ma Ying-jeou administration understands that.
Despite the fact that Taiwan-China relations face many challenges ahead, Young said, they have gotten off to a good start and the outlook is optimistic.

Since it took office last May, the Ma administration has been exploring ways to enhance cooperation and reduce tensions with China through the acceleration of cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges, including direct air, sea and postal links.

As to U.S.-Taiwan relations, Young said bilateral cooperation is good at all levels because there is a dynamism that is based on the U.S. and Taiwan's constant search for new approaches to advance their mutual interests.

In an oblique reference to Taiwan's partial ban on U.S. beef imports, Young said that if Taiwan works to achieve progress on some of the bilateral agricultural issues, this might lead to visits by more senior level U.S. officials to the country.
Taiwan has not had any high level visits by Washington officials over the past few years.
However, Young said he is not distressed by the cooperation channels that exist between Taiwan and the U.S., given the informal nature of the bilateral relations.
"The trick is that over the 30 years since formal relations were terminated, we have built up a pretty good mechanism for getting our two sides to engage where it counts and when it counts," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet passes amendment to Physician Act

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed an amendment to the Physician Act Thursday in a bid to require Taiwanese students who have obtained medical education in foreign countries to pass qualification tests and internships first before being allowed to take part in the licensing examination.
The amended draft bill will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for screening.

The main revision of the law stipulates that Taiwanese students who study in medical schools overseas and who want to return to Taiwan to take part in the state licensing examination must first pass qualification tests by the Ministry of Education and complete successfully a certain period of internship at medical institutions designated by the Department of Health (DOH).

Currently, the act allows Taiwanese students who have attended medical schools in several countries, including the United States, Japan, Europe, Canada, Singapore, Australia and New Zealand, to skip qualification tests before taking part in national licensing examinations.
But the DOH said that the number of Taiwanese students who have studied in foreign medical schools and returned to Taiwan to take part in licensing exams have increased yearly.

"Given the differences in the education systems and medical care standards of various regions and countries, the waiving of the qualification tests is no longer appropriate, " a DOH official said recently, adding that it could even disrupt the local medical service environment.
The DOH had therefore proposed the draft amendment that passed the Cabinet Thursday.
The Cabinet's move came on the heels of a large demonstration by local medical students over the weekend.

Tens of hundreds of medical students took to the streets Sunday to demand that the government revise the law to address the problem that the standard of medical schools in foreign countries may vary from one to another.

They asked that Taiwanese students who graduate from foreign medical schools should have their credentials accredited and that they complete their internships before being allowed to join the licence examination.

They were especially dissatisfied with those students who have studied in medical schools in Poland, saying that in recent years local agents have made big profits by recruiting Taiwan's senior high school students to study in the East European country, where the tuition is cheaper and the entrance threshold is lower.

According to the statistics given by the Federation of Medical Students in Taiwan, of the estimated 100,000 senior high school students who took part in the college entrance examination last year, only around 700, or 0.7 percent, could get into the medical schools here.
In Taiwan, a physician is a lucrative and respected profession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese most satisfied with recycling efforts: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall performance in environmental protection was scored at 58.85 points by the public, with the field of resources recycling receiving the most satisfaction, according to results of a survey released Wednesday.

Nearly half - 48.6 percent - of the respondents think environmental ecology protection is more important than economic development, while some 26.2 percent believe the opposite, according to the survey conducted by the Taiwan Public Opinion Studies Association via telephone May 22-24.
Respondents of the survey also listed air quality, water quality, and soil and water conservation as the country's priorities.
Survey respondents gave Taiwan 61.29 points on environmental quality and 65.09 points on diversity of environmental resources, with the full score being 100 points.

In addition to public opinion on the government's performance in environmental protection, the survey also includes 14 questions to test the public's level of environmental awareness, covering fields of knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, and practices. The average score of the test is 62.5 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's stock prices plunge

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 107.08 points, or 1.55 percent, to close at 6,786.06.
Influenced by the dropping of Asian markets, the local bourse opened lower at 6,887.88 and fluctuated between 6,907.87 and 6,716.33 during the trading session.
A total of 5.7 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$159.01 billion (US$4.86 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 2.3 percent. Textile stocks declined 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were down 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 1.5 percent, cement stocks decreased 1.2 percent, and foodstuff issues declined 0.9 percent.
Two other major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up 2.8 percent and paper and pulp issues advancing 1.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,368 to 820, with 111 stocks remaining unchanged.

Altogether, the three major institutional investors made net sales of NT$16.38 billion on shares -- NT$11.47 billion by foreign investors, NT$1.87 billion by investment trust firms and NT$3.04 billion by securities firms.
Analysts said that investors became cautious due to mounting profit-taking pressure on the market triggered by the market's failure to take a firm stand over the 7,000-threshold.
The market was mainly supported by small-and medium-sized shares, with shares in blue-ray hard disc and cell phone component industries rising significantly, according to the analysts.

To mark the 20th anniversary of the violent suppression of the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square by Chinese authorities, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on June 3 released a statement calling on China to reflect on the incident and grow from it.

She urged that China openly examine "the darker events of its past" and give a public accounting of "those killed, detained or missing, both to learn and to heal."

DOC.HEADLINE: Hepatitis B screening of migrant workers should continue: DOH

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan said Thursday that Taiwan should retain its policy of screening new migrant workers for hepatitis B, given that most of them work in close contact with their employers.
Yeh was referring to a recent decision by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) to revoke the policy of testing migrant workers for hepatitis B upon their arrival in Taiwan.

Speaking at a committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan, Yeh said the long existing regulation should be maintained, as it would help to prevent transmission of the liver disease from migrant workers -- over half of whom are caregivers -- to the wider population.
The tests would also help to monitor the health of foreign workers, he added.

"I will seek to further understand the CDC's decision and will make an announcement on the matter in two weeks time, "Yeh said, in response to a question by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hou Tsai-feng.
Around 170,000 of the 300,000 foreign workers in Taiwan are caregivers who come into close contact with their Taiwan employers and families, Hou said.
Hepatitis B screening of foreign workers upon entry to the country would help prevent transmission of the disease, if workers test positive, she added.
Describing the CDC's recent decision as debatable, she said the cancellation of hepatitis B testing of new migrant workers would put the country's citizens at risk of contracting the disease.

Also fielding questions at the legislative session, CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao said the center decided to revoke the screening regulation based on the consideration that the disease could only be transmitted via blood or body fluids.

Furthermore, hepatitis B is usually transmitted only by means of blood transfusions, sexual intercourse, or the sharing of hypodermic needles, Chou said, adding that it can also be passed directly from mother to newborn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records two more cases of swine flu

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported two more cases of swine flu Thursday, bringing to 16 the total number of influenza A(H1N1) infections recorded in the country.

The two infections, confirmed late Wednesday, were both imported cases involving Taiwanese citizens who returned recently from New York, said Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) spokesman Shih Wen-yi.
Shih said of the 16 cases recorded so far, all were mild infections, and only one was indigenous.

Noting that most of the cases were Taiwanese students studying in the United States, Shih predicted that the number of influenza A (HIN1) infections in Taiwan will continue to increase in the coming months as more students return home for the summer vacation.
One of the new cases was a 25-year-old graduate student of a university in New York City who returned to Taiwan May 29 via Hong Kong, according to the CECC.
The man came down with a fever and cough June 1 and sought medical treatment after calling the Centers for Disease Control's 1922 hotline.

The patient wore a mask throughout his journey from the United States to Taiwan and stayed home most of the time after he landed, the CECC said, adding that the patient's fever dropped after he was treated.
Family members who had had close contact with him were given preventive medication and asked to monitor their own health, the CECC said.
As the patient did not begin to experience flu symptoms until 48 hours after his arrival, the other passengers on the flight to Taiwan have not been listed as being at risk, according to the CECC.
The other case was a 24-year-old businessman based in New York City who returned to Taiwan June 1 via Hong Kong.
The patient developed muscle pains and a fever May 31 and he sought treatment June 2 after his return to Taiwan, as the symptoms persisted, the CECC said.
The CECC said the 55 passengers who shared the flight with him from Hong Kong to Taiwan are being traced.

On the New York to Hong Kong leg of the trip, the man took Cathay Pacific flight CX841 on May 31 and was assigned to seat number 32H. The passengers who sat next to him, and those three rows in front of and behind him are urged to contact health authorities immediately, as they are considered at high risk of being infected, the CECC said.
As of Wednesday, 66 countries had officially reported 19,273 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 117 deaths, according to the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese interested in buying rice straw crafts from Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Japanese businessman instructed Taiwanese craftswomen in making rice straw crafts in southern Taiwan Thursday, in an effort to prepare them for producing such products to export to Japan at the end of this year.

Sake Miyamura, who is in charge of a Japanese company selling decorative items, spent Thursday at an elementary school in Tainan County's Houbi township teaching a group of women to make traditional Japanese crafts with rice straw.
Houbi township is known for making crafts with rush grass. It developed the skill of making artifacts with rice stems in recent years.

Miyamura said Japanese people consume a lot of straw-woven crafts for use by both households and shrines during New Year holidays. New straw-woven products are bought to replace the old ones every year, so the consumption amount in Japan is huge, Miyamura added.
He said although many Japanese business people imported crafts of rush grass from China, he prefers selling products made of rice straw because rice stems better represent Japan's traditional spirit.
According to Miyamura, few people in Japan can make straw-woven products and the labor cost is relatively expensive in his country.
With the help of a Taiwan-Japan exchange association in Tainan County, Miyamura has visited the county three times this year to learn about cooperation opportunities.
Those who learned from Miyamura's instructions Thursday were senior craftswomen with excellent skills in making artifacts for local markets.

But they learned that it was not easy to make even a basic braided knot of about 50 cm, one of four ornaments they practiced making Thursday, because making Japanese artifacts requires strict standards.

Miyamura said his company will need 10,000 braided knots, and he expressed the hope that these craftswomen will improve their skills soon so he will be able to buy rice straw products from Taiwan at the end of this year.
Miyamura arrived in Taiwan Monday, and will return to Ishikawa Prefecture, where his company is based, Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply secure until late July: Cabinet

TEXT.P: Normal water supply for household, agriculture irrigation and industrial use in Taiwan's northern, central and southern regions is expected to last until late July, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.

"The government has readied itself for the worst scenario in case of a dry spree should seasonal plum rain not come, " Su said. "In the worst case scenario, water for irrigation purposes would be stopped and water for industrial use limited."

Su made the remarks following the weekly Cabinet meeting presided over by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who was briefed by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) about nationwide water supply situations at a time when a possible water shortage was looming.
According to MOEA officials, water supply in these regions is expected to remain stable as of the end of July despite the fact that rainfalls in May averaged lower than levels recorded in past years.
As new wet fronts are approaching and if rain pours in the coming days, normal water supply is likely to be in place through August, MOEA officials added.

Liu instructed that the Central Emergency Operation Center, a unit set up under the Executive Yuan to handle natural disasters which was originally to be dismissed, should keep on operating, citing his grave concern over the approaching typhoon season.
The premier also demanded the center review its operations more intensively and more frequently.

Meanwhile, the Shihmen Reservoir in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, has taken in more water thanks to approaching fronts. It has seen the level of its water conservation increase to 223.1 meters as of noon, providing a temporary relief to neighboring counties longing for rain.
It had rained 30 millimeters in the reservoir's water catchment area Thursday morning. Officials of the MOEA's water resources agency said more rain will fall in the area in the days ahead.
However, officials warned that the possibility of a water shortage remains for southern Taiwan as it has not rained much over the past day.

According to Central Weather Bureau forecast, the current plum rain fronts will bring more rain in northern and central Taiwan Thursday and Friday. The fronts would move toward the south from Thursday afternoon.

If no sufficient rain falls in the coming period from August to October, a serious water shortage might surge in southern Taiwan's Chiayi and Tainan counties -- an important rice and fruit producing area, warned officials of local farmers' associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign wives open take-out restaurant in Chiayi

TEXT.P: Eight foreign wives of Taiwanese men in southern Chiayi County jointly opened a take-out restaurant Thursday, and had their wares touted by Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen.

The eight women -- from Vietnam, Indonesia, Cambodia and China -- opened the restaurant to sell mainly boxed lunches and meals of typical Southeast Asian fare and set up their business with assistance from the county government's Department of Social Affairs.
To celebrate the restaurant's grand opening, the women staged a catwalk show in which they displayed the traditional national costumes of their respective countries.

They also introduced various ingredients used in preparing some traditional Southeast Asian foods, including lemongrass, coconut milk and prahoc -- fermented fish paste that is unique to Cambodian cuisine.
After the show, they offered 50 boxed lunches to their neighbors at a complimentary price of NT$1 per box, touted by Chen. The lunchboxes sold out within minutes.
Chen said the take-out restaurant represents a new partnership between the local government and the county's "new residents."
He noted that there are about 13,000 foreign spouses in Chiayi County, making the county the third-largest administrative area in Taiwan in terms of the number of foreign spouses living there.
To improve services to these foreign spouses, he went on, the county government has since 2006 operated a foreign spouse service center, providing various kinds of help and advice.

He added that over the past four years, the county government has helped 1,351 foreign spouses to obtain motorcycle licenses, helped 29 to find jobs, helped three to acquire licenses to work as professional nurses, and helped eight to obtain licenses to work as chefs in Chinese restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan railway to be repaired by October: Forestry Bureau

TEXT.P: A project to repair the famous alpine railway in the Alishan Forest Recreation Park in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County will be completed by the end of October, the Forestry Bureau's Chiayi office said Thursday.

The Chiayi Forestry District Office made the remarks amid reports that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan was extremely angry at the long delay in repairing the historic narrow gauge railway in one of Taiwan's most popular tourist spots, which offers views of spectacular sunrises, ancient trees and mountain scenery.

Liu was quoted as having said at a meeting with officials in charge of transport and tourist service affairs Wednesday that the procrastination over the railway repair project is "intolerable and unacceptable" and that the delay has seriously tarnished the government's image.

The Chan Nao Liao section at the 23.5 kilometer mark of the 71.4 km railway has been closed since last October due to a series of natural calamities, including typhoons and torrential rain. Nearly 70 meters of the railway's road base has collapsed into a ravine, leaving a section of the railway hanging in midair.

As a result, passengers at present have to disembark from the train at Chan Nao Liao Station and carry their luggage up a 500-meter mountain trail before getting on another train at the other end of the damaged section.
This has drawn vociferous complaints from tourists over the past few months, with not only local travelers but also tourists from China and other countries voiced disappointment over the service.

"It is outrageous that this world-class alpine railway suffers such a world- class inconvenience, " Liu said at Wednesday's meeting. "At this critical juncture of promoting our tourism industry, we cannot sit idly by any longer."
Liu reportedly has ordered Minister-without-Portfolio Ovid Tzeng to coordinate a quick solution to the issue.

The Alishan railway, one of just three remaining alpine railways in the world, is managed by the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture. The premier has expressed hope that the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will take over the management of the railway and that the Forest Bureau will be responsible only for the railway's soil and water conservation and flood-prevention work.

The railway has been operated by the Hungtu Alishan International Development Co. -- a private firm -- under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project since June 19, 2008, and Liu was also quoted as having demanded a review of the propriety of such an arrangement.

Yang Hung-chih, a department chief at the Chiayi Forestry District Office, said the delay in repairing the railway is mainly a result of Hungtu's unwillingness to assume a 20 percent share of the cost needed for the repair project.
Under the BOT contract, Hungtu is required to pay for a 20 percent share of the cost of repairs of damage caused by natural disasters.
Hungtu previously insisted that last October's disruption was not caused by natural disasters but rather by flawed soil conservation caused by the Forestry Bureau's negligence.
The bureau then commissioned a professional engineering company to conduct a thorough investigation to determine the cause of the disruption.
The final investigative report, released Wednesday, concludes that the disruption was caused by typhoons and torrential downpours in the region last year and not by Forestry Bureau negligence.
With Hungtu finally having agreed to pay its 20 percent share of the repair costs, Yang said the project will proceed immediately and will be completed by the end of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: President returns after fruitful diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday upon arrival home after his just-concluded Central America diplomatic tour that the trip was very productive and proves the success of his pragmatic diplomatic policy.

Traveling at the head of a large delegation composed of officials, lawmakers, musicians and other artists, Ma returned to Taipei after visiting three of the country's diplomatic allies in the region -- Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador.

Speaking upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Ma said he took the three-country trip as a litmus test of his diplomatic policy, which is characterized by pragmatism, flexibility and a diplomatic truce with China.
"The fruitful results of the tour indicate that our `modus vivendi' diplomatic strategy is effective and productive, " Ma said confidently.
Over the past year, he went on, cross-Taiwan Strait relations have turned from confrontational to reconciliatory, with bilateral exchanges expanding and becoming increasingly open.

As a result, Ma said, the two sides of the strait no longer engage in the diplomatic tug of war that characterized the diplomatic status in previous administrations. "We can now pursue our diplomatic goals in a normal, reasonable and dignified way on a reciprocal basis," he added.
During his visit to El Salvador, Ma attended the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Mauricio Funes and obtained his commitment to continue promoting bilateral ties.
During his visits to Belize and Guatemala, Ma also exchanged views with their top leaders and reaffirmed their determination to continue expanding cooperation in various fields.

On his way to and from Central America, Ma made transit stops in Los Angeles and Seattle, respectively, during which he met with several American congressmen and politicians for wide-ranging talks. He also had phone conversations with several key U.S. political figures to seek their continued support for Taiwan's cause.

Shortly after their return, Ma and first lady Chow Mei-ching paid a visit to Vice President Vincent Siew at the latter's home. Siew was discharged from the hospital the previous day following surgery to remove two malignant tumors from his lungs. He returned to work Thursday, having made a full recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Afghan doctors amazed by Chang Gung surgeons' skills

TEXT.P: An Afghan surgeon suffering from a serious tongue tumor that British and Indian doctors dared not touch recently had it removed in Taiwan, thanks to great skill and extraordinary courage demonstrated by doctors at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
Abdul Hadi Mateen, 58, underwent successful surgery to have tongue vascular anomalies or venous malformations removed and treated, the hospital announced Thursday.

Before the two-stage procedure -- performed by a Chang Gung team led by Dr. Chang Cheng-jen April 27 and May 18 -- Mateen suffered acute pain in the mouth and could hardly close his mouth because of the vascular anomalies, which looked like a cluster of rotten strawberries.
"Now I have a normal mouth and clear throat and bronchus. My life-long pain is gone," a moved Mateen said at a news conference.

Mateen was accompanied by his son, Abdul Karim Mateen, 30, who is a physician. The junior Mateen described their feelings before coming to Taiwan as "hopeless, " and the surgical team's performance as "amazing" and "extraordinary."

Karim said his father had traveled to the United Kingdom and India many times and was told by all the doctors they consulted there that surgery would be fatal and that no-one would dare to perform it, as the tumor was deeply embedded and expanded from the tongue down to the oropharynx and bronchus.

In great despair and hopelessness, Karim said, he sought help on the Internet, where he read a report by Chang on treating tongue vascular anomalies with lasers. He then wrote Chang and arranged to come to Taiwan.

Diagnosing Mateen's tongue -- which was three times larger than normal -- Chang knew through his rich clinical experience that the patient would constantly suffer bleeding from his tongue during day time and breathlessness and choking while he was sleeping.

Chang -- who has treated 1,000-odd venous malformation patients, 20 of which were tongue vascular anomaly cases -- decided to try a complicated technique known as intralesional photocoagulation on Mateen.
"The two parts of the surgical procedure were daunting challenges that could not have been carried out by a single surgeon, " Chang said at the news conference.
"Rebuilding a respiratory tract was also a critical step of the surgery," he said.

He said that during the operations, he realized why the U.K. and Indian surgeons would not do it -- cutting the tumor was deemed simply too dangerous, as massive bleeding would occur as the anomalies were deeply entwined with blood vessels.
"It took us four hours to remove the tumor system, a surgery that usually would take only about half an hour," he said.
The Mateens offered their gratitude to the Chang Gung surgeons, reiterating that the operation was successful beyond their imaginations.
Since Taiwan and Afghanistan maintain no formal diplomatic relations, it took the Mateens months to prepare their travel documents before coming to Taiwan April 23.
So far, Mateen has paid medical bills to the tune of NT$550,000 (US$17,200) -- a little more expensive than similar surgery in India but much cheaper than in the U.K.
Karim said that after his father is discharged from Chang Gung, they would like to try some "city tours" around Taiwan before heading home.
The success of the case is likely to give a boost to the government's recent promotion of medical tourism as means of attracting visitors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior Hong Kong official visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui- lung arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit.

Lam, who is being accompanied on his visit by several other officials, has become the highest-ranking Hong Kong official ever to visit Taiwan since the former British colony reverted to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
Lam, the top Hong Kong official in charge of Taiwan-related affairs, told local reporters that the main purpose of his visit is to promote trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Lam was scheduled to meet Friday with Fu Dong-cheng, vice chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, on measures to boost exchanges and cooperation in the fields of economics, trade and culture.
He was also expected to pay a visit to the Taipei city government that same day for talks with Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Ching-chi on possible cooperative projects between the two cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 5, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese most satisfied with recycling efforts: survey

As of Wednesday, 66 countries had officially reported 19,273 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 117 deaths, according to the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese interested in buying rice straw crafts from Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Japanese businessman instructed Taiwanese craftswomen in making rice straw crafts in southern Taiwan Thursday, in an effort to prepare them for producing such products to export to Japan at the end of this year.

Sake Miyamura, who is in charge of a Japanese company selling decorative items, spent Thursday at an elementary school in Tainan County's Houbi township teaching a group of women to make traditional Japanese crafts with rice straw.
Houbi township is known for making crafts with rush grass. It developed the skill of making artifacts with rice stems in recent years.

Miyamura said Japanese people consume a lot of straw-woven crafts for use by both households and shrines during New Year holidays. New straw-woven products are bought to replace the old ones every year, so the consumption amount in Japan is huge, Miyamura added.
He said although many Japanese business people imported crafts of rush grass from China, he prefers selling products made of rice straw because rice stems better represent Japan's traditional spirit.
According to Miyamura, few people in Japan can make straw-woven products and the labor cost is relatively expensive in his country.
With the help of a Taiwan-Japan exchange association in Tainan County, Miyamura has visited the county three times this year to learn about cooperation opportunities.
Those who learned from Miyamura's instructions Thursday were senior craftswomen with excellent skills in making artifacts for local markets.

But they learned that it was not easy to make even a basic braided knot of about 50 cm, one of four ornaments they practiced making Thursday, because making Japanese artifacts requires strict standards.

Miyamura said his company will need 10,000 braided knots, and he expressed the hope that these craftswomen will improve their skills soon so he will be able to buy rice straw products from Taiwan at the end of this year.
Miyamura arrived in Taiwan Monday, and will return to Ishikawa Prefecture, where his company is based, Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply secure until late July: Cabinet

TEXT.P: Normal water supply for household, agriculture irrigation and industrial use in Taiwan's northern, central and southern regions is expected to last until late July, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.

"The government has readied itself for the worst scenario in case of a dry spree should seasonal plum rain not come, " Su said. "In the worst case scenario, water for irrigation purposes would be stopped and water for industrial use limited."

Su made the remarks following the weekly Cabinet meeting presided over by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who was briefed by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) about nationwide water supply situations at a time when a possible water shortage was looming.
According to MOEA officials, water supply in these regions is expected to remain stable as of the end of July despite the fact that rainfalls in May averaged lower than levels recorded in past years.
As new wet fronts are approaching and if rain pours in the coming days, normal water supply is likely to be in place through August, MOEA officials added.

Liu instructed that the Central Emergency Operation Center, a unit set up under the Executive Yuan to handle natural disasters which was originally to be dismissed, should keep on operating, citing his grave concern over the approaching typhoon season.
The premier also demanded the center review its operations more intensively and more frequently.

Meanwhile, the Shihmen Reservoir in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, has taken in more water thanks to approaching fronts. It has seen the level of its water conservation increase to 223.1 meters as of noon, providing a temporary relief to neighboring counties longing for rain.
It had rained 30 millimeters in the reservoir's water catchment area Thursday morning. Officials of the MOEA's water resources agency said more rain will fall in the area in the days ahead.
However, officials warned that the possibility of a water shortage remains for southern Taiwan as it has not rained much over the past day.

According to Central Weather Bureau forecast, the current plum rain fronts will bring more rain in northern and central Taiwan Thursday and Friday. The fronts would move toward the south from Thursday afternoon.

If no sufficient rain falls in the coming period from August to October, a serious water shortage might surge in southern Taiwan's Chiayi and Tainan counties -- an important rice and fruit producing area, warned officials of local farmers' associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign wives open take-out restaurant in Chiayi

TEXT.P: Eight foreign wives of Taiwanese men in southern Chiayi County jointly opened a take-out restaurant Thursday, and had their wares touted by Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen.

The eight women -- from Vietnam, Indonesia, Cambodia and China -- opened the restaurant to sell mainly boxed lunches and meals of typical Southeast Asian fare and set up their business with assistance from the county government's Department of Social Affairs.
To celebrate the restaurant's grand opening, the women staged a catwalk show in which they displayed the traditional national costumes of their respective countries.

They also introduced various ingredients used in preparing some traditional Southeast Asian foods, including lemongrass, coconut milk and prahoc -- fermented fish paste that is unique to Cambodian cuisine.
After the show, they offered 50 boxed lunches to their neighbors at a complimentary price of NT$1 per box, touted by Chen. The lunchboxes sold out within minutes.
Chen said the take-out restaurant represents a new partnership between the local government and the county's "new residents."
He noted that there are about 13,000 foreign spouses in Chiayi County, making the county the third-largest administrative area in Taiwan in terms of the number of foreign spouses living there.
To improve services to these foreign spouses, he went on, the county government has since 2006 operated a foreign spouse service center, providing various kinds of help and advice.

He added that over the past four years, the county government has helped 1,351 foreign spouses to obtain motorcycle licenses, helped 29 to find jobs, helped three to acquire licenses to work as professional nurses, and helped eight to obtain licenses to work as chefs in Chinese restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alishan railway to be repaired by October: Forestry Bureau

TEXT.P: A project to repair the famous alpine railway in the Alishan Forest Recreation Park in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County will be completed by the end of October, the Forestry Bureau's Chiayi office said Thursday.

The Chiayi Forestry District Office made the remarks amid reports that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan was extremely angry at the long delay in repairing the historic narrow gauge railway in one of Taiwan's most popular tourist spots, which offers views of spectacular sunrises, ancient trees and mountain scenery.

Liu was quoted as having said at a meeting with officials in charge of transport and tourist service affairs Wednesday that the procrastination over the railway repair project is "intolerable and unacceptable" and that the delay has seriously tarnished the government's image.

The Chan Nao Liao section at the 23.5 kilometer mark of the 71.4 km railway has been closed since last October due to a series of natural calamities, including typhoons and torrential rain. Nearly 70 meters of the railway's road base has collapsed into a ravine, leaving a section of the railway hanging in midair.

As a result, passengers at present have to disembark from the train at Chan Nao Liao Station and carry their luggage up a 500-meter mountain trail before getting on another train at the other end of the damaged section.
This has drawn vociferous complaints from tourists over the past few months, with not only local travelers but also tourists from China and other countries voiced disappointment over the service.

"It is outrageous that this world-class alpine railway suffers such a world- class inconvenience, " Liu said at Wednesday's meeting. "At this critical juncture of promoting our tourism industry, we cannot sit idly by any longer."
Liu reportedly has ordered Minister-without-Portfolio Ovid Tzeng to coordinate a quick solution to the issue.

The Alishan railway, one of just three remaining alpine railways in the world, is managed by the Forestry Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture. The premier has expressed hope that the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will take over the management of the railway and that the Forest Bureau will be responsible only for the railway's soil and water conservation and flood-prevention work.

The railway has been operated by the Hungtu Alishan International Development Co. -- a private firm -- under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) project since June 19, 2008, and Liu was also quoted as having demanded a review of the propriety of such an arrangement.

Yang Hung-chih, a department chief at the Chiayi Forestry District Office, said the delay in repairing the railway is mainly a result of Hungtu's unwillingness to assume a 20 percent share of the cost needed for the repair project.
Under the BOT contract, Hungtu is required to pay for a 20 percent share of the cost of repairs of damage caused by natural disasters.
Hungtu previously insisted that last October's disruption was not caused by natural disasters but rather by flawed soil conservation caused by the Forestry Bureau's negligence.
The bureau then commissioned a professional engineering company to conduct a thorough investigation to determine the cause of the disruption.
The final investigative report, released Wednesday, concludes that the disruption was caused by typhoons and torrential downpours in the region last year and not by Forestry Bureau negligence.
With Hungtu finally having agreed to pay its 20 percent share of the repair costs, Yang said the project will proceed immediately and will be completed by the end of October.

DOC.HEADLINE: President returns after fruitful diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday upon arrival home after his just-concluded Central America diplomatic tour that the trip was very productive and proves the success of his pragmatic diplomatic policy.

Traveling at the head of a large delegation composed of officials, lawmakers, musicians and other artists, Ma returned to Taipei after visiting three of the country's diplomatic allies in the region -- Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador.

Speaking upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Ma said he took the three-country trip as a litmus test of his diplomatic policy, which is characterized by pragmatism, flexibility and a diplomatic truce with China.
"The fruitful results of the tour indicate that our `modus vivendi' diplomatic strategy is effective and productive, " Ma said confidently.
Over the past year, he went on, cross-Taiwan Strait relations have turned from confrontational to reconciliatory, with bilateral exchanges expanding and becoming increasingly open.

As a result, Ma said, the two sides of the strait no longer engage in the diplomatic tug of war that characterized the diplomatic status in previous administrations. "We can now pursue our diplomatic goals in a normal, reasonable and dignified way on a reciprocal basis," he added.
During his visit to El Salvador, Ma attended the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Mauricio Funes and obtained his commitment to continue promoting bilateral ties.
During his visits to Belize and Guatemala, Ma also exchanged views with their top leaders and reaffirmed their determination to continue expanding cooperation in various fields.

On his way to and from Central America, Ma made transit stops in Los Angeles and Seattle, respectively, during which he met with several American congressmen and politicians for wide-ranging talks. He also had phone conversations with several key U.S. political figures to seek their continued support for Taiwan's cause.

Shortly after their return, Ma and first lady Chow Mei-ching paid a visit to Vice President Vincent Siew at the latter's home. Siew was discharged from the hospital the previous day following surgery to remove two malignant tumors from his lungs. He returned to work Thursday, having made a full recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Afghan doctors amazed by Chang Gung surgeons' skills

TEXT.P: An Afghan surgeon suffering from a serious tongue tumor that British and Indian doctors dared not touch recently had it removed in Taiwan, thanks to great skill and extraordinary courage demonstrated by doctors at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
Abdul Hadi Mateen, 58, underwent successful surgery to have tongue vascular anomalies or venous malformations removed and treated, the hospital announced Thursday.

Before the two-stage procedure -- performed by a Chang Gung team led by Dr. Chang Cheng-jen April 27 and May 18 -- Mateen suffered acute pain in the mouth and could hardly close his mouth because of the vascular anomalies, which looked like a cluster of rotten strawberries.
"Now I have a normal mouth and clear throat and bronchus. My life-long pain is gone," a moved Mateen said at a news conference.

Mateen was accompanied by his son, Abdul Karim Mateen, 30, who is a physician. The junior Mateen described their feelings before coming to Taiwan as "hopeless, " and the surgical team's performance as "amazing" and "extraordinary."

Karim said his father had traveled to the United Kingdom and India many times and was told by all the doctors they consulted there that surgery would be fatal and that no-one would dare to perform it, as the tumor was deeply embedded and expanded from the tongue down to the oropharynx and bronchus.

In great despair and hopelessness, Karim said, he sought help on the Internet, where he read a report by Chang on treating tongue vascular anomalies with lasers. He then wrote Chang and arranged to come to Taiwan.

Diagnosing Mateen's tongue -- which was three times larger than normal -- Chang knew through his rich clinical experience that the patient would constantly suffer bleeding from his tongue during day time and breathlessness and choking while he was sleeping.

Chang -- who has treated 1,000-odd venous malformation patients, 20 of which were tongue vascular anomaly cases -- decided to try a complicated technique known as intralesional photocoagulation on Mateen.
"The two parts of the surgical procedure were daunting challenges that could not have been carried out by a single surgeon, " Chang said at the news conference.
"Rebuilding a respiratory tract was also a critical step of the surgery," he said.

He said that during the operations, he realized why the U.K. and Indian surgeons would not do it -- cutting the tumor was deemed simply too dangerous, as massive bleeding would occur as the anomalies were deeply entwined with blood vessels.
"It took us four hours to remove the tumor system, a surgery that usually would take only about half an hour," he said.
The Mateens offered their gratitude to the Chang Gung surgeons, reiterating that the operation was successful beyond their imaginations.
Since Taiwan and Afghanistan maintain no formal diplomatic relations, it took the Mateens months to prepare their travel documents before coming to Taiwan April 23.
So far, Mateen has paid medical bills to the tune of NT$550,000 (US$17,200) -- a little more expensive than similar surgery in India but much cheaper than in the U.K.
Karim said that after his father is discharged from Chang Gung, they would like to try some "city tours" around Taiwan before heading home.
The success of the case is likely to give a boost to the government's recent promotion of medical tourism as means of attracting visitors to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior Hong Kong official visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui- lung arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit.

Lam, who is being accompanied on his visit by several other officials, has become the highest-ranking Hong Kong official ever to visit Taiwan since the former British colony reverted to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
Lam, the top Hong Kong official in charge of Taiwan-related affairs, told local reporters that the main purpose of his visit is to promote trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Lam was scheduled to meet Friday with Fu Dong-cheng, vice chairman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, on measures to boost exchanges and cooperation in the fields of economics, trade and culture.
He was also expected to pay a visit to the Taipei city government that same day for talks with Taipei Deputy Mayor Wu Ching-chi on possible cooperative projects between the two cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 5, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday, moving up 39.67 points at 6,825.73 on a turnover of NT$4.08 billion (US$125.16 million).
The weighted price index lost 107.08 points, or 1.55 percent, to close at 6,786.06 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 5, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that in addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expected to open 100 fields to Chinese investment

TEXT.P: The Cabinet decided Thursday to exclude Chinese medicine manufacturing from a tentative list of fields of investment to be opened to Chinese capital, reducing to 100 the total number of fields permitted in the initial stages.
The decision was made at an inter-ministerial meeting coordinated by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Tain-jy to review the provisional list.

The list is still pending finalization by the Cabinet and is expected to be officially published by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) June 20, along with regulations governing such Chinese investment in Taiwan.

Fan Liang-tung, executive secretary of the Investment Commission under the MOEA, explained that the Cabinet decided to remove Chinese medicine manufacturing from the list because Chinese medicine manufacturers in Taiwan have expressed opposition to the plan.
The list of permitted areas for Chinese investment includes 64 industries in the manufacturing sector, 25 in the service sector and 11 in the infrastructure sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor opposes expansion of coal-fired generators

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu expressed vehement opposition Friday to plans by Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) to expand its existing coal-fired generators in her city, saying she does not want the country's major electricity supplier to further pollute the southern port city.

"Kaohsiung City will absolutely not accept Taipower's coal-fired generator expansion plan, which is under screening by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration and pending approval," Chen said.
"Taipower is engaging in technical maneuvers to expand its coal-fired electricity generation at its Dalin plant in the name of renewing its facilities, " Chen went on.

According to officials from the Kaohsiung Department of Environmental Protection, Taipower is planning to remodel the Nos. 1-5 generators at the Dalin plant into four coal-fired generators, which will substantially increase its power generation capacity, while retaining the No. 6 generator, which is a liquefied natural gas (LNG)-fired model.

Noting that Taipower is aiming to generate a much greater volume of electricity to serve the north of the country rather than the south, Chen said Kaohsiung City should not be a victim of Taipower's business maneuvers.
If the Taipower expansion plan is approved, she continued, Kaohsiung City's carbon dioxide emissions will be greatly increased.
"These extra emissions would only be evened out if the entire city were to stop driving cars and motorbikes for four consecutive years, " she claimed.
It is unfair of Taipower to operate the much cleaner LNG-fired generators in other cities and counties around the country while seeking to expand coal-fired generation in Kaohsiung, she argued.
According to a survey conducted in 2005 by the Kaohsiung Department of Environmental Protection, the carbon dioxide emissions of the Dalin plant totaled 6.89 million tons per year.
"The emissions would shoot up to 17.69 million tons per year if the expansion plan is approved and carried out, " department officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will not open fully to Chinese advertising: official

TEXT.P: The government will not fully open local media for Chinese advertising and will in particular maintain its ban on real estate and investment advertisements, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Liu Te-hsun said Thursday.

Liu made the comments after a legislative committee deferred the screening of amendments to regulations governing Chinese advertisements for products and services on the local market due to a boycott by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators, who said permitting such Chinese ads will enable China to manipulate Taiwanese media.
If passed, the amendments will allow Chinese firms to advertise products and services in Taiwanese media without requiring permission from Taiwan's government.

Liu said that MAC has convened at least two supra-ministerial meetings and an initial resolution has been reached that includes the proviso that Chinese product commercials will only be allowed in Taiwanese media if the products being advertised are actually sold in Taiwan.

This means that property ads and investment-soliciting ads by China's central and local governments, as well as ads promoting images of Chinese enterprises and ads for China's official or semi-official activities, are not permitted, according to Liu.

Liu also claimed that there is "no necessity" for the 8,000 items of Chinese products currently allowed to be sold in Taiwan to be advertised because they already have clear and distinctive product positioning.
