However, he went on, there is a need for Chinese firms to advertise their products and services that are currently not available in Taiwan and are seeking a clear brand image following increasingly frequent exchanges between Taiwan and China, such as law firms, product patent rights, intellectual property rights, and corporate image. He added that there is still room for discussion on whether these types of ads should be allowed.

At present, Chinese advertisers must obtain permission to advertise in Taiwanese media, according to Article 34 of the Statute Governing Relations Between Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
However, until the statute is amended, the government will continue to impose fines on media outlets that carry such illegal ads, Liu noted.

Since 2003, the Ministry of the Interior has issued 20 fines to local media outlets for illegally running real estate advertisements placed by Chinese firms, including one each to the Taipei-based China Times and the Commercial Times in May, according to statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan expects orders worth US$2.2 billion from Chinese buyers

TEXT.P: The members of a Chinese purchase delegation that made a May 31-June 5 visit to Taiwan are expected to place orders worth more than US$2.2 billion, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Thursday.

More than 40 Chinese companies took part in the mission organized by China's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS) , an organization set up by China's Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges.
Most of the participants have won bids to provide products under China's latest economic stimulus measures that encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers.

According to TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang, the buyers had one-on-one sessions with more than 300 Taiwanese suppliers, mainly focusing on home appliances and consumer electronics such as television sets and computers.
The buyers are likely to place orders worth US$827 million by the end of July, while more orders worth a total of US$1.4 billion are expected over the coming year, Wang said.

Meanwhile, TAITRA officials said two more purchase delegations organized by the AETATS are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan between late June and July, with the products targeted including daily necessities, processed food, plastics, petrochemicals, machinery equipment and electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daughter of ex-president faces travel restrictions

TEXT.P: The daughter of former President Chen Shui-bian, Chen Hsing-yu, was listed Friday as an individual requiring to give exit-entrance notification should she wish to leave the country, according to the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

Chen Hsing-yu was indicted Wednesday for giving false testimony during investigations into the ex-first family's alleged corruption and money laundering over the past two years and was listed as a person whose movements in relation to attempted overseas travel should be monitored by prosecutors.

She was the final member of the scandal-embroiled ex-first family to be indicted on corruption and money laundering charges. All 14 of the other people in the family, including former President Chen Shui-bian, his wife Wu Shu-jen, their son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and son-in-law Chao Chien- ming, have been indicted since 2006.
Also indicted Wednesday in same case was Taipei 101 former Chairwoman Diana Chen, for giving false testimony.

According to the prosecutors, she lied about having delivered a check for NT$10 million under the name of a friend, Chen Chin-wen, to Wu Shu-jen's brother Wu Jin-mao in 2004, denying that she made any such delivery.

After being transferred into several overseas bank accounts, the money eventually ended up in a Swiss bank account owned jointly by Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung and his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
Wu Shu-jen was first indicted Nov. 3, 2006 for claiming reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million from her husband's special state affairs funds using invoices she took from other people.

Chen Shui-bian was not indicted at that time because he was protected by presidential immunity, but as soon as he left office in May 2008, he was charged along with his wife and 13 former aides, officials and family members for taking a total of NT$490 million in bribes during his eight years in office.
The money came to light thanks to an international anti-money laundering group that alerted Taiwanese authorities to the ex-first family's overseas bank accounts in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply in southern Taiwan stable until late July

TEXT.P: Recent rains in southern Taiwan have increased the water supply in Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County, ensuring that the water supply in the region will remain stable until at least late July.

Heavy precipitation on Thursday pushed the reservoir's water level to 194.48 meters and boosted the amount of stored water by 3 percent to 140 million cubic meters, Chiu Chi-fang, director of the Tsengwen Reservoir Administration Center, said Friday.
Though the Tsengwen Reservoir supplies some water to households and factories in the area, its main purpose is to meet the irrigation needs of local farms.
Because of Thursday's rainfall, water needed for the second planting of rice in the Tainan and neighboring Chiayi areas, to start June 16, has been secured, Chiu said.

Thursday's rains also provided much needed relief to other parts of the country. More than 200 millimeters of rain accumulated in northern and central Taiwan, and Hualien County on the island's east coast.
The rainfall especially benefited Shihmen and Feitsui reservoirs, northern Taiwan's two main reservoirs.
The Shihmen Reservoir's water level rose to 223.1 meters as of Thursday noon, providing at least temporary relief to neighboring counties that have recently battled water shortages.
As wet fronts are moving toward southern Taiwan, more showers are expected there over the weekend, the Central Weather Bureau forecast.
If southern Taiwan experiences heavy rains in the coming days, the region's water supply is likely to be stable through August, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said.
They warned, however, that the possibility of a water shortage in the region after July remains.
Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday following the weekly Cabinet meeting that "the government has readied itself for the worst case scenario if seasonal plum rains do not show up."
"In the worst case scenario, water for irrigation purposes would be stopped and water for industrial use would be restricted, " he said.

Inadequate rainfall between August and October could result in a serious water shortage in southern Taiwan's Chiayi and Tainan counties -- important vegetable and fruit producing areas -- warned local farmers' associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled psychotherapist wins Love of Lives medal

TEXT.P: A physically challenged American psychotherapist was presented with the 2009 Fervent Global Love of Lives Medal in Taiwan Thursday, in honor of his contribution in encouraging people to cherish and respect life.

Daniel Gottlieb, a psychologist and family therapist in New Jersey, received the award along with other 11 winners. The medal has been awarded annually since being established in 1998 by the Taiwan-based Chou Ta-Kuan Cultural and Education Foundation.
Gottlieb was paralyzed below the neck in a traffic accident 30 years ago while out looking for a gift for his wife for their 10th wedding anniversary. He was 33 at the time.

Full of remorse and unable to accept his condition after the accident, Gottlieb suffered further blows when his wife divorced him and his parents and sister died within the next five years, leaving him no reason to stay alive.

While he was lying in an intensive care unit one night and wishing he would not have to wake up after shutting his eyes, a nurse in grief asked him whether he would counsel her on dealing with the pain and grief she felt after losing a loved one.
Gottlieb listened and helped alleviate her pain, making him realize that he still had the ability to help people and spread love. After that, he resumed his professional practice.
Gottlieb said that although the traffic accident took away the use of his body, he still had the ability to alleviate other's pain as a psychologist.
"Books only taught me psychology superficially. The accident that disabled my limbs taught me to sit quietly and open my heart and listen to the world," he said.
Gottlieb also hosts a radio show on Philadelphia's National Public Radio station and has also written a column for the Philadelphia Inquirer for 10 years.

He has also written a number of books on psychotherapy, including "Voices of Conflict: Voices of Healing, " which is a compilation of some of his columns and observations from his professional experience.

Another of his works, "Letters to Sam, " which has sold 2 million copies in America, was written for his autistic grandson Sam. Gottlieb donated the book's royalties to organizations that treat autism and deal with other children's health issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Railways folding bicycles to go on sale

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) will begin selling folding bicycles on June 9 to mark its 122nd anniversary and promote the government's policy of carbon dioxide emission reduction.

The electric and non-motorized folding bicycles were introduced at an event Friday that presented a wide array of memorabilia in commemoration of the 122nd anniversary of the opening of Taiwan's first rail line.

The electric folding bicycles, the world's first of their kind, are manufactured by a company in southern Taiwan and can be easily folded in one second by pressing a button, said a company representative.
The electric folding bikes come in two sizes --12 inches and 16 inches -- that weigh 21 kilograms and 23 kilograms and carry price tags of NT$19,800 (US$607.36) and NT$26,800, respectively.
Consumers can apply for a subsidy of NT$3,000 when buying one of the eco- friendly bikes, the representative said.
Once folded, the bike can be rolled on its wheels like luggage. The bike's battery can last 30-40 kilometers per charge and requires about two hours of recharging, he added.

As for non-electric folding bikes, there are three different sizes -- 12 inches, 16 inches and 20 inches -- which sell for NT$5,980, NT$8,800, and NT$9,800, respectively. The 12-inch model weighs 12 kg, while the 16-inch and 20-inch bikes weigh 23 kg, according to the company representative.

The bikes can be ordered at train stations around Taiwan from June 9-14. About 40 types of souvenirs will also go on sale as part of the anniversary sale, including oval shaped stainless lunch boxes, commemorative coins, commemorative stamps, TRA antique glass cups, specially designed lunch boxes, train models and i-cash cards.
The bicycles and some of the memorabilia can also be ordered at participating 7-Eleven convenience stores until July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water company asked for incentive program to encourage saving water

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has asked Taiwan Water Corp. to come up with an incentive program that will reduce water consumption, but Taiwan Water's chairman warned that the idea would deepen the company's losses.

Water Resources Agency Director Chen Shen-hsien said Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan has asked the water company to devise discounts that will encourage water conservation, possibly mirroring those offered by Taiwan's power utility to reduce electricity consumption.
The government wants Taiwan Water to submit a plan within one month and have it finalized by October so that it can be implemented starting in November, when the dry season begins, he noted.
In addition to household tap water users, heavy commercial consumers of water will also be offered incentives, including cash rewards, if they succeed in saving water, Chen added.

Taiwan Water Corp. Chairman Liao Tsung-sheng reacted negatively to the proposed plan, however. He said the company was already suffering financial woes even before industrial water consumption declined by 20 percent in the first five months of this year as a result of the global economic downturn.
"Taiwan Water Corp. will suffer a further shortfall of an estimated NT$1.02 billion in revenues a year if new water-saving incentives are put in place," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.010 to close at NT$32.607.
A total of US$687 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.670 and fluctuated between NT$32.517 and NT$32.700.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen residents enjoy top welfare benefits

TEXT.P: Kinmen County, a Taiwan-held outlying island group with a population of around 84,000 that lies off the coast of China's Fujian province, may boast the best welfare benefits of any of Taiwan's cities and counties.
The list of benefits is long and one that residents in other parts of the country may envy.
For a start, Kinmen residents over 65 years old receive a monthly stipend of at least NT$3,000 per month, the same amount given to stay-at-home mothers every month.
Students from kindergarten through junior high school get free lunches at schools, and they also don't pay for tuition and miscellaneous fees.

Then there is free public transportation on buses or boats. Families receive subsidies from the county government for having a child, and cervical cancer vaccinations given to female students in senior high or vocation schools are also paid for by the county.

A series of new benefits for students was added this year. Students from kindergarten though junior high school now get free fresh milk, and local high school or college students receive education and transportation subsidies.
College students can receive up to NT$10,000 in subsidies and NT$4,000 in transportation vouchers during a school year.
Even students from Taiwan proper who study in Kinmen schools are covered by the generous benefits.
These many benefits are financed by the success of Kinmen Kaoliang Corp., which is widely known for its strong liquor made of fermented sorghum that has long served as the county's cash cow.

Controlled by the county government, the company posted sales of NT$12.2 billion in 2008, the highest since its inception in 1953 and 8.04 percent higher than in 2007. Pre-tax profit was NT$4.78 billion, also a new record.

Although the company increased its production capacity to 24.71 million liters last year, it still has been unable to keep pace with growing demand, but that has not stopped the county from making the liquor part of its package of benefits.

For years, it has sold kaoliang at a discount during Chinese New Year, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival, and because of the good quality of the liquor, residents can easily earn themselves a"red envelope" of between NT$2,000 and NT$3,000 by reselling it.

A liquor voucher plan was also introduced this year to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou, a battle fought over Kinmen in the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Civil War in 1949.

Under the plan, each Kinmen resident is being presented by Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc., with vouchers worth NT$3,600 on Tomb Sweeping Day, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival this year, which can be used to buy the company's products at local retail outlets.

With these many benefits, it may not be surprising then that Kinmen County recorded the fastest population growth of any city or county, with its current population far outpacing the 76,491 people living there in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop slightly on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Finishing lower for the fourth consecutive session, Taiwan's share prices edged down slightly Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 18.96 points, or 0.27 percent, to close at 6,767.10.
Following Wall Street's gains overnight, the local bourse opened at 6,825.73 and shot to the day's high of 6,829.66, before dropping to a low of 6,743.15.
A total of 4.59 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$121.80 billion (US$3.74 billion), the lowest volume since May.
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up 0.8 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks dropping the most at 1.9 percent. Textile shares fell 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals issues shed 1.2 percent, cement issues lost 1.1 percent, paper and pulp stocks dropped 1 percent, and banking and financial shares lost 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,110 to 968, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$2.78 billion in shares.
One analyst said the market is likely test the 6,800-point level because of its failure to take a firm stand over the 7,000-threshold and maintain market turnover above NT$160 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teachers, military personnel banned from going on strike

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment into law Friday to ban military personnel as well as faculty and workers in educational institutions from going on strike.

The amendment to the Settlement of Labor Disputes Law also stipulates that labor unions of public utility companies, hospitals, banking institutions and insurance firms are not allowed to stage strikes unless labor and management have worked out measures to maintain basic services during strike action.
Labor unions of the telecommunications business sector could go on strike only after they guarantee that basic services will be secured during strikes, according to the amendment.
Local governments can ban or restrict strike actions when a major disaster hits which needs intervention by public offices, the amendment stipulates.

It also stipulates that supervisory agencies in the central government are obliged to financially support the establishment of labor funds in different sectors to protect the laborers' rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City holds exhibition on new uses for recycled materials

TEXT.P: Taipei City's Department of Environmental Protection marked World Environment Day Friday by opening an exhibition that showcased creative ways to turn recycled flags and banners into beautiful garments and home decorations.

"Sometimes trash can become gold simply by using your creativity, which is also the spirit of this exhibition, " said Deputy Mayor Lin Chien-yuan at a news conference co-hosted by the Recycle Creative Association.

Lin said it is meaningful to celebrate the day by educating the public on recycling resources and making something useful out of them because environmental protection should start at the community level and among the younger generation, he added.
Lian Yuan-lin, chairwomen of the Recycle Creative Association, said on the same occasion that it is important to think about how things can be reused before casting them away.
You can actually find aesthetics in discarded materials, which can become new resources if you put them in the right place, " she said.

Lian designed six garments made of election flags and advertising banners that were modeled at the press conference by six female Taipei City councilors -- Lin Yi-hua, Hsu Shu-hwa, Wu Si-yao, Wang Hung-wei, Wang Chih-ping and Chieh Mei-sha.
According to Lian, each election produces tens of thousands of tons of cloth flags, and they are a good material not only for clothes but also for shopping bags and other products.

The exhibition, which will run through June 8, features booths teaching citizens to turn recycled materials such as compact discs, tin cans and banners into decorative items that can add a touch of style to their homes.

Established by the United Nations General Assembly in 1972 to mark the opening of the Stockholm Conference on the Human Environment, World Environment Day is celebrated annually on June 5 to stimulate worldwide awareness of the environment and enhance attention and action.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit record high in May

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a record high of US$312.64 billion at the end of May, an increase of US$7.983 billion over the April figure, the country's central bank reported Friday.
The central bank said the increase was mainly due to growing returns on its investments.

The appreciation of the euro, the British pound and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar also contributed to the increase as foreign exchange reserves denominated in these currencies were worth more in U.S. dollar terms, according to the bank.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rank fourth in the world, trailing only China (US$1.95 trillion as of the end of March, the latest figure available) , Japan (US$983.2 billion as of the end of April), and Russia (US$353.8 billion as of May).
India, with US$250.2 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of May 22, and South Korea, with US$225.8 billion in reserves, followed behind Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's wholesale price index (WPI) fell 13.45 percent in May from a year ago to 99.59, the biggest single-month contraction ever.

The sharp decline resulted mainly from lower international prices for agricultural commodities and industrial raw materials compared to the same period last year, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.
The consumer price index (CPI) fell 0.08 percent in May compared to a year earlier but rose 0.42 percent month-on-month, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China's medical groups forge cooperation ties

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Nongovernmental Hospitals and Clinics Association (NHCA) signed a contract with a Chinese medical care management consultant company Friday in hopes that the company will promote Taiwan's medical services in China and help lure Chinese patients to the island for treatment.

The cooperation with the Guardian Healthcare Co. Ltd., a subsidiary company of the Beijing-based Harvest Medical Investment and Operation Group, was built to promote medical exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, said Wu Yen-ming, the chief executive of the NHCA's Taiwan Task Force for Medical Travel.
Under the cooperation program, Guardian Healthcare will help publicize Taiwanese medical clinics and hospitals on the mainland and refer Chinese patients to Taiwan for medical treatment, Wu noted.

According to the association, Guardian Healthcare serves mainly Chinese people and Taiwanese business people operating in China with health care management and patient referral services. The association has been contracted by Taiwan's Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to carry out its medical services globalisation project, aimed at promoting Taiwan's medical treatment services in the international market.

Taiwan is eager to develop medical tourism, much as Singapore and Thailand have done, by offering its relatively cheaper medical care to people in developed countries and quality services to well-off people in developing countries who cannot find the level of expertise in their own country.

Wu from the association said they have decided to focus on China as the major source of clients for Taiwanese medical services. However, there are barriers blocking mainlanders from coming to Taiwan for medical care, he said.

Taiwan opened the doors on Aug. 1, 2007 for Chinese people to come to the island to receive medical treatment, but only allow those who need living donor organ transplants, maxillofacial reconstruction, artificial insemination, joint replacement, and cardiovascular invasive treatment.
Local hospital operators said China is supposed to be the closest market for Taiwan's medical treatment services after the two sides launched first-ever regular direct transport services.
They said the government should lift current restrictions prohibiting a larger number of Chinese to come to Taiwan for treatment.
Statistics show the current number of Chinese patients coming to Taiwan for medical care is small.

According to Department of Health statistics, the number of Chinese patients who applied for permission from the Mainland Affairs Council to come to Taiwan for medical treatment has never surpassed 100 a year since the second half of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous children's choir from Pingtung to perform in Europe

TEXT.P: An indigenous children's choir from the southern county of Pingtung is scheduled to depart Sunday for Europe, where they will present ancient songs of the Paiwan tribe to their audience.

The tour, which will take the team to Belgium, Luxembourg, France and Germany, is organized with the co-sponsorship of the Teco Technology Foundation. It will mark the first overseas performance by the 20-member choir from the Tai Wu Elementary School, said school principal Jean Yen-hui.

Jean said all the songs to be sung by the choir are traditional tunes passed down from generation to generation within the Paiwan tribe. The younger generation in the tribe are becoming increasingly unfamiliar with the songs due to a cultural crisis experienced by all indigenous tribes in Taiwan, Jean said.

Due to previous periods of oppression of aborigines and continuing pressures to assimilate into mainstream society, fewer young aborigines in Taiwan can speak their native language or sing their tribe's songs.
The songs were taught to students after the school recorded the singing demonstrated by Paiwan elders, Jean said.
According to Camake Valaule, a school teacher who serves as the choir's instructor, such faithfulness to tradition has distinguished the choir from others.
The choir's cause "to sing one's own songs" obtained the support of many, and eventually won it the rare opportunity to perform in Europe, Camake said.

Although the choir was not officially established until 2006, the singing by children from the small, mountainous school of less than 50 students won fame as early as 2003 when one of them obtained the first prize in a national indigenous singing contest.
Over the past few years, the school's singing group has received numerous invitations to perform in various areas around the country, and their songs have also been included in some music recordings.

With the assistance of the Teco Technology Foundation, the choir has since 2007 received NT$200,000 (US$6,154) per year in corporate sponsorships, which helps relieve its financial difficulty, Jean said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian canoe polo championship to take place in eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The annual Asian Canoe Polo Championship will take place in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan from June 12-14, with Taiwan's men determined to grab their fourth consecutive title, the event organizer said Friday.
Canoe polo is a competitive ball sport played by two teams, each with five players in their own kayaks on a defined water area.

According to Chang Chih-man, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Canoe Association, Taiwan will compete with teams from Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, and Iran in men's women's and under-21 categories.
Japan and Iran are expected to provide the toughest competition to Taiwan, which holds ambitions of winning the three titles up for grabs, Chang said.

Taiwan's teams trained in Germany earlier this year in preparation for the Asian championships and the World Games, which will take place in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in July. Canoe polo is one of the more than 30 events on the World Games schedule.
The sport has elements of polo, basketball, handball, soccer, and canoeing, but has relatively flexible standards when it comes to physical contact, making the sport fun to watch, Chang said.
The canoe polo event drew more than 20,000 spectators at the previous World Games held in Duisburg, Germany, four years ago, according to Chang.

The Swiss-based International Canoe Federation, which is the umbrella organization of all national canoe organizations worldwide, has sent staff members to Asia and Africa to promote canoe polo, which is most popular in Europe, Chang said.

The Hualien County government estimated that the event, which will host 400 people, including athletes, coaches, and their families, is expected to inject about NT$10 million into the county's economy,

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice farmers want more subsidies for spring damage to crops

TEXT.P: Hundreds of rice farmers from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties protested Friday in front of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture's (COA) office, demanding it pay more subsidies for the damage done to their crops by cold weather.
Angry farmers, led by Kuomintang Legislator Fu Kun-chi, almost pulled down the COA's gate while demanding to meet with COA Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung over the issue.
Chen Wen-teh, director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, met the farmers on behalf of the chairman, who was away to observe a military exercise.

Fu said the spring harvest in more than 2,000 hectares of rice paddies in Hualien County was hit hard by low temperatures in early April, and asked that the COA subsidize NT$16,000 (US$490) to farmers for each hectare of farmland that had no harvest to help offset their losses.

The subsidy is twice the level that the COA plans to give to the farmers. If farmers are not planning to reap their crop even it is not fully destroyed, they will get an additional NT$12,000 in subsidy for each hectare of land. Altogether, farmers can get NT$20,000 in compensation for each hectare of fruitless paddy.
Hualien and Taitung farmers are extremely dissatisfied with the COA's offers, which they said are much lower than their production costs and will leave them penniless.
A farmer surnamed Huang said he earned only NT$20,000 in the spring harvest after deducting production costs.
"I was not even able to pay my children's school tuition with what I gained," Huang said.

Earlier the same day, Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen, leading a dozen Taitung farmers, met COA Deputy Minister Huang Yu-tsai over the same issue. Kuang argued that the COA should pay NT$45,000 per hectare in compensation to the affected farmers.
Huang promised to give the farmers' a response by next Monday.

Despite damage to the crops' spring harvest in eastern Taiwan, COA officials said Thursday that rice prices will remain stable, because the damaged crops' impact on the country's overall rice production is limited.
Rice grown in eastern Taiwan enjoys widespread popularity among consumers because of its high quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic recession encourages healthier lifestyles, survey shows

TEXT.P: The economic recession has triggered changes in office workers' lifestyles by forcing them to reduce their late-night social activities, a survey targeting young and middle-aged workers has found.
The survey was conducted by the Havo Preventive Medicine Institute to understand changes in lifestyles among local office workers over the past six months.

The results of the survey, released Thursday, found that office workers have been more willing to participate in family activities and live a relatively healthier lifestyle since the recession hit, but they also continue to show disdain for exercise.

The survey also showed that a growing number of people are choosing to stay at home after work. Some 40 percent of respondents said they are spending more time at home, mostly to surf the Internet and sleep, while neglecting to exercise.
As for changes in eating habits in Taiwan, 20 percent to 30 percent of respondents say they eat more fruits and vegetables, eat out less and cook more at home.

One-quarter of respondents said they are cutting back on unhealthy behavior, such as staying up late or going out. One in eight respondents who normally drink said they are drinking less and one in 15 smokers said they are smoking less, the survey found.
The survey was conducted from April 15 to May 15. The male-female ratio was 40/60 and the average age of respondents was 36.7. The survey received 865 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, HK will set up offices to promote bilateral cooperation

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong have agreed to set up quasi-official organizations that will represent them in bilateral talks on economic and cultural issues and possibly lead to meetings between top officials from their two governments.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng and visiting Hong Kong Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui-lung jointly made the announcement at a press conference held following their talks in Taipei Friday.

During the talks, Fu said the two parties agreed that Taiwan will act to establish a Taiwan-Hong Kong economic and cultural cooperation promotion committee while Hong Kong will open a Hong Kong-Taiwan trade cooperation commission under its Trade Development Council.
The planned organizations will focus on promoting trade, investment, travel and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong, he said.

Fu further noted that high-ranking officials from Taiwan and Hong Kong will also participate in activities organized by the two new organizations to strengthen normal interactions between the Taiwan and Hong Kong governments.
Such interaction was not possible until relations between Taiwan and China improved after Ma Ying-jeou became Taiwan's president in May 2008, Fu said.
Lam said the planned institutes are expected to be established in the short term and hold their first meeting soon after.

As to what rank of official will attend the future meetings under the new cooperation platform, both Fu and Lam said the issue still needs to be discussed, but Fu said "the official level will be lifted higher gradually."

Asked about when Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tseng, who has previously expressed interest in visiting Taiwan, will come here, Lam replied that he believes the planned organizations will help create an environment enabling the head of Hong Kong's government to visit Taiwan in the future.

Lam arrived in Taiwan Thursday for the talks with Fu at the MAC's invitation. His arrival marks the first official visit to Taiwan by a policy-making-level official of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people on the dole continues to decline: CLA

TEXT.P: The number of people collecting unemployment benefits declined in May for the second consecutive month, according to initial statistics released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Friday.
The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants also fell in May for the third consecutive month, the statistics showed.
"All these figures indicate that domestic joblessness triggered by a global economic recession is easing, " the CLA said in a statement.

According to CLA tallies, the number of applications for unemployment benefits jumped to 124,460 in March at the height of the recession and approved payouts exceeded NT$2.13 billion (US$65.34 million).

The number of applications declined to 114,800 in April, with total payouts of NT$1.92 billion, and the number further slid by about 10,000 in May to roughly 105,000, with total payouts of around NT$1.56 billion.

The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants has also slid since peaking at 35,208 in February this year. The number fell to 28,043 in March, to 21,300 in April and then to about 16,000 in May.
Meanwhile, the number of those on unpaid leave also dropped to 147,021 at the end of May from a high of 238,975 in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Italy holds national day celebration

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Italian Economic Trade and Cultural Promotion Office (IETCPO) held a national day reception Friday to celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the foundation of the Italian Republic.
Mario Palma, head of the IETCPO, praised the good relations between Taiwan and Italy at the function, attended by members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.

Noting that both sides have frequent exchanges and work closely in economic, trade, cultural and art sectors, Palma specifically mentioned the friendship between parliaments in the two countries and said that suchparliamentary diplomacycreated a significant political-institutional framework conducive to the sound development of bilateral relations.

The top Italian envoy to Taiwan was referring to the visit in February to Italy of Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, and the visit to Taiwan of two Italian parliamentary delegations.

Economic cooperation between Taiwan and Italy is also close, Palma said, citing as examples the renewal of the air transport agreement between Rome and Taipei and the contract to build the first phase of the Taipei Metro Circular Line, which was awarded to Italian transportation technology firm Ansaldo STS.

Even in such dire economic situations, (we should) always be able to detect and value whatever positive signals and trends which could then lead in the foreseeable future to a new expansion in our overall relationship,Palma said.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lin said at the function that cultural exchanges between Italy and Taiwan have been impressive, with over 200,000 Taiwanese tourists visiting Italy every year, a number Lin believed would continue to rise in the future.
Also, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Italy reached over US$4 billion in 2008, making Italy Taiwan's fourth largest trading partner in the European Union, Lin said.
He said he was confident that through joint efforts substantive bilateral relations between the two countries will be further strengthened in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO extends deadline for Taiwan to submit GPA document

TEXT.P: A World Trade Organization committee has agreed to a request by Taiwan to extend by one month until July 9 the submission of its instrument of accession to the WTO Government Procurement Agreement (GPA), a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Friday.
Economics Vice Minister John Deng said Taiwan requested the extension for "administrative" reasons, mainly involving a scheduling snafu.
The WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved Taiwan's application to enter the GPA on Dec. 9, 2008.

Taiwan was required to send its instrument of accession to the WTO Secretariat within six months to complete the accession procedure. The agreement then enters into force on the 30th day following the date of its accession.

Taiwan's Legislative Yuan endorsed the decision to admit Taiwan into the GPA on May 15. According to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official, there was then a two-week waiting period for the legislature to express dissent before President Ma Ying-jeou could sign the instrument of accession as required.
Because the two-week period had not expired by the time Ma departed on a trip to Central America, the government asked for an extension, the MOFA official said.
The GPA was adopted by the WTO in 1981 with the purpose of opening up as much government procurement as possible to international competition.

It was designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.
There are currently 40 members of the GPA, most of them developed countries.
Following the accession, Taiwan's government procurement market will be open to other GPA members, and vice versa, based on the principles of reciprocity and national treatment.
The WTO Secretariat estimates the government procurement market in GPA signatory countries totals US$5.55 trillion per year, which will now be open to Taiwanese companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has not relaxed combat preparedness: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his administration has not relaxed efforts to strengthen the military's arsenal and combat preparedness despite its progress in improving relations with China.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of overseas offspring of cadets of the now-defunct Whampoa Military Academy. The academy, based in southern China's Guangzhou, officially opening in 1924 and served as the training ground for the Kuomintang's most prestigious commanders until it lost the Chinese civil war in 1949.

Ma, who just returned to Taipei the previous day after a three-leg Central America diplomatic tour, told his guests that he got up at 4 a.m. Friday to participate in a virtual military exercise simulating an attempted invasion of Taiwan by China.
In addition to military personnel, senior government officials also took part in the computerized war games to test coordination between the military and the executive branch.
Ma said the war games were part of Taiwan's efforts to beef up its defense capabilities and combat preparedness.

As China still deploys missiles targeting Taiwan, Ma said, Taiwan, while continuing to improve relations with China, cannot afford to relax in enhancing its crisis management and honing its defense strategies and tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 6, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects orders worth US$2.2 billion from Chinese buyers

TEXT.P: The members of a Chinese purchase delegation that made a May 31-June 5 visit to Taiwan are expected to place orders worth more than US$2.2 billion, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Thursday.

More than 40 Chinese companies took part in the mission organized by China's Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits (AETATS) , an organization set up by China's Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges.
Most of the participants have won bids to provide products under China's latest economic stimulus measures that encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers.

According to TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang, the buyers had one-on-one sessions with more than 300 Taiwanese suppliers, mainly focusing on home appliances and consumer electronics such as television sets and computers.
The buyers are likely to place orders worth US$827 million by the end of July, while more orders worth a total of US$1.4 billion are expected over the coming year, Wang said.

Meanwhile, TAITRA officials said two more purchase delegations organized by the AETATS are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan between late June and July, with the products targeted including daily necessities, processed food, plastics, petrochemicals, machinery equipment and electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daughter of ex-president faces travel restrictions

TEXT.P: The daughter of former President Chen Shui-bian, Chen Hsing-yu, was listed Friday as an individual requiring to give exit-entrance notification should she wish to leave the country, according to the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

Chen Hsing-yu was indicted Wednesday for giving false testimony during investigations into the ex-first family's alleged corruption and money laundering over the past two years and was listed as a person whose movements in relation to attempted overseas travel should be monitored by prosecutors.

She was the final member of the scandal-embroiled ex-first family to be indicted on corruption and money laundering charges. All 14 of the other people in the family, including former President Chen Shui-bian, his wife Wu Shu-jen, their son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and son-in-law Chao Chien- ming, have been indicted since 2006.
Also indicted Wednesday in same case was Taipei 101 former Chairwoman Diana Chen, for giving false testimony.

According to the prosecutors, she lied about having delivered a check for NT$10 million under the name of a friend, Chen Chin-wen, to Wu Shu-jen's brother Wu Jin-mao in 2004, denying that she made any such delivery.

After being transferred into several overseas bank accounts, the money eventually ended up in a Swiss bank account owned jointly by Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung and his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
Wu Shu-jen was first indicted Nov. 3, 2006 for claiming reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million from her husband's special state affairs funds using invoices she took from other people.

Chen Shui-bian was not indicted at that time because he was protected by presidential immunity, but as soon as he left office in May 2008, he was charged along with his wife and 13 former aides, officials and family members for taking a total of NT$490 million in bribes during his eight years in office.
The money came to light thanks to an international anti-money laundering group that alerted Taiwanese authorities to the ex-first family's overseas bank accounts in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply in southern Taiwan stable until late July

TEXT.P: Recent rains in southern Taiwan have increased the water supply in Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County, ensuring that the water supply in the region will remain stable until at least late July.

Heavy precipitation on Thursday pushed the reservoir's water level to 194.48 meters and boosted the amount of stored water by 3 percent to 140 million cubic meters, Chiu Chi-fang, director of the Tsengwen Reservoir Administration Center, said Friday.
Though the Tsengwen Reservoir supplies some water to households and factories in the area, its main purpose is to meet the irrigation needs of local farms.
Because of Thursday's rainfall, water needed for the second planting of rice in the Tainan and neighboring Chiayi areas, to start June 16, has been secured, Chiu said.

Thursday's rains also provided much needed relief to other parts of the country. More than 200 millimeters of rain accumulated in northern and central Taiwan, and Hualien County on the island's east coast.
The rainfall especially benefited Shihmen and Feitsui reservoirs, northern Taiwan's two main reservoirs.
The Shihmen Reservoir's water level rose to 223.1 meters as of Thursday noon, providing at least temporary relief to neighboring counties that have recently battled water shortages.
As wet fronts are moving toward southern Taiwan, more showers are expected there over the weekend, the Central Weather Bureau forecast.
If southern Taiwan experiences heavy rains in the coming days, the region's water supply is likely to be stable through August, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said.
They warned, however, that the possibility of a water shortage in the region after July remains.
Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday following the weekly Cabinet meeting that "the government has readied itself for the worst case scenario if seasonal plum rains do not show up."
"In the worst case scenario, water for irrigation purposes would be stopped and water for industrial use would be restricted, " he said.

Inadequate rainfall between August and October could result in a serious water shortage in southern Taiwan's Chiayi and Tainan counties -- important vegetable and fruit producing areas -- warned local farmers' associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled psychotherapist wins Love of Lives medal

TEXT.P: A physically challenged American psychotherapist was presented with the 2009 Fervent Global Love of Lives Medal in Taiwan Thursday, in honor of his contribution in encouraging people to cherish and respect life.

Daniel Gottlieb, a psychologist and family therapist in New Jersey, received the award along with other 11 winners. The medal has been awarded annually since being established in 1998 by the Taiwan-based Chou Ta-Kuan Cultural and Education Foundation.
Gottlieb was paralyzed below the neck in a traffic accident 30 years ago while out looking for a gift for his wife for their 10th wedding anniversary. He was 33 at the time.

Full of remorse and unable to accept his condition after the accident, Gottlieb suffered further blows when his wife divorced him and his parents and sister died within the next five years, leaving him no reason to stay alive.

While he was lying in an intensive care unit one night and wishing he would not have to wake up after shutting his eyes, a nurse in grief asked him whether he would counsel her on dealing with the pain and grief she felt after losing a loved one.
Gottlieb listened and helped alleviate her pain, making him realize that he still had the ability to help people and spread love. After that, he resumed his professional practice.
Gottlieb said that although the traffic accident took away the use of his body, he still had the ability to alleviate other's pain as a psychologist.
"Books only taught me psychology superficially. The accident that disabled my limbs taught me to sit quietly and open my heart and listen to the world," he said.
Gottlieb also hosts a radio show on Philadelphia's National Public Radio station and has also written a column for the Philadelphia Inquirer for 10 years.

He has also written a number of books on psychotherapy, including "Voices of Conflict: Voices of Healing, " which is a compilation of some of his columns and observations from his professional experience.

Another of his works, "Letters to Sam, " which has sold 2 million copies in America, was written for his autistic grandson Sam. Gottlieb donated the book's royalties to organizations that treat autism and deal with other children's health issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Railways folding bicycles to go on sale

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) will begin selling folding bicycles on June 9 to mark its 122nd anniversary and promote the government's policy of carbon dioxide emission reduction.

The electric and non-motorized folding bicycles were introduced at an event Friday that presented a wide array of memorabilia in commemoration of the 122nd anniversary of the opening of Taiwan's first rail line.

The electric folding bicycles, the world's first of their kind, are manufactured by a company in southern Taiwan and can be easily folded in one second by pressing a button, said a company representative.
The electric folding bikes come in two sizes --12 inches and 16 inches -- that weigh 21 kilograms and 23 kilograms and carry price tags of NT$19,800 (US$607.36) and NT$26,800, respectively.
Consumers can apply for a subsidy of NT$3,000 when buying one of the eco- friendly bikes, the representative said.
Once folded, the bike can be rolled on its wheels like luggage. The bike's battery can last 30-40 kilometers per charge and requires about two hours of recharging, he added.

As for non-electric folding bikes, there are three different sizes -- 12 inches, 16 inches and 20 inches -- which sell for NT$5,980, NT$8,800, and NT$9,800, respectively. The 12-inch model weighs 12 kg, while the 16-inch and 20-inch bikes weigh 23 kg, according to the company representative.

The bikes can be ordered at train stations around Taiwan from June 9-14. About 40 types of souvenirs will also go on sale as part of the anniversary sale, including oval shaped stainless lunch boxes, commemorative coins, commemorative stamps, TRA antique glass cups, specially designed lunch boxes, train models and i-cash cards.
The bicycles and some of the memorabilia can also be ordered at participating 7-Eleven convenience stores until July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water company asked for incentive program to encourage saving water

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has asked Taiwan Water Corp. to come up with an incentive program that will reduce water consumption, but Taiwan Water's chairman warned that the idea would deepen the company's losses.

Water Resources Agency Director Chen Shen-hsien said Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan has asked the water company to devise discounts that will encourage water conservation, possibly mirroring those offered by Taiwan's power utility to reduce electricity consumption.
The government wants Taiwan Water to submit a plan within one month and have it finalized by October so that it can be implemented starting in November, when the dry season begins, he noted.
In addition to household tap water users, heavy commercial consumers of water will also be offered incentives, including cash rewards, if they succeed in saving water, Chen added.

Taiwan Water Corp. Chairman Liao Tsung-sheng reacted negatively to the proposed plan, however. He said the company was already suffering financial woes even before industrial water consumption declined by 20 percent in the first five months of this year as a result of the global economic downturn.
"Taiwan Water Corp. will suffer a further shortfall of an estimated NT$1.02 billion in revenues a year if new water-saving incentives are put in place," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.010 to close at NT$32.607.
A total of US$687 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.670 and fluctuated between NT$32.517 and NT$32.700.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen residents enjoy top welfare benefits

TEXT.P: Kinmen County, a Taiwan-held outlying island group with a population of around 84,000 that lies off the coast of China's Fujian province, may boast the best welfare benefits of any of Taiwan's cities and counties.
The list of benefits is long and one that residents in other parts of the country may envy.
For a start, Kinmen residents over 65 years old receive a monthly stipend of at least NT$3,000 per month, the same amount given to stay-at-home mothers every month.
Students from kindergarten through junior high school get free lunches at schools, and they also don't pay for tuition and miscellaneous fees.

Then there is free public transportation on buses or boats. Families receive subsidies from the county government for having a child, and cervical cancer vaccinations given to female students in senior high or vocation schools are also paid for by the county.

A series of new benefits for students was added this year. Students from kindergarten though junior high school now get free fresh milk, and local high school or college students receive education and transportation subsidies.
College students can receive up to NT$10,000 in subsidies and NT$4,000 in transportation vouchers during a school year.
Even students from Taiwan proper who study in Kinmen schools are covered by the generous benefits.
These many benefits are financed by the success of Kinmen Kaoliang Corp., which is widely known for its strong liquor made of fermented sorghum that has long served as the county's cash cow.

Controlled by the county government, the company posted sales of NT$12.2 billion in 2008, the highest since its inception in 1953 and 8.04 percent higher than in 2007. Pre-tax profit was NT$4.78 billion, also a new record.

Although the company increased its production capacity to 24.71 million liters last year, it still has been unable to keep pace with growing demand, but that has not stopped the county from making the liquor part of its package of benefits.

For years, it has sold kaoliang at a discount during Chinese New Year, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival, and because of the good quality of the liquor, residents can easily earn themselves a"red envelope" of between NT$2,000 and NT$3,000 by reselling it.

A liquor voucher plan was also introduced this year to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Battle of Kuningtou, a battle fought over Kinmen in the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Civil War in 1949.

Under the plan, each Kinmen resident is being presented by Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc., with vouchers worth NT$3,600 on Tomb Sweeping Day, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival this year, which can be used to buy the company's products at local retail outlets.

With these many benefits, it may not be surprising then that Kinmen County recorded the fastest population growth of any city or county, with its current population far outpacing the 76,491 people living there in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop slightly on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Finishing lower for the fourth consecutive session, Taiwan's share prices edged down slightly Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 18.96 points, or 0.27 percent, to close at 6,767.10.
Following Wall Street's gains overnight, the local bourse opened at 6,825.73 and shot to the day's high of 6,829.66, before dropping to a low of 6,743.15.
A total of 4.59 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$121.80 billion (US$3.74 billion), the lowest volume since May.
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up 0.8 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks dropping the most at 1.9 percent. Textile shares fell 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals issues shed 1.2 percent, cement issues lost 1.1 percent, paper and pulp stocks dropped 1 percent, and banking and financial shares lost 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,110 to 968, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$2.78 billion in shares.
One analyst said the market is likely test the 6,800-point level because of its failure to take a firm stand over the 7,000-threshold and maintain market turnover above NT$160 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teachers, military personnel banned from going on strike

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment into law Friday to ban military personnel as well as faculty and workers in educational institutions from going on strike.

The amendment to the Settlement of Labor Disputes Law also stipulates that labor unions of public utility companies, hospitals, banking institutions and insurance firms are not allowed to stage strikes unless labor and management have worked out measures to maintain basic services during strike action.
Labor unions of the telecommunications business sector could go on strike only after they guarantee that basic services will be secured during strikes, according to the amendment.
Local governments can ban or restrict strike actions when a major disaster hits which needs intervention by public offices, the amendment stipulates.

It also stipulates that supervisory agencies in the central government are obliged to financially support the establishment of labor funds in different sectors to protect the laborers' rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City holds exhibition on new uses for recycled materials

TEXT.P: Taipei City's Department of Environmental Protection marked World Environment Day Friday by opening an exhibition that showcased creative ways to turn recycled flags and banners into beautiful garments and home decorations.

"Sometimes trash can become gold simply by using your creativity, which is also the spirit of this exhibition, " said Deputy Mayor Lin Chien-yuan at a news conference co-hosted by the Recycle Creative Association.

Lin said it is meaningful to celebrate the day by educating the public on recycling resources and making something useful out of them because environmental protection should start at the community level and among the younger generation, he added.
Lian Yuan-lin, chairwomen of the Recycle Creative Association, said on the same occasion that it is important to think about how things can be reused before casting them away.
You can actually find aesthetics in discarded materials, which can become new resources if you put them in the right place, " she said.

Lian designed six garments made of election flags and advertising banners that were modeled at the press conference by six female Taipei City councilors -- Lin Yi-hua, Hsu Shu-hwa, Wu Si-yao, Wang Hung-wei, Wang Chih-ping and Chieh Mei-sha.
According to Lian, each election produces tens of thousands of tons of cloth flags, and they are a good material not only for clothes but also for shopping bags and other products.

The exhibition, which will run through June 8, features booths teaching citizens to turn recycled materials such as compact discs, tin cans and banners into decorative items that can add a touch of style to their homes.

Established by the United Nations General Assembly in 1972 to mark the opening of the Stockholm Conference on the Human Environment, World Environment Day is celebrated annually on June 5 to stimulate worldwide awareness of the environment and enhance attention and action.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit record high in May

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a record high of US$312.64 billion at the end of May, an increase of US$7.983 billion over the April figure, the country's central bank reported Friday.
The central bank said the increase was mainly due to growing returns on its investments.

The appreciation of the euro, the British pound and other major currencies against the U.S. dollar also contributed to the increase as foreign exchange reserves denominated in these currencies were worth more in U.S. dollar terms, according to the bank.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rank fourth in the world, trailing only China (US$1.95 trillion as of the end of March, the latest figure available) , Japan (US$983.2 billion as of the end of April), and Russia (US$353.8 billion as of May).
India, with US$250.2 billion in foreign exchange reserves as of May 22, and South Korea, with US$225.8 billion in reserves, followed behind Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's wholesale price index (WPI) fell 13.45 percent in May from a year ago to 99.59, the biggest single-month contraction ever.

The sharp decline resulted mainly from lower international prices for agricultural commodities and industrial raw materials compared to the same period last year, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.
The consumer price index (CPI) fell 0.08 percent in May compared to a year earlier but rose 0.42 percent month-on-month, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China's medical groups forge cooperation ties

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Nongovernmental Hospitals and Clinics Association (NHCA) signed a contract with a Chinese medical care management consultant company Friday in hopes that the company will promote Taiwan's medical services in China and help lure Chinese patients to the island for treatment.

The cooperation with the Guardian Healthcare Co. Ltd., a subsidiary company of the Beijing-based Harvest Medical Investment and Operation Group, was built to promote medical exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, said Wu Yen-ming, the chief executive of the NHCA's Taiwan Task Force for Medical Travel.
Under the cooperation program, Guardian Healthcare will help publicize Taiwanese medical clinics and hospitals on the mainland and refer Chinese patients to Taiwan for medical treatment, Wu noted.

According to the association, Guardian Healthcare serves mainly Chinese people and Taiwanese business people operating in China with health care management and patient referral services. The association has been contracted by Taiwan's Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) to carry out its medical services globalisation project, aimed at promoting Taiwan's medical treatment services in the international market.

Taiwan is eager to develop medical tourism, much as Singapore and Thailand have done, by offering its relatively cheaper medical care to people in developed countries and quality services to well-off people in developing countries who cannot find the level of expertise in their own country.

Wu from the association said they have decided to focus on China as the major source of clients for Taiwanese medical services. However, there are barriers blocking mainlanders from coming to Taiwan for medical care, he said.

Taiwan opened the doors on Aug. 1, 2007 for Chinese people to come to the island to receive medical treatment, but only allow those who need living donor organ transplants, maxillofacial reconstruction, artificial insemination, joint replacement, and cardiovascular invasive treatment.
Local hospital operators said China is supposed to be the closest market for Taiwan's medical treatment services after the two sides launched first-ever regular direct transport services.
They said the government should lift current restrictions prohibiting a larger number of Chinese to come to Taiwan for treatment.
Statistics show the current number of Chinese patients coming to Taiwan for medical care is small.

According to Department of Health statistics, the number of Chinese patients who applied for permission from the Mainland Affairs Council to come to Taiwan for medical treatment has never surpassed 100 a year since the second half of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous children's choir from Pingtung to perform in Europe

TEXT.P: An indigenous children's choir from the southern county of Pingtung is scheduled to depart Sunday for Europe, where they will present ancient songs of the Paiwan tribe to their audience.

The tour, which will take the team to Belgium, Luxembourg, France and Germany, is organized with the co-sponsorship of the Teco Technology Foundation. It will mark the first overseas performance by the 20-member choir from the Tai Wu Elementary School, said school principal Jean Yen-hui.

Jean said all the songs to be sung by the choir are traditional tunes passed down from generation to generation within the Paiwan tribe. The younger generation in the tribe are becoming increasingly unfamiliar with the songs due to a cultural crisis experienced by all indigenous tribes in Taiwan, Jean said.

Due to previous periods of oppression of aborigines and continuing pressures to assimilate into mainstream society, fewer young aborigines in Taiwan can speak their native language or sing their tribe's songs.
The songs were taught to students after the school recorded the singing demonstrated by Paiwan elders, Jean said.
According to Camake Valaule, a school teacher who serves as the choir's instructor, such faithfulness to tradition has distinguished the choir from others.
The choir's cause "to sing one's own songs" obtained the support of many, and eventually won it the rare opportunity to perform in Europe, Camake said.

Although the choir was not officially established until 2006, the singing by children from the small, mountainous school of less than 50 students won fame as early as 2003 when one of them obtained the first prize in a national indigenous singing contest.
Over the past few years, the school's singing group has received numerous invitations to perform in various areas around the country, and their songs have also been included in some music recordings.

With the assistance of the Teco Technology Foundation, the choir has since 2007 received NT$200,000 (US$6,154) per year in corporate sponsorships, which helps relieve its financial difficulty, Jean said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian canoe polo championship to take place in eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The annual Asian Canoe Polo Championship will take place in Hualien County in eastern Taiwan from June 12-14, with Taiwan's men determined to grab their fourth consecutive title, the event organizer said Friday.
Canoe polo is a competitive ball sport played by two teams, each with five players in their own kayaks on a defined water area.

According to Chang Chih-man, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Canoe Association, Taiwan will compete with teams from Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, and Iran in men's women's and under-21 categories.
Japan and Iran are expected to provide the toughest competition to Taiwan, which holds ambitions of winning the three titles up for grabs, Chang said.

Taiwan's teams trained in Germany earlier this year in preparation for the Asian championships and the World Games, which will take place in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in July. Canoe polo is one of the more than 30 events on the World Games schedule.
The sport has elements of polo, basketball, handball, soccer, and canoeing, but has relatively flexible standards when it comes to physical contact, making the sport fun to watch, Chang said.
The canoe polo event drew more than 20,000 spectators at the previous World Games held in Duisburg, Germany, four years ago, according to Chang.

The Swiss-based International Canoe Federation, which is the umbrella organization of all national canoe organizations worldwide, has sent staff members to Asia and Africa to promote canoe polo, which is most popular in Europe, Chang said.

The Hualien County government estimated that the event, which will host 400 people, including athletes, coaches, and their families, is expected to inject about NT$10 million into the county's economy,

DOC.HEADLINE: Rice farmers want more subsidies for spring damage to crops

TEXT.P: Hundreds of rice farmers from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties protested Friday in front of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture's (COA) office, demanding it pay more subsidies for the damage done to their crops by cold weather.
Angry farmers, led by Kuomintang Legislator Fu Kun-chi, almost pulled down the COA's gate while demanding to meet with COA Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung over the issue.
Chen Wen-teh, director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency, met the farmers on behalf of the chairman, who was away to observe a military exercise.

Fu said the spring harvest in more than 2,000 hectares of rice paddies in Hualien County was hit hard by low temperatures in early April, and asked that the COA subsidize NT$16,000 (US$490) to farmers for each hectare of farmland that had no harvest to help offset their losses.

The subsidy is twice the level that the COA plans to give to the farmers. If farmers are not planning to reap their crop even it is not fully destroyed, they will get an additional NT$12,000 in subsidy for each hectare of land. Altogether, farmers can get NT$20,000 in compensation for each hectare of fruitless paddy.
Hualien and Taitung farmers are extremely dissatisfied with the COA's offers, which they said are much lower than their production costs and will leave them penniless.
A farmer surnamed Huang said he earned only NT$20,000 in the spring harvest after deducting production costs.
"I was not even able to pay my children's school tuition with what I gained," Huang said.

Earlier the same day, Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen, leading a dozen Taitung farmers, met COA Deputy Minister Huang Yu-tsai over the same issue. Kuang argued that the COA should pay NT$45,000 per hectare in compensation to the affected farmers.
Huang promised to give the farmers' a response by next Monday.

Despite damage to the crops' spring harvest in eastern Taiwan, COA officials said Thursday that rice prices will remain stable, because the damaged crops' impact on the country's overall rice production is limited.
Rice grown in eastern Taiwan enjoys widespread popularity among consumers because of its high quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic recession encourages healthier lifestyles, survey shows

TEXT.P: The economic recession has triggered changes in office workers' lifestyles by forcing them to reduce their late-night social activities, a survey targeting young and middle-aged workers has found.
The survey was conducted by the Havo Preventive Medicine Institute to understand changes in lifestyles among local office workers over the past six months.

The results of the survey, released Thursday, found that office workers have been more willing to participate in family activities and live a relatively healthier lifestyle since the recession hit, but they also continue to show disdain for exercise.

The survey also showed that a growing number of people are choosing to stay at home after work. Some 40 percent of respondents said they are spending more time at home, mostly to surf the Internet and sleep, while neglecting to exercise.
As for changes in eating habits in Taiwan, 20 percent to 30 percent of respondents say they eat more fruits and vegetables, eat out less and cook more at home.

One-quarter of respondents said they are cutting back on unhealthy behavior, such as staying up late or going out. One in eight respondents who normally drink said they are drinking less and one in 15 smokers said they are smoking less, the survey found.
The survey was conducted from April 15 to May 15. The male-female ratio was 40/60 and the average age of respondents was 36.7. The survey received 865 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, HK will set up offices to promote bilateral cooperation

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong have agreed to set up quasi-official organizations that will represent them in bilateral talks on economic and cultural issues and possibly lead to meetings between top officials from their two governments.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng and visiting Hong Kong Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Stephen Lam Sui-lung jointly made the announcement at a press conference held following their talks in Taipei Friday.

During the talks, Fu said the two parties agreed that Taiwan will act to establish a Taiwan-Hong Kong economic and cultural cooperation promotion committee while Hong Kong will open a Hong Kong-Taiwan trade cooperation commission under its Trade Development Council.
The planned organizations will focus on promoting trade, investment, travel and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong, he said.

Fu further noted that high-ranking officials from Taiwan and Hong Kong will also participate in activities organized by the two new organizations to strengthen normal interactions between the Taiwan and Hong Kong governments.
Such interaction was not possible until relations between Taiwan and China improved after Ma Ying-jeou became Taiwan's president in May 2008, Fu said.
Lam said the planned institutes are expected to be established in the short term and hold their first meeting soon after.

As to what rank of official will attend the future meetings under the new cooperation platform, both Fu and Lam said the issue still needs to be discussed, but Fu said "the official level will be lifted higher gradually."

Asked about when Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tseng, who has previously expressed interest in visiting Taiwan, will come here, Lam replied that he believes the planned organizations will help create an environment enabling the head of Hong Kong's government to visit Taiwan in the future.

Lam arrived in Taiwan Thursday for the talks with Fu at the MAC's invitation. His arrival marks the first official visit to Taiwan by a policy-making-level official of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people on the dole continues to decline: CLA

TEXT.P: The number of people collecting unemployment benefits declined in May for the second consecutive month, according to initial statistics released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Friday.
The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants also fell in May for the third consecutive month, the statistics showed.
"All these figures indicate that domestic joblessness triggered by a global economic recession is easing, " the CLA said in a statement.

According to CLA tallies, the number of applications for unemployment benefits jumped to 124,460 in March at the height of the recession and approved payouts exceeded NT$2.13 billion (US$65.34 million).

The number of applications declined to 114,800 in April, with total payouts of NT$1.92 billion, and the number further slid by about 10,000 in May to roughly 105,000, with total payouts of around NT$1.56 billion.

The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants has also slid since peaking at 35,208 in February this year. The number fell to 28,043 in March, to 21,300 in April and then to about 16,000 in May.
Meanwhile, the number of those on unpaid leave also dropped to 147,021 at the end of May from a high of 238,975 in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Italy holds national day celebration

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Italian Economic Trade and Cultural Promotion Office (IETCPO) held a national day reception Friday to celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the foundation of the Italian Republic.
Mario Palma, head of the IETCPO, praised the good relations between Taiwan and Italy at the function, attended by members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.

Noting that both sides have frequent exchanges and work closely in economic, trade, cultural and art sectors, Palma specifically mentioned the friendship between parliaments in the two countries and said that suchparliamentary diplomacycreated a significant political-institutional framework conducive to the sound development of bilateral relations.

The top Italian envoy to Taiwan was referring to the visit in February to Italy of Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, and the visit to Taiwan of two Italian parliamentary delegations.

Economic cooperation between Taiwan and Italy is also close, Palma said, citing as examples the renewal of the air transport agreement between Rome and Taipei and the contract to build the first phase of the Taipei Metro Circular Line, which was awarded to Italian transportation technology firm Ansaldo STS.

Even in such dire economic situations, (we should) always be able to detect and value whatever positive signals and trends which could then lead in the foreseeable future to a new expansion in our overall relationship,Palma said.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lin said at the function that cultural exchanges between Italy and Taiwan have been impressive, with over 200,000 Taiwanese tourists visiting Italy every year, a number Lin believed would continue to rise in the future.
Also, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Italy reached over US$4 billion in 2008, making Italy Taiwan's fourth largest trading partner in the European Union, Lin said.
He said he was confident that through joint efforts substantive bilateral relations between the two countries will be further strengthened in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO extends deadline for Taiwan to submit GPA document

TEXT.P: A World Trade Organization committee has agreed to a request by Taiwan to extend by one month until July 9 the submission of its instrument of accession to the WTO Government Procurement Agreement (GPA), a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Friday.
Economics Vice Minister John Deng said Taiwan requested the extension for "administrative" reasons, mainly involving a scheduling snafu.
The WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved Taiwan's application to enter the GPA on Dec. 9, 2008.

Taiwan was required to send its instrument of accession to the WTO Secretariat within six months to complete the accession procedure. The agreement then enters into force on the 30th day following the date of its accession.

Taiwan's Legislative Yuan endorsed the decision to admit Taiwan into the GPA on May 15.
