According to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official, there was then a two-week waiting period for the legislature to express dissent before President Ma Ying-jeou could sign the instrument of accession as required.
Because the two-week period had not expired by the time Ma departed on a trip to Central America, the government asked for an extension, the MOFA official said.
The GPA was adopted by the WTO in 1981 with the purpose of opening up as much government procurement as possible to international competition.

It was designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.
There are currently 40 members of the GPA, most of them developed countries.
Following the accession, Taiwan's government procurement market will be open to other GPA members, and vice versa, based on the principles of reciprocity and national treatment.
The WTO Secretariat estimates the government procurement market in GPA signatory countries totals US$5.55 trillion per year, which will now be open to Taiwanese companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has not relaxed combat preparedness: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his administration has not relaxed efforts to strengthen the military's arsenal and combat preparedness despite its progress in improving relations with China.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of overseas offspring of cadets of the now-defunct Whampoa Military Academy. The academy, based in southern China's Guangzhou, officially opening in 1924 and served as the training ground for the Kuomintang's most prestigious commanders until it lost the Chinese civil war in 1949.

Ma, who just returned to Taipei the previous day after a three-leg Central America diplomatic tour, told his guests that he got up at 4 a.m. Friday to participate in a virtual military exercise simulating an attempted invasion of Taiwan by China.
In addition to military personnel, senior government officials also took part in the computerized war games to test coordination between the military and the executive branch.
Ma said the war games were part of Taiwan's efforts to beef up its defense capabilities and combat preparedness.

As China still deploys missiles targeting Taiwan, Ma said, Taiwan, while continuing to improve relations with China, cannot afford to relax in enhancing its crisis management and honing its defense strategies and tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 6, 2009

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Saturday, moving up 28.77 points at 6,795.87 on a turnover of NT$2.84 billion (US$87.1 million).
The weighted price index lost 18.96 points, or 0.27 percent, to close at 6,767.10 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.684 at 10 a.m. Saturday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.077 from Friday's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 6, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: Italy holds national day celebration

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 5 (CNA) The Taipei-based Italian Economic Trade and Cultural Promotion Office (IETCPO) held a national day reception Friday to celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the foundation of the Italian Republic.
Mario Palma, head of the IETCPO, praised the good relations between Taiwan and Italy at the function, attended by members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.

Noting that both sides have frequent exchanges and work closely in economic, trade, cultural and art sectors, Palma specifically mentioned the friendship between parliaments in the two countries and said that such"parliamentary diplomacy"created a significant political-institutional framework conducive to the sound development of bilateral relations.

The top Italian envoy to Taiwan was referring to the visit in February to Italy of Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, and the visit to Taiwan of two Italian parliamentary delegations.

Economic cooperation between Taiwan and Italy is also close, Palma said, citing as examples the renewal of the air transport agreement between Rome and Taipei and the contract to build the first phase of the Taipei Metro Circular Line, which was awarded to Italian transportation technology firm Ansaldo STS.

"Even in such dire economic situations, (we should) always be able to detect and value whatever positive signals and trends which could then lead in the foreseeable future to a new expansion in our overall relationship,"Palma said.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lin said at the function that cultural exchanges between Italy and Taiwan have been impressive, with over 200,000 Taiwanese tourists visiting Italy every year, a number Lin believed would continue to rise in the future.
Also, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Italy reached over US$4 billion in 2008, making Italy Taiwan's fourth largest trading partner in the European Union, Lin said.
He said he was confident that through joint efforts substantive bilateral relations between the two countries will be further strengthened in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of people on the dole continues to decline: CLA

TEXT.P: The number of people collecting unemployment benefits declined in May for the second consecutive month, according to initial statistics released by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Friday.
The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants also fell in May for the third consecutive month, the statistics showed.
"All these figures indicate that domestic joblessness triggered by a global economic recession is easing, " the CLA said in a statement.

According to CLA tallies, the number of applications for unemployment benefits jumped to 124,460 in March at the height of the recession and approved payouts exceeded NT$2.13 billion (US$65.34 million).

The number of applications declined to 114,800 in April, with total payouts of NT$1.92 billion, and the number further slid by about 10,000 in May to roughly 105,000, with total payouts of around NT$1.56 billion.

The number of first-time jobless benefit applicants has also slid since peaking at 35,208 in February this year. The number fell to 28,043 in March, to 21,300 in April and then to about 16,000 in May.
Meanwhile, the number of those on unpaid leave also dropped to 147,021 at the end of May from a high of 238,975 in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOEA to review restrictions on China investment by chipmakers

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will evaluate whether to allow semiconductor manufacturers to move their 12-inch wafer fabs to China during a review in July of existing restrictions on China-bound investment by Taiwanese businesses, an official said Friday.

According to Woody Duh, head of the ministry's Industrial Development Bureau, the government will comply with the Wassenaar Arrangement on Export Controls for Conventional Arms and Dual-Use Goods and Technologies in dealing with the issue.

The multilateral arrangement was established in 1996 to ensure that transfers of these items do not contribute to the development or enhancement of military capabilities that undermine regional and international security and stability.

The arrangement does not restrict the export of 0.18-micron chipmaking technology but require participating states to decide on a case-by-case basis whether to allow the export of technologies using processes smaller than 0.18-microns.
Taiwan has so far allowed chipmakers to produce only 8-inch or smaller semiconductor wafers and to use 0.18-micron or larger processes in China.
Currently, 0.13-micron or smaller processes are mainly used by 12-inch wafer fabs.

While receiving U.S.-based Applied Materials Inc. Chairman Michael R. Splinter Friday, President Ma Ying-jeou said the government will not rule out the possibility of liberalizing 12-inch wafer manufacturing in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records imported case of valley fever

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported Saturday Taiwan's first imported case of valley fever for the year, which involved a Taiwanese citizen returning recently from the United States, where the disease is endemic.
This was the third valley fever case ever recorded in Taiwan. The previous two cases, also imported, were recorded in 2005 and 1991, respectively, according to a statement issued by the CDC.
The latest case was a 30-year-old woman who was in the United States between July 1, 2008 and May 1, 2009. The infection was diagnosed June 3 through blood tests, the CDC said.
Valley fever is caused by Coccidioides immitis, a fungus commonly found in the soil of desert regions in the United States, Mexico, and Central and South America, the CDC said.
People can be infected after inhaling the fungus spores in the air. The disease is not spread from person to person.
While many infected persons display no symptoms, some may develop fever, cough, chills, night sweats, headache, joint aches, chest pain, and a red spotty rash.
In some rare cases, the infection can lead to pneumonia, meningitis, and even death.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung travel fair attracts big crowds with attractive discounts

TEXT.P: Hordes of people descended upon the 2009 Taichung Summer Travel Fair Saturday, looking for bargains among a wide variety of discounted tour packages.

By the time the World Trade Center Taichung opened its doors for the show Saturday morning, a long line of people extending all the way to a nearby road had built up, causing serious traffic congestion in the surrounding neighborhood.
Many visitors said they were looking for an interesting but inexpensive tour package suitable for a summer vacation for the whole family.

Huang Lin-huei, a project manager of Taichung-based Bosstar International Co. Ltd. -- the fair's organizer -- said that most of the travel agencies participating in the three-day fair that opened Friday are offering discounted domestic and overseas tour packages to attract buyers.
For example, Huang said, a seven-day tour to Thailand and Hong Kong is being offered for NT$18,000 (US$550) per adult, with children enjoying a further reduction of NT$4,000 per person.

As to local tours, "paying the same price for a bed and breakfast as in the past, you can now not only have the bed and breakfast, but also a free afternoon tea, a visit to a hot spring and extra tour guide services, " said Huang. "The packages really offer big incentives."

Affected by the global outbreak of a new strain of swine flu, known formally as influenza A (H1N1) , the overseas travel market declined by 30 percent in May but the domestic market grew by between 10 percent and 20 percent, Huang said, noting that there are now signs showing that overseas travel is slowly recovering.
More than 150 local and foreign travel business operators, including Star Cruises, have set up 250 booths at the annual travel fair in the central Taiwan city.

They are promoting services ranging from stays at hot spring hotels or upscale business hostels and rural tour packages to leisure-oriented and bicycle-related treks and overseas honeymoon packages, according to Bosstar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rise in rare Saturday session

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 89.64 points, or 1.32 percent, to close at 6,856.74.

Rebounding after four consecutive losing sessions, the local bourse opened at 6,795.87 and fluctuated between 6,856.74 and 6,781.69 during Saturday's session, held to make up for a vacation day during last week's Dragon Boat Festival.
A total of 3.93 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.34 billion (US$2.89 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 3.5 percent, foodstuff issues rose 1.7 percent, banking and financial shares increased 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks both gained 1.4 percent, cement stocks were up 1.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares rose 1.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,423 to 607, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors sold a net NT$602 million in shares.
Although the market rebounded Saturday, Mega Securities assistant manager Alex Huang said the reduced turnover cast doubt over how long the rally can be sustained.

Analysts at KGI Securities Co. agreed that the lower volume could put downward pressure on the market, but with world markets generally positive at the moment, they believed that once turnover falls to the year-average level, prices could rebound.
At the same time, however, they said room for upward growth would be limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computex Taipei wraps up with record size, scale and turnout

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2009 attracted more visitors and generated more new business than last year's show despite adverse market conditions and the global swine flu outbreak, a sign that the global economy may be on the rebound, show organizers said Saturday.

"This year's Computex Taipei was in the global limelight with international coverage from the British Broadcasting Corporation, the New York Times, Bloomberg and NHK. It also served as an important benchmark of global economic recovery, " said Walter Yeh, executive vice president of the semi-official trade promotion body Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

"It demonstrated that new business opportunities lie in new innovative products, " added Yeh, speaking at the show's final-day press conference to close the world's leading information communication technology (ICT) show.

According to Yeh, this year's Computex Taipei, which hosted 1,712 exhibitors occupying 4,498 booths, received 32,178 international buyers from 214 countries and territories, an increase of 1 percent compared to the previous year and generated US$20 billion in business.

TAITRA arranged more than 2,000 one-on-one procurement meetings attended by 256 overseas companies from 42 countries, which generated US$100 million in on-site business on their own and created US$700 million in follow-up business.
The show also attracted more than 100,000 international and local visitors during its first four days June 2-5, an increase of 5 percent over last year's number, he said.
The United States, Japan, Hong Kong, China and South Korea were the top five countries represented by international buyers, with Australia a new addition to the top 10 this year, Yeh said.

Chang Li, deputy secretary-general of the show's co-organizer, the Taipei Computer Association, attributed Computex Taipei's success to its evolving status as a multi-industry info-hub and platform for companies to launch new products.

"International buyers want new products with innovative features, but with a reasonal price tag, and Taiwanese companies always manage to achieve that, " Chang said. "I believe next year Computex will see bigger growth, as more Chinese companies and overseas companies return to the show after the global economy recovers."
The show annually previews the coming year's hottest trends, and this year's Computex was about netbooks, green-tech and self-branding, according to TAITRA.

Buyers included big names such as Siemens and Alcatel-Lucent from Germany, Best Buy and Future Shop from Canada, Esprinet from Italy and Ryoden from Japan, TAITRA said, adding that most of them showed great interest in notebooks, netbooks, GPS devices, and LCD monitors.

Noting that Computex Taipei will celebrate its 30th anniversary in 2010, Yeh said the show has transformed itself into not only the world's leading ICT procurement platform, but also a perfect world stage for launching new products and technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Saturday, increasing NT$0.113 to close at NT$32.720.
A total of US$328 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.807 and reached a low of NT$32.650.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65% of businesses to hire fresh graduates: survey

TEXT.P: More than 65 percent of businesses have plans to recruit fresh graduates this year, about the same as last year when the job market was stronger, according to the results of a survey released Saturday by an online employment broker.
Of all the new jobs being offered by these businesses, 17.68 percent will go to fresh graduates, the survey conducted by 1111 Job Bank showed.

The largest portion -- 38.89 percent -- of the positions are in the areas of customer service, sales and trade. Operational, technical and maintenance positions account for 9.26 percent, and administrative positions account for 6.48 percent.

Although the percentage of companies looking to hire new graduates remained about the same, the weak economy is being reflected in the average starting monthly salary being offered to fresh graduates, which at NT$24,133 (US$743) is NT$2,010 lower than last year.
The survey found that 91.67 percent of this year's graduates are bracing for a long job search period in light of the constricted employment market as a result of the economic downturn.
Among respondents who have not found a job, 77.04 percent began to prepare their resumes before graduation.
Considerations in seeking jobs mentioned by graduates include the duties of the positions offered, whether the positions meet their expertise and interest, the work environment and the pay offered.

The pay expectations of this year's graduates have also been tempered by Taiwan's floundering economy. Respondents said they are expecting a starting salary of NT$22,599 on average, a decrease of NT$3,349 from last year.
The survey was conducted between May 22 and June 4 among 1,356 students set to graduate from colleges or universities this summer. It had a margin of error of 2.66 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysians hold local birthday celebration for king

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Malaysian Friendship and Trade Centre held a reception Saturday to celebrate the 46th birthday of Tuanku Mizan Zainal Abidin, the 13th Yang di- Pertuan Agong, or king, of Malaysia.
The Malaysian king's birthday is a public holiday in the country and all missions abroad hold receptions to celebrate the day.
Dato' Abdullah Mohd Salleh, top Malaysian envoy to Taiwan, led a prayer in Malay to wish the king good health at the function, which was attended by Malaysian expatriates and businessmen in Taiwan.
Mizan, who is the 16th Sultan of the state of Terengganu, became king of Malaysia on Dec. 13, 2006 following a five-year rotational constitutional monarchy system practiced among nine Malay rulers.
Ascending to the throne at the age of 44, he is the second youngest Yang di- Pertuan Agong since the office was established in 1957.
Abdullah also touched on bilateral relations during the occasion, saying that Taiwan and Malaysia enjoy a good relationship in trade, investment and tourism.
Taiwan is Malaysia's ninth biggest trading partner, Abdullah said, and 10,000 Malaysians are living in Taiwan, of which 3,800 are students.

Some 170,000 tourists from Taiwan visited Malaysia in 2008, a slight decrease from the 200,000 who visited in 2007 because of the economic downturn, but Abdullah expected the number to rebound in 2009.

Bilateral relations will be further strengthened with two more direct flights scheduled to be launched between Taiwan and Malaysia on July 1 and July 2 by Air Asia and Malaysia Airlines, respectively, the envoy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA issues more swine flu yellow travel alerts

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued yellow travel alerts Saturday for Ukraine, Malaysia, French Polynesia and Trinidad & Tobago over new confirmed cases of swine flu in those countries.
The ministry said in a statement that in issuing the alert, it is advising citizens traveling to those countries to take health precautions.
At the same time, the ministry retracted its yellow travel advisory for Hungary, given that no new cases of the swine flu have emerged recently in the country, it added.

A yellow alert, the lowest level of a three-color travel advisory scale, serves as a reminder for travelers to exercise caution. An orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, while a red alert warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.
On June 1, the ministry adjusted its travel advisory from orange to yellow for Mexico -- the source of the worldwide outbreak of swine flu, known officially as influenza A (H1N1).
Taiwan has issued yellow alerts for 67 countries and areas that have reported swine flu cases.
Taiwan meanwhile confirmed two more cases of swine flu Thursday, bringing to 16 the total number of influenza A (H1N1) infections recorded in the country, with no deaths.
As of Friday, 69 countries have officially reported 21,940 cases of influenza A infection, including 125 deaths, according to World Health Organization data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to shut down five overseas offices

TEXT.P: The government will close down five underutilized overseas offices in the coming months, in an effort to put the country's diplomatic resources to better use, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou said Saturday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs had previously announced that offices in Venezuela, Bolivia and Bangladesh would be shut down, but Ou added the consulate-general in Colon, Panama, and the liaison office in Johannesburg, South Africa to the list Saturday.
Taiwan currently has 121 offices around the world, a number that Ou admitted was too high in light of the country's small size.
Among the many reasons to shut down the selected offices are the unfriendly attitude of the concerned countries toward Taiwan or the existence of more than one office within close proximity, Ou said.

For example, although the Bangladesh representative office has been open for four years, the Bangladesh government remains unwilling to have any contact with Taiwanese officials and refuses to allow the office to operate visa services, according to Ou.
In the case of the Johannesburg office, it is only about a 10-minute drive from Taiwan's main South African mission located in Pretoria, the minister said.
A similar situation exists between the Colon consulate-general and the country's embassy in Panama, he added.
Ou stressed that the measures are aimed at ensuring an efficient use of diplomatic resources and do not mean that Taiwan does not value relations with the concerned countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 84-year-old college graduate honored in a special way

TEXT.P: Eighty-four-year-old Shen Chien-yi was honored in a special way at the commencement ceremony of Chang Jung Christian University in southern Taiwan's Tainan County Saturday.

Shen had his feet washed by the school's President Chen Chin-seng while other 23 students had their feet washed by other faculty members. Having school faculty wash the feet of selected students is a traditional ritual of the school to underscore the value of service with a humble spirit.
The 24 students were selected because of their special attributes, either for excellent performance or an enthusiasm in serving others.
Shen was chosen because he has shown a passion for learning and has not missed a class during his four years of college, making him a shining example of "life- long learning," the school said.
Shen held a personal exhibition earlier this week to mark his commencement, featuring more than 100 works of art that included oil paintings, watercolors, stereography and Chinese brush calligraphy.
Shen presented one of his creative works -- "Watching Quietly" -- to the university during the ceremony.

He also donated a check of NT$100,000 to the school to be used to fund scholarships and urged his peers-- six decades younger than him -- to "seize their prime days in a lifetime and learn with zest every day."
Shen has been fond of painting since his childhood, but born in a tumultuous era in China, he was not been able to receive a formal fine arts education.
Shen, who fought in World War II as a career military officer, came to Taiwan from China more than five decades ago to work as a public functionary.
He was chief of the Tainan City government's news department before he was transferred to the Kaohsiung City government where he worked in the secretariat until his retirement.
Shen applied to study at China Academy of Art in Hangzhou at the age of 73, years after his retirement.

He was accepted and began his program at the academy, but was forced to return to Taiwan less than two years later when his health began to decline due to age and fatigue from the frequent trips across the Taiwan Strait to attend school.

Determined not to give up his dream, Shen, at the age of 80, registered four years ago for classes in watercolor painting with professor Tsai Mau-sung, director of Chang Jung Christian University's Department of Visual Art.
In 2005, he took the department's entrance exams and began full- time studies there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recession not affecting vaccines paid for by parents

TEXT.P: Local parents spent more on vaccinating their children last year than in 2007, countering fears that the opposite would be true during the economic downturn, the results of an online survey released Saturday show.

The survey was jointly conducted by the Taiwan Immunization Vision and Strategy (TIVS) alliance and the Chinese-language Baby & Mother monthly magazine between April 30 and May 25 among parents with children aged under 5.
It found that 67.7 percent of respondents thought the recession would shake the willingness of parents in Taiwan to pay for vaccines for their children.

But, in fact, the percentage of parents who paid for inoculations for their babies and toddlers stood at 92.9 percent in the May survey, 6.2 percentage points higher than the previous poll conducted in October 2007.
The survey also found the amount of money spent on out-of-pocket vaccines increased to average NT$13,203 (US$403) per family a year, higher than the NT$10,843 shown in the 2007 survey, TIVS said.
At present, the government covers infant vaccines for Hepatitis B, influenza, the measles, and varicella, among others.

But parents have to pay for Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine, hepatitis A vaccine, and pneumococcal vaccine, along with a number of new combination vaccines that inoculate infants against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and hepatitis B with one shot.
The alliance said the results show a growing number of parents have come to realize the importance of vaccines to their children's health.
Although many parents are paying for inoculations, TIVS Secretary-General Lee Ping-ing urged the government to make it a priority to cover the cost of more vaccines for infants and toddlers.
Just over 90 percent of survey respondents said the government covers the cost of too few vaccines at present to maintain their children's health.

That was 8 percent more than in the previous survey, an indication of the growing dismay over the government's existing inoculation policy because of the added vaccine costs parents are now forced to pay out-of-pocket, Lin said.
The policy is especially unfair to families that cannot afford to foot the cost of vaccines because of the recession, he noted.
A total of 1,017 valid samples were collected for the survey, and 93 percent of the respondents were women, TIVS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President proposes WiMAX ambulance project

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he looks forward to the introduction of WiMAX technology in ambulance service systems to upgrade the quality and efficiency of first aid operations.
Ma brought up the idea while attending a news conference at the Taipei World Trade Center to mark the inauguration of WiMAX commercial operations earlier this week.

Ten years ago, Ma recalled, during his tenure as mayor of Taipei, he took the lead in offering free e-mail addresses to 250,000 city residents as part of his efforts to promote e-government. At the time, neither hotmail nor yahoo had done so.

Moreover, Ma said, the city government under his leadership began a Wifly project that covers the whole city acreage of 130 square kilometers and enables all of its 2.3 million residents easy access to the Internet service.

However, Wifly signals are unreceivable on vehicles traveling faster than 30 kilometers per hour. The inauguration of WiMax commercial operations will offer much better wireless Internet connections, Ma said.

"I'm hopeful that the WiMAX technology can be introduced into ambulance service systems to enable firefighters and nurses aboard ambulances to connect with medical doctors at major hospitals around the city through WiMax, " Ma said.
"Once such mobile broadband wireless access network becomes available on ambulances, our emergency medical operations will be far more efficient."
Before attending the news conference, Ma took a ride on the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system's Muzha line to try out swift access to the Internet on a laptop with built-in WiMAX modules.
WiMAX services became available on eight trains of the Taipei MRT's Muzha line earlier this month to allow passengers to try out the world's first mobile broadband wireless access network.

"The experience was amazing and thrilling, " Ma said, adding that he felt gratified to be able to get quick and easy access to the Internet abaord an MRT train. On the train ride, Ma received e-mails on a laptop.

Noting that the government has invested NT$37 billion in an ambitious project aimed at building Taiwan into a country that features mobility and digitization, Ma said WiMAX service will play a key role in accomplishing this lofty goal.

"With the launch of WiMAX service on the MRT system, I'm convinced that wireless broadband communications services will be even widely used when easy access to the Internet on all moblie vehicles are available," he added.

WiMAX (Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access) , a big broadband wireless application, processes data at a speed three to four times faster than ADSL, allowing users to download a 2G film in only 20-30 seconds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City reinforces fight against prohibited graffiti

TEXT.P: Taipei City has decided to reinforce measures to crack down on the use of graffiti to deface public property and keep the city clean, officials of the city Department of Environmental Protection said Saturday.
Those who are found arbitrarily defacing public property will be faced with a fine of up to NT$6,000 (US$183), the officials said.

The city decided to crack down on the practice because it has had trouble cleaning graffiti done with unwashable markers or spray paint and has had to pay considerable sums to get it off the city's walls and other venues.

The department advised people who are passionate about graffiti to practice their art at five public parks where it is legal: the Ying Feng Riverside Park, the Meiti Riverside Park, the JingMei Riverside Park, the Fuhe Riverside Park, and the Bailing Riverside Park North.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese business visitors can stay longer under new rule

TEXT.P: Restrictions on Chinese business visitors were eased Saturday, with the duration of stay extended to one month from previous 14 days.

Ho Jung-chun, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, said the relaxation was part of amended regulations governing visits by Chinese business executives and professionals promulgated by the ministry the day before.
From now on, Ho said, Chinese businessmen can stay in Taiwan for up to one month on each visit for business purposes.
According to Ho, Chinese citizens made about 80,000 business visits to Taiwan in 2008.

Previous regulations stipulated that local companies with an annual business turnover of less than NT$30 million (US$917,431) were eligible to host a maximum of 15 Chinese business visitors annually. Under the new regulations, the number increases to 45.
The number of Chinese business visitors that local businesses with annual business turnover of NT$30 million or over can host each year has also been raised to 200 from original 50.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65% of businesses to hire fresh graduates: survey

TEXT.P: More than 65 percent of businesses have plans to recruit fresh graduates this year, about the same as last year when the job market was stronger, according to the results of a survey released Saturday by an online employment broker.
Of all the new jobs being offered by these businesses, 17.68 percent will go to fresh graduates, the survey conducted by 1111 Job Bank showed.

The largest portion -- 38.89 percent -- of the positions are in the areas of customer service, sales and trade. Operational, technical and maintenance positions account for 9.26 percent, and administrative positions account for 6.48 percent.

Although the percentage of companies looking to hire new graduates remained about the same, the weak economy is being reflected in the average starting monthly salary being offered to fresh graduates, which at NT$24,133 (US$743) is NT$2,010 lower than last year.
The survey found that 91.67 percent of this year's graduates are bracing for a long job search period in light of the constricted employment market as a result of the economic downturn.
Among respondents who have not found a job, 77.04 percent began to prepare their resumes before graduation.
Considerations in seeking jobs mentioned by graduates include the duties of the positions offered, whether the positions meet their expertise and interest, the work environment and the pay offered.

The pay expectations of this year's graduates have also been tempered by Taiwan's floundering economy. Respondents said they are expecting a starting salary of NT$22,599 on average, a decrease of NT$3,349 from last year.
The survey was conducted between May 22 and June 4 among 1,356 students set to graduate from colleges or universities this summer. It had a margin of error of 2.66 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysians hold local birthday celebration for king

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Malaysian Friendship and Trade Centre held a reception Saturday to celebrate the 46th birthday of Tuanku Mizan Zainal Abidin, the 13th Yang di- Pertuan Agong, or king, of Malaysia.
The Malaysian king's birthday is a public holiday in the country and all missions abroad hold receptions to celebrate the day.
Dato' Abdullah Mohd Salleh, top Malaysian envoy to Taiwan, led a prayer in Malay to wish the king good health at the function, which was attended by Malaysian expatriates and businessmen in Taiwan.
Mizan, who is the 16th Sultan of the state of Terengganu, became king of Malaysia on Dec. 13, 2006 following a five-year rotational constitutional monarchy system practiced among nine Malay rulers.
Ascending to the throne at the age of 44, he is the second youngest Yang di- Pertuan Agong since the office was established in 1957.
Abdullah also touched on bilateral relations during the occasion, saying that Taiwan and Malaysia enjoy a good relationship in trade, investment and tourism.
Taiwan is Malaysia's ninth biggest trading partner, Abdullah said, and 10,000 Malaysians are living in Taiwan, of which 3,800 are students.

Some 170,000 tourists from Taiwan visited Malaysia in 2008, a slight decrease from the 200,000 who visited in 2007 because of the economic downturn, but Abdullah expected the number to rebound in 2009.

Bilateral relations will be further strengthened with two more direct flights scheduled to be launched between Taiwan and Malaysia on July 1 and July 2 by Air Asia and Malaysia Airlines, respectively, the envoy said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA issues more swine flu yellow travel alerts

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued yellow travel alerts Saturday for Ukraine, Malaysia, French Polynesia and Trinidad & Tobago over new confirmed cases of swine flu in those countries.
The ministry said in a statement that in issuing the alert, it is advising citizens traveling to those countries to take health precautions.
At the same time, the ministry retracted its yellow travel advisory for Hungary, given that no new cases of the swine flu have emerged recently in the country, it added.

A yellow alert, the lowest level of a three-color travel advisory scale, serves as a reminder for travelers to exercise caution. An orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, while a red alert warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.
On June 1, the ministry adjusted its travel advisory from orange to yellow for Mexico -- the source of the worldwide outbreak of swine flu, known officially as influenza A (H1N1).
Taiwan has issued yellow alerts for 67 countries and areas that have reported swine flu cases.
Taiwan meanwhile confirmed two more cases of swine flu Thursday, bringing to 16 the total number of influenza A (H1N1) infections recorded in the country, with no deaths.
As of Friday, 69 countries have officially reported 21,940 cases of influenza A infection, including 125 deaths, according to World Health Organization data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to shut down five overseas offices

TEXT.P: The government will close down five underutilized overseas offices in the coming months, in an effort to put the country's diplomatic resources to better use, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou said Saturday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs had previously announced that offices in Venezuela, Bolivia and Bangladesh would be shut down, but Ou added the consulate-general in Colon, Panama, and the liaison office in Johannesburg, South Africa to the list Saturday.
Taiwan currently has 121 offices around the world, a number that Ou admitted was too high in light of the country's small size.
Among the many reasons to shut down the selected offices are the unfriendly attitude of the concerned countries toward Taiwan or the existence of more than one office within close proximity, Ou said.

For example, although the Bangladesh representative office has been open for four years, the Bangladesh government remains unwilling to have any contact with Taiwanese officials and refuses to allow the office to operate visa services, according to Ou.
In the case of the Johannesburg office, it is only about a 10-minute drive from Taiwan's main South African mission located in Pretoria, the minister said.
A similar situation exists between the Colon consulate-general and the country's embassy in Panama, he added.
Ou stressed that the measures are aimed at ensuring an efficient use of diplomatic resources and do not mean that Taiwan does not value relations with the concerned countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 84-year-old college graduate honored in a special way

TEXT.P: Eighty-four-year-old Shen Chien-yi was honored in a special way at the commencement ceremony of Chang Jung Christian University in southern Taiwan's Tainan County Saturday.

Shen had his feet washed by the school's President Chen Chin-seng while other 23 students had their feet washed by other faculty members. Having school faculty wash the feet of selected students is a traditional ritual of the school to underscore the value of service with a humble spirit.
The 24 students were selected because of their special attributes, either for excellent performance or an enthusiasm in serving others.
Shen was chosen because he has shown a passion for learning and has not missed a class during his four years of college, making him a shining example of "life- long learning," the school said.
Shen held a personal exhibition earlier this week to mark his commencement, featuring more than 100 works of art that included oil paintings, watercolors, stereography and Chinese brush calligraphy.
Shen presented one of his creative works -- "Watching Quietly" -- to the university during the ceremony.

He also donated a check of NT$100,000 to the school to be used to fund scholarships and urged his peers-- six decades younger than him -- to "seize their prime days in a lifetime and learn with zest every day."
Shen has been fond of painting since his childhood, but born in a tumultuous era in China, he was not been able to receive a formal fine arts education.
Shen, who fought in World War II as a career military officer, came to Taiwan from China more than five decades ago to work as a public functionary.
He was chief of the Tainan City government's news department before he was transferred to the Kaohsiung City government where he worked in the secretariat until his retirement.
Shen applied to study at China Academy of Art in Hangzhou at the age of 73, years after his retirement.

He was accepted and began his program at the academy, but was forced to return to Taiwan less than two years later when his health began to decline due to age and fatigue from the frequent trips across the Taiwan Strait to attend school.

Determined not to give up his dream, Shen, at the age of 80, registered four years ago for classes in watercolor painting with professor Tsai Mau-sung, director of Chang Jung Christian University's Department of Visual Art.
In 2005, he took the department's entrance exams and began full- time studies there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recession not affecting vaccines paid for by parents

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 7, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan to focus on joining U.N. agencies: foreign ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan will make greater efforts to take part in United Nations-affiliated activities and join U.N. specialized agencies as a member, rather than renewing its campaign for direct participation in the U.N., the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Sunday.

A MOFA official told the Central News Agency that while the ministry could ask Taiwan's diplomatic allies as it did last year to submit a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat calling for reconsideration of Taiwan's bid to meaningfully take part in U.N. specialized agencies, the MOFA is considering a different approach.
"Taiwan may also choose to be more realistic and not submit a U.N. proposal at all this year," said the official.
"It would be easier to maintain our efforts of the past, but we consider it as unrealistic to try to force a way into the U.N., which is politically a highly sensitive matter," said the official.

Instead, the Foreign Ministry will seek this year to gain a foothold in one or two U.N. agencies using the pragmatic approach that enabled Taiwan to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva in mid-May, he added.

"We will work out solid action plans to seek international support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in U.N.-affiliated activities, he said. "Of course, this is presuming that mainland China does not oppose such efforts."

"Our priority is to seek entry to the United Nations' 15 specialized agencies, such as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) which develops international standards for aviation safety and the International Marine Organization (IMO) which is concerned with the safety of shipping and cleaner oceans, " he added.

Because of Taiwan's absence from the ICAO, for example, there is gap in the global aviation safety network because the Taipei Flight Information Region, located in the center of Southeast Asia, covers a vast air space of 176,000 square nautical miles in which 12 international air routes and four domestic air routes operate, he pointed out.

In the case of the IMO, he said, although Taiwan ranks 10th in the world in terms of ocean navigation capability, it has no access to first-hand navigation information and seamen identification issued in Taiwan is often questioned around the world because Taiwan is not an IMO member.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently attributed Taiwan's success in gaining admission to the World Health Organization (WHO) annual executive assembly this year mainly to his administration's pragmatic policies and improved Taiwan-China relations over the past several months.

The previous Democratic Progressive Party administration applied in 2007 for the first time for Taiwan to join the U.N. as a full member under the name "Taiwan." However, that proposal did not make it onto the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly.

Since 1993, Taiwan's supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list Taiwan's application for admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.

Taiwan has not been represented in the world body since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China, and it has been trying unsuccessfully to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993.

In a departure from the 2007 approach of pushing for full membership under the name Taiwan, the country in 2008 promoted a bid to "participate meaningfully in the activities of the U.N. specialized agencies," in line with Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.

However, a request jointly put forth by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies to include the issue as a supplementary item on the agenda of the 63rd session of the U.N. General Assembly was rejected last September by the U.N. General Committee, again because of China's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma envisages Taiwan as a 'tourism island'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou outlined his vision Sunday for turning Taiwan into a "tourism island" with the concerted effort of the private and public sectors.

Addressing the faculty and students of National Kaohsiung Hospitality College, Ma said that in light of the improved relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan can save the energy and resources it would direct toward war preparedness and instead seek to boost its tourism development.
"I've asked my administration to make tourism one of the six sectors to be further developed, with governmental assistance, into Taiwan's flagship industries," he said.

He said Taiwan should emulate Hong Kong and Singapore, noting that tourist arrivals in each of those two countries exceed 10 million a year, a number that is far in excess of their respective populations.
"There is ample room for Taiwan to catch up in terms of tourism development," Ma said.
He exhorted the college to play a leading role in revving up hospitality development and education in Taiwan.
The president sampled the dishes and dessert wine that were researched and developed by the students at the college.

National Kaohsiung Hospitality College is the only professional college in Taiwan that specializes in hospitality training. Its mission is to train and educate managers for work in the tourism, travel and restaurant industries, and foster the advancement and development of local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long-term health care plan is taking shape: official

TEXT.P: The Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is expected to come up with a bill by the end of this year on a long-term care insurance system that will require a budget of NT$25 billion- NT$30 billion a year, according to Minister without Portfolio Tsai Tsun-hsiung.

There are two versions of the plan -- one to provide long-term health care insurance coverage to every citizen, and the other one to cover people over the age of 40. The difference between the two versions lies in the insurance premiums, Tsai, who is coordinating an inter-ministerial effort to introduce this system, said Saturday after a routine Cabinet meeting at which the CEPD gave a briefing on the plan.

The premiums would be lower if a universal mandatory long- term care program is adopted, but that means many young people would not be willing to participate in the program and it would therefore not have wide support, the CEPD was quoted as saying.
But on the other hand, if the plan provided coverage only for people over the age of 40, then the insurance premiums would be higher, according to the CEPD.
The CEPD will hold a series of hearings and forums around Taiwan to obtain the opinions of local governments and residents on the two versions, Tsai said.

Once the program takes effect, all insured citizens will be eligible to apply for some type of long-term care, following evaluation by a planned bureau in charge of the execution of the program and the social welfare authorities, Tsai explained. The insured will be provided services based on the terms and conditions of their insurance plan, including in-home nursing, and organizational care, he added.

At present, the most important task of the government is to build long-term care facilities, partner with long term care organizations, and help train skilled caregivers in preparation for the implementation of the program, Tsai said.

If the bill clears the legislative floor, a bureau responsible for the program's implementation will be established to handle related affairs, he said. The bureau will be under the jurisdiction of the existing Department of Health or the proposed Ministry of Health and Welfare, he added.
At the Cabinet meeting, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed the hope that the program will be written into legislation next year to pave the way for its implementation by 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: President joins 4 km run to promote Deaflympics

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou took part in a 4-kilometer road run Sunday that was designed to promote the upcoming Taipei Deaflympics.
Ma joined some 3,000 other people on the run -- dubbed "Power in Me" -- from the Presidential Office plaza through the streets of Taipei.
The participants, including more than 20 people with hearing disabilities and 10 visually impaired runners, vied for medals in two divisions -- the 4 km race and an 8 km run.

In a conversation with Chen Lan-feng, one of the hearing-impaired runners who will represent Taiwan in the 2009 Deaflympics in Taipei City, Ma exhorted her to train even harder so that she could give an outstanding performance in the Sept. 5-15 games.
Chen is known as "the deer woman" in local athletics circles because of her swift, silent movements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic slowdown to wane in second half of 2009: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic slowdown is expected to gradually ease in the second half of this year as several international forecasting organizations have predicted that the global economy will bottom out in the fourth quarter, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

Major economies experienced a huge slowdown and soaring unemployment rate in the first quarter of this year compared to the fourth quarter of last year, due to the impact of the global financial crisis, the CEPD noted.

The global economy is widely predicted to bottom out in the fourth quarter of this year and to rebound next year as the measures taken by the economies, including efficient inventory management, relaxed monetary policies, and economic stimulus packages, take effect, the CEPD reported.

As for Taiwan, its economy shrank by a record 10.24 percent year-on-year in the first quarter of this year, due mainly to declining exports and investments during the global financial crisis, according to the CEPD.
Taiwan's exports and production continued to slump in April, signs that the economy is still in recession, but the decline of the economy appears to have slowed, the CEPD indicated.
Despite a drop in the unemployment rate in April, the national job market remains challenging, the CEPD said.

However, the country's consumer confidence index went up for the third consecutive month in May, the stock market has risen more than 25 percent so far this year, and the Taiwan dollar has jumped to its highest level in more than 5 months against the U.S. currency, the CEPD noted. There are all indicators of growing confidence in the economy among foreign investors and the local people, the CEPD added.

In its outlook for the year, the CEPD said the pace of economic decline in Taiwan will slow gradually in the second half of this year thanks to a Chinese economic stimulus plan aimed at expanding domestic demand and to the increased stability of the U.S. economy.

Other factors include an expected influx of capital because of the increasingly warmer cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the anticipated effects of the implementation of the public construction projects in the last six months of the year, and the development of six emerging industries to boost Taiwan's competitiveness, it said.

However, the swine flu (H1N1) outbreak could be an uncertain factor in Taiwan's economic recovery, even though the flu situation is stabilizing, because the possibility of an epidemic in the autumn and winter seasons this year cannot be ruled out, the CEPD added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan confirms 1st imported swine flu case from Australia

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese woman who came down with a fever and cough after her return from a recent visit to Australia was confirmed Saturday to have the A(H1N1) flu virus, Taiwan health authorities said Sunday.

The 32-year-old woman, who was on a sightseeing trip in Australia from May 30-June 5, was Taiwan's first confirmed case of swine flu imported from that country and the 18th case in Taiwan, said Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) spokesman Shih Wen-yi.
The woman was one of the two new A(H1N1) cases that were confirmed Sunday and brought to 19 the total number of swine flu infections recorded in the country.

According to Shih, the infected woman did not wear a face mask on her flight home and is now in quarantine and under observation at Taoyuan General Hospital near the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
Her husband, who was on the Australia trip with her, has also developed flu symptoms is now in quarantine at the hospital where he is being tested for swine flu, according to Shih.

Thirteen other members of the tour group and the 29 passengers who sat closest to woman on the flight to Taiwan were advised to monitor their health at home and contact the center if they develop any flu symptoms, Shih said.

Meanwhile, a 15-year-old American boy from the U.S. state of Utah was found to have a fever of 38 degrees Celsius upon arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport with his mother June 4 and was confirmed Saturday to be infected with the A(H1N1) virus -- the 19th case of swine flu recorded in Taiwan.
The teenager, who did not wear a face mask during his flights from Los Angeles via Japan, was whisked away to Taoyuan General Hospital immediately after his flight landed.
His mother, who showed flu symptoms after arriving in Taiwan, has also been placed in quarantine.
Six other people who had come into close contact with the boy have been asked to monitor their health at home.
Of the 19 confirmed swine flu cases in Taiwan so far, one was indigenous, 12 were imported from the United States, three from the Philippines, and one each from Canada, Hong Kong and Australia.
As of Friday, 69 countries had officially reported 21,940 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 125 deaths, according to the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government taking steps to help boost birth rate: official

TEXT.P: The government will strive to create a better social and economic environment to encourage people to have children, Deputy Minister of the Interior Chien Tai- lang said Sunday.

Chien made the remarks after a recent survey showed that the current economic recession, the social welfare system, and poor social order are the three main factors that have dampened people's willingness to have children.
Chien acknowledged that the government needs to do more to help boost the country's birth rate, which has been in decline for the past 30 years.

The birth rate, which measures the average number of times a woman gives birth during her lifetime, was 7.04 in 1951, but by 1984 it had dropped to below 2.1 and last year it fell to a record low of 1.05, Ministry of the Interior (MOI) statistics showed.
Last year, fewer than 200,000 babies were born in Taiwan, while the average number of births per 1,000 persons per year -- also known as crude birth rate -- was 8.54.
These figures were all at record lows, according to the MOI statistics.
Meanwhile, the number of people aged 65 years and older in Taiwan is expected to rise to 39 percent of the total population by 2051, Chien said, citing a projection by sociologists.
Therefore, encouraging more births is one the government's policies, Chien said, adding that increasing the birth rate is not only the responsibility of individuals but also of the government.

The government has launched a number of initiatives to provide assistance to the parents and guardians of young children, such as offering vouchers for nursery school costs and medical allowances for children under the age of 3.
In addition, the Cabinet has introduced laws that allow parents to apply for leave without pay for up to two years to take care of their children.
Moreover, the Legislative Yuan is expected to pass amendments to the Employment Insurance Law to provide subsidies to workers who are on parental leave.
The MOI has also commissioned researchers to study the feasibility of providing living allowances for children, in an effort to help alleviate the financial burden on parents.

Several city and county governments, including the governments of Hsinchu city and county, Chiayi city and county and Yunlin county, all provide childbirth subsidies. For a first baby, parents are entitled to NT$15,000, for a second baby the sum is NT$20,000, for a third birth the subsidy is NT$25,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits orphan girl he sponsors

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday visited an orphan girl whom he has been helping for many years.
The president called on Shih Yun-shuan at Kangda House, a halfway home run by the Roman Catholic church in Kaohsiung City, and gave the 13-year-old an iPod.

Shih came to the attention of Ma in 2006 after he learned in the press that a young girl had burst into tears because she failed to get a glimpse of him while he was stumping in Kaohsiung for a Kuomintang city councilor candidate.
The news report stated that the girl Shih Yun-shuan was a firm supporter of Ma, and eagerly soaked up any information related to him.
The report stated that Shih's mother, who was raising her child single-handedly, was suffering from terminal cancer and may not live to see her daughter grow up.
Ma, who was serving as KMT chairman at that time, began to write to his young fan out of concern and to provide financial and other assistance to her through his office.
Toward the end of her life, Shih's mother put the girl into the care of a friend but the child refused to leave her mother and stayed with her until her death in 2006.
After that, the girl was put into Kangda House, which enrolled her in a boarding school. She returned to the halfway house only on weekends.
During this time, Ma was writing to Shih regularly and continued to do so even after he was elected president of the country.
During Sunday's meeting, Shih broke into tears when the president gave her a warm hug.
Ma urged the teenager to call him or write to him whenever she wants to.
"As president of the state, I am capable of doing more for you than before," he assured her.
He encouraged the girl to face adversity with courage, confidence and patience, and he extended his thanks to Kangda House for taking care of Shih and other girls who need help.
Kangda House, founded in 1998, shelters girls who have been abused, who are dropouts, or delinquents.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to set up marine affairs ministry

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that his administration will set up a marine affairs ministry in two phases.
He made the remarks at the end of an anti-terrorism drill carried out by the Coast Guard Administration at the Kaohsiung Harbor.
"As a country lies between the East China Sea and South China Sea, Taiwan plays a special strategic role, and thereby needs a ministry in charge of marine affairs." Ma said.

Reciting a plan included in his campaign promise, the president said, his administration will set up a marine affairs commission which will be enlarged and converted gradually into a ministry to formulate and enforce the country's marine policy.

Noting that Taiwan ranks 10th in the world in terms of its annual fish catch, Ma, whose four-year term will end in 2012 and can be reelected no more than once, said the government will budget NT$25 billion (US$7.8 billion) to buy a frigate with a displacement of more than 2000 tons in 2017 to boost the Coast Guard's strength.
The largest frigate owned by the Coast Guard Administration now has a displacement of 1800 tons.
