DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 7, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese business visitors can stay longer under new rule

TEXT.P: Restrictions on Chinese business visitors were eased Saturday, with the duration of stay extended to one month from previous 14 days.

Ho Jung-chun, deputy director-general of the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior, said the relaxation was part of amended regulations governing visits by Chinese business executives and professionals promulgated by the ministry the day before.
From now on, Ho said, Chinese businessmen can stay in Taiwan for up to one month on each visit for business purposes.
According to Ho, Chinese citizens made about 80,000 business visits to Taiwan in 2008.

Previous regulations stipulated that local companies with an annual business turnover of less than NT$30 million (US$917,431) were eligible to host a maximum of 15 Chinese business visitors annually. Under the new regulations, the number increases to 45.
The number of Chinese business visitors that local businesses with annual business turnover of NT$30 million or over can host each year has also been raised to 200 from original 50.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan to focus on joining U.N. agencies: foreign ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan will make greater efforts to take part in United Nations-affiliated activities and join U.N. specialized agencies as a member, rather than renewing its campaign for direct participation in the U.N., the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Sunday.

A MOFA official told the Central News Agency that while the ministry could ask Taiwan's diplomatic allies as it did last year to submit a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat calling for reconsideration of Taiwan's bid to meaningfully take part in U.N. specialized agencies, the MOFA is considering a different approach.
"Taiwan may also choose to be more realistic and not submit a U.N. proposal at all this year," said the official.
"It would be easier to maintain our efforts of the past, but we consider it as unrealistic to try to force a way into the U.N., which is politically a highly sensitive matter," said the official.

Instead, the Foreign Ministry will seek this year to gain a foothold in one or two U.N. agencies using the pragmatic approach that enabled Taiwan to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva in mid-May, he added.

"We will work out solid action plans to seek international support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in U.N.-affiliated activities, he said. "Of course, this is presuming that mainland China does not oppose such efforts."

"Our priority is to seek entry to the United Nations' 15 specialized agencies, such as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) which develops international standards for aviation safety and the International Marine Organization (IMO) which is concerned with the safety of shipping and cleaner oceans, " he added.

Because of Taiwan's absence from the ICAO, for example, there is gap in the global aviation safety network because the Taipei Flight Information Region, located in the center of Southeast Asia, covers a vast air space of 176,000 square nautical miles in which 12 international air routes and four domestic air routes operate, he pointed out.

In the case of the IMO, he said, although Taiwan ranks 10th in the world in terms of ocean navigation capability, it has no access to first-hand navigation information and seamen identification issued in Taiwan is often questioned around the world because Taiwan is not an IMO member.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently attributed Taiwan's success in gaining admission to the World Health Organization (WHO) annual executive assembly this year mainly to his administration's pragmatic policies and improved Taiwan-China relations over the past several months.

The previous Democratic Progressive Party administration applied in 2007 for the first time for Taiwan to join the U.N. as a full member under the name "Taiwan." However, that proposal did not make it onto the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly.

Since 1993, Taiwan's supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list Taiwan's application for admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.

Taiwan has not been represented in the world body since 1971, when the Republic of China's seat was given to the People's Republic of China, and it has been trying unsuccessfully to have the United Nations consider the issue of its representation since 1993.

In a departure from the 2007 approach of pushing for full membership under the name Taiwan, the country in 2008 promoted a bid to "participate meaningfully in the activities of the U.N. specialized agencies," in line with Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that favors a moderate and pragmatic approach.

However, a request jointly put forth by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies to include the issue as a supplementary item on the agenda of the 63rd session of the U.N. General Assembly was rejected last September by the U.N. General Committee, again because of China's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma envisages Taiwan as a 'tourism island'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou outlined his vision Sunday for turning Taiwan into a "tourism island" with the concerted effort of the private and public sectors.

Addressing the faculty and students of National Kaohsiung Hospitality College, Ma said that in light of the improved relations across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan can save the energy and resources it would direct toward war preparedness and instead seek to boost its tourism development.
"I've asked my administration to make tourism one of the six sectors to be further developed, with governmental assistance, into Taiwan's flagship industries," he said.

He said Taiwan should emulate Hong Kong and Singapore, noting that tourist arrivals in each of those two countries exceed 10 million a year, a number that is far in excess of their respective populations.
"There is ample room for Taiwan to catch up in terms of tourism development," Ma said.
He exhorted the college to play a leading role in revving up hospitality development and education in Taiwan.
The president sampled the dishes and dessert wine that were researched and developed by the students at the college.

National Kaohsiung Hospitality College is the only professional college in Taiwan that specializes in hospitality training. Its mission is to train and educate managers for work in the tourism, travel and restaurant industries, and foster the advancement and development of local tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long-term health care plan is taking shape: official

TEXT.P: The Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is expected to come up with a bill by the end of this year on a long-term care insurance system that will require a budget of NT$25 billion- NT$30 billion a year, according to Minister without Portfolio Tsai Tsun-hsiung.

There are two versions of the plan -- one to provide long-term health care insurance coverage to every citizen, and the other one to cover people over the age of 40. The difference between the two versions lies in the insurance premiums, Tsai, who is coordinating an inter-ministerial effort to introduce this system, said Saturday after a routine Cabinet meeting at which the CEPD gave a briefing on the plan.

The premiums would be lower if a universal mandatory long- term care program is adopted, but that means many young people would not be willing to participate in the program and it would therefore not have wide support, the CEPD was quoted as saying.
But on the other hand, if the plan provided coverage only for people over the age of 40, then the insurance premiums would be higher, according to the CEPD.
The CEPD will hold a series of hearings and forums around Taiwan to obtain the opinions of local governments and residents on the two versions, Tsai said.

Once the program takes effect, all insured citizens will be eligible to apply for some type of long-term care, following evaluation by a planned bureau in charge of the execution of the program and the social welfare authorities, Tsai explained. The insured will be provided services based on the terms and conditions of their insurance plan, including in-home nursing, and organizational care, he added.

At present, the most important task of the government is to build long-term care facilities, partner with long term care organizations, and help train skilled caregivers in preparation for the implementation of the program, Tsai said.

If the bill clears the legislative floor, a bureau responsible for the program's implementation will be established to handle related affairs, he said. The bureau will be under the jurisdiction of the existing Department of Health or the proposed Ministry of Health and Welfare, he added.
At the Cabinet meeting, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed the hope that the program will be written into legislation next year to pave the way for its implementation by 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: President joins 4 km run to promote Deaflympics

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou took part in a 4-kilometer road run Sunday that was designed to promote the upcoming Taipei Deaflympics.
Ma joined some 3,000 other people on the run -- dubbed "Power in Me" -- from the Presidential Office plaza through the streets of Taipei.

There will also be a series of large-scale performances to promote the 21st Summer Deaflympics Taipei 2009, which is expected to draw over 10,000 people from 85 countries.

The performances will include Taiwanese operas as well as shows staged by the world-famous creative organization Blue Man Group, a folk music and dance troupe from China's Yunnan Province, and aboriginal singers, Sheng said.

The report stated that Shih's mother, who was raising her child single-handedly, was suffering from terminal cancer and may not live to see her daughter grow up.
Ma, who was serving as KMT chairman at that time, began to write to his young fan out of concern and to provide financial and other assistance to her through his office.
Toward the end of her life, Shih's mother put the girl into the care of a friend but the child refused to leave her mother and stayed with her until her death in 2006.
After that, the girl was put into Kangda House, which enrolled her in a boarding school. She returned to the halfway house only on weekends.
During this time, Ma was writing to Shih regularly and continued to do so even after he was elected president of the country.
During Sunday's meeting, Shih broke into tears when the president gave her a warm hug.
Ma urged the teenager to call him or write to him whenever she wants to.
"As president of the state, I am capable of doing more for you than before," he assured her.
He encouraged the girl to face adversity with courage, confidence and patience, and he extended his thanks to Kangda House for taking care of Shih and other girls who need help.
Kangda House, founded in 1998, shelters girls who have been abused, who are dropouts, or delinquents.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to set up marine affairs ministry

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that his administration will set up a marine affairs ministry in two phases.
He made the remarks at the end of an anti-terrorism drill carried out by the Coast Guard Administration at the Kaohsiung Harbor.
"As a country lies between the East China Sea and South China Sea, Taiwan plays a special strategic role, and thereby needs a ministry in charge of marine affairs." Ma said.

Reciting a plan included in his campaign promise, the president said, his administration will set up a marine affairs commission which will be enlarged and converted gradually into a ministry to formulate and enforce the country's marine policy.

Noting that Taiwan ranks 10th in the world in terms of its annual fish catch, Ma, whose four-year term will end in 2012 and can be reelected no more than once, said the government will budget NT$25 billion (US$7.8 billion) to buy a frigate with a displacement of more than 2000 tons in 2017 to boost the Coast Guard's strength.
The largest frigate owned by the Coast Guard Administration now has a displacement of 1800 tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 8, or the 16th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard." "But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: The expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Gov't plans marine affairs council as precursor to ministry

TEXT.P: The administration plans to establish a Cabinet-level marine affairs council then later upgrade it to a full ministry, the head of a governmental research agency said Monday.

The marine affairs council will be established to gather information related to the portfolio and to coordinate with other Cabinet-level agencies on relevant policies, said Jiang Yi-huah, minister in charge of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

The proposed council will be responsible for implementing policy on matters ranging from marine industry, resources, ecology, culture and education, to security of the country's maritime territory, Jiang said.

He said that right now there is no timetable for upgrading the planned marine affairs council to a ministry. The necessity for a ministry will be determined based on the contents of the relevant policies and how the council performs, he added.

Jiang made the remarks during a legislative committee meeting at which opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators criticized President Ma Ying-jeou for failing to set up a marine affairs ministry as promised during his election campaign.
The DPP legislators said that Ma has been in office for more than one year and there are as yet no plans in sight for the establishment of a marine affairs ministry.
Ma, during a whirlwind visit to the southern port city of Kaohsiung the day before, said that his administration will set up a marine affairs ministry in two phases.
"Taiwan has a special strategic role in the region, located as it is in the area of the East China Sea and South China, and therefore needs a ministry to handle marine affairs." Ma said.

Reiterating one his campaign promises, the president said his administration will set up a marine affairs council which will be expanded and converted gradually into a ministry to formulate and enforce the country's marine policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local astronomer to receive NASA medal for space exploration work

TEXT.P: The U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) is scheduled to confer a medal June 9 on an astronomy professor at National Central University (NCU) in recognition of his achievements on a Saturn exploration space project.

Ip Wing-huen, a professor at NCU's Graduate Institute of Astronomy, is an internationally renowned astronomer and one of the initiators of the "Cassini- Huygens" space mission, an international collaboration project involving NASA, the European Space Agency (ESA) and the Italian Space Agency (ASI).

Ip, along with two other initiators, Daniel Gautier from the Observatoire Meudon and Toby Owen from the University of Hawaii, has been chosen to receive the NASA's Exceptional Public Service Medal, NCU said in a press release.
Ip's daughter Anita Ip will accept the award on behalf of her father at an award ceremony to be held at NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California on June 9, NCU added.
"Everyone has dreams but realizing them is most important, " Ip said in the press release.

He said that it is because planetary science received scant attention in the early 1980s that a budding astronomer like him was able to initiate the project. Studying astronomy is a long path, he said, as he thanked his wife for her full support during the time he was committed to the Cassini project.

The US$3.26 billion Cassini-Huygens project was launched on Oct. 15, 1997 with the participation of 256 scientists from 18 countries. It is the second largest space mission next to the International Space Station program.

The mission is composed of two elements, the NASA Cassini orbiter and the ESA Huygens probe, and is aimed at studying the planet Saturn and its moons. The Huygens probe landed on Saturn's moon Titan Jan. 14, 2005 and began transmitting scientific data, which helped scientists in their study of not only the atmospheric structure of Titan, but also of the origin of life on earth.

NASA announced on April 18, 2008 a two year extension of the exploration, which is called the "Cassini Equinox mission," as it is seeking answers to new questions that arose from the first orbit of Saturn by the spacecraft Cassini.

Ip, who was born in Macau and was employed as the chief scientist at Taiwan's National Space Organization in 1991, said that investment in scientific research to is crucial to social sustainable development, as this encourages scientific creativity in a country.

"Back in the 1980s, there were only two Titan experts in Europe, but they were already planning to go to Titian. That was because Europe had hundreds of years of scientific development and historical heritage and could therefore invest in what seemed unachievable at the time," he said.

Ip is now heading a project to build what is called the Lulin Two-meter Telescope at Lulin Observatory in the Yushan National Park in central Taiwan. This project would allow greater participation by Taiwanese scientists in major international astronomical projects, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan helps train Afghan health care personnel

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Nurses Association started a nursing training program for 10 Afghan trainees Monday, Taiwan's first effort in helping the war-worn country develop its health care personnel, the association announced that same day.

The association, a Taipei-based civic group that includes the promotion of international nursing services among its functions, organized the program with the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , the Cabinet-level Department of Health and the government-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
The trainees arrived in Taiwan June 5 and started with two days of classroom instruction Monday, according to the association.

They will then receive clinical training at the Tri-Service General Hospital in Taipei June 10-Aug. 26 to learn about maternal and child health, wound care, emergency medical treatment, community health care and nursing administration.

Sun Huei-fang, director-general of the hospital's Department of Nursing, said the trainees will learn skills and gain experience in various medical fields such as surgery, anesthesiology, pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology, in the three-month program.
They will also benefit from the hospital's resources for treating the war injuries common in the country as a result of the conflict there, Sun said.
Afghanistan has suffered continuous civil war, in addition to foreign intervention, since the 1970s.

The 10 trainees were recommended by Afghanistan's non-profit Shuhada Organization, which operates clinics and hospitals in Afghanistan and Pakistan dedicated to the provision of health care to Afghan women and girls.
It also operates schools for girls and boys in Afghanistan and for Afghan refugees in the city of Quetta in neighboring Pakistan.

Sima Samar, founder of the organization, was presented with the 2008 Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, receiving the award from President Ma Ying-jeou last December.
Samar served as deputy prime minister and minister of women's affairs in the interim administration of Afghanistan from Dec. 22, 2001 to June 22, 2002.

According to David Wu, vice chairman of the MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, Samar wrote to him after returning to Afghanistan to express hope that Taiwan's non- government organizations can provide help to improve Afghanistan's medical environment.

Wu said he hopes Taiwan can contribute more knowledge and experience in medical care -- one of Taiwan's areas of expertise -- to the world, and that the training program will help its non-government organizations make better connections with international aid efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more confirmed swine flu cases reported

TEXT.P: The Central Epidemics Command Center reported Monday two more cases of imported swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1) , bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 21.

The center said the 20th case is a 27-year-old woman who traveled with her husband to New York May 11 on a backpacking tour and was detected with a fever at the airport upon her return to Taiwan June 6.

A center official said the woman began feeling unwell June 3 and took over-the- counter medication. She wore a mask throughout the flight and the official estimated that the passengers who shared the flight with her had no risk of being infected -- although her husband was given anti-flu medicine as a precautionary measure.
The official said the 21st case is a 21-year-old student who went to the United States in January to study. She toured New York and Los Angles before returning to Taiwan June 3.
As she reported that she had stayed at home since her return, the center issued anti-flu medicine to five members of her family.
As of 2 p.m. Monday, 73 countries have officially reported 25,288 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 139 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: President signs GPA accession instrument

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou signed an instrument of accession to the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) Monday, completing the procedure to make Taiwan the 41st signatory to the multilateral accord.
This means that the Taiwan's government procurement market will be open to other GPA members, and vice versa, based on the principles of reciprocity and national parity.

Noting that the government procurement market in the other GPA signatory countries totals US$960 billion per year, Ma said his administration will spare no effort to assist Taiwanese companies to explore markets around the world that will now be open to them.
Taiwan's public sector markets will also be open to the other GPA signatory countries.
"The multi-billion dollar 'i-Taiwan 12 Development Projects' that the administration has been pushing since early this year are good sources of government procurement for foreign bidders," he added.

Ma said joining the GPA was one of the most important commitments that Taiwan made after it was admitted to the World Trade Organization in 2002. The consultations for GPA accession were completed that same year, but Taiwan could not enter into the accord until this year because of differences across the Taiwan Strait.
Ma said that since he took office in May 2008, he has been striving to employ a "modus vivendi" or pragmatic diplomatic strategy in relations with China and other countries in the world.

After strenuous efforts by Taiwan to communicate with the WTO, the WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved Taiwan's application to enter the GPA on Dec. 9, 2008 and the Legislative Yuan endorsed the decision May 15, Ma added.
The GPA was adopted by the WTO in 1981 with the purpose of opening up as much government procurement as possible to international competition.

It was designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.

Noting that Taiwan hopes to play a more active and responsible role in the international community, Ma said the country will continue to study international covenants to facilitate its efforts to integrate into the world.

He added that because Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, his administration will pull out all the stops, including ratifying international covenants as domestic laws, to achieve international participation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dementia sufferer numbers increasing in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A signing activity for an online global petition calling for dementia to be made a health-care priority has been launched, the non-profit Taiwan Alzheimer's Disease Association (TADA) said Monday.
The petition aims to increase government awareness of the disease and improve the quality of life and care for individuals with dementia, according to the association.
The association organized a promotional activity Sunday to encourage local people to sign the Global Charter for Alzheimer's Disease petition.
During the Sunday event, the association also called on the government to adopt a more active and pragmatic approach toward care for dementia sufferers.

Chen Ta-fu, a doctor at the Neurology Department of National Taiwan University Hospital who concurrently serves as deputy chief of the TADA's education and publicity section, estimated the dementia prevalence among different age groups at 1.2 percent of people aged 65-69, 2.2 percent of those aged 70-74, 4.3 percent of those aged 75-79, 8.4 percent of those aged 80-84, 16.3 percent of those aged 85-89 and 30.9 percent of those aged 90 or over.

In Taiwan, the population of people suffering from dementia is around 160,000, a number that is expected to exceed 620,000 by 2056, or an increase of 10,000 people every year, according to TADA President Lee Ming-bing.

"This means that elderly population ratio is increasing and that the number of elderly citizens supported by every 100 young and middle-aged people will have increased from 14 to 75 by that time, " Lee elaborated.

At present, there are 2.4 million people aged 65 or over in the country, said Huang Pi-hsia, director of the Department of Social Affairs under the Ministry of the Interior. Of these, 10 percent are classed as disabled and 5 percent of those suffer from dementia. Approximately 20,000 dementia sufferers are being cared for by various organizations and 120,000 are using services provided by their communities.
Huang suggested that future services for dementia sufferers should focus on local communities, such as setting up special areas, day care services and group homes.

At present, the assessment criteria for disability are different to those for dementia and elderly people with dementia are usually otherwise healthy and cannot be diagnosed in the early stages of the disease, according to TADA Secretary-General Tang Li-yu. They therefore require different care than other disabled elderly people, she said.

According to Lee, two major reforms of social welfare policy are in the works this year, including a long-term care insurance system and a scheme for international classification of functioning, disability and health, both of which have significant influence on the welfare of dementia patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chance of yuan being adopted as Asian currency low: economist

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese economist said Monday that the possibility of the yuan being adopted as the single currency in Asia is not very high because nations like Japan and India are unlikely to support that idea.

Cheng Siwei, who is regarded as a pioneer in China's risk investment industry, made the remarks on the sidelines of a symposium held by Taipei-based Shih Hsin University to discuss risks and survival strategies in relation to the global financial storm.

Cheng, a former vice chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China, is now the dean of the Graduate School of Management at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. He is in Taiwan at the invitation of Shih Hsin University to deliver a speech at the symposium.
Asked about a proposal to create a regional currency along the lines of the euro arrangement, Cheng said that "it will be a long time before there could be an Asian dollar."
"It would take at least 10 years," the economist said, explaining that it took Europe a decade to initiate, plan, and implement its single currency mechanism.

It would take even longer for Asian countries to develop a similar currency system in the region because the differences in economic conditions and degrees of economic development among Asian economies are greater than among European countries, Cheng said.
A single currency cannot be successfully adopted unless the gaps narrow in the economic conditions of the countries in the region, he said.
Asked whether he thought the yuan could become the regional currency, Cheng said that would be very difficult.

As to the suggested establishment of a yuan-based clearance and settlement mechanism in light of the free trade integration of 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China, Cheng said "we agree" to that proposal, but cannot force people to accept it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese exports in May set six-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwanese exports in May amounted to US$16.17 billion, setting a six-month high, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Monday.

The figure represented a decrease of 31.4 percent from the same month of last year, although the decline was less than the average of 36 percent for the first four months, as well as the drop of 41.9 percent recorded last December.
Imports in May totaled US$13.01 billion, up 2.3 percent, or US$300 million from the previous month, which represented a decline of 39.1 percent year-on-year.
Taiwan recorded a trade surplus of US$3.17 billion in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.155 to close at NT$32.875.
A total of US$1.19 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.920 and fluctuated between NT$32.658 and NT$32.924.

DOC.HEADLINE: Selling pressure drives share prices down sharply

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed 3.33 percent lower Monday, dropping below the 6,700-point level and their 10-day moving average due to strong selling pressure.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 228.72 points to close at 6,628.02.
The local bourse opened at the day's high of 6,907.32 and dropped to the day's low of 6,628.02.
The market pullback came following recent gains after the stock market rose above the index's 10-year moving average of 6,434 last month.
A total of 5.65 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$147.3 billion (US$ 4.48 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares dropping the most at 5.3 percent. Construction stocks dropped 4.4 percent, cement issues fell 3.6 percent, textile shares shed 3.5 percent, paper and pulp stocks lost 3.3 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 3.0 percent, and foodstuff shares fell 2.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,829 to 444, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.91 billion.

Traditional industry stocks outperformed the overall market, with Shihlin Paper Corp., Shihlin Electric and Engineering Corp. and Shinkong Textile Co. rising by their 7 percent daily maximum limit at one point.
However, strong selling pressure sent big-cap shares and financial and banking stocks tumbling.
Morgan Stanley analyst Jesse Wang said that despite Monday's fall, the worst time to invest in Taiwan's stock market has passed.

He predicted that the market could test the 8,500-point level by the end of this year because of unprecedented market liquidity and Taiwan's rapidly warming ties with China, which are expected to help fuel economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH firm on qualification tests for returning medical students

TEXT.P: Returning Taiwanese students with diplomas issued by foreign medical schools must sit the Ministry of Education's qualification test and complete an internship at an appointed local hospital before they can qualify for the state licensing examination, the health minister said Monday.

Yeh Ching-chun, minister of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said the DOH will stand firm on this requirement so as to better protect the people's health. He was referring to a demand by some Taiwanese graduates from Polish medical schools that they be allowed to take part in the national licensing examination without going through the first two stages.

In accordance with the present Physician Act, Taiwanese medical school graduates, except those who obtain a diploma at medical institutes in the United States, Japan, the European Union, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore and Hong Kong, must meet the requirement before participating in the state licensing examination.

However, an amendment to the law put forward by the DOH and passed by the Cabinet June 4, as well as other revisions submitted by legislators from ruling and opposition parties, have coincided to end these exceptions, so that all medical school students educated abroad will have to sit the qualification tests and complete internship first.
Although Yeh praised Poland's level of medical education, he said that as many as 150 Taiwanese students opt to study medicine in Poland every year.

According to Yeh, Taiwanese students do not have to take an examination to enter Poland's medical institutes, but students from Taiwan who take courses in English are not allowed to practice in Poland after graduation.
"This is a strange system and it seems that Poland allows for the system to serve Taiwanese students," he said.

It is estimated that over 600 Taiwanese students are studying in Polish medical schools, whose desire to practice in Taiwan after they return from Poland might be lessened by the outcome of the law amendment.
Thousands of medical students took to the streets in late May to demand that the government revise the law to level the playing field for local graduates.

They were especially unhappy with students returning from Poland, saying that in recent years, local agents have made lucrative profits by recruiting Taiwanese senior high school students to study in the East European country, where the tuition is cheaper and the entry threshold is lower.

In Taiwan, there is fierce competition among senior high school students each year for only around 700 local medical school places, which means only 0.7 percent of the some 100,000 high school graduates each year can find a place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Russia relations progressing well: representative

TEXT.P: Russia's top diplomat in Taipei said Monday that bilateral relations between Taiwan and Russia are progressing well and that the opening of a retail store in Taipei for the oldest Russian winery is a further step in the promotion of exchanges between the two countries.

"Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Russia are progressing now. Compared to 15 years ago when there was not much contact, the relations are moving in a very good way, " said Sergey N. Gubarev, head of the Representative Office in Taipei for the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation.

Gubarev made the remarks at a ribbon-cutting ceremony to open the first local retail store of Massandra, the oldest winery in Russia which supplies top quality wine to Russian Czars and the royal family.
The wine store will contribute to the promotion of bilateral trade relations, Gubarev told the Central News Agency.

The Representative Office in Taipei for the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation serves as the de facto Russian embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Noting that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia reached a record US$4 billion in 2008, Gubarev said that there is close economic cooperation between the two sides.

He cited as an example the fact that Taiwan's Foxconn Technology Group, the world's largest provider of electronics manufacturing services, has invested US$50 million to build a computer assembly plant in St. Petersburg.
Also, the Taiwanese company Green Country was recently awarded a contract to construct an aquarium in Vladivostok, which is scheduled to open in 2011, he added.

People-to-people exchanges are also vibrant, with some 300 Taiwanese students in Russia and 200 Russian students in Taiwan, Gubarev said, adding that around 10,000 to 12,000 Taiwanese travelers go to Russia each year.

Alexander Braslavskiy, president of the Russian Business Development Center in Taiwan and owner of the wine store, said that he hopes the store will help bridge the cultural gap between Taiwan and Russia and serve as a platform for people in Taiwan to better understand the history of Russia.

Established in 1894 under the order of Russian Czar Nicholas II, the Massandra winery is frequently honored as the finest in Russia. The winery holds a Guinness World Record for its collection of over a million bottles of both Russian and Western European wines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin wants FPG naphtha cracker closed on cancer fears

TEXT.P: A sub-group of the Yunlin County Council said Monday they want a chemical plant owned by Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in the southwestern Taiwan county to suspend operations immediately to prevent locals from being further inflicted with cancer-causing air pollution from the plant.

The Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant in Mailiao, Yunlin has been in operation since 1999. Naphtha cracking plants produce the raw materials for plastics. Cracking is a refining process using heat and pressure.

The sub-group formed by Yunlin councilors from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cited results of an investigation conducted by professor Chan Chang-chuan with National Taiwan University which indicated that cancer rates in the areas near the plant had grown substantially since the factory was opened.

According to the investigation report, cancer incidents have grown noticeably among residents in Mailiao township and four other adjacent townships of Taisi, Dongshih, Lunbei and Sihhu since the cracking plant began to emit volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in 1999.

Infliction rates of liver cancer have grown 30 percent in Taisi township over the past nine years, according to the investigation conducted by Chan under the consignment of the Yunlin County Environmental Protection Bureau.

Noting that the Yunlin residents' cancer infliction rate is now 1.7 times higher than the average of residents in other cities and counties around Taiwan, DPP Councilor Liao Ching-hsiang said measures must be taken immediately to address the issue.

Meanwhile, the Formosa office in Mailiao said that the Yunlin County Environmental Protection Bureau had conducted testing of the air in the areas near the cracking plant many times over the past several years and that the air quality was found to be normal.
"It's hard to pinpoint one single factor as the culprit of cancers since factors that may cause cancers are so many, " said a Formosa staff member.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government evaluating allowing local 12-inch fabs in China

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is evaluating whether to allow semiconductor manufacturers to move their 12-inch wafer fabs to China, an evaluation that will be the ministry's main task in the second half of the year, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou said Monday.
Hwang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to lawmakers' questions stemming from an earlier statement on the move by President Ma Ying- jeou.
Ma said in a statement June 5 after meeting Applied Materials Inc. (AMAT.O) President and CEO Michael Splinter that Taiwan does not rule out allowing local 12-inch wafer fabs to go to China.

Responding to a question from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua, Hwang said the policy has not yet been hammered out and added that the ministry's evaluation will craft measures to keep research and development and advanced technology in Taiwan, although he admitted it is unavoidable that some technicians and engineers will move to China.
Taiwanese businessmen will "not necessarily" immediately invest in China once the government lifts the restrictions, according to Hwang.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Pan Meng-an said that establishing a 12-inch fab in China costs at least NT$100 billion (US$3.04 billion) , and will attract economic resources from up- and down-stream, which he warned will result in the "eradication" of the industry from Taiwan.

Hwang said the ministry's evaluation will focus on the division of labor between Taiwan and China, emphasizing that state-of-the-art technology will be made to stay in Taiwan, while older technology will be allowed to move to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Increased subsidies announced for Hualien rice farmers

TEXT.P: Rice farmers in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County will get more subsidies for their spring crops damaged by low temperatures in early April, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Monday.

The COA's Agriculture and Food Agency announced that Hualien rice farmers will be subsidized NT$16,000 (US$486.9) in cash for each hectare of land, if 20 percent of their rice paddy or more was hit by the cold weather. Farmers whose paddy was at least 80 percent damaged will get an additional NT$12,000 in clean- up fees.
The NT$16,000 was on par with the request by Hualien farmers, and twice the level the COA was originally planning to give to farmers.

The increased subsidies come a couple of days after hundreds of rice farmers from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties protested last Friday in front of the COA headquarters, demanding it pay more subsidies for the damage done to their crops by the low temperatures.
According to the Hualien County, 3,229 hectares of the county's farmland were affected by the weather condition, resulting in a loss of rice production worth NT$169.5 million.
Meanwhile, some rice paddies in Taitung and Ylan counties were also affected. But the COA is still investigating to what extent the two counties in eastern Taiwan have been affected.
Despite damage to the crops' spring harvest in eastern Taiwan, rice prices have remained stable, as the damaged crops' impact on the country's overall rice production is limited.
Rice planted in eastern Taiwan enjoys widespread popularity among consumers because of its high quality. The rice has also successfully edged into the quality-conscious Japanese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paiwan artist tells tribal stories on coffee cups

TEXT.P: Am artist from Pingtung County in southern Taiwan who belongs to the Paiwan aboriginal tribe has been telling stories of his people through paintings on coffee cups in the hope that the common modern utility can spread greater understanding of his tribe's culture.

Fifty-year-old Ljegeay Mavalin said Monday in an interview with CNA he hopes that when people sip coffee out of his cups with their friends, they will talk to each other about the stories told on the receptacles.
"In this way the stories will be passed on, " he said, adding that he has thought long and hard since embarking on his artistic career about how to keep Paiwan culture alive in the modern world.
Asked what inspired him to use coffee cups as his canvas, Ljegeay -- who uses only his first name -- said coffee has a very big global market, which gives his work a large area in which to circulate.
The stories feature traditional trappings of Paiwan life such as tribal ceramic pots, glass beads and the Formosan sambar deer.
The image of the Formosa sambar in particular is often seen in Ljegeay's recent work, because, he said, he wants to raise consciousness about environmental protection.

In the past, the animal was easily spotted in the mountains all over Taiwan. Today, however, the species is seen only rarely at high altitude, having been forced upward by human encroachment, Ljegeay said.
His unique cups have been selected this year by the Pingtung county government as one of the best souvenirs of the county.
Marketing the product along with coffee grown by his tribe in the Pingtung mountains, Ljegeay said he wants not just sell Paiwan culture but also to promote tribal industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Brisk business outlook for central science park

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park Administration forecast Monday that the park's business turnover for the whole of this year will exceed NT$250 billion (US$7.6 billion) , based on increased monthly growth.

Thanks to improved business conditions around the globe since late last year, the park recorded a combined NT$29.5 billion in revenue for the March-April period, marking a 55 percent rise over the January-February level, according to statistics compiled by the administration.
In terms of industry, opto-electronics contributed the largest share of 77.58 percent to the park's total turnover in March and April, followed by the semiconductor industry with 19.26 percent.
The park's business is expected to continue showing monthly growth over the next several months, administration officials said.
The park's business turnover in February totaled NT$10.3 billion (US$308 million) , up by about 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, according to administration tallies.
The Central Taiwan Science Park, which has facilities in Taichung City, Taichung County and in nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, houses more than 150 high- tech companies.
It was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan and is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two located in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu and in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports will show positive annual growth late this year: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) predicted Monday that the annual growth rate for Taiwanese exports will turn from negative to positive this year, but not until November or December.
Lin Lee-jen, director of the ministry's Department of Statistics, noted that exports in the first 10 months of last year were high and she made her forecast based on this high comparison base.
Taiwan's exports in November 2008 totaled US$16.77 billion, down sharply from the preceding month's US$20.81 billion.

Lin's remarks came as the department unveiled May's export figures, which amounted to US$16.17 billion, a new high over the past six months and an increase of 8.9 percent, or US$1.33 billion, over the April figure.

However, the amount represented a decrease of US$7.42 billion, or 31.4 percent, from the same month of last year, a smaller decline than the average of 36 percent for the first four months and also less than the drop of 41.9 percent recorded last December.
The MOF said this shows that "export decline has slowed down" and that "exports will gradually pick up."
Imports in May totaled US$13.01 billion, up for the fifth consecutive year and representing an increase of US$300 million from April, giving the country a trade surplus of US$3.17 billion.

Lin said Taiwan's exports to major trading partners all recorded increases. Among them, the increases were most visible in the China and Hong Kong figures, followed by the six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries -- Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam.

The ratio of exports to China and Hong Kong accounted for 41.7 percent of the total exports for May, up from 29.9 percent recorded for January this year, while the ratio for ASEAN accounted for 15 percent of the total and the ratios for the United States, Europe and Japan were 11.4 percent, 10.3 percent and 7.1 percent, respectively.
Among the export increases, electronics products increased by US$230 million, chemicals increased by US$210 million and optical instrument increased by US$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation visits Taiwan to discuss judicial exchanges

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese legal officials arrived in Taiwan Monday at the invitation of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation for a week-long visit to discuss judicial exchanges with the Taiwanese officials.
The 16-member delegation is headed by Zhou Ning, director of the Department of Law and Regulation of the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office.

Zhou said upon arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that the goal of the visit is to talk with relevant Taiwanese authorities on technical issues relating to a planned agreement by the two sides of Taiwan Strait to jointly combat crime.

The members of the delegation also include Shao Wenhong, president of the People's Court Daily; Cai Xiaoxue, head of the administrative tribunal of the Supreme People's Court; and Xu Jinhuei of the Supreme People's Procuratorate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade, economy to be theme of president's upcoming overseas visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's second Central America diplomatic tour this year will center on promoting trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region, Presidential Office sources said Monday.
Fresh from a three-leg Central America visit from May 26-June 4 that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again late this month on a similar diplomatic mission.

High on Ma's itinerary this time around will be attending the inauguration of Panama President-elect Ricardo Martinelli. The main event of his just-concluded trip was the inauguration of new El Salvador President Mauricio Funes.

Ma is scheduled to depart Taipei June 29 for Panama City via San Francisco. Following the Panama visit, he will proceed to Nicaragua and then Honduras for state visits before returning to Taipei July 7 via a transit stop in Hawaii.

Presidential Office sources said that although Ma canceled a plan to meet with Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega while both of them were in San Salvador early this month to attend Funes' inauguration, Ma's plan to visit Nicaragua during his upcoming diplomatic tour remains unchanged.
According to the sources, Ma had courtesy phone conversations with Ortega before leaving the Salvadoran capital June 2 for home.

"The cancellation of the meeting with Ortega in San Salvador will neither affect President Ma's Nicaragua travel plan nor relations between the two countries, " said a Presidential Office staffer who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Noting that Ma's last Central America tour focused on promoting cultural exchanges, the official said the Panama-Nicaragua-Honduras trip will carry a theme of promoting trade and economic ties.

As many Taiwanese business groups have major investment projects in Panama, the official went on, some prominent business executives such as Evergreen Marine Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa will accompany Ma on his trip.
Ma will also charter a plane from EVA Airways -- an Evergreen Marine Group affiliate -- to carry him and his entourage.
First lady Chow Mei-ching and the famed Ju Percussion Group will also accompany Ma as they did on his last trip, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction on new AIT compound to start June 22

TEXT.P: Construction on a new office complex of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) in Taipei's Neihu District will get underway June 22, the representative office of the United States said Monday.

According to AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges, the U.S. State Department approved last October a US$176 million budget for the construction project to house the AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
AIT Director Stephen Young will preside over a groundbreaking ceremony June 22, Hodges said.

Completion of the first phase of the project, on a 6.5-hectare site that has been leased for 99 years from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, Taiwan's representative office in the United States, is expected to take about two years.

The first phase of the project will include clearing and grading the site in suburban Neihu District as well as building a perimeter security system, vehicular and pedestrian access control facilities, recreational facilities, guards quarters, maintenance buildings and a surface parking area.
The second phase of the project, which will include the construction of the new office facility, will take another two-and-a-half years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 9, 2009

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese exports in May set six-month high

TEXT.P: Taiwanese exports in May amounted to US$16.17 billion, setting a six-month high, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Monday.

The figure represented a decrease of 31.4 percent from the same month of last year, although the decline was less than the average of 36 percent for the first four months, as well as the drop of 41.9 percent recorded last December.
Imports in May totaled US$13.01 billion, up 2.3 percent, or US$300 million from the previous month, which represented a decline of 39.1 percent year-on-year.
Taiwan recorded a trade surplus of US$3.17 billion in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.155 to close at NT$32.875.
A total of US$1.19 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.920 and fluctuated between NT$32.658 and NT$32.924.

DOC.HEADLINE: Selling pressure drives share prices down sharply

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high but closed 3.33 percent lower Monday, dropping below the 6,700-point level and their 10-day moving average due to strong selling pressure.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 228.72 points to close at 6,628.02.
The local bourse opened at the day's high of 6,907.32 and dropped to the day's low of 6,628.02.
The market pullback came following recent gains after the stock market rose above the index's 10-year moving average of 6,434 last month.
A total of 5.65 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$147.3 billion (US$ 4.48 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares dropping the most at 5.3 percent. Construction stocks dropped 4.4 percent, cement issues fell 3.6 percent, textile shares shed 3.5 percent, paper and pulp stocks lost 3.3 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 3.0 percent, and foodstuff shares fell 2.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,829 to 444, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.91 billion.

Traditional industry stocks outperformed the overall market, with Shihlin Paper Corp., Shihlin Electric and Engineering Corp. and Shinkong Textile Co. rising by their 7 percent daily maximum limit at one point.
However, strong selling pressure sent big-cap shares and financial and banking stocks tumbling.
Morgan Stanley analyst Jesse Wang said that despite Monday's fall, the worst time to invest in Taiwan's stock market has passed.

He predicted that the market could test the 8,500-point level by the end of this year because of unprecedented market liquidity and Taiwan's rapidly warming ties with China, which are expected to help fuel economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH firm on qualification tests for returning medical students

TEXT.P: Returning Taiwanese students with diplomas issued by foreign medical schools must sit the Ministry of Education's qualification test and complete an internship at an appointed local hospital before they can qualify for the state licensing examination, the health minister said Monday.

Yeh Ching-chun, minister of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH), said the DOH will stand firm on this requirement so as to better protect the people's health. He was referring to a demand by some Taiwanese graduates from Polish medical schools that they be allowed to take part in the national licensing examination without going through the first two stages.

In accordance with the present Physician Act, Taiwanese medical school graduates, except those who obtain a diploma at medical institutes in the United States, Japan, the European Union, Canada, South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore and Hong Kong, must meet the requirement before participating in the state licensing examination.

However, an amendment to the law put forward by the DOH and passed by the Cabinet June 4, as well as other revisions submitted by legislators from ruling and opposition parties, have coincided to end these exceptions, so that all medical school students educated abroad will have to sit the qualification tests and complete internship first.
Although Yeh praised Poland's level of medical education, he said that as many as 150 Taiwanese students opt to study medicine in Poland every year.

According to Yeh, Taiwanese students do not have to take an examination to enter Poland's medical institutes, but students from Taiwan who take courses in English are not allowed to practice in Poland after graduation.
"This is a strange system and it seems that Poland allows for the system to serve Taiwanese students," he said.

It is estimated that over 600 Taiwanese students are studying in Polish medical schools, whose desire to practice in Taiwan after they return from Poland might be lessened by the outcome of the law amendment.
Thousands of medical students took to the streets in late May to demand that the government revise the law to level the playing field for local graduates.

They were especially unhappy with students returning from Poland, saying that in recent years, local agents have made lucrative profits by recruiting Taiwanese senior high school students to study in the East European country, where the tuition is cheaper and the entry threshold is lower.

In Taiwan, there is fierce competition among senior high school students each year for only around 700 local medical school places, which means only 0.7 percent of the some 100,000 high school graduates each year can find a place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Russia relations progressing well: representative

TEXT.P: Russia's top diplomat in Taipei said Monday that bilateral relations between Taiwan and Russia are progressing well and that the opening of a retail store in Taipei for the oldest Russian winery is a further step in the promotion of exchanges between the two countries.

"Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Russia are progressing now. Compared to 15 years ago when there was not much contact, the relations are moving in a very good way, " said Sergey N. Gubarev, head of the Representative Office in Taipei for the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation.

Gubarev made the remarks at a ribbon-cutting ceremony to open the first local retail store of Massandra, the oldest winery in Russia which supplies top quality wine to Russian Czars and the royal family.
The wine store will contribute to the promotion of bilateral trade relations, Gubarev told the Central News Agency.

The Representative Office in Taipei for the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation serves as the de facto Russian embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Noting that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia reached a record US$4 billion in 2008, Gubarev said that there is close economic cooperation between the two sides.

He cited as an example the fact that Taiwan's Foxconn Technology Group, the world's largest provider of electronics manufacturing services, has invested US$50 million to build a computer assembly plant in St. Petersburg.
Also, the Taiwanese company Green Country was recently awarded a contract to construct an aquarium in Vladivostok, which is scheduled to open in 2011, he added.

People-to-people exchanges are also vibrant, with some 300 Taiwanese students in Russia and 200 Russian students in Taiwan, Gubarev said, adding that around 10,000 to 12,000 Taiwanese travelers go to Russia each year.

Alexander Braslavskiy, president of the Russian Business Development Center in Taiwan and owner of the wine store, said that he hopes the store will help bridge the cultural gap between Taiwan and Russia and serve as a platform for people in Taiwan to better understand the history of Russia.

Established in 1894 under the order of Russian Czar Nicholas II, the Massandra winery is frequently honored as the finest in Russia. The winery holds a Guinness World Record for its collection of over a million bottles of both Russian and Western European wines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin wants FPG naphtha cracker closed on cancer fears

TEXT.P: A sub-group of the Yunlin County Council said Monday they want a chemical plant owned by Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) in the southwestern Taiwan county to suspend operations immediately to prevent locals from being further inflicted with cancer-causing air pollution from the plant.

The Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant in Mailiao, Yunlin has been in operation since 1999. Naphtha cracking plants produce the raw materials for plastics. Cracking is a refining process using heat and pressure.

The sub-group formed by Yunlin councilors from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cited results of an investigation conducted by professor Chan Chang-chuan with National Taiwan University which indicated that cancer rates in the areas near the plant had grown substantially since the factory was opened.

According to the investigation report, cancer incidents have grown noticeably among residents in Mailiao township and four other adjacent townships of Taisi, Dongshih, Lunbei and Sihhu since the cracking plant began to emit volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in 1999.

Infliction rates of liver cancer have grown 30 percent in Taisi township over the past nine years, according to the investigation conducted by Chan under the consignment of the Yunlin County Environmental Protection Bureau.

Noting that the Yunlin residents' cancer infliction rate is now 1.7 times higher than the average of residents in other cities and counties around Taiwan, DPP Councilor Liao Ching-hsiang said measures must be taken immediately to address the issue.

Meanwhile, the Formosa office in Mailiao said that the Yunlin County Environmental Protection Bureau had conducted testing of the air in the areas near the cracking plant many times over the past several years and that the air quality was found to be normal.
"It's hard to pinpoint one single factor as the culprit of cancers since factors that may cause cancers are so many, " said a Formosa staff member.

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Science Park Administration forecast Monday that the park's business turnover for the whole of this year will exceed NT$250 billion (US$7.6 billion) , based on increased monthly growth.

Thanks to improved business conditions around the globe since late last year, the park recorded a combined NT$29.5 billion in revenue for the March-April period, marking a 55 percent rise over the January-February level, according to statistics compiled by the administration.
In terms of industry, opto-electronics contributed the largest share of 77.58 percent to the park's total turnover in March and April, followed by the semiconductor industry with 19.26 percent.
The park's business is expected to continue showing monthly growth over the next several months, administration officials said.
The park's business turnover in February totaled NT$10.3 billion (US$308 million) , up by about 20 percent over the January figure of NT$8.6 billion, according to administration tallies.
The Central Taiwan Science Park, which has facilities in Taichung City, Taichung County and in nearby Changhua and Yunlin counties, houses more than 150 high- tech companies.
It was established in 2002 by the Executive Yuan and is one of three major science parks in Taiwan, with the other two located in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu and in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exports will show positive annual growth late this year: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) predicted Monday that the annual growth rate for Taiwanese exports will turn from negative to positive this year, but not until November or December.
Lin Lee-jen, director of the ministry's Department of Statistics, noted that exports in the first 10 months of last year were high and she made her forecast based on this high comparison base.
Taiwan's exports in November 2008 totaled US$16.77 billion, down sharply from the preceding month's US$20.81 billion.

Lin's remarks came as the department unveiled May's export figures, which amounted to US$16.17 billion, a new high over the past six months and an increase of 8.9 percent, or US$1.33 billion, over the April figure.

However, the amount represented a decrease of US$7.42 billion, or 31.4 percent, from the same month of last year, a smaller decline than the average of 36 percent for the first four months and also less than the drop of 41.9 percent recorded last December.
The MOF said this shows that "export decline has slowed down" and that "exports will gradually pick up."
Imports in May totaled US$13.01 billion, up for the fifth consecutive year and representing an increase of US$300 million from April, giving the country a trade surplus of US$3.17 billion.

Lin said Taiwan's exports to major trading partners all recorded increases. Among them, the increases were most visible in the China and Hong Kong figures, followed by the six Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries -- Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam.

The ratio of exports to China and Hong Kong accounted for 41.7 percent of the total exports for May, up from 29.9 percent recorded for January this year, while the ratio for ASEAN accounted for 15 percent of the total and the ratios for the United States, Europe and Japan were 11.4 percent, 10.3 percent and 7.1 percent, respectively.
Among the export increases, electronics products increased by US$230 million, chemicals increased by US$210 million and optical instrument increased by US$200 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation visits Taiwan to discuss judicial exchanges

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese legal officials arrived in Taiwan Monday at the invitation of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation for a week-long visit to discuss judicial exchanges with the Taiwanese officials.
The 16-member delegation is headed by Zhou Ning, director of the Department of Law and Regulation of the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office.

Zhou said upon arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that the goal of the visit is to talk with relevant Taiwanese authorities on technical issues relating to a planned agreement by the two sides of Taiwan Strait to jointly combat crime.

The members of the delegation also include Shao Wenhong, president of the People's Court Daily; Cai Xiaoxue, head of the administrative tribunal of the Supreme People's Court; and Xu Jinhuei of the Supreme People's Procuratorate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade, economy to be theme of president's upcoming overseas visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's second Central America diplomatic tour this year will center on promoting trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region, Presidential Office sources said Monday.
Fresh from a three-leg Central America visit from May 26-June 4 that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again late this month on a similar diplomatic mission.

High on Ma's itinerary this time around will be attending the inauguration of Panama President-elect Ricardo Martinelli. The main event of his just-concluded trip was the inauguration of new El Salvador President Mauricio Funes.

Ma is scheduled to depart Taipei June 29 for Panama City via San Francisco. Following the Panama visit, he will proceed to Nicaragua and then Honduras for state visits before returning to Taipei July 7 via a transit stop in Hawaii.

Presidential Office sources said that although Ma canceled a plan to meet with Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega while both of them were in San Salvador early this month to attend Funes' inauguration, Ma's plan to visit Nicaragua during his upcoming diplomatic tour remains unchanged.
According to the sources, Ma had courtesy phone conversations with Ortega before leaving the Salvadoran capital June 2 for home.

"The cancellation of the meeting with Ortega in San Salvador will neither affect President Ma's Nicaragua travel plan nor relations between the two countries, " said a Presidential Office staffer who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Noting that Ma's last Central America tour focused on promoting cultural exchanges, the official said the Panama-Nicaragua-Honduras trip will carry a theme of promoting trade and economic ties.

As many Taiwanese business groups have major investment projects in Panama, the official went on, some prominent business executives such as Evergreen Marine Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa will accompany Ma on his trip.
Ma will also charter a plane from EVA Airways -- an Evergreen Marine Group affiliate -- to carry him and his entourage.
First lady Chow Mei-ching and the famed Ju Percussion Group will also accompany Ma as they did on his last trip, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction on new AIT compound to start June 22

TEXT.P: Construction on a new office complex of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) in Taipei's Neihu District will get underway June 22, the representative office of the United States said Monday.

According to AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges, the U.S. State Department approved last October a US$176 million budget for the construction project to house the AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
AIT Director Stephen Young will preside over a groundbreaking ceremony June 22, Hodges said.

Completion of the first phase of the project, on a 6.5-hectare site that has been leased for 99 years from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, Taiwan's representative office in the United States, is expected to take about two years.

The first phase of the project will include clearing and grading the site in suburban Neihu District as well as building a perimeter security system, vehicular and pedestrian access control facilities, recreational facilities, guards quarters, maintenance buildings and a surface parking area.
The second phase of the project, which will include the construction of the new office facility, will take another two-and-a-half years.

The weighted price index lost 228.72 points, or 3.33 percent, to close at 6,628.02 Monday.
