DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Population exceeds 23.06 million in May: interior ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national population was 23,063,027 as of the end of May, an increase of 74,599 or 0.325 percent from last year, according to the latest statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior.
The outlying counties of Kinmen and Penghu recorded the highest annual population growth rates at 6.086 percent and 2.291 percent, respectively, the statistical report showed.
The biggest decline was recorded in the offshore Lienchiang County at 1.798 percent, followed by Taipei City at 0.492 percent.
The male population in Taiwan was 11,626,940, while the female population was 11,436,087, statistics showed.
The number of registered households was 7.706 million at the end of May, up by 1.91 percent, or 144,780 households, from last year's figure, according to the report.

Taipei County had the highest number of registered households, 1.35 million, or 17.54 percent of the national total. Taipei City and Taoyuan County ranked second and third respectively in this category, accounting for 12.47 percent and 8.34 percent, respectively, of the total number in the country.

As for births and deaths, the statistics showed that 12,646 babies were born in May, with one born every 3.5 minutes, while the number of deaths in the same month was 10,327, an average of one every 4.3 minutes.
Meanwhile, 9,132 couples got married in May, while there were 4,233 divorces during the same period, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: President suggests learning simplified Chinese characters

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou proposed Tuesday that people learning Chinese should learn to read the traditional Chinese characters used in Taiwan and Hong Kong but at the same time should also know how to use the simplified character system engineered by the communist regime in China.
Ma said he hopes his proposal of "recognizing traditional Chinese characters but also knowing simplified" will be put on the agenda of discussions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Ma made the remarks at the Presidential Office in a meeting with a group of overseas Chinese who live in the United States.

Traditional Chinese characters and the simplified version are two standard sets of printed Chinese characters, with the traditional used in Taiwan as the official written language, while China uses the simplified characters it introduced in the 1950s in an effort to reduce illiteracy among rural Chinese.

Ma said he has spared no efforts to promote the use of traditional Chinese characters over the years and pointed out that the system is essential for people who want to read books written in China 2,000 or 3,000 years ago.

"There are few cultures in the world apart from Chinese whose writing systems have remained viable throughout so many different eras, " he said, underlining the importance of preserving the traditional system of writing Chinese characters.
Ma said that in many Chinese schools overseas, they teach students from Taiwan traditional characters, but lecture students from China using simplified.
He said it is a pity that those who only know simplified characters cannot read words in traditional characters, while people taught using traditional characters can quite easily read simplified.
Therefore, he proposed that traditional characters should be used in printing as much as possible to allow the Chinese canon to remain linked to tradition Chinese culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rare megamouth shark caught off Taitung

TEXT.P: A megamouth shark, one of the world's rarest species, was caught Monday by a fisherman from the eastern county of Taitung, marine biologists said Tuesday.

According to National Taiwan Ocean University's Department of Environmental Biology and Fisheries Science, the shark is only the 42nd that has been caught or sighted worldwide and the ninth in Taiwan since the species was discovered in 1976.

The shark was 3.9 meter long, weighed 350 kilograms and its mouth when opened measured 75 centimeters across. It was netted off the county's Chenggong coast and was sold Tuesday for NT$18,000 (US$549) to a local shark museum where it will be displayed as a preserved specimen.

The fish was identified by a researcher surnamed Tien, from the Eastern Marine Biology Research Center under the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Research Institute. Tien said the species is very unusual and that it was the first time in his career that he ever saw a megamouth shark.
Chen Wen-jung, the owner of the shark museum, said he has collected dozens of shark specimens but this was his first megamouth.
The last record of the species being spotted was in late March, when a 500-kilogram, 4-meter megamouth was caught off Burias Island in the Philippines.
The megamouth shark is so named because of its large mouth.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to visit South Pacific allies later this year: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it is planning for President Ma Ying-jeou to travel to the South Pacific in the later half of the year to attend the Taiwan-South Pacific leaders' summit in the Solomon Islands and to visit several diplomatic allies in the region.

"The preparations for the summit are progressing well and all the leaders of Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the region will most likely attend, " said Frances Lee, acting director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region are the Solomon Islands, the Marshall Islands, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru and Tuvalu.
According to Lee, this year's leaders' summit will touch on issues such as the global economic downturn, climate change and fishery resources.

The Foreign Ministry will also seek to establish a long-term cooperation mechanism with the allies based on the main objective stated in its recent foreign aid white paper, which is to provide more effective and meaningful assistance overseas, she added.
Details such as the exact date of the summit have not yet confirmed, but it will probably be in October or November, Lee said.

According to Lee, President Ma was greatly impressed with the World War II historical sites and the friendly and passionate people of Solomon Islands during his visit as a scholar to the country in 1997. The president is therefore excited about traveling to the South Pacific country again and is also planning to visit one or two other diplomatic allies in the region, she added.
The trip to the South Pacific, if it takes place, will be Ma's third diplomatic tour this year.

Fresh from a three-leg Central America visit May 26-June 4 that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again later this month to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Ricardo Martinelli and will then visit Nicaragua and Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.022 to close at NT$32.853.
A total of US$1.054 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.875 and fluctuated between NT$32.800 and NT$32.951.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX loses 213.63 points as selling pressure persists

TEXT.P: The weighted stock price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged 3.22 percent Tuesday, or 213.63 points, to close at 6,414.39 as strong selling pressure persisted.
The local bourse opened high at 6,636.84 before rising to the day's high of 6,640.44 and dropping below the 6,400-point level to the day's low of 6,394.34.
The sharp fall came after a big drop of 228.72 points a day before.
A total of 5.96 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$159.12 billion (US$ 4.84 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 6.5 percent. Construction stocks dropped 6.4 percent, banking and financial shares lost 4.6 percent, textile stocks dropped 4.2 percent, cement issues fell 3.7 percent, foodstuff shares shed 3.2 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 3.1 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks fell 2.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,997 to 338, with 60 stocks remaining unchanged.

Altogether, the three major institutional investors made net sales of NT$5.61 billion on shares -- NT$2.85 billion by foreign investors, NT$3.23 billion by investment trust firms and NT$477 million by securities firms.
Shares in the traditional industries, electronics, and financial and banking sectors took the brunt of the selling.
Wang Chao-li, an analyst with Polaris Securities Co., attributed the drop in electronics stocks to the impact of the off-peak effect and the appreciation of the local currency.
He predicted that the market will have a good chance of rebounding following two consecutive days of sharp losses and will hover between 6,000 and 6,600.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records three imported cases of swine flu from Thailand

TEXT.P: The health authorities reported Tuesday three new cases of swine flu imported from Thailand, bringing to 24 the total number of influenza A(H1N1) infections recorded in the country.

The three cases are students who were traveling in two separate graduation tours to Thailand June 1-7, which mainly stayed in Bangkok and Pattaya, according to Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) spokesman Shih Wen-yi.
One of the groups had 57 members, while the other had 17.

Two of the confirmed cases began displaying flu symptoms while in Thailand. They were sent to hospital immediately upon their June 7 arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport where they were detected as having fevers, Shih said.
The other confirmed case was in a group of six students who had complained of flu-like symptoms and were given blood tests, Shih went on.

He said 10 of the other students had been listed as suspected cases after reporting flu-like symptoms after their return, making it likely that the number of confirmed infections would further increase.
The CECC has informed the World Health Organization and the Thai government of the situation, Shih said.
According to the CECC, of the 24 cases recorded in Taiwan so far, only one has been indigenous and there have been no community outbreaks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City pins development hopes on airport

TEXT.P: A government blueprint to build a terminal for international flights at Taichung City's Chingchuankang Airport will definitely boost the central city's development, Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said Tuesday.

Construction of the facility will help the city move a step forward toward its desire to build an aviation park near the airport by linking adjacent areas that can be developed into a warehousing and commercial zone, Hsiao said.

The city government also looks forward to setting up a network that will connect the airport, Taichung Harbor, the Central Taiwan Science Park and the city center to give an additional boost to local development, he explained.

Hsiao's remarks came after the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) a day earlier approved an "overall development project and first-phase construction plan for an international airport in central Taiwan" submitted by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Under the project, the central government will earmark NT$3.9 billion (US$118.9 million) to build Chinachuankang Airport's international terminal by 2012, with the aim of serving 1.35 million passengers per year and promoting the international charter flight business in central Taiwan.
The CEPD plans to make Chingchuankang Airport into a regional hub serving passenger charter flights and cross-Taiwan Strait routes.
The central Taiwan airport served 1.1 million passengers last year, with 640,000 flying on domestic routes, while its international traffic volume has continued to grow in recent years.
According to CEPD statistics, the airport served a total of 461,575 travelers on international charter flights in 2008, compared with 3,528 in 2004.

Although Shanghai is the most popular Chinese destination among Taiwanese carriers, none have applied to ply the Taichung-Shanghai route due to the limitations of Chingchuankang Airport, which can only accommodate smaller planes with a seat capacity of some 100 passengers, despite the fact that scheduled cross-strait flights are set to be expanded in July.

In response to rising local demand, the CAA has asked China Airlines, EVA Airways and Trans Asia Airways, all of which fly to Shanghai from either Taipei or Kaohsiung, to offer one flight per week each from Chingchuankang Airport to Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeking contestants for 'Best Trip in the World' contest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 9 (CNA) 06/09/09 19:40:53 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Tourism Bureau is seeking more contestants for a contest to design the best itinerary for traveling in Taiwan - part of efforts to promote tourism on the island.
So far, the "Best Trip in the World -- Taiwan Explorers Wanted" contest has generated interest from people around the world and many teams have signed up.

The Bureau, however, is hoping more teams will register for the competition to attract more interest, especially online, about the island, which in previous decades had not promoted its tourism sector, focusing instead on its high-tech and electronics industries.
Anyone can enter the contest as long as his or her team has at least two people and at least one team member is a non-Taiwanese national.

Fifty teams which have the best itineraries will be selected and each will get NT$ 7,000 (around US$215) per day for up to 4 days, or NT$ 28,000 in total, to travel during those four days. Team members must buy their own airplane ticket to come to Taiwan but the Bureau can help them obtain special discounts from Taiwanese carriers.
The 50 teams will be selected based on how creative and inexpensive their itinerary is, as well as how feasible and popular it is with online readers.
Contestants must upload a video introducing their team on the contest website and submit their itinerary for their four-day trip in Taiwan by the deadline of June 30.
The most popular teams will be selected in each of the contest's three groups: Chinese, English, and Japanese.
During their four-day travels, the 50 teams must upload a short video about their daily adventures in Taiwan with a 200-word description on the official contest website.
The team that generates the most interest online stands the best chance of winning the grand prize - NT$1,000,000 (around US$30,446) to travel in Taiwan for a month.
The grand prize winning team will come back to Taiwan in February or March in 2010 for a one-month trip that will be used to promote Taiwan as a top travel destination to people overseas.
The Tourism Bureau will announce the list of 50 winning teams for the first stage of the contest by July 10.
Each of the winning teams must complete its itinerary from July 11 to Aug. 31.
Online voting results will be part of the criteria to choose the grand prize winner, which will be announced on Nov. 15.

The Tourism Bureau expects the contest will draw more international tourists to Taiwan who will share their travel experience with the world as a way to promote Taiwan tourism, the Bureau's New York representative office said.

Taiwan so far draws a little less than 4 million visitors a year, much less than its neighboring countries, even those that are a lot smaller and with far less natural scenic attractions, such as Singapore.
Detailed contest rules and related registration forms are available on the contest's official Web site at http://www.TaiwanBestTrip.net.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green photonics dominates Photonics Festival 2009

TEXT.P: This year's Photonics Festival in Taiwan will open Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall 1, covering solar energy, LED, precision optics and other areas of photonics, according to the Photonics Industry and Technology Development Association, the event's organizer.
Manufacturers from Taiwan and China are expected to use the show to establish connections for future business, the association said in a press statement issued Tuesday.

With about 360 exhibitors and 800 booths, the show, which is in conjunction with Display Taiwan 2009, is expected to attract 35,000 visitors this year and to generate over NT$30 billion (US$914.6 million)-worth of business opportunities for the second half of this year.

Business opportunities created by LEDs and solar energy are expected to further encourage buying, the organizers said, adding that with the continued pushing of LED applications, the momentum of the industry's growth is expected to recover when the economy bottoms out.
The solar energy industry has not been affected by the global recession, with the output growth last year recording 60 percent and total output value reaching NT$106.1 billion.

With manufacturers continuing to expand production and significantly increase capacity for the production of thin film panels, the growth rate is expected to reach 23 percent, according to the organizers.

In addition, the output of the local photovoltaic system industry was around NT$500 million in 2008. With various photovoltaic plans in the works this year, investment in the photovoltaic plan by the Taiwan Power Company and the passage of the Renewable Energy Development Bill, the output growth rate is expected to reach 47 percent.
Other featured exhibition areas include a "cross-strait photonics show, " with the organizers noting that the increasing cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges are influencing the future of industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan county mangoes to target top-spending Japanese customers

TEXT.P: Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-jhih said Tuesday that he will target top spenders when promoting the county's Irwin strain of mangoes during a trip to Japan.
Su made the remarks at a news conference prior to his scheduled departure for Japan Thursday to promote the fruit, of which a first batch of more than 500 kg was undergoing the quarantine process.
Su is expected to take part in a series of promotional activities in department stores and hotels in Tokyo, Osaka and Hokkaido during his six-day visit.
Su said the Irwin mangoes will "target top-spending customers, " adding that a case of just three mangoes will be sold from 2,800 yen (US$28.4) to 6,300 yen, depending on quality.
Every case will include a Japanese introduction to the fruit, as well as stay- fresh bags, Su said.
Su said the county government worked with international delivery operators last year to send their products directly to the customers in an "order from Japan with direct delivery from Taiwan" system.
"In this way, we sold 2,000 cases of mangoes in just three weeks," he noted.
This year, Taiwan and Japan will increase cooperation, with home delivery, online ordering and for the first time, ordering via a Japanese department store with outlets around the country.
Wei Te-sheng, director of the blockbuster romantic film "Cape No. 7, " who happened to be visiting the Tainan county government, was also invited to promote the mangoes at the news conference.
Kuo Yi-pin, director of the county government's Department of Agriculture, said that annual production of the Irwin strain of mangoes in the county is around 100,000 metric tons.
The county government has promoted the fruit since 2004 and has made successful inroads into the Japanese market, which has helped prop up the price of local mangoes, Kuo said.
"This year, mangoes from Taiwan will be available in major cities in Japan, " Kuo said, estimating that 10,000 cases will be sold this year, up five-fold from last year.
Agriculture officials said this year's mango crop is down from last year's and that exports, which usually continue until August, will finish by the end of July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group racks up over US$3 million worth of business in Central Asia

TEXT.P: A trade group organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) that is visiting three countries in the Middle East and Central Asia has racked up good business on the Mid-East leg of the trip, TAITRA officials said Tuesday.

The delegation of representatives of 18 local companies, including the Export- Import Bank of China (Taipei) , embarked on the tour May 30 and has visited Jordan and Syria, with the Kazakhstan leg slated to begin June 9, TAITRA officials said.
Based upon on-the-spot interviews with group members, TAITRA estimated that the delegation will be able to chalk up business worth US$3.25 million after wrapping up its two-day visit to Kazakhstan.
TAITRA decided to send the trade-promotion mission to the three countries in an effort to help local enterprises hit by the global financial crisis more effectively explore emerging markets.

On June 1, it held its first seminar with businessmen from Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon in the Jordanian capital of Amman, obtaining business worth US$1.35 million, with strong demand for construction materias, hardware, textiles, car components and accessories.

As Jordan is slated to sign a free trade agreement with the United States in 2010, Taiwanese companies interested in setting up strongholds in the country will stand a good chance of seizing business opportunities in neighboring Iraq's reconstruction program as Jordan holds a key location for travel to Iraq.
Two-way Taiwan-Jordan trade totaled US$250.3 million in 2008, up by 20.5 percent over the 2007 figure, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$126.7 million.
During the second seminar held June 4 in Damascus, capital of Syria, close to 200 businessmen attended the event and business worth US$1.9 million was secured, according to TAITRA,
TAITRA officials said Syria also has a strong demand for textiles and hardware products, as well as for car components and electrical wire, because the country has been promoting light industry.
Taiwanese exports to Syria in 2008 reached US$166.71 million, marking an increase of 26 percent year on year, TAITRA tallies show.
With a population of 22 million, Syria provides a promising market for Taiwanese businesses because it remains almost untouched by the vast majority of local companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students urged to turn off computers at night

TEXT.P: A local university is launching a campaign aimed at encouraging students to shut down their computers at night after discovering that doing so helps reduce carbon dioxide emissions significantly.

The findings were made by a group of students at National Chiao Tung University who took a class this year given by senior lecturer Niu Yu-chen on the relationship between ecology and health, according to a statement released by the university on its Web site Tuesday.

Based on a calculation formula adopted by the Environmental Protection Administration, the students found that a computer running round the clock consumes 8.6 kilowatt hours of electricity per day, causing a daily carbon dioxide emission of 6 kg, according to the statement.
The students then concluded that switching off the computer for six hours every night can help save 56 kWh per month, as well reduce carbon dioxide emissions by nearly 40 kg each month.

After a campus survey found that 71 percent of the students at the university are not in the habit of turning off their computers at night, the students further concluded that taking the 7,000 beds in the school's dormitories as an example, if 71 percent of the students living in the dormitories during term- time adopted the practice of switching off at night, they would save more than 2.5 million kWh per year.

This would reduce carbon dioxide emissions by nearly 1.79 million kg, the students said, noting that they then initiated a campaign titled "PC vs. Earth, KO or OK? " in the hope of raising environmental awareness among other students.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Lucky tours' in Taipei target Japanese tourists

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government and EVA Airways are cooperating to provide a "lucky tour" program in a bid to attract Japanese tourists, whose numbers have declined sharply because of fears over swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1).
The selling points of the tour include the slogans that it "will bring good luck" and that "the more you stay in Taipei, the luckier you will become."
Several tour plans have been mapped out for Japanese visitors, each of which features scenic spots and local delicacies available in the city.

Each tour plan also recommends visits to various temples, such as one for lovers, who can visit the Xiahai City Lord Temple, while those seeking career success can visit the Xintian Temple, those seeking divine help for their health can visit the Baoan Temple and those who want success in examinations can visit the Confucius Temple.

In addition to visiting temples, the scenic spots listed in the travel plans also have special meanings. For example, those who want to have career success can visit Taipei 101 to symbolize a gradual ascent to a higher position, while those who want good health can visit the Chinese herbal tea shops in the Wanhua area and those who want success in examinations can visit the giant Eslite bookstore.

Air carriers have complained that due to the swine flu scare, passenger rates on Japanese routes have dropped to below 60 percent from the more usual 80 percent. The drop has been sharpest among all flight routes serving Taiwan and both EVA Airways and China Airlines, the nation's largest air carriers, have cut flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses' work rights eased as law revisions passed

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a package of law amendments Tuesday that shorten the waiting periods for Chinese spouses of local citizens before they can obtain residency and citizenship, and greatly eases restrictions on their work rights.

The ruling Kuomintang-controlled legislature completed a third reading of the raft of amendments to the Statute Governing Relations between the People of Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area at a floor meeting.

Under the amended law, Chinese spouses will be eligible to apply to stay in Taiwan once they enter Taiwan with legal travel documents and can apply for a change to long-term stay status after having lived in Taiwan for four years. They will later be eligible to apply to settle in Taiwan after having stayed here for two more consecutive years.
The revisions will mean that Chinese citizens can apply for settlement or citizenship six years after their arrival, rather than the eight years stipulated at present.

The amended law will also allow them to work right after they enter Taiwan to live with their Taiwanese spouses. Under the current law, Chinese spouses cannot work until after they acquire long-term stay status.
The amended regulations will take effect after promulgation by the Presidential Office.
Meanwhile, the amendments also do away with a NT$2 million cap on inheritances or gifts that Chinese spouses are allowed to accept.
In addition, Chinese spouses who have acquired long-term stay status will be eligible to inherit real estate in Taiwan once the new law is promulgated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government announces school digitalization program

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced a digitalization program for elementary and junior high schools Tuesday, saying that the Cabinet will earmark NT$7.1 billion (US$216.5 million) to build advanced classrooms in schools all over the country as part of the government's education reforms.

Liu made the announcement during a visit to the Shenkeng Elementary School in northern Taiwan's Taipei County. He was accompanied by Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng, Minister without Portfolio Ovid J.L. Tzeng and Taipei Magistrate Chou Shi-wei.
"Software infrastructure, namely education, is an extremely important aspect of the government's all-out efforts to improve Taiwan's environment and advance its high-tech standards, " he said.

Under the program, the government aims to provide elementary and high school students with a computerized wireless learning environment in which they can interact with their teachers through electronic boards and remote control devices instead of the traditional classroom blackboard, the premier said.
According to Liu, close to 60,000 classrooms will be fully computerized by the end of this year, while the government may need to purchase in excess of 90,000 personal computers as part of the plan.

By the time that has been achieved, every school will have at least one digitalized classroom for their students -- which Cheng said will help reduce the marked digital gap between rural and urban areas.

Schools in remote areas and outlying islands and those catering to aboriginal students in mountainous areas will be the first to be included in the NT$7.1 billion program, the education minister said.
The program forms part of a four-year, NT$500 billion economic stimulus package announced by the Executive Yuan late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Small-, medium-sized enterprises optimistic about economy

TEXT.P: Half of the small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) polled recently in Taiwan believe the recession will bottom out in 2010, according to the 2009 UPS Asia Business Monitor report.

The percentage is the highest among the 12 countries surveyed, followed by 46 percent in China and 44 percent of those in India, UPS Taiwan General Manager Gary Wu said Tuesday while explaining the parts of the survey results that relate to Taiwan.
Wu also pointed out that the information technology, manufacturing and biotech industries will continue to be the major pillars supporting Taiwan's economy within the next three to five years.
Meanwhile, the survey found that 44 percent of Taiwanese SMEs believe that their best chance for growth is to seek upgrades of their products and services to produce greater added value.

UPS began the annual Asia Business Monitor in 2005, surveying 1,200 business decision makers in 12 countries and areas -- Australia, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand -- to acquire the latest insights on the changing opinions, attitudes and habits of business leaders in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: BTCO holds reception to celebrate Queen's Birthday

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) held a reception Tuesday to celebrate the 83rd birthday of Queen Elizabeth II, the British monarch.

BTCO Director David Campbell praised the good relations between Taiwan and the United Kingdom during the function, which was attended by Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia and vice foreign ministers David Lin and Javier Hou, as well as members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.
"2009 has been a very positive year for relations between the U.K. and Taiwan," said Campbell, who took office as Britain's top envoy in Taiwan in February.

Noting that Taiwan and the U.K. have close relations in economic, trade, investment, cultural, educational and the arts sectors, Campbell said the close exchanges have been further strengthened since Taiwan was included in the U.K.'s visa waiver program that started March 3.

The official travel figures from Taiwan to the U.K. will be released later this year, Campbell went on, adding that one major Taiwanese tour company told his office that they had arranged more travel packages to the U.K. over the past three months than in the whole of last year.
"I am sure we will see a considerable increase in the number of Taiwanese visiting the U.K. I hope this in turn will lead to much greater awareness of Taiwan among British people," Campbell said.

He also noted that the U.K. will send a large contingent of athletes to participate in the upcoming World Games in Kaohsiung in July and to the Deaflympics in Taipei in September, as sport in particular is an activity that brings people closer together.
Hsia for his part said the U.K., which has offered great support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in international organizations, is an invaluable partner of Taiwan.
The two countries' shared beliefs in freedom, democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law bring the two sides closer despite the thousands of miles separating them, he added.

What brings Taiwan and the U.K. even closer is their bilateral trade and investment relations, as well as the increasingly wide range of exchanges in the areas of economy, tourism, science and technology, culture and education, Hsia went on.

Bilateral trade reached US$5.55 billion in 2008 and the U.K. was Taiwan's 5th- largest foreign investor, Hsia continued, adding that there are some 15,000 Taiwanese students in the U.K., representing 25 percent of the total number of local people studying abroad.

"There is still plenty of room for further cooperation between Taiwan and the U.K. in all areas and I'm confident that our relations will continue to grow on the already substantial foundations, " Hsia added.

The Queen's Official Birthday is celebrated as a public holiday in several Commonwealth countries. While the exact date of the celebration varies from country to country, it does not usually mark the real birthday of the sovereign, as Queen Elizabeth II was born April 21, 1926.

DOC.HEADLINE: President defends decision to continue lawsuit against prosecutor

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou defended Tuesday his pursuit of legal action against a prosecutor in his 2007 corruption trial who allegedly falsified a witness statement, arguing that the case will have a positive effect on judicial reform.

Ma instructed his attorneys to lodge an appeal with the Taipei District Court in March, which is now under review. If the court finds that Prosecutor Hou Kuan- jen did not accurately document his questioning of Ma's witness, Wu Li-ju -- a Taipei city government treasurer -- Hou will be indicted and the case sent to trial.

Hou, a prosecutor on the Special Investigation Division of the Supreme Prosecutors Office, was one of the prosecutors investigating Ma's handling of his special allowance funds during his tenure as mayor of Taipei from 1998-2006.
Ma was indicted Feb. 13, 2007 on charges of embezzling some NT$11 million (US$333,000) from his special mayoral allowance fund and using it for private purposes.

That same day, Ma stepped down as Kuomintang chairman and announced his candidacy for the 2008 presidential race. At the time, Ma said being indicted for corruption was more painful than losing his life.

In August 2007, the Taipei District Court acquitted Ma after finding he had no criminal intent nor did he act deceitfully. Prosecutors appealed the court's decision, which was eventually decided again in Ma's favor Dec. 28, 2007.
At the time, Ma argued that Hou had not documented his questioning of Wu correctly and sued the prosecutor for forgery in January last year.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office argued that even if the written record of Wu's testimony was incomplete, it could not be used as evidence in a trial. For this reason, it was concluded that there were no grounds for inferring that Hou deliberately falsified documents. On Dec. 31, 2008, the prosecutors office declined to pursue action against Hou.

Following the decision, Ma appealed to the Taiwan High Prosecutors Office, but was rejected again on the grounds that the witness did not express any opinion after listening to Hou's documentation of her statements being read aloud.

Ma's appeal for District Court action drew criticism from the opposition, to which Presidential Office Public Affairs Department Director Tsai Chung-li said that Ma's decision to appeal was not made out of his personal interest but to serve as an example to others, because every citizen could encounter such a situation.

"The case is not only about judicial rights but also part of judicial education. President Ma believes that the case will be helpful in better protecting local people's rights and will have a positive effect on judicial reform," Tsai added.
According to Tsai, Ma thought that he was duty-bound to pursue the lawsuit against the prosecutor.
"The president found that local prosecutors have become more prudent and circumspect in documenting witnesses' statements since he filed the lawsuit against the prosecutor," Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 10, or the 18th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," as well as "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: U.S. marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins a decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors and expands its territory by 200 percent.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for copyright infringements.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
2000: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race kicks off at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: The Chinese version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a new book by the Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, has been released in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

The weighted price index lost 213.63 points, or 3.22 percent, to close at 6,414.39 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan drums up support for Yushan as world wonder

TEXT.P: The Yushan National Park Headquarters called Wednesday on those who have not done so to vote for Yushan, or Jade Mountain, as one of the world's natural wonders, as the second stage of global online voting entered its final month.

The 3,952-meter mountain, the highest in Northeast Asia, has so far maintained the top position in the "mountain, volcanoes" category in the second round of voting for the world's new seven natural wonders organized by the Swiss-based New7Wonders Foundation, which is scheduled to end July 7.
According to the park headquarters, continued support for Yushan from the public is essential if it is to continue the leading position amid intense competition from other nominees.
Over the past month, many newcomers have entered the top five in the "mountain, volcanoes" ranking, squeezing Mount Everest and Mount Fuji off the list, park officials noted.

The five recent entries are Greece's Mount Olympus, which climbed from sixth to second; Italy's Mount Vesuvius, which shot up from 13th to third; Azerbaijan's Mud Volcanoes, which soared from 21st to fourth; and South Africa's Table Mountain, which rose from 27th to fifth.
To drum up support for Yushan, the park headquarters is holding various events in the coming month to encourage the public to take part in the voting being held at www.new7wonders.com.

They include an exhibition and performance scheduled for June 14 at Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, and a cycle race set for June 20 in Tataka, the highest point of the New Central Cross-Island Highway.
From June 22 to July 6, the seven Yushan publicity ambassadors -- selected in April through an online vote -- will make a cycling tour around Taiwan.

Yushan, located on the boundaries of Chiayi, Nantou and Kaohsiung counties, is known for its diverse wildlife and ecology. It is the only natural attraction from Taiwan to make the list of contenders in any category.

As of June 9, Africa's Kalahari Desert had taken the top position in the "landscape, ice formations" category; Ecuador's Galapagos Islands in the "islands" category; Serbia's Djavolja Varos in the "caves, rock formations, valleys" category; the Philippines's Puerto Princesa Subterranean River in the "forest, national parks, nature reserves" category; South America's Lake Titicaca in the "lakes, rivers, waterfalls" category; and Vietnam's Ha Long Bay in the "seascape" category.

The top 11 sites chosen in each of the seven categories by July 7 will then be reviewed by a panel of experts headed by Federico Mayor Zaragoza, former UNESCO director-general, who will select three nominees in each category.
The 21 nominees will be put to a final round of worldwide online voting in 2010 and 2011 to select the top seven natural wonders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight more students returning from Thailand infected with swine flu

TEXT.P: Eight more Taiwanese students who traveled on two recent graduation tours to Thailand were confirmed to have been infected with swine flu upon their return, bringing to 11 the total number of influenza A(H1N1) infections recorded in the groups, the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) said Wednesday.
The two separate tour groups, comprising a total of 74 members, were in Thailand June 1-7, staying mainly in Bangkok and Pattaya.

The groups were organized by the same Thai travel agency and met while in Thailand. The guide for one of the tours, who first displayed flu-like symptoms but later recovered, is the suspected origin of the mass infection.
The first three confirmed cases were reported by the CECC Tuesday, including two who were detected with fevers upon their arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport June 7.
According to the CECC, 32 cases of influenza A (H1N1) have been recorded in Taiwan so far, only one of which has been indigenous.
Data from the World Health Organization shows that as of June 8, 73 countries had officially reported 25,288 cases of swine flu infection, including 139 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka stronghold resists changing times

TEXT.P: Strolling around 273-year-old Meinong, a Hakka township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, one immediately notices rundown red-roofed sheds scattered across the town's fields.
These tobacco kilns, remnants of Meinong's bygone days when tobacco growing was the main source of income for many local families, add charm to the town that is now better known for tourism.

Its bucolic setting, with expansive fields bordered to the north by mountains, has fashioned Meinong as a rural retreat for travelers looking to escape city pressures, but the onset of more than 1 million tourists a year and land developers looking for new opportunities threaten the town's idyllic image.
Chung Kun-hung, a Meinong native who runs "Yekousan, " a magazine promoting Hakka culture in the town, feels the land developers present a big threat.
"Meinong has changed a lot, and the many new villas built in the field, with walls and swimming pools, have ruined its rustic landscape and ambiance, " he says.

As the traditional staples of the local economy -- tobacco growing and pig raising -- faded in importance in the early 2000s, some local people sold their land to outsiders and moved to cities in search of a better life.

"About 10 years ago, land developers, brokers and rich city dwellers began appearing in Meinong. They purchased land and constructed all kinds of new and luxury villas in the town, " Chung explained, saying that Meinong's unusually clean air and water and majestic vistas were attractive to people looking for a rural getaway.

"Now, you can still see many yellow land sales banners erected in the fields seeking buyers. Some land plots have even changed hands four or five times -- a result of the speculative land development business," Chung said.
According to Chung, no less than 5 percent of Meinong's land has been sold to outsiders, mostly from Kaohsiung City and neighboring townships in the county.
"Most Meinong people don't like it and are worried about what they see, but what can we do? " Chung said. "Although we want to maintain our conservative lifestyle, modernization is unavoidable."

Lo Chin-jung, secretary-general of Meinong township, acknowledged that the trend may have some discomforting consequences but he agreed that land development was unavoidable as traditional agriculture fades as a source of income.
He believes one solution could be stricter zoning and building codes.

"Both the central and local governments should come up with adequate laws and regulations and financial support to help Meinong keep its traditional look,"he said. "For a town like ours filled with Hakka heritage, new buildings should be erected with local features."
While some of these new villas and developments blot the Meinong landscape, a bigger problem is the heavy influx of tourists and the need for more modern facilities.

Although Meinong has long been a tourist attraction, drawing an estimated 500,000 visitors a year as early as 20 years ago, the larger number of tourists it now gets seem to be overloading the town's infrastructure, especially in terms of transportation.
A drive between Meinong and Kaohsiung City, the largest city in southern Taiwan, now only takes about 45 minutes, half the time needed in the past before the nearby No. 10 expressway was built.
But that convenient roadway creates traffic congestion on weekends and holidays that can rival the worst tie-ups seen in Taiwan's biggest cities.
Bathrooms are also in short supply when 250,000 visitors flock in during the town's flower festival during the Chinese New Year.

To be sure, Meinong, dubbed the most beautiful village in Taiwan, has many assets that continue to make it a popular destination. Its enchanting mountains, expanses of green wild fields and traditional Hakka architecture and culture remain popular magnets.

Some visitors enjoy biking around the town's narrow alleys and countryside, where there is plenty to explore, while others gravitate to Meinong's trademark crafts -- its oil-paper umbrellas or blue Hakka frocks.

But local residents like Hsu Man-hsian, a 73-year-old doctor who lives in downtown Meinong, fear that the town's once pure Hakka culture -- preserved intact over the centuries because of its remote location and 95 percent Hakka population -- is being eroded by modernization.

"Relevant government authorities have done nothing. There is no effort being made to help us integrate our traditions and tourism to pursue a better life," Hsu said, complaining that the town turns into a mess every time visitors pour in. "It's an insult to Meinong."

Huang Bin-shii, another Meinong native who is now an assistant professor at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, agrees that there has been a loss of traditional architecture and folk rituals, but he feels the town should confront it rather than accepting it with resignation.

Meinong, he said, should be brave enough to upgrade and add new meaning to its cultural content rather than simply conserve the tobacco kilns, oil-paper umbrellas or rice noodles it has long been known for.

It's not as though the town has nowhere to go for help. Because of the Hakka people's traditional emphasis on education and knowledge, Meinong is said to have the highest density of Ph.D. holders per land area of any region of Taiwan and now enjoys fame as the country's "home of pundits."
Though Meinong is stuck at a crossroad between the past and the future, it is still trying to offer the best to visitors.

"Meinong is not as famous as other townships like Danshuei or Jioufen in northern Taiwan or Lugang in central Taiwan, but it was voted as the country's 'happiest town' and 'town of smiles' by tourists in an online competition four years ago," Chung noted.

Many foreign tourists from Hong Kong, Japan Malaysia, Singapore and South Korea come to Meinong in the quest for the traces of a past Taiwan, he said. "To many of them, Meinong stands as the epitome of Taiwan's earliest days."

DOC.HEADLINE: Schools in Taiwan, Germany receive Taiwan-France cultural awards
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 10 (CNA) 06/10/09 15:55:57 (By Lin Yu-li and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taipei-based university and one in Germany have received the 13th Taiwan- France Cultural Awards in Paris, in recognition of their contributions to relations and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France.

The French Training Center at National Taiwan Normal University and the Department of Chinese Language and Literature at Ruhr University Bochum each received prize money of 25,000 euros in addition to the citations.

The award ceremony was held Monday at the prestigious Institute of France, presided over by Michel Albert, permanent secretary of the institute's Academy of Ethics and Political Sciences, and Huang Pi-twan, chairwoman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA).

According to the CCA's representative office in Paris, the French Training Center in Taiwan has made substantial contributions to cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France and has helped more than 90,000 people to achieve competency in French since it was established in 1984.

The award-winning department at the German university, meanwhile, has functioned as an important research institute for Taiwan studies in Europe, thanks to its research, its extensive library of Taiwan-related works, its seminars and its recruiting of Taiwanese professors.
The CCA and the Institute of France co-established the award in 1996 to recognize contributions by groups or individuals in cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France.
Winners are awarded for their performance in various aspects, such as literature, sinology, cultural studies, aboriginal studies and puppetry.
CCA Chairwoman Huang expressed hope that the award will serve as encouragement for those making efforts to improve cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: Study extensions to be allowed for women

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan completed Wednesday a preliminary review of a bill that would allow female undergraduate and graduate students who are parents to apply for extensions to their expected period of study.

The extensions would cover pregnancy, childbirth and the care of children under three years old, according to the draft amendment to the University Act, which cleared the legislature's Education and Culture Committee.
The proposed amendment was introduced in light of the fact that some students are often forced to give up their studies because of the demands of parenting.

Although the Ministry of Education in 2005 directed universities to allow maternity leave for pregnant students and to deduct the period of absence from their expected duration of study, some universities have not done so.

Under these circumstances, pregnant students have to ask for sick leave or private affairs leave instead, in which case they can face expulsion if they are absent from more than one-third of their classes in a semester.

If the students choose to withdraw temporarily from university, the maximum duration of such withdrawal, as stipulated in the University Act, is four years. In reality, however, most universities only allow a withdrawal of two years at the maximum.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.138 to close at NT$32.715.
A total of US$872 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.853 and fluctuated between NT$32.688 and NT$32.853.

DOC.HEADLINE: Documentary on black-faced spoonbill premiered

TEXT.P: The world's first documentary on the migration patterns of the endangered black- faced spoonbill, which makes an 8,000-km round trip from Northeast Asia to Taiwan every year, was premiered in Taipei Wednesday, one day before being broadcast on TV.

Chong Jong Ryol, a Japan-based North Korean scholar who is acclaimed as the world's first person to have bred the white wading bird with its distinctive black spoon-shaped beak, attended the premiere held by Taiwan's Public Television Service (PTS) Foundation.

The attendees at the event included Academia Sinica research fellow Lucia Liu Severinghaus, who proposed international cooperation for the protection of black-faced spoonbills at the 1994 Birdlife International Conference; Wang Ying, a professor of life science at National Taiwan Normal University who carried out Taiwan's first satellite tracking program on the waterfowl; and Taiwanese bird photographer Wang Cheng-chi.

Cloud Gate Dance Theatre founder and choreographer Lin Huai-min, who narrated the film in Mandarin, described the bird as Taiwan's most loyal ally, saying that "the government does not need to give money to black-faced spoonbills in order to persuade them to come here."

"Although Taiwan is isolated in the international community, black-faced spoonbills consistently come in October, when the country celebrates its national day, " Lin narrates in the documentary, which was produced through an international cooperation project involving British director Dean Johnson and Taiwanese bird photographer Liang Chieh-te.

To record how the graceful birds migrate every year from the north to warmer Asian wintering sites, the experts, carrying heavy high definition cameras and other sophisticated equipment, traveled from Taiwan and filmed in Japan, on an uninhabited island off the coast of northeastern China, and in the Korean Demilitarized Zone on the Korean peninsula in a single year, overcoming many challenges in order to get the shooting completed, according to the PST.
The film, to be broadcast in various countries, will be shown in Taiwan at 10 p.m. Thursday on PTS.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing's famous roast ducks will hit Taiwan's market in July

TEXT.P: Beijing's famous brand of roast ducks, Quanjude, will go trial sales in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City beginning July 10 as planned, the company's Taiwanese collaborator said Wednesday, denying recent rumors that the company might have changed its plan to open its first branch on the island.

Chang Su-luan, chairwoman of the Kaohsiung City Riverside Restaurant Group, said Quanjude (Group) Co. Ltd. may postpone the inauguration of its branch in Kaohsiung City because Taiwan's central government has yet to scrap its ban on Chinese investment in Taiwan.

The government, however, recently announced it will allow Chinese investments in Taiwan late this month or early next month. Investment will be allowed in around 100 sectors, including the service industry.
Chang added that the company's planned sales of the ducks in the city will still be launched as scheduled.

The trial sales will be held in the Kaohsiung Port's No. 3 wharf, and a dozen chefs from Beijing-based Quanjude will be stationed on the spot to entice Taiwanese customers with their world famous dish.
Ducks to be used during the launch will be high-quality ducks grown in neighboring Pingtung County, Chang said. Stoves to cook the ducks will be shipped from Beijing, she added.

To effectively preserve the original taste of the Quanjude roast duck, the Pingtung poultry farm which will provide the ducks used a different feed from the one it normally uses to help build protein in the ducks and shorten its maturation period from 72 days to 58.
Late last year, Quanjude signed an agreement with its Kaohsiung partner to sell its globally famous special dish to Taiwanese people in Taiwan's second largest city.
It set the date of trial sales at that time in the hope of taking advantage of the 2009 World Games, which will be held in the city from July 16-26.
Quanjude enjoys global fame due to the special techniques it uses to make the roast ducks and the quality of its dish.

Founded in 1864 during the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911), Quanjude is one of the most renowned restaurants in China. The company became a corporate group in 1993 and went public in 2007 on the Shenzhen bourse to support its goal of growing into an international brand.

It now operates 16 restaurants in Beijing, Shanghai, Chongqing and Changchun and sells more than 2 million ducks a year to some 5 million patrons. It also has 65 franchised outlets, 55 of which are based on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rise

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 47.88 points, or 0.74 percent, to close at 6,462.27.
Rebounding after two consecutive losing sessions, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 6,907.32 and closed at the day's low of 6,389.94.
A total of 4.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$114.3 billion (US$3.49 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent. Banking and financial shares advanced 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 0.6 percent, and cement stocks gained 0.3 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues and construction issues both moving down at 2.7 percent and textile stocks down 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,217 to 923, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.
The three major institutional investors made net sales of NT$287 million on shares.

Shares in some of the tourist agencies on the market rose by the maximum daily limit of 7 percent, which analysts attributed to the news that a 340-strong Chinese tour group is slated to arrive in Taiwan Sunday.

Meanwhile, shares in several food firms made significant gains, which analysts said were caused by an increase of salad oil and soy flour prices as a result of a sharp rise of soybean and corn prices on the international market.

Judging from the day's trading session, investors showed confidence that share prices will increase in the coming days, according to David Dong, an investment division executive of the President Investment Trust Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma announces bid for KMT chairmanship

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou announced Wednesday his intention to run for the chairmanship of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), breaking a one-year period of indecision on the matter.
Ma stressed that his plan to serve concurrently as the party chairman is not intended to expand his presidential power, but rather to more effectively fulfill his responsibilities.

"I hope my bid will be supported by the party members in the interest of facilitating closer cooperation between the ruling party and the administration and achieving more effective government, " Ma told a news conference.
Such teamwork is especially important at time when the country is experiencing economic hardships, according to Ma.

Ma pointed out that soon after his administration took office in May 2008, the global financial crisis and economic downturn hit Taiwan, forcing many businesses to shut down and leaving numerous people out of work.
Under these circumstances, the government is laden with responsibilities such as revitalizing the economy, stabilizing the financial market and protecting the disadvantaged, he said.

Although the country's economy has begun to improve through the efforts of various sectors, the government cannot relax its guard on the economic situation and should unite the nation in order to overcome the crisis, the president said.

Ma last assumed the KMT chairmanship in August 2005. He resigned from the party post in February 2007, after he was indicted on charges of mishandling funds and embezzling a total of NT$11.17 million from his special allowance fund during his term as Taipei mayor between 1998 and 2006. He was later found not guilty of the charges.

According to the president, incumbent KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung first floated the idea of Ma returning to the party helm in April 2008 -- one month after he was elected president -- and raised the proposal again in September the same year.
Ma said he then promised Wu that he would make a decision on the matter by June this year.

Also during Wednesday's news conference, Wu said his support for the idea of Ma as party chairman remains unchanged and that he will not run in the next chairmanship election now that Ma has decided to stand as a candidate.
It remains unclear if the election slated for July 26 will draw any other aspirants.
According to the KMT's schedule, registration forms for the election will be distributed June 15-16, with candidate registration to be accepted June 25-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Metro's passenger satisfaction for 2008 hits new high

TEXT.P: A survey has found that the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system's overall passenger satisfaction for 2008 reached a new high of 95 percent, according to statement released by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) Wednesday.

The survey results indicated that the system's passenger satisfaction rate has kept growing from that registered at 86.2 percent in 2003 when the company first began conducting the annual survey, according to the statement.
The figure for 2007 was 94.1 percent.

The cleanliness of stations received the highest level of satisfaction at 97.6 percent, followed by the cleanliness of trains at 97.1 percent, the convenience of ticket vending machines and add value machines at 93.7 percent, and the safety of escalators at 93.2 percent.

More than 91 percent of survey respondents were satisfied with the ventilation and air conditioning at stations. Meanwhile, 90.6 percent of the passengers expressed satisfaction with the information given about arriving trains, and 90.4 percent were content with the low occurrence of train delays.

The survey also showed that 60 percent of the passengers ride the MRT, also known as Metro, more than five days per week, an increase of 1.9 percent from the figure in 2007, and an indication that the public is relying more on this public transportation system.
Most passengers - 32.3 percent - ride the subway system for commuting, 20.5 percent take it to go to school, and 15.5 percent use it to get to places for recreation.

According to the TRTC's statement, the survey was commissioned by the TRTC and conducted by a market survey company via on-site interviews with passengers over 16 years old, along various MRT lines from Oct. 28 to Nov. 2, 2008. A total of 1,082 valid samples were collected.
The TRTC expressed gratitude for the public's support for the system, saying improvements will be made based on passengers' needs and suggestions.
Taipei's MRT started operations in March 1996. Its daily passenger volume exceeded 1.24 million this April.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's proposal targets simplified character users in China

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou was aiming his remarks at the 1.3 billion people of China who use simplified characters when he broached the idea of being able to recognize traditional characters but writing in simplified characters, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.
The Presidential Office dismissed media reports that Ma was advocating the use in Taiwan of simplified Chinese characters for writing.

The officials issued the clarification one day after Ma's remarks triggered concern among some scholars who said such a move would lead to pro-Taiwan overseas Chinese schools -- which only teach traditional Chinese -- beginning to accept "simplified characters in writing," which in turn would affect domestic teaching.

During a meeting with visiting overseas Chinese leaders, Ma proposed using traditional Chinese characters as much as possible in print, although he added that it would be acceptable to use simplified in writing. He expressed hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can "reach an agreement on the matter."
Taiwan and Hong Kong use traditional Chinese characters, while China and Singapore use a simplified version developed by Beijing in the 1950s in a bid to promote literacy among rural peasants.

The officials pointed out that China has used simplified Chinese characters for years and that Taiwan could not possibly force Beijing to change it. Ma's proposal was simply aimed at giving Chinese people the opportunity to learn how to recognize more traditional Chinese characters and was "by no means an attempt to promote simplified characters in Taiwan."
"There is no need to advocate the idea in Taiwan," an official went on, since people in Taiwan recognize traditional Chinese characters, which makes deciphering simplified a fairly simple process.

The official also noted that ever since the end of Japanese colonial rule, Taiwan has always used traditional Chinese characters and said its use represents a unique status in Chinese culture and also plays a role with regard to sovereignty.

The official said that Taiwanese people are used to writing in the traditional form, but added that if some use simplified, the government could not ban it, although in "schools, government offices and the military" the traditional system should still be adopted.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Ma is hoping that China could promote traditional Chinese characters to allow its people a deeper understanding of Chinese culture, while Taiwan will continue to read and write using the traditional system.

In the legislature, meanwhile, lawmakers reacted along party lines, with opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators Chen Ting-fei and Kuan Bi- ling saying that the president "should not promote" the recognition of simplified Chinese characters, which they claimed is evidence of Ma's tilting toward China.

However, ruling Kuomintang legislators Kuo Shu-chun and Hung Hsiu-chu said Ma's idea is actually to promote the use of traditional characters for cross-strait documents and papers, which they lauded as a "strong approach" toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA unlikely in second half of 2009: Mainland Affairs Council

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will not necessarily sign an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) in the second half of this year or the first half of 2010 during their coming rounds of talks, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Wednesday.
Lai made the remarks while answering questions from legislators on the issue at a joint legislative committee meeting.
Lai said she could not give any assurances concerning the issue, although she noted that the government hopes to start relevant talks with China as quickly as possible.
"The two sides will talk at the right time, when both of them have made sufficient preparations," she said.
According to the MAC chairwoman, timetables have not been set regarding either exchanges of offices or crime investigation officers between the two sides.
"The matter of exchanging offices has not been included on the agenda of the current stage of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations," she pointed out.

In the recent third round of bilateral negotiations, Taiwan and China reached preliminary agreement to discuss topics concerning the avoidance of double taxation, fishery cooperation, cooperation on agricultural quarantine and collaboration on standard product certification in their next meeting.

A consensus on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment was one of the agreements reached in the third round of cross-strait talks held in China's Nanjing in late April, following previous accords on direct transport and postal links between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: 98-year-old student to receive master's degree in philosophy

TEXT.P: Taiwan's oldest graduate student Chao Mu-he, 98, will be awarded a master's degree in philosophy Friday, in an embodiment of the adage "never too old to learn."
Chao was born on July 4, 1912, the year the Republic of China was established. Notably, his birthday also falls on the same date as the United States independence day.

Chao, who has mastered the "bird-worm-style" calligraphy, used his research on the spirit of the Chinese calligraphic art as the basis for his degree from the Graduate Institute of Philosophy, Nanhua University in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.
Chao said he learned the calligraphic style as child in China.
"It is a difficult form of calligraphy because each stroke in the script has to be shaped like a bird or worm," he said.
As he had spent several decades of his life learning the style, which is now almost obsolete, he knew it would be the best subject for his thesis, Chao said in an interview with CNA Wednesday.

Chao, a graduate of a teachers' college in Shandong in northern China, moved to Taiwan in 1951. He taught at Kaohsiung Girls Normal College, which later became National Kaohsiung Normal University, and had attained the position of director of general affairs at the university before his retirement in 1978.

Asked why he decided to pursue a graduate degree so late in life, Chao said he wanted to encourage one of his friend's sons who appeared reluctant to go back to school. Chao said he invited the young man to study with him in graduate school.
As Chao was living in Kaohsiung, he had to commute to Chiayi by bus to attend university, but he was proud to say that in two years of study he never missed a class.
Physically, Chao appears to be in good shape and moves around unassisted. Asked about the secret to his good health, he said there is none, but noted that he never quarrels with anyone.
Chen Teh-ho, who is Chao's thesis adviser, described his student as diligent and said he has a sense of humor. Chen added that he was impressed by Chao's desire to acquire knowledge.
Chao is the best example of the saying "never too old to learn, " Chen said, adding that his student will receive a special award at the graduation ceremony Friday in recognition of his diligence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan mayor sets terms for visit to China

TEXT.P: Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair said Wednesday that he will drop a plan to visit Xiamen in China's Fujian Province in early July, if China insists that he must enter with a travel document especially designed for people from Taiwan.

However, once the matter is handled as he wishes, Hsu said, he will definitely head for Xiamen to attend the First Strait Cup Sailing Boat Championship next month as scheduled, even if his pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) disagrees with his decision.
Hsu is slated to visit Xiamen July 17-21 for the regatta.

According to Tainan City's cultural bureau, the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Beijing-based State Council has yet to respond to the question of whether Hsu could enter China without a special entry permit issued by Beijing for travelers from Taiwan, known as "Taiwan Compatriot Travel Certificate."
Hsu's trip is being planned on the heels of visit to China by Chen Chu, a DPP heavyweight and mayor of Kaohsiung City, May 21-24.
Chen, the most prominent DPP incumbent official to have ever visited China, was on promotional trip for the World Games in Kaohsiung next month.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently said that he welcomed Chen's visit to China and that he hoped to see increased interaction between the DPP and Chinese officials. He said that such interaction will allow Beijing to more clearly hear voices from Taiwan other than those of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and will be conducive to further development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Ma encouraged DPP members to continue this approach for the sake of Taiwan and its people.

The president stressed that improving Taiwan-China ties is not a prerogative of the KMT. "Rather, it is a path that all Taiwan's political parties should take, because Taiwan needs to reach out in order to survive," he said.
The KMT favors strengthening relations with China, especially trade links, but the DPP has warned that some of Ma's China-friendly policies could jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outgoing KMT chairman to preside over next cross-strait forum

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Wednesday that its outgoing chairman, Wu Poh-hsiung, will preside over the fifth forum between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC), which will be held July 11-12 in Changsha, Hunan Province in central China.
The KMT issued the statement Wednesday after Wu made public his decision not to seek reelection in light of President Ma Ying-jeou's intention to run for the chairmanship.

The agenda of the planned KMT-CPC forum was decided at a preparatory meeting held earlier in the day in Taipei City. It was attended by KMT think tank members and a Chinese delegation headed by Zheng Lizhong, deputy director of CPC's Taiwan Affairs Office.

According to a KMT statement on the preparatory meeting, the two sides have agreed on three topics for discussion in the KMT-CPC forum, including the preservation of Chinese cultural heritage, and the promotion and expansion of cross-Taiwan Strait cultural and industrial cooperation.
The agenda will also include a conference on cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, according to the statement.
Some 200 scholars and experts from each side are expected to attend the forum.

Zheng, who is also vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, arrived in Taipei Wednesday for the preparatory meeting. On arrival, he said that during his visit he will also try to obtain opinions from the Taiwan people on the cross-strait transportation, postal and trade links.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't finance remains sound despite shrinking tax revenues:minister

TEXT.P: The government remains financially solvent, despite a record drop in tax revenues in the first five months of this year, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Wednesday.

According to the latest statistics released by the Ministry of Finance, the government's tax revenues amounted to NT$529.6 billion (US$16.2 billion) in the January-May period, marking a 19.2 percent decline year on year.

Speaking at news conference on government policies, Lee said that although the national coffers saw the largest ever decrease in tax revenues over the past five months because of the sluggish economy and sagging exports, the amount lost was actually less than expected.
Usually, the central government is able to save 5-to-8 percent annually on its projected expenditures, Lee said.
Last year, Lee noted, the government had a budget surplus of NT$90.9 billion. "This year, we should be able to save as much as that amount," he added.

Quoting a forecast by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Lee said the country's economic contraction will gradually narrow from the second quarter of this year and turn to positive growth in the fourth quarter. Against this backdrop, Lee said, tax revenue prospects will steadily improve as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China sign letter of intent on LED industry cooperation

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait signed a letter of intent Wednesday on cooperation in the development of light emitting diode (LED) lighting technology and production.
The agreement was signed at the conclusion of a two-day conference on cross- strait cooperation in the LED industry, which opened in Taipei Tuesday.
Under the accord, the two sides will cooperate to establish a platform for inspection, safety testing and certification of LED products.

The two-day conference brought together 450 LED experts, industry executives and relevant government officials from both sides to discuss cooperative measures for the establishment of the largest standardized market for LED products in the world.

Some 200 Taiwan companies sent representatives to meet with their counterparts from 71 Chinese corporations at the conference, which was the first large-scale cross-strait exchange in the LED industry.

Noting that China is promoting a project to install LED street lamps in its 10 major cities, Lee Chung-hsi, director of Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , said the project will provide an estimated NT$80 billion worth of business opportunities.
Lee said local LED companies should step up efforts to cooperate with Chinese corporations to secure a share of that huge pie.

ITRI Deputy Director Chu Hsin-sheng said the LED industry will see a fierce patent battle in the next few years. Against this backdrop, he said, the two sides of the strait should cooperate and integrate their resources.

After two days of extensive discussions, the two sides reached a six-point consensus to jointly craft a permanent cooperative mechanism, form a cross- strait LED industry alliance, set up a cross-strait LED patent databank, design a standardization mechanism and jointly establish an LED production chain.
Taiwan is the world's largest manufacturer of LED lighting products, with sales reaching NT$54 billion in 2008.
