DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 11, or the 19th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
2004: The Legislative Yuan passes amendments to the Labor Standard Law to allow laborers to open portable pension account.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: Nominee reaffirms U.S. commitment to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 10 (CNA) 06/11/09 11:44:14 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States remains strongly committed to preserving peace between Taiwan and China and will continue to meet Taiwan's defensive needs in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, the nominee for the U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs said Wednesday.

Kurt Campbell said the U.S. government remains very firm in terms of its response to any potential provocation in the Taiwan Strait and has demonstrated a clear determination to follow strictly and carefully the guidelines set forth in the Taiwan Relations Act.

"And that is to provide the appropriate defense articles to Taiwan, to consult closely with Congress and to ensure that the Taiwanese have the confidence of the United States as they embark upon diplomacy with China," Campbell said.
He said the United States encourages the "active diplomacy" that has been emerging between Taiwan and China over the past several months and wants to make sure that it continues in a peaceful way.
"We think we can provide the best context for that by both engaging China and also committing to Taiwan that we will meet their essential defensive needs," he said.

Campbell was testifying before a confirmation hearing held by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, during which he was asked about his position on the outstanding request for arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA to make decision soon on Taiwan's U.N. bid: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Thursday that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is now evaluating how to present the country's United Nations bid this year, and will make a decision soon.

"All possibilities are under evaluation," said Ou while reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee on President Ma Ying-jeou's recent state visit to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America.

"Basically, the Foreign Ministry is considering applying again for entry, but we are also evaluating under what circumstances we may not do so this year," he said. "There are several options and we will make a decision after consultations with the National Security Council."

Ou noted that Taiwan has made impressive progress in terms of international participation since its pragmatic approach to its U.N. bid last year and because of improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which he said resulted in its participation as an observer in the World Health Assembly this May.
The Foreign Ministry will carefully evaluate how to best make substantial gains while protecting the country's dignity in its U.N. bid this year, he added.

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator John Chiang said that if Taiwan decides not to make a bid this year, the foreign ministry must produce a position paper to explain the reasons clearly to the country's diplomatic allies.
Chiang suggested the MOFA give greater priority to Taiwan's efforts to join the International Civil Aviation Organization and International Maritime Organization.

In addition, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Twu Shiing-jer suggested Taiwan try to gain entry to the Universal Postal Union and the International Meteorological Organization, which are also U.N.-affiliated bodies.

In keeping with Ma's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy which favors a moderate and pragmatic approach, Taiwan asked the U.N. last September to consider its meaningful participation in affiliated agencies, rather than full membership in the U.N.

However, Taiwan's attempt to have its case included as a supplementary item on the agenda of the 63rd session of the U.N. General Assembly was rejected. But President Ma has said repeatedly that the more moderate approach was well- received in the international community, as evidenced by the fact that many major countries voiced support for the effort.
Taiwan has not been a member of the U.N. since 1971, when the People's Republic of China took over the China seat from the Republic of China.

Over the past 15 years, efforts to persuade the General Assembly to list the issue of Taiwan's membership on the U.N. agenda have failed mainly because of obstruction from China, which is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council and has veto power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two leading smart cards to be merged by year end

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two leading smart cards, or electronic purses, are likely to be merged by the end of this year, the heads of the issuing enterprises said Thursday.

Lien Shen-wen, chairman of EasyCard Corporation, which to date has issued 16 million EasyCards, and Hsu Chung-ren, chief executive officer of President Chain Store Corp., which has so far issued 7.4 million icash cards, announced Thursday their decision to integrate the cards.
Lien said they began exploring the possibility of a joint operation after the Legislative Yuan passed a bill to allow for the issue of multi-purpose electronic purses.

Although, the bill would not take effect before relevant regulation details could be worked out by the Finance Supervisory Commission, Lien said, "we will merge the two cards as soon as it is legally possible."

Lin Chih-ying, the chief executive officer of EasyCard Corp., forecast that the relevant regulations will be ready before the end of this year. "Our application for a merger is expected to be approved by the Finance Supervisory Commission one month after that," he added.

EasyCard, which originated in Taipei City as a pass to its mass transit system, is now being used in public transportation systems in northern Taiwan, mainly in Taipei County, Keelung County, Yilan County, and the island county of Lienchiang.
The iCash card is mainly used for payment at the country's 4,800-odd 7-Eleven chain stores that are operated by President Corp.
Currently, holders of EasyCard and iCash and can store credit of up to NT$10,000 on each card and use them to pay for public transportation and 7-Eleven purchases, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Findings show typhoons trigger slow earthquakes

TEXT.P: Typhoons, one of the most common natural phenomena in Taiwan, can trigger slow earthquakes, the findings of a joint Taiwan-U.S. research project showed Thursday.
Slow earthquakes are non-violent fault slippage events that release energy over a period of hours to months, instead of a few seconds to minutes as is characteristic of a typical earthquake.

The results were published in the June 11 issue of the international weekly journal Nature, in an article co-written by Liu Chi-ching, an associate research fellow at the Institute of Earth Science of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, and Alan Linde and Selwyn Sacks from the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism of the U.S.-based Carnegie Institution of Washington.

According to Liu, for the purpose of the research, three sensitive borehole strainmeters were installed 200 meters to 270 meters underground in Rueisuei, Dagangkou and Jhangyuan in eastern Taiwan to detect otherwise imperceptible seismic movements.
Between August 2003 and August 2007, a total of 20 slow earthquakes were recorded, with 11 occurring simultaneously with typhoons, Liu said.
These 11 events were also stronger and characterized by more complex waveforms than the other nine, he said.

On the question of how typhoons trigger the slow quakes, the research team explained that the low pressure associated with typhoons impacts only on land areas and does not affect conditions at the bottom of the ocean, because water moves into the area and equalizes the pressure there.
The reduction in pressure above one section of an obliquely dipping fault that runs partly under land and partly under the ocean floor tends to unclamp it, they explained.

The researchers speculated that the reason devastating earthquakes are rare in eastern Taiwan is because the slow earthquakes act as valves, releasing the stress frequently along a small section of the fault.
This eliminates a situation where a long segment sustains continuous high stresses until it ruptures in a single huge earthquake, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sets sights on young tourists at Hong Kong travel fair
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/09 15:54:39 (By Mandy Wong and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Youth Commission (NYC) is promoting a range of special offers specifically geared toward young people, as part of its promotional efforts at the ongoing International Travel Expo in Hong Kong.
The commission is focusing on promoting its "Youth Travel in Taiwan" Web site and Youth Travel Card which offer a number of special deals and discounts for young travelers.

Under a promotional campaign, launched by the commission in cooperation with China Airlines (CAL) , people who apply for a Youth Travel Card and are members of CAL's Dynasty Flyer Program are entitled to airfare discounts of 40 percent and are permitted to check luggage weighing 10 kilograms in excess of the standard limit. They will also have a chance to win a round-trip air ticket between Hong Kong and Taipei.

In addition, on-site applicants for the Youth Travel Card are eligible to enter another lucky draw for a free in-depth trip to Taiwan and are given a pair of sandals at the fair, which will run until June 14.
Youth Travel Card holders will also have access to a wide array of special offers for sightseeing, shopping, transportation, accommodation, Chinese language learning and many other purposes.

Moreover, backpacking card holders can apply for free use of the commission's Digital Tour Buddy, a bilingual mobile phone service to a24-hour hotline that offers foreign backpackers travel and service information.
To encourage young tourists to visit Taiwan, the NYC and four Taiwan universities have trained a number of local youth volunteers to serve as tour guides.

Meanwhile, as part of the youth travel promotion effort, Taiwan Railways Administration is issuing TRPass for eligible Hong Kong and foreign students, which will give them lower fares for travel around the country by train.
The commission, in conjunction with operators of local youth hostels, is also providing safe and quality lodging at low prices to lure young Hong Kong travelers to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung County to be cruise destination in August

TEXT.P: Taichung County in central Taiwan will be a destination for international passenger cruise lines in August, in the latest positive development in Taiwan's quest to attract more tourists, an official said Thursday.

A Hong Kong-based passenger liner operated by the Star Cruises company, Asia's largest cruise operator, will stop at the county's Taichung Port Aug. 4, bringing 1,600 tourists from China to visit the county, according to Chen Chin- fah, the county government's executive officer.
The company agreed to include Taichung County on its route during a county delegation's visit to Hong Kong earlier this month to promote tourism, Chen said.

Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng led the delegation to Hong Kong to promote the county's agricultural products and tourism from June 5-8. During his stay there, he met with the cruise company's president David Chua Ming-huat to facilitate the cooperation, Chen said
He added that the county government has designed three different itineraries -- covering mountains, costal lines, and the plains - - to appeal to the Chinese tourists.
Star Cruises will send a representative to Taichung to better understand the travel routes.
The company said it would include Taichung County into regular cruise lines if the destination gains popularity in the future, according to Chen.
Currently, Keelung Port in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan are the island's only two destinations included in passenger cruises operated by Star Cruises.

During its trip to Hong Kong, the Taichung county delegation also met with representatives of Hong Kong's food importers and food processing industry to pave the way for exporting the county's agricultural products to Hong Kong in the future, Chen said.

Taiwan's Tourism Bureau has designated 2008 and 2009 as "Tour Taiwan Years", rolling out a host of special deals and incentives, including the chance for North American and European transit passengers to stay in one of Taipei's finest hotels for US$1 or 1 euro a night.

The Bureau recently also launched the "Best Trip in the World" contest aimed at luring interest from all over the world by offering winning teams of contestants money to spend during their travels in Taiwan, as long as they publicize their trip online.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU office in Taiwan to hold exhibition on climate change

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) -- the European Union's de Facto embassy in Taiwan -- said Thursday that it will hold an exhibition on climate change this month to raise awareness about the issue and encourage efforts to battle global warming.
"The aim of this exhibition on climate change is to raise awareness of the Taiwanese public of the need for global action in the fight against climate change," the EETO said in a press release.
"Cooperation and exchanges of ideas and techniques are important strategies in the common fight against global warning," it added.

According to the EETO, the exhibition will show that the European Union offers its expertise and technical know-how to ensure the protection of the environment, while encouraging Taiwanese citizens and companies to use simple, but effective measures, to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
The office noted that the European Union has already adopted a plan to reduce CO2 emissions to an average of 20 percent below the 1990 level by the year 2020.

It said that 2009 is a particularly important year regarding climate change as the international community will gather in Copenhagen in December to decide on the level of reduction of green house gas emissions with commitment by each country.

To realize these ambitious goals for the benefit of the globe, the EU needs the cooperation and support from every country and that is why the EU is stepping up its contacts with partners, both in the United Nations and beyond, the EETO said.

The exhibition is scheduled to be held from June 17- 19 and July 4-8 at the atrium of the Taipei City government before moving on to a tour in October and November to National Taiwan University, National Chung Hsing University, National Sun Yat-sen University and National Dong Hwa University.
The EETO serves as the de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: 89% of undergraduates plan to find summer jobs: survey

TEXT.P: Eighty-nine percent of undergraduates are planning to work during the coming summer vacation, with waitering topping the list of most-wanted jobs, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by an online employment broker.
Among those who intend to find summer work, 86 percent said they are doing so to earn pocket money or to support their own lifestyle, the results showed.
Sixty-one percent mentioned the need to enrich their work experience in preparation for their job searches after graduation, and 37 percent said they need money to pay their tuition fees.
Asked to name the positions they will be seeking, 56 percent said they wanted to work as restaurant waiters, and 43 percent mentioned customer service representatives.
Among other popular positions were educational guidance counselors, favored by 22 percent, and jobs in the travel and leisure sector, preferred by 17 percent.
The survey was conducted by 104 Job Bank from June 4-9 among 9,419 undergraduates. It had a margin of error of 1.01 percentage points.

According to minijob.com.tw, a brokerage site run by the job bank to serve small and medium-sized businesses, a total of 16,000 part-time jobs are listed on the site this month, while 25,000 undergraduates are searching on the site for part- time work.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower calls for urgent assistance to poor families

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) has launched a campaign to help 500 economically disadvantaged families around the country, through a direct donation and 12- hour "famine experience" event to raise funds for the underprivileged.

Taipower Chairman Edward K.M.Chen and 180 employees of the company went without solid food for 12 hours Wednesday as part of an anti-famine drive initiated by the Christian charity World Vision Taiwan.
"Because of the economic recession, many economically disadvantaged families in Taiwan are in need of support, " Chen said. "We hope our fund- raising efforts will help more people," he added.
Taipower also announced at the event that it is donating NT$1.5 million (US$45,816) to provide assistance to 500 poor families.
The company is simultaneously running a "Light up Taiwan with Love, Power up Disadvantaged Families" campaign to give more punch to the anti-famine efforts.

Sue Yue, a lifetime volunteer with World Vision Taiwan, met Wednesday with the Taipower employees who were participating in the drive and shared with them his experience at fasting. He also encouraged them to get involved in the charity sales that are part of the event and to make donations.
Sun Yue said that he has seen the worldwide benefits of World Vision's 30-Hour Famine campaign over the last 20 years, and that he is pleased to see Taipower participating.

World Vision will celebrate the 20th anniversary of its 30-hour anti-famine drive at Linkou Multipurpose Gymnasium in Taipei County, Aug. 15 - 16. With 344 groups and 44,000 individuals already enrolled to join the effort, the number of participants is expected to exceed the 27,430 that attended last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President eyes emerging markets to reduce reliance on China

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that Taiwan cannot solely rely on the Chinese market to improve its economy, and it is necessary for the country to explore emerging markets to obtain sustainable economic development.

"China represents both a threat and an opportunity and Taiwan must be very cautious in dealing with it, " Ma said in a meeting with representatives of the Taipei-based China Youth Career Development Association from across the country at the Presidential Office.
Improved Taiwan-China relations over the past year has helped minimize the impact of the global financial crisis on Taiwan's economy, Ma said.
But he added that Taiwan needs to set its sight on other emerging markets, such as Brazil, India, Indonesia and Russia, in its future market exploration efforts.
As Taiwan's economic growth relies heavily on exports, domestic businesses should edge into other markets with large populations and great potential for consumption, Ma said.

Currently, thousands of passengers from India make a transit each week at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport on their way to the United States, which underlines Taiwan's key location in the region and provides a clue for Taiwanese companies in their search of a new marketplace and ways to reduce risks arising from over-reliance on the Chinese market, Ma noted.
He added that high-quality and reasonably-priced Taiwanese products should be very attractive to the people in these new emerging markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Envoy urges Taiwanese companies to tap Malaysian market

TEXT.P: Abdullah Mohd Salleh, president of the Taipei-based Malaysian Friendship and Trade Center (MFTC) and Malaysias top envoy to Taiwan, urged Taiwanese companies Thursday to explore business opportunities in his country and use it as the springboard to the market of the Association for Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , starting by participating in Malaysia's trade exhibition later this year.

Given that Malaysia is considered the commerce center of the ASEAN bloc, INTRADE Malaysia 2009 can also be used as a springboard to penetrate the ASEAN market of 600 million consumers as well as the Middle East markets, especially for Halal products,said Abdullah at a news conference to promote INTRADE Malaysia, which will take place Nov. 10-12 in Kuala Lumpur for the third consecutive year.
Abdullah said the strong trade and investment relationship between Taiwan and Malaysia has become the foundation for developing cooperation in tourism, education, culture and friendship.

According to Abdullah, the two sides can also cooperate in other sectors, such as construction services, building materials, Islamic finance, Halal products, palm oil-based products, agro-biotechnology, marine, pharmaceutical and tropical medicine.

Muhd Shahrulmiza Zakaria, director of trade at MFTC, said on the same occasion that INTRADE Malaysia is an ideal platform to make new contacts and explore opportunities with business people from various countries.

He noted that last year alone, the trade show was participated by 368 exhibitors from 32 countries and attracted some 4,800 visitors to generate US$60 million in sales and US$ 700 million in following-up business.

Given the potential opportunities for growth in trade and business in Malaysia, which is strategically located in the ASEAN region, and taking into consideration the difficult times we are in today, it is important for the business community to strengthen their strategic alliances and work together in identifying avenues to enhance commercial collaborations,Shahrulmiza said.

In 2008, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Malaysia recorded a positive growth of 2.52 percent with total trade valued at US$12.15 billion. Taiwans imports from Malaysia increased to US$6.78 billion, a growth of 2.8 percent, while exports to Malaysia increased to US$5.37 billion, a 2.2 percent increase.
Malaysia was Taiwan's ninth largest trading partner and export destination and its 10th largest source of imports in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese business group visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Chinese business group, led by China's former Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng, is in Taipei to explore opportunities for investment and the procurement of Taiwan-made products.

Shi and the 25-member group, which arrived in Taiwan Wednesday, attended a roundtable meeting Thursday sponsored by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) on the prospects of bilateral trade across the Taiwan Strait and how the business sectors from the two sides could further explore the vast mainland Chinese markets.

The group -- comprised of officials from China's Ministry of Commerce and executives from the private China Association of Enterprises with Foreign Investment (CAEFI) -- was invited to attend a dinner hosted by Cathay Financial Holdings Thursday.

Shi, who is now chairman of the CAEFI, and his delegation are scheduled to visit the headquarters of the Formosa Plastics Group in Taipei Friday and to travel to central Taiwan Saturday before returning to Taipei next Monday.

The Chinese delegation includes executives from some of China's major industrial players such as COFCO, the country's largest foodstuff importer and exporter, and China Minmetals Corp., the largest mines and hardware company in China.

The Chinese business leaders will visit other leading Taiwanese enterprises before heading to Kinmen next Tuesday, where they will catch a ferry to China's southeastern port city of Xiamen, according to TAITRA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: BNHI urged to cover early-stage breast cancer treatment

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) will later this month study the feasibility of covering the costs of targeted therapy for early-stage breast cancer under the national health insurance system, a BNHI official said Thursday.

Sheen Mao-ting, a BNHI official in charge of reviewing medical claims, made the comment in response to a call by several ruling Kuomintang legislators for the national health insurance to cover this type of treatment.

Legislator Huang Chao-shun said that targeted therapy for early-stage breast cancer, which aims to slow the growth of cancer cells, costs 20 times less than the medical bills for treating such cancers if they spread.
She added that in many countries, including Thailand, targeted therapies are covered by national health insurance. "Why can't Taiwan do the same?" she asked.

Legislator Lin Hung-chih also said that the government's tax revenues from a hike in the health surcharge on cigarettes, beginning June 1, are expected to be more than NT$20 billion per year, while the cost of covering targeted medicines for early-stage breast cancer would be only NT$900 million.
Therefore, he said, he hopes the BNHI would soon agree to cover the payments for that type of treatment.

The health and welfare surcharge on tobacco products will be increased from NT$10 per pack to NT$20 per pack with effect from June 1. Seventy percent of the surcharge revenues will be used by the BNHI in various areas, including cancer prevention which will be allocated 6 percent of the revenues.

Yang Li-huan, another KMT legislator and a breast cancer survivor, said that women around the age of 40 years make up the largest group of breast cancer sufferers and are also the main supporters of their families. In view of the fact that early detection of cancer greatly increases the chances of successful treatment, the government should quickly allocate funds for early treatment of the disease, she urged.

Citing a report released March by the Department of Health, Taiwan Breast Cancer Alliance Secretary-General Lin Wei-jie said that 6,895 new breast cancer cases were recorded in Taiwan in 2006, and 1,552 women died of that type of malignancy in 2007.

Lin said the national health insurance system covers targeted therapy only for fourth-stage breast cancer treatment. However, after treatment, the survival rate of cancer patients in this stage is only 30 percent, she noted.
It costs about NT$700,000 to NT$800,000 to undergo a program of targeted therapy, Lin said, adding that most early-stage breast cancer sufferers can hardly afford to pay that.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rebound to break 6,500 mark

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the second consecutive day Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 105.10 points, or 1.62 percent, to close at 6,567.37.
Following Wall Street's overnight loss, the local bourse opened low at 6,458.62 and dropped to the day's low of 6,353.78 before closing at the day's high of 6,567.37
A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$116.66 billion (US$3.56 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.1 percent. Cement stocks rose 3.5 percent, textile shares advanced 2.1 percent, banking and financial shares gained 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 1.3 percent, and foodstuff stocks gained 1.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,514 to 649, with 130 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$735 million on shares.

Banking and financial shares closed higher, reversing earlier losses during the session on news that the timetable for a financial supervisory cooperation agreement between Taiwan and China might be pushed back from the first half of this year.
The TAIEX shed more than 400 points in the first two days of the week before rallying for two consecutive days.
An analyst with KGI Securities Co. predicted that the market could make a comeback if the rising streak continues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.083 to close at NT$32.798.
A total of US$765 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.865 and dropping to the day's low of NT$32.655.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Shanghai set to forge closer economic ties
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/09 19:10:45 (By P.Y. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Encouraged by improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties and ever-increasing exchanges, Taiwan and Shanghai are poised to boost mutually beneficial two-way trade and economic cooperation, a Taiwan trade promoter said Thursday.

Chao Yung-chuan, general-secretary of Taiwan's semi-official trade-promoting agency -- Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), made the remarks following a visit to Cen Furong, chairman of the Council for the China Promotion of International Trade Shanghai (CCPIT Shanghai Sub-Council) to exchange views on ways to step up bilateral trade and economic links.

"The two sides agreed to step up two-way trade and economic activities, " Chao said, adding that the fast-growing Chinese market provides a powerful engine that contributes to Taiwan's economic progress.

Chao said he has invited Cen and other CCPIT Shanghai Sub-Council members to attend a TAITRA-sponsored trade fair featuring Taiwan's famous brands of products -- to be held from Sept. 17-20 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province.
More than 200 Shanghai-based Taiwanese companies have registered to take part in the show, Chao said.

Chao arrived in Shanghai Tuesday and along with famous architect C.Y. Lee, met with the authorities of World Expo 2010 Shanghai Tuesday and Wednesday to explore ideas relating to construction of the Taiwan Pavilion at the expo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteer divers invited to join coral reef inspection mission

TEXT.P: Two environmental groups invited divers Thursday to take part in an annual coral reef inspection program in which they will help monitor and report on the health of coral reefs in Taiwan's coastal waters.

The program, now in its 10th year, had been funded in past years by the government and held as part of academic research. But this year, it is being organized by the private Taiwan Environmental Information Association and the Taiwan Marine Environment Education Promotion Association as a public activity for the first time.

According to the groups, registration for the "2009 Reef Check" is open to individuals who are certified as advance divers. Participants will need to pay for the costs related to the activity and will be given the required scientific training before the event starts.

A total of eight sessions are scheduled between May 23 and late September in Taiwan's northeast coast, Green Island, Orchid Island, Liouciouyu, Penghu and Taitung's Shanyuan, the groups said, adding that registration is set to end three weeks before each session.
Those interested in taking part can visit the activity's Web site at http://e-info.org.tw/node/40662.

Allen Chen, an associate research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Biodiversity Research Center, said he believes the activity will help raise public awareness about the conservation of coral reefs, whose survival is being threatened by climate change, land pollutants released into seas, overdevelopment of coastal regions and overfishing.
Frank, a participant of the "2009 reef check," pointed out that a large variety of rare marine life, including pygmy seahorses, can be found in coral reefs in Taiwan's waters.
Such abundance reef resources should be properly conserved because they are one of Taiwan's most important attractions to tourists, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four more imported swine flu cases confirmed

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported Thursday four more cases of imported swine flu, with three from Thailand and one from America, bringing to 36 the country's total number of confirmed cases.

According to the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC), one of the four new cases is a 22-year-old female, who traveled on a college graduation trip to Thailand from June 3-9 along with a 22-member group. She was found with a fever upon her arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at the end of her trip.
Two students in the same group found with fevers have been found not to be infected with swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1).

The 34th case is a 26-year-old man, who was in a 30-member tour group to Thailand from June 3-8. The man began to suffer from symptoms of fever and coughing after returning to Taiwan, and went to the hospital on June 9.
No other member in the man's group has been discovered with swine flu symptoms, the center said.

The 35th case is a 30-year-old Thai engineer working in Taiwan, who returned to and stayed in his country from May 27-June 7. The man came down with a fever and a runny nose from June 9 and went to the hospital by himself the following day.
He had contacts with a friend with swine flu symptoms, and also had short contacts with his colleagues in Taiwan from May 31-June 2.
The center has asked those who had been around him to monitor their own health.

The last case is a 14-year-old American boy who arrived in Taiwan on June 5. The boy started to experience coughing and a fever from June 9. He canceled his trip to Australia and stayed in Taiwan to cooperate with the country's epidemic prevention measures, the center said.

The center has reported the four new cases to the World Health Organization, which held a meeting Thursday on whether to raise the global swine flu pandemic alert from the current level five to level six.

Taiwan's center added that examinations showed none of those who had contact with a group of Taiwanese students, reported by the center on June 9 to have contracted swine flu during their graduation tour in Thailand, are infected.
According to WHO statistics, as of June 10, 74 countries have officially reported 27,737 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 141 deaths.
Among Taiwan's 36 confirmed cases, 35 are imported cases and only one is indigenous. The country has made examinations on 1,066 reported cases, and is conducting inspections on another 24 cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bunun children's choir wins prestigious music award

TEXT.P: An indigenous children's choir from the central county of Nantou was honored Thursday by the county magistrate for having recently won a Golden Melody Award, a local award sometimes described in Taiwan as the "Taiwan Grammys."

The Bunun children's choir of the Dongpu Elementary School -- a small school of just 67 students nestled at the foot of Yushan, Taiwan's highest peak -- won the award for a CD they produced, led by school principal Ma Pi-teh.

The 25 choristers, in grades three to six, sang one of the tunes off the CD, titled Sing It! -- a traditional Bunun tune titled The Welcoming Song -- at a reception held at Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching's office.

At the reception, Ma expressed his appreciation to several enterprises and individuals, including the Teco Technology Foundation, for their sponsorship of the choir, which has over the past three years been invited to perform at the National Music Hall in Taipei, in Bangkok and in the Chinese city of Xiamen.
Ma, himself a member of the Bunun tribe, said the choir was established mainly to build confidence among the Bunun children.

Ma, who established the choir and trains the children, said he disagrees with ignorant and racist voices who claim that "indigenous children have good voices because they are born to sing, " pointing out that the choir members' heavenly voices are simply the results of strenuous daily practice and determination.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC upgrades swine flu yellow travel alert for Hong Kong

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) issued a yellow phase-three travel alert for Hong Kong Thursday over concern about the first confirmed indigenous case of swine flu in the Chinese special administrative region.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the council decided to raise the previous yellow phase-two travel advisory for Hong Kong to yellow phase-three after an indigenous case of swine flu, known officially as influenza A (H1N1), was confirmed there earlier that day.
The Hong Kong authorities later announced that all elementary schools, kindergartens and nursery schools would close for two weeks from the following day.
Liu noted that the issuance of the phase-three alert advises people traveling to Hong Kong to take health precautions.
As of June 10, 74 countries had officially reported 27,737 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 141 deaths, according to World Health Organization data.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seaside schools to confer diplomas in underwater commencement

TEXT.P: A commencement ceremony beside the seaside is beautiful, but a group of elementary and junior high school graduates from Taipei County will go a step further, graduating in a ceremony they will remember for the rest of their lives.

A total of 101 graduates from seven elementary and junior high schools in Kungliao township, Taipei County, are scheduled to receive their diplomas from Principal Chang Po-tsang of the Homei Elementary School in Kungliao at an underwater commencement slated for Saturday.
The graduates will first snorkel out for about 100 meters to a floating command bridge, where they will then dive underwater to get their diplomas, according to Chang.

The children have been practicing since May to prepare for the underwater commencement. Apart from the students from Homei Elementary and Fulien Elementary schools, which are located by the seaside, some of the 101 graduates are first-time swimmers, according to Chang.

Homei Elementary School was the first school in Taiwan to have an underwater commencement, an event has been well-received by the entire Homei community, a fishing village near deep water in which coral, fish and plants are both abundant and magnificent, Chang said.
Almost all the students of the Homei school come from homes dependent on the fishing industry, so none of them are strangers to the sea, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE unveils regulations for universities to leave market

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) unveiled a package of regulations Thursday to pave the way for local universities that have failed ministry evaluations or are unable to recruit enough students to gradually exit the education market.

Under the new regulations, universities that fail to recruit up to 70 percent of their officially approved student numbers for three consecutive years will have their annual quotas cut by 10 percent to 30 percent.
As a result of the regulations, no local universities will see their student quotas slashed until the 2011 school year, which critics said will hold back domestic education reform.
According to MOE statistics, enrollment at local tertiary education institutions fell short of the target by nearly 60,000 in the 2008 school year, the largest shortfall in five years.
The average freshman registration rate also fell to a five-year low of 82.98 percent, the statistics show.

Twenty-four of the 162 universities and technology institutes in Taiwan -- all 24 of which are privately run -- saw their freshmen registration rates fall short of the 70 percent target in the 2008 school year and one of them even had a miserable registration rate of just 11.62 percent.

MOE officials said the ministry has included the student enrollment rate into a list of measurement indicators in its tertiary education institutions assessment system to better reflect the education market situation.

Under the newly unveiled university quantitative control regulations, faculty quality and quantity, as well as the faculty/student ratio, will also be factored in when deciding each school's student enrollment quota.

Meanwhile, media reports said that even though the government's plan to open Taiwan to Chinese university hopefuls is still in the works, many local private tertiary education institutions have been preparing to attract Chinese youngsters to their campuses.

Because of Taiwan's declining birth rate, the number of local university students has been dropping steadily. Out of concern that they may not be able to recruit enough students in the coming years, school authorities have pegged their hopes on Chinese students as a new source of income.

Ou Shan-hui, president of the private Tajen University in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, was quoted as having said recently that the difficulties schools face in recruiting enough students could be largely resolved if they can attract even just 1 percent of the over 10 million Chinese students who vie to enter Chinese universities annually.

According to Ou, his school has been forging cooperative ties with various universities in China since last year. While China has many tertiary education institutions, Ou said, it lags behind Taiwan in the development of colleges catering to the needs of the leisure industry.

"I believe our school's department of recreation and sport management, department of hospitality and hotel management and department of tourism should be attractive to Chinese college hopefuls," said Ou.

Tunghai University in central Taiwan has also stepped up efforts to explore Chinese students' learning preferences and demand by exchanges students with several prestigious universities in China, such as Peking University, Fudan University and Nanjing University.

The university, founded by Methodist missionaries in Taichung City in 1955, has also set aside budget for advertising on major Web portals in China to enhance the school's awareness among Chinese students, a Tunghai official said.

Nevertheless, the official went on, Tunghai will not go into the China market blind. "We will carefully evaluate the financial status of any Chinese applicants, as well as their academic qualifications, before recruiting them," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOU on financial cooperation could come soon: FSC

TEXT.P: It is conceivable that a Taiwan-China memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation could be signed this month or next, but it would be unwise to predict a timetable for such an MOU before negotiations on the issue have ended, Financial Supervisory Committee (FSC) Chairman Sean C. Chen said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks when making a report on the possible impact of Chinese investment in Taiwan's market at a joint legislative committee meeting attended by officials from the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Despite Taiwan's recent opening of its securities and futures markets to Chinese qualified domestic institutional investors, those investors cannot invest in Taiwanese shares until the MOU on financial supervisory cooperation with China is signed, Chen noted recently.

Following the signing of a financial cooperation agreement with China during a third round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations April 26 in Nanjing, Taiwan's financial authorities have placed more emphasis on inking an MOU with China to allow for two-way collaboration in the supervision and regulation of the banking, securities and futures, and insurance sectors.

According to Chen, Taiwan and China have no problem with the MOU's content, but the two required versions of the MOU -- one in the traditional Chinese characters used in Taiwan and the other in the simplified characters used in China -- would make matters more complex.

In response to lawmakers' questions regarding the establishment of a much- anticipated Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said that in line with an MOEA projection, two sides are expected to start talks on the issue by the end of this year.

A day earlier, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that "Taiwan and China will not necessarily sign an ECFA in the second half of this year or the first half of 2010 in their coming rounds of talks, " while answering questions from legislators at a joint legislative committee meeting.
Lai said she could not give any assurances concerning the issue, although she noted that the government hopes to start relevant talks with China as quickly as possible.
The idea of an ECFA with China has touched a nerve of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which fears that Taiwan's independent sovereignty might be hurt by the planned accord.
The DPP wants the issue to be decided by the people in a referendum and has been collecting signatures from its supporters in support of its plan. It hopes to obtain 100,000 signatures by early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 high speed rail passengers affected by switch dysfunction

TEXT.P: Nearly 20,000 passengers on Taiwan's high speed railway were affected Thursday by a dysfunctional switch on the section of line between Taipei and Banciao stations in northern Taiwan.
Trains operated by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. stopped services between Taipei and Banciao for five hours between 11 a.m. and 4 p.m., affecting some 20,000 passengers, THSRC authorities said.

The switch dysfunction led to delays for 14 trains, seven of which were held up for more than 30 minutes, entitling around 4,000 passengers aboard these trains to receive a 50 percent refund on the cost of their tickets, THSRC authorities said.

The 345-km railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, inaugurated in January 2007, has reduced rail travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to 90 minutes from the previous four-and-a-half hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian envoy gratified with close Taipei-Moscow ties

TEXT.P: The top Russian envoy to Taiwan praised relations between Taipei and Moscow Thursday, saying the two countries have close ties not only on the economic and trade fronts but also in many other fields such as science and technology, culture and education.

Sergey N. Gubarev made the remarks at a reception hosted by the Representative Office of the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation Thursday on the eve of Russia's national day.

"I've already worked here for 3.5 years and in this period I've never met a cold attitude on the part of Taiwanese, " Gubarev said at the function, which was attended by Vice Foreign Minister Javier Hou, members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.

According to Gubarev, while bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia reached a record US$4 billion in 2008, people-to-people exchanges are also vibrant, with some 300 Taiwanese students in Russia and 200 Russian students in Taiwan, as well as around 10,000 Taiwanese travelers going to Russia each year.

Hou said for his part that despite the close economic ties, there is still ample room for growth in bilateral relations and he expressed pleasure that the government's "New Zheng He" export promotion plan has set Russia as one of the countries with which Taiwan aims to boost economic and trade exchanges.
"I'm confident that the already solid foundations and pragmatic approaches in bilateral relations will allow even greater mutual development and beneficial growth in the future," Hou added.
Established in 1992, the representative office is the de facto Russian embassy in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Russia and Taiwan.

On June 12, 1990, the Russian parliament formally declared its sovereignty from the Soviet Union, which set the wheels in motion for the creation of what is now known as the Russian Federation. Russian Day was officially recognized as a national holiday by former President Boris Yeltsin in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax exemption for teachers, military to be phased out

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, the Executive Yuan finally passed a draft legal amendment Thursday that, if approved by the legislature, will cancel the decades-old income tax exemption for grassroots school teachers and military personnel.
The Executive Yuan passed the draft amendment to the Income Tax Law at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

If the draft package clears the legislative floor, the amended law will be put into force at the beginning of next year, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said at a news conference held after the meeting.
Su called on the ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislative Yuan to approve the draft as soon as possible.

According to Su, the law revision will affect some 350,000 people, including the country's active duty military personnel and teachers at day care centers and kindergartens, as well as at public and private elementary and junior high schools.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said the national coffers will receive an estimated NT$16 billion (US$487.8 million) in increased tax revenues annually as a result of the revisions.

He added that the increased tax revenues in the first year will all be returned to the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of National Defense for various projects to improve welfare services for school faculty members and military personnel.
In the future, however, the national coffers will gradually benefit from the annulment of the tax exemption privileges, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 12, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Envoy urges Taiwanese companies to tap Malaysian market

TEXT.P: Abdullah Mohd Salleh, president of the Taipei-based Malaysian Friendship and Trade Center (MFTC) and Malaysias top envoy to Taiwan, urged Taiwanese companies Thursday to explore business opportunities in his country and use it as the springboard to the market of the Association for Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , starting by participating in Malaysia's trade exhibition later this year.

Given that Malaysia is considered the commerce center of the ASEAN bloc, INTRADE Malaysia 2009 can also be used as a springboard to penetrate the ASEAN market of 600 million consumers as well as the Middle East markets, especially for Halal products,said Abdullah at a news conference to promote INTRADE Malaysia, which will take place Nov. 10-12 in Kuala Lumpur for the third consecutive year.
Abdullah said the strong trade and investment relationship between Taiwan and Malaysia has become the foundation for developing cooperation in tourism, education, culture and friendship.

According to Abdullah, the two sides can also cooperate in other sectors, such as construction services, building materials, Islamic finance, Halal products, palm oil-based products, agro-biotechnology, marine, pharmaceutical and tropical medicine.

Muhd Shahrulmiza Zakaria, director of trade at MFTC, said on the same occasion that INTRADE Malaysia is an ideal platform to make new contacts and explore opportunities with business people from various countries.

He noted that last year alone, the trade show was participated by 368 exhibitors from 32 countries and attracted some 4,800 visitors to generate US$60 million in sales and US$ 700 million in following-up business.

Given the potential opportunities for growth in trade and business in Malaysia, which is strategically located in the ASEAN region, and taking into consideration the difficult times we are in today, it is important for the business community to strengthen their strategic alliances and work together in identifying avenues to enhance commercial collaborations,Shahrulmiza said.

In 2008, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Malaysia recorded a positive growth of 2.52 percent with total trade valued at US$12.15 billion. Taiwans imports from Malaysia increased to US$6.78 billion, a growth of 2.8 percent, while exports to Malaysia increased to US$5.37 billion, a 2.2 percent increase.
Malaysia was Taiwan's ninth largest trading partner and export destination and its 10th largest source of imports in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese business group visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Chinese business group, led by China's former Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng, is in Taipei to explore opportunities for investment and the procurement of Taiwan-made products.

Shi and the 25-member group, which arrived in Taiwan Wednesday, attended a roundtable meeting Thursday sponsored by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) on the prospects of bilateral trade across the Taiwan Strait and how the business sectors from the two sides could further explore the vast mainland Chinese markets.

The group -- comprised of officials from China's Ministry of Commerce and executives from the private China Association of Enterprises with Foreign Investment (CAEFI) -- was invited to attend a dinner hosted by Cathay Financial Holdings Thursday.

Shi, who is now chairman of the CAEFI, and his delegation are scheduled to visit the headquarters of the Formosa Plastics Group in Taipei Friday and to travel to central Taiwan Saturday before returning to Taipei next Monday.

The Chinese delegation includes executives from some of China's major industrial players such as COFCO, the country's largest foodstuff importer and exporter, and China Minmetals Corp., the largest mines and hardware company in China.

The Chinese business leaders will visit other leading Taiwanese enterprises before heading to Kinmen next Tuesday, where they will catch a ferry to China's southeastern port city of Xiamen, according to TAITRA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: BNHI urged to cover early-stage breast cancer treatment

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) will later this month study the feasibility of covering the costs of targeted therapy for early-stage breast cancer under the national health insurance system, a BNHI official said Thursday.

Sheen Mao-ting, a BNHI official in charge of reviewing medical claims, made the comment in response to a call by several ruling Kuomintang legislators for the national health insurance to cover this type of treatment.

Legislator Huang Chao-shun said that targeted therapy for early-stage breast cancer, which aims to slow the growth of cancer cells, costs 20 times less than the medical bills for treating such cancers if they spread.
She added that in many countries, including Thailand, targeted therapies are covered by national health insurance. "Why can't Taiwan do the same?" she asked.

Legislator Lin Hung-chih also said that the government's tax revenues from a hike in the health surcharge on cigarettes, beginning June 1, are expected to be more than NT$20 billion per year, while the cost of covering targeted medicines for early-stage breast cancer would be only NT$900 million.
Therefore, he said, he hopes the BNHI would soon agree to cover the payments for that type of treatment.

The health and welfare surcharge on tobacco products will be increased from NT$10 per pack to NT$20 per pack with effect from June 1. Seventy percent of the surcharge revenues will be used by the BNHI in various areas, including cancer prevention which will be allocated 6 percent of the revenues.

Yang Li-huan, another KMT legislator and a breast cancer survivor, said that women around the age of 40 years make up the largest group of breast cancer sufferers and are also the main supporters of their families. In view of the fact that early detection of cancer greatly increases the chances of successful treatment, the government should quickly allocate funds for early treatment of the disease, she urged.

Citing a report released March by the Department of Health, Taiwan Breast Cancer Alliance Secretary-General Lin Wei-jie said that 6,895 new breast cancer cases were recorded in Taiwan in 2006, and 1,552 women died of that type of malignancy in 2007.

Lin said the national health insurance system covers targeted therapy only for fourth-stage breast cancer treatment. However, after treatment, the survival rate of cancer patients in this stage is only 30 percent, she noted.
It costs about NT$700,000 to NT$800,000 to undergo a program of targeted therapy, Lin said, adding that most early-stage breast cancer sufferers can hardly afford to pay that.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rebound to break 6,500 mark

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher for the second consecutive day Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, advancing 105.10 points, or 1.62 percent, to close at 6,567.37.
Following Wall Street's overnight loss, the local bourse opened low at 6,458.62 and dropped to the day's low of 6,353.78 before closing at the day's high of 6,567.37
A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$116.66 billion (US$3.56 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.1 percent. Cement stocks rose 3.5 percent, textile shares advanced 2.1 percent, banking and financial shares gained 1.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 1.3 percent, and foodstuff stocks gained 1.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,514 to 649, with 130 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$735 million on shares.

Banking and financial shares closed higher, reversing earlier losses during the session on news that the timetable for a financial supervisory cooperation agreement between Taiwan and China might be pushed back from the first half of this year.
The TAIEX shed more than 400 points in the first two days of the week before rallying for two consecutive days.
An analyst with KGI Securities Co. predicted that the market could make a comeback if the rising streak continues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.083 to close at NT$32.798.
A total of US$765 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.865 and dropping to the day's low of NT$32.655.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Shanghai set to forge closer economic ties
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 11 (CNA) 06/11/09 19:10:45 (By P.Y. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Encouraged by improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties and ever-increasing exchanges, Taiwan and Shanghai are poised to boost mutually beneficial two-way trade and economic cooperation, a Taiwan trade promoter said Thursday.

Chao Yung-chuan, general-secretary of Taiwan's semi-official trade-promoting agency -- Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), made the remarks following a visit to Cen Furong, chairman of the Council for the China Promotion of International Trade Shanghai (CCPIT Shanghai Sub-Council) to exchange views on ways to step up bilateral trade and economic links.

"The two sides agreed to step up two-way trade and economic activities, " Chao said, adding that the fast-growing Chinese market provides a powerful engine that contributes to Taiwan's economic progress.

Chao said he has invited Cen and other CCPIT Shanghai Sub-Council members to attend a TAITRA-sponsored trade fair featuring Taiwan's famous brands of products -- to be held from Sept. 17-20 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province.
More than 200 Shanghai-based Taiwanese companies have registered to take part in the show, Chao said.

Chao arrived in Shanghai Tuesday and along with famous architect C.Y. Lee, met with the authorities of World Expo 2010 Shanghai Tuesday and Wednesday to explore ideas relating to construction of the Taiwan Pavilion at the expo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Volunteer divers invited to join coral reef inspection mission

TEXT.P: Two environmental groups invited divers Thursday to take part in an annual coral reef inspection program in which they will help monitor and report on the health of coral reefs in Taiwan's coastal waters.

The program, now in its 10th year, had been funded in past years by the government and held as part of academic research. But this year, it is being organized by the private Taiwan Environmental Information Association and the Taiwan Marine Environment Education Promotion Association as a public activity for the first time.

According to the groups, registration for the "2009 Reef Check" is open to individuals who are certified as advance divers. Participants will need to pay for the costs related to the activity and will be given the required scientific training before the event starts.

A total of eight sessions are scheduled between May 23 and late September in Taiwan's northeast coast, Green Island, Orchid Island, Liouciouyu, Penghu and Taitung's Shanyuan, the groups said, adding that registration is set to end three weeks before each session.
Those interested in taking part can visit the activity's Web site at http://e-info.org.tw/node/40662.

Allen Chen, an associate research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Biodiversity Research Center, said he believes the activity will help raise public awareness about the conservation of coral reefs, whose survival is being threatened by climate change, land pollutants released into seas, overdevelopment of coastal regions and overfishing.
Frank, a participant of the "2009 reef check," pointed out that a large variety of rare marine life, including pygmy seahorses, can be found in coral reefs in Taiwan's waters.
Such abundance reef resources should be properly conserved because they are one of Taiwan's most important attractions to tourists, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four more imported swine flu cases confirmed

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported Thursday four more cases of imported swine flu, with three from Thailand and one from America, bringing to 36 the country's total number of confirmed cases.

According to the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC), one of the four new cases is a 22-year-old female, who traveled on a college graduation trip to Thailand from June 3-9 along with a 22-member group. She was found with a fever upon her arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport at the end of her trip.
Two students in the same group found with fevers have been found not to be infected with swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1).

The 34th case is a 26-year-old man, who was in a 30-member tour group to Thailand from June 3-8. The man began to suffer from symptoms of fever and coughing after returning to Taiwan, and went to the hospital on June 9.
No other member in the man's group has been discovered with swine flu symptoms, the center said.

The 35th case is a 30-year-old Thai engineer working in Taiwan, who returned to and stayed in his country from May 27-June 7. The man came down with a fever and a runny nose from June 9 and went to the hospital by himself the following day.
He had contacts with a friend with swine flu symptoms, and also had short contacts with his colleagues in Taiwan from May 31-June 2.
The center has asked those who had been around him to monitor their own health.

The last case is a 14-year-old American boy who arrived in Taiwan on June 5. The boy started to experience coughing and a fever from June 9. He canceled his trip to Australia and stayed in Taiwan to cooperate with the country's epidemic prevention measures, the center said.

The center has reported the four new cases to the World Health Organization, which held a meeting Thursday on whether to raise the global swine flu pandemic alert from the current level five to level six.

Taiwan's center added that examinations showed none of those who had contact with a group of Taiwanese students, reported by the center on June 9 to have contracted swine flu during their graduation tour in Thailand, are infected.
According to WHO statistics, as of June 10, 74 countries have officially reported 27,737 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 141 deaths.
Among Taiwan's 36 confirmed cases, 35 are imported cases and only one is indigenous. The country has made examinations on 1,066 reported cases, and is conducting inspections on another 24 cases.

TEXT.P: It is conceivable that a Taiwan-China memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation could be signed this month or next, but it would be unwise to predict a timetable for such an MOU before negotiations on the issue have ended, Financial Supervisory Committee (FSC) Chairman Sean C. Chen said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks when making a report on the possible impact of Chinese investment in Taiwan's market at a joint legislative committee meeting attended by officials from the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Despite Taiwan's recent opening of its securities and futures markets to Chinese qualified domestic institutional investors, those investors cannot invest in Taiwanese shares until the MOU on financial supervisory cooperation with China is signed, Chen noted recently.

Following the signing of a financial cooperation agreement with China during a third round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations April 26 in Nanjing, Taiwan's financial authorities have placed more emphasis on inking an MOU with China to allow for two-way collaboration in the supervision and regulation of the banking, securities and futures, and insurance sectors.

According to Chen, Taiwan and China have no problem with the MOU's content, but the two required versions of the MOU -- one in the traditional Chinese characters used in Taiwan and the other in the simplified characters used in China -- would make matters more complex.

In response to lawmakers' questions regarding the establishment of a much- anticipated Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said that in line with an MOEA projection, two sides are expected to start talks on the issue by the end of this year.

A day earlier, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said that "Taiwan and China will not necessarily sign an ECFA in the second half of this year or the first half of 2010 in their coming rounds of talks, " while answering questions from legislators at a joint legislative committee meeting.
Lai said she could not give any assurances concerning the issue, although she noted that the government hopes to start relevant talks with China as quickly as possible.
The idea of an ECFA with China has touched a nerve of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which fears that Taiwan's independent sovereignty might be hurt by the planned accord.
The DPP wants the issue to be decided by the people in a referendum and has been collecting signatures from its supporters in support of its plan. It hopes to obtain 100,000 signatures by early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 high speed rail passengers affected by switch dysfunction

TEXT.P: Nearly 20,000 passengers on Taiwan's high speed railway were affected Thursday by a dysfunctional switch on the section of line between Taipei and Banciao stations in northern Taiwan.
Trains operated by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. stopped services between Taipei and Banciao for five hours between 11 a.m. and 4 p.m., affecting some 20,000 passengers, THSRC authorities said.

The switch dysfunction led to delays for 14 trains, seven of which were held up for more than 30 minutes, entitling around 4,000 passengers aboard these trains to receive a 50 percent refund on the cost of their tickets, THSRC authorities said.

The 345-km railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, inaugurated in January 2007, has reduced rail travel time between Taiwan's two largest cities to 90 minutes from the previous four-and-a-half hours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Russian envoy gratified with close Taipei-Moscow ties

TEXT.P: The top Russian envoy to Taiwan praised relations between Taipei and Moscow Thursday, saying the two countries have close ties not only on the economic and trade fronts but also in many other fields such as science and technology, culture and education.

Sergey N. Gubarev made the remarks at a reception hosted by the Representative Office of the Moscow-Taipei Coordination Commission on Economic and Cultural Cooperation Thursday on the eve of Russia's national day.

"I've already worked here for 3.5 years and in this period I've never met a cold attitude on the part of Taiwanese, " Gubarev said at the function, which was attended by Vice Foreign Minister Javier Hou, members of the diplomatic corps and other dignitaries.

According to Gubarev, while bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia reached a record US$4 billion in 2008, people-to-people exchanges are also vibrant, with some 300 Taiwanese students in Russia and 200 Russian students in Taiwan, as well as around 10,000 Taiwanese travelers going to Russia each year.

Hou said for his part that despite the close economic ties, there is still ample room for growth in bilateral relations and he expressed pleasure that the government's "New Zheng He" export promotion plan has set Russia as one of the countries with which Taiwan aims to boost economic and trade exchanges.
"I'm confident that the already solid foundations and pragmatic approaches in bilateral relations will allow even greater mutual development and beneficial growth in the future," Hou added.
Established in 1992, the representative office is the de facto Russian embassy in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Russia and Taiwan.

On June 12, 1990, the Russian parliament formally declared its sovereignty from the Soviet Union, which set the wheels in motion for the creation of what is now known as the Russian Federation. Russian Day was officially recognized as a national holiday by former President Boris Yeltsin in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax exemption for teachers, military to be phased out

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, the Executive Yuan finally passed a draft legal amendment Thursday that, if approved by the legislature, will cancel the decades-old income tax exemption for grassroots school teachers and military personnel.
The Executive Yuan passed the draft amendment to the Income Tax Law at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

If the draft package clears the legislative floor, the amended law will be put into force at the beginning of next year, Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-pin said at a news conference held after the meeting.
Su called on the ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislative Yuan to approve the draft as soon as possible.

According to Su, the law revision will affect some 350,000 people, including the country's active duty military personnel and teachers at day care centers and kindergartens, as well as at public and private elementary and junior high schools.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said the national coffers will receive an estimated NT$16 billion (US$487.8 million) in increased tax revenues annually as a result of the revisions.

He added that the increased tax revenues in the first year will all be returned to the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of National Defense for various projects to improve welfare services for school faculty members and military personnel.
In the future, however, the national coffers will gradually benefit from the annulment of the tax exemption privileges, he said.

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally lower Friday, moving down 14.79 points at 6,552.58 on a turnover of NT$4.04 billion (US$123.18 million).
The weighted price index gained 105.10 points, or 1.62 percent, to close at 6,567.37 Thursday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at NT$32.724 at 9:45 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.074 from Thursday's close.
