DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 12, or the 20th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1938: China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human- powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti- Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
2001: The Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan gives a speech at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focuses on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: Activist group wants law to legalize sex workers

TEXT.P: Members of a women's rights activist organization appealed Friday to the government to speed up legislation to legalize workers in the sex trade.

Wang Fang-ping, secretary-general of the private Je-Je-chuen Compassionate Concern Association, which fights for the rights of licensed prostitutes, said her group wants the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to draft an amendment to the Statute of the Maintenance of Social Order and get it passed in two years to protect the rights of sex workers.

Wang, flanked by more than 20 supporters of the association, said the MOI has come up with a plan to allow exclusive sex trade zones to be established around the country, with local city or county governments sponsoring referendums for final decisions on the issue.
However, Wang argued, the plan is just an empty framework lacking details or coping measures for implementation.

She called for the MOI to sponsor civic forums in northern, central and southern Taiwan on government policies on the sex trade and related affairs so that forum discussions and opinions can be used as references when the government is drafting the amendment.
"Sex workers' voices should also be counted," she noted.

Ho Ming-liao, deputy director of the MOI's Department of Social Affairs, who acknowledged Wang and her group's appeal, said the ministry will take all points of view into consideration before coming up with a draft bill, but he declined to make any commitment to Wang's appeal for a timetable for the legislation and the content of the draft bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: Highest quality standards ready for World Games broadcast

TEXT.P: The Public Television Service (PTS) will use the highest transmission standards ever used in Taiwan to broadcast the July 16-26 World Games in Kaohsiung, PTS Deputy Executive Director Chung Yu-yuan said Wednesday.

PTS has leased four satellites to transmit the July 16 opening ceremony to ensure that audiences in five continents can view the games live, Chung said at a news briefing on details about TV coverage for the games.

In addition, more than 30 outside broadcast vans equipped with high definition television (HDTV) cameras will be mobilized, in what Chung described as the biggest event in TV broadcasting in Taiwan's history.

A 20-meter long helium-filled blimp will also fly over the World Games Main Stadium to film the opening and closing ceremonies, Chung went on, adding that the airship can stay aloft for four hours at a time.
Government Information Office Minister Su Jun-bin, who was also present at the news conference, thanked PTS for its efforts to promote the games and Taiwan to the world.
Su also said that through the games, which are expected to attract the participation of 102 countries, the visibility of Taiwan and Kaohsiung will be increased.
The opening ceremony will feature singers Hayley Westenra of New Zealand and Russell Watson of Britain, as well as local pop singers Huang Hisao-hu and Ah Shin, according to event organizers.

In addition to PTS, Chunghwa Telecom will deploy more than 500 staff to broadcast 35 sports from 23 event venues via its Media on Demand (MOD) system, hiChannel Internet and emome cell phone platforms, the organizers added.

In preparation for the games, the Kaohsiung city government began Friday to partially drain Lotus Lake -- the largest lake in the city -- in order to refill it with better quality water later this month to meet the requirements of the water sports events.
At present, the lake is not suitable for water sports because it has been depleted of oxygen due to a high concentration of algae, Huang said.
The water skiing, dragon boat racing and canoe polo events will be held on the lake.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flagship foods from five allies to be displayed at Taipei expo

TEXT.P: Flagship foods from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies that have signed free trade agreements (FTAs) with the country will be on display at this year's Taipei International Food Show slated to kick off June 23, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Friday.

Twenty companies from Panama, Guatemala, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras will display their most representative food products in 14 booths at the show, which will take place at the Taipei World Trade Center Nankang Exhibition Hall until June 26, TAITRA officials said.
The products expected to be exhibited at the Panama Booth will include coffee, dried papaya, hot chili sauces and noni products, to be offered by six Panamanian companies.

Two Guatemalan companies will display their products at the Guatemala Booth, including dried vegetables and fruit, nuts, roselle and lemongrass, while two Nicaraguan companies will show products such as honey, coffee, peanuts and frozen beef.
Two other Nicaraguan companies will use the fair to seek Taiwanese suppliers of food processing and packing machines, TAITRA officials said.

On display at the El Salvador Booth will be products from six companies, including organic lemon salt, organic lemon tea, roselle tea, coffee, noni juice, cashew nuts, organic soap, massage oils and shrimp powder.
Four Honduran companies will display products including palm oil, frozen shrimps, frozen lobsters, hot chili sauces, snack foods and jams, TAITRA officials said.

Exhibitors from the five countries are also expected to meet Taiwanese food importers for discussions on further cooperation during the fair, which is an important platform for domestic food producers and importers seeking to make contacts around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diabetes affects nearly 10% of Taiwan's population: study

TEXT.P: In 2008, nearly one in every 10 people in Taiwan were suffering from diabetes, a disease that is becoming increasingly prevalent in the country, according to the results of a study released Friday by the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI).
The study found that 9.2 percent of Taiwan's population was affected by the disease in 2008, up 2.7 percentage points from 2002, when the prevalence rate was 6.5 percent.

The disease was more common among men than among women, with the prevalence rate among men reaching 11.1 percent in 2008, up from 7.5 percent in 2002 and 5.4 percent for the 1993-1996 period, the results show.
The highest prevalence was found among men aged 65 and older -- registering 28.5 percent in 2008, a sharp rise from 17.6 percent in 2002 and 13.1 percent for the 1993-1996 period.

Chang Hsin-yi, an associate research fellow at the NHRI's Institute of Population Health Sciences, noted that the prevalence of diabetes tends to increase with age, which is true for both men and women.

According to Chang, diabetes-related treatment now claims the fifth-largest share of National Health Insurance expenditure and was the fourth-most common cause of death in Taiwan in 2007, indicating that the disease is becoming an urgent health concern.
The Department of Health (DOH), meanwhile, advised the public to get regular health check-ups to facilitate early diagnosis.
To prevent the disease, people should adopt a diet with a high proportion of vegetables and whole grains and control their weight within ideal limits, the DOH said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Average ages for first marriage rise: CEPD statistics

TEXT.P: The average ages at first marriage for men and women in 2007 were 31 and 28.1, respectively, both rising by about two years from the 1991 figures, according to statistics released Friday by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The report also shows that the number of people of both genders aged between 15-39 who were married had fallen, with the rate of married male people aged between 30-34 -- which covers men's age at first marriage -- dropping from 73.2 percent in 1991 to 47.3 percent in 2007.
The rate for women aged between 25-29 -- which covers women's age at first marriage -- fell from 65.1 percent in 1991 to 31.4 percent in the same year.
The overall percentage of married men aged over 15 in 2007 was 44.8 percent, while that of married women aged over 15 was 52.8 percent, according to the statistics.
The report did not provide official figures for 2008.

The report pointed out that education, financial independence of both genders, and changes in societal values have resulted in the rising ages at first marriage and the falling percentages of married people.

In addition, about 148,000 couples got married in 2008, representing a marriage rate of 0.65 percent of the population. About 56,000 couples divorced in the same year, representing a divorce rate of 0.243 percent, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese longans to hit U.S. market from mid-June
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) 06/12/09 16:53:47 (By C.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: After seven years of negotiations, Washington has finally approved Taiwan's application to export fresh longans to the whole of the United States except for the state of Florida, Taiwan's representative office in the United States said Thursday.

According to the Washington-based Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, Taiwanese fresh longans (Euphoria longana) , after having been stored for 17 days at temperatures lower than 1 degree Celsius or for 20 days at under 1.38 degrees Celsius, will be allowed onto the U.S. market from June 20, one day after U.S. notification detailing quarantine conditions for such exports from Taiwan takes effect.
This will make longans the fourth Taiwan-produced fruit eligible to be sold in the United States after lychees, star fruit and mangoes, said a Taiwanese official stationed in Washington.
The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Taipei-based Council of Agriculture (COA) referred the application to Washington in 2002 seeking U.S. export approval.

The bureau's advanced quarantine techniques has also succeeded in helping Taiwanese lychees, star fruit, mangoes, oranges, grapes and papayas to break into the Japanese, U.S., South Korean, New Zealand and Australian markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Men account for 11% of approved parental leave subsidy applications

TEXT.P: Some 11 percent of the first batch of 3,963 employees who were recently approved to receive subsidies for unpaid parental leave from the employment insurance program were men, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan said Friday.
Nearly 9,000 workers applied for the six months of parental leave subsidies, equivalent to 60 percent of their insured salaries, since the program went into effect May 1, according to Wang.
The number applying for unpaid parental leave reached 3,000 over the past year, Wang added.
When the parental leave subsidy program was first announced, critics believed it would favor employees of state-run enterprises, according to Wang.

However, among the 3,963 approved applications, 1,856 involved workers at insured companies of fewer than 30 employees, 2,017 involved workers at companies of more than 30 employees, while employees of state-run enterprises, government agencies and schools accounted for only 182 cases, Wang noted.

The subsidy program was designed to encourage both working mothers and working fathers to share the responsibility of child rearing and to allow both mothers and fathers to ask for unpaid parental leave for up to two years until their children reach the age of three, Wang explained.
Men in the 30-34 age group made up the largest group comprising 454 fathers who were approved to receive the subsidies, Wang went on.

The number of applications for the subsidies was earlier projected by the CLA at about 30,000 per year, but 9,000 applications have been filed in only about one month since the program's implementation, according to Wang.

Workers who have paid into the labor insurance program for at least one year and who take unpaid parental leave under the Gender Equality in Employment Act are eligible for the monthly subsidies, Wang noted.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.002 to close at NT$32.800.
A total of US$573 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.798 and fluctuated between NT$32.696 and NT$.32.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices drop on swine flu fears

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed 1.81 percent lower Friday, a day after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared a swine flu pandemic -- the first global flu epidemic in 41 years.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 119.14 points to close at 6,448.23.
The local bourse opened at 6,552.58 and fluctuated between 6,586.20 and 6,443.86. A total of 4.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$128.85 billion (US$3.93 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares dropping the most at 2.9 percent. Machinery and electronics shares shed 2.0 percent, construction stocks dropped 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 1.3 percent, cement issues fell 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares fell 0.3 percent, paper and pulp stocks lost 0.2 percent, and textile stocks dropped 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,268 to 886, with 167 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.53 billion.

Following two days of gains, the market could not maintain its momentum after the WHO raised the swine flu alert level from phase 5 to phase 6 -- the agency's highest alert level -- which means a pandemic is under way.
However, the announcement pushed a rise in shares of pharmaceutical and biotechnology issues.
Foodstuff shares were propped up by a surge in the global prices of oil, soybeans, wheat and bulk commodities.

Real estate shares also outperformed the overall market as the property market has shown recent signs of recovery along with the completion of several public construction projects, with Huaku Development Corp. and Huang Hsiang Construction Corp. rising by the maximum daily limit of 7 percent.
Shihlin Paper Corp., Shihlin Electric and Engineering Corp. and Shinkong Textile Co. also made strong showings, all surging by more than 3 percent.
Shares in LED companies were pushed up due to an influx of orders from China and the bright outlook for the sector.
A SinoPac Securities analyst said that if the global market does not face technical resistance in the short term, the TAIEX could hover between 6,650 and 6,750.

DOC.HEADLINE: College student loses drastic weight to donate liver to father

TEXT.P: A college student has lost a whopping 17.4 kg over the past six months to prepare himself for surgery in a race against time to donate part of his liver to save his father, who is awaiting a transplant.
The 160 cm college student surnamed Chou, who originally weighed 90 kg, is expected to reach his ideal weight of 70 kg by the middle of this month, to be fit to undergo the liver donation procedure.
Chou said Friday he has been chubby since he was a baby, adding that if it were not for his excess weight, he would have donated liver to his father more than a year ago.
Chou's father was diagnosed with liver disease two years ago and doctors suggested a transplant.

However, since compatible liver donors are difficult to find and because time is running out for the senior Chou, his son decided to do what it takes to make it possible for him to donate part of his liver to save his father's life.

Although tests showed that his liver is a match for his father, his weight made him unfit for surgery, in addition to which, he suffered from fatty liver. A weight management center at the Taipei Medical University Hospital then stepped in to plan a weight-loss program for him.
Center director Wang Wei said that most people seek to lose weight because of their health or their looks, and that Chou's case was the first of its kind he has encountered.
"Chou's determination has moved a lot of my colleagues, " he noted.
Wang inserted a water balloon in Chou's abdomen last December to reduce the size of his stomach, and after six months with careful monitoring, his weight had dropped by 17.4 kg to 72.6 kg.

During the half-year period, Chou said, he felt discomfort only for the first four days of living with the balloon in his stomach, suffering initial queasiness and vomiting but otherwise experiencing no distress.
Chou said he feels confident that the liver surgery will be a success and that he is not afraid of the procedure.
"Donating liver to my father is one way to repay my indebtedness to him," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malaysian congressman receives honorary doctorate in Taiwan

TEXT.P: An overseas Chinese community leader and parliamentarian in Malaysia was conferred with an honorary doctorate Friday by National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in recognition of his longstanding contributions to exchanges between Taiwan and Malaysia.

Dato Seri Tiong King Sing, a member of the Malaysian Parliament and an influential business leader, received the honorary doctorate in agriculture from the university's president, Professor Mike Y.K. Guu, at the school's commencement ceremony.

Tiong, 48, born in Malaysia to Chinese parents, pursued his advanced studies in New Zealand and Ireland before venturing into politics and business. He was honored for his long-term efforts in boosting agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and Malaysia, according to a statement issued by the university.

He was conferred the prestigious federal title of Datuk Seri by King Mizan Zainal Abidin in 2007 and has over the years strenuously sought benefits for Malaysian students studying in Taiwan, as well as seeking Malaysian recognition of academic credentials obtained in Taiwan, the statement said.

A total of 2,289 students obtained their Bachelor's degrees from the university, while 685 were awarded Master's degrees and nine received doctorates at Friday's commencement, which was witnessed by various political and academic leaders, including Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Andrew Hsia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan focusing on preparations to avoid flu pandemic

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reiterated Friday that the goal of efforts to keep a global swine flu pandemic from spreading to Taiwan has been revised from "blocking" entry to the country by the virus to "controlling" outbreaks.

DOH Centers for Disease Control Director-General Kuo Hsu-sung said Taiwan needs to be prepared for a possible community outbreak despite having done well in stopping the A(H1N1) influenza virus from entering the country.
Taiwan has so far reported 36 confirmed cases, only one of which is indigenous. No local deaths have been reported.

The Central Epidemic Command Center (CECC) held a meeting earlier in the day that was attended by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, officials from relevant authorities and experts in epidemic disease control, who discussed Taiwan's preparations after the World Health Organization (WHO) raised the level of influenza pandemic alert from phase 5 to phase 6, the highest level on the scale.

Chang Shan-chwen, associate dean of the National Taiwan University College of Medicine, noted after the meeting that although the WHO has described the latest pandemic as being of "moderate severity," the cases in Taiwan have all been mild and confined.

What Taiwan needs is to stockpile vaccines and if the vaccine supply cannot meet demand, prepare sufficient anti-flu medication for possible severe infections, Chang said in response to media inquiries.

Friday's CECC meeting, the 12th of its kind since the center's establishment April 28, produced six resolutions regarding the WHO pandemic alert, which include accelerating work to stock up on materials required to stem any outbreaks.

The second resolution demands changing the infection monitoring measure from voluntary reporting by hospitals and local clinics that discover infection cases to overall detection and monitoring of the virus, while the third requires medical facilities to reinforce anti-flu preparations and use all their resources to cure flu patients.

The CECC meeting also concluded that large-scale international activities such as the July 16-26 World Games 2009 in Kaohsiung and the Sept. 5-15 Deaflympics in Taipei, can take place as scheduled, and that the government will draft a special statute to authorize compensation to those who suffer losses caused by the pandemic.
The last CECC resolution calls on the public to cooperate with the government measures to fight any outbreaks.
Meanwhile, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan announced that the government has decided to double the amount of A(H1N1) vaccine it plans to buy from overseas from 2.5 million doses to 5 million doses.

Yeh admitted that "it is not sure Taiwan will be able to secure all the vaccine it has ordered, " since all countries around the world want the vaccine too. However, he promised that people at high risk of contracting the virus, such as those working in the health care sector, will be first to be vaccinated.
He revealed that the inoculation program will be launched at the beginning of autumn.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's state visit to Nicaragua unchanged: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Friday that the cancellation of a meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega while the two heads of state were in El Salvador earlier this month will not affect Ma's upcoming state visit to Nicaragua.

"I can guarantee that here are no hard feelings at all, " Ou said after presiding over a book donation ceremony to commemorate the late Foreign Minister Chu Fu-sung that was attended by Ding Mao-shih, former secretary-general of the National Security Council, as well as various retired diplomats.

According to Ou, the meeting was canceled simply because the two presidents, who were in El Salvador to attend the inauguration of President Mauricio Funes, were unable to find a convenient time to meet. The fact that Ortega's wife invited Ma and his wife to stay an extra night during his visit in July is a clear sign that the cancellation did not hurt bilateral relations, said Ou.

Fresh from a three-leg Central America visit that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again June 29-July 7 to attend the inauguration of Panama President-elect Ricardo Martinelli and visit two of Taiwan's other Central American diplomatic allies, Nicaragua and Honduras.

Ou said members of the president's travel delegation will include entrepreneurs such as Chang Yung-fa, founder and chairman of the Evergreen Group, and Eugene Wu, chairman of Shin Kong Financial Holding Co., Ltd., which have large investments in Panama and Nicaragua, respectively.
This is the first time Ma has invited businessmen to join him on a state visit. Other members of the delegation will include legislators, county magistrates and cultural groups.
Asked whether the president's travel plans will be affected by the World Health Organization's declaration of a swine flu pandemic, Ou said there have been no changes so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former antique trader weathers adversities through scavenging

TEXT.P: Chen Chien-li experienced the most unthinkable mishaps of his life in just 10 years -- his home was destroyed in an earthquake and his antique business ruined in a subsequent flood. Despite these unfortunate incidents, the unbeaten man is now rebuilding his career by trash scavenging, in the hopes he will soon be able to return to his old home.
"My greatest wish is to go back to the home in the Tunghsing Building," said 42 -year-old Chen.
Chen had been living in an apartment in the 12-story building since moving to Taipei City from Taiwan's outlying island Penghu with his parents when he was 16.
The building stood witness to his entrepreneurship as an eyeglasses and antiques dealer, his marriage with his wife and the birth of their first child, a daughter.

Many of his belongings and memorabilia, however, were destroyed when a tremendous earthquake struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 and crumpled the building located more than 200 kilometers away from the epicenter.
Chen's mother and younger brother were among a total of 87 residents killed in the disaster, while he and his father sustained injuries.
Fortunately, Chen's daughter and his wife, who was expecting their second child, were safe and unharmed.

Just when Chen and other surviving residents were still seeking a reconstruction of their lost homes, a second misfortune happened. In September 2001, a severe flood caused by Typhoon Nari swamped his temporary residence and eyeglasses store, destroying all his antique collections.
Forced to close his business, Chen opted to stay home to take care of his children and allowed his wife -- who is a nurse -- to assume the role as the family's sole breadwinner.
This was also when he began a life scavenging through garbage piles.

In the beginning, Chen was just looking for furniture or toys dumped by other households for use by his family. But he later came across many other items which through the eyes of an antique connoisseur are treasures.
Among these were a rare Japanese doll, Chinese porcelain wares that were no longer in production, portraits of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and old- fashioned liquor bottles of various shapes.

There were also account books and diaries written by Japanese prisoners during the Japanese colonial period, pornographic playing cards from the martial law era, as well as documents, passports and jewelry discarded by veterans who came from mainland China.
Chen began to auction the items online in 2005 -- a business that helps him earn up to NT$60,000 (US$1,829) a month when sales are brisk.
Now that he has found a new start for his career, his dream to rebuild his home remains unfulfilled even though 10 years have passed.

The reconstruction project of the Tunghsing Building, which only started in 2004 -- four years after the earthquake -- was forced to be suspended in October 2006 as a result of a financial crisis faced by the contractor.
The project was taken over in August 2008 by another contractor, which again halted the project two months later after experiencing a similar problem as its predecessor.
A third contractor has continued the project since December 2008.
"Although I'm now living very close to the original site of the Tunghsing Building, I have not been able to return home all these 10 years. This is my greatest regret," Chen said.

The day, however, may not be far away when Chen and other former residents can finally move into their new homes, given that the reconstruction project is expected to be completed in August this year.
Chen said he hopes his experience in fighting against ill fate will inspire others facing adversities to "never give up hope."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung atemoya set to enter Japan market: official

TEXT.P: The prospects of Taiwan's atemoya making inroads into the Japanese market looks favorable, as an official from the Japan Association of Travel Agents (JATA) has promised to promote the fruit, an official of the Taitung County government said Friday.

Ho Shih-min, who is in charge of the cultural and tourism affairs of the city government, said that during a visit to Taitung by members of the JATA in February, Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-cheng recommended the fruit to the visitors.

JATA President Tomoaki Hukuhara liked the taste of the fruit -- sweet and yet slightly tart -- and before his departure vowed to "make every effort to promote the fruit so it could make inroads into the Japan market," Ho said.

During another visit to Taitung earlier this month, Hukuhara learned that the county produces about 120,000 tons of atemoya annually, and made a commitment to buy 10,000 tons for export to Japan, according to Ho.
Although the fruit was not in season at the time, Hukuhara visited the production region, Ho added.
The magistrate said the quarantine problems related to the fruit can be overcome and that he hopes to impress Japanese consumers with the product.
In recent years, Taitung has been aggressively promoting its atemoya and has made inroads into the China and Hong Kong markets.

The atemoya, or Annonax atemoya, is a cross between two tropical fruits -- the sweetsop (Annona squamosa) and the cherimoya (Annona cherimola) -- which are both native fruits of the tropical Americas. It is popular in Taiwan where it is known as the "pineapple sweetsop."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung to get more China flights; Beijing route planned: CAA

TEXT.P: Apart from Shanghai and Shenzhen, Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung City will soon handle regularly scheduled flights to and from Beijing, an official in charge of the issue said Friday.

"After the program of expanding cross-Taiwan Strait flights kicks off in July or August, the central Taiwan airport will also serve a flight to Beijing each week, in addition to Shanghai and Shenzhen, " said Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director- General Lee Lung-wen at a Legislative Yuan news conference, as he sought to ease concerns that the central Taiwanese city was losing out on direct transportation links with China.

"Talks with Taiwan's carriers on arranging a weekly flight from Taiwan's third largest city Taichung to Beijing will start next week," Lee said in response to complaints by legislators from central regions that the city was being left out.

Some 5 million people, or 21 percent of the country's total population, live in central Taiwan, but legislators pointed out that it is extremely unfair to local residents that there are no direct flights between Taichung and destinations in China after non-stop charter flights were launched in July last year.
"It is normal that central Taiwan's residents want more flights between Chingchuankang Airport and a larger number of Chinese destinations," Legislator Lin Chang-min said.

Although Taiwan is entitled to operate 135 scheduled flights per week to China beginning in this summer based on an accord reached in April between the two sides, the legislators said that Chingchuankang Airport has only been allotted a total of five flights per week in the program that has yet to begin.
Lin and other legislators also asked the CAA to improve the airport's runways so they can accommodate larger airplanes.

Responding to Lin's requests, Lee said the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has ironed out a blueprint to build a terminal for larger airplanes and international flights at the Chingchuankang Airport, with the aim of serving 1.35 million passengers per year in the short term.

Under the project, the central government will earmark NT$3.9 billion (US$118.9 million) to build an international terminal at the airport. Construction of the facility is slated to be completed by 2012.

The CEPD plans to turn Chingchuankang Airport into a regional hub serving passenger flights and cross-strait routes. It projects that the airport could serve at least 3.5 million passengers each year in the long term, Lee said.

Demand for flights from residents in the Taichung area has steadily risen over the years. According to CEPD statistics, the airport served a total of 461,575 travelers on international charter flights in 2008, compared with 3,528 in 2004.

Although Shanghai is the most popular Chinese destination among Taiwanese carriers, Lee said earlier this week that none had applied to ply the Taichung- Shanghai route due to the limitations of the runways at the Chingchuankang Airport, which can only accommodate small planes with a seat capacity of some 100 passengers.

Lee revealed that the CAA asked Taiwanese carriers, including China Airlines, EVA Airways and Trans Asia Airways, all of which fly to Shanghai from either Taipei or Kaohsiung, to offer one flight per week each from Chingchuankang Airport to Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor inspects World Games facilities

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu on Friday inspected the facilities for the rock- climbing events in the July 16-26 World Games in Kaohsiung, as the countdown to the opening reached 33 days.
Braving the rain that persisted during the inspection tour, Chen cheered on a number of athletes who were training at the rock-climbing venue at Kaohsiung Municipal Shou Shan Junior High School.

She expressed satisfaction with the facilities, saying that the heavy rain that day served as a test of the rock-climbing area and equipment, and that they met the requirements for the upcoming competition.

The rock-climbing facilities at the school were expanded and refurbished after the International Federation of Sport Climbing selected the campus as the venue for the rock-climbing events, according to the World Games 2009 Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC).
Meanwhile, as the KOC moved into the final stages of preparations for the games, it warned people against scalping tickets for the opening ceremony.
The 30,000 tickets that were available for the opening ceremony sold like hot cakes when they were released and people are now looking online for scalped tickets, the KOC said.

In April, the KOC began sales of the total 350,000 tickets available for the opening and closing ceremonies and the sports events, but only those for the opening ceremony have sold out, according to a KOC official.

As the opening date draws near, some sports fans who did not manage to obtain tickets for the July 16 opening ceremony are becoming frantic and are trying to buy scalped tickets online, the official said. Tickets are being resold on the Internet at 1.5 times the original price, the official added.
Citing a complaint lodged with the city government, the official said that a NT$600 ticket for the opening had been resold for NT$900.
The KOC warned that anyone found reselling World Games tickets could face penalties, and advised the public not to buy tickets from scalpers.
People who did not get tickets for the opening ceremony can watch it live on TV, the official said, urging that they buy tickets instead for sports events and closing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: Student arrested for selling banned plants online

TEXT.P: A 25-year-old graduate student was arrested Friday on suspicion of selling tropical plants imported from countries known to be affected by a plant parasite called burrowing nematode.

According to the Criminal Investigation Bureau's report, the suspect, surnamed Hu, was found purchasing pitcher plants online from Australia and Thailand, shipping them to Japan -- a non-affected area -- then to Taiwan by airmail to avoid customs checks.
The police said that over the past two years Hu had been selling banned pitcher plants, which he advertised as a "living art, at a price of between NT$200 and NT$5,000 each, depending on the variety.
The police estimated that Hu had sold more than 200 plants, netting around NT$1 million.
In the raid Friday, the police seized around 100 pitcher plants, the report stated.
Under the Plant Protection and Quarantine Act, people who import banned plants could face a penalty of up to three years in prison and a fine up to NT$150,000.

There is no blanket ban on the importation of pitcher plants to Taiwan, but they are not allowed in if they originated in nematode-affected regions such as Australia, several states of the United States, Malaysia or Thailand, the report stated.

The burrowing nematode is a pest that can devastate banana and citrus crops and can also affect coconut, avocado, coffee and sugarcane plantations as well as several types of grasses and ornamental plants.
The nematode causes a lesion on the plant's root, which develops into a canker, and the plant suffers from malnutrition while the parasite completes its life cycle within the root.

DOC.HEADLINE: Less than half of local people exercise daily: poll

TEXT.P: Less than half of respondents to a recent survey on the lifestyles of health and sustainability (LOHAS) said that they exercise daily, according to pollsters Friday.
The telephone poll of randomly chosen citizens over the age of 15 was conducted by Shih Hsin University to explore local people's awareness of and attitude toward the LOHAS lifestyles.
The results showed while 59.2 percent of those interviewed recognized the importance of daily exercise to the LOHAS lifestyles, only 45 percent said they had been following that regimen.

On the importance of LOHAS, the respondents gave it an average score of 7.2 on a 1-to-10-point scale, with those in the age group 45-64 and residing in rural counties of Yilan, Hualien and Taitung and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu giving the highest score of 7.6 points.

The average score given by all respondents to the compatibility of LOHAS with their own lifestyles was 5.7 points. Among them, those aged over 55, residing in Yilan, Hualien, Taitung, Kinmen and Matsu and with an average monthly income of over NT$50,000 had the highest score of 6.1 points. In comparison, central Taiwan residents aged between 25 and 34 had the lowest score of 5.4 points.

Analyzing the survey results, Lee Yi-tien, a polling manager at Shih Hsin's opinion survey center, said the gap between the 7.2 points given by respondents to the importance of healthy lifestyles and the 5.7 points for their actual lifestyles reflects that there is still ample room for local people to improve their lifestyles.

According to the survey, 59.2 percent said regular exercise is most important to the LOHAS lifestyles, compared to 28.1 percent who cited eating organic and natural health foods and 19.5 percent who mentioned purchasing energy-saving products, cycling and backpacking as the most important ways to love themselves and the Earth.
The survey collected 1,189 valid samples, and had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of 2.84 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: No leak of radiative substance in fire at nuclear power plant: AEC

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Friday that a fire at the third nuclear power plant in Hengchun in southern Taiwan earlier in the day did not cause any radioactive leaks.
The two nuclear reactors at the plant have been running as usual, AEC officials said in an attempt to allay public concerns.
The fire started on a transformer, triggering the automatic fire fighting system at the plant and alerting fire fighting personnel who put out the blaze within 30 minutes, the AEC said.

The fire ranked zero on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), which means that there were no radioactive or safety concerns, the state-run Taiwan Power Company said, adding that the cause of the blaze is being investigated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Threat of water shortage dissipating: water company

TEXT.P: The threat of a possible water shortage in the southern areas of the country is dissipating, thanks to the wet fronts that have moved into the south of the island in recent days, a spokesman for the Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC) said Thursday.
With the recent monsoon rains in southern Taiwan's Tainan area, the Nanhua Reservoir was able to collect about 1.2 million metric tons of water Thursday alone, the official said.
Before the beginning of last week, southern Taiwan had had scant rainfall this year, which prompted concerns over the impact on rice plantation and domestic water supplies.
However, according to the spokesman, the situation has since eased.
"The threat of a looming water shortage will dissipate once the reservoir collects more water during the coming typhoon season, before the dry season begins again at the end of the year," he said.

Currently, the Nanhua Reservoir, which supplies water to the Tainan and Kaohsiung areas, contains 40 million metric tons of water -- 10 million metric tons less than the volume at the same time last -- despite lower demand from the nearby South Taiwan Science Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign launched to name protected bear cub

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo launched a campaign Thursday to solicit entries for naming its five-month-old Formosan black bear male cub, as part of its efforts to raise public awareness of the importance of wildlife conservation.

The cub was bred under a cooperative project between the city zoo and Lee Teng- cheng, a resident in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County who owns a pair of Formosan black bears, said Taipei Zoo Director Jason Yeh.

The zoo struck the cooperation deal with Lee in February 2007 and the male cub was born last December -- the first of the protected species to be bred through a cooperative effort by the public and private sectors, Yeh said.
Noting that the Formosan black bear has a very low reproduction rate, Yeh said the zoo hopes to enhance local people's awareness of this rare endemic species' life history through the naming project.

According to Yeh, Taiwan now has 32 Formosan black bears living in captivity. In recent years, he said, there have been incremental technical advances in the efforts to breed the species in captivity.

Nevertheless, Yeh said, basic biological data about the species remains limited. Against this backdrop, documentation of the five-month-old cub's growth is tremendously important to the work of raising and managing bear litters in the future, he added.
"We look forward to preserving the pure Formosan bear species by managing the bloodlines when the bears are bred in captivity, " Yeh explained.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-pin, Pingtung Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, and the cub's breeder Lee Teng-cheng all attended a news conference to launch the name soliciting campaign, in a show of support for the project.

Entries will be accepted at the city zoo in Muzha in suburban Taipei until June 28, and an online vote on the suggestions will be held from July through July 14 at http: //www.zoo.gov.tw. The results of the vote will be published July 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: Statute on renewable energy development clears legislature

TEXT.P: A statute aimed at promoting renewable energy development cleared the legislative floor Friday, paving the way for domestic renewable power generation capacity to be increased by 6.5 million kilowatts to 10 million kilowatts over the next 20 years.

Yeh Hui-ching, director of the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, hailed the completion of a third reading of the new law in the Legislative Yuan, saying that with the enactment of the statute, Taiwan will be able to join the ranks of countries with sustainable energy.
The statute lays down the legal infrastructure to encourage investment in renewable energy production and offer incentives to local consumers to install renewable energy facilities.

In addition to permitting the state-run Taiwan Power Co. to buy electricity generated by private renewable energy investors, the bill will also allow the government to offer other incentives to speed up the development of renewable energy technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 13, or the 21st day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital pharmacists overworked, provide little advice: survey

TEXT.P: Pharmacists working in Taiwan hospitals tend to have too heavy a workload, which leaves them little time to advise patients, according to the results of a survey released Saturday by the Taiwan Healthcare Reform Foundation.

The survey, conducted from Jan. 19-21 at 20 medical centers around Taiwan, found that, on average, the pharmacists served 450 patients per day during the three- day period leading up to the Lunar New Year holiday this year.
The results revealed that more than one quarter of pharmacists are so busy that they cannot provide any verbal information to patients.
Among those who could do so, 80 percent only spoke if the patients asked them questions, with the conversations averaging just 35 seconds, the results showed.
Also, 6.3 percent of pharmacists do not verify the identities of patients before distributing medicines to them, which could increase the chances of mistakes, the poll found.

Meanwhile, approximately 60 percent of the patients surveyed thought that pharmacists should explain to them matters such as possible side effects of the medicines and whether there is likely to be any interaction with other drugs or food. However, only about one quarter of pharmacists offer such information verbally to patients, the survey showed.

Kao Yea-huei, an associate professor at National Cheng Kung University's Institute of Clinical Pharmacy, estimated that it takes at least 7 minutes and 32 seconds for a pharmacist to fill a single prescription and that it would take another two minutes and nine seconds to give verbal instructions on use of the drugs.
Therefore, the maximum number of prescriptions handled by each pharmacist should be 64 per day, Kao suggested.

However, a Department of Health estimate in 2004 showed that on average, pharmacists in Taiwan completed one prescription in 2.9 minutes, with each pharmacist handling up to 165 prescriptions per day.
The number was significantly higher than the maximum limit of 30 prescriptions per day set by the United States and 40 set by Japan, the foundation said.
Taiwan's Bureau of National Health Insurance currently sets a limit of 100 prescriptions per day.

According to the foundation, hospitals in Taiwan have not paid attention to the quality of service provided by their pharmacists because this aspect is not part of the evaluation criteria for hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister leaves for Panama to prepare for president's visit

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou left for Panama late Friday night to prepare for President Ma Ying-jeou's upcoming state visit to the country, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.

According to the MOFA, Ou, who is being accompanied by Joseph Kuo, director- general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, will arrive in Panama June 14 and return to Taiwan June 18.
"The foreign minister is traveling to the Central American country to make arrangements for President Ma's visit there later this month," MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said.
"Ou will also meet with Panama President-elect Ricardo Martinelli to exchange views on future cooperation, " Chang said.

The foreign minister will also take the opportunity to thank the outgoing Panama government for its long-term support for Taiwan and will review the execution of bilateral cooperative projects in Panama, he added.

Fresh from a three-leg Central American visit that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again June 29-July 7 to attend the inauguration of Martinelli and visit two of Taiwan's other Central American diplomatic allies, Nicaragua and Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should divert from U.N. bid: scholars

TEXT.P: Several international relations scholars from National Chengchi University (NCCU) said Saturday that instead of seeking to join the United Nations, Taiwan should focus on applying for entry to U.N.-related agencies and programs that are more in line with the country's substantive interests.

Teng Chung-chian, director of NCCU's Center for International Negotiation, and Yen Chen-shen, chairman of the NCCU Institute of International Relations America-Europe Division, made the remarks in a forum that discussed President Ma Ying-jeou's pursuit of a "diplomatic truce" with China and Taiwan's foreign relations strategies.

"We don't have to participate in the U.N. Instead, we should try to tap into other U.N. organizations, based on the World Health Assembly (WHA) model, " Teng contended, referring to Taiwan's participation in this year's WHA as an observer under the designation "Chinese Taipei."
"We should weave our way through, given all the advantages we have, which can be used for expanding Taiwan's international space, " he added.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office in May 2008, and his proposed "diplomatic truce" is aimed at ending the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides over allies.
Ma is also touting the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "flexible diplomacy" to leverage greater international space for Taiwan.

The WHA's invitation to Taiwan this year to attend for the first time as an observer, after 12 failed attempts by the country to do so, is widely viewed as a measure of the success of Ma's policies and his administration's engagement with China.

Yen said at the forum that the "Chinese Taipei" designation used in the WHA may be the best possible common ground that Taiwan and China can find on the issue of Taiwan's participation in international agencies. Taiwan should use that model and set its priorities straight on the question of which international organizations it wants to join, he suggested.

According to Yen, it might be possible for Taiwan to participate in U.N. specialized agencies, funds and programs such as the International Labor Organization; United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization; U.N. Environment Programme; U.N. Children's Fund; International Atomic Energy Agency; United Nations Institute for Training and Research; and the Office of the United Nations High Commission for Human Rights.

He said that public hearings should be held, with the participation of relevant social groups and experts, to determine which organizations should be given priority in Taiwan's efforts to expand its international space.
Also, Yeh went on, Taiwan must file its applications before going to the negotiation table with Beijing.
"We should not naively believe that China will just let us participate in those organizations," he cautioned.

As to how long the flexible diplomacy strategy will work, Yen said that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is a key factor, as Beijing is likely to make certain concessions for fear that the Taiwan-centric DPP might return to power.
Cheng Tuan-yao, director of NCCU's Institute of International Relations, said that stable cross-Taiwan Strait relations are the pillar on which Ma's "flexible diplomacy" rests.

"Our government should maintain effective communication with Beijing. At the moment, there is only indirect communication and some goodwill, and there is lack of mutual trust between the two sides, " Cheng said.

He contended that in order to put Taiwan's diplomatic efforts on the right track, the country should continue to seek a "balance point with China," consensus with the opposition, and the support of major international countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: New marriages up 12% in 2008 ahead of 'lonely phoenix year'

TEXT.P: The number of new marriages recorded in 2008 was 12.57 percent higher than in the previous year -- a sudden surge related to the superstition that 2009 is an inauspicious year for marriage, according to a report released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
The report showed that a total of 148,425 couples tied the knot in 2008, an increase of 16,574 from 2007.

The MOI attributed the jump to a trend in which many lovers chose to get married early because they wanted to avoid doing so in 2009 -- which is believed to be a "ku luan nien," or "lonely phoenix year."

The superstition that the chances of losing one's partner are higher in certain years, including 2009, originated in Japan. A "lonely phoenix year" is usually one in which there are two "li chun," or Beginnings of Spring -- one of the 24 seasonal periods in a lunar year.
As "spring" is metaphoric of romance in the Chinese language, the appearance of two "springs" in a lunar year is believed to be unfavorable to the longevity of marriages.
A "lonely phoenix year" can come every four to five years. The last such year was in 2004.
According to the MOI report, 85.43 percent of men who got married in 2008 were first-time grooms and 87.41 percent of women were first-time brides.
The average age of the first-time husbands was 31.1, while for the first-time brides it was 28.4, an increase of 0.1 years and 0.3 years, respectively, from 2007.
Of all the new marriages recorded last year, 14.49 percent involved one foreign spouse or one from China, Hong Kong or Macau, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young 'reporters' to head to El Salvador on volunteer trip

TEXT.P: As part of its children exchange program, World Vision Taiwan held a training camp Saturday to prepare 12 aspiring journalists aged 12-15 for an upcoming humanitarian trip to El Salvador in summer.
The youngsters, who learnt photography, writing, and basic Spanish at the camp, will interact with El Salvadoran children sponsored by World Vision, from July 1-10.
The Taiwanese youth will engage in volunteer social service work and report on their experience in the Central American country through pictures, articles and paintings.
The young reporters said that they are looking forward to the trip and to exploring a culture that is very different from Taiwan's.
"I'm proud to be part of a group like this again after a similar trip to Thailand last year, which left me with many unforgettable memories," said 14 -year-old Chen Yi-jan.

Another participant, Yeh Ting-shuan, said that she thinks she will enjoy the visit to El Salvador, as she is very independent and has been traveling to other countries with her family since she was three years old.

World Vision Taiwan's "humanitarian care by young journalists" project was started in 1994 with the aim of inspiring children to care for others, respect different cultures, and expand their own perspectives and vision.
The trip to El Salvador -- one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies -- will be the first outside the Asian region since the project was launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's IC sector expected to pick up in second half of 2009

TEXT.P: The performance of Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) sector is expected to improve in the second half of this year, thanks to increased demand for electronic products in China, the Topology Research Institute (TRI) forecast Saturday.

According to the TRI, the IC sector will benefit from China's economic stimulus measures that encourage home appliance purchases by rural consumers and a growing market in China for "shan zhai" or "bandit" products -- copies of branded electronic items sold at low prices.
The sector's recovery will also be helped by strong demand for touch-screen products and 3G mobile phones, the TRI said.

However, the overall 2009 performance of the IC sector -- covering design, manufacturing, packaging and testing -- will still be below par compared to 2008, due to the lingering impact of the global economic downturn, the TRI forecast.
The total output of the sector is expected to amount to 1.15 trillion in 2009, a decline of 14.41 percent from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should not agree to China offices in allied nations: scholar

TEXT.P: A scholar from a top local university warned Saturday that the government should not entertain the idea of China setting up representative offices in the countries that are Taiwan's diplomatic allies because Beijing might overshadow Taipei, given China's economic and trade advantages.

Yen Chen-shen, chairman of Institute of International Relations America-Europe Division, National Chengchi University (NCCU) , made the remarks at a forum held by NCCU to discuss President Ma Ying-jeou's pursuit of a "diplomatic truce" with China.

Ma is proposing that the two sides end their longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war over allies. He has also said that Taiwan is not opposed to its diplomatic allies developing economic or trade relations with Beijing.

However, Yen warned that if China sets up representative offices in countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan and starts building substantial links with them, it could overshadow Taiwan and thus cause confusion, given the larger numbers of Chinese expatriates in those countries and China's economic clout.

With regard to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) recent decision to close five of its overseas representative offices, Yen said it was justified, but suggested that the MOFA also identify potential new locations to set up offices.

Taking into consideration Taiwan's strategic plans and energy needs, the government should try to develop substantial relations with countries such as Iran and Kazakhstan, Egypt, Kenya and Ghana and set up offices there, he suggested.

Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said June 6 that in an effort to put the country's diplomatic resources to better use, the government will close down five underutilized overseas offices in the coming months, including its representative offices in Venezuela, Bolivia, and Bangladesh, its consulate- general offices in Colon, Panama, and its liaison office in Johannesburg, South Africa.
The reasons Ou listed for the closures included a perception of unfriendliness of some of the countries toward Taiwan and the existence of more than one office within close proximity of each other.

However, Chiu Kun-shuan, director of NCCU's Graduate Institute of East Asian Studies, said that the closure of the Venezuela and Bangladesh offices might also be viewed as "a favor done at little cost" to demonstrate Taiwan's goodwill toward China, as those two countries are of great strategic importance because of their energy resources.
Taiwan currently has 121 offices in countries around the world, a number that Ou said was too high in relation to the size of Taiwan.

Cheng Tuan-yao, director of NCCU's Institute of International Relations, said at the forum that Taiwan should carefully evaluate its decisions regarding representative offices so that any expansion would not be mistaken by Beijing as an offensive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese players dominate Japanese Go world
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 13 (CNA) 06/13/09 19:48:31 (By Yang Ming-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan's professional Go scene is now dominated by players from Taiwan, with Cho U and Hsieh Yi Min jointly holding seven of the 10 most prestigious titles in the Japanese male and female professional Go competitions.
Cho, 29, holds five of the seven major titles in Japan's male Go ranks, while 19 -year-old Hsieh controls two of the three principal titles on the women's scene.

Impressed by the pair's extraordinary achievements in the subtle Oriental board game known as "wei-chi" in Taiwan, Hideo Otake, president of the Japan Go Association, better known as Nihon Ki-in in Japan, said Friday that Taiwanese Go players are amazing.

"Taiwanese Go players are really outstanding... What are Japanese players doing? They should step up," Otake said in a speech delivered during a ceremony at which Cho was given the Judan crown, the fifth title he has won so far this year, and Hsieh was awarded the women's Meijin crown, her second this year.
Cho, who went to Japan at the tender age of 10 to pursue a Go career, now also holds four other major titles -- Meijin, Tengen, Oza and Gosei.
Hsieh, an emerging star on Japan's female Go scene, is also the women's Honinbo title holder.
Addressing the crowning ceremony, Cho said he is gratified at setting a new record with his capture of five coveted titles.

"I take pride in my accomplishments. This time, the Judan competition drew a lot of attention. I was lucky to be able to live up to my usual standards, but there is still ample room for improvement," a jubilant Cho said.

For her part, Hsieh said she has been yearning to excel in major international Go competitions. "But this dream has not yet been realized. I'll redouble my efforts to score more wins in prestigious world games," the Go prodigy said modestly.

It was the first time that the Sankei Shimbun economic daily presented the male Judan and women's Honinbo titles simultaneously, which allowed the two outstanding Taiwanese Go players to receive their career laurels on the same stage.
Taiwan's representative to Japan, John Feng, was invited to attend the ceremony.
Speaking in fluent Japanese, Feng said that his first public speech in Japanese after he assumed his post last autumn was at a ceremony honoring Cho for his career achievements.
"With Cho and Hsieh continuing to capture titles in the Go arena, I have since attended many similar crowning ceremonies, which has given me a chance to improve my Japanese," he said jokingly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven new swine flu cases reported, bringing total to 44

TEXT.P: The Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) reported seven new swine flu cases Saturday, bringing to 44 the total number of influenza A (H1N1) infections recorded in Taiwan.
"All seven new cases were infected during tours of Thailand," CECC spokesman Shih Wen-yi said.
He advised travelers to Thailand to refrain from going to crowded indoor places such as pubs, and to stick instead to outdoor activities to avoid the risk of A(H1N1) infection.
Among the seven new cases, three were male students who went to Thailand on graduation trips, while the other four were members of tour groups from Taiwan to the Southeastern Asian country, he said.

Shih said the seven patients are now in quarantine and are being treated. Individuals who had come into close contact with the patients have been asked to monitor their own condition, even if they have no flu-like symptoms, he added.
Data from the World Health Organization shows that as of June 12, 74 countries had officially reported 29,669 cases of influenza A(H1N1) infection, including 145 deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: German Buddy bear enters Taiwan high school campus

TEXT.P: Germany has presented one of its famous Buddy bears to a senior high school in southern Taiwan as part of its efforts to promote its ideal of "living together in peace and harmony on the Earth".
Fengshan Senior High School in Kaohsiung County's Fengshan City hosted a ceremony Saturday to celebrate its receipt of Germany's trademark fiberglass Buddy bear.

Many dignitaries, including Birgitt Ory, director-general of the German Institute in Taipei which represents German interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, and Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing attended the Buddy bear donation ceremony.

Since the Buddy bear was delivered four days ago, Hung Chun-yuan, a fine arts teacher at the school, has been leading a group of students to paint it. Four students from the German School in Taipei also joined the efforts Saturday to paint the bear in acrylic colors.

The painting project is scheduled to be completed Sunday and the bear will then be sent to Germany's representative office in Taipei where a formal inauguration ceremony will be held June 27 to mark the Buddy bear's arrival on a Taiwan school campus.
Yang said he welcomes the gift of a Buddy bear to help promote student and cultural exchanges between his county and Germany.
"The Buddy bear will certainly inspire more interaction and cooperation between our two countries and help expand local students' international perspectives and vision," Yang said.

The Buddy bear, a "hybrid" of Taiwan's endemic Formosan black bear and Germany's indigenous Brown bear, will be taken to two major international sports events to be held in Taiwan later this year -- the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung City and the 21st Summer Deaflympics in Taipei.
The German Institute in Taipei has launched a campaign to solicit entries for naming the Buddy bear. Prospective participants should mail their entries before Oct.3, it said.
Germany has presented a total of 1,300 Buddy bears to countries around the world and one at the Fengshan school has been given the serial number "1289."

The German Institute in Taipei has forged partnerships with five Taiwan schools, one of which is Fengshan Senior High School. Twelve German students were at the Fengshan school on a study tour in May, and 12 students from the school are scheduled to visit Germany for two weeks later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Railways administration working to cut Taitung-Taipei travel time

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) said Saturday that the travel time between Taipei and Taitung will be greatly reduced when the railway section between Hualien and Taitung goes electric in five years time.
"When that happens, the travel time between Taitung and Taipei will be cut to four hours from the current seven-plus hours, " said Chang Chien-li, deputy head of TRA's Hualien Transportation Section.
"It will also greatly reduce the time it takes to travel between urban and rural areas," Chang added.
The segment of railway between Taipei and Hualien is electric, but all trains on the Hualien-Taitung section have to switch to non-electric locomotives to be able to enter the Taitung station.
Meanwhile, Chang said that in order to meet weekend visitor demand, the TRA will add two Chukuang-class express trains to its service on weekends, starting June 16.
The TRA will also step up its cooperation with local tourism promotion efforts, he added.

For example, 13 flagship bicycle rental booths will be set up at train stations along eastern Taiwan from Yilan to Taitung, in tandem with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' efforts to combine and promote bicycle and train tourism, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled artist holds solo exhibition of paintings

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he was impressed and moved by the amazing paintings by Chen Tzi-jung, a mentally challenged artist, and described them as full of feeling and imagination.
Ma made the remarks after visiting an exhibition hall at Far East University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan's Tainan County where Chen is holding her second solo exhibition.
On display are 80-plus oil paintings by the 26-year-old artist who suffered brain damage at the age of 3, due to injuries sustained in a traffic accident.
Ma said he was fascinated by Chen's colorful cubist paintings, which he said reflect her love for life and her feelings and insight with regard to day-to-day affairs.
In a brief encounter with Chen at the exhibition hall, Ma expressed his admiration for her perseverance in overcoming her disabilities and pursuing excellence in the art world.
Ma also encouraged Chen to continue her art career to make her life as colorful as her paintings.
As Chen had difficulty memorizing and could not speak normally, she had a hard time learning and communicating with others. She informed her family of her daily needs by drawing.

Her major breakthrough in life came seven years ago when Chao Si-chiang, a professor at Far East University of Science and Technology, discovered Chen's artistic talent and began to teach her to paint, free of cost.
Since then, Chen has not stopped painting and she held her first-ever solo painting exhibition last year.
This time around, the exhibition will tour major cities in Taiwan.
Chao said Chen has expressed her understanding, feelings, imagination and insight with respect to her environment. "She also aspires to bring joy and happiness to others," Chao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to create 70,000 jobs in two years

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday the government will invest NT$30 billion (US$914.63 million) in the coming two years to create 70,000 jobs and 42,000 vocational training opportunities.
Liu made the remarks at a commencement ceremony at National Sun Yat-sen University in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
In his speech, Liu said while knowledge is important, common sense should not be overlooked. Without common sense, knowledge cannot be fully employed, he added.
"In our society, many people, including some government officials, who have rich professional knowledge, lack common sense and a deep understanding of social problems," Liu lamented.

Liu encouraged all new graduates to tackle adversities they may face after graduation amid the current global economic downturn with "five senses and 3Cs," namely knowledge, common sense, vision, courage and gratitude as well challenge, chance and chance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 14, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

In a brief encounter with Chen at the exhibition hall, Ma expressed his admiration for her perseverance in overcoming her disabilities and pursuing excellence in the art world.
Ma also encouraged Chen to continue her art career to make her life as colorful as her paintings.
As Chen had difficulty memorizing and could not speak normally, she had a hard time learning and communicating with others. She informed her family of her daily needs by drawing.

Her major breakthrough in life came seven years ago when Chao Si-chiang, a professor at Far East University of Science and Technology, discovered Chen's artistic talent and began to teach her to paint, free of cost.
Since then, Chen has not stopped painting and she held her first-ever solo painting exhibition last year.
This time around, the exhibition will tour major cities in Taiwan.
Chao said Chen has expressed her understanding, feelings, imagination and insight with respect to her environment. "She also aspires to bring joy and happiness to others," Chao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises to create 70,000 jobs in two years

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday the government will invest NT$30 billion (US$914.63 million) in the coming two years to create 70,000 jobs and 42,000 vocational training opportunities.
Liu made the remarks at a commencement ceremony at National Sun Yat-sen University in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
In his speech, Liu said while knowledge is important, common sense should not be overlooked. Without common sense, knowledge cannot be fully employed, he added.
"In our society, many people, including some government officials, who have rich professional knowledge, lack common sense and a deep understanding of social problems," Liu lamented.

Liu encouraged all new graduates to tackle adversities they may face after graduation amid the current global economic downturn with "five senses and 3Cs," namely knowledge, common sense, vision, courage and gratitude as well challenge, chance and chance.
