DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 15, or the 23rd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1944: U.S. forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the U.S. envoy to China notifies the Chinese government of the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the U.S., Great Britain and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastics raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries -- Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest level ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.
2000: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
2001: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says the information technology (IT) industry will remain be the top player among all industries in the next 10 years.
2004: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union is inaugurated with former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya as its founding chairwoman.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: Community service plan a 'win-win-win' policy: Justice Ministry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) welcomed Sunday the recent passage of a statue that would allow prosecutors to seek community service assignments, rather than prison sentences, for some felons.

MOJ officials said this is a "win-win-win" policy that will cost the government less than building new prisons and detention centers or expanding existing ones to deal with the problem of overcrowding.
The community service program will allow prisoners -- who are "consumers" in sociological terms -- to become "producers" by serving in communities, the officials said.
The program will also be of advantage to the felons' families, as community work will allow the convicts go home every day, according to the officials.

The no-pay community service assignments for felons could range from household caregiving and care of the elderly and members of disadvantaged families, to mountain and beach cleaning, the officials said.
The felons could also serve as community and natural sanctuary guards, office staff and traffic safety personnel, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's blood donation rate highest in Asia: foundation

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the highest rate of blood donation among all the countries in Asia, the Taiwan Blood Services Foundation said Monday.

Foundation chairman Lin Kuo-hsin said that people in Taiwan donated a total of 2.39 million 250-ml bags of blood last year, representing a donation rate of 7.86 percent, a figure that tops all other countries in Asia.

Donors with the blood type O positive accounted for 43.56 percent of the total number in 2008 -- the highest percentage of donors that year among the different blood groups, according to the foundation.
The foundation sponsored a carnival-style blood drive Sunday at its six blood centers around the country in observance of World Blood Donor Day, which is marked annually on June 14.
Lin said that millions of people around the world owe their lives to individuals they will never meet -- people who donate their blood to help others.
To drive home the message that blood donation is not limited by borders, Lin said, the foundation invited five foreign donors to tell their stories.

A slender woman from the United States who has been in Taiwan over the last 25 years and is now teaching English at National Taiwan University, said she was not allowed to donate blood in the U.S. because of her weight, but can do so in Taiwan because she meets the minimum weight requirement of 45 kg.

A French professor at Tamkang University said he began donating blood at the age of 19, and that after he got married and had children in Taiwan, he continued to donate blood as a way of showing his love for the country.
A Japanese woman, who has been living in Taiwan for nine years, said that giving blood is good for the health of the donor, in addition to the obvious value to the recipients.

An Indian man from Mumbai who has lived in Taiwan for 30 years said he has given blood in Taiwan "too many times to remember." He said it is amazing that God has created people of different nationalities but with the same blood types so they can share.
"Whether American, French, Japanese, or Taiwanese, the people on Earth are one family," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma stresses lawfulness, frugality in KMT head run

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has said that he and his aides will stick to the principles of lawfulness and frugality while seeking the chairmanship of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , Legislative Yuan Vice Speaker Tseng Yung-chuan said Monday.

Tseng, who picked up candidate registration forms for the KMT chairmanship on behalf of Ma that day, relayed the president's message that in his run for the party chairmanship, lawfulness and frugality will be the supreme guiding principles and that his campaign headquarters will operate in a spirit of simplicity and efficiency.
"The campaign headquarters will be operated by volunteers only and no extra spokesmen or officials will be established for the election," Tseng quoted Ma as saying.
Ma announced June 10 his intention to run for the KMT chairmanship, breaking a one-year silence on the matter.

Upon making the announcement, Ma said that his plan to serve concurrently as the nation's president and as party chairman is not intended to expand his presidential power, but rather to more effectively fulfill his responsibilities.

"I hope my bid will be supported by the party members in the interest of facilitating closer cooperation between the ruling party and the administration and achieving more effective government, " Ma said at the June 10 news conference to announce his bid.

According to the president, incumbent KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung first floated the idea of Ma returning to the party helm in April 2008 -- one month after he was elected president -- and raised the proposal again in September that same year.
Ma said that at the time, he promised Wu that he would make a decision on the matter by June this year.

Also during the June 10 news conference, Wu said his support for the idea of Ma as party chairman remains unchanged and that he will not run in the next chairmanship election now that Ma has decided to stand as a candidate.
It remains unclear if the election slated for July 26 will draw any other aspirants.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA denies trying to legalize Chinese workers

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) denied Monday that it has been drafting regulations governing Chinese people working in Taiwan.

Chen Yi-min, director-general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said his office has not been making plans for granting work permits to Chinese citizens, as Taiwan has not opened its doors to Chinese workers, either white- collar or blue-collar.

He made the remarks in response to a report published in the Liberty Times newspaper that day that said the CLA is moving to grant work permits to Chinese workers and have relevant regulations drafted, "paving the way for Chinese- funded companies operating in Taiwan to hire Chinese white-collar professionals to work in Taiwan."

Discounting the report, Chen noted that the administration has no plans so far to open Taiwan's job market to Chinese workers. In addition, he argued, it is difficult to differentiate between white-collar and blue-collar workers.
"It will be up to the development of the domestic job market and how cross- Taiwan Strait relations unfold in the future as to whether Taiwan will open its job market to Chinese workers," he said.

Chen also pointed out that professionals from China, including property developers and real estate operators, have been allowed to come to Taiwan for short periods of stay under Article 10 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
"No Chinese professionals or workers are allowed by the country's laws to come to Taiwan for long-term employment, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign minister optimistic on ties with Panama
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 14 (CNA) 06/15/09 17:24:23 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou expressed optimism Sunday about the future of ties between his country and Panama -- one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America.

Ou made the remarks in an interview with CNA in Panama City. He arrived there earlier in the day for a two-day visit, which he said is aimed at acquiring knowledge of the incoming Panamanian government's policies and top priorities.
He reiterated the ROC government's willingness to reinforce cooperation with its ally.
Speaking of the outlook for Taiwan-Panama ties, Ou said he believes they will continue on a stable and solid basis, given that the two countries have maintained friendship since 1954.

During his stay, Ou said, he will visit President-elect Ricardo Martinelli and his appointed foreign affairs minister, Juan Carlos Varela, for talks that will allow him to find out the country's development needs, as well as exchange views on future cooperation between the two countries.
He will also give a briefing on Taiwan's development and offer Taiwanese assistance in helping Panama promote its economic development, Ou said.
Martinelli and Varela will assume office July 1.
Ou said the ROC wants to cooperate fully with the new government of Panama.
Asked about Martinelli's earlier statement that he would reconsider Panama's relations with China if elected, Ou said he believes the president-elect will continue his country's ties with Taiwan.

Meanwhile, faced with pleas from several Taiwanese expatriates not to close the consulate-general office in Panama's Colon, Ou explained that the decision to shut down the facility was taken to make better use of Taiwan's limited diplomatic resources.
He noted that Colon is just a one-hour drive from Panama City, where the ROC Embassy can offer all the necessary services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City mayor willing to visit China again: report
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, July 15 (CNA) 06/15/09 17:33:11 (By Charles Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Following her recent ice-breaking visit to China in mid-May, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chen Chu, said she would like to visit China again if there is another chance to do so, the Singapore-based Lianhe Zaobo reported Monday.

"Of course I would like to visit China again, if the opportunity arises, although I don't know when, " Chen was quoted by the newspaper as saying during an interview last week in Taiwan. "As a member of the global village, we should reach out and must not leave out China."
Chen visited China May 21-24 to promote this summer's World Games that will be held in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City July 16-26.
On the question of whether the China trip had impacted on her political ideas and beliefs, Chen said "no, " adding that it is impossible for that to happen in three days.
She called on Beijing to listen to voices other than those of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) if it wants to gain a better and more accurate understanding of Taiwan.
If Beijing only engages the KMT, it will not be able to hear the different opinions in Taiwan, she said.

"Whether or not you like it, the opposition DPP still has the support of some 40 percent of the Taiwan people, " she said. "This is precisely the biggest difference between Taiwan and China. In contrast to China, Taiwan is a democratic and multi-faceted society."

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong selling pressure sends TAIEX tumbling

TEXT.P: The weighted stock price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged 3.45 percent Monday, or 222.67 points, to close at 6,225.56 due mainly to investors rushing to unload their shareholdings.
The local bourse opened high at 6,362.22 before rising to the day's high of 6,383.98 and dropping below the 6,200-point level to the day's low of 6,188.70.
The sharp fall came after the TAIEX index dropped 408 points last week, the biggest weekly decline in seven months.
A total of 4.35 billion shares changed hands on shrinking market turnover of NT$112.63 billion (US$3.42 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 6.8 percent. Construction stocks dropped 5.4 percent, textile stocks dropped 4.9 percent, foodstuff issues fell 4.7 percent, cement stocks dropped 4.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 3.9 percent, banking and financial shares lost 2.7 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks fell 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,938 to 354, with 41 stocks remaining unchanged.

The three major institutional investors made net sales of NT$5.62 billion on shares -- NT$2.64 billion by foreign investors, NT$1.60 billion by investment trust firms and NT$1.38 billion by securities firms.
United Microelectronics Corp. and Chi Mei Optoelectronics took the brunt of the selling, dropping by their 7 percent daily maximum limit.
An analyst said that the market is likely to test the technical resistance level of 6,100 if it continues to run out of steam and fails to stand firm between 6,200 and 6,300.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.140 to close at NT$32.940.
A total of US$973 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.900 and fluctuated between NT$32.780 and NT$32.940.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP should adjust strategy to deal with rising China: Tainan mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 15 (CNA) 06/15/09 19:05:57 (By Charles Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not rashly engage China but should adjust its strategy to deal with a rising China, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, a prominent DPP member, was reported as saying Monday.
"I harbor no hostility toward China, but the DPP must stick firm to its standpoint, " Hsu said in a report published by the Singapore-based Lianhe Zaobo newspaper that same day.
"The DPP should strengthen its internal confidence and must not engage China amid an ambiguous and unequal situation, " he was quoted as saying.
Turning to a visit he plans to make to China July 17-21, Hsu described it as a "sports and cultural" journey.

During his stay in China, he will attend the First Straits Cup Sailing Boat Championship to be held between Fujian Province's Xiamen and Tainan's Anping -- a cross-Taiwan Strait route that used to be thriving prior to World War Two. He will also visit the cities of Zhangzhou and Quangzhou, also in Fujian Province.

He reiterated his demands that he should be allowed to enter China without a special entry permit issued by Beijing for travelers from Taiwan, commonly known as the "Taiwan Compatriot Travel Certificate" and stressed that China must not describe Taiwan as a "province of China."
"However, it is acceptable if China views Tainan as a city of Taiwan Province, the Republic of China, or Tainan City, Taiwan, or simply Tainan City," he added.

"Although some DPP members are opposed to my (planned) China journey, a majority of them support my decision to go and help attract more Chinese tourists to Tainan City, " he explained, stressing that "it will provide a chance for the Taiwanese people to test China's true colors if Beijing attempts to suppress me during this trip."
Commenting on an allegation that variables might arise ahead of the official opening of the regatta, Hsu said he is still looking forward to the trip.
He made it clear last week that he will drop his plans if Beijing insists that he must enter with the "Taiwan Compatriot Travel Certificate."
In addition, the Tainan mayor admitted that he might consider running for the DPP chairmanship, as many backers have encouraged him to take on the challenge.
Hsu's planned trip comes on the heels of a May 21-24 visit to China by Chen Chu, also a DPP heavyweight and mayor of Kaohsiung City.
Chen, the most prominent DPP incumbent official to have ever visited China, was making a promotional trip for the World Games in Kaohsiung next July 16-26.

President Ma Ying-jeou said in late May that improving Taiwan-China ties is not a prerogative of the ruling Kuomintang but is rather a path that all Taiwan's political parties should take because Taiwan needs to reach out in order to survive.
He encouraged DPP members to increase their contacts with China for the benefit of Taiwan.
The KMT favors strengthening relations with China, especially trade and economic links, but the DPP fears that some of Ma's China-friendly policies could undermine Taiwan's independent sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poll finds most Kaohsiung residents satisfied with city government

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City government under the leadership of Mayor Chen Chu has earned the acclaim of its residents after completing several public infrastructure projects, according to a local poll.

A survey of city residents conducted by the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) June 7-9 found that 72.4 percent of respondents were satisfied with the Kaohsiung government's performance, up 7.6 percentage points from a similar survey conducted in May.
Mayor Chen, a bigwig of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, had a 76 percent approval rating, with 11.6 percent of respondents expressing disapproval.

The poll also found that 81.5 percent of those surveyed said they felt proud to be a resident of the southern Taiwan city that features the country's biggest port, while 8.6 percent held an opposing view.

RDEC Executive Director Hsu Li-ming attributed the rising satisfaction rating to the completion of significant public infrastructure projects, including the city's subway system, and the improvement of the city's environment and quality of life.

Those who expressed dissatisfaction with the government's administrative performance complained about the poor quality of city roads, haphazard construction on the city's roads, chaotic traffic, the city's dirty and disorderly appearance, poor public safety, high unemployment and air pollution, according to the RDEC.

Meanwhile, 79 percent of respondents recognized Chen's visit to China in May as a move to fulfill her duty in promoting Kaohsiung and the upcoming 2009 World Games, slated for July 16-26 in Kaohsiung City, while 11 percent thought the trip was not necessary.
A total of 1,081 valid samples were collected for the survey, which has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.98 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100 swimmers to challenge 1st cross-strait mass swim

TEXT.P: A mass swim across the Taiwan Strait is scheduled to be held Aug. 15, with 100 swimmers from Taiwan and China taking part, Lee Chu-feng, magistrate of Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen, said in Taipei Monday.

Lee said at a news conference that 50 swimmers from Taiwan will join 50 swimmers from China in the Fujian Province port city of Xiamen in southeastern China Aug. 15 to embark on the historic swim across the Taiwan Strait to Hsiao Kinmen -- a small islet west of Kinmen -- an 8.5-km swim that is expected to take several hours.
The swim, which is being sponsored by the Kinmen county government and the Xiamen city government, will begin from Xiamen's Yefengzhai Beach and finish on Hsiao Kinmen's Shuangkou Beach, Lee said.
He noted that the direct distance between the two beaches is about 6 km, but pointed out that the swimmers will have to actually swim up to 8.5 km due to the pull of ocean currents.
"They must finish the swim in 3.5 hours or less, " the magistrate said.

Addressing the news conference, Lee said the Kinmen-Xiamen swim will not only be a sports contest but also a major activity promoting cross-strait peace, as tension between Taiwan and China has noticeably eased since President Ma Ying- jeou took office in May 2008.
"We hope Kinmen will rid itself of its memories as an anti-communist battlefield six decades ago and that cross-strait peace and new possibilities will arrive after the swim," he said.

Careful to minimize the risks involved in the swim, the sponsors decided to conduct test swims June 17 and July 17 to allow the swimmers to get a better grasp of the conditions in the Taiwan Strait so that they can fully prepare themselves.
In addition, the Kinmen county government will remove spear-like anti-landing barricades from the Shuangkou Beach before August to allow easier access for the swimmers.
The devices -- built in the shallow waters of the beach during the Cold War era to obstruct landing craft from China -- will be replaced after the event, according to county government officials.
Meanwhile, the workers assigned to Kinmen to clear landmines left over from the same period will be put to work cleaning up the Shuangkou Beach area the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: First grader donates NT$10 a day to help the disadvantaged

TEXT.P: A first grade student from the Guo An Elementary School in central Taiwan's Taichung City, has been publicly commended for donating her piggy bank savings, on her own initiative, to help economically disadvantaged students.

Tsai Ching-yu's parents were not aware of her actions until they were informed that she was to receive Sunday a commendation from the Long Yan Ling Foundation, the non-profit group that launched the charity drive to help poor families.

The foundation, which is dedicated to assisting such families and helping disadvantaged children fulfill their dreams, initiated a "NT$10-a-day, pay it forward" campaign that Ching-yu became aware of in school.
At the function Sunday, the "Long Yan Angels" -- donors whose generosity helped poor children to realize their dreams -- were commended for their efforts and Ching-yu was the star of the event.
Her daily NT$10 donations were noticed by her school teachers but they thought that she had been asking her parents for the money.

They later learned that she had earned the money by helping her family with the housework. The foundation then decided to invite her to the charity show and commended her for her initiative and her beneficence.

One of the recipients, Tung Hsiao-chieh, a fifth grade soccer player who did not have the required NT$50,000 (US$1,520) to travel to Spain with his school's soccer team, expressed his appreciation to the "angels" who made his dream come true.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese official hopes for cross-strait agricultural cooperation

TEXT.P: Zheng Lizhong, the visiting deputy director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, met with local farmers on a visit to Tainan County in southern Taiwan Monday and expressed an interest in further agricultural cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Zheng, who also serves as vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said China's government has attached great importance to its agricultural development.

After seeing that Tainan County enjoys a competitive edge in the sector with its high-quality subtropical fruits, Zheng suggested the county capitalize on its advantages in cooperating with China, focusing on high value-added items and strengthening the division of labor across the Taiwan Strait.
He said his country will soon send a procurement delegation to Tainan and that he hopes the county will sell its best fruit to the mainland.

As to the problems of quarantine and customs clearance, Zheng said he anticipated they would be likely put on the agenda of the fourth round of talks between the ARATS and Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation -- two intermediary bodies founded to handle cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the absence of official links.
On Monday, Zheng also visited Chiayi County where he toured Budai harbor, a designated destination for direct cross-strait cargo shipping links.

Zheng arrived in Taiwan last Wednesday to work out the agenda of the planned fifth forum between Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China, which will be held July 11-12 in Changsha, Hunan Province in central China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on Chinese executives' length of stay to be eased

TEXT.P: Chinese business executives will be allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to one year if revised regulations proposed by the National Immigration Agency (NIA) take effect.

NIA officials said Monday executives of Chinese companies that have obtained approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to invest in Taiwan would be allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to one year under the planned revision.

If the executives have children 18 years of age or older who are living with them, the children can also apply to study in Taiwan in line with regulations governing multinational business executives in Taiwan.

The revised regulations on Chinese professionals coming to Taiwan for professional activities are among the complementary measures being planned in anticipation of the scheduled announcement by the MOEA on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment at the end of the month.

Regulations would also be revised for Chinese nationals investing in the local property market. Existing guidelines limit the stay of Chinese invited to Taiwan to one month, but under the proposed revisions, they could make an unlimited number of visits and stay in Taiwan for up to four months of the year.
The latest proposals follow an announcement earlier this month that Chinese visitors can extend their stay in Taiwan from 14 days to one month when traveling in Taiwan on business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspects in aimless killing in Hsinchu City arrested

TEXT.P: Five teenagers were arrested in the northern city of Hsinchu Monday for allegedly beating a former semiconductor engineer to death last week, police said.

Yu Che-pin, a Canada-trained master's degree holder who once worked for a semiconductor company in the Hsinchu Science Park, was fatally beaten while chatting with a friend in the city's coastal Nanliao Park early Wednesday. He died shortly after being rushed to a nearby hospital.

Police said they had screened security videos at 100-plus locations in the vicinity of the crime scene, including those installed at nearby convenience stores, and pored over data on more than 200 notorious street dragsters and those with previous criminal records in the city before tracking down the five suspected assailants.
"The five adolescent suspects have confessed to their involvement in the aimless killing spree," said a Hsinchu police officer.

The suspects told police that they rode on three motorcycles to Nanliao Park at around 1 a.m. June 10. They were having fun drinking on the park's elevated observation platform when they spotted Yu talking with a woman on the lawn nearby at around 2:30 a.m.
They then planted a wooden bar in front of Yu in a provocative gesture. When Yu attempted to leave the scene, one of the suspects hit his head with another wooden stick found on park grounds.
The four other accomplices then continued beating Yu and eventually fled when he collapsed to the ground.
The teen attackers said they did not realize Yu had died until the following day when they read about it on the Internet.
Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi and Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer jointly hosted a news conference at Hsinchu City police headquarters to announce that the tragic case had been broken.
Liao said the government put a high priority on the case and that the speed with which the crime was solved signified the government's determination to crack down on youth crime.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lin said the city government will install more lamps and monitoring cameras at scenic spots around the city and step up counseling services for school dropouts to reduce the juvenile crime rate.

Yu's death triggered an uproar in the city, which is the home of Taiwan's high- tech nerve center -- the Hsinchu Science Park. Internet users in the city launched a "one man one letter" campaign after news of Yu's death spread.

Local activists blamed the city government for failing to take effective measures to wipe out what they called rampant drag racing in the city. They recalled that three years ago, two science park engineers were seriously wounded by teen attackers in two separate cases.
They appealed to campaign supporters to write to President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and urge them to take immediate steps to solve the case.
They also questioned the credibility of Lin's high approval rating in some public opinion surveys, claiming that he has been unable to reduce the city's juvenile crime rate.
Yu's heartbroken mother was quoted by local papers as saying that she hoped her son would be the last victim of this kind of aimless killing spree.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paiwan woman retires after devoting 47 years to education

TEXT.P: Kao Chin-yu, a 65-year-old member of the Paiwan aboriginal tribe, will retire Aug. 1 after teaching for 47 years in her hometown in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County and taking on the role of mother and esteemed colleague to many in her remote village.

Kao has never looked back since becoming a teacher at Sinsing Elementary School in her native Jinfong Township at the age of 18, but the time has finally arrived for her to exit the stage that has meant so much to her.

Also retiring will be Lu Shien-nan, the principal of Sanchien Elementary School, who was one of Kao's students in 1962 -- the year she began teaching at Sinsing Elementary shortly after graduating from "Taitung Normal School."
At the only school in the small township, almost every township resident was once her student. Kao even taught her own daughters and granddaughter as well as three generations of one family.
"I treated all of them equally," Kao said.
"She is our mom, co-worker and grandma, " explained Cheng Hui-feng, director of the Sinsing Elementary School.
"She is truly one of a kind," hailed Sinsing Elementary principal Cheng Hen-wen. "There will never be anyone again who will be able to serve so many years at the same school as she has."

After the normal education system, responsible for producing Taiwan's teachers, was upgraded to the higher university level, normal university graduates are now generally at least 22 years old, making a repeat of Kao's career a near impossibility.

For Kao to be admitted to her county's normal school in the late 1950s was truly a feat in itself. It was a "great honor" for her tribe and the underprivileged township, which is secluded in a mountainous area in sparsely populated southeastern Taiwan and did not have any resources in that underdeveloped era.
Recalling her long-term devotion to grassroots education in Jinfong Township, Kao said her most unforgettable experience was the so-called "lunch box episode."

Because many parents of her students were poor, some of them would knock on her door early in the morning and ask her to help them nourish their children, Kao said. By lunch time, the entire class, including Kao, would have similar lunch boxes, she remembered.
Apart from educating young children, Kao also enthusiastically promoted learning and knowledge among adult Paiwan men and women.
In 1992, she was cited by the Ministry of Education as the "outstanding teacher" of the year in honor of her life-long contribution to the indigenous Paiwan people.

Although Kao will officially retire on August 1, township residents have decided to host a big feast for Kao on Wednesday to express their deepest gratitude to a person so dear and so precious to them.
"She is the pride of our tribe and our town, " township representative Hu Chao- ching said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 16, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on the premiere of "A Taiwan to the World Series - 3," a documentary co-produced by the Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel. DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 16, or the 24th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1972: Guatemalan President Carlos Arana Osorio arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Gen. John W. Voge Jr., commander-in-chief of the U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: China Airlines inaugurates a Boeing 747 jumbo jet service to Los Angeles.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo inspects cadets of the Military Academy on its 52nd anniversary.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the U.S. Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1982: The 11-member ROC Goodwill Mission of Mayors, led by Mayor Jackson C.T. Yang of Taipei, leaves for a 20-day visit to the United States.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash their strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
1999: Thabo Mbeki becomes president of South Africa, succeeding Nelson Mandela.
2000: A new shortened work-week program, allowing Taiwan's workers and employers to work 84 hours every two weeks instead of the former 96 hours, is passed overwhelmingly at the legislature.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

The weighted price index lost 222.67 points, or 3.45 percent, to close at 6,225.56 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on Chinese executives' length of stay to be eased

TEXT.P: Chinese business executives will be allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to one year if revised regulations proposed by the National Immigration Agency (NIA) take effect.

NIA officials said Monday executives of Chinese companies that have obtained approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to invest in Taiwan would be allowed to stay in Taiwan for up to one year under the planned revision.

If the executives have children 18 years of age or older who are living with them, the children can also apply to study in Taiwan in line with regulations governing multinational business executives in Taiwan.

The revised regulations on Chinese professionals coming to Taiwan for professional activities are among the complementary measures being planned in anticipation of the scheduled announcement by the MOEA on opening Taiwan to Chinese investment at the end of the month.

Regulations would also be revised for Chinese nationals investing in the local property market. Existing guidelines limit the stay of Chinese invited to Taiwan to one month, but under the proposed revisions, they could make an unlimited number of visits and stay in Taiwan for up to four months of the year.
The latest proposals follow an announcement earlier this month that Chinese visitors can extend their stay in Taiwan from 14 days to one month when traveling in Taiwan on business.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspects in aimless killing in Hsinchu City arrested

TEXT.P: Five teenagers were arrested in the northern city of Hsinchu Monday for allegedly beating a former semiconductor engineer to death last week, police said.

Yu Che-pin, a Canada-trained master's degree holder who once worked for a semiconductor company in the Hsinchu Science Park, was fatally beaten while chatting with a friend in the city's coastal Nanliao Park early Wednesday. He died shortly after being rushed to a nearby hospital.

Police said they had screened security videos at 100-plus locations in the vicinity of the crime scene, including those installed at nearby convenience stores, and pored over data on more than 200 notorious street dragsters and those with previous criminal records in the city before tracking down the five suspected assailants.
"The five adolescent suspects have confessed to their involvement in the aimless killing spree," said a Hsinchu police officer.

The suspects told police that they rode on three motorcycles to Nanliao Park at around 1 a.m. June 10. They were having fun drinking on the park's elevated observation platform when they spotted Yu talking with a woman on the lawn nearby at around 2:30 a.m.
They then planted a wooden bar in front of Yu in a provocative gesture. When Yu attempted to leave the scene, one of the suspects hit his head with another wooden stick found on park grounds.
The four other accomplices then continued beating Yu and eventually fled when he collapsed to the ground.
The teen attackers said they did not realize Yu had died until the following day when they read about it on the Internet.
Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi and Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tzer jointly hosted a news conference at Hsinchu City police headquarters to announce that the tragic case had been broken.
Liao said the government put a high priority on the case and that the speed with which the crime was solved signified the government's determination to crack down on youth crime.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lin said the city government will install more lamps and monitoring cameras at scenic spots around the city and step up counseling services for school dropouts to reduce the juvenile crime rate.

Yu's death triggered an uproar in the city, which is the home of Taiwan's high- tech nerve center -- the Hsinchu Science Park. Internet users in the city launched a "one man one letter" campaign after news of Yu's death spread.

Local activists blamed the city government for failing to take effective measures to wipe out what they called rampant drag racing in the city. They recalled that three years ago, two science park engineers were seriously wounded by teen attackers in two separate cases.
They appealed to campaign supporters to write to President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and urge them to take immediate steps to solve the case.
They also questioned the credibility of Lin's high approval rating in some public opinion surveys, claiming that he has been unable to reduce the city's juvenile crime rate.
Yu's heartbroken mother was quoted by local papers as saying that she hoped her son would be the last victim of this kind of aimless killing spree.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paiwan woman retires after devoting 47 years to education

TEXT.P: Kao Chin-yu, a 65-year-old member of the Paiwan aboriginal tribe, will retire Aug. 1 after teaching for 47 years in her hometown in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County and taking on the role of mother and esteemed colleague to many in her remote village.

Kao has never looked back since becoming a teacher at Sinsing Elementary School in her native Jinfong Township at the age of 18, but the time has finally arrived for her to exit the stage that has meant so much to her.

Also retiring will be Lu Shien-nan, the principal of Sanchien Elementary School, who was one of Kao's students in 1962 -- the year she began teaching at Sinsing Elementary shortly after graduating from "Taitung Normal School."
At the only school in the small township, almost every township resident was once her student. Kao even taught her own daughters and granddaughter as well as three generations of one family.
"I treated all of them equally," Kao said.
"She is our mom, co-worker and grandma, " explained Cheng Hui-feng, director of the Sinsing Elementary School.
"She is truly one of a kind," hailed Sinsing Elementary principal Cheng Hen-wen. "There will never be anyone again who will be able to serve so many years at the same school as she has."

After the normal education system, responsible for producing Taiwan's teachers, was upgraded to the higher university level, normal university graduates are now generally at least 22 years old, making a repeat of Kao's career a near impossibility.

For Kao to be admitted to her county's normal school in the late 1950s was truly a feat in itself. It was a "great honor" for her tribe and the underprivileged township, which is secluded in a mountainous area in sparsely populated southeastern Taiwan and did not have any resources in that underdeveloped era.
Recalling her long-term devotion to grassroots education in Jinfong Township, Kao said her most unforgettable experience was the so-called "lunch box episode."

Because many parents of her students were poor, some of them would knock on her door early in the morning and ask her to help them nourish their children, Kao said. By lunch time, the entire class, including Kao, would have similar lunch boxes, she remembered.
Apart from educating young children, Kao also enthusiastically promoted learning and knowledge among adult Paiwan men and women.
In 1992, she was cited by the Ministry of Education as the "outstanding teacher" of the year in honor of her life-long contribution to the indigenous Paiwan people.

Although Kao will officially retire on August 1, township residents have decided to host a big feast for Kao on Wednesday to express their deepest gratitude to a person so dear and so precious to them.
"She is the pride of our tribe and our town, " township representative Hu Chao- ching said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
GPA to take effect July 15 for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 15 (CNA) 06/16/09 12:07:58 (By Jou Ying-cheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The World Trade Organization (WTO) received Monday an instrument of accession to the Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) submitted by Taiwan -- the 41st signatory of the plurilateral accord, WTO spokesman Josep Bosch said.
Taiwan completed the accession procedure after depositing the instrument of accession with the WTO.

Though Taiwan has now formally become a signatory of the GPA, the agreement will not enter into force until the 30th day (in this case July 15) following the date on which the instrument of accession has been received by the WTO, according to the terms of the GPA.
The WTO Committee on Government Procurement formally approved Taiwan's application to enter the GPA on Dec. 9, 2008.

Taiwan was originally required to submit the instrument of accession by June 9, but it asked that the deadline of the submission be extended for one month to July 9, a request which was approved by the WTO.
The GPA was adopted by the WTO in 1981 with the purpose of opening up as much government procurement as possible to international competition.

It was designed to make laws, regulations, procedures and practices regarding government procurement more transparent and to ensure they do not protect domestic products or suppliers, or discriminate against foreign products or suppliers.
Following the accession, Taiwan's government procurement market will be open to the 40 other GPA members, and vice versa, based on the principles of reciprocity and national treatment.
Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs has estimated that the government procurement market in GPA signatory countries totals US$960 billion per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Direct sales company regional to draw 20,000 people

TEXT.P: Herbalife, a U.S.-based personal care direct sales company, will hold its annual Asia Pacific leadership conference in Taiwan Sept. 11-13, a meeting that is expected to draw the participation of some 20,000 Herbalife members from home and abroad.

William Rahn, managing director of the company's Asia Pacific region, made the announcement at a news conference Monday that was also attended by Bureau of Foreign Trade Deputy Director General Chiang Shih-hwang and Tourism Bureau Deputy Director General David Hsieh Wei-chun.

Expected to attend the conference at the Taipei World Trade Center Nangang Exhibition Hall are an estimated 10,000 Herbalife members from Taiwan and another 10,000 top sales executives from 11 other Asia Pacific countries, including Japan, Korea, Hong Kong, New Zealand and Australia.

Foreign sales leaders will stay in Taiwan for at least five days and four nights. Aside from attending the 3-day conference, they will travel around Taiwan, according to Lu Jun-han, general manager of Herbalife Taiwan.

The top sales executives' visit to Taiwan is expected to generate hundreds of millions of Taiwan dollars of business for local hotels, restaurants, and transportation providers because each of them earns annual incomes between NT$1 million and NT$10 million, Lu said.
As the Taipei Deaflympics will coincide with the conference, Lu anticipates a shortage of hotel rooms in Taipei city and county during the conference.
She said that Herbalife Taiwan is therefore planning to arrange accommodation for some of the attendees in Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: President could visit Africa next year: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that the most likely timing for President Ma Ying-jeou to pay a state visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Africa is sometime next year.

Our African allies are glad to know that President Ma has expressed the willingness to visit them, and the Foreign Ministry will make relative arrangements,said Andrew Chang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
Given the president's tight schedule this year, it will probably be more possible for him to make such a trip next year, " Chang said.

Ma said May 25 at the African Day Reception that he was deeply moved by the solid friendship shown by Taiwan's four diplomatic allies in Africa -- Burkina Faso, Gambia, Swaziland and Sao Tome and Principe -- which all sent top leaders to attend his inauguration ceremony May 20, 2008.
He said he wished to visit these countries during his first term of presidency.

According to Chang, next year might be the time for Ma to visit Africa because Burkina Faso will probably hold its presidential election in October 2010. The Foreign Ministry will plan the state visit once it receives the nod from the Presidential Office, he added.

Fresh from a three-leg Central American visit that took him to Belize, Guatemala and El Salvador, Ma will head for the region again June 29-July 7 to attend the inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Ricardo Martinelli and visit two of Taiwan's other Central American diplomatic allies, Nicaragua and Honduras.

Ma is also planning to visit the South Pacific in the later half of the year to attend the Taiwan-South Pacific leaders's summit in the Solomon Islands and to visit several diplomatic allies in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to allow use of Chinese yuan at duty-free shops: official

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF), in a bid to boost Chinese tourists arrivals, is planning to permit the use of the Chinese currency at duty-free shops at the country's airports and seaports, with effect from early July, a ministry official said Tuesday.
The government will revise the relevant regulations to permit transactions of up to 20,000 yuan at such shops, according to the official.

Under the existing regulations governing the operation of duty-free stores, foreign currencies and New Taiwan dollars may be used for transactions at duty- free shops. However, the yuan is not categorized in the regulations as a foreign currency.

In an effort to keep step with a government policy of attracting more Chinese tourists to Taiwan, the ministry is planning to amend the rules to allow duty- free shop operators at the country's ports of entry to accept the Chinese yuan, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan County promotes tourism through innovative aboriginal gifts

TEXT.P: Yilan County recently showcased gifts specially crafted by its indigenous people to promote tourism there, hoping that Atayal handicrafts, school bags, and hunter's banana rice cakes for cyclists will spark visitor interest.
Yilan County Magistrate Lu Guo-hwa said booths exhibiting and selling these aboriginal gifts will be incorporated into major tourism promotion activities in the future by the county government.
The campaign is aimed at attracting tourists from outside the county and generating local business opportunities, Lu added.
Most of Yilan County's indigenous people, mainly the Atayal tribe, live in Datong and Nanao townships and are skilled at hunting and weaving and manage to eke out a living by growing vegetables.

To boost local economy, the county's Department of Indigenous Affairs, in conjunction with Yilan University, has recreated various traditional gifts by repackaging existing products and providing guidance on the creation of new items.
These gifts, which symbolize Atayal culture, emphasize environmental consciousness and respect concepts of traditional indigenous lifestyles.
The gifts include racks, mobile phone bags, coasters and backpacks.
In addition, the hunter's rice cake wrapped in banana leaves, which was originally standard fare for Atayal hunters, has now been redesigned for cyclists to eat during and after their outings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese crew charged with murder found not guilty: MOFA

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese crew members on trial in Mauritius for murdering two people on their fishing vessel were found not guilty recently and returned to Taiwan June 11, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

The MOFA is pleased to learn that the Mauritius court ruled the three crew members not guilty because of insufficient evidence and the lack of credible testimony,said Andrew Chang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, at a regular press briefing.

The Taiwanese fishing boat Jui Yin and the 35 people on board, including three Taiwanese nationals -- the captain, the first mate and one crew member -- were detained over a year ago by Mauritius police on murder charges after two frozen corpses were discovered in the vessel's freezer.

Chang said the Foreign Ministry's representative office in South Africa had visited the three many times and provided necessary assistance to them during the trial and was glad to see that the case had come to a happy ending for the crew members.
The trial was not the only case related to a Taiwanese fishing boat off Africa's southeastern coast that the ministry has been monitoring.
Taiwanese fishing boat CT7-0266 MV Chi Jing No. 3 sent out a warning signal May 28 that it was being chased by an unknown ship in the Indian Ocean southeast of Madagascar, according to Chang.
The boat, with four Taiwanese nationals, 33 Chinese, one Indonesian and four Filipinos on board, was told not to stop by its company in Taiwan, he added.

Chang said the Foreign Ministry immediately reported the situation to the International Maritime Bureau Piracy Reporting Center in Kuala Lumpur and the U.S. Navys Fifth Fleet Bahrain headquarters and later learned that the unknown ship was a revenue cutter belonging to French Reunion, an island situated about 680 kilometers east of Madagascar.

The revenue cutter was chasing Chi Jing No. 3 because the Taiwanese vessel did not apply for a permit to pass through the economic zone of Reunion, but the cutter gave up after a day-long chase because it was smaller than Chi Jing No. 3, Chang said.

The entire incident was a misunderstanding. However, the Foreign Ministry would like to urge all Taiwanese deep-sea fishing boats to apply for permits when passing through other countries' economic zones and to navigate along the permitted route in order to avoid a similar situation,Chang said.
Though this is an isolated incident, the MOFA hopes that it will not happen again because things like this will harm the image and credibility of not only our ships but also our country, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan remains world's 6th largest net foreign creditor

TEXT.P: Taiwan's net international investment position at the end of 2008 was US$576.7 billion, which kept the country in its rank as the world's sixth largest net foreign creditor, according to a report released Monday by the Central Bank of the Republic of China.

At the end of 2008, the external assets held by Taiwan were valued at US$877.8 billion, up 1.2 percent from the year-earlier level, mainly due to an increase in Taiwan's official reserve assets as well as foreign loans and deposits by Taiwanese banks, the central bank said.
Residents' portfolio investment, however, shrank by US$60.1 billion, or 24.1 percent, as the private sector holdings of foreign securities decreased in reaction to the global financial crisis.
Meanwhile, the country's external liabilities went down 22.5 percent to US$301.1 billion, as a result of lower stock prices and reduced acquisitions of Taiwanese stocks by foreign investors.
The net international investment position of US$576.7 billion posted by Taiwan was lower only than that of Japan, China, Germany, Hong Kong and Switzerland, according to the central bank.
The United States, with net external liabilities of US$2.44 trillion, was the world's largest net foreign debtor in 2008, followed by Brazil, France, Australia and Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop slightly on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged down Tuesday to finish lower for the third consecutive day, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 4.75 points, or 0.07 percent, to close at 6,220.81.
Following Wall Street's big drop overnight, the local bourse opened at 6,220.54 and fluctuated between 6,257.13 and 6,143.24.
A total of 4.07 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$109.22 billion (US$3.32 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks advancing the most at 1.4 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 0.8 percent, and foodstuff shares gained 0.7 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with cement issues moving down the most at 1.0 percent. Textile stocks fell 0.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 0.3 percent, banking and financial shares and plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 0.1 percent each.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,290 to 887, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$267 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan honored for helping developing economies develop
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) 06/16/09 18:13:01 (By Chiehyu Lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was recognized Monday for its contributions in helping developing countries increase their international economic and trading competitiveness during a meeting in the island nation of Saint Lucia.

Taiwan's Ambassador to Saint Lucia Tom Chou told CNA's Washington-based reporter by phone that Saint Lucia's Minister of Foreign Affairs Rufus Bousquet expressed in his speech at the opening ceremony of the meeting that people of his country were all grateful for Taiwan's assistance in helping the country in the Caribbean Sea develop economically and socially over the past two years.
Bousquet was speaking at the Seminar on Trade Related Assistance in the Caribbean Area, which opened in Saint Lucia Monday.

The seminar is jointly sponsored by the Taiwan-based International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) and the Agency for International Trade Information and Cooperation (AITIC), which is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.
Among its assistance to Saint Lucia, Taiwan has been helping its ally since 2008 in establishing a computerized government system to improve administrative efficiency.

In the first phase of the program last year, Taiwan assisted St. Lucia with the development of a crime records management system, as well as an e-system in the transportation department which features efficient management modules for vehicle and driver registration and licenses.

The cooperation program entered its second phrase in May, with Taiwan to assist the diplomatic ally in building an agricultural information system and an e-databank and management system for ID cards and birth registration information.
Saint Lucia is one of the 23 countries which has diplomatic relations with Taiwan instead of China.

A total of 39 representatives from 15 countries attended the three-day seminar aimed at assisting developing and under-developed countries in following the international multilateral economic and trading mechanism.
Discussions at the seminar will focus on tourism, women's social position and trading efficiency, Chou said.

The AITIC is an important inter-governmental organization whose goal is to assist less-advantaged countries to have more effective trade-led growth through personalized assistance and capacity-building programs. It is made of four sponsoring members -- Switzerland, Sweden, Ireland and Taiwan -- and 65 participating members, according to Chou.
Also participating in the opening ceremony were Saint Lucia Deputy Prime Minister Lenard Montoute, AITIC Executive Director Esperanza Duran and ICDF Deputy Secretary General Lee Pai-po.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei MRT Neihu line to begin operations July 4

TEXT.P: The new Neihu line on the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system will begin regular operations July 4, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday.
Hau also said that for three days, beginning July 4, passengers paying with the city's Easy card will enjoy a 50 percent discount on the line.

Hau said the city has invited President Ma Ying-jeou -- a former Taipei mayor -- legislators, city councilors, media reporters, and 48 borough chiefs to take the maiden ride on June 28. Ma has already confirmed that he will be there, Hau added.
On June 29, some 25,000 people who live along the new MRT line will be offered free rides that can be claimed with the use of special coupons distributed at borough and community offices, Hau said.
According to the mayor, this is the city's way of saying thanks to the residents who supported the project and endured all the inconvenience caused by the construction of the line.
On June 30, the new line will be opened to the wider public for free rides, the mayor added.

The Taipei Metro Neihu Line, a Phase-2 Brown Line extension, is a medium capacity system that has been built on viaducts, except for the section near the Songshan Airport, which goes underground and surfaces again on the other side of the Keelung river.
The new line, 14.8 kilometers long, is an extension of the Muzha Line and will provide direct service to the Neihu, Nangang and Muzha districts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taipei good luck tour' campaign kicks off in Tokyo
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 16 (CNA) 06/16/09 18:49:30 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government and EVA Airways jointly launched a campaign in Tokyo Monday to promote a package of "Good Luck Travel to Taipei" in bid to draw more Japanese tourists to the Taiwan capital.

Rosy Chao, deputy chief executive of the Taipei City's Tourism Commission, and Nie Kuo-wei, CEO of the Taipei-based Evergreen Group, co-chaired the ceremony at a local exhibition hall. About 80 representatives of Japanese tour agencies and the media attended the event.

According to Chao, the "Good Luck Travel to Taipei" package is comprised of six "pleasure routes" that would allow Japanese visitors to explore different facets of the city. The tours are touted to be able to bring visitors good fortune in the areas of love, work, finances, health, examinations and competition.
Taiwan's envoy to Japan John Fang, who delivered an address at the function, urged Japanese to visit Taipei by buying the special packages.
Fan said he had purchased two of the tours as a treat for two Japanese workers at his office.

The number of tourist arrivals from Taiwan to Japan totals around 1.4 million per year, as compared to 1.1 million from Japan to Taiwan. "We hope to push the number of two-way visitors to 3 million a year by 2010," Chao said after the news conference.

Over three-quarters of Japanese think that the bilateral relations between Taiwan and Japan are in good shape and 61 percent are interested in visiting Taiwan, according to a poll commissioned by the Taiwan representative office in Japan and conducted by U.S.-based polling company Gallup, Inc. from April 10-19.
Taiwan has designated 2009 as a year to strengthen the two-way special partnership with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government promotes long-term elderly care program

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior on Tuesday encouraged elderly people and disabled senior citizens who need long-term care services to apply for government subsidies for such services.
The ministry, in conjunction with the Department of Health, launched the subsidy program last year to meet the rapidly increasing need for long-term care in Taiwan's aging population.
Last year, more than 36,000 elderly people were subsidized through the program which is funded by the central government and operated by local governments, the ministry said in a statement.
Many spaces are available on the scheme, which is geared for people aged 65 or over and disabled people between the ages of 50 and 65.

The government provides subsidies in different amounts to eligible applicants based on the extent of their disability and their families' economic situation. People with a higher level of disability and with lower family income will be granted a higher amount of subsidy, according to the ministry.

Normally, the government provides 60 percent of long-term care subsidies for people from middle-income families, 90 percent for people from lower middle- income families, and 100 percent for low-income families, the statement indicated.

Through the program, people in need of long-term care can continue to live in their own home if they prefer to do so and would not cause a burden or pressure on their families because a caregiver is provided, the statement noted.

People who need long-term care services are encouraged to contact a long-term care management center in their neighborhood for a family assessment. Further information is available on the ministry's Web site at: //www.moi.gov.tw.

Taiwan has the second fastest aging population in the world behind Japan. At present, people aged over 65 make up 10 percent of the country's population. Around 2020, the aged population is expected to reach 20 percent in Taiwan, a recent report said.
According to the United Nations definition of "aging society, "when the percentage of population of people over 65 years old is more than 7 percent, that society will be called "aging society".

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan lemon exports expected to hit 800 tons: official

TEXT.P: With locally grown lemons becoming increasingly popular worldwide, exports of fresh lemons and lemon juice this year are expected to exceed 800 metric tons, Hsu Han-chin, chief secretary of the Agriculture and Food Agency, said Tuesday.

The southern counties of Pingtung and Kaohsiung are the major lemon-producing areas in the country. This year, more 2,000 hectares of farmlands have been dedicated to the cultivation of the Eureka Seedless lemons and other seedless lemon varieties, according to Hsu.
The total production volume of the crop is estimated at 15,000 tons, down 15 percent from last year due to drastic temperature changes in January and February, Hsu said.
Despite the drop in production volume, the quality of this year's lemon crop is still good, and the citrus fruit's popularity among foreign buyers has lead to a surge in exports, according to Hsu.
The agency has predicted that exports of the fresh fruit will reach 350 tons, while exports of lemon juice will amount to nearly 500 tons, a sharp increase from last year's 90 tons, Hsu said.
Taiwan grown lemons are mainly exported to Japan, Singapore, Malaysia and China.

In addition to helping local growers make inroads into foreign markets, the agency will assist them in expanding domestic sales and in developing other uses for lemons, Hsu said. Some of the possibilities are lemon essential oil, lemon honey lozenges, lemon vinegar, and lemon sauce, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President proposes expanding training program for allies

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday raised the possibility of expanding the scope of Taiwan's training program for government officials of its diplomatic allies, as part of efforts to strengthen bilateral friendship.

Touching upon the issue during an interview with the CNA, Ma noted that the "Friend from Afar" program has targeted mainly military and police officers from Latin American nations and he suggested that the program should also cover broader issues such as economics, agriculture and health.

According to the president, such a military-centered training program served the need of the Latin American allies very well in the past because many of these countries were governed by military strongmen.
However, many leftist politicians who have since come to power are paying more attention to issues related to the economic development rather than military issues.

"If we share Taiwan's national development experience with them (the allies) , we should be able to move them and truly help them. They will also feel that Taiwan is very pragmatic and grassroots (oriented)," Ma said.

The "Friend from Afar" program was launched as early as the 1960s during the Cold War era as part of Taiwan's campaign to fight against Communism. Courses were provided to help Latin American, Middle Eastern and African countries train their junior military officers, some of whom later became national leaders or politicians.

On his administration's foreign aid policy, Ma stressed that in providing aid to Taiwan's allies, the government will make sure that the work serves legitimate purposes, follows legal process and achieves effective implementation.
For example, he said, Taiwan has been transferring rice-farming technology to Belize in a bid to boost rice production in the Central American ally country and help it become a rice exporter.
Taiwan has also provided Belize with tilapia fish farming technology, and the fish raised using the technology is now being exported to the United States for processing into fish fillets, Ma said.
"We should not only teach our diplomatic allies how to fish, but should also teach them how to sell fish," he said.
Asked about his administration's strategy to promote Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations in September, Ma said the government will only decide on the matter in August.

According to the president, the government must be very careful in dealing with the issue of Taiwan's participation in international organizations because it is "more sensitive" than issues involving bilateral relations.

Ma added that although the improvement in Taiwan's ties with China over the past year seems to have facilitated the promotion of Taiwan's foreign relations, Taiwan should not be content or light-headed.

Pointing to Taiwan's recent success in obtaining observer status for the first time in the World Health Assembly, Ma said the government is watching to see if the status will open the doors for Taiwan's participation in other activities of the World Health Organization (WHO), in addition to attending the annual assembly.
Ma said the government will not rush into the next step, but will first try to play a positive role in the WHO to impress other member nations and win their goodwill.

In this regard, the influenza A(H1N1) outbreak provides a good opportunity for Taiwan to contribute to the international community, because Taiwan is one of the few countries that are capable of producing a vaccine against the disease, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New research expected to help develop universal flu vaccine

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong said Tuesday that he has discovered a way to develop and produce a "universal vaccine" that can protect against most influenza viruses.

Wong released the results of his research in a speech titled "Protein Glycosylation: New Challenges and Opportunities" delivered at the five-day 12th International Symposium of the Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America (SCBA) , which opened at Academia Sinica Sunday.

The expert in bio-organic and synthetic chemistry and biocatalysis said his team found that once the glycoprotein the flu virus uses to cover its existence is removed, the human immune system can identify it and attack when the virus invades the body.
Wong explained that more than 50 percent of the proteins found in humans are glocosylated, which is why flu virus uses glycoprotein as a disguise.

Given the fact that the protein sequence within the glycoprotein is mostly conserved, it is theoretically possible to make a molecular vaccine with a flu virus that has had its disguise removed, therefore allowing the immune system to identify the virus, Wong said.

The theoretical molecular vaccine could maintain its anti-flu capability for several years, unlike the existing virus vaccines, which must be updated every year to maintain their effectiveness, Wong said.
In addition, he noted, such a molecular vaccine could theoretically be used to fight against almost all kinds of flu virus.

As the research is still now in the animal testing stages, it will take up to 10 years before a new vaccine is commercially available, Wong said, noting that the development and manufacture of the vaccine, however, can all be achieved in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, he also noted that his team has discovered that breast, lung, large intestine, ovarian and prostate cancers all have a unique glocoaprotein named Globo H.
With this discovery, a molecular vaccine can be developed against those cancers, Wong said, adding that this work will also be conducted in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF seeks ARATS help over murders of Taiwanese businessmen

TEXT.P: The semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Tuesday that it had contacted its Chinese counterpart to help in issues relating to the death of two Taiwanese businessmen murdered by a Chinese man a day earlier in Dongguan, Guangdong Province.

Chen Jung-yuan, director of the SEF's trade and commerce department, said it sent a letter on Monday to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) asking for its assistance in dealing with the murders after the news reached Taipei from Donguan's Dalang township.
The SEF is also helping the families of the Taiwanese victims to travel to Dongguan Wednesday to take care of their relatives' remains, Chen said.
The three men are all from central Taiwan's Taichung County.

The Taiwanese victims were Lin Yu-teng, a 33-year-old general manager of a Taiwanese-owned hardware factory, the factory's 40-year-old manager named Lai Chen-jui and its 50-year-old deputy general manager Shao Cheng-chi. The three men were attacked Monday at the factory's main gate by Liu Hanhuang, a 26-year- old worker from Guizhou Province, after negotiations on compensation for Liu's work-related injury broke down earlier the same day, China's official Xinhua news agency quoted Chinese security officers as saying.
Liu's right hand was damaged by a machine while he was at work last September and had to be amputated.
Although the company has paid out compensation of 50,000 yuan (US$7,315) for Liu's injury in line with local labor laws, Liu was not satisfied and filed a complaint against the company.
Although Liu and the company executives had agreed to start talks on the issue again that day, Liu intercepted Lai at the main gate as he was preparing to leave the company.
Liu and Lai had a fierce quarrel into which Lin and Shao were drawn.
During the argument, Liu pulled out a knife and stabbed the three men, Xinhua said.

Shao was killed on the spot, while Lin was pronounced dead after being rushed to a nearby hospital. Lai was seriously injured and had to undergo emergency treatment at a hospital. Liu was arrested by Dongguan public security officials near the factory.
The incident was the first labor dispute-related murder involving a Taiwanese- invested business in Dongguan.
The Taipei-based SEF is an intermediary organization responsible for cross- Taiwan Strait exchanges through dealings with the ARATS in the absence of government-to-government contact.
