Wang said Ma shares the concept of "no unification, no independence and no use of force" with the majority of the people in Taiwan toward cross-strait relations, in other words, maintaining the status quo in political terms.

On the "no independence" statement, the president explained that different political parties maintain different agendas on Taiwan's future. For the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), seeking de jure independence will never be an option, because Taiwan is already an independent nation and there is no need for it to struggle for de jure independence.

Ma was also asked during the interview about his decision to run for the KMT chairmanship. Ma said that his plan to serve concurrently as the nation's president and as ruling party chairman is not intended to expand his presidential power, but rather to more effectively fulfill his responsibilities.

Ma expressed hope that his bid will be supported by the party members in the interest of facilitating closer cooperation between the ruling party and the administration and achieving more effective government.

"If I assume the party chairmanship, the KMT will serve as a platform for communication between the administration and the party, while the Cabinet will remain the decision-making and executive body," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT and local shopping mall to hold America Month event

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Commercial Section and a local shopping mall will collaborate to host an America Month event in celebration of the 233rd Independence Day of the United States, according to an AIT press release.
"AIT extends a warm invitation for everyone to visit Miramar from June 19 to July 5 to enjoy the festive atmosphere and a variety of activities," the release stated.

According to the AIT, the theme for the event is "American Beauty and Strength" and it will feature products and activities that reflect an energetic American lifestyle, its free spirit and multi-faceted culture.

It added that a variety of events are scheduled during America Month, such as the premiere of the latest Ice Age movie "Ice Age 3: Dawn of the Dinosaurs, " Disney storytelling sessions, Johnson & Johnson's singing and dancing show, a U.S. education seminar, and a live graffiti demonstration.

America Month will climax on July 4 with a number of activities that will include a toddler's parade, cheerleading performance, Hawaiian hula dance show, hip-hop dancing, and a 233-second fireworks display, the AIT said.

As the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) Neihu Line will commence its operation soon, the AIT said it is strongly encouraging Taipei residents to take the MRT to the Jianan Road Station to participate in the America Month events and celebrate Independence Day.
The AIT serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC denies moving fourth round of talks with China forward

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has denied a report published Wednesday that said Taiwan wanted to hold the next round of talks with China earlier than scheduled to expedite the signing of an agreement on economic cooperation with Beijing.
"How could that be possible? " wondered MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng Wednesday.

He said the two sides have yet to hold a work meeting to pave the way for an official meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

"As the accords signed in the previous round of negotiations in April in Nanjing have yet to take effect, how could it be possible for the two sides to discuss the planned topics projected for the next round of negotiations or touch on the date of the talks now, " Fu added.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Ma Shao-chang said Wednesday that the only thing that is sure about the fourth round of talks with China is that they will be held in Taiwan, but he insisted he had not heard anything about any other details related to the meeting.
Taiwan and China have to date agreed to discuss two-way cooperation on farm produce quarantines, standard product certification and the avoidance of double taxation at the fourth round of talks.

The Taipei-based Commercial Times reported Wednesday that the talks might be held in late July or August rather than late in the year to expedite the signing of an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA).
The paper reported that Taiwan and China have been making arrangements for signing such an agreement.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said that if conditions allow, an ECFA could be clinched during the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations.

The Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries published a white paper Tuesday, calling for the early establishment of the planned ECFA to tackle the formation of a regional trade bloc between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.004 to close at NT$32.889.
A total of US$497 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.935 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.860.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop below 6,200 on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell below the 6,200 mark Wednesday to finish lower for the fourth consecutive day, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 24.90 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 6,195.91.

Despite a 107.46-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average overnight, the local bourse, buoyed by a strong showing from the banking and financial sector, opened high at 6,239.51. It later rose to 6,306.46 at one point and dropped to the day's low of 6,191.58.
A total of 3.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$99.11 billion (US$3.01 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks advancing the most at 2.4 percent. Construction shares gained 0.5 percent and textile issues rose 0.1 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent. Machinery and electronics shares and plastics and chemicals stocks dropped 1.0 percent each, foodstuff shares fell 0.9 percent, and cement issues shed 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,093 to 994, with 182 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.58 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU Hospital mission to leave on Myanmar aid mission

TEXT.P: A medical mission from National Cheng Kung University Hospital is set to depart from Taiwan Thursday for Myanmar on a medical aid mission to help residents in a village near the country's capital that is still recovering from a storm that inundated the Irrawaddy river delta in May 2008.

According to hospital authorities, the mission -- comprised of two doctors, four nurses and one pharmacist -- will be making its fourth trip to the village of Aung Zayar Min near the capital of Yangon to help speed up medical reconstruction there.

The mission will conduct a public health survey among the villagers, build a medical service station, improve public health education, and provide training to potential nursing and caregiving personnel during its eight-day stay, hospital officials said.
The Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society based in northeastern Taiwan is co- organizing the mission and has offered to build houses and public health facilities in the village, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hepatitis C patients tend to develop liver cancer: researcher

TEXT.P: People infected with hepatitis C have an approximately five times greater risk of developing liver cancer than those with hepatitis B, and have a 10 times risk of liver cancer if they also drink alcohol, Michael Ming-Chiao Lai, an Academia Sinica academician specializing in life sciences, said Wednesday.
He made the remarks in a keynote speech at the 12th Society of Chinese Bioscientists in America International Symposium held by Academia Sinica.

Lai, who is also president of National Cheng Kung University, said there are five types of hepatitis viruses -- A, B, C, D and E. The hepatitis viruses A and E can cause acute hepatitis, while the hepatitis B, C, and D viruses can cause chronic hepatitis.

Before a hepatitis B vaccine was developed, up to 90 percent of liver cancer was caused by hepatitis B. At present, as no vaccine is yet available against hepatitis C, half of the liver cancer cases in southern Taiwan are associated with hepatitis C, according to Lai.
There is an urgent need to develop hepatitis C vaccine as medications for hepatitis C treatment have been found ineffective for most patients and could cause side effects, Lai went on.

Patients with hepatitis B have 100 times higher risk of liver cancer than people who don't have hepatitis infection. Most people are infected with hepatitis C virus when they grow up and the duration of infection of the virus is normally shorter than that of people with hepatitis B virus, so under the circumstance, hepatitis C patients should have relatively low risk of liver cancer, Lai said.
However, if people who infected with hepatitis B and hepatitis C at the same time, hepatitis C patients have five times higher risk of liver cancer than hepatitis B patients, according to Lai.

The prevalence of hepatitis C virus infection in Taiwan is 2 percent, with the highest prevalence seen in a village in southern Taiwan, where 60 percent of the residents are infected with the virus, Lai noted.

Between 50 percent and 80 percent of those infected with hepatitis C have a tendency to develop chronic hepatitis, liver cirrhosis and carcinoma of the liver, Lai went on, adding that if hepatitis C patients drink alcohol or eat fatty food, their risk of developing liver cancer will be 10 times higher than that if they do not.

Lai suggested that hepatitis C patients refrain from drinking alcohol, eating fatty foods and taking uncertified medicines. He also advised them to undergo ultrasound examinations every four months for timely treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pavilion to open at Beijing summer travel expo
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 17 (CNA) 06/17/09 18:53:58 (By C.K. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Over 90 tourism operators from Taiwan will take part in the opening of a Taiwan pavilion Thursday at the Beijing International Travel Expo 2009 that will run through June 20, Taipei-based Travel Association of Chinese (TAC) Chairman Hsu Chin-jui announced Wednesday at a news conference in Beijing.

Hsu said Taiwan welcomes Chinese people wishing to visit and that the theme of the Taiwan pavilion at the Beijing tourism expo revolves around this point to allow visitors to get a feel for Taiwan's charm and vigor and the hospitality of its people.
A total of 33 travel agencies from around Taiwan, including Taipei City, Taipei County, Miaoli County, Nantou County and Kaohsiung City, have sent officials to participate in the fair.

Chin Hui-chu, Taipei County tourism bureau chief, and local government representatives from Nantou, Miaoli and Kaohsiung, introduced tourist spots and folk rituals from their areas at the news conference.

Speaking after the news conference, Chin encouraged Taiwan's tourism operators to offer high-end quality services to foreign tourists, as even larger numbers of Chinese tourists are expected to flock to Taiwan in the years to come.

Chin urged the government to honor President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promise that the current daily quota imposed on Chinese tourists should be increased from 3,000 in the first year to 5,000 in the second year and 7,000 in the third year.
Since July last year, a maximum 3,000 Chinese tourists have been permitted to enter Taiwan per day.

Meanwhile, Lai Jui-long, secretary-general of the Kaohsiung City tourism bureau, pushed carriers to open more cross-Taiwan Strait flights between Kaohsiung City and destinations in China to better serve southern Taiwan residents.
Lai gave his assurance that passenger loads will not be a problem, as the existing cross-strait flights from and to Kaohsiung are running at almost full capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: No sale, display of C-string underwear at rock festival

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government declared a ban Wednesday on the sale and display of C-string "invisible underwear" at an upcoming music festival to be held in the county, on the grounds of modesty.

Those who wear this type of underwear will also "not be welcomed" -- at least by county government officials -- at the Ho-Hai-Yan Rock Festival slated for July 10-12 at Fulong beach in the county's Gongliao township, according to officials of the county's Tourism and Travel Bureau.

Saying that the local government wants the annual music festival to be "healthy and simple, " the officials said anyone who breaks the ban on the skimpy smalls can be arrested by the police for "violating public modesty."
The ban was imposed in the wake of reports that a seller of the garment has recruited models to exhibit and sell the product at the venue of the popular festival, now in its 10th year.

The strapless panty is designed with a flexible internal frame that hugs and holds it to the body. The product is advertised as being perfect for wearing either under clothing or alone as beachwear for tanning, because it does not produce any panty lines or tan lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT announces site dedication for new office compound

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Tuesday that it will hold a site dedication ceremony June 22 for the AIT's new office compound in Neihu.

"AIT's new compound will be a spacious, state-of-the-art, environmentally friendly structure befitting the robust ties between the people of Taiwan and the people of the United States, " the AIT said in a press release.

AIT Director Stephen M. Young and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will both speak at the site dedication before an audience of individuals who have played a key role in advancing the many elements of Taiwan's relationship with the U.S., according to the press release.

The AIT said the US$170 million compound will include an office building of approximately 14,000 square meters, a parking structure and support structures, with all of AIT's Taipei offices, including the American Cultural Center, the Commercial Section, the Chinese Language and Area Studies School and the Agricultural Trade Office located for the first time at one single site.
The 6.5 hectare site is within walking distance of the planned Neihu stop of Taipei's Neihu MRT line, it added.

The compound will be constructed in three stages. The first phase -- rear access road construction -- started in March and will be completed in six to nine months, while the second phase will consist of site clearing and grading, and construction of perimeter security systems and the third phase will consist of construction of the new office building, the contract for which has not yet been awarded.
The AIT serves as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suicide mortality rate rose 3.3 percent in 2008: report

TEXT.P: The suicide mortality rate rose by 3.3 percent in 2008 from the previous year, according to a Department of Health (DOH) report released Wednesday, an increase that one psychiatrist said could be linked to the economic downturn.
Suicide was the ninth top cause of death in Taiwan last year, up one notch from the 2007, the DOH report on 2008 death rates in Taiwan showed.

Psychiatrist Chang Chia-ming from the DOH-run Suicide Prevention Center said that the highest suicide mortality rate was among elderly people suffering from chronic diseases, with the suicides rate in this group at 36.6 per 100,000 population in 2008.

He speculated that the major reason why people in this category commit suicide is because they do not wish to live a life racked by long-term illness. However, the reasons behind acts of suicide are often complicated, he added.

Meanwhile, he noted that the suicide rate in the 25-44 age group rose in 2008 by 8.1 percent -- the steepest increase registered among the different age categories. This could be related to the economic downturn as people in this age group are the main breadwinners in the family, he said.
However, "there's no evidence to prove that the suicides were related to economic factors, " he added, reiterating that the underlying reasons are often complex.

The DOH report showed that cancer was the number one cause of death in the country in 2008, followed by heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, pneumonia, diabetes, accidents, chronic respiratory disease, chronic liver disease and cirrhosis, suicide, nephritis, nephritic syndrome and nephrosis.
Notably, the accident fatality rate fell 6.4 percent from the previous year -- the largest drop among the listed causes of death in 2008.
The number of people who died in accidents last year was 7,077, representing a crude death rate of 30.8 per 100,000 population, the lowest in nearly 20 years, the DOH reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: Swimmers 'test waters' ahead of mass cross-strait swim

TEXT.P: Six swimmers from Taiwan and mainland China swam across a section of the Taiwan Strait Wednesday to test the waters in preparation for a historic mass swim across the Taiwan Strait slated for Aug. 15.

The eight swimmers, including two from Taiwan and four from China, took two hours and 20 minutes from Fujian Province's port city of Xiamen in southeastern China to Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen. This was a test swim prior to the first Kinmen-Xiamen mass crossing that will be attempted by 100 swimmers from Taiwan and China.
The eight swimmers kicked off an at 11: 40 a.m. from Xiamen's Yefengzhai Beach and came ashore on Shuangkou Beach on Hsiao Kinmen, a small islet west of Kinmen, completing a distance of 8.5 km.
A professional swimmer, Lin Jiayong from China, finished first in a time of 1: 29: 23.
Taiwanese swimmer Ni Sheng-liang, 46, completed the distance in 2: 10: 00 to become the first Taiwanese to legally swim from Xiamen to Kinmen in 60 years.
Ni said the swim was more complicated than he had anticipated, as the currents were more unpredictable than he had imagined.

The swimmers covered an actual distance of about 8 km from Yefengzhai Beach to Shuangkou Beach due to the pull of the ocean currents, although the direct distance between the two points is about 6 km.
The other four Chinese swimmers did not make it to Hsiao Kinmen and were ferried back to Xiamen by two rubber boats.
The historic mass swim is being sponsored by the Kinmen county government and the Xiamen city government.
In an attempt to minimize the risks involved in the venture, the sponsors decided to allow test swims June 17 and July 17 so that the swimmers could assess the conditions in the Taiwan Strait.
In addition, the Kinmen county government will remove the spear-like anti- landing barricades from the Shuangkou Beach 20 days before the Aug. 15 mass swim to allow the swimmers easier access.
The barricades, erected in the shallow waters of the beach during the Cold War era to block landing craft from China, will be replaced after the event, according to county government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong philanthropist visits Taiwan for children's club donation

TEXT.P: An 87-year old Hong Kong philanthropist arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to work out a plan to donate a children's club to Taiwan.

The billionaire real estate tycoon Yu Pang-lin, who has invested heavily in Shenzhen in China's Guangdong Province, said upon his arrival that he intends to donate a children's club to Taiwan and that the purpose of his visit is to check out the location of the club and the plan for establishing the center.
Yu declined to reveal the amount of his donation.
The proposed children's club will include medical facilities, a library, an amusement park and a hotel.
In addition, Yu said that he will take the opportunity to visit his old friends in Taiwan and stressed that he has a deep affection for Taiwan.

Asked about his previous promise to give all his assets to charity, leaving nothing to his offspring, Yu said: "If my sons are not as capable as I am, it would not help if I leave them money; while if they are more capable than me, why should I leave them money?"
During his three-day visit here, Yu will also meet President Ma Ying-jeou.

Yu is well-known for being the owner of famous kung fu actor Bruce Lee's last residence in Hong Kong before his death in 1973. Yu agreed this year to donate the house, which will be restored to its original state and turned into a museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alien magpie flock in southern Taiwan growing

TEXT.P: A flock of distinctive azure-winged magpies along the coast of Tainan City in southern Taiwan is growing larger, giving rise to concerns among local bird watchers that the alien species might threaten the survival of the common magpies in the city.
According to the Wild Bird Society of Tainan, the magpies with the blue wings and tail are believed to have been imported from China.
The members of the society said that some of the imported birds were probably released into the wild for religious reasons, or they escaped from cages, then settled in the coastal region.
The coastal flock, which is now comprised of 40-50 birds, began to gather more than five years ago, the society estimated.
Mature azure-winged magpies -- which belong to the crow family -- are 31-35 centimeters long, which means they are smaller than the common magpies frequently seen in the downtown areas of Tainan.

A member of the society Lee Yu-jen, who has been observing the alien magpies for five years, said they like to hop around. But Lee said that he has not been able to take any photos detailed enough to study the birds, nor has he ever found any of their nests.

The common magpie, which is black and white, was selected as the bird of Tainan in 2005. However, Lee said this is also an alien species from mainland China that was introduced into Taiwan during the Ching dynasty.
According to Tainan city statistics, its population of common magpies stands at around 1,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Irwin mangoes gain popularity in Japan: Tainan county chief

TEXT.P: Tainan-grown Irwin mangoes have successfully hit the Japanese market this year, as more than half of the 10,000 cases especially prepared for retail sales in Japan have been sold, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih said Wednesday.

"As of Tuesday, some 5,400 cases of Irwin mangoes were sold at Japanese department stores and through online shopping sites, " Su told a news conference while reporting on his six-day mango promotional tour to Japan.

Although Su took pride in seeing increased exports of the fruit to Japan in recent years, he, however, said the mangoes will have to be improved to do even better in the Japanese market in the future.
"To make greater breakthrough in the Japanese market, the next step will be developing more advanced techniques to plant the fruit and make it more competitive in Japan," Su said.

Some Japanese retailers were shown on local TV commenting that due to some of the Taiwan's mangoes having black spots on them, it made it difficult for them to sell the mangoes to some Japanese consumers known for not only wanting tasty, but perfect-looking fruits.
Keen to help promote the fruit to Japanese consumers, Su led a group of Tainan County officials to Tokyo, Osaka, and Ishikawa and Hokkaido prefectures from June 12-16.

Based on last year's success, which saw 2,000 cases of Irwin mangoes sold in two weeks in the Japanese market, Tainan County in southern Taiwan again launched a special promotional sale of the fruit targeting Japanese consumers this year in conjunction with a private Taiwan-Japan joint venture company.

The Irwin mangoes, labeled as "Midsummer's Ruby" exclusively for the quality- conscious Japanese market, are being sold in Hankyu Department Store and online shopping sites, such as www.rakuten.co.jp. -- Japan's largest of its kind.

An executive at Japan's Yamato Transport Co., Ltd., said last weekend that the 10,000 cases, which each contains three mangoes and sell for 2,800 yen (US$28) on the Internet and 6,300 yen at the department store, respectively, should be sold out by early July. Orders have begun pouring in since early June, he noted.
"We hope to present Taiwan's Irwin mangoes as a 'cheap and good' alternative to the more pricey mangoes produced in Japan's Miyazaki Prefecture," the Japanese executive noted.

The Tainan County government has promoted the fruit since 2004 and has made successful inroads into the Japanese, South Korean and Australian markets, which has helped push up the price of local mangoes, county officials said.
Japan is the No. 1 overseas market of Taiwan's agricultural and farm product exports, according to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

In 2008, Taiwan fruit shipments to Japan hit US$22.72 million, accounting for 54 percent of the country's total fresh fruit exports last year, COA statistics showed. Taiwan's 2008 mango exports to Japan were worth US$5.21 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung reports first case of Japanese encephalitis this year

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung reported Wednesday the first case of Japanese encephalitis infection this year, but said there were no signs of the virus spreading.

The city's Bureau of Health said in a statement that the patient was a male city resident who works in Kaohsiung County as a breeder of racing pigeons and other domestic birds, including chickens and ducks.
The man, who has not traveled overseas this year, developed symptoms such as a fever and headache on May 27, during the racing pigeon season, according to the bureau..
He is being treated at a local medical center, the bureau added.
Japanese encephalitis is caused by a mosquito-borne virus and is not transmissible between humans. Domestic pigs and wild birds are usually hosts to the virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan launches new life movement

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education launched a "Taiwan Has Taste" campaign Wednesday to inspire local people to lead a life that prizes moral values, work quality and fine taste.

President Ma Ying-jeou attended the campaign's inaugural ceremony at the Taipei Main Station, marking the first time that he has presided over the launch of a public education program since he assumed the presidency more than a year ago.
Addressing the ceremony, Ma said he hopes the campaign will become a new life movement to instill a new spirit and taste for morality and quality into the everyday lives of people.

"Challenges and tricks abound in our society. We need to value good character, ethical conduct, qualitative upgrades and tasteful lifestyles to maintain social order and sustain national development," Ma said.

Noting that he has upheld two principles -- "Engage people with sincerity and work with devotion and diligence" -- as his mottos throughout his life, Ma said he believes those values conform to the main goals of the "Taiwan Has Taste" campaign.

The campaign is also expected to complement the Executive Yuan's policy of accelerating development of six new emerging industries -- creative and culture industry, tourism, medical and health care, green energy, biotechnology and refined agriculture, Ma said. This development will help to upgrade the quality of life for local people, he added.
Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Education Cheng Jui-cheng said Taiwan is already a cultured society with good taste. Nevertheless, he said, there is still ample room for improvement.

"A spate of violence and drug abuse cases on school campuses and aimless killings involving adolescents indicate that there are still problems that need to be addressed with immediate and effective measures such as this campaign to cultivate a taste for good character and good work quality," Cheng added.

Celebrities from various fields, including Cloud Gate Dance Theatre founder and artistic director Lin Hwei-min, lyricist Fang Wen-shan, and Olympic taekwondo athlete Su Li-wen, and senior executives of major cultural foundations established by prominent business groups such as Quanta Computer Inc. attended the inaugural ceremony to throw their support behind the campaign.

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday, moving up 50.94 points at 6,246.85 on a turnover of NT$2.29 billion (US$69.63 million).
The weighted price index lost 24.90 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 6,195.91 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 18, or the 26th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The U.S. Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan province, is executed for sedition.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei- yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as the "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of the sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The opposition Kuomintang passes a party reform package that includes provisions for the popular election of its party chairman following a nationwide party membership verification and registration process.
2001: The ROC breaks off diplomatic relations with Macedonia after the Balkan state made its intention clear that it would establish formal ties with China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwanese companies see U.K. as springboard for growth: BTCO

TEXT.P: Asian companies, including those in Taiwan, continue to view the United Kingdom as a springboard for global growth, with foreign investment there rising despite the world economic downturn, the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) stated Thursday.
"Companies from Taiwan increasingly see the U.K. as an ideal hub for their international ambitions," BTCO Director David Campbell said in a press release.

"The U.K. continues to be a leading destination for foreign investment because companies going global recognize it has the best environment for business. It is a gateway to international connections including a huge market in Europe of 455 million consumers," he added.

According to the press release, companies from around the world invested in 1,744 foreign direct investment (FDI) projects during the 2008-2009 financial year to March, which was an 11 percent increase and growth for the fifth successive year.

It added that the record numbers have been achieved in a year when the latest United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) figures confirmed the U.K. to be ahead of most global competitors, attracting US$1.348 billion in foreign investment to take up a share of 8.9 percent of its stock market and trailing only behind the United States.
Campbell noted that Taiwanese investment in the U.K. has increased across a range of sectors such as information communication technology (ICT), healthcare, chemicals, and transportation.

ICT continued to be a strong sector for Taiwanese investors, including LCD screen manufacturer Hannstar, which set up its European sales and marketing office in Hemel Hempstead northwest of London, and IC design company Mediatek, which set up its R&D center in Cambridge, he stated.
There is increasing focus on the healthcare sector, with Caremed Supply setting up its European sales and marketing in the U.K. to work with the British National Health Service (NHS).
"We chose the U.K. because of the centralized NHS procurement system and the U.K. market size," Antony Liu, Chairman of Caremed Supply, said in the press release.

Moreover, Chang Chun Group has established its European headquarters in the U.K. and Yang Ming Marine has expanded its operations with an additional logistics center in Manchester to serve the U.K. market.
"The U.K.'s world-class creativity and innovation fused with its commitment to R&D are also major attractions," Campbell said.
The BTCO serves as the de facto British embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA launches anti-dengue fever drive ahead of World Games

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday that it has launched a one-month clean-up campaign to prevent any dengue fever outbreaks during the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung City this summer.

EPA Minister Shen Shu-hung said at the Executive Yuan that the drive will last until July 15, the day before the World Games open in the southern Taiwan city, to eliminate the chances of dengue fever illness among the athletes and tourists who will be in the country at that time.
The EPA decided to expand the clean-up program this year, in light of its success last year through the joint efforts of five city and county governments, according to Shen.
The minister said that 92 percent of the 218 villages and boroughs that participated in last year's campaign passed the subsequent environmental inspections.
This year, the EPA will adopt strict inspection standards and will mobilize more villages and boroughs to join the clean-up drive, Shen added.

According to EPA statistics, as of June 15 this year, 81 cases of dengue fever had been reported in Taiwan, which signaled an earlier start of the dengue fever season. The possibility of a dengue fever outbreak in Taiwan therefore cannot be ruled out, the EPA stated.
Shen warned that if property owners, managers or tenants fail to clean up their environs as stipulated, they could face fines of up to NT$6,000.
In related news, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu lambasted the Sports Affairs Council at a news conference Wednesday for slashing its budget for the World Games by NT$230 million.
The council had originally planned to allocate NT$845 million for the games, but the budget was cut to NT$614 million, according to Chen.

The city government had considered launching a fund raising drive to raise the budget difference, but that is not permissible under the regulations, therefore the city would have to cut spending instead, she said.

The NT$230 million that was cut from the budget was intended for World Games broadcast, a World Games exposition, rental of the Kaohsiung Arena, the hosting of an athletes night, and for cultural exchanges.

The city will stand on its own feet for the games, even though it does not feel good to be belittled in this way, Chen said. The city council, local citizens will stand behind the city government to make the games a success, she added.
The July 16-26 World Games are expected to attract 4,000 athletes from some 100 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial excerpts

TEXT.P: The following are excerpts from selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
United Daily News: On the corruption case of ex-first family

There are many fallacies in the argument presented by Chen Jui-ren -- the prosecutor who handled the corruption case involving former President Chen Shui- bian and his family -- in defense of his earlier decision not to list the former president's daughter, Chen Hsing-yu, as an accomplice in the case. Chen Hsing-yu was recently placed under investigation by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office on perjury charges, based on findings by the Special Investigation Division (SID) of the Supreme Prosecutors Office.

As a matter of fact, Chen Jui-ren's failure to properly deal with the alleged irregularities involving members of the former first family was probably what indirectly allowed them to continue their money-laundering activities overseas, even after the indictment of Chen Shui-bian's wife, Wu Shu-jen, in November 1996.
When criticizing the SID, Chen Jui-ren should probably first consider whether he was responsible for the loopholes in the case that are still open up to today.
Liberty Times: On Taiwan's investment in China

Since the inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou in May 2008, his administration has been leaning heavily toward China and has painted China as the world's most important market, giving the impression that there will be no tomorrow for Taiwanese businesses unless they enter the China market.

However, statistics compiled by the Straits Exchange Foundation show that since 1991, 102 Taiwanese businessmen have been killed in China, while more than 300 others have been reported missing. There have also been numerous reports of China-based Taiwanese businesses falling victim to embezzlement or saddled with bad debts.
To put it simply, the Chinese market is like a dark jungle. Taiwanese businesses must open their eyes to this reality in order to avoid falling into the abyss.
Apple Daily: on President Ma's China policy

In a recent magazine interview, President Ma Ying-jeou said he "does not rule out unification as an option" in the future development of relations between Taiwan and China. A few years ago, Ma also mentioned Taiwan independence as an option.
The words that he spoke before he came to power cannot be taken seriously, but those spoken after are from the bottom of his heart.

Over the past year, all of Ma's policies have been geared toward one end: moving closer to China. This is not the image of a normal country. We should be watchful of this trend and seek to deter its progress.
China Times: On Want Want China Times Group's planned legal action

The Want Want China Times Group has heard the criticisms of its intention to sue those who made unfounded speculations about its takeover of China Television Co. and CTiTV. We deeply regret that our ideals are repeatedly and grossly distorted.

As media outlets and academics continue to voice suspicions that there is Chinese capital in the Want Want Group and to doubt our reasons for purchasing the China Times Group, do we not have the right to rebut?

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry issues travel advisory for Iran

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued an orange travel advisory for Iran Thursday, suggesting that travelers postpone any visits to the country because of the mass street protests following last week's presidential election there.

"In light of the upheaval in Iran, the Foreign Ministry is also urging Taiwanese expatriates in Iran to stay vigilant and watch out for their own safety, " said Ali Yang, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
"The ministry is advising business travelers and other visitors to postpone their travel plans for Iran," he stated.

According to Yang, there are fewer than 10 Taiwanese studying in Iran and only five or six Taiwanese expatriates in the country, most of whom are married to Iranians. The ministry has made contact with them all, but they think that there is no need for them to leave the country as the protests are confined to Tehran, he said.
"I believe the unrest is only temporary and Iran will soon return to peace," he said.
In case of emergency, Taiwanese nationals can contact the MOFA's representative office in Dubai at 971-50-6453018, he added.

A yellow alert, the lowest on a three-color travel advisory scale, serves as a reminder for travelers to exercise caution. An orange travel alert advises travelers to postpone their trips, while a red alert warns travelers not to enter the area in question under any circumstances.
Meanwhile, according to Yang, oil supplies from Iran have not been affected by the unrest.
Iran is Taiwan's third largest oil supplier, after Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Iran amounts to US$4 billion per year.

Thousands of supporters of the reformist presidential candidate Mir-Hossein Mousavi took to the streets of Tehran for the fifth consecutive day Wednesday in protest against the disputed presidential election results.

According to the Iranian Interior Ministry, incumbent President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad won 62.63 percent of the vote in the June 12 presidential election, while his main rival Mousavi took 33.75 percent.

Demonstrators, who have either accused the government of massive vote fraud or the United States of interference in Iranian internal affairs, have had clashes with local police and dozens of people have reportedly been killed.
The Iranian Guardian Council has agreed on a recount of disputed ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Europe youth exchange program draws flood of applications

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that applications have been flooding in for a Europe-Taiwan youth summer program to promote interaction between young people of the two sides.

"So far, the Foreign Ministry has received many applications from European youth, which indicates that the financial crisis has not affected their interest in learning more about Taiwan," said Anne Hung, director-general of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, at a regular press briefing.
"The MOFA hopes that the program will help promote exchanges between young people in Europe and Taiwan and allow Europeans to learn more about our country," she added.

According to Hung, the exchange program is receiving great attention particularly in Austria and Hungary, and the Foreign Ministry is encouraging young people aged 18-40 to sign up before the 100 openings are filled.

The MOFA has commissioned the non-governmental China Youth Corps to organize two workshops from July 28-Aug. 10 and Aug. 18-31 in Taipei to give the participants a better understanding of Taiwan through interactions with local youth, she added.
While similar programs were held more than 10 years ago, Hung said the Foreign Ministry hopes that this time the program will help to lift Taiwan's profile in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung lychees hit Japanese market

TEXT.P: Dashu township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County has increased exports of its famous Jade Purse lychees to Japan this year, following a good crop over the past month, said the town's farmers association Thursday.

Dashu township has harvested about 18,000 metric tons of Jade Purse lychees over the past month, and some 30 metric tons of the fruit has been exported to Japan, six times the volume last year, association officials said.
Dashu growers were originally slated to provide 200 metric tons of the fresh fruit to Japan buyers, who offered to purchase it through the farmers association at NT$80-NT$90 (US$2.5) per kilogram.
But local farmers were only able to supply 30 metric tons, because it is difficult to produce the fruit in bulk over a short period, the farmers association officials explained.
Lychees for export to Japan must meet strict quarantine standards and must be labeled with a detailed production profile.
Lychees, mangoes and pineapples are popular summer fruit in Taiwan, and are mainly grown in the Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas in the south.

Japan is the No. 1 overseas market for Taiwan's agricultural and farm product exports. In 2008, Taiwan fruit shipments to Japan reached US$22.72 million, accounting for 54 percent of the country's total fresh fruit exports that year, according to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices drop in weak turnover

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell below the four-month moving average of 6,160 in shrinking turnover Thursday.
Finishing lower for the fifth consecutive day, the weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 51.38 points, or 0.82 percent, to close at 6,144.53.
The local bourse opened high at 6,246.85 and rose to 6,279.36 at one point before dropping to the day's low of 6,100.08.
A total of 3.69 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.92 billion (US$2.88 billion).
Among the eight major stock categories, only textiles gained ground, advancing 0.2 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent. Banking and financial shares dropped 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues fell 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks shed 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.4 percent, and construction shares fell 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,534 to 617, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.53 billion.

Shares of Taiwan's largest memory-chip maker Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. dropped by the daily maximum of 7 percent because its stocks will be downgraded to the full-cash delivery stock class Friday if it fails to secure approval for its plan to reset the conversion price of its ECBs from bondholders.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.015 to close at the day's high of NT$32.904.
A total of US$636 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.889 and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$32.924.

DOC.HEADLINE: Energy bills planned for next legislative session: official

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen has said that it is not appropriate to write the goal and timetable for cutting the country's greenhouse gas emissions into legislation before international consensus is reached on this issue.

Shen, who was speaking at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, was referring to adraft bill to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The bill has yet to pass the Legislative Yuan in the current session because legislators across party lines hope it will be discussed only after new standards for emissions are set at the United Nations Climate Change Conference slated for December in Copenhagen.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyng-ping had previously voiced similar views.
Environmental groups, however, have called for including the county's goal and timeframe of emission reduction into the draft bill.

In response to the group's demands, Shen said at the Cabinet meeting that emission reduction issues have been listed in the Executive Yuan's guidelines on sustainable energy and that it is not appropriate to write them into law before an international agreement is reached.
Doing so would mean Taiwan would have less flexibility in international negotiations on emissions control, Shen said.
As for a proposal by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to enact an energy tax bill, Shen agreed it should be given a higher priority.

Many European countries would take into account the overall imposition of carbon and energy taxes, as well as a cap on greenhouse gas emissions, while enacting relevant laws, Shen said. This approach can serve as a reference for Taiwan.

He further explained that if enterprises impose a high carbon tax for emitting high volumes of carbon dioxide emissions, that would influence their international competitiveness. Therefore, Shen said, in most European countries, a carbon tax is only part of a broad-based energy tax aimed at encouraging individuals to save energy, accounting for only 10 percent-20 percent of the total.
A carbon trading approach would be more effective in forcing major polluters to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, he added.

Shen also said the EPA hopes the Executive Yuan would soon submit the energy tax draft bill to the Legislative Yuan to allow it to be reviewed along with the greenhouse gas reduction draft act so that both can be passed in the next session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan smashes 'largest-ever' human smuggling ring

TEXT.P: Immigration authorities announced Thursday that they have smashed the largest- ever human smuggling ring in Taiwan's history, a case that involved over 50 Chinese children who were taken to the United States using fake documents obtained from Taiwanese parents and accompanied by a Taiwanese chaperone.

Members of the human trafficking gang swindled local children's ID documents from their parents and used them to apply for Republic of China passports which were later doctored with photos of the Chinese children, according to the Border Affairs Corps of the National Immigration Agency.

Ring members then used these forged passports to apply for U.S. visas. Once they got the visas in Taiwan, they took the fake passports to Hong Kong, where the fake passport holders, mainly underage children from China, would use them to travel to the United States, accompanied by one of several Taiwanese women hired by the gang to serve as a pseudo parent or guardian for the child to dupe U.S. immigration officials.
These Taiwanese women, aware or unaware of the scheme, were paid US$1,000 to US$1,500 in reward for each trip.
Under the fraudulent scheme, more than 50 Chinese children, all underage girls, have successfully entered the United States using the fake ROC passports, the corps said.
A total of 74 Taiwanese suspects allegedly involved in the smuggling operation have been handed over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for further investigation, according to the agency.
The corps said it tracked down the ring after analyzing clues from scores of cases which seemed irrelevant on the surface. It finally solved the case following months of investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy likely to shrink 3.46% in 2009: Academia Sinica

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) is likely to contract by 3.46 percent -- the worst in history -- in 2009, due to the prolonged recovery process of the global economy, the Academic Sinica forecasted Thursday.
The projection, however, is more optimistic than the official projection of -4.25 percent, released on May 21 by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
According to the Sinica's Institute of Economics, Taiwan is expected to gradually get out of the worst period for its economy later this year and move slowly toward recovery.

While government investment will be the key to Taiwan's economic recovery, there are uncertainties such as international commodity and oil prices, recovery in the global economy, Taiwan's economic ties with China, and the development of the influenza A(H1N1) pandemic, the institute said.
It predicted that in 2009, the real private consumption will likely post a 0.26 percent increase, reversing the negative growth of -0.3 percent recorded last year.
However, with businesses' demand for equipment expansion remaining weak, the contraction in real private-sector investment is expected to widen from -13.28 percent in 2008 to -23.97 percent in 2009.
The decline in exports of goods and services will deepen from -0.03 percent in 2008 to -13.97 percent in 2009, while the fall in imports will broaden from -3.98 percent in 2008 to -17.41 percent.

The slowing commodity demand will be reflected in the wholesale price index, which is expected to drop by 7.46 percent in 2009. The consumer price index, meanwhile, is likely to decline 0.19 percent, the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU, e-learning firm sign joint venture to teach Chinese online

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) and a local enterprise TutorABC signed a joint venture Thursday to tap into the global Chinese language learning market via the world's first real-time interactive online Mandarin learning platform.
NTU President Lee Si-chen signed a contract with TutorABC Chairman Yang Cheng- tah Thursday, committing to an expansion of the platform known as TutorMing.

The joint venture is aimed at meeting a growing demand for Chinese-language study and making inroads into the global Chinese-language market that is expected to be worth NT$2 trillion (US$62.5 billion) in the next five years, they said.

At signing ceremony, Lee said that in light of the fact that Chinese language learning has become a major trend of the 21st century and the shortage of Mandarin teachers will become more acute in the future, the NTU is collaborating with TutorABC to expand TutorMing.
TutorMing employs a type of voice recognition technology developed by NTU under the leadership of professor Lee Lin-shan.

"It is hoped that through the TutorMing online Chinese-learning program, Taiwan would be able to send Chinese-learning tools to every corner of the world where Chinese teachers are not available in person," Lee said.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Yang said TutorABC was the world's first technology consultancy enterprise to develop the online intelligent learning system Smart Enterprise Suites, and to provide real-time, interactive, tailored content with accurate efficacy tracing.
Yang said currently TutorABC provides a total of 40,000 hours of online English teaching sessions for some 80,000 students per week, with teachers from 56 cities in 29 countries.

He forecast a huge growth in demand for Chinese language classes, citing China's forecast that by 2010, about 100 million non-Chinese speaking people will be learning Mandarin. He also cited a U.S. estimate that by 2015, some 750,000 American middle school students will be learning Mandarin.
"Based on these estimates, the global business opportunities linked to Chinese learning and teaching are expected to top NT$2 trillion in the next five years," he said.
The global demand for Chinese teachers will grow to 500,000 in the next few years, five times the current number of 100,000, he predicted.
"TutorABC hopes to employ 100,000 Chinese teachers in the next few years, which would in turn generate NT$1 billion in business opportunities," he said.
He said the expansion of TutorMing will provide a golden opportunity for Taiwanese teachers who have been unemployed for the past few years due to over supply.

"Taiwanese teachers are generally better Mandarin teachers than those from China and other Chinese-speaking communities throughout the world because they have a global perspective, online and digital skills, and a lively teaching style," he said.

Sergey Redkin, a Russian working in Taiwan, said at the ceremony that he had had trouble with Mandarin tongue twisters even after years of Chinese-language study, but that has changed since he has been taking Chinese classes on TutorMing.

Janelle Harrington, a U.S. student who recently arrived in Taiwan, said her Mandarin has improved significantly since she began learning on TutorMing, which is accessible round-the-clock and has no location restrictions.
"Most of all, it's inexpensive at only US$15 per hour," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical storm forms in Pacific Ocean

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Thursday that it is closely monitoring a new tropical storm that formed at around 2 p.m. the same day in the Pacific Ocean.

The tropical storm, named Linfa, was located about 630 km southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi as of 4 p.m. Thursday, moving east-northeast at a slow pace of 8 km per hour, according to the CWB.
The meteorologists said it was still too early to speculate on whether Linfa will make a direct hit on Taiwan in the coming few days.

"If it moves a little north, then Taiwan's central and southern areas will experience torrential rain in the coming few days, but if it moves a little south, it might sweep through the Bashi Channel and spare Taiwan altogether," they forecast.
Packing maximum sustained winds of up to 64 kph, Linfa, this year's third tropical storm to form in the West Pacific region, has a radius of 100 km, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan GDP to turn positive in September: tycoon

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to return to positive in September in tandem with the United States, Morris Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), predicted Thursday.

The U.S. economy would experience its worst recession in the third quarter, and its GDP would turn positive in September, according to Chang, the chairman of the world's largest contract chipmaker, who also forecasted the global economy will begin to recover in 2010.

While giving his outlook for the semiconductor industry for the third quarter, Chang said that the road to recovery will not be straight and smooth, but could be a bumpy one. However, he maintained his optimistic forecast that Q3 will be better than Q2.

Touching on his reassumption of the post as TSMC CEO earlier in the month, Chang said that the company's CEO serves as a coordinator to connect with clients, investors and company personnel and his main task is to collaborate with company colleagues on meeting business demand. Describing himself as an extroverted CEO, Chang said he will strive to fulfill the task.

Talking about TSMC's future goals, Chang said the company will focus on improving its techniques, adding that despite its business turnover being lower than that of last year, the funds allocated for research and development this year were more than that of last year, and the amount of expenditures budgeted for this year was on par with last year.
TSMC will also upgrade its production capacity to meet client demand, including demand that comes in the form of rush orders, Chang said.
Moreover, the company will strengthen partnerships with clients in an attempt to create a win-win situation for both sides, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Astronomer announces century's longest total eclipse July 22

TEXT.P: A local astronomer said Thursday that July 22 will mark the century's longest and most spectacular total solar eclipse.

Sun Wei-hsin, a professor at National Taiwan University's (NTU's) Graduate Institute of Astrophysics, made the announcement at a news conference hosted by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC).

Noting that the United Nations has designated 2009 as the International Year of Astronomy, Sun said more than 140 countries around the world have been sponsoring activities to promote scientific and astronomical education during the year.
"One of the most fascinating activities this year will be observing the upcoming total solar eclipse, " Sun said, adding that people should not miss the opportunity to witness the event.

The solar eclipse will be total through a narrow corridor stretching from northern India, eastern Nepal, northern Bangladesh, Bhutan, the northern tip of Myanmar, central China and a narrow ribbon of the Pacific Ocean that includes the Marshall Islands and Kiribati, Sun said, adding that the eclipse will also be partially visible in Taiwan.
"This solar eclipse will be the longest total eclipse to occur in the 21st Century, " Sun went on.
According to Sun, total solar eclipses are rare and only 28 percent of the average 238 eclipses that occur each century are total eclipses.

"This means that a total solar eclipse appears once every one-and-a-half years, " Sun said, adding that it takes an average of 450 years for a total solar eclipse to be visible at the same location twice.

In Taiwan, the last total solar eclipse was seen around the northern port city of Keelung in 1941 and the next one is expected to be visible near the Hengchun peninsula in the south in 2070, Sun said.
"Local people will be able to see an 'almost total' annular partial eclipse July 22, " Sun said, adding that Taiwan people won't be able to see such a similar scene until 2046.

Pointing out that the ancient Chinese have used beautiful and poetic terms to describe the five stages of a total solar eclipse, Sun said many Chinese people are enthusiastically waiting for the arrival of the rare astronomical event.

In Taiwan, the NSC is collaborating with the Ministry of Education, Academia Sinica and the Council for Cultural Affairs to organize a series of outdoor activities this summer to inspire local interest in astronomy.
These activities will include a lights-down campaign that will be held June 21 in which local people will be encouraged to turn off lights and go outdoors to observe the skies.

In July, a series of astronomy education camps will be organized for youngsters from Taiwan and other Asia-Pacific countries. In addition, a science festival will take place Aug. 8 through mid-September to boost astronomical education.
In related news, prospective participants in an astronomy education program organized by NTU's Graduate Institute of Astrophysics can register online at http://star.phy.ntu.edu.tw/astronomy.php.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to do more to fight human trafficking: U.S. report

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made some progress in combating human trafficking over the past year, but should do much more, including extending labor protections to all categories of workers to prevent labor trafficking, according to the just-released 2009 U.S. Department of State's Trafficking in Persons Report.

The annual report placed Taiwan in Tier 2 ranking, which is for governments that are making significant efforts to meet the minimum standards for eliminating trafficking prescribed by the U.S. law that guides anti-human trafficking efforts - the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000.
Governments that fully comply are placed in Tier 1. Governments that do not fully comply with the minimum standards and are not making significant efforts to do so are placed in Tier 3.

"Taiwan authorities made noticeable progress during the reporting period by passing a new anti-trafficking law, bolstering law enforcement efforts, and approving a budget plan of US$14.8 million for victim protection measures," the report acknowledged.
Trafficked victims - including men, women and children - are usually brought to Taiwan for forced labor and commercial sexual exploitation, according to the report.

Most trafficking victims are workers from rural areas of Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines. They are employed through recruitment agencies and brokers to perform low-skilled work in Taiwan's construction, fishing, and manufacturing industries, or to work as domestic helpers.

"Many of these workers fall victim to labor trafficking by unscrupulous brokers and employers, who force workers to perform work outside the scope of their contract and often under exploitative conditions, " the report said, which is available online.

Some women and girls from China and Southeast Asian countries are trafficked to Taiwan through fraudulent marriages, deceptive employment offers, and illegal smuggling for sexual exploitation and forced labor, the report found.
It said many migrant workers are charged job placement and service fees up to the equivalent of US$14,000, some of which are unlawful.
The report added that this results in substantial debt for the workers that unscrupulous labor brokers or employers may use as a coercive tool to subject the workers to involuntary servitude.
"Many foreign workers remain vulnerable to trafficking because legal protections, oversight by authorities and enforcement efforts are currently inadequate, " said the report.

Taiwan's regulations currently allow employers to implement a system of "forced savings, " whereby employers deduct up to 30 percent of a foreign worker's monthly salary to be placed in a bank account in the worker's name, but inaccessible to the worker, the report said. This system has facilitated trafficking, it said.

The report cited NGOs saying that immigration, police and local law enforcement officials continue to view trafficking victims as runaways or criminals, resulting in some victims being penalized rather than assisted.

In addition to recommending that Taiwan extend labor protections to all categories of workers, the report also suggested that Taiwan implement its new comprehensive anti-trafficking law and effectively carry out its victim and witness protections so that victims are not penalized for acts committed as a direct result of being trafficked, which would encourage them to seek help.

It also suggested Taiwan increase police efforts to investigate trafficking crimes and to identify trafficking victims, and improve cooperation with governments of labor source countries on trafficking investigations.

Taiwan's National Immigration Agency (NIA), which did not have a direct response to the findings of the report, said Thursday that Taiwan has remained on Tier 2 in the annual report for three consecutive years. It said Japan and Singapore also received Tier 2 ranking.
The agency said Taiwan was placed on Tier 2 Watch List in 2006 and upgraded to Tier 2 the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK people support ROC rejoining U.N.

TEXT.P: Fifty-one percent of the respondents to a recent poll conducted in Hong Kong support the idea of the Republic of China rejoining the United Nations, according to the survey results released Thursday.
The survey was carried out among 1,002 people by the Public Opinion Programme at the University of Hong Kong a week earlier.

Asked whether they support the ROC rejoining the U.N., 51 percent said "yes, " up from the 14 percent in a similar survey three months ago, while the opposition rate was 32 percent, down by 16 percent from the previous poll.
However, the same survey shows that 75 percent of the respondents are against Taiwan independence, while the support rate was 16 percent.
Robert Ting-Yiu Chung, director of the Public Opinion Programme, said the Hong Kong support rate for the ROC rejoining the U.N. has reached a record high since August 1994.
"The net support rate now stands at 19 percentage points, probably because Taiwan was recently invited to join the World Health Assembly as an observer, " said Chung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever human smuggling ring smashed (Update-1)

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) announced Thursday that it has smashed a large-scale human trafficking ring involving suspects from Taiwan, Hong Kong, China and the United States.

The cross-border human smuggling gang is the largest ever uncovered in Taiwan in collaboration with the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, a spokesman for the NIA's Border Affairs Corps told a news conference.
Seventy-four Taiwanese suspects of the ring were turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for further investigation, the spokesman said.

According to the initial investigation, a Chinese man surnamed Wang was the mastermind of the ring, which helped Chinese women obtain passports of the Republic of China altered with their photos. The fake passports were then used to apply for valid U.S. visas so that the women could enter the United States using the forged passports.

A Taiwanese accomplice surnamed Yang was allegedly responsible for swindling local young girls' ID documents from their parents, mainly in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County. And a tour agency manager identified as Liao used the documents to apply for ROC passports and for U.S. visas, which were later doctored with photos of young Chinese women.

NIA officials said Liao was able to obtain genuine ROC passports and valid U.S. visas for Chinese women seeking to smuggle into the United States, as the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan does not require Taiwanese applicants younger than 14 years old to undergo an interview.

After Liao got the passports, someone else would take them to Hong Kong, where Taiwanese women hired by the gang would accompany these Chinese women to travel to the United States by serving as a pseudo companion.

More than 30 Taiwanese women, some of whom were college lecturers, former flight attendants and nurses, were employed to accompany the Chinese women, and were paid US$1,000 to US$1,500 in reward for each trip. Some of these Taiwanese women claimed to have no knowledge about the scheme.

Citing information provided by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, the corps said under the fraudulent scheme, more than 40 Chinese women have successfully entered the United States using the forged ROC passports.

Each of these Chinese women paid US$60,000 to US$70,000 to be smuggled to the United States, and the U.S. authorities strongly suspect that they might be illegally engaged in prostitution in the country, the corps said.

Meanwhile, Hualien County police authorities said they have launched an in-depth investigation into the case, because they suspect that personal data of young girls at some local aboriginal villages were illegally sold to criminal elements.
The indigenous girls' families said they were fooled into thinking the people who took their daughter's documents would help their family apply for government subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: President officiates at inauguration of major vaccine plant

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou officiated Thursday at the inauguration of a new vaccine facility in central Taiwan run by Adimmune Corp. that is capable of producing vaccines against the influenza A(H1N1) strain.

Addressing the inauguration, Ma said Taiwan is one of just 11 countries in the world capable of producing vaccine for swine flu and he added that it is important that Taiwan, as a member of the international community, can and will share the vaccine with other countries that need it in the face of the swine flu pandemic.

Immediately after its inauguration, Adimmune's new plant in Tantzu, Taichung County will ramp up its production to meet an order placed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) for 5 million doses of influenza A(H1N1) vaccine, Ma said.

He said that flu, although a common ailment, should never be taken lightly, pointing out that in 1918, 20 million people were killed in a Spanish flu pandemic, a figure equal to the World War 1 casualties of 10 nations.
He also gave the thumbs-up to Adimmune Corp. Chairman Chan Chi-hsien, who was elected chairman of the company only last year but streamlined its finances in a mere two months.

Soon after that, he said, Chan, a former DOH minister, then instigated planning for the new plant and solicited investment from the government to facilitate construction, making it possible for Taiwan to pitch in with the global production of A(H1N1) vaccine in a timely manner.

Ma noted that although the flu infections have been declared by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a level-six pandemic -- the highest level on the WHO scale -- the situation is much milder than previously anticipated thanks to concerted efforts by countries around the world and heightened vigilance against the disease.
He said that Taiwan, one of only 11 countries capable of producing A(H1N1) vaccine, is now among the countries that are most advanced in terms of biotechnological research and applications.
Adimmune Corp., the largest vaccine-producing company in Asia, has a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine produced at its Miaoli plant and Tantzu plant.
Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer, Adimmune Corp. has recently received seed viruses for production provided by Australia, Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen promised Chinese supplies of fresh water, electricity

TEXT.P: The visiting deputy director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office promised Kinmen County Council Speaker Hsieh Yi-chang Thursday that he will "proactively" see to it that Kinmen is supplied with fresh water and electricity from China.

Zheng Lizhong's remarks were in response to a proposal from Hsieh during a lunch meeting on Kinmen that China speed up plans for supplying fresh water and electricity to Taiwan's outlying island that is located nearer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper.

Hsieh said discussions have been held for years on plans to lay undersea pipelines so that fresh water from Fujian Province can be provided to Kinmen, but added that the discussions have never moved beyond the talking stage.

Zheng, who also serves as vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), arrived in Taiwan June 10 mainly to work out the agenda for a planned fifth forum between Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China, which will be held July 11-12 in Changsha, in Central China's Hunan Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animal abusers can be fined or jailed: COA

TEXT.P: Anyone caught abusing stray cats or dogs can be slapped with heavy fines or can be sentenced to a maximum one-year prison term, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday in response to a spate of reports of animal abuse in recent weeks. Hsu Kuei-sen, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, pointed out that the Animal Protection Act prohibits maltreatment or abuse of animals, with violators facing fines ranging between NT$100,000 (US$3,030) and NT$1 million or sentences of up to a year.

Anyone who spots cases involving animal abuse can report them to city or county animal protection authorities, Hsu said, adding that if a case is considered a danger to public security, it should be reported to the closest police station.

In the latest alleged animal abuse case, a pet dog raised by a 78-year-old woman in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County was shot dead by the military last weekend after the animal intruded onto a runway at the Chiayi air base.
The owner said she was not convinced her dog would have intruded into the off- limits area because it was a pet and not a stray.
The Chiayi county animal disease quarantine bureau said it had launched an investigation into the case and added that if air base staff randomly shot the animal, they will be fined.

An air force officer visited the dog's elderly owner a day earlier to apologize for the killing. According to the officer, pilots were conducting landing and takeoff training when the dog intruded onto the runway.

"As it was an emergency situation, a non-commissioned officer shot the dog, " the officer explained, adding that his colleague was doing so in line with air force standard operating procedures to ensure flight safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel sign pact on mutual customs services aid

TEXT.P: Israel's representative to Taiwan, Raphael Gamzou, signed an agreement with Taiwan Thursday on mutual assistance and cooperation in customs affairs designed to ensure trade security, convenience and efficiency.
It was the third agreement of its kind that Taiwan has reached with various trade partners following similar deals with the United States and the Philippines.
Taiwan and Israel began to negotiate the agreement in April and the Executive Yuan authorized Taiwan's representative office in Tel Aviv May 6 to sign the agreement.
Ting Kan-cheng, Taiwan's representative to Israel, signed the accord in the Israeli capital the following day.
Gamzou's signing completed the process of sealing the bilateral agreement.
Gamzou inked the pact in a ceremony held at the Ministry of Finance, with Vice Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ho and Doron Arbely, head of Israel's customs administration witnessing.

Addressing the ceremony, Gamzou said that although both Taiwan and Israel are small countries, they are high-tech superpowers. The newly signed agreement will further boost bilateral cooperation in technology and other fields, he added.
Finance Ministry officials said the two countries will hereafter strengthen cooperation in thwarting smuggling and upgrade customs inspection efficiency.
