DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung lychees hit Japanese market

TEXT.P: Dashu township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County has increased exports of its famous Jade Purse lychees to Japan this year, following a good crop over the past month, said the town's farmers association Thursday.

Dashu township has harvested about 18,000 metric tons of Jade Purse lychees over the past month, and some 30 metric tons of the fruit has been exported to Japan, six times the volume last year, association officials said.
Dashu growers were originally slated to provide 200 metric tons of the fresh fruit to Japan buyers, who offered to purchase it through the farmers association at NT$80-NT$90 (US$2.5) per kilogram.
But local farmers were only able to supply 30 metric tons, because it is difficult to produce the fruit in bulk over a short period, the farmers association officials explained.
Lychees for export to Japan must meet strict quarantine standards and must be labeled with a detailed production profile.
Lychees, mangoes and pineapples are popular summer fruit in Taiwan, and are mainly grown in the Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas in the south.

Japan is the No. 1 overseas market for Taiwan's agricultural and farm product exports. In 2008, Taiwan fruit shipments to Japan reached US$22.72 million, accounting for 54 percent of the country's total fresh fruit exports that year, according to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices drop in weak turnover

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell below the four-month moving average of 6,160 in shrinking turnover Thursday.
Finishing lower for the fifth consecutive day, the weighted index, the market's key barometer, lost 51.38 points, or 0.82 percent, to close at 6,144.53.
The local bourse opened high at 6,246.85 and rose to 6,279.36 at one point before dropping to the day's low of 6,100.08.
A total of 3.69 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.92 billion (US$2.88 billion).
Among the eight major stock categories, only textiles gained ground, advancing 0.2 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent. Banking and financial shares dropped 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues fell 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks shed 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.4 percent, and construction shares fell 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,534 to 617, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.53 billion.

Shares of Taiwan's largest memory-chip maker Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. dropped by the daily maximum of 7 percent because its stocks will be downgraded to the full-cash delivery stock class Friday if it fails to secure approval for its plan to reset the conversion price of its ECBs from bondholders.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.015 to close at the day's high of NT$32.904.
A total of US$636 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.889 and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$32.924.

DOC.HEADLINE: Energy bills planned for next legislative session: official

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen has said that it is not appropriate to write the goal and timetable for cutting the country's greenhouse gas emissions into legislation before international consensus is reached on this issue.

Shen, who was speaking at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, was referring to adraft bill to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The bill has yet to pass the Legislative Yuan in the current session because legislators across party lines hope it will be discussed only after new standards for emissions are set at the United Nations Climate Change Conference slated for December in Copenhagen.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyng-ping had previously voiced similar views.
Environmental groups, however, have called for including the county's goal and timeframe of emission reduction into the draft bill.

In response to the group's demands, Shen said at the Cabinet meeting that emission reduction issues have been listed in the Executive Yuan's guidelines on sustainable energy and that it is not appropriate to write them into law before an international agreement is reached.
Doing so would mean Taiwan would have less flexibility in international negotiations on emissions control, Shen said.
As for a proposal by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to enact an energy tax bill, Shen agreed it should be given a higher priority.

Many European countries would take into account the overall imposition of carbon and energy taxes, as well as a cap on greenhouse gas emissions, while enacting relevant laws, Shen said. This approach can serve as a reference for Taiwan.

He further explained that if enterprises impose a high carbon tax for emitting high volumes of carbon dioxide emissions, that would influence their international competitiveness. Therefore, Shen said, in most European countries, a carbon tax is only part of a broad-based energy tax aimed at encouraging individuals to save energy, accounting for only 10 percent-20 percent of the total.
A carbon trading approach would be more effective in forcing major polluters to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, he added.

Shen also said the EPA hopes the Executive Yuan would soon submit the energy tax draft bill to the Legislative Yuan to allow it to be reviewed along with the greenhouse gas reduction draft act so that both can be passed in the next session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan smashes 'largest-ever' human smuggling ring

TEXT.P: Immigration authorities announced Thursday that they have smashed the largest- ever human smuggling ring in Taiwan's history, a case that involved over 50 Chinese children who were taken to the United States using fake documents obtained from Taiwanese parents and accompanied by a Taiwanese chaperone.

Members of the human trafficking gang swindled local children's ID documents from their parents and used them to apply for Republic of China passports which were later doctored with photos of the Chinese children, according to the Border Affairs Corps of the National Immigration Agency.

Ring members then used these forged passports to apply for U.S. visas. Once they got the visas in Taiwan, they took the fake passports to Hong Kong, where the fake passport holders, mainly underage children from China, would use them to travel to the United States, accompanied by one of several Taiwanese women hired by the gang to serve as a pseudo parent or guardian for the child to dupe U.S. immigration officials.
These Taiwanese women, aware or unaware of the scheme, were paid US$1,000 to US$1,500 in reward for each trip.
Under the fraudulent scheme, more than 50 Chinese children, all underage girls, have successfully entered the United States using the fake ROC passports, the corps said.
A total of 74 Taiwanese suspects allegedly involved in the smuggling operation have been handed over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for further investigation, according to the agency.
The corps said it tracked down the ring after analyzing clues from scores of cases which seemed irrelevant on the surface. It finally solved the case following months of investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy likely to shrink 3.46% in 2009: Academia Sinica

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) is likely to contract by 3.46 percent -- the worst in history -- in 2009, due to the prolonged recovery process of the global economy, the Academic Sinica forecasted Thursday.
The projection, however, is more optimistic than the official projection of -4.25 percent, released on May 21 by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
According to the Sinica's Institute of Economics, Taiwan is expected to gradually get out of the worst period for its economy later this year and move slowly toward recovery.

While government investment will be the key to Taiwan's economic recovery, there are uncertainties such as international commodity and oil prices, recovery in the global economy, Taiwan's economic ties with China, and the development of the influenza A(H1N1) pandemic, the institute said.
It predicted that in 2009, the real private consumption will likely post a 0.26 percent increase, reversing the negative growth of -0.3 percent recorded last year.
However, with businesses' demand for equipment expansion remaining weak, the contraction in real private-sector investment is expected to widen from -13.28 percent in 2008 to -23.97 percent in 2009.
The decline in exports of goods and services will deepen from -0.03 percent in 2008 to -13.97 percent in 2009, while the fall in imports will broaden from -3.98 percent in 2008 to -17.41 percent.

The slowing commodity demand will be reflected in the wholesale price index, which is expected to drop by 7.46 percent in 2009. The consumer price index, meanwhile, is likely to decline 0.19 percent, the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU, e-learning firm sign joint venture to teach Chinese online

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) and a local enterprise TutorABC signed a joint venture Thursday to tap into the global Chinese language learning market via the world's first real-time interactive online Mandarin learning platform.
NTU President Lee Si-chen signed a contract with TutorABC Chairman Yang Cheng- tah Thursday, committing to an expansion of the platform known as TutorMing.

The joint venture is aimed at meeting a growing demand for Chinese-language study and making inroads into the global Chinese-language market that is expected to be worth NT$2 trillion (US$62.5 billion) in the next five years, they said.

At signing ceremony, Lee said that in light of the fact that Chinese language learning has become a major trend of the 21st century and the shortage of Mandarin teachers will become more acute in the future, the NTU is collaborating with TutorABC to expand TutorMing.
TutorMing employs a type of voice recognition technology developed by NTU under the leadership of professor Lee Lin-shan.

"It is hoped that through the TutorMing online Chinese-learning program, Taiwan would be able to send Chinese-learning tools to every corner of the world where Chinese teachers are not available in person," Lee said.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Yang said TutorABC was the world's first technology consultancy enterprise to develop the online intelligent learning system Smart Enterprise Suites, and to provide real-time, interactive, tailored content with accurate efficacy tracing.
Yang said currently TutorABC provides a total of 40,000 hours of online English teaching sessions for some 80,000 students per week, with teachers from 56 cities in 29 countries.

He forecast a huge growth in demand for Chinese language classes, citing China's forecast that by 2010, about 100 million non-Chinese speaking people will be learning Mandarin. He also cited a U.S. estimate that by 2015, some 750,000 American middle school students will be learning Mandarin.
"Based on these estimates, the global business opportunities linked to Chinese learning and teaching are expected to top NT$2 trillion in the next five years," he said.
The global demand for Chinese teachers will grow to 500,000 in the next few years, five times the current number of 100,000, he predicted.
"TutorABC hopes to employ 100,000 Chinese teachers in the next few years, which would in turn generate NT$1 billion in business opportunities," he said.
He said the expansion of TutorMing will provide a golden opportunity for Taiwanese teachers who have been unemployed for the past few years due to over supply.

"Taiwanese teachers are generally better Mandarin teachers than those from China and other Chinese-speaking communities throughout the world because they have a global perspective, online and digital skills, and a lively teaching style," he said.

Sergey Redkin, a Russian working in Taiwan, said at the ceremony that he had had trouble with Mandarin tongue twisters even after years of Chinese-language study, but that has changed since he has been taking Chinese classes on TutorMing.

Janelle Harrington, a U.S. student who recently arrived in Taiwan, said her Mandarin has improved significantly since she began learning on TutorMing, which is accessible round-the-clock and has no location restrictions.
"Most of all, it's inexpensive at only US$15 per hour," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical storm forms in Pacific Ocean

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Thursday that it is closely monitoring a new tropical storm that formed at around 2 p.m. the same day in the Pacific Ocean.

The tropical storm, named Linfa, was located about 630 km southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi as of 4 p.m. Thursday, moving east-northeast at a slow pace of 8 km per hour, according to the CWB.
The meteorologists said it was still too early to speculate on whether Linfa will make a direct hit on Taiwan in the coming few days.

"If it moves a little north, then Taiwan's central and southern areas will experience torrential rain in the coming few days, but if it moves a little south, it might sweep through the Bashi Channel and spare Taiwan altogether," they forecast.
Packing maximum sustained winds of up to 64 kph, Linfa, this year's third tropical storm to form in the West Pacific region, has a radius of 100 km, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan GDP to turn positive in September: tycoon

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to return to positive in September in tandem with the United States, Morris Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), predicted Thursday.

The U.S. economy would experience its worst recession in the third quarter, and its GDP would turn positive in September, according to Chang, the chairman of the world's largest contract chipmaker, who also forecasted the global economy will begin to recover in 2010.

While giving his outlook for the semiconductor industry for the third quarter, Chang said that the road to recovery will not be straight and smooth, but could be a bumpy one. However, he maintained his optimistic forecast that Q3 will be better than Q2.

Touching on his reassumption of the post as TSMC CEO earlier in the month, Chang said that the company's CEO serves as a coordinator to connect with clients, investors and company personnel and his main task is to collaborate with company colleagues on meeting business demand. Describing himself as an extroverted CEO, Chang said he will strive to fulfill the task.

Talking about TSMC's future goals, Chang said the company will focus on improving its techniques, adding that despite its business turnover being lower than that of last year, the funds allocated for research and development this year were more than that of last year, and the amount of expenditures budgeted for this year was on par with last year.
TSMC will also upgrade its production capacity to meet client demand, including demand that comes in the form of rush orders, Chang said.
Moreover, the company will strengthen partnerships with clients in an attempt to create a win-win situation for both sides, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Astronomer announces century's longest total eclipse July 22

TEXT.P: A local astronomer said Thursday that July 22 will mark the century's longest and most spectacular total solar eclipse.

Sun Wei-hsin, a professor at National Taiwan University's (NTU's) Graduate Institute of Astrophysics, made the announcement at a news conference hosted by the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC).

Noting that the United Nations has designated 2009 as the International Year of Astronomy, Sun said more than 140 countries around the world have been sponsoring activities to promote scientific and astronomical education during the year.
"One of the most fascinating activities this year will be observing the upcoming total solar eclipse, " Sun said, adding that people should not miss the opportunity to witness the event.

The solar eclipse will be total through a narrow corridor stretching from northern India, eastern Nepal, northern Bangladesh, Bhutan, the northern tip of Myanmar, central China and a narrow ribbon of the Pacific Ocean that includes the Marshall Islands and Kiribati, Sun said, adding that the eclipse will also be partially visible in Taiwan.
"This solar eclipse will be the longest total eclipse to occur in the 21st Century, " Sun went on.
According to Sun, total solar eclipses are rare and only 28 percent of the average 238 eclipses that occur each century are total eclipses.

"This means that a total solar eclipse appears once every one-and-a-half years, " Sun said, adding that it takes an average of 450 years for a total solar eclipse to be visible at the same location twice.

In Taiwan, the last total solar eclipse was seen around the northern port city of Keelung in 1941 and the next one is expected to be visible near the Hengchun peninsula in the south in 2070, Sun said.
"Local people will be able to see an 'almost total' annular partial eclipse July 22, " Sun said, adding that Taiwan people won't be able to see such a similar scene until 2046.

Pointing out that the ancient Chinese have used beautiful and poetic terms to describe the five stages of a total solar eclipse, Sun said many Chinese people are enthusiastically waiting for the arrival of the rare astronomical event.

In Taiwan, the NSC is collaborating with the Ministry of Education, Academia Sinica and the Council for Cultural Affairs to organize a series of outdoor activities this summer to inspire local interest in astronomy.
These activities will include a lights-down campaign that will be held June 21 in which local people will be encouraged to turn off lights and go outdoors to observe the skies.

In July, a series of astronomy education camps will be organized for youngsters from Taiwan and other Asia-Pacific countries. In addition, a science festival will take place Aug. 8 through mid-September to boost astronomical education.
In related news, prospective participants in an astronomy education program organized by NTU's Graduate Institute of Astrophysics can register online at http://star.phy.ntu.edu.tw/astronomy.php.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to do more to fight human trafficking: U.S. report

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made some progress in combating human trafficking over the past year, but should do much more, including extending labor protections to all categories of workers to prevent labor trafficking, according to the just-released 2009 U.S. Department of State's Trafficking in Persons Report.

The annual report placed Taiwan in Tier 2 ranking, which is for governments that are making significant efforts to meet the minimum standards for eliminating trafficking prescribed by the U.S. law that guides anti-human trafficking efforts - the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000.
Governments that fully comply are placed in Tier 1. Governments that do not fully comply with the minimum standards and are not making significant efforts to do so are placed in Tier 3.

"Taiwan authorities made noticeable progress during the reporting period by passing a new anti-trafficking law, bolstering law enforcement efforts, and approving a budget plan of US$14.8 million for victim protection measures," the report acknowledged.
Trafficked victims - including men, women and children - are usually brought to Taiwan for forced labor and commercial sexual exploitation, according to the report.

Most trafficking victims are workers from rural areas of Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines. They are employed through recruitment agencies and brokers to perform low-skilled work in Taiwan's construction, fishing, and manufacturing industries, or to work as domestic helpers.

"Many of these workers fall victim to labor trafficking by unscrupulous brokers and employers, who force workers to perform work outside the scope of their contract and often under exploitative conditions, " the report said, which is available online.

Some women and girls from China and Southeast Asian countries are trafficked to Taiwan through fraudulent marriages, deceptive employment offers, and illegal smuggling for sexual exploitation and forced labor, the report found.
It said many migrant workers are charged job placement and service fees up to the equivalent of US$14,000, some of which are unlawful.
The report added that this results in substantial debt for the workers that unscrupulous labor brokers or employers may use as a coercive tool to subject the workers to involuntary servitude.
"Many foreign workers remain vulnerable to trafficking because legal protections, oversight by authorities and enforcement efforts are currently inadequate, " said the report.

Taiwan's regulations currently allow employers to implement a system of "forced savings, " whereby employers deduct up to 30 percent of a foreign worker's monthly salary to be placed in a bank account in the worker's name, but inaccessible to the worker, the report said. This system has facilitated trafficking, it said.

The report cited NGOs saying that immigration, police and local law enforcement officials continue to view trafficking victims as runaways or criminals, resulting in some victims being penalized rather than assisted.

In addition to recommending that Taiwan extend labor protections to all categories of workers, the report also suggested that Taiwan implement its new comprehensive anti-trafficking law and effectively carry out its victim and witness protections so that victims are not penalized for acts committed as a direct result of being trafficked, which would encourage them to seek help.

It also suggested Taiwan increase police efforts to investigate trafficking crimes and to identify trafficking victims, and improve cooperation with governments of labor source countries on trafficking investigations.

Taiwan's National Immigration Agency (NIA), which did not have a direct response to the findings of the report, said Thursday that Taiwan has remained on Tier 2 in the annual report for three consecutive years. It said Japan and Singapore also received Tier 2 ranking.
The agency said Taiwan was placed on Tier 2 Watch List in 2006 and upgraded to Tier 2 the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK people support ROC rejoining U.N.

TEXT.P: Fifty-one percent of the respondents to a recent poll conducted in Hong Kong support the idea of the Republic of China rejoining the United Nations, according to the survey results released Thursday.
The survey was carried out among 1,002 people by the Public Opinion Programme at the University of Hong Kong a week earlier.

Asked whether they support the ROC rejoining the U.N., 51 percent said "yes, " up from the 14 percent in a similar survey three months ago, while the opposition rate was 32 percent, down by 16 percent from the previous poll.
However, the same survey shows that 75 percent of the respondents are against Taiwan independence, while the support rate was 16 percent.
Robert Ting-Yiu Chung, director of the Public Opinion Programme, said the Hong Kong support rate for the ROC rejoining the U.N. has reached a record high since August 1994.
"The net support rate now stands at 19 percentage points, probably because Taiwan was recently invited to join the World Health Assembly as an observer, " said Chung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever human smuggling ring smashed (Update-1)

DOC.HEADLINE: President officiates at inauguration of major vaccine plant

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou officiated Thursday at the inauguration of a new vaccine facility in central Taiwan run by Adimmune Corp. that is capable of producing vaccines against the influenza A(H1N1) strain.

Addressing the inauguration, Ma said Taiwan is one of just 11 countries in the world capable of producing vaccine for swine flu and he added that it is important that Taiwan, as a member of the international community, can and will share the vaccine with other countries that need it in the face of the swine flu pandemic.

Immediately after its inauguration, Adimmune's new plant in Tantzu, Taichung County will ramp up its production to meet an order placed by the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) for 5 million doses of influenza A(H1N1) vaccine, Ma said.

He said that flu, although a common ailment, should never be taken lightly, pointing out that in 1918, 20 million people were killed in a Spanish flu pandemic, a figure equal to the World War 1 casualties of 10 nations.
He also gave the thumbs-up to Adimmune Corp. Chairman Chan Chi-hsien, who was elected chairman of the company only last year but streamlined its finances in a mere two months.

Soon after that, he said, Chan, a former DOH minister, then instigated planning for the new plant and solicited investment from the government to facilitate construction, making it possible for Taiwan to pitch in with the global production of A(H1N1) vaccine in a timely manner.

Ma noted that although the flu infections have been declared by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a level-six pandemic -- the highest level on the WHO scale -- the situation is much milder than previously anticipated thanks to concerted efforts by countries around the world and heightened vigilance against the disease.
He said that Taiwan, one of only 11 countries capable of producing A(H1N1) vaccine, is now among the countries that are most advanced in terms of biotechnological research and applications.
Adimmune Corp., the largest vaccine-producing company in Asia, has a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine produced at its Miaoli plant and Tantzu plant.
Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer, Adimmune Corp. has recently received seed viruses for production provided by Australia, Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen promised Chinese supplies of fresh water, electricity

TEXT.P: The visiting deputy director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office promised Kinmen County Council Speaker Hsieh Yi-chang Thursday that he will "proactively" see to it that Kinmen is supplied with fresh water and electricity from China.

Zheng Lizhong's remarks were in response to a proposal from Hsieh during a lunch meeting on Kinmen that China speed up plans for supplying fresh water and electricity to Taiwan's outlying island that is located nearer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper.

Hsieh said discussions have been held for years on plans to lay undersea pipelines so that fresh water from Fujian Province can be provided to Kinmen, but added that the discussions have never moved beyond the talking stage.

Zheng, who also serves as vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), arrived in Taiwan June 10 mainly to work out the agenda for a planned fifth forum between Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China, which will be held July 11-12 in Changsha, in Central China's Hunan Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animal abusers can be fined or jailed: COA

TEXT.P: Anyone caught abusing stray cats or dogs can be slapped with heavy fines or can be sentenced to a maximum one-year prison term, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday in response to a spate of reports of animal abuse in recent weeks. Hsu Kuei-sen, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, pointed out that the Animal Protection Act prohibits maltreatment or abuse of animals, with violators facing fines ranging between NT$100,000 (US$3,030) and NT$1 million or sentences of up to a year.

Anyone who spots cases involving animal abuse can report them to city or county animal protection authorities, Hsu said, adding that if a case is considered a danger to public security, it should be reported to the closest police station.

In the latest alleged animal abuse case, a pet dog raised by a 78-year-old woman in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County was shot dead by the military last weekend after the animal intruded onto a runway at the Chiayi air base.
The owner said she was not convinced her dog would have intruded into the off- limits area because it was a pet and not a stray.
The Chiayi county animal disease quarantine bureau said it had launched an investigation into the case and added that if air base staff randomly shot the animal, they will be fined.

An air force officer visited the dog's elderly owner a day earlier to apologize for the killing. According to the officer, pilots were conducting landing and takeoff training when the dog intruded onto the runway.

"As it was an emergency situation, a non-commissioned officer shot the dog, " the officer explained, adding that his colleague was doing so in line with air force standard operating procedures to ensure flight safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel sign pact on mutual customs services aid

TEXT.P: Israel's representative to Taiwan, Raphael Gamzou, signed an agreement with Taiwan Thursday on mutual assistance and cooperation in customs affairs designed to ensure trade security, convenience and efficiency.
It was the third agreement of its kind that Taiwan has reached with various trade partners following similar deals with the United States and the Philippines.
Taiwan and Israel began to negotiate the agreement in April and the Executive Yuan authorized Taiwan's representative office in Tel Aviv May 6 to sign the agreement.
Ting Kan-cheng, Taiwan's representative to Israel, signed the accord in the Israeli capital the following day.
Gamzou's signing completed the process of sealing the bilateral agreement.
Gamzou inked the pact in a ceremony held at the Ministry of Finance, with Vice Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ho and Doron Arbely, head of Israel's customs administration witnessing.

Addressing the ceremony, Gamzou said that although both Taiwan and Israel are small countries, they are high-tech superpowers. The newly signed agreement will further boost bilateral cooperation in technology and other fields, he added.
Finance Ministry officials said the two countries will hereafter strengthen cooperation in thwarting smuggling and upgrade customs inspection efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical storm expected to affect Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecast Friday that the outer rim of tropical storm Linfa is expected to affect Taiwan from Saturday.
The storm was located about 600 km southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi as of 8 a.m. that day, in an almost stationary pattern, CWB meteorologists said.
The weathermen forecast that it will speed up from Saturday and move in an east- northeasterly direction toward Taiwan.
Taiwan proper, particularly the central and southern areas, will experience sporadic or torrential rain over the next several days, they predicted.
Packing maximum sustained winds of up to 64 kph, Linfa, this year's third tropical storm to form in the West Pacific region, has a radius of 100 km, according to the CWB.

Meanwhile, hot weather was still persisting, with temperatures expected to reach 33 degrees Celsius in the north and 32 degrees in other parts of the island Friday, while some areas might experience downpours, the CWB warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 19, or the 27th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.
2001: Formosa Platics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching says that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan trains Afghan nurses

TEXT.P: A group of Afghan nurses attending a nursing training program in Taiwan said recently that they will become much more skilled and able to provide better care for patients in their country by learning from Taiwan's advanced nursing skills, standardized systems and modern facilities.
Hossin Dad, Hakima Sadat, Abdul Amid -- three of the 10 nurses who are being trained in Taipei's Tri-Service General Hospital, made the remarks in an interview with CNA.
"We hope that by coming to Taiwan, we can gain more knowledge, skills and experience and apply what we learn here to help our people," said Hossin, a pediatric nurse and the group's leader.
Despite the steady deterioration of Afghanistan's medical infrastructure, the nurses believe their pioneering mission to Taiwan is of great importance for the country.

"We are being trained for the future, " Hossin said. "Although we don't have modern equipment or standardized nursing administration at the moment, we are readying ourselves for a time when these facilities will be available," he added.

The training program was initiated by Sima Samar, founder of Afghanistan's non- profit Shuhada Organization, which operates clinics and hospitals in Afghanistan and Pakistan dedicated to the provision of health care to Afghan women and girls.

After winning the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy's (TFD's) Asia Democracy and Human Rights Award last December, Samar wrote to the NGO Affairs Committee under Taiwan's Foreign Ministry and expressed hope that the country's non- government organizations can provide help to improve Afghanistan's medical environment.

The three-month nurse training program -- the first of its kind -- was then launched by the Taiwan Nurses Association in collaboration with the Foreign Ministry, the Cabinet-level Department of Health and the government-funded TFD.

The nurses arrived in Taiwan June 5 and started their clinical training at the Tri-Service General hospital June 10, learning about maternal and child health, wound care, emergency medical treatment, community health care and nursing administration.

Speaking about the poor medical situation in Afghanistan, pediatric nurse Abdul said his hospital does not have enough beds, nurses, doctors, modern equipment or a standard system for patient-care and that they sometimes even have to put four children in one bed.
"I hope the Taiwanese government can help our country by allowing more doctors and nurses to receive training here," Abdul said.
"The program is a pioneering start for bilateral medical cooperation," he added.

Hakima, who works as a midwife and nurse in obstetrics and gynecology, said that over the past week, the Tri-Service General Hospital has offered a lot of different training and courses according to their specific fields and that she felt she gained a lot of additional knowledge about patient-care.

Weng Min-hsueh, a supervisor of the hospital's Department of Nursing said the hospital has not only tailored training courses in various medical fields such as surgery, anesthesiology and pediatrics specifically for the Afghan nurses, but is also teaching them how to use the Internet and computers to do work- related research.
They will also benefit from the hospital's resources for treating the war injuries common in Afghanistan as a result of the decades of conflict there, she added.
Afghanistan has suffered continuous civil war, in addition to foreign intervention, since the 1970s, and Hossin, Abdul and Hakima all have their own stories about life in the war-torn country.
Abdul, who comes from Bamyan Province in central Afghanistan, said that the Taleban regime destroyed his hometown and that he lost everything, including his cousin, during the conflict.
However, he said he has not told his five children about his tragic past because he does not want them to carry the burden of hatred and hopes that Afghanistan will achieve peace step-by-step.

Speaking about their impressions of Taiwan, the three nurses said with one voice that before coming to the country, they had no idea what Taiwan is like, apart from its geographic location on the map and seeing the landmark Taipei 101 building on television.
After spending one week in Taipei, they were amazed at how advanced and modern the city is and have taken time out of their busy training program to look around and see the sights.

Having visited places such as Taipei 101, Kuantu Temple, Taipei City Zoo, the Shihlin night market and the Grand Hotel, Hakima said she was particularly impressed by the scale of a supermarket they visited, pointing out that they do not have similar things in her hometown.
Hossin said he was deeply touched by the hospitality of the Taiwanese people, who have treated him like a true friend despite the thousands of miles between Taiwan and Afghanistan.
"We will bring back to our country not only medical skills and experience, but also many beautiful pictures and precious memories," Abdul said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Liberty Times: On the opposition's drive for ECFA referendum

On the issue of holding a referendum on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, all the officials in President Ma Ying- jeou's administration say that "it has nothing to do with sovereignty or politics and there is no need for a referendum." We want to tell President Ma: you are wrong, terribly wrong.

Ma has reiterated on many occasions that "Taiwan's future should be decided by Taiwan's 23 million people, " but he is now attempting to sign an ECFA with China based on the "one China" framework, without the consent of the Taiwanese people. Isn't this against the international human rights covenants that he signed recently?

Therefore, in promoting a referendum on ECFA, the opposition must break through the shackles of the Referendum Act and make the referendum a "new civic movement, " in order to safeguard the well-being of the Taiwanese people and offer Ma a lesson on "popular sovereignty."
Apple Daily: On organ donation
A 48-year-old man has donated his kidney and part of his liver to his wife over the last seven years.
At a time when the divorce rate is higher than the marriage rate, it is rare for any husbands and wives to help and support each other so much so that they would sacrifice their organs.

Those who live in impoverished countries and are forced to sell their organs for a living deserve our sympathy. And those who sign a donor card to indicate their wish to donate their organs after death are admirable. It is even more rare and commendable for those who donate parts of their organs to others in need while they are alive, without asking for reward.
China Times: On the reasons for dropping legal action

As the largest shareholder of the China Times Group, Want Want Group Chairman Tsai Eng-meng has the right to seek justice for the humiliation he suffered as a result of recent defamation (speculation that the Want Want Group is backed by China) . Tsai can choose to exercise this right but he can also choose not to.

It was his choice to enter the media sector and shoulder the social responsibility. If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. Sometimes, making the decision not to uphold one's rights is also a kind of social responsibility.
United Daily News: On Taiwan's economic development

A recent decision by MSCI Inc. to place Taiwan's markets under review for a possible upgrade to "developed" status has brought surprising joy to many people. At the same time, it is sad that Taiwan is the last of Asia's four little dragons to be included on the list.

When Taiwan was wasting its energy on politics over the past 10 years, South Korea quickly passed Taiwan and many developing countries were catching up. In these 10 years, Taiwan's global ranking in terms of good exports dropped from 14th to 18th, while its ranking for service exports declined from 18th to 28th.
When we took the plunge into politics, we brought tremendous disaster to our economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games highlighted at Olympic Museum in Lausanne
DOC.DATELINE: Lausanne, Switzerland, June 18 (CNA) 06/19/09 15:21:17 (By Y.C. Jou and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Five athletes who will participate in the World Games 2009 Kaohsiung promoted the games Thursday at the Olympic Museum in Lausanne, Switzerland.
The publicity event, touted as the most vigorous campaign during a one- and-a-half month promotion of the games in the Olympic capital, was held by the International World Games Association.

IWGA President Ron Froehlich and Kaohsiung Organizing Committee Managing Director Liu Shyh-fang presided over the event to familiarize museum visitors with the games, which are expected to bring together 4,500 athletes from 91 countries.

One of the event's highlights was a performance by the Swiss brother-sister team Jade and Maurizio Mandorino -- the champions in several acrobatic rock and roll dance competitions -- and three other pairs of dancers, who dazzled museum visitors with spectacular somersaults.

In addition, French trio Fred Fugen, Vincent Reffet and Cathy Bouette (FRA) -- winners of the World Freefly Parachuting Championships and the World Games -- thrilled the audience with video clips of their high-flying disciplines.
The eighth World Games will take place July 16-26 in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

Froehlich said it will be "a good opportunity for Taiwan to raise its international visibility, " adding that the IWGA has been holding an exhibition showcasing videos and photos of the World Games at the Olympic Museum that will last until the close of the games.

Under the patronage of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), the IWGA holds promotional activities at the museum during the World Games, an international multi-sport event held every fourth year under the auspices of the IWGA, Froehlich added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Variables exist in swine flu vaccine production: Adimmune

TEXT.P: The price of a planned domestically developed vaccine against the influenza A(H1N1) virus, better known as swine flu, will be competitive compared to imported vaccines, but variables still exist in the development process, Adimmune Corp. said Thursday.

While inaugurating its new plant in Taichung County, central Taiwan, the management of Adimmune Corp. -- the only company in Taiwan qualified to mass produce the A(H1N1) vaccine -- said the price of the domestically developed vaccine could be controlled to remain as low US$10 per dose, compared to 10 euros or US$15-US$20 per dose for counterparts quoted on the international pharmaceuticals market.

Adimmune has received vials of the virus strain for vaccine production from four World Health Organization (WHO) -authorized labs in Australia, Britain and the United States but has yet to decide which strain to use for domestic development, said Ignatius Wei, deputy CEO and president of Adimmune.
Adimmune will produce the vaccine based on chicken embryos, said Chang Chin- chuan, vice president of the company.

A total of 8 million chicken eggs meeting a specific set of requirements that were sourced domestically since last year will be used to produce the vaccine, Chang said, adding that some 10 million doses are expected to be produced between July and September this year.
The company is planning to place orders for additional chicken eggs for medical use from abroad, at a unit price of NT$18-NT$20, he added.

"At issue is the fact that Adimmune has not yet conducted animal or human trials on the A(H1N1) vaccine and nobody in the world knows so far whether one dose is enough to contain the infection or allow the patient to produce enough antibodies," he went on.
"If it requires two doses to make the vaccination effective, Adimmune will be forced to ramp up production to meet the orders placed by the Department of Health," he added.
According to DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan, the Centers for Disease Control will authorize an open bid at the end of June for Taiwan's purchases of 5 million doses of the vaccine from overseas.
Nevertheless, he predicted that global demand will exceed supply as the vaccine is in high demand worldwide since swine flu has been declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO).
Taiwan is currently one of only 11 countries capable of producing A(H1N1) vaccine.
Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer and the largest vaccine-producing company in Asia, has a maximum annual capacity of 30 million doses of vaccine.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor to visit China to promote trade

TEXT.P: Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu is scheduled to fly to Beijing on June 26 to help promote agricultural products from Taiwan in northern China.
Hu said Friday that he will be accompanying a trade delegation from neighboring Changhua County to jointly push agricultural products from central Taiwan.

When asked whether he will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his visit in Beijing, Hu, who served as foreign minister and head of the Government Information Office in the 1990s, said no such arrangment has been made given his "low status."

After the Beijing visit, Hu will proceed to China's northeastern province of Jilin with a group of property developers and real estate brokers from Taichung to explore the real estate market in that part of the country.
The Taichung developers are expected to meet their Jilin counterparts for talks on potential joint ventures and bilateral cooperation in the trade, cultural and construction fields, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung bartender to serve as World Games flag-bearer: city official

TEXT.P: The flag-bearer for the World Games opening ceremony will be a bartender from Kaohsiung, Kaohsiung City Culture Bureau Director-General Shih Jhe said Friday, although he declined to disclose the name of the person selected.
Shih revealed this at a news conference to promote the 15th Golden Cup Cocktail Competition slated to open Saturday in the southern port city.
The two-day competition, organized by the bureau and the Bartenders Association of Taiwan, will take place at the Pier-2 Art Center.

To promote the games during the news conference, the winners of various world bartending competitions dressed in creative costumes demonstrated the sports of rock-climbing, tug-of-war, skating and martial arts.

This year's Golden Cup Cocktail Competition has drawn the largest ever number of contestants, with 600 competing on the first day, according to Kuo Chao-kun, president of the International Bartender Association's Far East region.
The competition is divided into the categories of senior high school, college and creative teams, each of which will compete in traditional and flair bartending contests, said Kuo.

Since Taiwan began to host the Golden Cup competition in 2007, the World Games have been a promotional focus of the competition and this year, the teams in the creative category are required to create their cocktails surrounding the theme of the games, which will take place July 16-26 in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aims to boost wind power capacity to 980,000 kilowatts by 2010

TEXT.P: Taiwan's installed wind power capacity is expected to increase to 980,000 kilowatts by 2010, under a new government policy to develop green energy, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.
The capacity will continue to rise over the next 15 years, to reach 1.48 million kilowatts by 2015 and 3 million kilowatts by 2025, the CEPD said.
In 2008, installed wind power capacity in Taiwan reached 358,000 kilowatts, making the country the world's 23rd largest producer of wind power, according to the CEPD.
The council noted that wind power is one of the most important types of renewable energy and that its development is encouraged by many countries around the world.

The International Energy Agency (IEA) has predicted that the world's total power generation capacity will jump from 18.9 trillion kilowatt-hour (kwh) in 2006 to 25 trillion kwh by 2015, with the annual growth rate registering 3.1 percent.

The total renewable energy generation capacity, meanwhile, is likely to increase at an annual rate of 4.1 percent, rising from 3.47 trillion kwh in 2006 to 4.97 trillion kwh in 2015, according to the IEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.026 to close at NT$32.878.
A total of US$599 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.005 and fluctuated between NT$32.850 and NT$33.010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rise as turnover continues to fall

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 86.62 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 6,231.15.
Rebounding after five consecutive losing sessions, the local bourse opened at 6,187.97 and fluctuated between 6,231.88 and 6,151.51.

A total of 3.20 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$82.97 billion (US$2.52 billion), the lowest volume since the Taiex began retreating from 7,000-point territory at the beginning of this month.

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 4.5 percent. Construction stocks rose 3.4 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 3.2 percent, cement shares advanced 2.3 percent, banking and financial shares advanced 1.7 percent, foodstuff issues as well as plastics and chemicals shares rose 1.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were up 1.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,502 to 635, with 128 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$850 million in shares.
The market was buoyed by a strong showing in asset shares, with Taiwan Fertilizer Co., Far Eastern Textile Ltd., and Shihlin Paper Corp. all rising by the maximum daily limit of 7 percent.
The Taiex had fallen below the quarterly moving average of 6,160 Thursday.

Alex Huang, assistant vice president of Mega Securities Co., said that with the Taiex retreating nearly 1,000 points since early June and turnover shrinking rapidly, the Taiex was nearing bottom, and he predicted that the market would offer resistance at around the 6,000-point level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Workers entitled to paid 'typhoon days': CLA

TEXT.P: Workers in Taiwan now are eligible to paid "typhoon breaks" whenever local governments declare schools and government office closed, the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday.
In the event of a typhoon, flood or strong earthquake, office and factory workers could take the day off with pay, once the local governments close schools and government offices, the CLA announced.
If employees are asked to work on "typhoon days, " they should be paid overtime and given transportation and other allowances, in addition to their daily wages, CLA officials said.
However, workers should be allowed to stay at home on government declared typhoon days, as they could be injured while traveling to and from work, the officials added.

Generally, employees of private companies are usually required to work on officially declared typhoon days, once they cannot produce evidence to prove that their personal safety would be jeopardized on their way to and from work.
According to a survey conducted by the 1111 Job Bank in August 2008, closure for one day due to a typhoon could lead to an average loss of NT$593,100 (US$18,500) for private enterprises.

However, the online survey on typhoon breaks conducted among private enterprises showed that 80.65 percent of the respondent companies said they usually adhere to the government's announcements for closure during typhoons, while 19.35 percent said they do not.

Among the companies that said they did not follow the government's lead on typhoon days, 10.67 percent said they did their own evaluation of the severity of the storm before deciding whether or not to give their employees a day off, and 8.68 percent said some of their staff were given the day off while others are expected to work, depending on their responsibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changsha-Taipei charter flights to be increased in July

TEXT.P: Direct charter flight service between Taiwan and Hunan capital Changsha will be expanded from the current one flight per week to eight flights per week in July, an official from China's Hunan province said Friday in Taipei.

Hunan province's Vice Governor Gan Lin, in Taiwan to promote travel exchanges, said the decision was made after planning for a cross-Taiwan Strait forum on economic, trading and cultural issues between Taiwan's Kuomintang and China's Communist Party was completed.
The annual forum, set to take place in Changsha on July 11-12, is the fifth of its kind.
Taipei-Changsha flight services were launched Jan. 15, with China's Xiamen Airlines operating one flight per week.

In July, the carrier will add one more flight on the route while Guangzhou-based China Southern Airlines, and Taiwan's China Airlines and TransAsia Airways will all offer two flights per week between the destinations, Gan said.
Among the main attractions in Hunan province is its natural forest park, Zhangjiajie, listed as one of the world's natural legacies.
According to statistics from Hunan provincial travel authorities, the number of Taiwanese visitors to the southern China province reached 164,000 in 2008, 11.3 percent more than a year earlier.
In the first five months of 2009, 86,000 Taiwanese visited Hunan, 7.7 percent higher compared with the same period a year ago, statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of draft-age men up 7.81 percent

TEXT.P: The number of men of draft age totals 174,772 this year, up 7.81 percent from 2008, according to a report released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior.

The figure saw five straight years of decline from 2001 to 2005 owing to the drop in Taiwan's birth rate. After a slight growth in 2006 and an abrupt rise in 2007, a 10.71 percent plunge was recorded in 2008, the MOI said.
Of all men reaching draft age this year, 141,581, or 81 percent cannot accept conscription. The most common reason -- given by 93.8 percent of them -- is that they are still studying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more confirmed swine flu cases reported

TEXT.P: The Central Epidemics Command Center reported Friday two more cases of imported swine flu, officially known as influenza A(H1N1), raising the total number of confirmed cases to 60.

The center said the patients are two female students, 14 and 21 years old, who returned home from California. One of them developed swine flu symptoms after her return to Taiwan, while the other was found to have a fever upon arrival at the Taiwan airport.
There were no signs of swine flu symptoms among members of the students' families, the center said.
Meanwhile, one of the two indigenous cases of swine flu in Taiwan has not yet fully recovered, the center added.

Although community outbreaks of swine flu were reported in Hong Kong and Thailand, Taiwan has no plan to revise its pandemic alert level or to upgrade its yellow travel advisory for the two countries, the center said.
The World Health Organization on June 11 raised its global swine flu alert to level 6, which is the highest on the scale.

Mainland Affairs Council spokesman Liu Teh-shun reminded people traveling to or transiting in Hong Kong to pay attention to their personal hygiene, adding that the council's Hong Kong office and the Taiwan Department of Health will keep a close watch on swine flu developments in Hong Kong.

Effective Wednesday, Hong Kong health authorities confirmed 13 imported and 40 locally contracted swine flu cases, bringing to nearly 200 the total number of recorded infections in the Chinese special administrative region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to host first NBA game

TEXT.P: Taiwan will host a National Basketball Association (NBA) game for the first time when the Denver Nuggets and Indiana Pacers play an exhibition game at Taipei Arena Oct. 8, a breakthrough for a country in which the NBA has a devoted following.

NBA China CEO Tim Chen, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Sports Affairs Council Minister Tai Hsia-ling and Chinese Taipei Basketball Association Chairman Wang Jen-tar were on hand when the announcement was made, with Chen describing the game as the "best gift" for the long-term support of Taiwanese NBA fans.

"Oct. 8 will become a historic day for the NBA and millions of local fans in Taiwan. We are honored to present two of the best NBA teams to Taiwanese fans, who are full of passion for the game," Chen said.

Taipei will become the 8th Asian city to host an NBA exhibition or regular season game. Tokyo, Yokohoma and Saitama hosted six regular season two-game series between 1990 and 2003, while exhibitions have been held in recent years in Beijing, Guangzhou, Macau, and Shanghai.
Tai said 2009 was a year of sports for Taiwan, as the NBA exhibition game joins the World Games scheduled to be held in Kaohsiung in July and the Deaflympics in Taipei in September as marquee events.
Hau said Taipei was honored to be chosen to host an NBA game.
"The Taipei City government will use all administrative resources to make the game a great success," the Taipei mayor said.

According to the organizers, a series of NBA-related activities, including the NBA Cares program that promotes social responsibility and community charity, will be held before the game between the Nuggets and Pacers is contested in the 12,874-seat Taipei Arena.

Led by two-time NBA All-Star Carmelo Anthony and 2004 NBA Finals MVP Chauncey Billups, the Nuggets provided a strong challenge to the Los Angeles Lakers before being ousted by the eventual NBA champion in the 2009 Western Conference Championship.

The rebuilding Pacers finished ninth in the NBA's Eastern Conference in the 2008-2009 season, three games out of a playoff spot. They are led by Danny Granger, who won the 2008-2009 NBA Most Improved Player Award, and point guard T.J. Ford.

Tickets for the game, one of only two NBA games to be played in Asia this year, will go on sale June 22 exclusively for Cathay United Bank credit card holders at www.allgenki.net/ticket before being opened to everyone on June 25.
The organizers said ticket prices will range from NT$800-7,500 (US$24-228) to satisfy all kinds of NBA fans in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 5,000 people to test for 21 teaching openings

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County began a search for 21 elementary school and kindergarten teachers Friday that attracted 5,100 applicants.
The selection process will last three days, with applicants to face qualification exams in July, the local government said.
One applicant submitting her resume to the county government said she hopes she can pass the tests to become a full-time teacher after having served as a substitute teacher for over 10 years.

The last time the southern Taiwan county hired elementary school teachers was in 2003. There have been no openings since then due to a declining birth rate that has led to fewer public elementary school and kindergarten classes.
According to Ministry of Education statistics, 38,413 people with teaching certificates took national examinations in 2008 to fill public elementary school teaching openings in Taiwan.
Only 2,857 people, or 7.4 percent of the applicants, passed the tests. The 7.4 percent success rate was down from an 8.6 percent success rate in 2007, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hundreds of discarded icons from Taiwan on display in Paris
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 19 (CNA) 06/19/09 22:08:49 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A piece of installation art featuring hundreds of discarded statues and images of deities from Taiwan is currently being exhibited at Musee Guimet in Paris, part of the museum's efforts to attract new visitors through the introduction of exotic works.

The piece, dubbed God Pound, was created by Taiwanese artist Peng Hung-chih and symbolizes the special cultural phenomenon in Taiwan where people throw away statues of deities as easily as they abandon their pets under certain circumstances, said Chen Chih-cheng, director of the Taiwan Cultural Center in Paris.

According to Chen, Jacques Gies, the French museum's new curator, was fascinated by Peng's installation work when he first saw it while touring a Taiwanese contemporary art exhibition at the Academy of Fine Arts near the renowned Louvre museum recently.

Gies then invited Peng to exhibit the work in the museum, consistent with Gies' efforts to promote "dialogue" between classic and contemporary works since assuming office not long ago and attract a new generation of visitors, Chen explained.

Peng's installation art work consists of 606 deserted statues and representations of deities lining the museum's atrium to form a spectacular sight, but the statues all face a video screen playing a documentary in which a dog narrates the story of the icons being worshipped in temples one day and dumped like waste the next.

Chen said the piece embodies the similarity between the fates of stray dogs and scrapped deity statues, and hopes to inspire visitors to think about the meaning of consumerism and significance of faith in people's lives.
All of the statues were disinfected and treated for pests before being put on display, Chen said, adding that the exhibition will run until Oct.19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan still needs U.S. help in national security: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday Taiwan still needs help from the United States in defending its national security even if once tense relations with China have grown more relaxed since he took power in May 2008.
Ma made the statement during a meeting with visiting U.S. scholars, including former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Susan Shirk.

The visitors expressed concern over Washington's role in the Taiwan Strait and over the development of Taiwan-China relations, but Ma contended that changes in cross-strait ties over the past year were beneficial to Taiwan, China and the U.S.

Despite the improvement in relations, however, Taiwan still needs U.S. help in safeguarding national security, Ma said, reiterating his desire to continue to maintain the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
Meanwhile, Ma also reiterated his call for a "diplomatic truce" between Taiwan and China, saying he would not block moves by Taiwan's diplomatic allies move to pursue economic relations with China.

While Taiwan is actively trying to improve cross-strait ties and expand its relations with diplomatic allies, it is also working to maintain good relations with old friends Japan and the U.S. and find a good balance among all of its relations, the president said.
Shirk described Ma's cross-strait policy as practical and said she was deeply impressed by the progress made in cross-strait ties over the past year.
Shirk, an expert on Chinese politics, was invited to attend an international academic symposium organized by National Taiwan University's Center for China Studies, slated for Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sea warning issued for tropical storm Linfa

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for this year's third tropical storm, Linfa, at 8:30 p.m. Friday.

CWB weathermen said that as of 8 p.m., Linfa was located at sea 470 km southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Eluanbi, with a 120-kilometer radius. It was packing maximum sustained winds of 83 km per hour, was moving north-northeast at 14 km per hour.
The meteorologists urged the public to refrain from activities along the seaside as it generate big waves along the coast from southwestern Taiwan to the Hengchun Peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fire at NTU College of Medicine lab put out, no casualties reported

TEXT.P: No casualties were reported after a blaze broke out in an experiment box in a laboratory at National Taiwan University College of Medicine (NTUCM) Friday night, Taipei City firefighters said.

Firefighters said the lab's box on the ninth floor started to burn for unknown reasons at 7: 08 p.m. The school had to call emergency hotline 119 after an attempt to extinguish it failed. The fire was put out at 7:50 p.m.

An initial investigation found that the lab was partially destroyed but that the fire had not spread to other rooms. Although it is a biochemistry lab, the NTUCM reported no toxic materials being released or risks of biochemical pollution.
Yang Pan-chyr, dean of NTU College of Medicine, said the fire was probably caused by improper handling of lab instruments.
One graduate student said the lab conducts mainly cell and genetic research.

He said that this was the third fire that had broken out this year at the College of Medicine. The first fire broke out in an operating room at National Taiwan University Hospital, while the second time was a small fire in a lab on the sixth floor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bike rental station set up to promote leisurely Kaohsiung tour

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) has set up a folding bike rental station at Zuoying station, the southern terminus of Taiwan's high speed rail line, to make it easier for people to tour Kaohsiung in a more leisurely way.

KRTC officials said that in view of the biking craze in recent years, they came up with the idea of providing folding bikes to those who arrive in Kaohsiung via the high speed rail line or mass rapid transit system.
They noted that Kaohsiung has nearly 100 kilometers of bike lanes that take cyclists to such scenic spots as Love River, Cijin and Lotus Pond.
The rental fee for the bikes will be NT$200 for a full day and NT$100 for four hours after June 26, they added.
The company will monitor the results of the bike rental station service to decide whether to offer such services at more MRT stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military evaluating third generation of fighter aircraft

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is still working on plans to acquire a new generation of military aircraft, an official said Friday.

Military spokesman Yu Sy-tue was responding to a newspaper report that the state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (ADIC) has designed a new generation of jet fighters that cater to the military's special needs.
According to the China Times report, the ADIC has completed the design of the new military aircraft with assistance from Russian experts in the field.
In the process, the Taipei-based daily said, the ADIC had sent people to Russia to consult with Russian strategists and engineers on the design of the new fighter.
The paper further said the ADIC-designed jet fighters will be equipped with twin engines and will be capable of taking off and landing over short distances.
Commenting on the report, Yu said the military is planning the acquisition of a new generation of jet fighters.

"The military will take into account the changing international strategic environment, enemy threat, government finances, development trends in jet fighters and the possibility of acquiring them while working on new aircraft acquisition plans," Yu explained.
He would not divulge details, however, on the military's acquisition and reasearch plans.
Instead, Yu said, jet fighters with short take-off and landing requirements, stealth qualities and beyond-vision combat functions are all features that meet the military's future combat requirements.
Meanwhile, ADIC spokesman Lee Shih-chang said the company has never sent any R&D staff to Russia, in an indirect denial of the newspaper report.

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Former Vice President Annette Lu departing on a visit to Canada and U.S. to promote her plan to launch a new newspaper. Date and Time: 06:30 p.m., Saturday, June 20, 2009. Place: Taoyuan Airport, Tayuan, Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 20, or the 28th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
2001: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concludes in Taipei after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Jan.-May inward foreign direct investment down 44.91% year-on-year

TEXT.P: Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) approved by the government in the first five months of 2009 amounted to US$1.67 billion, down 44.91 percent from the year-earlier level, according to a report released Friday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
In May alone, approved inward FDI plunged 80.23 percent year-on-year to US$165.35 million, statistics from the ministry's Investment Commission show.

Meanwhile, registered outward FDI soared 71.2 percent year-on-year to US$392.73 million in May, but showed an overall drop of 55.87 percent for the first five months of the year, amounting to US$943.14 million.

In terms of China-bound investment, the amount approved in May was US$301.88 million, down 71.5 percent year-on-year, while US$1.35 billion was approved for the Jan.-May period, a decrease of 65.03 percent year-on-year, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: U-Theatre good example of Taiwan's soft power: Israeli envoy

TEXT.P: U-Theatre, a renowned Taipei-based drumming group, serves as a good example of Taiwan's "soft power, " as it has bridged the cultural gap between Taiwan and Israel, the top Israeli envoy to Taiwan said Saturday.

Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , made the remarks in a press release in light of the fact that Nimroda Markin, a retired Israeli psychotherapist, is visiting Taiwan to find out more about the cultural treasures of the country after being struck by U-Theatre performances in Israel.
"This is an amazing example of the ability of art and culture to build bridges between peoples from different backgrounds, " Gamzou said.
"It is also an amazing example of the impact of Taiwan soft power as an incentive to discover the island, its treasures and the treasures of this society and its culture," he added.

U-Theatre was invited to tour Israel through efforts by the ISECO and by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel Aviv, including a major opening performance at the Israel Spring Festival last March.

According to the ISECO, Markin purchased tickets for the first performance in northern Israel and was so amazed by the drummers that she decided to purchase tickets for the next show in a different venue 150 km from her hometown.

Her attendance at the second performance did not diminish the impact of her first experience, but rather, she found it was still not sufficient and therefore made up her mind to find out more about the group, its culture and its country, the press release stated.

Markin, who had never visited Asia before, traveled thousands of miles to Taiwan two weeks ago, where she was allowed to join the U-Theatre performers in rehearsals and in a variety of different activities.

The ISECO is scheduled to hold a tea party in collaboration with U- Theatre's Artistic Director Liu Rou-yu for Markin June 22, in which she will share her experience of the group and the discoveries she has made in Taiwan, the statement said.
