DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical storm Linfa expected to bring heavy rain to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) advised the public Saturday to prepare for heavy rain expected as a result of tropical storm Linfa, which was approaching the Taiwan Strait.

The outer rim of the storm was expected to bring heavy rain or extremely heavy rain to southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan, the bureau said, adding that other areas could expect downpours in the afternoon.
According to the CWB's definition, heavy rain refers to 24-hour accumulated rainfall exceeding 50 mm, while extremely heavy rain means 24-hour accumulated rainfall exceeding 130 mm.

At 11 a.m. that day, Linfa was centered 410 km west-southwest of Eluanbi, Taiwan's southernmost tip, packing maximum sustained winds of 90 kph and moving north-northeast at 10 kph toward the Taiwan Strait, according to bureau data.
The bureau urged shipping in the Taiwan Strait, Bashi Channel and waters surrounding the Pratas Islands to take precautions against heavy weather.

DOC.HEADLINE: Democrats Abroad sets up Taiwan branch

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of Democrats Abroad, the official Democratic Party organization for the millions of Americans living outside the United States, announced Saturday in a press release that Democrats Abroad Taiwan (DAT) has been approved as the organization's new country committee.

Officially established May 26, the press release said the DAT's current executive committee consists of five enthusiastic leaders, including John Eastwood, a law firm partner who serves as DAT chairman, and Justine Chen, a senior policy researcher who serves as DAT vice chairwoman.

Other DAT members are Michael Turton, who serves as DAT secretary, Josh Davis, an MBA student at National Sun Yat-sen University who is DAT treasurer, and David Bell, a graduate student in Chinese history at National Taiwan University who serves as DAT counsel, it added.
Christine Schon Marques, international chairwoman of Democrats Abroad, said in the press release that members of the organization are pleased to welcome the establishment of DAT.
"Taiwan's technology sector makes it home to many Americans, and in fact, many Democrats living abroad," Marques said.

"We know that under John Eastwood's leadership, DAT will bring a great deal of energy and enthusiasm to the entire organization and will help expand the number of Democrats in Congress in 2010, " she added.
According to Eastwood, in the days right after the U.S. went into Iraq, anyone who expressed serious concerns about where the country was going would get their patriotism questioned.
"Although Democrats Abroad had previously been active in Taiwan, we had to start over in those difficult years," Eastwood said.

Through organizing social events, Eastwood went on, he and like-minded friends living in Taiwan created a safe place for fellow Americans to talk about what was happening to their country and it was when the Democrats took Congress back in 2006 that they began having some real momentum to further expand the scale of the activities.

Eastwood worked with longtime member Tammy Turner to organize events and provide overseas-voting information to fellow Democrats through the 2004, 2006, and 2008 elections. The effort was furthered when Bell and Cynthia Teeters joined forces with other Democrats for the start- up efforts to establish DAT.

Democrats Abroad has committees throughout Europe, the U.S., the Middle East, Africa, Asia and the Antipodes. These country committees keep Americans abroad informed of their rights and help them participate in the U.S. political process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Artist Village open call for 2010 artist-in-residence

TEXT.P: The Taipei Artist Village (TAV) , a non- government organization in the nation's capital, launched its 2010 Artist-in-Residence (AIR) Taipei Open Call for both international and local artists to submit projects related to art and culture, the creative industry and interdisciplinary and business-art collaboration, according to a TAV press statement released Saturday.

Residence projects in three categories are requested for 2010 -- individual artists or teams, the creative industry and interdisciplinary and business-art collaboration -- according to the TAV, which added that applicants must have a minimum of three years' experience or professional practice, while students, as well as AIR grantees from 2007 and 2008, are not eligible to apply.

Applications and portfolios including up to a maximum of six pieces of work submitted on a PC-compatible CD-ROM or DVD or VCD from the last two years of the artist's work, or an excerpt from six pieces of work, should be presented in English and sent by post, it added.

Other than the international open call for artists of any nationality, the competitive category of international artists-in- residence, will continue the "New Immigrants Taiwan" project for Southeast Asian artists, as well as the "Artists from Sister Cities of Taipei, " which was introduced last year, according to the press release.
"Through these projects, we wish to make art as the bridge connecting Taipei with cities worldwide," the TAV said.

The application deadline for both domestic and international programs is July 31, and decisions on the successful applicants will be announced by October on the TAV Web site at http://www.artistvillage.org.

Established in 2001, the TAV sees exchanges between local and international talent as its most important mission and it has taken a leading role in providing a platform for international artists and cultural exchanges.

In January 2008, with the aim of offering a greater space for cross- cultural and interdisciplinary dialogue, the AIR Program was expanded to AIR Taipei, encompassing not only the TAV in downtown Taipei but also Grass Mountain Artist Village, located in Yangmingshan National Park.
As of August 2008, 200 international artists from 35 countries had stayed at TAV as artists-in-residence, while nearly 80 Taiwanese artists had also participated in AIT programs abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dance created by Taiwanese choreographer to have France premiere
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 19 (CNA) 06/20/09 16:11:42 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A dance rendition of the story of legendary Chinese goddess Nu Wa created by Germany-based Taiwanese dancer-choreographer Sun Shang-chi will premiere in the Avignon Off Festival in southern France July 8.
Sun said Friday that Nu Wa, who legend says created mankind, symbolizes the human imagination of nature and the universe.

"I intend to search for the metaphor of the human body through the dance, as well as the origin of human language, literature, rhythm and music, " Sun said, adding that the dance is infused with Oriental mythology.
The dance features interaction between two dancers and a pianist, the 32-year- old dancer-choreographer went on.
According to Sun, the background music was composed by Taiwanese composer Shih Pei-yu, who is doing a doctoral program in Britain.
German pianist Andreas Kern will not only play the score of Nu Wa but will also improvise with the two dancers -- Sun himself and Nefeli Skarmea, a Greek female dancer.
Skarmea, who collaborated with Sun in the Nuremberg Modern Dance Theatre for many years, praised Sun as an outstanding dancer and talented choreographer with a unique style.
Sun received financial support from Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs, the Lo Man-fei Dance Scholarship and France's Lyon Dancers House in the process of creating Nu Wa.
Chen Chih-cheng, director of the Taiwan Culture Center in Paris, noted that few Taiwanese choreographers have been able to edge into the European dance arena -- known as a Mecca for modern dance.
"It is an extraordinary achievement for Sun to have emerged in Europe as an up- and-coming choreographer," he added.
Nu Wa will be previewed at the Dock 11 theater in Berlin next week before heading for Avignon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first HCPV solar power system inaugurated

TEXT.P: A ceremony was held Saturday in southern Taiwan to inaugurate the country's first commercial-grade high concentration photovoltaic (HCPV) solar power system, which will have a total installed capacity of one megawatt once the construction project is completed.

The inauguration marked the first-stage operation of the system, located in the Liuying Environment Science and Technology Park in Tainan County. At present, it can generate 100 kilowatts of clean electricity per hour.

Eric Tsai, general manager of the Taipei-based Advanced Renewable Energy Inc. (AREi) , which is cooperating with the Tainan county government in developing solar energy, said at the ceremony that 14 HCPV devices have been installed to achieve an annual output of 190,000 kWh per year.
In the future, the company will install other planned facilities to enable power generation of 900 kilowatts per hour, he added.
Tsai further said that through a grid system, the clean power from the facility will be provided for the use of AREi's photovoltaic research center at the science park.
Any additional power will be sold to the state-run Taiwan Power Company, he noted.
According to Tsai, the cost of constructing a HCPV solar power system is much more than that of building a traditional solar power system, but requires 50 percent less land.

The company is expected to earn its investment back in less than 14 years, thanks to the passage of the Renewable Energy Development Act, which allows government subsidies for private companies involved in the development of clean energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Breast cancer awareness group completes round-Taiwan cycle tour

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei greeted the return Saturday of a group of cyclists that had just completed a 13-day round-Taiwan cycle tour aimed at raising public awareness about the forms of cancer that affect women.
The group, organized by the Taiwan Breast Cancer Alliance (TBCA), comprised breast cancer sufferers and members of their families who set off on the 1,000-km tour from Taipei County June 8.
Chou praised the cyclists for completing the task, especially challenging for a cancer victim.

Huang Pu-hsin, a representative for the cancer sufferers, said their next step is to cycle through every township in Taiwan within three years to teach locals there how to conduct self-examinations and face the disease.
Citing statistics released by the Department of Health in 2006, Huang said 6,895 people were diagnosed with breast cancer that year while 1,439 people died of the disease.
"Each number represents sad lives, " she said, recalling her terror upon being informed that she had breast cancer.

It was this experience that prompted her to join the cycle tour and the upcoming TBCA township activity to awaken other female citizens to the importance of regular health checks in the prevention and control of breast cancer, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier inspects emergency center as storm approaches

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung inspected the Central Emergency Operations Center (CEOC) in Taipei County's Sindian City Saturday to see at first-hand the preparations being made for disaster prevention amid the approach of tropical storm Linfa.

Chiu issued the directive that southern Taiwan, as well as the outlying islands of Kinmen and Penghu, be fully alerted over possible flooding after the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported that the storm was expected to bring heavy rain to southwestern parts of the country.
He also ordered the Government Information Office to warn the public to refrain from visiting beaches and avoid outdoor activities during the storm.

The CWB had already released a sea warning for shipping and had reported earlier in the day that the outer rim of the storm was expected to bring heavy rain or extremely heavy rain to southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan, with other areas receiving downpours in the afternoon.

At 5: 30 p.m., Linfa was centered 380 km west-southwest of Oluanbi, Taiwan's southernmost tip, packing maximum sustained winds of 101 kph and moving north- northeast at 10 kph toward the Taiwan Strait, according to bureau data.
The storm was expected to be 160 km west-southwest of the Penghu Islands off southwestern Taiwan at 5 p.m. the next day.
The bureau urged shipping in the Taiwan Strait, Bashi Channel and waters surrounding the Pratas Islands to take precautions against heavy weather.

Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said vegetable supplies were sufficient and normal, noting that the average wholesale price at the Taipei market was within the normal range at NT$20.3 per kg earlier in the day.
The COA urged farmers to prepare for the storm and advised them to get their ripe crops harvested as quickly as possible.
In the eastern county of Hualien, police stationed at the scenic Taroko National Park began evacuating hikers from mountains in the park despite clear skies and no signs of Linfa's approach.
The police also rejected many applications for permits to enter restricted mountain areas that same day out of safety concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visually impaired graduate vows to develop audio books

TEXT.P: Overcoming severe visual disability, Chuang Ching-chieh obtained a bachelor's degree in computer science Saturday and won the highest honor awarded by National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) for its graduates -- the Mei Yi-Chi Commemorative Award.
Chuang said she is committed to continuing her studies in the same field and seeking to realize her dream -- developing and producing audio books to help other visually impaired people.
"I thought I had lost everything but luckily, I'm still capable of cherishing what I have," she said.
Chuang had a happy childhood and had big, beautiful eyes that led to her nickname "big-eye girl."
Upon reaching the age of 13, however, she began to experience a decline in her vision and was later diagnosed with macular degeneration.

Her parents took her on a desperate search for a cure that included trips to Japan and the United States, as well as a range of alternative therapies and folk remedies that contained grotesque ingredients such as centipede legs, bat guano and chicken gall.
They grasped at every hope, but on each occasion, their hopes were shattered, which made Chuang worry that her parents would go broke on her account.
Her parents' support touched her deeply and gave her the courage to live as fully and passionately as she can.
"I did not want my father and mother to put the blame on themselves and think that my vision problems were their fault, " Chuang said.

Because of the disease, she encountered numerous frustrations in her daily life, once showing her disability certificate to a bus driver in order to get a discount, only to be rejected because she did not "look" disabled.

Not being able to see clearly, she also had the experience of treading on a puppy by accident when walking on campus, while in class, she had to use a telescope to see the teachers' writing on the blackboard and a microscope to read her books.

Writing computer programs involved the help of a closed circuit television system with her face close to the monitor. Work that would usually take her classmates seven hours to complete would often take her four times as long.
She kept telling herself to keep going because "if I give up on myself, no-one in the world can save me."
Having gained admission to a master's program in computer science at NTHU, Chuang said she will continue working toward her goal of improving the design of audio books from the user's perspective.

She pointed out that at present, users of audio books have to listen from the beginning and cannot browse back and forth freely. In addition, existing products do not allow users to underline or bookmark passages they think are important, which is a major inconvenience.
Chuang said she hopes her story will remind others to value what they have and encourage them to seek to fulfill their wishes whenever they can.
"You never know. If you don't do it now, you may not have the chance to do so later," she pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT hails China's response to call for truce on expatriate front

TEXT.P: China's positive response to Taiwan's call for a truce among expatriates from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will contribute to the peaceful development of cross-strait relations, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) official said Saturday.

KMT Deputy Secretary-General Chang Jung-kung made the remarks after Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said in Los Angeles the previous day that the once-strained cross-strait relations have taken a historic turn for the better over the past year.

Against this backdrop, Wang said at a meeting with Chinese expatriate community leaders at China's Consulate General in Los Angeles that the concept of "a truce and no attrition of resources" on the diplomatic front can also be applied to the expatriate front.
From now on, Wang continued, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should stop their confrontation in dealing with expatriate affairs.

"Wang's statements mark the latest expression of China's attitude toward expatriate affairs," Chang said, adding that his remarks also symbolize Beijing's positive response to President Ma Ying-jeou's recent appeal for a truce between Taiwanese and Chinese expatriate groups.
Noting that Taiwan has benefited from the cross-strait diplomatic truce over the past year, Chang said the two sides of the strait should expand this conciliatory approach to expatriate front.

Taiwan and China once engaged in a diplomatic tug-of-war in which both sides often had to spend huge amounts of their national resources to lure diplomatic allies. Since Ma assumed office in May 2008, he has advocated a "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy to pave the way for a cross-strait diplomatic truce.

"This kind of detente should be extended to expatriate communities around the world, " Chang said, adding that the goodwill strategy would spare overseas people of Chinese descent from taking sides and could instead promote exchanges and harmony between expatriate groups, as well as cross-strait peace.

Acknowledging that the decades-old cross-strait confrontation on the expatriate front has a very complex background, Chang said he believes the hostility can be gradually resolved in a pragmatic manner.

"Both sides could start by shelving disputes and forging mutual trust, gradually working more and more closely together to sort out measures for peaceful co- existence, " Chang said, adding that such a truce would help create a win-win situation for both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier favors focusing on general tourism in Penghu development

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday that he supports the idea of focusing on tourism in general, allowing the casino trade to play more of a supplementary role, in the development of the outlying islands of the Penghu archipelago.

The premier made the remarks when he toured the outlying county's city of Magong during which he visited the airport and harbor, as well as listening to a briefing prepared by the Penghu county government.

Among those accompanying him were Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai, Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min and Legislator Lin Ping- kuan of the opposition Non-partisan Solidarity Union.
Liu said his visit was aimed at learning "how to develop Penghu's tourism, and not just seeing how it is going to build casinos."

The legislature passed a draft amendment to a statute governing the development of the country's outlying islands in January, paving the way for legalizing gambling on the outlying islands, including the Penghu group.

The premier also said that a draft bill on gambling management and complementary measures drawn up by related government agencies will be ready by the end of the year, adding that "whatever the results of a referendum by Penghu residents on the casinos, the preparations will not be done in vain."
The casino plan for Penghu will require "yes" votes from over half of the total ballots cast in the referendum.

Liu also said that to develop the county's tourism, the renovation and expansion of facilities such as the harbor and airport will be crucial, and he asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to take the matter in hand.

Mao noted that the No. 1 wharf length at Magong Harbor will be expanded from the present 126 meters to 190 meters by the end of the year, which will allow it to accept moorings by large cruisers up to 40,000 tons upon its completion.
In addition, the selection of construction companies for a NT$1.8 billion renovation program for the runways and taxiways of the airport will be completed by the end of July, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas travel business battered by flu pandemic

TEXT.P: Taiwan's travel agencies, who still have not recovered from the global financial storm, have been left reeling even further with the World Health Organization declaration of a global pandemic of the A(H1N1) influenza virus, which has frightened many local people into avoiding foreign travel.

According to the latest Tourism Bureau statistics, only a few first-stop overseas destinations such as South Korea, Britain, Palau and Australia, enjoyed growth in the number of travelers from Taiwan in May thanks to the incentives that included favorable exchange rates, visa free privileges and convenient flight services.

The number of Taiwanese travelers to Japan, which attracts over 1 million Taiwanese visitors each year, had only 80,382 visits by this group in May, marking a drop of 35.41 percent from the same month of the previous year, the statistics show.

In the case of Thailand, visitors from Taiwan in May fell by 36.4 percent compared with the same month of last year, while the number of Taiwanese travelers to the United States fell by 33.63 percent.
All those countries had reported increasing numbers of A(H1N1) infections over the past month.
The statistics also show the overall number of travelers departing Taiwan in May registered a drop of 13.28 percent.
Local travel agents have predicted an even worse situation in the upcoming summer break, but anticipated significant growth in the number of people embarking on domestic tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer than 100 inmates get early release on 1st day of new ruling

TEXT.P: Only 64 out of several hundred petty criminals had been released from prison before noon Saturday under a new ruling by the Justices of the Constitutional Court that allows those who have been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions to pay fines in lieu of spending time behind bars.
The grand justices issued the new ruling a day earlier, under which those who are serving time in prisons and meet the new requirements could apply for release from Saturday.

As the grand justices did not give any grace period for implementation of the new ruling, local prosecutors decided to allow those who meet the requirements for release to walk out of prison gates even before judges determine the amount of fines they would have to pay.
According to Ministry of Justice (MOJ) statistics, 1,802 prison inmates are eligible to apply for early release by paying fines.
As of noon Saturday, 64 of the 768 applicants had been released. Among them, only 29 had paid fines, with the rest promising to pay later.
If they fail to make payments as scheduled, they will have to return to jails and serve out their terms or be put on the wanted list, prosecutors said.
Prison sources said some inmates show no interest in early release because they are too poor to pay fines.

The new measure for petty criminals to regain freedom by paying fines became possible after the grand justices ruled as "unconstitutional" Article 41 of the Criminal Code that prohibited those who had been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions from paying fines.
MOJ officials said the ministry will come up with a draft package of amendments to the Criminal Code in line with the grand justices' new ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong student becomes 2 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: "I'm so lucky, " said a Hong Kong university student Saturday when he learned that he was the 2 millionth tourist to Taiwan this year and eligible to receive NT$200,000 in credit card spending during his stay.

Wong Chi Hoi, a sophomore at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, arrived at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan via a Taipei-based China Airlines flight Saturday afternoon along with three of his friends for a three- day-two-night backpacking trip.
This is Wong's first visit to Taiwan. He said he plans to tour scenic spots in Kaohsiung and the famed Kending National Park in neighboring Pingtung County.
"The prize comes as a big surprise to me. I'm blessed...I'll share the prize with my friends, " said a jubilant Wong who was also given a collection of gift items with local falvor.

The credit card prize is part of the Tourism Bureau's efforts to attract more tourists to Taiwan. The 1 millionth visitor this year was a Malaysian who entered Taiwan from Taoyuan International Airport in the north in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: 309 applicants for early release approved on 1st day of new ruling

TEXT.P: As of 8:00 p.m. Saturday, 309 applications for early release from prisons had been approved under a new ruling by the Justices of the Constitutional Court that allows those who have been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions to pay fines in lieu of spending time behind bars.
The grand justices issued the new ruling a day earlier, under which those who are serving time in prisons and meet the new requirements could apply for release from Saturday.

As the grand justices did not give any grace period for implementation of the new ruling, local prosecutors decided to allow those who meet the requirements for release to walk out of prison gates even before judges determine the amount of fines they would have to pay.
According to Ministry of Justice (MOJ) statistics, 1,802 prison inmates are eligible to apply for early release by paying fines.
As of Saturday evening, 309 of the 858 applications sent by prison authorities from around the country had been approved, MOJ officials said.
Among the released inmates, some have paid fines, with the rest promising to pay later.
If they fail to make payments as scheduled, they will have to return to jails and serve out their terms or be put on the wanted list, prosecutors said.
Prison sources said some inmates have shown no interest in early release because they are too poor to pay fines.

The new measure for petty criminals to regain freedom by paying fines became possible after the grand justices on Friday ruled as "unconstitutional" Article 41 of the Criminal Code that prohibited those who had been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions from paying fines to avoid incarceration.
MOJ officials said the ministry will come up with a draft package of amendments to the Criminal Code in line with the grand justices' new ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 21, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of the first film festival featuring movies produced by Taiwanese and Chinese filmmakers. Date and Time: 04:00 p.m., Sunday, June 21, 2009. Place: Shin Kong Cineplex Taichung, 13F, No.111, Zhonggang Road, Sec.2, Taichung City. Host and/or main speakers: Shao Hsiao-ling, wife of Taichung mayor. Organizers: Cross-Strait film exchange association. Press Contact: Tel. (04)2258-9911.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer than 100 inmates get early release on 1st day of new ruling

TEXT.P: Only 64 out of several hundred petty criminals had been released from prison before noon Saturday under a new ruling by the Justices of the Constitutional Court that allows those who have been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions to pay fines in lieu of spending time behind bars.
The grand justices issued the new ruling a day earlier, under which those who are serving time in prisons and meet the new requirements could apply for release from Saturday.

As the grand justices did not give any grace period for implementation of the new ruling, local prosecutors decided to allow those who meet the requirements for release to walk out of prison gates even before judges determine the amount of fines they would have to pay.
According to Ministry of Justice (MOJ) statistics, 1,802 prison inmates are eligible to apply for early release by paying fines.
As of noon Saturday, 64 of the 768 applicants had been released. Among them, only 29 had paid fines, with the rest promising to pay later.
If they fail to make payments as scheduled, they will have to return to jails and serve out their terms or be put on the wanted list, prosecutors said.
Prison sources said some inmates show no interest in early release because they are too poor to pay fines.

The new measure for petty criminals to regain freedom by paying fines became possible after the grand justices ruled as "unconstitutional" Article 41 of the Criminal Code that prohibited those who had been given terms of longer than six months for several petty convictions from paying fines.
MOJ officials said the ministry will come up with a draft package of amendments to the Criminal Code in line with the grand justices' new ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Offices, schools closed on outlying islands due to storm

TEXT.P: Local governments of Taiwan's outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matzu announced office and school closures Sunday after the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for tropical storm Linfa.
The first tropical storm to hit Taiwan this year, Linfa has also grounded air and shipping services between Taiwan proper and the three island groups.
According to the CWB, as of 2:30 p.m. Sunday, Linfa was located 50 km south of Kinmen, moving in a north-northeasterly direction toward China at a speed of 20 kph.

Packing maximum sustained winds of up to 90 kph, Linfa, this year's third tropical storm to form in the West Pacific region, was expected to trigger extremely heavy rain in areas from central to southern Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

They urged the public to stay out of the mountains and away from the seashore, as the storm could cause landslides as a result of flooding and generate heavy surf along the coast from southwestern Taiwan to the Hengchun peninsula.

Meanwhile, Hsu Han-ching, chief secretary of the Agriculture and Food Agency, said that both the quantity and prices of vegetables for sale in Taipei Sunday were normal -- totaling 1,570 tons at an average price of NT$20.2 (US$0.63) per kilogram.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alumnus donates NT$200 million to technology university

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (NTUST) received a NT$200 million (US$6.08) donation pledge Saturday from alumnus Zhuang Yong-shun, chairman of Aaeon Technology Co., the largest single donation ever made in Taiwan to a tertiary vocational training institution.
Zhuang, who is also a co-founder of Advantech Co., signed the donation agreement with NTUST President Chen Shi-shuenn in a ceremony held at the school.

Zhuang will provide NT$200 million for the construction of a teaching and research building slated to be completed in late July, while the university promised to name the structure the Aaeon Building, to build a bridge of cooperation between the business and academic sectors and a platform for collaborative development of power electronics technology and medical equipment.
The ceremony was witnessed by Mao Kao-wen, a former minister of education and former NTUST president, and Tsai Duei, a former minister of transportation and communications.

Zhuang graduated from NTUST's Department of Electronic Engineering in 1979 and then worked at Hewlett-Packard. Along with two Hewlett-Packard co-workers, he established Avantech Co. in 1983 and 10 years later set up Aaeon Technology.
Both companies, which are the world's premier manufacturers of industrial personal computers and related equipment, are listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

Displaying a wallet that was given to him 30 years ago by his teachers at NTUST with the aim of encouraging him to earn a lot of money and pay back society, Zhuang said he was pleased to be able to fulfill his teacher's instructions and added his hope that other members of the public will donate money for education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign oil tanker stranded off Pingtung

TEXT.P: A foreign oil tanker ran aground off the southern county of Pingtung late Saturday, but temporarily posed no threat of an oil spill, the Pingtung County Environmental Protection Bureau said Sunday.

The Colombo Queen, a 497-ton tanker registered in the Union of Comoros, an island nation in the Indian Ocean, went aground about 50 meters off Pingtung's scenic Jialeshuei coastal park amid strong winds and heavy seas whipped up by approaching tropical storm Linfa.
According to the National Rescue Command Center, the tanker, carrying 39,000 liters of fuel oil and nine crew members, sent out distress signals at around 8 p.m. Saturday.
The command center alerted rescue teams in Kaohsiung and Pingtung, but rescue helicopters in those two counties were unable to fly because of the bad weather.

The command center then called a Coast Guard Administration (CGA) unit in the eastern county of Taitung, where winds and waves were lighter, as the tropical storm was sweeping toward the Taiwan Strait to the west of Taiwan.
Upon reaching the area in the early hours of Sunday, the CGA patrol boat found the stranded oil tanker but could not spot any of the crew, who had abandoned ship, in the pitch darkness.

The patrol boat itself was taking a heavy pounding, but just before it gave up the search, a bolt of lightning struck, providing a flash of light that was enough for the rescuers to spot a life raft with all nine men aboard, about three nautical miles from the grounded tanker, a CGA official said.

Aung Win, the Burmese captain of the Colombo Queen, said he had tried to steer the tanker away from the coast but the winds were so strong that the vessel was blown toward Taiwan and the engine finally gave out.
"Thank Taiwan and thank Allah," Aung Win said.

Meanwhile, in Pingtung, county officials were meeting over fears that the stranded tanker might cause an ecological calamity to the Pingtung coast similar to a disastrous oil spill in January, 2001, when the Greek-registered bulk carrier Amorgos ran aground off the coast of Pingtung's Kenting National Park, spilling roughly 1,150 tons of fuel oil into the water.
Three kilometers of coastline, from the Lungkeng Ecological Preserve to the rocky cliffs at Oluanpi, were seriously polluted.

The ensuing clean-up work among the coral reefs, carried out be local residents and 1,600 military personnel, was extremely difficult and it took six years for the 60-hectare Lungkeng Ecological Preserve to recover, as well as years of fighting in international courts for Taiwan to get any compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Department of Health to procure mobile clinics for remote areas

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will acquire six more mobile clinics to extend the reach of health care services into remote areas of the country, paying for the vehicles with the revenues from the increased health surcharge on cigarettes, a DOH official said Sunday.

Anticipating that the government's tax revenues from a hike in the surcharge on cigarettes from June 1 will top NT$30 billion per year, DOH Minister Yeh Chin- chuan instructed that a portion of the revenues should be used to provide medical treatment for residents in remote mountainous and outlying areas, according to Shih Chung-liang, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs.
As a result, 4 percent of the anticipated additional revenues -- an estimated NT$900 million -- will be used for areas lacking medical resources, Shih added.

In view of the fact that people in remote areas, including 30 rural mountainous townships and 18 outlying islands, have poor access to health services, the DOH has been making efforts on three fronts -- providing free vaccines, strengthening recruitment and training for medical professionals, and improving medical care quality at hospitals in the areas -- Shih noted.

Another important task of the agency is improving the delivery of health care to remote areas. Under an integrated program for medical treatment consultation, the DOH has been collaborating with regional and larger hospitals to dispatch physicians to provide medical services in such areas on a regular basis, according to Shih.

Taian township in the northern county of Miaoli, as well as Heping township and Lishan township in the central county of Taichung have the most pressing need for mobile clinics, said Lo Wen-min of the Bureau of Nursing and Health Services Development under the DOH.

The DOH plans to purchase 11 dentist chairs and six vehicles that will be equipped with different types of equipment, including X-ray, ultrasound and cancer detection facilities, dependent on the needs of the residents they will serve, Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students embark on marathon trek from Taipei to Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: Nine postgraduate students left Taipei City Sunday on a marathon road run from northern Taiwan to the south aimed at getting a better idea of the land in which they live.

The students from National Taiwan University and National Taiwan University of Science and Technology hit the road at 5 a.m., heading south toward Taoyuan, where they were to continue their trek down Taiwan's western corridor to the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Before they reach Kaohsiung -- a journey they estimate will take eight days -- the students will jog through the counties of Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan, in that order, said Chen Yi-an, who is the public relations officer for the trek.
"The journey could possibly take longer than eight days, depending upon the health of the trekkers," Chen said.

Of the nine students, three will be jogging the whole way, while the others will spend some time jogging, riding bicycles and motorcycles while documenting the activity, taking care of liaison affairs and transporting luggage and supplies, Chen added.

According to itinerary of the trek, the students will pass through 60 townships on the west coast, traveling an average 40km-50km each day. The group will rest at around noon every day for lunch and to meet with the locals.

The Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, sponsor of the activity, welcomes members of the public to join the nine students by running alongside them, taking pictures of them, or offering them accommodation.

DOC.HEADLINE: First medical tourism group from China arrives

TEXT.P: A 32-member medical tour group from China arrived in Taiwan Sunday for health check-ups, making it the first Chinese group to visit Taiwan for medical tourism since last July, when the government began allowing Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan as tourists.
During their six-day stay, the members of the group are scheduled to visit six medical centers and hospitals, at one of which they will have their physical examinations.
They are also expected to visit several clinics specializing in cosmetic surgery, according to the local travel agency that arranged the tour.
"Each member of the group is expected to spend 5,000 Chinese yuan (US$731) on their check-up, " said an executive of the travel agency.
"Another group from China is expected to arrive in August for the same purpose if the first group is satisfied with its experience, " the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese violinist to perform in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Japanese violinist Ryu Goto, who at the age of 21 is listed in the top echelon of young performers in the world, will team up with Taiwanese pianist Hu Chih- long for a concert slated for July 18 in Taipei.
Goto, who is a physics major at Harvard University, is the younger bother of Midori Goto, a violinist considered a national treasure in Japan.

This will be Goto's second performance in Taiwan, having toured Taiwan, Hong Kong and China last year, according to Fan Man-nong, chairwoman of the International New Aspect Cultural and Educational Foundation, which is organizing the concert.
He will perform pieces by Bach and Beethoven, Fan said.
Describing him as a gifted and versatile young performer, Fan counted off several of Goto's impressive achievements, including making his concert debut at the age of seven in Japan.

At the age of 13, he appeared in an unprecedented series of 10 sold-out recitals at the Casals Hall in Tokyo. Since then, he has emerged as a soloist with a number of international orchestras, including the Dallas and Washington national symphonies in the United States, as well as the London Philharmonic Orchestra.

His eponymous debut CD, released in 2005, was the best-selling classical album in Japan for that year, Fan said, adding that his frequent appearances on TV have made the New York-born violinist particularly well-known in Japan.

Hu, 27, is a native of Taiwan who received a Master's Degree in Music from Taipei National University of the Arts and has won prizes in many international competitions, including the National Taipei Concert Hall Arising Stars and the prestigious Chi-Mei Artist Award. He is currently on the faculty of East Tennessee State University and has performed throughout Europe, Asia and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Filipina realizes dream in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Love changes everything.
When Rosel Be earned her bachelor's degree from National Kaohsiung University Saturday, the Philippines native understood fully what those three simple words mean.
Be's journey to love began in 1999, when she had to stop her life as a university freshman to earn her own living because her family could no longer to afford to pay for her studies.

She managed to land a job at an electronics factory in Nantzih, in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, but sent the bulk of her meager salary back home to her family every month, leaving her with very little for herself.

Her dream of one day finishing her university studies became more and more remote, giving way to thoughts about how she would earn enough money to improve her family's livelihood when her three-year contract in Taiwan expired.
However, Be met a Taiwanese engineer at her factory named Chu Yung-ren, who encouraged her to pursue her dream and offered her sympathy when she plunged into depression.

The friendship developed into a relationship, so that when she was ready to pack and leave Taiwan at the end of her contract, Chu popped the question and instead of leaving, Be stayed on in Taiwan as Chu's wife.
Driven by her desire to finish college, she enrolled in the Department of Western Languages and Literature at National Kaohsiung University and immersed herself in her studies.
On Saturday, she graduated summa cum laude and was admitted to the Graduate Institute of Foreign Languages and Literature at National Sun Yat-Sen University, also in Kaohsiung.

Be, who still does not have a thorough command of mandarin Chinese, threw herself into her husband's arms after receiving her diploma at the commencement ceremony, saying that she owed her husband any glory she earned at the university.
Now she is looking forward to her graduate studies, with high hopes that she will be able to land a teaching job after earning her master's degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: President has earned enough sponsors to run for KMT chief

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou who is to run for chairmanship of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has solicited sponsors among party members enough and to spare for his candidacy.
A worker for Ma's campaign said Sunday that more than 30,000 party members had signed to endorse Ma's candidacy thus far, almost two times more than what is needed.
According to the KMT chapter, whoever wants to run for party chairmanship should seek endorsement by 3 percent of the party members which stands at 503,184.
Ma who picked up registration forms for candidacy June 16 is the only one who bids to run and is considered a shoo-in in the election which is slated for July 26.

Zhuang will provide NT$200 million for the construction of a teaching and research building slated to be completed in late July, while the university promised to name the structure the Aaeon Building, to build a bridge of cooperation between the business and academic sectors and a platform for collaborative development of power electronics technology and medical equipment.
The ceremony was witnessed by Mao Kao-wen, a former minister of education and former NTUST president, and Tsai Duei, a former minister of transportation and communications.

Zhuang graduated from NTUST's Department of Electronic Engineering in 1979 and then worked at Hewlett-Packard. Along with two Hewlett-Packard co-workers, he established Avantech Co. in 1983 and 10 years later set up Aaeon Technology.
Both companies, which are the world's premier manufacturers of industrial personal computers and related equipment, are listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

Displaying a wallet that was given to him 30 years ago by his teachers at NTUST with the aim of encouraging him to earn a lot of money and pay back society, Zhuang said he was pleased to be able to fulfill his teacher's instructions and added his hope that other members of the public will donate money for education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign oil tanker stranded off Pingtung

TEXT.P: A foreign oil tanker ran aground off the southern county of Pingtung late Saturday, but temporarily posed no threat of an oil spill, the Pingtung County Environmental Protection Bureau said Sunday.

The Colombo Queen, a 497-ton tanker registered in the Union of Comoros, an island nation in the Indian Ocean, went aground about 50 meters off Pingtung's scenic Jialeshuei coastal park amid strong winds and heavy seas whipped up by approaching tropical storm Linfa.
According to the National Rescue Command Center, the tanker, carrying 39,000 liters of fuel oil and nine crew members, sent out distress signals at around 8 p.m. Saturday.
The command center alerted rescue teams in Kaohsiung and Pingtung, but rescue helicopters in those two counties were unable to fly because of the bad weather.

The command center then called a Coast Guard Administration (CGA) unit in the eastern county of Taitung, where winds and waves were lighter, as the tropical storm was sweeping toward the Taiwan Strait to the west of Taiwan.
Upon reaching the area in the early hours of Sunday, the CGA patrol boat found the stranded oil tanker but could not spot any of the crew, who had abandoned ship, in the pitch darkness.

The patrol boat itself was taking a heavy pounding, but just before it gave up the search, a bolt of lightning struck, providing a flash of light that was enough for the rescuers to spot a life raft with all nine men aboard, about three nautical miles from the grounded tanker, a CGA official said.

Aung Win, the Burmese captain of the Colombo Queen, said he had tried to steer the tanker away from the coast but the winds were so strong that the vessel was blown toward Taiwan and the engine finally gave out.
"Thank Taiwan and thank Allah," Aung Win said.

Meanwhile, in Pingtung, county officials were meeting over fears that the stranded tanker might cause an ecological calamity to the Pingtung coast similar to a disastrous oil spill in January, 2001, when the Greek-registered bulk carrier Amorgos ran aground off the coast of Pingtung's Kenting National Park, spilling roughly 1,150 tons of fuel oil into the water.
Three kilometers of coastline, from the Lungkeng Ecological Preserve to the rocky cliffs at Oluanpi, were seriously polluted.

The ensuing clean-up work among the coral reefs, carried out be local residents and 1,600 military personnel, was extremely difficult and it took six years for the 60-hectare Lungkeng Ecological Preserve to recover, as well as years of fighting in international courts for Taiwan to get any compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Department of Health to procure mobile clinics for remote areas

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will acquire six more mobile clinics to extend the reach of health care services into remote areas of the country, paying for the vehicles with the revenues from the increased health surcharge on cigarettes, a DOH official said Sunday.

Anticipating that the government's tax revenues from a hike in the surcharge on cigarettes from June 1 will top NT$30 billion per year, DOH Minister Yeh Chin- chuan instructed that a portion of the revenues should be used to provide medical treatment for residents in remote mountainous and outlying areas, according to Shih Chung-liang, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Medical Affairs.
As a result, 4 percent of the anticipated additional revenues -- an estimated NT$900 million -- will be used for areas lacking medical resources, Shih added.

In view of the fact that people in remote areas, including 30 rural mountainous townships and 18 outlying islands, have poor access to health services, the DOH has been making efforts on three fronts -- providing free vaccines, strengthening recruitment and training for medical professionals, and improving medical care quality at hospitals in the areas -- Shih noted.

Another important task of the agency is improving the delivery of health care to remote areas. Under an integrated program for medical treatment consultation, the DOH has been collaborating with regional and larger hospitals to dispatch physicians to provide medical services in such areas on a regular basis, according to Shih.

Taian township in the northern county of Miaoli, as well as Heping township and Lishan township in the central county of Taichung have the most pressing need for mobile clinics, said Lo Wen-min of the Bureau of Nursing and Health Services Development under the DOH.

The DOH plans to purchase 11 dentist chairs and six vehicles that will be equipped with different types of equipment, including X-ray, ultrasound and cancer detection facilities, dependent on the needs of the residents they will serve, Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Students embark on marathon trek from Taipei to Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: Nine postgraduate students left Taipei City Sunday on a marathon road run from northern Taiwan to the south aimed at getting a better idea of the land in which they live.

The students from National Taiwan University and National Taiwan University of Science and Technology hit the road at 5 a.m., heading south toward Taoyuan, where they were to continue their trek down Taiwan's western corridor to the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Before they reach Kaohsiung -- a journey they estimate will take eight days -- the students will jog through the counties of Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan, in that order, said Chen Yi-an, who is the public relations officer for the trek.
"The journey could possibly take longer than eight days, depending upon the health of the trekkers," Chen said.

Of the nine students, three will be jogging the whole way, while the others will spend some time jogging, riding bicycles and motorcycles while documenting the activity, taking care of liaison affairs and transporting luggage and supplies, Chen added.

According to itinerary of the trek, the students will pass through 60 townships on the west coast, traveling an average 40km-50km each day. The group will rest at around noon every day for lunch and to meet with the locals.

The Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, sponsor of the activity, welcomes members of the public to join the nine students by running alongside them, taking pictures of them, or offering them accommodation.

DOC.HEADLINE: First medical tourism group from China arrives

TEXT.P: A 32-member medical tour group from China arrived in Taiwan Sunday for health check-ups, making it the first Chinese group to visit Taiwan for medical tourism since last July, when the government began allowing Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan as tourists.
During their six-day stay, the members of the group are scheduled to visit six medical centers and hospitals, at one of which they will have their physical examinations.
They are also expected to visit several clinics specializing in cosmetic surgery, according to the local travel agency that arranged the tour.
"Each member of the group is expected to spend 5,000 Chinese yuan (US$731) on their check-up, " said an executive of the travel agency.
"Another group from China is expected to arrive in August for the same purpose if the first group is satisfied with its experience, " the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hong Kong student becomes 2 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year

TEXT.P: "I'm so lucky, " said a Hong Kong university student Saturday when he learned that he was the 2 millionth tourist to Taiwan this year and eligible to receive NT$200,000 in credit card spending during his stay.

Wong Chi Hoi, a sophomore at Hong Kong Polytechnic University, arrived at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan via a Taipei-based China Airlines flight Saturday afternoon along with three of his friends for a three- day-two-night backpacking trip.
This is Wong's first visit to Taiwan. He said he plans to tour scenic spots in Kaohsiung and the famed Kending National Park in neighboring Pingtung County.
"The prize comes as a big surprise to me. I'm blessed...I'll share the prize with my friends, " said a jubilant Wong who was also given a collection of gift items with local falvor.

The credit card prize is part of the Tourism Bureau's efforts to attract more tourists to Taiwan. The 1 millionth visitor this year was a Malaysian who entered Taiwan from Taoyuan International Airport in the north in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese violinist to perform in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Japanese violinist Ryu Goto, who at the age of 21 is listed in the top echelon of young performers in the world, will team up with Taiwanese pianist Hu Chih- long for a concert slated for July 18 in Taipei.
Goto, who is a physics major at Harvard University, is the younger bother of Midori Goto, a violinist considered a national treasure in Japan.

This will be Goto's second performance in Taiwan, having toured Taiwan, Hong Kong and China last year, according to Fan Man-nong, chairwoman of the International New Aspect Cultural and Educational Foundation, which is organizing the concert.
He will perform pieces by Bach and Beethoven, Fan said.
Describing him as a gifted and versatile young performer, Fan counted off several of Goto's impressive achievements, including making his concert debut at the age of seven in Japan.

At the age of 13, he appeared in an unprecedented series of 10 sold-out recitals at the Casals Hall in Tokyo. Since then, he has emerged as a soloist with a number of international orchestras, including the Dallas and Washington national symphonies in the United States, as well as the London Philharmonic Orchestra.

His eponymous debut CD, released in 2005, was the best-selling classical album in Japan for that year, Fan said, adding that his frequent appearances on TV have made the New York-born violinist particularly well-known in Japan.

Hu, 27, is a native of Taiwan who received a Master's Degree in Music from Taipei National University of the Arts and has won prizes in many international competitions, including the National Taipei Concert Hall Arising Stars and the prestigious Chi-Mei Artist Award. He is currently on the faculty of East Tennessee State University and has performed throughout Europe, Asia and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Filipina realizes dream in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Love changes everything.
When Rosel Be earned her bachelor's degree from National Kaohsiung University Saturday, the Philippines native understood fully what those three simple words mean.
Be's journey to love began in 1999, when she had to stop her life as a university freshman to earn her own living because her family could no longer to afford to pay for her studies.

She managed to land a job at an electronics factory in Nantzih, in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, but sent the bulk of her meager salary back home to her family every month, leaving her with very little for herself.

Her dream of one day finishing her university studies became more and more remote, giving way to thoughts about how she would earn enough money to improve her family's livelihood when her three-year contract in Taiwan expired.
However, Be met a Taiwanese engineer at her factory named Chu Yung-ren, who encouraged her to pursue her dream and offered her sympathy when she plunged into depression.

The friendship developed into a relationship, so that when she was ready to pack and leave Taiwan at the end of her contract, Chu popped the question and instead of leaving, Be stayed on in Taiwan as Chu's wife.
Driven by her desire to finish college, she enrolled in the Department of Western Languages and Literature at National Kaohsiung University and immersed herself in her studies.
On Saturday, she graduated summa cum laude and was admitted to the Graduate Institute of Foreign Languages and Literature at National Sun Yat-Sen University, also in Kaohsiung.

Be, who still does not have a thorough command of mandarin Chinese, threw herself into her husband's arms after receiving her diploma at the commencement ceremony, saying that she owed her husband any glory she earned at the university.
Now she is looking forward to her graduate studies, with high hopes that she will be able to land a teaching job after earning her master's degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: President has earned enough sponsors to run for KMT chief

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou who is to run for chairmanship of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has solicited sponsors among party members enough and to spare for his candidacy.
A worker for Ma's campaign said Sunday that more than 30,000 party members had signed to endorse Ma's candidacy thus far, almost two times more than what is needed.
According to the KMT chapter, whoever wants to run for party chairmanship should seek endorsement by 3 percent of the party members which stands at 503,184.
Ma who picked up registration forms for candidacy June 16 is the only one who bids to run and is considered a shoo-in in the election which is slated for July 26.

The weighted price index surged 86.62 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 6,231.15 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 22, or the 30th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
2001: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosts a "Latin Night" to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
First medical tourism group from China visits Taiwan

TEXT.P: The first Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan for medical purposes checked into four medical centers around the country Monday for physical examinations.

Five of the 30 Chinese tourists in the group from Guangzhou received health checks at Cathay General Hospital in Taipei City, while the others had physical examinations done at Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in Taipei, Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung Medical University Chung Ho Memorial Hospital in the south.

The health checks were carried out with the use of high-tech diagnostic procedures such as position emission tomography (PET) , magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computerized tomography (CT) , which can detect cancers as well as brain and heart problems.

A thirty-year-old woman surnamed Cao said she joined the medical tourism group with her husband, a professional athlete, because she had learned that health care standards in Taiwan were higher than on the Chinese mainland.
The reports have proved true, she said, adding that she was impressed with the examinations.
"The medical facilities are cutting-edge and the medical personnel are kind," she said.

The tourists, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday, were the first group from China to visit Taiwan for medical tourism since the government gave permission last July for significantly larger numbers of Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

They were also the first Chinese tourists since then to visit Taiwan for the three-fold purpose of medical care, spa treatment, and sightseeing, according to Zhang Yen, one of the visitors who owns an international trading company that specializes in the export of jeans.
Zhang and several others in the group booked into an upscale spa resort in Taipei's Xinyi District within hours of their arrival in Taiwan Sunday.
Zhang said she very much enjoyed the treatment at the resort, which she said offered a completely different experience from those in Japan or Thailand.
A woman surnamed Tan, who works in Guangzhou's financial service sector, said Taiwan's spas are on a par with Japan's, and come at a lower price.
"They're highly competitive, " she said."I would visit Taipei more frequently for the joy of the spa treatments if there were more direct flights for Guangzhou to Taipei," she said.
The group's travel route was from Guangzhou to Hong Kong by highway bus and then to Taiwan by plane, she noted.

The visitors also toured the bustling Hsimending business district in Taipei City's western suburb Sunday afternoon, where they had rice noodles with duck, cold pot-stewed duck tongues, and other local delicacies.

DOC.HEADLINE: New AIT compound will mirror U.S.-Taiwan relations: director

TEXT.P: The building of a new office compound for the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) will reflect the continuum of broader relations between Taiwan and the United States and will become a focal point of everything that is beneficial to bilateral ties, AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen M. Young said Monday.

"The new AIT building that will one day stand on this site will weave together these various strands of our complex, productive, and friendly relationship," Young said at a dedication ceremony for the site of the new AIT compound.
"I am proud to say that on this site we will be building a 21st century complex that embodies America's 21st century relationship with Taiwan," he added.
According to Young, the proposal to build a new AIT compound was initiated more than 10 years ago, but it has taken time for the project to finally get off the ground.

The de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan attributed the launch of the project to the long-term partnership and cooperation between his office and the Taipei City government, the Ministry of Interior, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, the Environmental Protection Administration and many others.
"I can leave here feeling that I've done my job," said Young, who is due to vacate the post soon.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said at the ceremony that the fact that the U.S. is the first country to build a de facto embassy compound in Taiwan, in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, is of great symbolic importance and turns a new page in bilateral ties.

"We hope that U.S.-Taiwan relations will continue to develop on the existing foundations into an even more solid one and that more high-level U.S. officials, including members of Congress, will be able to visit Taiwan in the future," Wang said.

Su Chi, secretary-general of the National Security Council, said that the U.S. has been a most cordial and supportive friend of Taiwan's over the past 60 years and that the construction of a new AIT office compound is a declaration that bilateral relations remain steady on the solid foundation of "mutual trust."

Noting that the building project is being implemented as a result of the hard work of previous and incumbent administrations of Taiwan and the U.S., a former top Taiwanese envoy to the U.S. Joseph Wu said that it symbolizes a more permanent relationship between the two sides.

The AIT said the US$170 million compound will include an office building of approximately 14,000 square meters, a parking area and ancillary structures. All of the AIT's Taipei offices, including the American Cultural Center, the Commercial Section, the Chinese Language and Area Studies School, and the Agricultural Trade Office, will be located for the first time at a single site, it added.
The 6.5 hectare site, which has been leased to the AIT for 99 years, is within walking distance of the Neihu stop of Taipei's Neihu MRT line, which is scheduled to begin operations July 4.

In the preparatory stages of the project, a rear access road, which was started in March, will be completed in six to nine months. The first phase of the project will involve clearing and grading of the site, and the new office building will be constructed in the second phase.
Weston Solutions, Inc. of West Chester, Pennsylvania has been awarded the US$54.4 million contract for phase one, while the contract for phase two has not yet been awarded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Power-saving initiative measures to be expanded

TEXT.P: Government measures that have been in place for nearly a year to encourage people to save power will be further expanded July 1, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs John C.C. Deng announced Monday.

Deng said at a news conference that household users who have achieved a drop in power consumption for two consecutive years and a power-saving rate of more than 20 percent in the past two years will be entitled to greater discounts on their power bills.
The discounts will be expanded from the current range of between 5 percent and 20 percent to between 10 percent and 30 percent, Deng said.

The ministry began the original measures last July, since which time the country had as of May 31 saved 4.2 billion kWh in terms of power consumed, a volume that surpassed the total one-year power consumption of all household users in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, according to the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).
During the period, Taipower saved NT$18.8 billion (US$570.7 million in fuel costs and helped cut emissions of carbon dioxide by 2.66 million tons.

The money the household users of electricity saved under the energy-saving initiative measures reached NT$14.2 billion during the 10-month period, NT$5.9 billion of which was used to cover the discounts to the public, Taipower said.

The company assessed that the expanded measures will help save 3.8 billion kWh in the coming year and will help household users save a combined NT$12.8 billion on their electricity bills, of which NT$8.3 billion will be used to cover the discounts under the expanded program.
It added that the company itself will save NT$12.4 billion in fuel costs and will cut carbon dioxide emissions by 2.39 million tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday:
Apple Daily: Ma's risky unilateralism
Former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Susan Shirk said China is reinforcing President Ma Ying-jeou's leadership in Taiwan by unveiling a series of policies favorable to the island.

It is no surprise that China would employ this trick, but Taiwan should guard against becoming a political satellite of China. Taiwan should do this by engaging not just with China, but also with other powers.
China Times: How can a referendum be held on the proposed trade pact with China when it only an outline?

The trade pact with China proposed by Ma's administration is to be completed in two phases, but the initial phrase, to be concluded by year end or early next year, is nothing but a outline, which is like a list of the chapters of a book.
What matters is the details of each chapter, which would take years to develop, as the Ma administration has admitted.

Since the proposed pact is devoid of any details in the initial phrase, how could it be put to a referendum? Is the DPP's call for a referendum another attempt to block any contact with China, and if it is, how is this different from blind isolation of the country in the international community?
United Daily News: DPP should press Beijing over proposed trade pact

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party should push Beijing into promising to help Taiwan forge free trade pacts with other countries rather than try to thwart the ruling KMT's plan to clinch trade agreements with China.

With ten free trade partners under its belt, China is set to sign agreements with another ten countries in the near future. The DPP is trying to blunt Taiwan's competitive edge in the Chinese market against these countries by opposing the planned trade pact between Taipei and Beijing.

You have to open your market to your partners if you want to gain access to theirs, and opening is the order of the day. The DPP cannot buck the trend by fooling its supporters into believing that Taiwan would fare better without the Chinese market.
Liberty Times: Plan for joint editing of dictionary by Taiwan and China is a plot to transform Taiwanese into Chinese.

President Ma's proposal for Taiwan and China to jointly edit a Chinese dictionary is another indication, along with his calls for China and Taiwan to adopt the same written Chinese characters, of his scheme to brainwash Taiwanese into becoming Chinese.

Written language has always been a tool for rulers, and this explains why Qin Shi Huang wanted to adopt a single form of writing when he conquered other six states in China, and why the Communist Party of China proclaimed as official the use of simplified Chinese characters.
Now, the Ma administration's efforts to introduce to Taiwanese the idea of using simplified Chinese is a step toward reunification with China.
Once Ma carries out this scheme, his goal of Taiwan's reunification with China will be achieved.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical tourism poised to create new business niche

TEXT.P: The arrival of a 30-member medical tour group from China Sunday marks a milestone in medical tourism development across the Taiwan Strait and is poised to create a new business niche, a corporate source said Monday.

The group from the Chinese city of Guangzhou for a six-day medical tour is expected to open an era for new business opportunities for Taiwan, although it could also lead to cutthroat competition among relevant businesses in the tourism, medical and insurance sectors, said Hung Zi-jen, vice president of the Shin Kong Medical Club.

According to Hung, thanks to the assistance of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, the Guangzhou-based Zion Health Club, which is a subsidiary of the Women's World Spa Resort Group -- a Taiwanese-financed company that has at least 600,000 members around China -- reached an agreement in March with 13 medical centers and hospitals in Taiwan to organize medical tourism groups from China for three-fold purpose of medical care, spa treatment and sightseeing.
The first tour group members checked into four medical centers around the country Monday for physical examinations.

Five of the 30-strong group received health checks at Cathay General Hospital in Taipei City, while the others had their physical examinations at Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in Taipei, Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung Medical University Chung Ho Memorial Hospital in the south.

With cross-strait charter flights set to be increased to regular daily flights, later this year, Hung said he is confident that Taiwan is capable of capitalizing on the golden opportunity offered by medical tourism, taking full advantage of its many signature tourist attractions and high-quality medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abandoned rabbits increasing, councilor urges measures

TEXT.P: Two rabbit rescue organizations have urged the Taipei city government to adopt a more active approach toward dealing with the problem of abandoned animals other than cats and dogs.
In response to the call, Yen I-feng, director of the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health, vowed to further cooperate with animal organizations to stop people abandoning their pets.
He made the remarks Monday following a campaign initiated a day earlier by the Taipei Rabbit Society and a rabbit adoption Web site.

At a function Sunday that was part of the campaign, a group of "bunny girls" -- volunteers from the two groups, along with Taipei City Councilor Wu Ssu-yao, dressed up like Playboy bunnies -- promoted an "I love rabbits " campaign, displaying abandoned pet rabbits that had been rescued from city streets.

Wu claimed that rabbits kept as pets carry and transmit fewer zoonotic diseases than cats and dogs and noted that they require relatively smaller living space than cats or dogs. She therefore asked the institute to extend the seven-day limit for killing unwanted rabbits.

Yen emphasized that animals should be treated equally without discrimination and condemned owners who dump their pets. He also vowed to cooperate further with animal protection groups to stop people abandoning animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daughter, son-in-law of ex-president admit giving false testimony

TEXT.P: The daughter and son-in-law of former President Chen Shui-bian admitted Monday that they gave false testimony over the past two years during investigations into the ex-first family's alleged corruption and money laundering.

Chen Hsing-yu and her husband, Chao Chien-ming, admitted in court that they gave false testimony on various occasions to prosecutors and judges regarding the case involving their mother, Wu Shu-jen, and her claims for reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million (US$451,219) from her husband's special state affairs funds using invoices she took from other people, according to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.
The prosecutors, however, declined to divulge the identity of the individual or individuals Chao and Chen named as having instructed them to lie.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office decided in mid-May to list the couple as defendants, as well as Chen's younger brother Chen Chih-chung, after discovering that the three gave different accounts during investigations into the false reimbursement case.
Chen Hsing-yu was indicted June 3, making her the final member of the scandal- embroiled ex-first family to be indicted on corruption and money laundering charges.
She was listed June 5 as a person whose movements in relation to attempted overseas travel should be monitored by prosecutors, a step below an outright travel ban.

All 14 of the other people in the family, including former President Chen Shui- bian, his wife Wu Shu-jen, their son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, have been indicted since 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think tank adjusts upward economic forecast for Taiwan
