TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Polaris Research Institute adjusted its economic forecast for Taiwan Monday, predicting that the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) will shrink 4.6 percent in 2009, instead of 4.8 percent it had previously forecast.

The economic outlook was the most pessimistic among the forecasts issued by economic research institutes in Taiwan, including the government Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics which predicted in May a GDP contraction of 4.25 percent this year.
Academia Sinica predicted a drop of 3.46 percent, while the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research forecast a slight shrinkage of 0.11 percent.

Polaris President Liang Kuo-yuan released the latest forecast at a press conference, saying that while "Taiwan's economy is improving, " it is doing so on a small scale because there are still negative factors affecting its recovery, such as a decrease in foreign orders.
However, Liang forecast that the economy will record growth of 3.87 percent in the fourth quarter of this year.
Meanwhile, he raised the consumers' price index growth forecast to "-0.78 percent" for 2009 due to increases in the price of raw material on the international market recently.
The value of the New Taiwan dollar will average NT$33.4 against the greenback in 2009, Liang said.

While the improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties will help attract foreign investment to support the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate, a drastic appreciation is not likely this year as the U.S. Federal Reserve Board may raise interest rate to back the greenback, according to Liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA unrelated to independence-unification issue: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Monday that Taiwan's planned trade pact with China is simply an economic matter and will not touch on the independence or the unification issue or undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.

"Taiwan and China should ink an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) to avoid Taiwan's marginalization in East Asia, as a free trade agreement (FTA) among China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is set to take effect next January, " Ma said in a meeting with Yasuo Hayashi, chairman of Japan's External Trade Organization, at the Presidential Office.

"We feel it necessary to open the talks with China as quickly as possible, in view of the China-ASEAN FTA, which will allow zero tariffs on exports from either side and thus greatly hurt Taiwan's competitiveness," the president said.
The results of recent surveys showed that some 60 percent of the Taiwan people endorsed the government's efforts to clinch an ECFA with China, he noted.
"The government will continue to give the people a clear explanation of the ECFA in order to win even greater public support for it," Ma said in response to questions from Hayashi.
In framing his questions, Hayashi citied the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) concerns over the possibility that the proposed pact would compromise Taiwan's independent statehood.

"It is critical that people understand the importance of the ECFA, as it will lead to a normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic activity and pave the way for similar negotiations with other countries," the president said.
If Taiwan and China fail to put an ECFA in place, Taiwan's petrochemical, car accessory, machinery and textile exports to China will be hit with custom duties of 10 to 15 percent, he said.

If these industries cannot survive in Taiwan and are forced to relocate to China or the ASEAN states in search of lower costs, this would result in 100,000 job losses in Taiwan, Ma said, citing estimates by economic research institutes.

The government-related Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) works to promote mutual trade and investment between Japan and the rest of the world. Originally established in 1958 to promote Japanese exports abroad, JETRO's focus has shifted toward promoting foreign direct investment in Japan and helping small to medium size Japanese firms maximize their global export potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% of office workers want to work in medical sectors: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly 75 percent of Taiwan's office workers would like to switch careers and work in the medical and related sectors, seeing the healthcare industry as insulated from the ups and downs of the economy, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey conducted by the online employment service 1111 Job Bank indicated that 74.96 percent of the office workers responding to the poll would like to switch to the medical field, given the opportunity.
When asked why, 44.91 percent of the respondents cited as the top reason their belief that medical-related businesses are least affected by economic downturns.

A large number of respondents - 43.96 percent - also said they would choose this field because medical businesses have bright prospects, while 25.66 percent of the people surveyed said they personally possess (medical-)related skills and knowledge.

Some 36.6 percent of the respondents said they would work in hospitals and general medical institutions; while 31.89 percent said they prefer pharmaceutical companies and medical products manufacturing companies.

In addition, 30.75 percent said they would like to work in food and biomedical companies; 27.92 percent in drug stores and pharmaceuticals retailers; and 21.89 percent in medical beauty clinics, according to the survey.

The online survey was conducted between June 5-18 among office workers, with 1,202 valid samples collected. It has a confidence level of 95 percentage points and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.02 to close at NT$32.898.
A total of US$619 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.908 and fluctuated between NT$32.820 and NT$32.916.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rise back above 6,300

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose back above the 6,300 mark Monday to finish higher for the second consecutive trading day, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 110.06 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at 6,341.21.
Following losses on Wall Street the previous Friday, the local bourse opened at 6,256.38 and dropped to 6,193.09 at one point before rising to the day's high of 6348.74.
A total of 3.51 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$95.55 billion (US$2.90 billion) , an increase of NT$12.58 billion over the previous session.

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 4.5 percent. Construction stocks rose 3 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 2.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 2.5 percent, foodstuff issues rose 0.9 percent, cement shares advanced 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares advanced 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares rose 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,461 to 693, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$3.13 billion in shares.

The market was buoyed by a strong showing among flat panel display makers due to soaring demand for television products, with HannStar Display Corp. and Innolux Display Corp. both rising by the maximum daily limit of 7 percent.

An investment analyst at Dah Chang Securities Co. said that as the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose above the five-day moving average but was still below the 10-day moving average of 6,353, the market would probably not drop below the 6,350-point level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate hit record high of 5.82% in May: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to 5.82 percent in May, the highest level since the government began compiling jobless figures in 1978, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Monday.

The number of jobless people increased to 633,000 in May -- also a record high since 1978, representing a growth of 8,000 jobless people from the previous month, said Huang Chien-chung, the deputy chief of the DGBAS' fourth division.
Huang attributed the increase in unemployment to graduate students seeking jobs after graduating recently.

The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for May stood at 5.84 percent, up 0.07 percentage points from the level in April. It marked the 14th consecutive month that Taiwan's jobless rate has been rising, Huang said.
The average jobless rate in the first five months of the year recorded was 5.69 percent, which also represented the highest level since 1978, the DGBAS statistics showed.

Meanwhile, Huang pointed out that the number of the employees in the industrial and services sectors amounted to 6.28 million people at the end of April, posing a decline of 15,000, or 0.24 percent, from the previous month.
This also marked a drop in the number of jobs in these two sectors for the eighth consecutive month since last September, Huang added.

The industrial and service sectors were the hardest hit by the economic downturn, which caused Taiwan's economy to contract by a record 10.24 percent in the first quarter and exports to plunge by as much as 30 percent in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural exchanges can promote Taiwan's profile: Israeli envoy

TEXT.P: Cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Israel is the perfect tool to not only serve as a bridge between the people of both sides but also to promote Taiwan's international profile, the top Israeli envoy to Taiwan said Monday.

Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , made the remarks at a tea party for Nimroda Markin, a retired Israeli psychotherapist who is visiting Taiwan to experience first-hand the cultural treasures of the country after being stuck by performances in Israel by U-Theatre, a renowned Taipei-based drumming group.
"Good cultural events are sometimes more powerful and effective than the words of a good diplomat," Gamzou said.
"This is a perfect example of how Taiwan's image is improved through cultural exchanges," he added.

Markin, who had never visited Asia before, traveled thousands of miles to Taiwan two weeks ago, where she was allowed to join the U-Theatre performers in rehearsals and vipassana activities, having been starstruck by the troupe and its act when it performed in Israel last year.

U-Theatre was invited to tour Israel through efforts by the ISECO and by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel Aviv, including a major opening performance at the Israel Spring Festival last March.

Describing the U-Theatre's performances as "magic on the stage" and the "sound of life, " Markin said she was left "speechless and breathless" after seeing them and decided immediately that she had to see with her own eyes the country and people that nurtured such spiritual performances.
"I kept asking myself what is it that moves me so deeply? It is the sense of holiness of life," Markin said.
"We Israelis might know how to respect the dead but we don't know how to respect life enough," she added.
Markin, who turned 70 in May, said that coming to Taiwan was a birthday present to herself and that the unique country, as well as its extremely friendly people, have owned her heart completely.
She has found Taiwan to be not only a combination of simplicity and sophistication but also a modern place with a touch of the West, so good that even the sound of the language is pleasant.

"I feel I am being treated as a guest rather than as a tourist or foreigner, " according to Markin, who added that the smiles and sincerity of the Taiwanese people and the discoveries of her stay in Taiwan are the best souvenirs for her family in Israel.
Scheduled to return to Israel in three days, Markin also said she had decided to learn Chinese and that she can't wait to come back to Taiwan in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tourist market has good potential: Alaska State's rep

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourist market has good potential and the number of Taiwanese travelers visiting Alaska is growing steadily despite the economic downturn, said the trade representative of the Taipei-based State of Alaska Office Monday.

The number of visitors from Taiwan to Alaska is pretty steady, some growth but very steady, given that there is some decline in other markets, Erick Kish told the Central News Agency at a news conference to launch Japan Airlines (JALs) summer aurora viewing tours to Fairbanks, Alaska.

An average of 5,000 people travel from Taiwan to Alaska annually. While most of them join cruises, a growing number of travelers are taking advantage of China Airlines' direct flights to Anchorage, according to Kish.
With the launch of the JAL aurora tours, Kish expressed confidence that more Taiwanese people will choose to visit Alaska.

Hiroshi Yamato, JAL Taiwan director of passenger sales, said on the same occasion that last December Taiwan became the first country to which JAL extended its charter service to Fairbanks. That service received great response from Taiwanese customers, he said.

This summer, JAL will offer five charter flights, leaving on Aug. 17, 22, 27 and Sept. 1, 7 from Taipei to Fairbanks via Tokyo, and more seats will be given to Taiwanese tourists if the demand continues to grow, Yamato added.

According to the State of Alaska Office, August and September are the best times to visit Alaska because the weather is pleasantly cool then and there are many clear nights, which are perfect for viewing aurora borealis, or northern polar lights.

In addition, visitors to Alaska at that time can choose from a wider variety of activities than if they were to visit in the winter. These include wildlife viewing, glacier cruise tours, airplane and helicopter tours, river rafting and biking, the Office said.
The State of Alaska Office in Taiwan is an official representative office of the Alaska state government that promotes tourism, trade, investment and educational exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film company chief calls for cooperation with China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's filmmaking industry should join hands with its Chinese counterpart to explore the global market, T. C. Guo, chairman of the Taipei-based Central Motion Pictures Corp. (CMPC), said Monday.

Although cooperation in this regard between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has been halted over the past decades due to political factors, Guo said cooperating with Chinese filmmakers will be an unavoidable trend for the local industry, especially if it wants to go international.

Although Guo said the popular Taiwan blockbuster "Cape No. 7" -- a locally produced movie shot in Kenting, a beach resort in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County -- seemed to help inject a new lease on life in Taiwan's filmmaking industry, Taiwan's filmmakers, including the CMPC, should collaborate with the Chinese side to explore new horizons.
"Taiwan's talent pool and China's huge and fast-growing market are complementary and can give a boost to Taiwan's filmmaking industry, "he suggested.
The CMPC has also began contacting Chinese filmmakers in its initial efforts to move toward that goal, Guo told a news conference prior to a ceremony held at the Government Information Office (GIO).

In the ceremony presided over by GIO Minister Su Jun-pin, Guo, on behalf of the CMPC, was to hand over a total of 947 old documentaries and movies to the GIO's Chinese Taipei Film Archive for conservation.
The old movies and documentaries were produced by the CMPC over the past 55 years.

In line with the government policy designating cultural innovation as one of Taiwan's six promising industries, Guo said he plans to make the CMPC's Culture City in the city's outskirts into a cultural innovation park.
Many CMPC pictures were shoot in its Culture City in the Shilin district when the company enjoyed a booming business during the 1960s-1970s.

Guo said it is his mission to push the CMPC to assume a bigger role in Taiwan's filmmaking history despite the fact that it used to be an enterprise run by the Kuomintang (KMT) and is saddled with historical burden.

Guo, a prominent businessman, is the chairman of Foxlink -- a leading developer and manufacturer of communication devices, computers and consumer electronics. He took over the CMPC's helm after acquiring a 42 percent stake of the filmmaking company from the KMT-owned Central Investment Corp. in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Storm fails to ease northern Taiwan drought conditions

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Linfa spread rainfall throughout Taiwan while sweeping up the Taiwan Strait over the weekend, but it apparently failed to alleviate drought conditions in the northern part of the island.

Water Resources Agency Deputy Director Wu Yueh-hsi said the storm -- the first tropical storm to hit Taiwan this year -- significantly boosted central and southern Taiwan's water supply to ease the potential of a looming drought there.

Two reservoirs in the southern county of Tainan -- the Wushantou and Nan Hua -- accumulated a combined 30 million cubic meters of rainwater from the storm, while the Tseng Wen Reservoir, which straddles Chiayi and Tainan counties, received about 16 million cubic meters of rainwater, Wu said.

The northern part of Taiwan was not so lucky, Wu said, as precipitation in the region fell far short of expectations. The water storage rate of Shihmen Reservoir, located in between Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties, only increased to 44.84 percent.
"Drought conditions still exist," Wu said.

Meanwhile, the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture said Monday that vegetable supplies around the island were normal and appeared not to have been affected by the tropical storm.
That means post-storm vegetable prices should remain stable, the agency said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to ask that oil used in fast food chains be monitored

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will ask local health bureaus to monitor the frying oil used in fast food outlets after spot checks found that some big name chains did not change the oil on a daily basis.

Liu Fang-ming, a DOH food safety official, said Monday that Taipei County consumer protection officials found in spot inspections of fast found restaurants such as McDonald's, KFC, Napoli Pizza, and Domino's Pizza on Sunday that one only changed the oil twice a week or partially.
The officials worried that the continued use of frying oil at high temperatures would result in the release of carcinogenic substances, thus posing a health hazard to consumers.
Liu said that the DOH will ask local health officials to "include the checking of frying oil as one of the priorities in monitoring food safety."

But he also acknowledged that the DOH could only ask officials to use their own eyes to "check the condition of the oil" and that it did not have the authority to regulate restaurants on how often they should use fresh oil.
Liu noted that restaurants' procedures on oil vary due to the method of cooking and the frequency of its use.

At present, no law exists stipulating how often virgin oil should be used. Officials can only determine if the texture of the oil has become unhealthy by viewing its color, foam formation and turbidity.
Health authorities can, however, slap a fine between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 on food operators if they notice the cooking oil has turned and failed to improve.
After Sunday's raids, Liu said he believed fast food restaurants will "more diligently change their frying oil, and that officials will probably not find anything for the time being."
He pointed out that fast food operators presently filter the used oil and mix it with new oil for reuse.
"The DOH will continue to communicate with the food vendors to work out a solution to the problem," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma set to depart June 29 for another diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is set to depart next Monday on another diplomatic tour that will take him to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras, an official announced Monday.

"The main purpose of President Ma's upcoming Central America tour is to attend the inauguration of Panama's president-elect, Ricardo Martinelli, in Panama City July 1, " said Javier Hou, vice minister of foreign affairs, at a Presidential Office news conference.

It will be Ma's second trip to the region this year. He concluded a three-leg Central America tour June 4, during which he attended El Salvador President Mauricio Funes's inaugural ceremony and visited two neighboring allies -- Belize and Guatemala.

In addition to attending Martinelli's inauguration, Ma will hold talks with senior officials of the new Panamanian government, tour the Panama Canal, give interviews to international news media and meet with Taiwanese community leaders during his stay in Panama, Hou said.

First lady Chow Mei-ching will accompany Ma on the June 29-July 7 diplomatic tour as she did on the president's last trip, Hou said, adding that Chow will visit a charity organization led by the new Panamanian first lady.

Following his trip to Panama, Ma will travel to Nicaragua where Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega will drive Ma to the hub of a bilateral technological cooperation project, which will allow Ma to have direct contact with Nicaraguan citizens.
Ma will also attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a large-scale trade fair to be held in Nicaragua July 1-5, in which many Taiwanese companies will exhibit their latest products, Hou said.
He indicated that Ma's cancellation of a planned meeting with Ortega in San Salvador early this month had not had any impact on relations between Taipei and Managua.

During the Nicaragua visit, first lady Chow will visit the local branch of the World Vision -- a Christian chairty dedicated to help disadvantaged people around the world -- and a disabled children's development center.
On the third and last leg of his tour, Ma will visit Honduras, where he will deliver a speech at the Honduran parliament and visit the site of a Taiwan- Honduras cooperative project.
Ma will make a transit stop in San Francisco en route to Panama and will stop in Hawaii on his way home.

As Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Ma has consistently kept a low profile and refrained from leaving the hotels where he was staying during his previous layovers.
Media reports said Ma is likely to walk out of his hotel during his forthcoming visit in Hawaii and may even hold a seminar with think tank scholars there.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, would not confirm the reports, however, saying instead that Ma's main principle is to "make things simple."
"Making a transit stop is our top goal and it remains uncertain whether there will be any activities outside the hotel," Wang added.

Accompanying Ma will be a 129-member delegation, composed of government officials, legislators, industry exeuctives, academics, university presidents, local government chiefs, charity group executives and performing artists.
Some 40 local journalists will be on hand to cover Ma's third diplomatic journey since he assumed office in May 2008, Hou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu swept aside by Federer at Wimbledon

TEXT.P: Having won a total of one match since early May, Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun figured to be an unlikely candidate to upset world No. 2 Roger Federer in the opening match on center court of this year's Wimbledon.
But the world No. 65 never held back during the 105-minute match, playing aggressively and trying to put pressure on Federer whenever he could before falling in 105 minutes, 7-5, 6-3, 6-2.
"He was tough and he hit some really good shots," Federer said of his game opponent.
"I knew the danger today. He's beaten good players in the past... That was a tough first set. He actually remained tough throughout the match, which was good to see, in a way."
Lu, playing at Wimbledon for the sixth time, had been sidetracked by a viral infection since winning a Challenger event in Israel the second week of May.

His grass court preparation consisted of two defeats and a victory over a British player ranked No. 493 in the world, not exactly an inspiring track record one would hope for ahead of a match against Federer on perhaps his favorite court in the world.
Lu showed some toughness early, saving four break points in the second game of the match and actually taking a 3-2 lead in the first set when he broke Federer's serve.
But Federer immediately returned the favor, and the two players stayed on serve until the final game of the set.
Lu had a chance to set up game point with a relatively simple drop volley, but could not push it over the net, and then he netted a backhand to give Federer the first set, 7-5.
Whatever tension may have existed seemed to evaporate after that game, and early Federer breaks in the second and third sets only added to the seeming inevitability of a victory for the Swiss.

As the match wore on, Federer's superior shot-making skills and serve became more assertive, and his almost effortless footwork often left him in control of the points, sending Lu chasing balls around the court or forcing him to rush to keep up with rapidly returned shots.
The world No. 2, gunning for an all-time best 15th grand slam title at Wimbledon, only lost 10 points on serve in the final two sets, giving Lu little chance to reassert himself.

Despite the straight set defeat, Lu played at a relatively high level, making only 11 unforced errors (to Federer's 10) , including only four in the first two sets, and he got nearly 70 percent of his first serves in, an unusually high percentage for the 25-year-old.
With the defeat of Lu, whose best showings at Wimbledon came in 2004 and 2005 when he reached the second round, Taiwan had one player left in a main singles draw at this year's Wimbledon.
Out of action for a good part of 2009 recovering from injury, Chan Yung-jan was to play 12th-seed Marion Bartoli of France later Monday in a first round women's singles match.

DOC.HEADLINE: More medical tourism groups from China to come

TEXT.P: Several medical tour groups from China will come to Taiwan in the latter part of the year, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Monday.
TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Walter Yeh said more groups were likely to come a day after the first 30-member medical tour group arrived from China for a six- day visit.
The first tour group members checked into four medical centers around the country Monday for physical examinations.

Thanks to the assistance of the TAITRA, the Guangzhou-based Zion Health Club reached an agreement in March with 13 medical centers and hospitals in Taiwan to organize medical tourism groups from China for the three-fold purpose of medical care, spa treatment and sightseeing.
Zion Health Club is a subsidiary of the Women's World Spa Resort Group -- a Taiwanese-financed company that has at least 600,000 members around China.
Yeh said that since last June to mid-June this year, the TAITRA has assisted 698 Chinese people to come to Taiwan for medical treatment and among them, 228 were for physical check-ups.
Lin Hwai, chairperson of Guangzhou's Women's World, said that after the first group, the next group of 50 members is scheduled to arrive in late August.
"There will be five or six such groups to arrive by next Chinese New Year," Lin said.
TAITRA officials said Taiwan's advanced medical facilities and high standard of medical professionals have attracted the medical tour groups.
It is estimated that one such group from the West Coast of the United States and two such groups from the East Coast, as well as several Chinese groups will arrive in the second half of this year.

With Chinese tourists coming from relatively high income brackets, if each of them spend NT$200,000 in Taiwan, coupled with the group fee of NT$60,000 and the full physical fee of NT$20,000, then the first Chinese medical tour group could inject NT$8.4 million into the local economy, TAITRA officials said.
Lin said that although the amount was not too high initially, it would definitely grow given the marked improvement in relations between Taiwan and China.
The TAITRA is scheduled to organize a group to visit northeastern China's Dalian and Qingdao this October to promote Taiwan's medical tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for June 23, 2009

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Marissa Mayer, Google's vice president, delivering a speech. Date and Time: 01:30 p.m., Tuesday, June 23, 2009. Place: Taipei International Convention Center's 101 conference hall, No.1, Xinyi Road, Sec.5, Taipei City. Press Contact: Tel. 2723-2535.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical tourism poised to create new business niche

TEXT.P: The arrival of a 30-member medical tour group from China Sunday marks a milestone in medical tourism development across the Taiwan Strait and is poised to create a new business niche, a corporate source said Monday.

The group from the Chinese city of Guangzhou for a six-day medical tour is expected to open an era for new business opportunities for Taiwan, although it could also lead to cutthroat competition among relevant businesses in the tourism, medical and insurance sectors, said Hung Zi-jen, vice president of the Shin Kong Medical Club.

According to Hung, thanks to the assistance of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, the Guangzhou-based Zion Health Club, which is a subsidiary of the Women's World Spa Resort Group -- a Taiwanese-financed company that has at least 600,000 members around China -- reached an agreement in March with 13 medical centers and hospitals in Taiwan to organize medical tourism groups from China for three-fold purpose of medical care, spa treatment and sightseeing.
The first tour group members checked into four medical centers around the country Monday for physical examinations.

Five of the 30-strong group received health checks at Cathay General Hospital in Taipei City, while the others had their physical examinations at Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in Taipei, Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung Medical University Chung Ho Memorial Hospital in the south.

With cross-strait charter flights set to be increased to regular daily flights, later this year, Hung said he is confident that Taiwan is capable of capitalizing on the golden opportunity offered by medical tourism, taking full advantage of its many signature tourist attractions and high-quality medical services.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abandoned rabbits increasing, councilor urges measures

TEXT.P: Two rabbit rescue organizations have urged the Taipei city government to adopt a more active approach toward dealing with the problem of abandoned animals other than cats and dogs.
In response to the call, Yen I-feng, director of the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health, vowed to further cooperate with animal organizations to stop people abandoning their pets.
He made the remarks Monday following a campaign initiated a day earlier by the Taipei Rabbit Society and a rabbit adoption Web site.

At a function Sunday that was part of the campaign, a group of "bunny girls" -- volunteers from the two groups, along with Taipei City Councilor Wu Ssu-yao, dressed up like Playboy bunnies -- promoted an "I love rabbits " campaign, displaying abandoned pet rabbits that had been rescued from city streets.

Wu claimed that rabbits kept as pets carry and transmit fewer zoonotic diseases than cats and dogs and noted that they require relatively smaller living space than cats or dogs. She therefore asked the institute to extend the seven-day limit for killing unwanted rabbits.

Yen emphasized that animals should be treated equally without discrimination and condemned owners who dump their pets. He also vowed to cooperate further with animal protection groups to stop people abandoning animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Daughter, son-in-law of ex-president admit giving false testimony

TEXT.P: The daughter and son-in-law of former President Chen Shui-bian admitted Monday that they gave false testimony over the past two years during investigations into the ex-first family's alleged corruption and money laundering.

Chen Hsing-yu and her husband, Chao Chien-ming, admitted in court that they gave false testimony on various occasions to prosecutors and judges regarding the case involving their mother, Wu Shu-jen, and her claims for reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million (US$451,219) from her husband's special state affairs funds using invoices she took from other people, according to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office.
The prosecutors, however, declined to divulge the identity of the individual or individuals Chao and Chen named as having instructed them to lie.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office decided in mid-May to list the couple as defendants, as well as Chen's younger brother Chen Chih-chung, after discovering that the three gave different accounts during investigations into the false reimbursement case.
Chen Hsing-yu was indicted June 3, making her the final member of the scandal- embroiled ex-first family to be indicted on corruption and money laundering charges.
She was listed June 5 as a person whose movements in relation to attempted overseas travel should be monitored by prosecutors, a step below an outright travel ban.

All 14 of the other people in the family, including former President Chen Shui- bian, his wife Wu Shu-jen, their son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, have been indicted since 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think tank adjusts upward economic forecast for Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Polaris Research Institute adjusted its economic forecast for Taiwan Monday, predicting that the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) will shrink 4.6 percent in 2009, instead of 4.8 percent it had previously forecast.

The economic outlook was the most pessimistic among the forecasts issued by economic research institutes in Taiwan, including the government Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics which predicted in May a GDP contraction of 4.25 percent this year.
Academia Sinica predicted a drop of 3.46 percent, while the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research forecast a slight shrinkage of 0.11 percent.

Polaris President Liang Kuo-yuan released the latest forecast at a press conference, saying that while "Taiwan's economy is improving, " it is doing so on a small scale because there are still negative factors affecting its recovery, such as a decrease in foreign orders.
However, Liang forecast that the economy will record growth of 3.87 percent in the fourth quarter of this year.
Meanwhile, he raised the consumers' price index growth forecast to "-0.78 percent" for 2009 due to increases in the price of raw material on the international market recently.
The value of the New Taiwan dollar will average NT$33.4 against the greenback in 2009, Liang said.

While the improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties will help attract foreign investment to support the Taiwan dollar's exchange rate, a drastic appreciation is not likely this year as the U.S. Federal Reserve Board may raise interest rate to back the greenback, according to Liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA unrelated to independence-unification issue: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Monday that Taiwan's planned trade pact with China is simply an economic matter and will not touch on the independence or the unification issue or undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.

"Taiwan and China should ink an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) to avoid Taiwan's marginalization in East Asia, as a free trade agreement (FTA) among China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is set to take effect next January, " Ma said in a meeting with Yasuo Hayashi, chairman of Japan's External Trade Organization, at the Presidential Office.

"We feel it necessary to open the talks with China as quickly as possible, in view of the China-ASEAN FTA, which will allow zero tariffs on exports from either side and thus greatly hurt Taiwan's competitiveness," the president said.
The results of recent surveys showed that some 60 percent of the Taiwan people endorsed the government's efforts to clinch an ECFA with China, he noted.
"The government will continue to give the people a clear explanation of the ECFA in order to win even greater public support for it," Ma said in response to questions from Hayashi.
In framing his questions, Hayashi citied the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) concerns over the possibility that the proposed pact would compromise Taiwan's independent statehood.

"It is critical that people understand the importance of the ECFA, as it will lead to a normalization of cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic activity and pave the way for similar negotiations with other countries," the president said.
If Taiwan and China fail to put an ECFA in place, Taiwan's petrochemical, car accessory, machinery and textile exports to China will be hit with custom duties of 10 to 15 percent, he said.

If these industries cannot survive in Taiwan and are forced to relocate to China or the ASEAN states in search of lower costs, this would result in 100,000 job losses in Taiwan, Ma said, citing estimates by economic research institutes.

The government-related Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) works to promote mutual trade and investment between Japan and the rest of the world. Originally established in 1958 to promote Japanese exports abroad, JETRO's focus has shifted toward promoting foreign direct investment in Japan and helping small to medium size Japanese firms maximize their global export potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% of office workers want to work in medical sectors: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly 75 percent of Taiwan's office workers would like to switch careers and work in the medical and related sectors, seeing the healthcare industry as insulated from the ups and downs of the economy, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The survey conducted by the online employment service 1111 Job Bank indicated that 74.96 percent of the office workers responding to the poll would like to switch to the medical field, given the opportunity.
When asked why, 44.91 percent of the respondents cited as the top reason their belief that medical-related businesses are least affected by economic downturns.

A large number of respondents - 43.96 percent - also said they would choose this field because medical businesses have bright prospects, while 25.66 percent of the people surveyed said they personally possess (medical-)related skills and knowledge.

Some 36.6 percent of the respondents said they would work in hospitals and general medical institutions; while 31.89 percent said they prefer pharmaceutical companies and medical products manufacturing companies.

In addition, 30.75 percent said they would like to work in food and biomedical companies; 27.92 percent in drug stores and pharmaceuticals retailers; and 21.89 percent in medical beauty clinics, according to the survey.

The online survey was conducted between June 5-18 among office workers, with 1,202 valid samples collected. It has a confidence level of 95 percentage points and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.02 to close at NT$32.898.
A total of US$619 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.908 and fluctuated between NT$32.820 and NT$32.916.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices rise back above 6,300

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose back above the 6,300 mark Monday to finish higher for the second consecutive trading day, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 110.06 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at 6,341.21.
Following losses on Wall Street the previous Friday, the local bourse opened at 6,256.38 and dropped to 6,193.09 at one point before rising to the day's high of 6348.74.
A total of 3.51 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$95.55 billion (US$2.90 billion) , an increase of NT$12.58 billion over the previous session.

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 4.5 percent. Construction stocks rose 3 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 2.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 2.5 percent, foodstuff issues rose 0.9 percent, cement shares advanced 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares advanced 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares rose 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,461 to 693, with 156 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$3.13 billion in shares.

The market was buoyed by a strong showing among flat panel display makers due to soaring demand for television products, with HannStar Display Corp. and Innolux Display Corp. both rising by the maximum daily limit of 7 percent.

An investment analyst at Dah Chang Securities Co. said that as the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose above the five-day moving average but was still below the 10-day moving average of 6,353, the market would probably not drop below the 6,350-point level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unemployment rate hit record high of 5.82% in May: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to 5.82 percent in May, the highest level since the government began compiling jobless figures in 1978, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Monday.

The number of jobless people increased to 633,000 in May -- also a record high since 1978, representing a growth of 8,000 jobless people from the previous month, said Huang Chien-chung, the deputy chief of the DGBAS' fourth division.
Huang attributed the increase in unemployment to graduate students seeking jobs after graduating recently.

The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for May stood at 5.84 percent, up 0.07 percentage points from the level in April. It marked the 14th consecutive month that Taiwan's jobless rate has been rising, Huang said.
The average jobless rate in the first five months of the year recorded was 5.69 percent, which also represented the highest level since 1978, the DGBAS statistics showed.

Meanwhile, Huang pointed out that the number of the employees in the industrial and services sectors amounted to 6.28 million people at the end of April, posing a decline of 15,000, or 0.24 percent, from the previous month.
This also marked a drop in the number of jobs in these two sectors for the eighth consecutive month since last September, Huang added.

The industrial and service sectors were the hardest hit by the economic downturn, which caused Taiwan's economy to contract by a record 10.24 percent in the first quarter and exports to plunge by as much as 30 percent in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural exchanges can promote Taiwan's profile: Israeli envoy

TEXT.P: Cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Israel is the perfect tool to not only serve as a bridge between the people of both sides but also to promote Taiwan's international profile, the top Israeli envoy to Taiwan said Monday.

Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , made the remarks at a tea party for Nimroda Markin, a retired Israeli psychotherapist who is visiting Taiwan to experience first-hand the cultural treasures of the country after being stuck by performances in Israel by U-Theatre, a renowned Taipei-based drumming group.
"Good cultural events are sometimes more powerful and effective than the words of a good diplomat," Gamzou said.
"This is a perfect example of how Taiwan's image is improved through cultural exchanges," he added.

Markin, who had never visited Asia before, traveled thousands of miles to Taiwan two weeks ago, where she was allowed to join the U-Theatre performers in rehearsals and vipassana activities, having been starstruck by the troupe and its act when it performed in Israel last year.

U-Theatre was invited to tour Israel through efforts by the ISECO and by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tel Aviv, including a major opening performance at the Israel Spring Festival last March.

Describing the U-Theatre's performances as "magic on the stage" and the "sound of life, " Markin said she was left "speechless and breathless" after seeing them and decided immediately that she had to see with her own eyes the country and people that nurtured such spiritual performances.
"I kept asking myself what is it that moves me so deeply? It is the sense of holiness of life," Markin said.
"We Israelis might know how to respect the dead but we don't know how to respect life enough," she added.
Markin, who turned 70 in May, said that coming to Taiwan was a birthday present to herself and that the unique country, as well as its extremely friendly people, have owned her heart completely.
She has found Taiwan to be not only a combination of simplicity and sophistication but also a modern place with a touch of the West, so good that even the sound of the language is pleasant.

"I feel I am being treated as a guest rather than as a tourist or foreigner, " according to Markin, who added that the smiles and sincerity of the Taiwanese people and the discoveries of her stay in Taiwan are the best souvenirs for her family in Israel.
Scheduled to return to Israel in three days, Markin also said she had decided to learn Chinese and that she can't wait to come back to Taiwan in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tourist market has good potential: Alaska State's rep

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourist market has good potential and the number of Taiwanese travelers visiting Alaska is growing steadily despite the economic downturn, said the trade representative of the Taipei-based State of Alaska Office Monday.

The number of visitors from Taiwan to Alaska is pretty steady, some growth but very steady, given that there is some decline in other markets, Erick Kish told the Central News Agency at a news conference to launch Japan Airlines (JALs) summer aurora viewing tours to Fairbanks, Alaska.

An average of 5,000 people travel from Taiwan to Alaska annually. While most of them join cruises, a growing number of travelers are taking advantage of China Airlines' direct flights to Anchorage, according to Kish.
With the launch of the JAL aurora tours, Kish expressed confidence that more Taiwanese people will choose to visit Alaska.

Hiroshi Yamato, JAL Taiwan director of passenger sales, said on the same occasion that last December Taiwan became the first country to which JAL extended its charter service to Fairbanks. That service received great response from Taiwanese customers, he said.

This summer, JAL will offer five charter flights, leaving on Aug. 17, 22, 27 and Sept. 1, 7 from Taipei to Fairbanks via Tokyo, and more seats will be given to Taiwanese tourists if the demand continues to grow, Yamato added.

According to the State of Alaska Office, August and September are the best times to visit Alaska because the weather is pleasantly cool then and there are many clear nights, which are perfect for viewing aurora borealis, or northern polar lights.

In addition, visitors to Alaska at that time can choose from a wider variety of activities than if they were to visit in the winter. These include wildlife viewing, glacier cruise tours, airplane and helicopter tours, river rafting and biking, the Office said.
The State of Alaska Office in Taiwan is an official representative office of the Alaska state government that promotes tourism, trade, investment and educational exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film company chief calls for cooperation with China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's filmmaking industry should join hands with its Chinese counterpart to explore the global market, T. C. Guo, chairman of the Taipei-based Central Motion Pictures Corp. (CMPC), said Monday.

Although cooperation in this regard between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has been halted over the past decades due to political factors, Guo said cooperating with Chinese filmmakers will be an unavoidable trend for the local industry, especially if it wants to go international.

Although Guo said the popular Taiwan blockbuster "Cape No. 7" -- a locally produced movie shot in Kenting, a beach resort in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County -- seemed to help inject a new lease on life in Taiwan's filmmaking industry, Taiwan's filmmakers, including the CMPC, should collaborate with the Chinese side to explore new horizons.
"Taiwan's talent pool and China's huge and fast-growing market are complementary and can give a boost to Taiwan's filmmaking industry, "he suggested.
The CMPC has also began contacting Chinese filmmakers in its initial efforts to move toward that goal, Guo told a news conference prior to a ceremony held at the Government Information Office (GIO).

In the ceremony presided over by GIO Minister Su Jun-pin, Guo, on behalf of the CMPC, was to hand over a total of 947 old documentaries and movies to the GIO's Chinese Taipei Film Archive for conservation.
The old movies and documentaries were produced by the CMPC over the past 55 years.

In line with the government policy designating cultural innovation as one of Taiwan's six promising industries, Guo said he plans to make the CMPC's Culture City in the city's outskirts into a cultural innovation park.
Many CMPC pictures were shoot in its Culture City in the Shilin district when the company enjoyed a booming business during the 1960s-1970s.

Guo said it is his mission to push the CMPC to assume a bigger role in Taiwan's filmmaking history despite the fact that it used to be an enterprise run by the Kuomintang (KMT) and is saddled with historical burden.

Guo, a prominent businessman, is the chairman of Foxlink -- a leading developer and manufacturer of communication devices, computers and consumer electronics. He took over the CMPC's helm after acquiring a 42 percent stake of the filmmaking company from the KMT-owned Central Investment Corp. in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Storm fails to ease northern Taiwan drought conditions

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Linfa spread rainfall throughout Taiwan while sweeping up the Taiwan Strait over the weekend, but it apparently failed to alleviate drought conditions in the northern part of the island.

Water Resources Agency Deputy Director Wu Yueh-hsi said the storm -- the first tropical storm to hit Taiwan this year -- significantly boosted central and southern Taiwan's water supply to ease the potential of a looming drought there.

Two reservoirs in the southern county of Tainan -- the Wushantou and Nan Hua -- accumulated a combined 30 million cubic meters of rainwater from the storm, while the Tseng Wen Reservoir, which straddles Chiayi and Tainan counties, received about 16 million cubic meters of rainwater, Wu said.

The northern part of Taiwan was not so lucky, Wu said, as precipitation in the region fell far short of expectations. The water storage rate of Shihmen Reservoir, located in between Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties, only increased to 44.84 percent.
"Drought conditions still exist," Wu said.

Meanwhile, the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture said Monday that vegetable supplies around the island were normal and appeared not to have been affected by the tropical storm.
That means post-storm vegetable prices should remain stable, the agency said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to ask that oil used in fast food chains be monitored

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will ask local health bureaus to monitor the frying oil used in fast food outlets after spot checks found that some big name chains did not change the oil on a daily basis.

Liu Fang-ming, a DOH food safety official, said Monday that Taipei County consumer protection officials found in spot inspections of fast found restaurants such as McDonald's, KFC, Napoli Pizza, and Domino's Pizza on Sunday that one only changed the oil twice a week or partially.
The officials worried that the continued use of frying oil at high temperatures would result in the release of carcinogenic substances, thus posing a health hazard to consumers.
Liu said that the DOH will ask local health officials to "include the checking of frying oil as one of the priorities in monitoring food safety."

But he also acknowledged that the DOH could only ask officials to use their own eyes to "check the condition of the oil" and that it did not have the authority to regulate restaurants on how often they should use fresh oil.
Liu noted that restaurants' procedures on oil vary due to the method of cooking and the frequency of its use.

At present, no law exists stipulating how often virgin oil should be used. Officials can only determine if the texture of the oil has become unhealthy by viewing its color, foam formation and turbidity.
Health authorities can, however, slap a fine between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 on food operators if they notice the cooking oil has turned and failed to improve.
After Sunday's raids, Liu said he believed fast food restaurants will "more diligently change their frying oil, and that officials will probably not find anything for the time being."
He pointed out that fast food operators presently filter the used oil and mix it with new oil for reuse.
"The DOH will continue to communicate with the food vendors to work out a solution to the problem," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma set to depart June 29 for another diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is set to depart next Monday on another diplomatic tour that will take him to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras, an official announced Monday.

"The main purpose of President Ma's upcoming Central America tour is to attend the inauguration of Panama's president-elect, Ricardo Martinelli, in Panama City July 1, " said Javier Hou, vice minister of foreign affairs, at a Presidential Office news conference.

It will be Ma's second trip to the region this year. He concluded a three-leg Central America tour June 4, during which he attended El Salvador President Mauricio Funes's inaugural ceremony and visited two neighboring allies -- Belize and Guatemala.

In addition to attending Martinelli's inauguration, Ma will hold talks with senior officials of the new Panamanian government, tour the Panama Canal, give interviews to international news media and meet with Taiwanese community leaders during his stay in Panama, Hou said.

First lady Chow Mei-ching will accompany Ma on the June 29-July 7 diplomatic tour as she did on the president's last trip, Hou said, adding that Chow will visit a charity organization led by the new Panamanian first lady.

Following his trip to Panama, Ma will travel to Nicaragua where Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega will drive Ma to the hub of a bilateral technological cooperation project, which will allow Ma to have direct contact with Nicaraguan citizens.
Ma will also attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a large-scale trade fair to be held in Nicaragua July 1-5, in which many Taiwanese companies will exhibit their latest products, Hou said.
He indicated that Ma's cancellation of a planned meeting with Ortega in San Salvador early this month had not had any impact on relations between Taipei and Managua.

During the Nicaragua visit, first lady Chow will visit the local branch of the World Vision -- a Christian chairty dedicated to help disadvantaged people around the world -- and a disabled children's development center.
On the third and last leg of his tour, Ma will visit Honduras, where he will deliver a speech at the Honduran parliament and visit the site of a Taiwan- Honduras cooperative project.
Ma will make a transit stop in San Francisco en route to Panama and will stop in Hawaii on his way home.

As Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Ma has consistently kept a low profile and refrained from leaving the hotels where he was staying during his previous layovers.
Media reports said Ma is likely to walk out of his hotel during his forthcoming visit in Hawaii and may even hold a seminar with think tank scholars there.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, would not confirm the reports, however, saying instead that Ma's main principle is to "make things simple."
"Making a transit stop is our top goal and it remains uncertain whether there will be any activities outside the hotel," Wang added.

Accompanying Ma will be a 129-member delegation, composed of government officials, legislators, industry exeuctives, academics, university presidents, local government chiefs, charity group executives and performing artists.
Some 40 local journalists will be on hand to cover Ma's third diplomatic journey since he assumed office in May 2008, Hou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu swept aside by Federer at Wimbledon

TEXT.P: Having won a total of one match since early May, Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun figured to be an unlikely candidate to upset world No. 2 Roger Federer in the opening match on center court of this year's Wimbledon.
But the world No. 65 never held back during the 105-minute match, playing aggressively and trying to put pressure on Federer whenever he could before falling in 105 minutes, 7-5, 6-3, 6-2.
"He was tough and he hit some really good shots," Federer said of his game opponent.
"I knew the danger today. He's beaten good players in the past... That was a tough first set. He actually remained tough throughout the match, which was good to see, in a way."
Lu, playing at Wimbledon for the sixth time, had been sidetracked by a viral infection since winning a Challenger event in Israel the second week of May.

His grass court preparation consisted of two defeats and a victory over a British player ranked No. 493 in the world, not exactly an inspiring track record one would hope for ahead of a match against Federer on perhaps his favorite court in the world.
Lu showed some toughness early, saving four break points in the second game of the match and actually taking a 3-2 lead in the first set when he broke Federer's serve.
But Federer immediately returned the favor, and the two players stayed on serve until the final game of the set.
Lu had a chance to set up game point with a relatively simple drop volley, but could not push it over the net, and then he netted a backhand to give Federer the first set, 7-5.
Whatever tension may have existed seemed to evaporate after that game, and early Federer breaks in the second and third sets only added to the seeming inevitability of a victory for the Swiss.

As the match wore on, Federer's superior shot-making skills and serve became more assertive, and his almost effortless footwork often left him in control of the points, sending Lu chasing balls around the court or forcing him to rush to keep up with rapidly returned shots.
The world No. 2, gunning for an all-time best 15th grand slam title at Wimbledon, only lost 10 points on serve in the final two sets, giving Lu little chance to reassert himself.

Despite the straight set defeat, Lu played at a relatively high level, making only 11 unforced errors (to Federer's 10) , including only four in the first two sets, and he got nearly 70 percent of his first serves in, an unusually high percentage for the 25-year-old.
With the defeat of Lu, whose best showings at Wimbledon came in 2004 and 2005 when he reached the second round, Taiwan had one player left in a main singles draw at this year's Wimbledon.
Out of action for a good part of 2009 recovering from injury, Chan Yung-jan was to play 12th-seed Marion Bartoli of France later Monday in a first round women's singles match.

DOC.HEADLINE: More medical tourism groups from China to come

TEXT.P: Several medical tour groups from China will come to Taiwan in the latter part of the year, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Monday.
TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Walter Yeh said more groups were likely to come a day after the first 30-member medical tour group arrived from China for a six- day visit.
The first tour group members checked into four medical centers around the country Monday for physical examinations.

Thanks to the assistance of the TAITRA, the Guangzhou-based Zion Health Club reached an agreement in March with 13 medical centers and hospitals in Taiwan to organize medical tourism groups from China for the three-fold purpose of medical care, spa treatment and sightseeing.
Zion Health Club is a subsidiary of the Women's World Spa Resort Group -- a Taiwanese-financed company that has at least 600,000 members around China.
Yeh said that since last June to mid-June this year, the TAITRA has assisted 698 Chinese people to come to Taiwan for medical treatment and among them, 228 were for physical check-ups.
Lin Hwai, chairperson of Guangzhou's Women's World, said that after the first group, the next group of 50 members is scheduled to arrive in late August.
"There will be five or six such groups to arrive by next Chinese New Year," Lin said.
TAITRA officials said Taiwan's advanced medical facilities and high standard of medical professionals have attracted the medical tour groups.
It is estimated that one such group from the West Coast of the United States and two such groups from the East Coast, as well as several Chinese groups will arrive in the second half of this year.

With Chinese tourists coming from relatively high income brackets, if each of them spend NT$200,000 in Taiwan, coupled with the group fee of NT$60,000 and the full physical fee of NT$20,000, then the first Chinese medical tour group could inject NT$8.4 million into the local economy, TAITRA officials said.
Lin said that although the amount was not too high initially, it would definitely grow given the marked improvement in relations between Taiwan and China.
The TAITRA is scheduled to organize a group to visit northeastern China's Dalian and Qingdao this October to promote Taiwan's medical tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 23, or the first day of the leap fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way
back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and
religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of
Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent
for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best
known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer
expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary
Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected
director-general.
1922: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Ting-fang,
who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying
that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social
Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival
returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi
and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes
off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law
during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate
membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in
California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation
agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao meets with
Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. ROC-Macedonia diplomatic ties ended less than a year later when Macedonian pro-Beijing forces gained the upper hand in the nation's coalition government and transferred diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
2001: The Navy General Headquarters says that it has commissioned
a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

Lin said that although the amount was not too high initially, it would definitely grow given the marked improvement in relations between Taiwan and China.
The TAITRA is scheduled to organize a group to visit northeastern China's Dalian and Qingdao this October to promote Taiwan's medical tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu swept aside by Federer at Wimbledon

TEXT.P: Having won a total of one match since early May, Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun figured to be an unlikely candidate to upset world No. 2 Roger Federer in the opening match on center court of this year's Wimbledon.
But the world No. 65 never held back during the 105-minute match, playing aggressively and trying to put pressure on Federer whenever he could before falling in 105 minutes, 7-5, 6-3, 6-2.
"He was tough and he hit some really good shots," Federer said of his game opponent.
"I knew the danger today. He's beaten good players in the past... That was a tough first set. He actually remained tough throughout the match, which was good to see, in a way."
Lu, playing at Wimbledon for the sixth time, had been sidetracked by a viral infection since winning a Challenger event in Israel the second week of May.

His grass court preparation consisted of two defeats and a victory over a British player ranked No. 493 in the world, not exactly an inspiring track record one would hope for ahead of a match against Federer on perhaps his favorite court in the world.
Lu showed some toughness early, saving four break points in the second game of the match and actually taking a 3-2 lead in the first set when he broke Federer's serve.
But Federer immediately returned the favor, and the two players stayed on serve until the final game of the set.
Lu had a chance to set up game point with a relatively simple drop volley, but could not push it over the net, and then he netted a backhand to give Federer the first set, 7-5.
Whatever tension may have existed seemed to evaporate after that game, and early Federer breaks in the second and third sets only added to the seeming inevitability of a victory for the Swiss.

As the match wore on, Federer's superior shot-making skills and serve became more assertive, and his almost effortless footwork often left him in control of the points, sending Lu chasing balls around the court or forcing him to rush to keep up with rapidly returned shots.
The world No. 2, gunning for an all-time best 15th grand slam title at Wimbledon, only lost 10 points on serve in the final two sets, giving Lu little chance to reassert himself.

Despite the straight set defeat, Lu played at a relatively high level, making only 11 unforced errors (to Federer's 10) , including only four in the first two sets, and he got nearly 70 percent of his first serves in, an unusually high percentage for the 25-year-old.
With the defeat of Lu, whose best showings at Wimbledon came in 2004 and 2005 when he reached the second round, Taiwan had one player left in a main singles draw at this year's Wimbledon.
Out of action for a good part of 2009 recovering from injury, Chan Yung-jan was to play 12th-seed Marion Bartoli of France later Monday in a first round women's singles match.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma set to depart June 29 for another diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is set to depart next Monday on another diplomatic tour that will take him to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras, an official announced Monday.

"The main purpose of President Ma's upcoming Central America tour is to attend the inauguration of Panama's president-elect, Ricardo Martinelli, in Panama City July 1, " said Javier Hou, vice minister of foreign affairs, at a Presidential Office news conference.

It will be Ma's second trip to the region this year. He concluded a three-leg Central America tour June 4, during which he attended El Salvador President Mauricio Funes's inaugural ceremony and visited two neighboring allies -- Belize and Guatemala.

In addition to attending Martinelli's inauguration, Ma will hold talks with senior officials of the new Panamanian government, tour the Panama Canal, give interviews to international news media and meet with Taiwanese community leaders during his stay in Panama, Hou said.

First lady Chow Mei-ching will accompany Ma on the June 29-July 7 diplomatic tour as she did on the president's last trip, Hou said, adding that Chow will visit a charity organization led by the new Panamanian first lady.

Following his trip to Panama, Ma will travel to Nicaragua where Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega will drive Ma to the hub of a bilateral technological cooperation project, which will allow Ma to have direct contact with Nicaraguan citizens.
Ma will also attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a large-scale trade fair to be held in Nicaragua July 1-5, in which many Taiwanese companies will exhibit their latest products, Hou said.
He indicated that Ma's cancellation of a planned meeting with Ortega in San Salvador early this month had not had any impact on relations between Taipei and Managua.

During the Nicaragua visit, first lady Chow will visit the local branch of the World Vision -- a Christian chairty dedicated to help disadvantaged people around the world -- and a disabled children's development center.
On the third and last leg of his tour, Ma will visit Honduras, where he will deliver a speech at the Honduran parliament and visit the site of a Taiwan- Honduras cooperative project.
Ma will make a transit stop in San Francisco en route to Panama and will stop in Hawaii on his way home.

As Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Ma has consistently kept a low profile and refrained from leaving the hotels where he was staying during his previous layovers.
Media reports said Ma is likely to walk out of his hotel during his forthcoming visit in Hawaii and may even hold a seminar with think tank scholars there.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, would not confirm the reports, however, saying instead that Ma's main principle is to "make things simple."
"Making a transit stop is our top goal and it remains uncertain whether there will be any activities outside the hotel," Wang added.

Accompanying Ma will be a 129-member delegation, composed of government officials, legislators, industry exeuctives, academics, university presidents, local government chiefs, charity group executives and performing artists.
Some 40 local journalists will be on hand to cover Ma's third diplomatic journey since he assumed office in May 2008, Hou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Opening Taiwan to U.S. beef in final stage of discussions: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States are currently conducting final negotiations on the controversial issue of fully opening Taiwan's market to U.S. beef, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Both sides are engaged in intensive final discussions, said Harry Tseng, director-general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, at regular press briefing.
Technical negotiations, he said, are being carried out by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Office of Trade Negotiations, the Council of Agriculture and the Department of Health (DOH).
"The Foreign Ministry is involved in the process, but I cannot comment on the details,he added.
Pressed on whether the issue could be resolved this year, Tseng said he is optimistic over the timeline.

The U.S. currently supplies 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, but under existing DOH regulations, only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced from certified slaughterhouses and without high-risk items such as brains and spinal cord marrow, can be imported to Taiwan.
Stephen M. Young, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan, has repeatedly urged Taiwan government to make a science-based decision on fully opening its market to U.S. beef.
All of Taiwan's scientific review and technical work indicates that U.S. beef does not pose a threat of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, Young has contended.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of BSE was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the local government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-April wages decline at record rate

TEXT.P: Wage data released by Taiwan's statistics bureau Monday showed that local workers have had to confront a record decline in their nominal and real incomes during the first four months of 2009.

The average monthly income of local employees between January to April fell by a record 8.54 percent year-on-year to NT$47,107, a Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) official said Monday.
The average regular monthly wage also contracted during the same period by a record 3.04 percent to NT$35,488, according to Huang Chien-chung, deputy director of the Fourth Bureau of the DGBAS.

The average monthly wage includes regular wages (salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses) plus overtime, and other non-regular wages (performance bonuses, year-end bonuses, and employee bonuses).

Real monthly income and the real regular monthly wage, which take into account the impact of inflation on wages, fell by 8.44 percent and 2.93 percent respectively, Huang said, after the consumer price index declined 0.12 percent during the first four months of the year.
All four income measures posted the steepest four-month declines since they were first compiled in 1980, Huang noted.

Nominal regular wages contracted by more than 2 percent every month between November and April, the statistics also showed. They fell by 2.52 percent in November, 3.41 percent in December, 4.63 percent in January, 2.56 percent in February, 2.39 percent in March, and 2.56 percent in April.
Huang attributed the persistent decline to the sagging commercial activity of domestic manufacturers as a result of the global economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma to make public appearances in Hawaii: MOFA

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will make public appearances in Hawaii in early July during a transit stop on his way home from a state visit to Central America, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Tuesday.

"There will be some different activities for President Ma during his transit stop in Hawaii, including public visits, said Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, at a regular press briefing.

While the press guidelines of the U.S. State Department remain unchanged -- Taiwanese media accompanying the president cannot report on his visits on U.S. soil -- Tseng said that taking pictures of Ma from a certain distance may be understandable on the part of the U.S. government.
Tseng declined, however, to disclose the destinations that Ma would visit.
Ma is set to depart next Monday on another diplomatic tour that will take him to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras.
The president will make a transit stop in San Francisco en route to Panama and will stop in Hawaii on his way home.

As Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Ma has consistently kept a low profile and refrained from leaving the hotels where he was staying during his previous layovers, making only phone calls or receiving some members of the U.S. Congress.
Hawaii might be the first time Ma makes a public appearance during similar transit stops in the U.S.
The main focus of Ma's trip will be to attend the inauguration ceremony of Panama's president-elect, Ricardo Martinelli, on July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu picks up confidence and a new coach in loss to Federer
DOC.DATELINE: London/Taipei, June 23 (CNA) 06/23/09 14:40:05 (By Jennifer Huang and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun was swept aside in straight sets by world No. 2 Roger Federer in a first round men's singles match at Wimbledon Monday, but he emerged from the encounter with more confidence and a new coach.
