Lu, who had been struggling to recover from an energy-sapping virus since mid- May, lost to the five-time Wimbledon champion 7-5, 6-3, 6-2 in 105 minutes, but he told the Central News Agency afterwards that holding a 3-2 lead in the first set despite a heavy bout of nerves left him more confident than ever.

"It had a real motivating effect, because it made me understand that even against a top player like Federer, I could still be competitive and fight to the end, " Lu said. "To have a good showing against a heavyweight is not an impossibility."

Lu struggled for much of his career against top-ranked players before defeating top 10 players Andy Murray in the Olympics in Beijing in 2008 and Argentine David Nalbandian in the second round of this year's Australian Open.
After Monday's match, even Federer came away impressed.

"I thought he played excellent. He's a wonderful player. He has got a nice forehand, a nice backhand, very sound game all around, " Federer said. "I knew the danger today. He's beaten good players in the past."

Although Lu said he learned a lot during the match and described playing him on perhaps the biggest stage in men's tennis -- center court at Wimbledon -- as a "special experience," it was not his dream draw.

"When the draw first came out, I thought I was really unlucky because I really felt comfortable on the grass surface. My coach told me beforehand that as long as I didn't draw Federer, I had a chance against any of the other 126 players entered."
The loss to Federer meant Lu was eliminated from Wimbledon for the fourth time in six tries, with his best showings second round finishes in 2004 and 2005.
His best performance in a grand slam singles event came at this year's Australian Open, when he reached the third round.

Lu said his stamina was not 100 percent against Federer, as he only began training in earnest 10 days ago after a blood test in England found everything was normal, and that he still needs time to regain his prior level of conditioning, but now he'll have extra incentive.

Former Australian doubles great Mark Woodforde, who won 12 grand slam doubles titles during his career, worked with Lu during the week prior to Wimbledon and will travel with the 25-year-old Taiwanese over the next month to help him during the U.S. hard court season.

Woodforde, who along with Lu's regular coach Dirk Hordorff, helped Lu devise the attacking strategy that paid some dividends against Federer, also used his privileges as a member of Wimbledon to get Lu into the closely guarded center court before the tournament began and get a feel for the intimidating arena.
Having a former player with Woodforde's experience and knowledge of the game at his side can only help Lu in the immediate future.
While Lu made a respectable showing in the men's draw, compatriot Chan Yung-jan showed she is still far from fully recovered following a two-month layoff due to a left toe fracture.

After falling to 12th seed Marion Bartoli of France 6-0, 6-0 in the first round of the women's singles, Chan said that while her toe had recovered physically, she had yet to overcome the psychological barrier of worrying about reinjuring it and often moved too cautiously around the court.
Her conditioning was also a long way from peak form after the layoff, making it difficult to work through long points, she said.
Her focus will now turn to doubles, where she will partner with Hungary's Agnes Szavay.
enditem/ .

DOC.HEADLINE: Palauan congressional leaders to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Palauan Senate President Mlib Tmetuchl and House Speaker Noah Idechong will arrive in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day visit at Taiwan's invitation, according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) statement.
During their stay, the Palauan congressional delegation will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou and visit a local high school baseball team.

The two congressional leaders, on their first visit to Taiwan since winning elections last November, will also visit the Legislative Yuan, the Environmental Protection Administration, and the National Palace Museum, the Foreign Ministry said in the statement released Monday.
Tmetuchl, who is a die-hard baseball fan, hopes to encourage more exchanges between Taiwanese baseball clubs and Palau's national baseball team.

At his invitation, the Kaohsiung Kao-Yuan Senior High School of Technology & Commerce baseball team, which won the Big League Baseball World Series (one of the tournaments organized by Little League International for 16-18 year olds) in 1996, visited Palau in 2008.

Idechong, one of eight "Heroes for the Planet" selected by Time magazine for Earth Day 2000, is an expert in marine resource management. As an expert in marine conservation, his work earned him several international recognitions.

Since establishing diplomatic ties in 1999, Taiwan and Palau have launched many cooperation programs in the areas of agriculture, health, tourism, culture, and telecommunications, according to the Foreign Ministry statement.
Palau has staunchly supported Taiwan's various bids to gain membership or observer status in international organizations, such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wants regular cross-strait flights to start before Aug. 31

TEXT.P: China has proposed Aug. 31 as the date for the launch of regularly scheduled cross-Taiwan Strait flights, but Taiwan is hoping that the date could be brought forward, a spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) confirmed Tuesday.
"Taiwan and China have yet to decide on the start date for the 270 regular two- way flights per week, " said Yeh Yung-ching, a CAA section chief who is in charge of the matter.

Commenting on a media report that the CAA and Taiwanese carriers have reached a decision that the ticket prices for cross-strait flights will be lowered by about 15 percent, Yeh said that the CAA simply urged the airlines to make some price adjustments in response to widespread public complaints about the cost.

Taiwan and China reached an agreement in April, in their third round of negotiations, to increase the number of cross-strait flights from the current 108 to 270 per week. But the two sides have yet to agree on a date for the implementation of the plan.

Since direct air travel between Taiwan and China kicked off in July last year, passenger loads on cross-strait charters have risen from 65 percent to an average of 78.8 percent, CAA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
China Times: On DPP's push for ex-president's release

Whether the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) can critically examine the corruption case involving former President Chen Shui-bian poses a test for the party's survival. Considered solely from a "pro-Chen" perspective, the DPP's plan to launch a petition drive calling for Chen's release lacks the depth of the human rights campaign that the party intends it to be.

The DPP does not need to wait until the conclusion of Chen's court cases to assess the rights and wrongs during his presidency. Chen himself confessed that "I did things that are not permitted by law," immediately after his family's money-laundering activities were exposed.

Because of the DPP leadership's failure to make a quick decision to take a critical stand against Chen and gain the moral high ground in the beginning, Chen has now seized the initiative to regain his influence in the party.
United Daily News: On DPP's drive for ex-president's release

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's plan to launch a petition drive calling for the release of former President Chen Shui-bian may help give vent to the resentment of pro-independence hardliners, but the move is also demonstrates to the mainstream public that Tsai and the DPP cannot get out of the mire surrounding the issue of supporting and rescuing Chen.

The Taiwan independence cause leads to a dead end, but Tsai dares not dump her sweeteners to the "deep greens." The path of supporting Chen also leads to a dead end, but again Tsai dares not discard her actions that pander to the "deep greens."
You cannot save the party if you choose to rescue Chen, and if you choose to save the party, you cannot rescue Chen. Tsai Ing-wen, how can you take a track that will lead the DPP to its doom?
Liberty Times: On status upgrades for selected localities

The Ministry of the Interior is set to review Tuesday the applications by seven localities to have their status upgraded to special municipalities, and to make a final decision by the end of the day. The process, however, is marred by rumors that the successful applicants have been predetermined to facilitate the ruling Kuomintang's political maneuvering for the year-end local elections.

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, which is a self-styled team of social elites, is engaged in various under-the-counter, illicit undertakings. This is the main reason that the incident has triggered social furor.

This type of public policy should adopt an open and transparent process of consensus building, and should not involve the granting of private favors by a minority of individuals behind closed doors. The decision-making process adopted by Ma's administration is against the principles of a modern government and gives the impression of being retrogressive.
Apple Daily: On the perjury investigation of ex-president's daughter

The situation in which the children of former President Chen Shui-bian are repeatedly summoned for questioning by prosecutors as part of the investigation into Chen's corruption case is to a certain extent inconsistent with humane and legal traditions.
U.S. law allows a defendant's spouse to refuse to testify against the defendant, while the continental legal system expands this exemption to cover close relatives.

The case does not only involve the deprivation of Chen's rights as a defendant, but also highlights the uncivilized nature of the judicial system under which children are compelled to testify against their parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government has plans to deal with unemployment: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday that the government has come up with several job creation programs to tackle the high unemployment rate recorded in May.

Liu made the remarks at a meeting of a local industrial and commerce association the day after the government's statistics agency reported that Taiwan's unemployment rate had surged to 5.82 percent in May, the highest level since the government began compiling jobless figures in 1978.

Liu attributed to the high unemployment figures in May to the number of new graduates in the job market, and said that the data was in line with Council for Economic Planning and Development's (CEPD's) projections.
The CEPD has further projected that the unemployment rate will reach 6 percent between June and September, he added.
However, the unemployment situation will ease gradually as the government rolls out its job matching plan for new university graduates and employers and many other job creation programs, he said.
Meanwhile, with export orders picking up, the rate of decline in exports is expected to continue to slow down, which in turn will prompt companies to expand employment, the premier said.

Echoing Liu's views, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming expressed confidence that the rate of job losses will begin to abate between the end of this year and early next year as the government phases in its four-year NT$500 billion major infrastructure projects from the second half of this year.

Yiin said the job market has shown signs of improvement, as evidenced by the fact that the number of employees placed on furlough in the country's export zones has dropped from a peak of 26,000 in February to 2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must redefine China as its best market: economics minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Tuesday that he sees China as Taiwan's best market and Taiwan should therefore revise its perception of China.

"Taiwan's best market opportunities are on mainland China; why should it fear being tagged with the 'one China' label?" Yiin said in akeynote speech at the ROC Council for Industrial and Commercial Development.

In his speech, which focused on the prospects for the Taiwan economy in light of the global changes, Yiin said the drivers of the global economy are weaker, referring to developed countries such as Japan and the United States.

Global Insight has forecast the global economy would contract by 2.6 percent in 2009, and that the U.S. and the Euro zone would see shrinkage in their economic development this year as a result of the global financial storm, Yiin said.
The less-developed Asian region would maintain its economic growth, due largely to the economic rise of China, he added.

According to the Global Insight economic forecast, China's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow 6.9 percent in 2009, which is expected to lift the global economy by some 0.5 percentage points, he said.
China was listed as the world's third largest economic entity, but is actually the second largest under the Purchasing Power Parity calculation system, he noted.
"Taiwan must redefine its position in relation to China, " he said.
Currently, he noted, the Taiwan government's cross-strait focus is to open the door to Chinese investments and to promote an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China.
The revision to the regulations to allow investments from China is expected to take effect June 30, and from July 1 Taiwan will begin the work of trying to attract Chinese capital, Yiin said.

He added that the planned ECFA will cover three areas -- tariff-free exports, the liberalization of the services sector, and an investment guarantee accord. Under an early implementation agreement, some 1,000 product categories will be included in the urgent tariff-free aspect of the trade pact, Yiin said.
As for the other parts of the ECFA, it doesn't matter if it takes 10 years to talk about them," he added.

President Ma Ying-jeou has been pushing for a trade pact with China in an effort to avoid Taiwan's marginalization in East Asia, as a free trade agreement among China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is set to take effect next January.
However, the ECFA proposal has been strongly opposed by the pro-independence opposition parties, which have argued that it will compromise Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop below 6,200 after unemployment report

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed lower to fall below the 6,200 mark Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 143.74 points, or 2.26 percent, to close at 6,197.47.

Following a 200-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average overnight, the local bourse opened low at 6,206.31 following government data showing that Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to a record high of 5.82 percent in May. It later rebounded to 6,262.29 and dropped to the day's low of 6,197.47.
A total of 3.41 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$91.56 billion (US$2.78 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 3.5 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares shed 3.4 percent, textile issues dropped 3.0 percent, banking and financial stocks lost 2.5 percent, construction shares fell 2.1 percent, machinery and electronics issues dropped 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares lost 1.1 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 1.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,531 to 501, with 133 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$12.89 billion.
Despite a lackluster performance on the Dow Jones industrial average, there were 500 stocks moving up in the local bourse, with 20 of which even rising by their 7 percent daily maximum limit.

Hsu Chen-chia, an analyst at the Cathay Securities Investment Trust Co., predicted that although there is little room for the Taiex to rise further in the short term, the market would likely hover between 6,400 and 6,500 in July if the trade volume increases to more than NT$110 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.027 to close at NT$32.925.
A total of US$665 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.000 and fluctuated between NT$32.912 and NT$33.010.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Chinese purchasing delegation to generate huge business: TAITRA

TEXT.P: The second Chinese purchasing delegation is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan July 12 and is expected to generate huge business opportunities for Taiwanese suppliers, according to a Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) press statement released Tuesday.

The delegation is composed of 167 people from 85 companies, most of which are chain department stores, supermarkets and logistics providers, including Beijing Hualian Group, Beijing Wangfujing Department Store, Hefei Department Store Group Co., Ltd., and Wuhan Zhongbai Group Co., Ltd., according to TAITRA.
It added that the buying mission is expected to place a huge amount of orders on Taiwan delicacies, fruits, daily supplies, arts and crafts and clothes.

The visit is being organized by Chinas Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (AETATS), which is an organization set up by Chinas Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges, the press release said.

On July 13 TAITRA will hold a seminar on business opportunities arising from Chinas latest economic stimulus measures aimed at expanding domestic demand, according to the press release. The measures are also benefiting Taiwan as they are leading to increased purchases of Taiwanese products.
There will be also time dedicated to increasing communications and understanding between Taiwanese suppliers and Chinese companies, according to the TAITRA.
One-on-one sessions will be arranged in Taipei and Tainan on July 13 and 15, respectively, the TAITRA said.
Taiwanese suppliers can sign up to participate in the event at http: //mainlandchina.taiwantrade.com.tw/comechina.aspx starting June 24.
Members of AETATSfirst purchasing delegation, which visited Taiwan from May 31- June 5, placed orders worth more than US$2.2 billion on home appliances and consumer electronics, according to TAITRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior ministry reviewing special municipality applications

TEXT.P: Despite robust competition among local governments for their cities or counties to be upgraded to special municipalities, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu said Tuesday that one each should be established in northern, central and southern Taiwan so as to achieve balanced regional development.

Hu made the remarks after stating reasons why Taichung City and Taichung County in central Taiwan should be merged into a special municipality, in a meeting of a panel convened by Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi to review seven similar applications from 11 local governments.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Taoyuan County Magistrate Eric Chu, Taitung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po- yuan, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming- wen, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing all presented their cases at the meeting.

Hu said he is confident that the Taichung City and Taichung County application would be approved, but added that it would give a boost to the country's overall competitiveness if a municipality is formed in each of the three major regions.

Brushing aside rampant rumors that it has been predetermined that Taichung City and Taichung County will be merged into a special municipality, Hu said that those allegations are unfair. He pointed out that one of President Ma Ying- jeou's campaign promises was to establish "three municipalities and 15 counties" in Taiwan.

Asked whether he is concerned about the fact that most local governments seeking an upgrade are eyeing bigger budgets and improved finances, Hu said that is an issue that President Ma and the central government should examine, as many localities have problems of revenue shortfalls.
Special municipalities fall under the direct jurisdiction of the central government and are entitled to have bigger budgets than other local governments.

Addressing the meeting, Liao said the panel's decisions would turn a new page in Taiwan's development. The critical issue is how to boost Taiwan's international competitiveness through the restructuring of central government functions and rezoning of administrative areas, he stressed.
Later in the day, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu said the proposed merger with Kaohsiung County is designed to address urgent development needs in southern Taiwan.

Taiwan not only has to compete with Japan and South Korea, but also faces competition from China, particularly from southern China, Chen said. It is therefore very important to sharpen the competitive edge of the greater Kaohsiung area in southern Taiwan and strike a balance in development between the north and south, she said.
For his part, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang said an upgrade of the Kaohsiung area is urgently necessary and that 78 percent of the county's residents support such a plan.

Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County complement each other, and a merger, backed by an additional budget of NT$13 billion (US$393 million) , will definitely boost regional competitiveness on a wide range of fronts, he said.
However, if the Taichung area is merged first, Kaohsiung would be marginalized, he added.
Meanwhile, the agricultural counties of Yunlin and Chiayi are also seeking to merge to facilitate development into an "agricultural municipality" that would mean greater economic prosperity.

Yunlin County has a population of over 720,000, while Chiayi County's is about 540,000. If they are merged, the combined population will be some 1.26 million people, which is in excess of the minimum 1 million specified for a special municipality, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ireland expected to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expecting another breakthrough in its efforts to seek visa waiver privileges from foreign countries, with evidence indicating that Ireland is soon to announce visa-free entry for Taiwanese nationals, according to a senior Taiwanese official familiar with the issue who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The official told CNA that Ireland is set to grant 90-day visa-free privileges to Taiwanese passport holders as soon as next week, adding that a formal announcement will be made in the next few days.
Asked to comment on the matter, Foreign Ministry Spokesman Henry Chen said the ministry is working hard on the issue.
"Things are moving in a positive direction with regard to the matter," Chen said.

The Republic of China government allows Republic of Ireland passport holders 30-day visa-free stays, which, on the principle of reciprocity, is expected to be extended to 90 days if Ireland decides to grant 90-day visa-free stays for Taiwanese visitors.

The United Kingdom, which started including Taiwan in its visa-waiver program March 3, became the first major Western country to lift visa requirements for Taiwanese citizens and has since spurred debate in other countries such as Germany on the possibility of making similar moves.

So far, the British visa-free treatment is the most favorable, allowing Taiwanese passport holders traveling to Britain for the purpose of tourism, business, short-term study or family visits visa-free status for up to six months.
According to the Irish government, the number of visa applications by Taiwanese passport holders is around 1,200 per year.
The fees for Irish visas are NT$2,700 (US$82) for a single-entry visa valid for three months or NT$4,500 for a multiple-entry visa valid for a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Progress reported in negotiations with U.S. on extradition pact
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) 06/23/09 19:52:39 (By Jorge Liu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Progress has been made in Taiwan's negotiations with the United States on the possibility of a bilateral extradition arrangement, Taiwan's representative to Washington, Jason Yuan, said Monday.
According to Yuan, the U.S. administration took Taiwan's request for such a pact seriously and responded with "good intentions."
However, he admitted that the U.S. executive branch is unable to clinch a treaty with Taiwan because of the lack of official ties between the two countries.

In order to sidestep this obstacle, Yuan said, the U.S. administration has joined hands with Taiwan to persuade Congress to come up with a bill that would have the same effect as an extradition agreement.

"It is a sign of the smooth communications between our representative office and the U.S. administration, " Yuan went on, adding that Taipei used to have difficulty even conveying its requests to the U.S. executive branch, far less working with it.
Although there are positive signs in the negotiations, there is red tape to circumvent and Congress has many other bills pending enactment, Yuan continued.
Just as Taiwan's requests for visa exemption privileges for its people when visiting the United States, a bill with the effect as an extradition pact will need time and patience, he said.
"I do not want to mislead our people into believing that this could be achieved any time soon," Yuan said.

Owing to the lack of an extradition arrangement, many of Taiwan's most high- profile fugitives are taking refuge in the United States, to the great chagrin of the Taiwanese authorities, who are powerless to bring them to justice.

Notable among these are Huang Fang-yen, who is alleged to have helped former President Chen Shui-bian launder his money, as well as Ching Chi-ju, who is reported to have duped the Foreign Ministry out of US$30 million, and Wang You- theng who stands accused in Taiwan of bilking billions of dollars from a business group he founded.

Chen Yu-hao, another business tycoon who is wanted for fraud in Taiwan, embarrassed former President Chen Shui-bian during his run for re-election in 2004 by claiming at a news conference in California that he was one of Chen's political contributors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cycling tour launched to promote Yushan as world wonder

TEXT.P: The ambassadors for Taiwan's campaign to get Yushan or Jade Mountain chosen as one of the world's natural wonders launched an around-the-island cycling tour Tuesday as part of their efforts to promote the bid.

During the 15 days leading up to the July 7 deadline for the second stage of global online voting, the ambassadors will call on opinion leaders in the business, religious, arts and cultural, and political sectors around Taiwan to encourage them to take part in the vote and offer their support for Yushan, according to the Yushan National Park Headquarters.

The ambassadors will also visit local communities and universities and invite people they encounter to draw a picture or write an article based on their impressions of Yushan, said Chen Lung-sheng, head of the park headquarters.
"Through thinking and perception covering different dimensions, we will be able to highlight the uniqueness of Yushan and inspire more people to join the vote," Chen said.
Coinciding with the cycling tour, a "vote wagon" is being sent around to allow the public to cast their votes using the computer systems installed on the vehicle, he said.

The 3,952-meter mountain, the highest in Northeast Asia, has so far maintained the top position in the "mountain, volcanoes" category in the second round of voting for the world's new seven natural wonders being held by the Swiss-based New7Wonders Foundation at www.new7wonders.com.

Located on the boundaries of Chiayi, Nantou and Kaohsiung counties, Yushan is known for its diverse wildlife and ecology. It is the only natural attraction from Taiwan to make the list of contenders in any category.

As of June 22, Africa's Kalahari Desert had taken the top position in the "landscape, ice formations" category; Ecuador's Galapagos Islands in the "islands" category; Serbia's Djavolja Varos in the "caves, rock formations, valleys" category; South America's Amazon Rainforest in the "forest, national parks, nature reserves" category; South America's Lake Titicaca in the "lakes, rivers, waterfalls" category; and Vietnam's Ha Long Bay in the "seascape" category.

The top 11 sites chosen in each of the seven categories by July 7 will then be reviewed by a panel of experts headed by Federico Mayor Zaragoza, former UNESCO director-general, who will select three nominees in each category.
The 21 nominees will be put to a final round of worldwide online voting in 2010 and 2011 to select the top seven natural wonders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's food exports in 2008 thrived despite economic downturn

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural and fishery exports in 2008 soared despite the global recession, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Tuesday at the opening of the 2009 Taipei International Food Show.

While the global economy was suffering a downturn last year, Taiwan's farm and seafood product exports still posted a 12.1 percent year-on-year growth to NT$3.85 billion last year, Chiu said at the Nangang Exhibition Hall in Taipei, where the food show is being held.

Rice exports posted the largest growth among all exports of Taiwan's agricultural and fishery products, up 10,647 percent year-on -year, followed by groupers, up 1,221 percent; carrots, up 565 percent; Taiwan tilapia, up 30 percent; and vegetable soybeans, up 15.2 percent, Chiu said, citing statistics.
Chiu was making a speech during the opening ceremony of the food show, where the Taiwan Pavilion has been taking center stage.

To showcase the freshness, safety and high quality of Taiwan's farm produce and fishery products, the Council of Agriculture (COA) has been taking part in the show by setting up the Taiwan Pavilion, which covers an area of 1,755 square meters and brings together 83 local exhibitors, according to COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung.

The Taiwan Pavilion comprises six sections, namely the Theme Section, Crop Products Section, Fishery Products Section, Livestock Products Section, Processed Food Section and Forest Products Section, Chen said.

The pavilion displays a wide variety of agricultural products such as rice, vegetables, mushrooms and processed food as well as fishery and livestock products that got certificates of the Certified Agriculture Standard (CAS), Critical Control Points (HACCP), or International Organization for Standardization (IOS).
A total of 826 exhibitors from 19 countries are taking part at the international food show, which opened Tuesday and will run until June 26. The exhibits cover an area of 14,690 square meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: National park to stock endangered salmon parr in historic habitats

TEXT.P: The Shei-Pa National Park Headquarters will hold a public activity June 26-27 in which captive-bred Formosan landlocked salmon parr will be released into the highly endangered fish's natural habitat.

The public are welcome to attend the "taking young salmon home" activity, an event that has taken place for the last two consecutive years, Liao Wu-yen, director of the park headquarters' Wuling Station, said Tuesday.

Liao said that 350 salmon parr -- juvenile salmon aged more than one year -- will be released in the Luoyehwei section of the Yousheng Creek, the Yikawan section of the Dajia River and in the Sijielan Creek.

He also expressed hope the releases will allow people to spot the national treasure in the rivers once again, and that the young fish will survive through the summer typhoons. He noted in the past two years, only 1 percent of the released parr are thought to have survived the annual typhoon season.

The conservation measures are aimed at expanding the fishes breeding territory in the wild. According to Liao, the number of Formosan landlocked salmon in the wild is around 3,500, all of which live in the Cijiawan Creek in Wuling.
The creek provides a stable environment for the delicate fish, Liao went on, adding that the park authorities still want to establish wild breeding colonies in other suitable areas.

Formosan landlocked salmon were originally migratory fish that lived in the frigid-temperate zone of the Northern Hemisphere. During the breeding season, they would swim upstream from the ocean to the upper reaches of the river where they were born, where they would mate and spawn. After the eggs hatched, the juvenile fish would return to the ocean, where they would grow to maturity before returning to the river of their birth to repeat the cycle.

Having evolved over many thousands of years to survive year-round in the fresh water of Taiwan's remote river systems without migrating to the sea, the species is now only found in Taiwan and was listed in 1984 as a precious natural resource.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air Asia to launch Taipei-Kuala Lumpur flights

TEXT.P: Air Asia announced Tuesday that it will be offering flights between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia from next month, joining the competition among several other carriers operating on the same route.
On July 1, an Air Asia Airbus A330 will make the maiden flight from Kuala Lumpur to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and will fly the return route one hour later.
The Taipei-based China Airlines and EVA Airways as well as Malaysia Airlines all operate flights between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.

Air Asia, based in Malaysia, will be the third low-fare, no-frills airline to serve Taiwan since the Singaporean JetStar Asia Airways and the Philippines- based Cebu Pacific Air began operations in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives advice on recession from influential economist

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou received Richard C. Koo, the chief economist of Japan's Nomura Research Institute, at the Presidential Office Tuesday, to take professional guidance in efforts to lead Taiwan out of its recession.

Koo, son of former senior adviser to the president, Koo Kuan-min, was invited by a group of heavyweight Taiwanese business tycoons, including Chinatrust Commercial Bank Chairman and CEO Jeffrey Koo, to visit Taiwan. He is Jeffrey Koo's cousin.

In the meeting, the economist renowned in both the United States and Japan told Ma that the global recession triggered by the financial storm that occurred in the U.S. last September has rarely happened in the global economic mechanism.

The financial problems caused by the credit crisis have led to companies devoting most of their resources to paying off their debts, even at a time when interest rates are near zero. As more money is deposited in banks, it can no longer flow through the market, the economist said, pointing out that the situation stems the movement of funds, which further affects an economy's economic growth.
He called this phenomenon a "balance-sheet recession" and said he believes it is behind the recession stagnation that has been hounding Japan for more than a decade.

To resolve the problem, he suggested that the government should launch long-term investment projects to increase the flow of funds in and out of the market and try to maintain the gross domestic production level.
"This process takes a very long time, so the government should be patient," he told Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's Central America tour to be extended by one day

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's planned visit to several countries in Central America will be extended by one day, an aide to the president said Tuesday.
In order to ensure that Ma can meet with Honduran President Jose Manuel Zelaya Rosales, he will arrive in that country July 4 rather than July 3 as initially scheduled.
The change was made to account for any possible delay in Zelaya's return to the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa from an overseas visit of his own, the anonymous aide said.
Although Zelaya had promised that he will return to Tegucigalpa before July 3, Ma would prefer to delay his visit by one day to be on the safe side, the aide said.
As a result, Ma will stay in Panama July 1-3 -- one day longer than scheduled originally -- and the date of his return to Taipei will therefore be postponed by one day to July 8.
Ma is set to depart June 29 for the visit to three of Taiwan's Central America allies -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras.
The main purpose of the trip is to attend the July 1 inauguration of Panamanian President-elect Ricardo Martinelli in Panama City.

Ma will be accompanied by first lady Chow Mei-ling, along with a 129-strong delegation of legislators, government officials, industry and academia representatives, local government chiefs and charity organization executives, as well as noted local entertainers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Panel approves creation of three new special municipalities

TEXT.P: An ad hoc panel organized by the Ministry of the Interior approved Tuesday the upgrade of Taipei County, Taichung City and Taichung County, and Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County to special municipalities.
Meanwhile, the panel rejected the upgrade applications submitted by Taoyuan County, Changhua County, and Yuling County and Chiayi County.

The panel, however failed to reach an unanimous decision on whether Tainan City and Tainan County should be merged and upgraded to a special municipality and the Ministry of the Interior said it will be referred to the Executive Yuan for a decision.
The panel's decisions were made by its members by consensus after a 15-hour meeting that day and was announced by Minister of Liao Liou-yi at a news conference.
Their decisions still have to be approved by the Executive Yuan.
A total of 11 counties and cities had asked for upgrade to seven municipalities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening Taiwan to U.S. beef in final stage of discussions: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States are currently conducting final negotiations on the controversial issue of fully opening Taiwan's market to U.S. beef, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
Both sides are engaged in intensive final discussions, said Harry Tseng, director-general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, at regular press briefing.
Technical negotiations, he said, are being carried out by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Office of Trade Negotiations, the Council of Agriculture and the Department of Health (DOH).
"The Foreign Ministry is involved in the process, but I cannot comment on the details,he added.
Pressed on whether the issue could be resolved this year, Tseng said he is optimistic over the timeline.

The U.S. currently supplies 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, but under existing DOH regulations, only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced from certified slaughterhouses and without high-risk items such as brains and spinal cord marrow, can be imported to Taiwan.
Stephen M. Young, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan, has repeatedly urged Taiwan government to make a science-based decision on fully opening its market to U.S. beef.
All of Taiwan's scientific review and technical work indicates that U.S. beef does not pose a threat of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, Young has contended.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of BSE was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the local government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: January-April wages decline at record rate

TEXT.P: Wage data released by Taiwan's statistics bureau Monday showed that local workers have had to confront a record decline in their nominal and real incomes during the first four months of 2009.

The average monthly income of local employees between January to April fell by a record 8.54 percent year-on-year to NT$47,107, a Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) official said Monday.
The average regular monthly wage also contracted during the same period by a record 3.04 percent to NT$35,488, according to Huang Chien-chung, deputy director of the Fourth Bureau of the DGBAS.

The average monthly wage includes regular wages (salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses) plus overtime, and other non-regular wages (performance bonuses, year-end bonuses, and employee bonuses).

Real monthly income and the real regular monthly wage, which take into account the impact of inflation on wages, fell by 8.44 percent and 2.93 percent respectively, Huang said, after the consumer price index declined 0.12 percent during the first four months of the year.
All four income measures posted the steepest four-month declines since they were first compiled in 1980, Huang noted.

Nominal regular wages contracted by more than 2 percent every month between November and April, the statistics also showed. They fell by 2.52 percent in November, 3.41 percent in December, 4.63 percent in January, 2.56 percent in February, 2.39 percent in March, and 2.56 percent in April.
Huang attributed the persistent decline to the sagging commercial activity of domestic manufacturers as a result of the global economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma to make public appearances in Hawaii: MOFA

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will make public appearances in Hawaii in early July during a transit stop on his way home from a state visit to Central America, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Tuesday.

"There will be some different activities for President Ma during his transit stop in Hawaii, including public visits, said Harry Tseng, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, at a regular press briefing.

While the press guidelines of the U.S. State Department remain unchanged -- Taiwanese media accompanying the president cannot report on his visits on U.S. soil -- Tseng said that taking pictures of Ma from a certain distance may be understandable on the part of the U.S. government.
Tseng declined, however, to disclose the destinations that Ma would visit.
Ma is set to depart next Monday on another diplomatic tour that will take him to three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras.
The president will make a transit stop in San Francisco en route to Panama and will stop in Hawaii on his way home.

As Taiwan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with the United States, Ma has consistently kept a low profile and refrained from leaving the hotels where he was staying during his previous layovers, making only phone calls or receiving some members of the U.S. Congress.
Hawaii might be the first time Ma makes a public appearance during similar transit stops in the U.S.
The main focus of Ma's trip will be to attend the inauguration ceremony of Panama's president-elect, Ricardo Martinelli, on July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu picks up confidence and a new coach in loss to Federer
DOC.DATELINE: London/Taipei, June 23 (CNA) 06/23/09 14:40:05 (By Jennifer Huang and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun was swept aside in straight sets by world No. 2 Roger Federer in a first round men's singles match at Wimbledon Monday, but he emerged from the encounter with more confidence and a new coach.

Lu, who had been struggling to recover from an energy-sapping virus since mid- May, lost to the five-time Wimbledon champion 7-5, 6-3, 6-2 in 105 minutes, but he told the Central News Agency afterwards that holding a 3-2 lead in the first set despite a heavy bout of nerves left him more confident than ever.

"It had a real motivating effect, because it made me understand that even against a top player like Federer, I could still be competitive and fight to the end, " Lu said. "To have a good showing against a heavyweight is not an impossibility."

Lu struggled for much of his career against top-ranked players before defeating top 10 players Andy Murray in the Olympics in Beijing in 2008 and Argentine David Nalbandian in the second round of this year's Australian Open.
After Monday's match, even Federer came away impressed.

"I thought he played excellent. He's a wonderful player. He has got a nice forehand, a nice backhand, very sound game all around, " Federer said. "I knew the danger today. He's beaten good players in the past."

Although Lu said he learned a lot during the match and described playing him on perhaps the biggest stage in men's tennis -- center court at Wimbledon -- as a "special experience," it was not his dream draw.

"When the draw first came out, I thought I was really unlucky because I really felt comfortable on the grass surface. My coach told me beforehand that as long as I didn't draw Federer, I had a chance against any of the other 126 players entered."
The loss to Federer meant Lu was eliminated from Wimbledon for the fourth time in six tries, with his best showings second round finishes in 2004 and 2005.
His best performance in a grand slam singles event came at this year's Australian Open, when he reached the third round.

Lu said his stamina was not 100 percent against Federer, as he only began training in earnest 10 days ago after a blood test in England found everything was normal, and that he still needs time to regain his prior level of conditioning, but now he'll have extra incentive.

Former Australian doubles great Mark Woodforde, who won 12 grand slam doubles titles during his career, worked with Lu during the week prior to Wimbledon and will travel with the 25-year-old Taiwanese over the next month to help him during the U.S. hard court season.

Woodforde, who along with Lu's regular coach Dirk Hordorff, helped Lu devise the attacking strategy that paid some dividends against Federer, also used his privileges as a member of Wimbledon to get Lu into the closely guarded center court before the tournament began and get a feel for the intimidating arena.
Having a former player with Woodforde's experience and knowledge of the game at his side can only help Lu in the immediate future.
While Lu made a respectable showing in the men's draw, compatriot Chan Yung-jan showed she is still far from fully recovered following a two-month layoff due to a left toe fracture.

After falling to 12th seed Marion Bartoli of France 6-0, 6-0 in the first round of the women's singles, Chan said that while her toe had recovered physically, she had yet to overcome the psychological barrier of worrying about reinjuring it and often moved too cautiously around the court.
Her conditioning was also a long way from peak form after the layoff, making it difficult to work through long points, she said.
Her focus will now turn to doubles, where she will partner with Hungary's Agnes Szavay.
enditem/ .

DOC.HEADLINE: Palauan congressional leaders to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Palauan Senate President Mlib Tmetuchl and House Speaker Noah Idechong will arrive in Taiwan Tuesday for a five-day visit at Taiwan's invitation, according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) statement.
During their stay, the Palauan congressional delegation will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou and visit a local high school baseball team.

The two congressional leaders, on their first visit to Taiwan since winning elections last November, will also visit the Legislative Yuan, the Environmental Protection Administration, and the National Palace Museum, the Foreign Ministry said in the statement released Monday.
Tmetuchl, who is a die-hard baseball fan, hopes to encourage more exchanges between Taiwanese baseball clubs and Palau's national baseball team.

At his invitation, the Kaohsiung Kao-Yuan Senior High School of Technology & Commerce baseball team, which won the Big League Baseball World Series (one of the tournaments organized by Little League International for 16-18 year olds) in 1996, visited Palau in 2008.

Idechong, one of eight "Heroes for the Planet" selected by Time magazine for Earth Day 2000, is an expert in marine resource management. As an expert in marine conservation, his work earned him several international recognitions.

Since establishing diplomatic ties in 1999, Taiwan and Palau have launched many cooperation programs in the areas of agriculture, health, tourism, culture, and telecommunications, according to the Foreign Ministry statement.
Palau has staunchly supported Taiwan's various bids to gain membership or observer status in international organizations, such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wants regular cross-strait flights to start before Aug. 31

TEXT.P: China has proposed Aug. 31 as the date for the launch of regularly scheduled cross-Taiwan Strait flights, but Taiwan is hoping that the date could be brought forward, a spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) confirmed Tuesday.
"Taiwan and China have yet to decide on the start date for the 270 regular two- way flights per week, " said Yeh Yung-ching, a CAA section chief who is in charge of the matter.

Commenting on a media report that the CAA and Taiwanese carriers have reached a decision that the ticket prices for cross-strait flights will be lowered by about 15 percent, Yeh said that the CAA simply urged the airlines to make some price adjustments in response to widespread public complaints about the cost.

Taiwan and China reached an agreement in April, in their third round of negotiations, to increase the number of cross-strait flights from the current 108 to 270 per week. But the two sides have yet to agree on a date for the implementation of the plan.

Since direct air travel between Taiwan and China kicked off in July last year, passenger loads on cross-strait charters have risen from 65 percent to an average of 78.8 percent, CAA statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday:
China Times: On DPP's push for ex-president's release

Whether the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) can critically examine the corruption case involving former President Chen Shui-bian poses a test for the party's survival. Considered solely from a "pro-Chen" perspective, the DPP's plan to launch a petition drive calling for Chen's release lacks the depth of the human rights campaign that the party intends it to be.

The DPP does not need to wait until the conclusion of Chen's court cases to assess the rights and wrongs during his presidency. Chen himself confessed that "I did things that are not permitted by law," immediately after his family's money-laundering activities were exposed.

Because of the DPP leadership's failure to make a quick decision to take a critical stand against Chen and gain the moral high ground in the beginning, Chen has now seized the initiative to regain his influence in the party.
United Daily News: On DPP's drive for ex-president's release

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's plan to launch a petition drive calling for the release of former President Chen Shui-bian may help give vent to the resentment of pro-independence hardliners, but the move is also demonstrates to the mainstream public that Tsai and the DPP cannot get out of the mire surrounding the issue of supporting and rescuing Chen.

The Taiwan independence cause leads to a dead end, but Tsai dares not dump her sweeteners to the "deep greens." The path of supporting Chen also leads to a dead end, but again Tsai dares not discard her actions that pander to the "deep greens."
You cannot save the party if you choose to rescue Chen, and if you choose to save the party, you cannot rescue Chen. Tsai Ing-wen, how can you take a track that will lead the DPP to its doom?
Liberty Times: On status upgrades for selected localities

The Ministry of the Interior is set to review Tuesday the applications by seven localities to have their status upgraded to special municipalities, and to make a final decision by the end of the day. The process, however, is marred by rumors that the successful applicants have been predetermined to facilitate the ruling Kuomintang's political maneuvering for the year-end local elections.

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, which is a self-styled team of social elites, is engaged in various under-the-counter, illicit undertakings. This is the main reason that the incident has triggered social furor.

This type of public policy should adopt an open and transparent process of consensus building, and should not involve the granting of private favors by a minority of individuals behind closed doors. The decision-making process adopted by Ma's administration is against the principles of a modern government and gives the impression of being retrogressive.
Apple Daily: On the perjury investigation of ex-president's daughter

The situation in which the children of former President Chen Shui-bian are repeatedly summoned for questioning by prosecutors as part of the investigation into Chen's corruption case is to a certain extent inconsistent with humane and legal traditions.
U.S. law allows a defendant's spouse to refuse to testify against the defendant, while the continental legal system expands this exemption to cover close relatives.

The case does not only involve the deprivation of Chen's rights as a defendant, but also highlights the uncivilized nature of the judicial system under which children are compelled to testify against their parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government has plans to deal with unemployment: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday that the government has come up with several job creation programs to tackle the high unemployment rate recorded in May.

Liu made the remarks at a meeting of a local industrial and commerce association the day after the government's statistics agency reported that Taiwan's unemployment rate had surged to 5.82 percent in May, the highest level since the government began compiling jobless figures in 1978.

Liu attributed to the high unemployment figures in May to the number of new graduates in the job market, and said that the data was in line with Council for Economic Planning and Development's (CEPD's) projections.
The CEPD has further projected that the unemployment rate will reach 6 percent between June and September, he added.
However, the unemployment situation will ease gradually as the government rolls out its job matching plan for new university graduates and employers and many other job creation programs, he said.
Meanwhile, with export orders picking up, the rate of decline in exports is expected to continue to slow down, which in turn will prompt companies to expand employment, the premier said.

Echoing Liu's views, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming expressed confidence that the rate of job losses will begin to abate between the end of this year and early next year as the government phases in its four-year NT$500 billion major infrastructure projects from the second half of this year.

Yiin said the job market has shown signs of improvement, as evidenced by the fact that the number of employees placed on furlough in the country's export zones has dropped from a peak of 26,000 in February to 2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must redefine China as its best market: economics minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Tuesday that he sees China as Taiwan's best market and Taiwan should therefore revise its perception of China.

"Taiwan's best market opportunities are on mainland China; why should it fear being tagged with the 'one China' label?" Yiin said in akeynote speech at the ROC Council for Industrial and Commercial Development.

In his speech, which focused on the prospects for the Taiwan economy in light of the global changes, Yiin said the drivers of the global economy are weaker, referring to developed countries such as Japan and the United States.

Global Insight has forecast the global economy would contract by 2.6 percent in 2009, and that the U.S. and the Euro zone would see shrinkage in their economic development this year as a result of the global financial storm, Yiin said.
The less-developed Asian region would maintain its economic growth, due largely to the economic rise of China, he added.

According to the Global Insight economic forecast, China's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow 6.9 percent in 2009, which is expected to lift the global economy by some 0.5 percentage points, he said.
China was listed as the world's third largest economic entity, but is actually the second largest under the Purchasing Power Parity calculation system, he noted.
"Taiwan must redefine its position in relation to China, " he said.
Currently, he noted, the Taiwan government's cross-strait focus is to open the door to Chinese investments and to promote an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China.
The revision to the regulations to allow investments from China is expected to take effect June 30, and from July 1 Taiwan will begin the work of trying to attract Chinese capital, Yiin said.

He added that the planned ECFA will cover three areas -- tariff-free exports, the liberalization of the services sector, and an investment guarantee accord. Under an early implementation agreement, some 1,000 product categories will be included in the urgent tariff-free aspect of the trade pact, Yiin said.
As for the other parts of the ECFA, it doesn't matter if it takes 10 years to talk about them," he added.

President Ma Ying-jeou has been pushing for a trade pact with China in an effort to avoid Taiwan's marginalization in East Asia, as a free trade agreement among China and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is set to take effect next January.
However, the ECFA proposal has been strongly opposed by the pro-independence opposition parties, which have argued that it will compromise Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop below 6,200 after unemployment report

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened low and closed lower to fall below the 6,200 mark Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 143.74 points, or 2.26 percent, to close at 6,197.47.

Following a 200-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average overnight, the local bourse opened low at 6,206.31 following government data showing that Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to a record high of 5.82 percent in May. It later rebounded to 6,262.29 and dropped to the day's low of 6,197.47.
A total of 3.41 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$91.56 billion (US$2.78 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 3.5 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares shed 3.4 percent, textile issues dropped 3.0 percent, banking and financial stocks lost 2.5 percent, construction shares fell 2.1 percent, machinery and electronics issues dropped 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares lost 1.1 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 1.0 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,531 to 501, with 133 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$12.89 billion.
Despite a lackluster performance on the Dow Jones industrial average, there were 500 stocks moving up in the local bourse, with 20 of which even rising by their 7 percent daily maximum limit.

Hsu Chen-chia, an analyst at the Cathay Securities Investment Trust Co., predicted that although there is little room for the Taiex to rise further in the short term, the market would likely hover between 6,400 and 6,500 in July if the trade volume increases to more than NT$110 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.027 to close at NT$32.925.
A total of US$665 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$33.000 and fluctuated between NT$32.912 and NT$33.010.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd Chinese purchasing delegation to generate huge business: TAITRA

TEXT.P: The second Chinese purchasing delegation is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan July 12 and is expected to generate huge business opportunities for Taiwanese suppliers, according to a Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) press statement released Tuesday.

The delegation is composed of 167 people from 85 companies, most of which are chain department stores, supermarkets and logistics providers, including Beijing Hualian Group, Beijing Wangfujing Department Store, Hefei Department Store Group Co., Ltd., and Wuhan Zhongbai Group Co., Ltd., according to TAITRA.
It added that the buying mission is expected to place a huge amount of orders on Taiwan delicacies, fruits, daily supplies, arts and crafts and clothes.

The visit is being organized by Chinas Association of Economy and Trade Across Taiwan Straits (AETATS), which is an organization set up by Chinas Ministry of Commerce to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade deals and promote commercial exchanges, the press release said.

On July 13 TAITRA will hold a seminar on business opportunities arising from Chinas latest economic stimulus measures aimed at expanding domestic demand, according to the press release. The measures are also benefiting Taiwan as they are leading to increased purchases of Taiwanese products.
There will be also time dedicated to increasing communications and understanding between Taiwanese suppliers and Chinese companies, according to the TAITRA.
One-on-one sessions will be arranged in Taipei and Tainan on July 13 and 15, respectively, the TAITRA said.
Taiwanese suppliers can sign up to participate in the event at http: //mainlandchina.taiwantrade.com.tw/comechina.aspx starting June 24.
Members of AETATSfirst purchasing delegation, which visited Taiwan from May 31- June 5, placed orders worth more than US$2.2 billion on home appliances and consumer electronics, according to TAITRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior ministry reviewing special municipality applications

TEXT.P: Despite robust competition among local governments for their cities or counties to be upgraded to special municipalities, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu said Tuesday that one each should be established in northern, central and southern Taiwan so as to achieve balanced regional development.

Hu made the remarks after stating reasons why Taichung City and Taichung County in central Taiwan should be merged into a special municipality, in a meeting of a panel convened by Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi to review seven similar applications from 11 local governments.

Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Taoyuan County Magistrate Eric Chu, Taitung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po- yuan, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming- wen, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing all presented their cases at the meeting.

Hu said he is confident that the Taichung City and Taichung County application would be approved, but added that it would give a boost to the country's overall competitiveness if a municipality is formed in each of the three major regions.

Brushing aside rampant rumors that it has been predetermined that Taichung City and Taichung County will be merged into a special municipality, Hu said that those allegations are unfair. He pointed out that one of President Ma Ying- jeou's campaign promises was to establish "three municipalities and 15 counties" in Taiwan.

Asked whether he is concerned about the fact that most local governments seeking an upgrade are eyeing bigger budgets and improved finances, Hu said that is an issue that President Ma and the central government should examine, as many localities have problems of revenue shortfalls.
Special municipalities fall under the direct jurisdiction of the central government and are entitled to have bigger budgets than other local governments.

Addressing the meeting, Liao said the panel's decisions would turn a new page in Taiwan's development. The critical issue is how to boost Taiwan's international competitiveness through the restructuring of central government functions and rezoning of administrative areas, he stressed.
Later in the day, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu said the proposed merger with Kaohsiung County is designed to address urgent development needs in southern Taiwan.

Taiwan not only has to compete with Japan and South Korea, but also faces competition from China, particularly from southern China, Chen said. It is therefore very important to sharpen the competitive edge of the greater Kaohsiung area in southern Taiwan and strike a balance in development between the north and south, she said.
For his part, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang said an upgrade of the Kaohsiung area is urgently necessary and that 78 percent of the county's residents support such a plan.

Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County complement each other, and a merger, backed by an additional budget of NT$13 billion (US$393 million) , will definitely boost regional competitiveness on a wide range of fronts, he said.
However, if the Taichung area is merged first, Kaohsiung would be marginalized, he added.
Meanwhile, the agricultural counties of Yunlin and Chiayi are also seeking to merge to facilitate development into an "agricultural municipality" that would mean greater economic prosperity.

Yunlin County has a population of over 720,000, while Chiayi County's is about 540,000. If they are merged, the combined population will be some 1.26 million people, which is in excess of the minimum 1 million specified for a special municipality, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ireland expected to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expecting another breakthrough in its efforts to seek visa waiver privileges from foreign countries, with evidence indicating that Ireland is soon to announce visa-free entry for Taiwanese nationals, according to a senior Taiwanese official familiar with the issue who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The official told CNA that Ireland is set to grant 90-day visa-free privileges to Taiwanese passport holders as soon as next week, adding that a formal announcement will be made in the next few days.
Asked to comment on the matter, Foreign Ministry Spokesman Henry Chen said the ministry is working hard on the issue.
"Things are moving in a positive direction with regard to the matter," Chen said.

The Republic of China government allows Republic of Ireland passport holders 30-day visa-free stays, which, on the principle of reciprocity, is expected to be extended to 90 days if Ireland decides to grant 90-day visa-free stays for Taiwanese visitors.

The United Kingdom, which started including Taiwan in its visa-waiver program March 3, became the first major Western country to lift visa requirements for Taiwanese citizens and has since spurred debate in other countries such as Germany on the possibility of making similar moves.

So far, the British visa-free treatment is the most favorable, allowing Taiwanese passport holders traveling to Britain for the purpose of tourism, business, short-term study or family visits visa-free status for up to six months.
According to the Irish government, the number of visa applications by Taiwanese passport holders is around 1,200 per year.
The fees for Irish visas are NT$2,700 (US$82) for a single-entry visa valid for three months or NT$4,500 for a multiple-entry visa valid for a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Progress reported in negotiations with U.S. on extradition pact
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) 06/23/09 19:52:39 (By Jorge Liu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Progress has been made in Taiwan's negotiations with the United States on the possibility of a bilateral extradition arrangement, Taiwan's representative to Washington, Jason Yuan, said Monday.
According to Yuan, the U.S. administration took Taiwan's request for such a pact seriously and responded with "good intentions."
However, he admitted that the U.S. executive branch is unable to clinch a treaty with Taiwan because of the lack of official ties between the two countries.

In order to sidestep this obstacle, Yuan said, the U.S. administration has joined hands with Taiwan to persuade Congress to come up with a bill that would have the same effect as an extradition agreement.

"It is a sign of the smooth communications between our representative office and the U.S. administration, " Yuan went on, adding that Taipei used to have difficulty even conveying its requests to the U.S. executive branch, far less working with it.
Although there are positive signs in the negotiations, there is red tape to circumvent and Congress has many other bills pending enactment, Yuan continued.
Just as Taiwan's requests for visa exemption privileges for its people when visiting the United States, a bill with the effect as an extradition pact will need time and patience, he said.
"I do not want to mislead our people into believing that this could be achieved any time soon," Yuan said.

Owing to the lack of an extradition arrangement, many of Taiwan's most high- profile fugitives are taking refuge in the United States, to the great chagrin of the Taiwanese authorities, who are powerless to bring them to justice.

Notable among these are Huang Fang-yen, who is alleged to have helped former President Chen Shui-bian launder his money, as well as Ching Chi-ju, who is reported to have duped the Foreign Ministry out of US$30 million, and Wang You- theng who stands accused in Taiwan of bilking billions of dollars from a business group he founded.

Chen Yu-hao, another business tycoon who is wanted for fraud in Taiwan, embarrassed former President Chen Shui-bian during his run for re-election in 2004 by claiming at a news conference in California that he was one of Chen's political contributors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cycling tour launched to promote Yushan as world wonder

TEXT.P: The ambassadors for Taiwan's campaign to get Yushan or Jade Mountain chosen as one of the world's natural wonders launched an around-the-island cycling tour Tuesday as part of their efforts to promote the bid.

During the 15 days leading up to the July 7 deadline for the second stage of global online voting, the ambassadors will call on opinion leaders in the business, religious, arts and cultural, and political sectors around Taiwan to encourage them to take part in the vote and offer their support for Yushan, according to the Yushan National Park Headquarters.

The ambassadors will also visit local communities and universities and invite people they encounter to draw a picture or write an article based on their impressions of Yushan, said Chen Lung-sheng, head of the park headquarters.
"Through thinking and perception covering different dimensions, we will be able to highlight the uniqueness of Yushan and inspire more people to join the vote," Chen said.
Coinciding with the cycling tour, a "vote wagon" is being sent around to allow the public to cast their votes using the computer systems installed on the vehicle, he said.

The 3,952-meter mountain, the highest in Northeast Asia, has so far maintained the top position in the "mountain, volcanoes" category in the second round of voting for the world's new seven natural wonders being held by the Swiss-based New7Wonders Foundation at www.new7wonders.com.

Located on the boundaries of Chiayi, Nantou and Kaohsiung counties, Yushan is known for its diverse wildlife and ecology. It is the only natural attraction from Taiwan to make the list of contenders in any category.

As of June 22, Africa's Kalahari Desert had taken the top position in the "landscape, ice formations" category; Ecuador's Galapagos Islands in the "islands" category; Serbia's Djavolja Varos in the "caves, rock formations, valleys" category; South America's Amazon Rainforest in the "forest, national parks, nature reserves" category; South America's Lake Titicaca in the "lakes, rivers, waterfalls" category; and Vietnam's Ha Long Bay in the "seascape" category.

The top 11 sites chosen in each of the seven categories by July 7 will then be reviewed by a panel of experts headed by Federico Mayor Zaragoza, former UNESCO director-general, who will select three nominees in each category.
The 21 nominees will be put to a final round of worldwide online voting in 2010 and 2011 to select the top seven natural wonders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's food exports in 2008 thrived despite economic downturn

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural and fishery exports in 2008 soared despite the global recession, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Tuesday at the opening of the 2009 Taipei International Food Show.

While the global economy was suffering a downturn last year, Taiwan's farm and seafood product exports still posted a 12.1 percent year-on-year growth to NT$3.85 billion last year, Chiu said at the Nangang Exhibition Hall in Taipei, where the food show is being held.

Rice exports posted the largest growth among all exports of Taiwan's agricultural and fishery products, up 10,647 percent year-on -year, followed by groupers, up 1,221 percent; carrots, up 565 percent; Taiwan tilapia, up 30 percent; and vegetable soybeans, up 15.2 percent, Chiu said, citing statistics.
Chiu was making a speech during the opening ceremony of the food show, where the Taiwan Pavilion has been taking center stage.

To showcase the freshness, safety and high quality of Taiwan's farm produce and fishery products, the Council of Agriculture (COA) has been taking part in the show by setting up the Taiwan Pavilion, which covers an area of 1,755 square meters and brings together 83 local exhibitors, according to COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung.

The Taiwan Pavilion comprises six sections, namely the Theme Section, Crop Products Section, Fishery Products Section, Livestock Products Section, Processed Food Section and Forest Products Section, Chen said.

The pavilion displays a wide variety of agricultural products such as rice, vegetables, mushrooms and processed food as well as fishery and livestock products that got certificates of the Certified Agriculture Standard (CAS), Critical Control Points (HACCP), or International Organization for Standardization (IOS).
A total of 826 exhibitors from 19 countries are taking part at the international food show, which opened Tuesday and will run until June 26. The exhibits cover an area of 14,690 square meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: National park to stock endangered salmon parr in historic habitats

TEXT.P: The Shei-Pa National Park Headquarters will hold a public activity June 26-27 in which captive-bred Formosan landlocked salmon parr will be released into the highly endangered fish's natural habitat.

The public are welcome to attend the "taking young salmon home" activity, an event that has taken place for the last two consecutive years, Liao Wu-yen, director of the park headquarters' Wuling Station, said Tuesday.

Liao said that 350 salmon parr -- juvenile salmon aged more than one year -- will be released in the Luoyehwei section of the Yousheng Creek, the Yikawan section of the Dajia River and in the Sijielan Creek.

He also expressed hope the releases will allow people to spot the national treasure in the rivers once again, and that the young fish will survive through the summer typhoons. He noted in the past two years, only 1 percent of the released parr are thought to have survived the annual typhoon season.

The conservation measures are aimed at expanding the fishes breeding territory in the wild. According to Liao, the number of Formosan landlocked salmon in the wild is around 3,500, all of which live in the Cijiawan Creek in Wuling.
The creek provides a stable environment for the delicate fish, Liao went on, adding that the park authorities still want to establish wild breeding colonies in other suitable areas.

Formosan landlocked salmon were originally migratory fish that lived in the frigid-temperate zone of the Northern Hemisphere. During the breeding season, they would swim upstream from the ocean to the upper reaches of the river where they were born, where they would mate and spawn. After the eggs hatched, the juvenile fish would return to the ocean, where they would grow to maturity before returning to the river of their birth to repeat the cycle.

Having evolved over many thousands of years to survive year-round in the fresh water of Taiwan's remote river systems without migrating to the sea, the species is now only found in Taiwan and was listed in 1984 as a precious natural resource.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air Asia to launch Taipei-Kuala Lumpur flights

TEXT.P: Air Asia announced Tuesday that it will be offering flights between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia from next month, joining the competition among several other carriers operating on the same route.
On July 1, an Air Asia Airbus A330 will make the maiden flight from Kuala Lumpur to Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and will fly the return route one hour later.
The Taipei-based China Airlines and EVA Airways as well as Malaysia Airlines all operate flights between Taipei and Kuala Lumpur.

Air Asia, based in Malaysia, will be the third low-fare, no-frills airline to serve Taiwan since the Singaporean JetStar Asia Airways and the Philippines- based Cebu Pacific Air began operations in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives advice on recession from influential economist

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou received Richard C. Koo, the chief economist of Japan's Nomura Research Institute, at the Presidential Office Tuesday, to take professional guidance in efforts to lead Taiwan out of its recession.

Koo, son of former senior adviser to the president, Koo Kuan-min, was invited by a group of heavyweight Taiwanese business tycoons, including Chinatrust Commercial Bank Chairman and CEO Jeffrey Koo, to visit Taiwan. He is Jeffrey Koo's cousin.

In the meeting, the economist renowned in both the United States and Japan told Ma that the global recession triggered by the financial storm that occurred in the U.S. last September has rarely happened in the global economic mechanism.

The financial problems caused by the credit crisis have led to companies devoting most of their resources to paying off their debts, even at a time when interest rates are near zero. As more money is deposited in banks, it can no longer flow through the market, the economist said, pointing out that the situation stems the movement of funds, which further affects an economy's economic growth.
He called this phenomenon a "balance-sheet recession" and said he believes it is behind the recession stagnation that has been hounding Japan for more than a decade.

To resolve the problem, he suggested that the government should launch long-term investment projects to increase the flow of funds in and out of the market and try to maintain the gross domestic production level.
"This process takes a very long time, so the government should be patient," he told Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's Central America tour to be extended by one day

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's planned visit to several countries in Central America will be extended by one day, an aide to the president said Tuesday.
