Fang noted that the European Union, one of his three major export destinations (the others are Japan and the United States), is very strict on the origin of imports, and some EU countries will not accept ornamental fish caught in the wild.
"The captive bred fish could easily make inroads into their markets," he says.

If Taiwan has the skills to artificially breed the clownfish and then mass produce them at a consistent level of high quality, it will have a significant competitive edge in the market, Fang believes.
That may also allow many young clownfish like Nemo to thrive once again in the wild and protect the coral reefs that serve as their natural habitats. /ls

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan could get lots more tourists with Shanghai cruise ship
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 24 (CNA) 06/24/09 21:06:58 (By P. Y. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A new cruise recently marketed by local tour agencies that will take travelers from Shanghai to Taiwan via Hong Kong has gained warm market response, particularly among families with children, as the summer vacation is just around the corner, a cruise executive said Wednesday.
According to the executive with the Shanghai Spring International Travel Service, the newly designed trip has been very popular as the first three trips have been fully booked.

He told CNA that many Shanghai parents are very interested in cruising with their kids to Taiwan and Hong Kong during the summer break despite a cost of about 9,000 Chinese yuan (US$1,323) per person for a week.

On the first day of the week-long trip, tourists will fly from Shanghai to Hong Kong, where they will depart for Taiwan the second day on board the SuperStar Aquarius cruise vessel, the executive said.
While in Taiwan, the ship will anchor in Keelung in the north, Taichung in central Taiwan, and Tainan in the south to allow tourists the opportunity to visit these Taiwanese cities.
After wrapping up tours in Taiwan, tourists will sail back to Hong Kong on the cruise ship and take a return flight from Hong Kong to Shanghai.
Each cruise ship can accommodate around 1,500 passengers, which could amount to a tourism windfall for Taiwan if the cruise route continues to be popular.

The executive said many Chinese parents are highly interested in taking part in the trip with their children, but that many of them were forced to drop the plan because the tour is strictly limited to legal residents of Shanghai City, not people who have moved from other parts of the country to live there and are not registered with the city government.
If one of the parents is not a legal Shanghai resident, the whole family will not be able to take part in the tour, the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister proposes opening Taiwan-Japan youth baseball camp

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou proposed Wednesday that Taiwan and Japan jointly open a youth baseball camp as part of their efforts to boost bilateral relations, an idea that was supported by Japanese baseball legend Sadaharu Oh.
Ou raised the proposal in a meeting with Oh, known in Taiwan as Wang Chen-chih, at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Ou said the idea was derived from President Ma Ying-jeou's focus on the importance of "cultural diplomacy" and "soft power" and the fact that baseball is one of Taiwan's best sports.
If Japan can organize a baseball camp for young Taiwanese players and thus help raise the level of baseball in Taiwan, this will contribute to closer ties between the two countries, Ou added.
The minister said he is a fan of Oh's, noting that the all time home run king was an ambassador-at-large for Taiwan who contributed a lot to the country's diplomatic efforts.
Ou said he hopes Oh will continue to use his influence and star power in Japan to help promote Taiwan-Japan relations.
In response, Oh said that baseball is all he knows and that if it can be used to enhance the links between Taiwan and Japan, he will do his best in this regard.

He said that he has been able to detect the Taiwan people's enthusiasm for baseball, and believes that if Taiwan is given the opportunity of hosting international baseball games, it will help to lift the level of the game in the country and the region.
Oh also applauded the minister's proposal to open a joint youth baseball camp and promised to convey the idea to the relevant Japanese authorities.
Oh, who retired from the Yomiuri Giants in 1980 at the age of 40, hit 868 home runs during his career, the most hit by a player in any professional league around the world.
The son of a Chinese father and a Japanese mother, Oh has stayed close to his Chinese heritage although he has spent most of his life in Japan.
He has always maintained a close relationship with Taiwan's baseball community and has contributed to the development of the sport in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prostitution to be decriminalized: official

TEXT.P: The government has tentatively decided to decriminalize prostitution in response to sex workers' appeals for better protection of their human rights, a senior official said Wednesday.
Jiang Yi-huah, minister of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, made the remarks after a meeting of the Executive Yuan's special task force on human rights.

The discussion in the meeting focused on the progress on domestic implementation of two United Nations-sponsored human rights treaties -- the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, Jiang said.

When President Ma Ying-jeou promulgated the two covenants May 14, he promised to bring all relevant domestic laws and statutes in line with the standards set forth in the two international treaties, within two years.

During Wednesday's meeting, Premier Liu was quoted as having said that the current regulations that criminalize prostitution and punish prostitutes should be amended in line with the principle of "exempting prostitutes from any penalties."
"As to whether a special district should be demarcated for the sex trade, the premier said it would be up to the local governments," Jiang told a post-meeting news conference.

Instead of putting the issue to a referendum, Jiang said, city/county councils and governments should decide on their own whether a special zone should be designated for sex trade in their administrative areas.

At the meeting, the premier also directed the Ministry of the Interior come up with a draft package of regulations on the management of sex workers and other ancillary matters within six months to pave the way for the decriminalization of prostitution.
Once the Interior Ministry completes those preparatory steps, Liu said, work should get started on amending the current statute that holds prostitutes liable to penalties.
Before the existing regulations are scrapped, the Executive Yuan will ask the Judicial Yuan to suggest that local courts fine prostitutes instead of detaining them, the premier said.
Liu also ordered the Interior Ministry not to include arrests for prostitution in the criteria for evaluating the performance of police officers.
"This will help to ensure that the police only arrest prostitutes under 'unavoidable circumstances,'" Jiang explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Irish lawmaker hails visa-free status as big step in bilateral ties
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 24 (CNA) 06/25/09 00:03:42 (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Ireland's decision to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwanese passport holders symbolizes its recognition of Taiwan's democratic development and President Ma Ying-jeou's efforts to improve relations with China, an influential Irish lawmaker said Wednesday.

"The visa-free privilege also marks a significant step forward in relations between our two countries, " said John Perry, chairman of the Ireland-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Society, in an interview with the Central News Agency.
From July 1, Taiwanese visiting Ireland for non-employment purposes such as tourism, business and family visits, will be able to enter without a visa for a maximum stay of 90 days.

This will make Ireland the second European country to offer visa exemptions to Taiwan passport holders, who will no longer have to pay NT$2,700 (US$82) for a single-entry visitor's visa or NT$4,500 for a multiple-entry visitor's visa to that country.
Since March this year, the United Kingdom has been allowing Taiwan citizens to enter the country visa-free for stays of up to six months.

Perry recalled that over the past 12 months he and scores of his colleagues in the Irish Parliament have collaborated with Taiwan's representative to Ireland, Lee Nan-yang, and several Irish universities to push the Irish government to grant visa-free treatment to visitors from Taiwan.

"I'm pleased to see our joint efforts finally bear fruit, " Perry said, adding that he believes the privilege will contribute to the promotion of trade and economic cooperation between the two countries and increased investment by Taiwan in Ireland.

The visa-free treatment is also expected to lure more Taiwanese youngsters to study in Ireland, Perry said. The Irish government hopes to attract at least 1,500 Taiwanese students per year, or 10 percent of the 15,000-plus Taiwan youths who travel annually to the neighboring United Kingdom for advanced study, he added.
Perry, who has been to Taiwan twice, is scheduled to visit the country again in September to meet with President Ma on new measures to further enhance bilateral ties.

According to official Irish statistics, Taiwan is Ireland's 21st largest trading partner, 14th largest import source and 33rd largest export outlet. Two-way trade amounted to 760 million euros (about US$1.07 billion) in 2008, with Ireland importing 536 million euros worth of goods from Taiwan and exporting 224 million euros worth of merchandise to Taiwan.

Under the new visa regulations, Taiwanese students will be allowed to enter Ireland with school admission certificates instead of student visas. If they want to stay for more than 90 days, they will be required to apply for a Certificate of Registration with the Garda National Immigration Bureau.

At the same time, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Wednesday that the 30-day visa-free period for visitors from Ireland to Taiwan will also be extended to 90 days, effective from July 1, in an effort to bolster two-way exchanges. The Taiwan government on April 1, 2003 began allowing Republic of Ireland passport holders visa-free entry for stays of up to 30 days.
Taiwanese citizens enjoy visa-free entry to 30 other countries apart from Ireland and Britain. These include Japan, Singapore and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Cross-strait talks on trade pact may start in October: minister

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait may start talks in October on the signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), according to Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming.

Yiin made the remarks Wednesday in an interview with the Central News Agency after Fan Liqing, spokeswoman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said earlier in the day that Taiwan and China are likely to start negotiations on the ECFA issue in the second half of this year.

Fan said that the two sides are stepping up preparations for striking an ECFA deal to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation. Whether the topic will be put on the agenda for the fourth round of cross-strait high-level talks scheduled for later this year will depend on the progress of the preparations by both sides, she added.

Responding to Fan's statement, Yiin said Taiwan's interacton with china in this regard has been on schedule. The research on all related subjects is expected to be completed at the end of this month, after which a comprehensive three-month study will be carried out, he added.
While the study is being conducted, the two sides will meet for preliminary talks, Yiin said, adding that this stage may not be completed in three months as scheduled.

"Conclusion of the comprehensive study will depend on whether the two sides can reach consensus on key matters of mutual concern," Yiin said. If all goes well, formal cross-strait talks on the ECFA may kick off in October at the earliest, he added.
On Vice Economics Minister Huang Chung-chiou's departure Wednesday on a visit to China, Yiin said the trip has nothing to do with the ECFA talks.

"Huang is not in charge of ECFA affairs and will therefore not talk about any issues related to that proposal during his visit.... the two sides have not yet had any exchanges on this topic," Yiin explained.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has commissioned the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research's Taiwan WTO Center to conduct an indepth study of all ECFA- related issues. Yiin said the think tank will unveil the results of the study at the end of June as scheduled.

Hopefully, the minister said, the Taiwan WTO Center and its Chinese counterpart -- the Economic and Trade Exchange Association -- would jointly organize a seminar soon on the ECFA initiative so as to explore whether both sides agree or disagree on any of the major components.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry to address gender equality issues in schools

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) plans to set up an action team to deal with gender discrimination and related issues in schools, Education Minister Cheng Jei-cheng said Wednesday.

Cheng made the announcement in the wake of a news conference held by several gender equity advocacy groups earlier in the day to review the Gender Equity Education Act five years after its implementation.

Chen Yi-chun, director of the Taiwan Gender Equity Education Association, said that while there have been encouraging signs in Taiwan's gender equity education, there is still ample room for improvement. She pointed to weak areas such as inadequate investigation into sexual harassment complaints by females, a skewed ratio of male to female faculty members, sexual bullying in schools, and a school dress code that requires all female students to wear skirts in summer.

Cheng Chih-wei, secretary-general of the Taiwan Tongzhi Hotline Association, urged the ministry to instill in students the concept of respecting people of different sexual orientations. He suggested the government promote education on homosexuality and gender differences in order to achieve gender equality in schools.

In response, the minister acknowledged that the NT$60 million earmarked by the MOE for gender equity education was inadequate, and said that the ministry will consider increasing the allocation based on the actual situation.
Minister Cheng also said that schools should not lay out a dress code for students, but if there is one, violators should not be punished.

Moreover, he admitted there are fewer female faculty members in schools in general, particularly in tertiary education institutions, However, the ministry cannot stipulate a ratio of male to female teaching staff in schools, he added.
The minister said an action team will be established to handle sexual harassment and gender bullying incidents in schools in a timely manner.

In Taiwan, females accounted for 34.12 percent of college and university faculty members in 2006, which was close to the average in countries that are members of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, and higher than the 17.9 percent in Japan, and the 30.88 percent in South Korea, according to ministry statistics.

Among 162 colleges and universities in Taiwan, only 14 are headed by female presidents. Meanwhile, Taiwan's literacy rate among females aged 15 and over surged to 96.1 percent in 2008 from 92 percent in 1999, the statistics revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA evaluating new cooperation projects with allies

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it is evaluating the possibility of starting new cooperation projects with two of its allies, in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of "economic and trade diplomacy."

Diego Chou, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central and South American Affairs, said at a regular press briefing that the Foreign Ministry is considering the possibility of launching a cooperation project with Belize on tilapia fish farming.
"Taiwan has extensive experience in tilapia fish farming, which is something Belize wants to get into. It will be a great new cooperation project between the two countries," Chou said.

Tilapia fish farming is one of the top priorities for the Belize government in its economic development of the country and it is prepared to offer aquaculture businesses a 15-year tax holiday, Chou said.

A group commissioned by the MOFA and coordinated by the non-governmental Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association visited Belize June 6-12 to study the feasibility of the project and the MOFA has asked its embassy in Belize to further evaluate the proposal, he said.
In addition, Taiwan and Saint Christopher and Nevis might also be able to cooperate in the future to explore the Caribbean ally's rich geothermal resources, according the Chou.

During his visit to Taiwan June 9-13, Joseph W. Parry, premier of Nevis Island Administration, invited Taiwan's Bureau of Energy to attend the first East Caribbean Geothermal Conference scheduled to open June 30, he added.
"We hope to help our allies through more cooperation projects -- an approach that is in line with President Ma's policy of 'economic and trade diplomacy,'" Chou said.
Ma has repeatedly said that his administration's new pragmatic diplomacy will focus on economic ties with its diplomatic allies through the provision of technology, expertise and training.

DOC.HEADLINE: Early phase clinical trial center opens in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: A center was opened at National Cheng Kung University Hospital (NCKUH) in southern Taiwan Thursday for early phase clinical trial of new drugs, mainly for cancer.

The center is a joint project launched by the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) and the hospital. Chen Jyh-hong, superintendent of the hospital, and Chang Jang-yang, director of the NHRI's National Institute of Cancer Research, presided over a plaque-unveiling ceremony to formally open the center.

NCKUH said that it set up a clinical trial center as early as 1990, but with Taiwan's advancement in new drug development and the willingness of foreign pharmaceuticals to commission clinical trials in Taiwan, the hospital decided to set up a separate early-phase clinical trial center.

Early phase clinical trials cover the first two stages of the four-phase trial of new drugs. In phase one the drug is tested on humans and the right dosages are determined. Phase two assess the effects and toxicity of the drug. Phase three researches the effects and safety of the drug, and in phase four it is monitored for side-effects after it is put on the market.
NCKUH said that the time frame for a new drug to proceed from development to clinical trials and then to the market is five to seven years and involves millions of dollars.
The hospital said it has been commissioned by local and foreign pharmaceutical companies to conduct clinical trials for 40 cancer drugs.
Most of the requests for clinical trials of new drugs have come from foreign counties, while 20 percent are from local pharmaceutical companies, the hospital said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Film Festival to feature six U.S. documentaries

TEXT.P: This year's Taipei Film Festival (TaipeiFF), which is scheduled to open June 26, will feature six U.S. documentaries, including Oscar-winning works, the American
Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Thursday.
"The AIT offers its congratulations to the 2009 TaipeiFF, with special thanks to the organizers for the inclusion of six U.S. documentary films," the AIT stated in a press release.

The six U.S. movies include four documentary films by the Oscar-winning U.S. director Rob Epstein -- The Times of Harvey Milk (1984), the winner of the 1985 Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature; Common Threads: Stories from the Quilt (1989), the winner of the 1990 Academy Award for Best Feature Documentary; The Celluloid Closet (1995); and Paragraph 175 (2000), according to the AIT.
The film festival will also include the popular documentaries The Yes Men (2003) and The Yes Men Fix the World (2009), it added.

Established in 1998, the TaipeiFF, which is organized by the Taipei City Government and the Taipei Culture Foundation, is the biggest showcase in Taiwan for international cinema and Chinese-language films.
It is scheduled to be held from June 26 to July 12 at Taipei Zhongshan Hall and Shin Kong Cineplex under the theme "Berlin" and will feature over 100 films from home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait culture summit slated for September in Beijing

TEXT.P: Officials from Taiwan and China will meet to exchange views and discuss ways to boost two-way cultural activities later this year in Beijing, it was announced Thursday.

Huang Pi-twan, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , said the two sides will hold a "cultural summit" in September in the Chinese capital to delve into several issues important to the promotion of cross-Taiwan Strait cultural exchanges.
"Culture is the largest common ground between Taiwan and China, and the two sides should set up a channel of negotiation," she told a news conference.

Huang revealed that she might take part in the Beijing summit and said that an upcoming forum between the Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China, scheduled for July in Changsha, China's Hunan Province, will also touch on the topic of cultural sharing.

In the Beijing meeting, officials from both sides will negotiate issues regarding arranging visits by cultural officials to each other's areas, organizing exhibitions, protecting intellectual property and cooperating in filmmaking and the promotion of Taiwanese art, Huang said.

Commenting on the Taiwan pavilion to be built at the Shanghai World Expo 2010, she said the facility will revolve around culture and the CCA will put forward several ideas and proposals to the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which is in charge of the construction.
The recent improvement in Taiwan-China relations has focused on setting up regular, direct transportation links as well as boosting trade and investment.
Culture, however, is believed to be one of the key factors in building mutual understanding between the two sides, whose relations have been long strained, observers said.

Taiwan's pop culture, especially music, has already been widely influential in mainland China, but its movies, performance arts and other cultural exchanges are still not widespread. Imports of Chinese contemporary culture to Taiwan is more uncommon, with no mainland Chinese TV channels accessible here, and few Chinese movies shown in theaters or singers performing here, they opined.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday:
Liberty Times: On the status upgrades for selected localities
The political manipulation underlying the government's recent decision to upgrade several localities to the level of special municipalities is the most controversial part about the decision.

Firstly, it is suspected to be a conspiracy designed to secure President Ma Ying-jeou's victory in his 2012 re-election bid. Under this conspiracy, the election for Taipei County -- a decisive race leading up to Ma's re-election bid -- will be postponed because of the county's upgrade. When the poor performance of the Kuomintang (KMT) incumbent Chou Hsi-wei is widely expected to lead to the party's defeat in the election, the postponement would help the KMT continue its grip of Taiwan's most populous locality.

It is unconstitutional for Ma's administration to put off the elections for localities affected by the upgrades. According to interpretations by the Constitutional Court, public office holders must be re-elected regularly unless there is a "major national emergency," and the upgrades do not fall under this definition.
Apple Daily: On the police's inability to deal with random assaults

The frequent occurrence of random assaults committed by anti-social individuals against innocent people poses a serious threat to society. The police, however, appear powerless to deal with such crime.
We surmise the situation would encourage more social perverts to follow suit, putting pedestrians in greater danger.

The government, especially the police, should feel ashamed when the country has become so dangerous that it is not even safe for people to simply walk or ride a motorcycle on the streets. Such a government should be condemned and ousted.
China Times: On the status upgrades for selected localities

The government's decision to upgrade several localities to the level of special municipalities is expected to bring major changes to Taiwan's political landscape, which deserve our attention. The possibilities of conflict are likely to increase not only between Taipei City and the upgraded Taipei County, but also between the central and local governments over the distribution of financial resources.

We always believe that the government should find a solution to the issue of revenue distribution first before dealing with the upgrade issue. Unfortunately, the government has put the horse before the cart.
We have no idea as to how much Taiwan will have to pay for such a premature policy. The shortsightedness of politicians is clearly demonstrated in this case.
United Daily News: On the Central Bank's monetary policy
The Central Bank is scheduled to meet Thursday to review its monetary policy. It is widely believed that the Central Bank will maintain its loose monetary policy.

With the momentum for an economic recovery remaining weak, the current policy, though not a stimulant, is a basic element for the economy to maintain its strength. Unless any of Taiwan's major competitors or trade partners change their monetary policies, it would be best for the Central Bank to stick to its present policy.

The policy adopted by the Central Bank since the start of the global financial crisis in September 2008 has been proven feasible, which helps maintain orderly market operations. At a time when the financial market has just begun to stabilize, the Central Bank's non-volatility is essential to sustaining the market's stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate calls for artists to join 2010 Wanderer program

TEXT.P: Cloud Gate Dance Theater, a renowned Taiwanese dance company, is calling for young and professional local artists to apply to join its 2010 Wanderer program and explore greater possibilities in life.

The 2010 Wanderer program is accepting applications until July 15 from people under the age of 35, budding and professional artists, and people under the age of 45 involved in social service and who have an enthusiasm for literature, music, performance art, image art or public service, a Cloud Gate press release stated.
"The experience of wandering around the world at a young age will permeate their entire lives," the press release said.
"The program will allow self reflection among the young people and help them to solidify their aspirations," it added.
According to Cloud Gate, application reviews and interviews will be conducted from Aug. 1 to Sept. 10, and the winners will be announced later in the month.
Winners will be awarded a grant of NT$80,000 to NT$150,000 (US$2,428 to US$4,553) plus return tickets, visa fees and insurance fees for a 60-day trip to any Asian country in 2010.
The Wanderer program was initiated in 2004 by Cloud Gate Theater founder Lin Hwai-min and has been sponsored since 2006 by Stat Shih, founder of the laptop- manufacturing giant, the Acer group.
Since then, a total of 41 Taiwanese artists have obtained grants under the program.
More information on the program is available on Cloud Gate's Web site at www.cloudgate.org.tw or via its telephone line 02-2712-2102.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Belgium sign financial supervisory cooperation accord

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) signed an exchange of letters (EOL) Wednesday with its Belgian counterpart --the Banking, Finance and Insurance Commission (CBFA) -- charting the way to strengthen cooperation on financial supervision.

The two commissions agreed to share information, hold regular meetings and keep in contact, conduct field inspections and visits, keep confidential the usage of information, and cooperate to fight financial crimes, according to the FSC.

Four banks in Taiwan -- Taiwan Cooperative Bank, Bank of Taiwan, Land Bank of Taiwan, and Taiwan Business Bank -- have jointly established the Taiwan United Bank in Brussels, while Belgium's KBC Bank N.V. and Fortis Bank have set up four branches in Taiwan, the FSC said.
To date, the FSC has signed 38 memorandums of understanding (MOUs) and EOLs with its counterparts in different countries around the world.
The FSC said it has signed either MOUs or EOLs, which are similar, with its foreign counterparts, depending on their preference.

A total of US$957 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.962 and fluctuated between NT$32.800 and NT$33.100.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices surge on hopes of broader cross-strait links

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices opened high and closed even higher Thursday on hopes that Taiwan and China will soon sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial supervisory cooperation and will hold talks in the second half of this year on an Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA).
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, rose 77.53 points, or 1.21 percent, to close at 6,457.61.
Finishing higher for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 6,427.88 and fluctuated between 6,497.38 and 6,404.38.
A total of 4.86 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$120.75 billion (US$3.66 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most 3.6 percent. Cement shares surged 3.5 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 3.1 percent, foodstuff stocks gained 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares added 1.2 percent, machinery and electronics issues advanced 1.1 percent, construction issues were up 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,523 to 727, with 142 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$9.36 billion in shares.

Shares in some of the assets, construction, and cement sectors on the market continued their second-day rally on news two days earlier that the Ministry of the Interior had approved an upgrade of Taipei County's status and mergers of Taichung city and county as well as Kaohsiung city and county.

An analyst at Mega International Investment Trust Co. said that the market is likely to surge in September, after the signing of the financial MOU with China, and will reach a new high in the fourth quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: 86% of gun crime cases in first five months of 2009 solved: ministry

TEXT.P: The rate of solving gun crimes stood at 86 percent in the first five months of 2009, down 3.1 percentage points from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of the Interior.
During the January-May period, the police handled a total of 107 gun crime cases, a decrease of 16.4 percent compared with the same time last year, the statistics showed.
The number of cases solved during the period, meanwhile, totaled 92.

Of the gun crime cases reported during that period, murder cases accounted for the largest number at 42, followed by robbery at 39. Compared with last year, the figures represented a drop of 12 cases and 7 cases, respectively.

The regions where gun crime were most prevalent were Taipei County and Kaohsiung County, which each recorded 14 such cases during the period. There were 12 cases in Taipei City and 10 cases in Tainan County.

Meanwhile, 751 illegal guns were seized by the police during the period, a drop of 21.3 percent year-on-year, while the number of bullets seized totaled 7,471, a decrease of 13.1 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma registers for KMT chairmanship election

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou registered as candidate for the chairmanship of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday, and vowed to lead the party on a path of democracy, integrity and efficiency.
Ma, accompanied by incumbent KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, a KMT Vice Chairman Wu Den-yih, and his campaign manager Tseng Yung-chuan, went to the party headquarters to register his candidacy.
Ma took with him the signatures of 138,857 KMT members who endorsed his bid for the chairmanship of the party.
According to the charter of the KMT, aspirants to the chairmanship position should seek the endorsement of at least 3 percent of the party membership, which currently stands at 503,184.

After completing the registration process, Ma said that his aim in bidding for the top position in the party is to more effectively fulfill his leadership responsibilities rather than "expand" his presidential power.

He vowed to lead the KMT on a path of democracy, integrity and efficiency, so as not to fail the public in its expectations, and stressed that he will campaign on a platform of reform and unity within the party.
As Ma has been the only candidate so far to register his candidacy for the KMT chairmanship, he is expected to be a shoo-in when the vote is held on July 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fresh fruit from Pingtung to make debut in Shanghai: executive

TEXT.P: Fresh fruit from southern Taiwan's Pingtung County will debut in Shanghai Sunday and will be offered as free samples to consumers in China's largest city in an effort to crack that potentially lucrative market, a corporate source said Thursday.

The government of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung is collaborating with Ganso Food Corp., a Taiwanese food company, to push Pingtung fruit products in the hope that Taiwanese fruit growers could gain access to the huge market in the greater Shanghai area, said Kuo Wen-ling, manager of Ganso's operations in Shanghai.

Some 1,000 kg of fresh fruit, including papayas, guavas, grapefruit, mangoes, bellfruit and lemons, will be displayed at the Bailian Zhonghuan Commercial Plaza, the largest shopping mall in Shanghai, from Sunday, Kuo said.
"All 1,000 kg of fruit on display will be offered to shoppers as free samples," she added.
Ganso will also be offering free fruit cakes and iced delights during the promotion, she said.
Ganso was recently selected by the Bureau of Shanghai Expo Coordination as an official sponsor of desserts and bread for Shanghai World Expo 2010, making it the 14th sponsor of the fair.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural authorities said U.S. beef safe for consumption

TEXT.P: As the issue over whether Taiwan should fully open its market to U.S. beef draws public debate, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday it believes that the products do not pose a health threat as long as the potentially risky parts of the cattle are removed.

Hsu Kuei-sen, director of the COA Animal Industry Department, said his department believes that "there should be no animal quarantine concerns" over U.S. beef once the cattle undergo health checks before and after they are slaughtered and the specified risk materials (SRMs) are taken off and discarded during the slaughtering process.

Hsu said his department came to this conclusion based on a decision by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) and Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH), which determined that U.S. beef, regardless of the age of the cattle, was safe.

Taiwan currently only allows boneless U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age to be imported, but the government is considering agreeing to a U.S. request to allow imports of U.S. beef from all cattle, regardless of age, and some beef with bones, to be imported, as long as the parts considered potentially risky are removed.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts of the cattle.

These include the brain, skull, eyes, trigeminal ganglion, notochord, backbone, and spinal nerve root, as well as all the cattle's tonsil and small intestines, according to information on the DOH's Web site.

Hsu on Thursday also noted that the United States has been recognized by the OIE as having a controlled risk to mad cow disease.
A controlled risk means the beef is safe once the cattle undergo health checks before and after slaughtering and the specified risk materials (SRMs) are removed during slaughtering.
Hsu also pointed out that Taiwan, as a World Trade Organization member, is obliged to open its market to beef imports.
He said Taiwan will import foreign beef as long as they meet existing food safety standards.
However, his office, the COA, and DOH have both stopped short of openly endorsing a full market opening for U.S. beef.

On Wednesday, DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan told the media that there is no timetable for fully opening the local market to U.S. beef. The issue also depends on whether the public will accept the product, he said.
Yeh made the remarks after Harry Tseng, head of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Department of North American Affairs expressed optimism over the timeline for full market opening.

DPP Legislator Wang Sing-nan said the government should safeguard people's health and should not be allowed to make compromises on the matter.
He called for every person in the country to telephone the DOH to directly raise their objections to the attempt to open Taiwan's doors fully to U.S. beef.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pacific high pressure system to decide tropical storm's movement

TEXT.P: With tropical storm Nangka approaching Taiwan from the Philippines, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Thursday that a Pacific high pressure system will determine how close the storm will come to Taiwan.
According to the CWB, Nangka was located 350 km west northwest of the Philippines capital of Manila as of 2 p.m. that day, moving in a north- northwesterly direction at a speed of 20 kph.

After detecting that the high pressure system was strengthening, a CWB meteorologist said that if the process is fast enough, the system will become so strong that it will force the storm west, moving it closer to China than Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the weather bureau issued a heavy rain alert for northern and eastern parts of Taiwan, as well mountainous areas of southern Taiwan, and urged the public to be aware of the dangers from sudden downpours, lightning and gusty winds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transport fee for bikes on trains to get 50 percent discount

TEXT.P: Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) announced Thursday that it will give a 50 percent discount for the transport of bikes on trains starting July 1.

At present, train passengers who take their bikes with them will have to pay the transport fee of a full-price ticket. Only groups with more than 10 passengers can get their bike transport fee at a discount of 20 percent.
In view of the current popularity of riding bikes, the TRA will provide the 50 percent discount to promote travel by train as well as biking activities.
If a group of more than 10 are taking bikes with them aboard the trains, the passengers will also enjoy a 20 percent discount of their ticket fares, the TRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung hotels 60 percent full ahead of World Games

TEXT.P: Over 60 percent of the hotels which normally cater to foreign tourists in Kaohsiung City have been booked ahead of the World Games to be held in the southern Taiwanese port city in July, a business source said Thursday.

Lin Chun-liang, CEO of the Kaohsiung Tourist Hotel Association, said the occupancy rates at eight local tourism hotels are averaging close to 70 percent over the period from July 13-29, which overlaps with the period when the games will be held from July 16-26.
Lin attributed the good occupancy rate at the eight hotels to business generated by the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC), which is organizing the games.
Meanwhile, the occupancy rate at other hotels in the city also hit around 60 percent, Lin said.

To support the games, 29 hotels affiliated with the association are offering their rooms at a preferential price of NT$2,000 (US$61) each on average, Lin noted, adding that the association is also keen on promoting tourism in Kaohsiung on the occasion of the World Games at a time when it is also a peak season for domestic travel.

Meanwhile, the Chengching Lake tourism area in neighboring Kaohsiung County's Niaosong township is undergoing an overhaul, including environmental cleanup and facilities renewal, to embrace the World Games and lure tourists.
Two competitions of the World Games -- field archery and orienteering -- will be held in the scenic area of more than 200 hectares.
In recent weeks, an increased number of Chinese and Japanese tourists have visited the area, said a local official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman launches drive pushing for ex-president's release

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen joined a group of academics and social activists Thursday to initiate a drive calling for an end to what they argue is the "unjustified detention" of former President Chen Shui-bian.
"The detention lacks legal necessity and legitimacy. Through this action, we want to highlight the unreasonableness of the existing detention system," Tsai said in a news conference.
Tsai said she hopes the drive will help muster the power of the public to promote reforms to the judicial system.

Co-sponsors of the action included former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan- tseh, Taiwan Bar Association Chairman Wellington Koo, Judicial Reform Foundation Chairman Huang Jui-ming, former Awakening Foundation Chairwoman Lee Yuan-chen, and Academic Sinica academician Chen Chien-jen.

Also on the list were Chen Hwei-syin, dean of the College of Law at National Chengchi University, Academia Sinica research fellows Michael Hsiao and Chiu Hei-yuan, and Ku Chung-hwa, chairman of the Citizen Congress Watch.
According to a statement signed by the initiators, the court decision's to continue the detention of Chen "seriously undermined the credibility of the judiciary."

The decision, the statement said, was based solely on irrelevant grounds, such as that Chen has denied he committed any crime, that he has published a book while in detention, that he has accepted visits from foreign journalists, that he has applied to rejoin the DPP, and that he has claimed he is not in good health.
Although the alleged irregularities involving Chen and his family are "disappointing, " his rights as a defendant must be upheld, according to the statement.
The former president was first detained Nov. 12, 2008 and released Dec. 13 following his indictment on charges of embezzlement, corruption and money laundering.
He was detained again Dec. 30 after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody.
Rejecting Chen's repeated requests to be freed on bail, the court ruled in March and again in May to continue his detention.
Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen are accused of siphoning off NT$104 million (US$3.15 million) from a special Presidential Office discretionary fund during his presidency from 2000 to May 2008.

They are also charged with accepting bribes in connection with a land procurement deal and kickbacks to help a contractor win the tender for a government construction project. They allegedly wired and stashed the funds overseas secretly through various intermediaries.
The couple is still being probed on suspicion of helping several financial conglomerates acquire financial holding companies in return for "political contributions."

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded oil tanker damages coral in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The stranded oil tanker Colombo Queen has left some coral formations off the southern county of Pingtung damaged, although it remains to be determined how much coral has been affected and to what extent, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

Results of a preliminary investigation show that an area of about 300 square meters surrounding the 497-ton tanker has been affected, about 150 square meters of which is covered with coral, said officials from the Construction and Planning Administration under the MOI.
The administration will continue to monitor the affected area to see whether any fuel oil has leaked from the stranded ship and whether it has affected any other marine life, the officials said.

Meanwhile, work that began a day earlier to remove the 39,000 liters of fuel oil from the stranded tanker was suspended Tuesday because of bad weather caused by the approaching tropical storm Nangka, said the Pingtung County Environmental Affairs Bureau.

As tropical storm Nangka is poised to sweep toward the Bashi Channel and the Taiwan Strait, the company authorized by the bureau to pump out the oil from the Colombo Queen began working instead to prevent further damage to the ship by strong winds that could trigger leakages.

The ship, registered in the East African island nation of the Comoros, got stuck on a reef just 50 meters from the coast in Pingtung County's scenic Jialeshuei coastal park area Saturday during tropical storm Linfa.
There were no signs of leakage from the vessel, but workers were called in to remove the fuel oil from the tanker before the authorities ask its owner to refloat the ship.

The Colombo Queen was on its way from Hiroshima in Japan to Sri Lanka and local authorities are concerned about a replay of the January 2001 Amorgos disaster, in which 1,150 liters of oil spilled from a Greek ship stranded in the same area. The valuable coral habitat took six years to recover from the damage, while Taiwan's efforts to sue for compensation in international courts took even longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Families of children raised by grandparents facing financial stress

TEXT.P: Many children raised by their grandparents said their family faces financial difficulties and they often experience feelings of abandonment, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

The survey was conducted by the non-profit Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) to gauge the living conditions of the increasing number of Taiwanese children being raised by their grandparents instead of their parents. According to a government estimate, Taiwan now has more than 90,000 households whose breadwinners are grandparents.
The survey found that 14 percent of the respondents said their families did not have fixed or regular income, which was 2.2 times that of those among normal families.

Most of the respondents' grandparents made a living scavenging because their age and stamina limited their job opportunities. Against this backdrop, 56 percent of the respondents said they often worry about their family's financial status.

Meanwhile, 30 percent said they do not like their living quarters because the houses were shabby, crowded, dirty, chaotic or had leaking roofs; and 32 percent said they could seldom pay school fees or tuition on time.

Up to 50 percent of the children surveyed said they feel that they are lagging behind their peers or classmates in their academic studies and need additional after-school tutoring; 52 percent said nobody could help them with their homework. Only 30 percent said they can afford to attend afterschool talent classes or cram schools.
Meanwhile, 40 percent of the children who responded to the survey also said they often feel abandoned and lonely.

The survey also showed that 39 percent of the children had once slept or stayed up overnight alone; 1 percent said they often or consistently take care of their own daily life by themselves; and 70 percent said they have never or only occasionally discussed things with grown-ups in their family.

CWLF executives said the campus life or relationship of children raised by their grandparents is worrisome as 50 percent of the respondents said they had been bullied by their classmates over the past two months and 5 percent said they were harassed by classmates every school day.

With the approach of summer vacation, the CWLF launched a campaign Thursday to raise funds to help school children raised by their grandparents attend talent classes or after-school classes during summer break.
The foundation began the survey late last year, targeting mainly fourth-to-sixth grade students from families with their grandparents as key breadwinners.
A total of 4,487 valid samples were collected. The survey results had a 99 percent confidence level and a margin of error of less than 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police in Taiwan and China to step up joint anti-fraud efforts

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will step up joint efforts to curb financial fraud that targets Chinese citizens, an aviation police officer said Thursday.

The statement came one day after Taoyuan prosecutors, in conjunction with some 60 police officers from various agencies, busted two Taiwan-based fraud rings that were duping Chinese citizens into transferring sums of money to bank accounts in Taiwan.

The law enforcement agents, in a raid on a residential building in Guanyin township in Taoyuan County, arrested 10 suspects and seized a number of computers, phone handsets, some 10 guidebooks, and several accounting books, according to the police officer.

Most of the victims of the phone scams were Chinese citizens who were told by impersonators of China's Public Security Bureau personnel that their phone bills were in arrears and they needed to transfer payments to designated accounts, the police officer said.
The files stored on the computers that were seized could yield more information how many Chinese people were defrauded, the officer added.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau will collaborate with China's Public Security Bureau to obtain statements from the victims' via video links, the officer said.

In another raid, seven people were arrested on suspicion of placing fake employment ads in newspapers and convincing job seekers to open new bank accounts, the officer disclosed. These accounts were later used, in a joint operation by the two fraud rings, to accept transfers from the Chinese citizens who fell for the phone bill story, he added.
All of the suspects were referred to the Taoyuan Persecutors Office for investigation, the officer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to be proactive in soliciting Chinese investors

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is scheduled to officially announce Taiwan's opening to Chinese investment capital June 30, MOEA officials said Thursday.

After lengthy inter-ministerial meetings over the past several months, the MOEA will publish next Tuesday regulations governing Chinese investment in Taiwan, regulations governing Chinese citizens establishing companies or offices in Taiwan, and a tentative list of fields of investment to be opened to Chinese capital.

Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming has instructed the ministry's Investment Commission and Industrial Development and Investment Center to be proactive in soliciting Chinese investors, including organizing investment promotion missions to China, according to the officials.
They added that major companies in China's textile, electronics, trading and car manufacturing sectors are set to invest in Taiwan.

In addition to printing investor-soliciting brochures, the MOEA will help increase the number of Chinese investment cases in Taiwan via the recommendations made by business and trade associations, as well as by cooperating with other public agencies and acting on recommendations made by Taiwanese individuals who maintain business operations in China, the officials said.

Meanwhile, Kao Koong-lien, vice chairman and secretary-general of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to visit northeastern China July 5-11 to gain a better understanding of economic development and of Taiwanese business operations there.
Kao will be accompanied by Yu Chi-cheng, deputy director of the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center during visits to Qingdao, Dalian, Shenyang and the Bohai area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals up 2.8-fold in first 5 months: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of tourist arrivals posted a 13.9 percent annual increase in the first five months of this year, with the number of visitors from China registering the largest surge, the government's statistics agency reported Thursday.

Up to 415,000 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan between January and May, marking a 2.8-fold increase year-on-year, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Quoting tallies compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the DGBAS said the number of inbound tourists reached 1.79 million in the January-May period, with visitors from China posting the largest increase, although the number of visitors from Hong Kong and Macau also increased an encouraging 26.3 percent during the five-month period.

In contrast, visitor numbers from all other areas posted negative growth, with the number of tourists from South Korea experiencing the steepest fall, down 41.9 percent year-on-year to 75,000. This was followed by an 11.7 percent drop in the number of passengers from the United States and an 8.8 percent decline in the number from Japan.
Meanwhile, the number of outbound travelers saw a 10 percent slide to 3.245 million in the five-month period.

Hong Kong was the top destination for outbound tourists, with local people making 952,000 visits during the period, followed by Japan, which attracted 427,000 Taiwanese tourists, and Macau, which hosted 313,000 Taiwanese visitors, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three cross-strait pacts take effect

TEXT.P: Three agreements signed by the top negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in late April took effect Thursday, paving the way for closer cross- strait cooperation in the financial, civil aviation and judicial fields.
Under the three agreements, the two sides will expand direct cross-strait flight services, cooperate in financial services, work together to fight crime and offer judicial aid to each other.

The three pacts were sealed in Nanjing in central China April 26 by Chiang Pin- kung, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
According to the aviation service expansion pact, the number of direct cross- strait flights will be significantly increased and will cover more destinations.

However, a provision in the aviation agreement for mutual tax exemption will not take effect along with the other clauses because a relevant law revision failed to clear the legislative floor due to a boycott from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the tax exemption clause will be implemented later after the opposition has been overcome.

As to when the two sides will sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in financial supervision to pave the way for local banks and other financial service companies to enter the Chinese market and vice versa, Liu said that relevant negotiations are proceeding between the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission and its Chinese counterpart and may reach a conclusion soon.

Touching on cross-strait judicial aid, Liu said, local citizens intending to travel to China to visit their family members serving times at Chinese prisons are advised to seek assistance of the Ministry of Justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma registers for KMT chairmanship election

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou registered as candidate for the chairmanship of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday, and vowed to lead the party on a path of democracy, integrity and efficiency.
Ma, accompanied by incumbent KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, a KMT Vice Chairman Wu Den-yih, and his campaign manager Tseng Yung-chuan, went to the party headquarters to register his candidacy.
Ma took with him the signatures of 138,857 KMT members who endorsed his bid for the chairmanship of the party.
According to the charter of the KMT, aspirants to the chairmanship position should seek the endorsement of at least 3 percent of the party membership, which currently stands at 503,184.

After completing the registration process, Ma said that his aim in bidding for the top position in the party is to more effectively fulfill his leadership responsibilities rather than "expand" his presidential power.

He vowed to lead the KMT on a path of democracy, integrity and efficiency, so as not to fail the public in its expectations, and stressed that he will campaign on a platform of reform and unity within the party.
As Ma has been the only candidate so far to register his candidacy for the KMT chairmanship, he is expected to be a shoo-in when the vote is held on July 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fresh fruit from Pingtung to make debut in Shanghai: executive

TEXT.P: Fresh fruit from southern Taiwan's Pingtung County will debut in Shanghai Sunday and will be offered as free samples to consumers in China's largest city in an effort to crack that potentially lucrative market, a corporate source said Thursday.

The government of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung is collaborating with Ganso Food Corp., a Taiwanese food company, to push Pingtung fruit products in the hope that Taiwanese fruit growers could gain access to the huge market in the greater Shanghai area, said Kuo Wen-ling, manager of Ganso's operations in Shanghai.

Some 1,000 kg of fresh fruit, including papayas, guavas, grapefruit, mangoes, bellfruit and lemons, will be displayed at the Bailian Zhonghuan Commercial Plaza, the largest shopping mall in Shanghai, from Sunday, Kuo said.
"All 1,000 kg of fruit on display will be offered to shoppers as free samples," she added.
Ganso will also be offering free fruit cakes and iced delights during the promotion, she said.
Ganso was recently selected by the Bureau of Shanghai Expo Coordination as an official sponsor of desserts and bread for Shanghai World Expo 2010, making it the 14th sponsor of the fair.

The Colombo Queen was on its way from Hiroshima in Japan to Sri Lanka and local authorities are concerned about a replay of the January 2001 Amorgos disaster, in which 1,150 liters of oil spilled from a Greek ship stranded in the same area. The valuable coral habitat took six years to recover from the damage, while Taiwan's efforts to sue for compensation in international courts took even longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Families of children raised by grandparents facing financial stress

TEXT.P: Many children raised by their grandparents said their family faces financial difficulties and they often experience feelings of abandonment, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

The survey was conducted by the non-profit Child Welfare League Foundation (CWLF) to gauge the living conditions of the increasing number of Taiwanese children being raised by their grandparents instead of their parents. According to a government estimate, Taiwan now has more than 90,000 households whose breadwinners are grandparents.
The survey found that 14 percent of the respondents said their families did not have fixed or regular income, which was 2.2 times that of those among normal families.

Most of the respondents' grandparents made a living scavenging because their age and stamina limited their job opportunities. Against this backdrop, 56 percent of the respondents said they often worry about their family's financial status.

Meanwhile, 30 percent said they do not like their living quarters because the houses were shabby, crowded, dirty, chaotic or had leaking roofs; and 32 percent said they could seldom pay school fees or tuition on time.

Up to 50 percent of the children surveyed said they feel that they are lagging behind their peers or classmates in their academic studies and need additional after-school tutoring; 52 percent said nobody could help them with their homework. Only 30 percent said they can afford to attend afterschool talent classes or cram schools.
Meanwhile, 40 percent of the children who responded to the survey also said they often feel abandoned and lonely.

The survey also showed that 39 percent of the children had once slept or stayed up overnight alone; 1 percent said they often or consistently take care of their own daily life by themselves; and 70 percent said they have never or only occasionally discussed things with grown-ups in their family.

CWLF executives said the campus life or relationship of children raised by their grandparents is worrisome as 50 percent of the respondents said they had been bullied by their classmates over the past two months and 5 percent said they were harassed by classmates every school day.

With the approach of summer vacation, the CWLF launched a campaign Thursday to raise funds to help school children raised by their grandparents attend talent classes or after-school classes during summer break.
The foundation began the survey late last year, targeting mainly fourth-to-sixth grade students from families with their grandparents as key breadwinners.
A total of 4,487 valid samples were collected. The survey results had a 99 percent confidence level and a margin of error of less than 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police in Taiwan and China to step up joint anti-fraud efforts

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will step up joint efforts to curb financial fraud that targets Chinese citizens, an aviation police officer said Thursday.

The statement came one day after Taoyuan prosecutors, in conjunction with some 60 police officers from various agencies, busted two Taiwan-based fraud rings that were duping Chinese citizens into transferring sums of money to bank accounts in Taiwan.

The law enforcement agents, in a raid on a residential building in Guanyin township in Taoyuan County, arrested 10 suspects and seized a number of computers, phone handsets, some 10 guidebooks, and several accounting books, according to the police officer.

Most of the victims of the phone scams were Chinese citizens who were told by impersonators of China's Public Security Bureau personnel that their phone bills were in arrears and they needed to transfer payments to designated accounts, the police officer said.
The files stored on the computers that were seized could yield more information how many Chinese people were defrauded, the officer added.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau will collaborate with China's Public Security Bureau to obtain statements from the victims' via video links, the officer said.

In another raid, seven people were arrested on suspicion of placing fake employment ads in newspapers and convincing job seekers to open new bank accounts, the officer disclosed. These accounts were later used, in a joint operation by the two fraud rings, to accept transfers from the Chinese citizens who fell for the phone bill story, he added.
All of the suspects were referred to the Taoyuan Persecutors Office for investigation, the officer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to be proactive in soliciting Chinese investors

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is scheduled to officially announce Taiwan's opening to Chinese investment capital June 30, MOEA officials said Thursday.

After lengthy inter-ministerial meetings over the past several months, the MOEA will publish next Tuesday regulations governing Chinese investment in Taiwan, regulations governing Chinese citizens establishing companies or offices in Taiwan, and a tentative list of fields of investment to be opened to Chinese capital.

Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming has instructed the ministry's Investment Commission and Industrial Development and Investment Center to be proactive in soliciting Chinese investors, including organizing investment promotion missions to China, according to the officials.
They added that major companies in China's textile, electronics, trading and car manufacturing sectors are set to invest in Taiwan.

In addition to printing investor-soliciting brochures, the MOEA will help increase the number of Chinese investment cases in Taiwan via the recommendations made by business and trade associations, as well as by cooperating with other public agencies and acting on recommendations made by Taiwanese individuals who maintain business operations in China, the officials said.

Meanwhile, Kao Koong-lien, vice chairman and secretary-general of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, is scheduled to visit northeastern China July 5-11 to gain a better understanding of economic development and of Taiwanese business operations there.
Kao will be accompanied by Yu Chi-cheng, deputy director of the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center during visits to Qingdao, Dalian, Shenyang and the Bohai area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourist arrivals up 2.8-fold in first 5 months: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The number of tourist arrivals posted a 13.9 percent annual increase in the first five months of this year, with the number of visitors from China registering the largest surge, the government's statistics agency reported Thursday.

Up to 415,000 Chinese tourists visited Taiwan between January and May, marking a 2.8-fold increase year-on-year, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Quoting tallies compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the DGBAS said the number of inbound tourists reached 1.79 million in the January-May period, with visitors from China posting the largest increase, although the number of visitors from Hong Kong and Macau also increased an encouraging 26.3 percent during the five-month period.

In contrast, visitor numbers from all other areas posted negative growth, with the number of tourists from South Korea experiencing the steepest fall, down 41.9 percent year-on-year to 75,000. This was followed by an 11.7 percent drop in the number of passengers from the United States and an 8.8 percent decline in the number from Japan.
Meanwhile, the number of outbound travelers saw a 10 percent slide to 3.245 million in the five-month period.

Hong Kong was the top destination for outbound tourists, with local people making 952,000 visits during the period, followed by Japan, which attracted 427,000 Taiwanese tourists, and Macau, which hosted 313,000 Taiwanese visitors, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three cross-strait pacts take effect

TEXT.P: Three agreements signed by the top negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in late April took effect Thursday, paving the way for closer cross- strait cooperation in the financial, civil aviation and judicial fields.
Under the three agreements, the two sides will expand direct cross-strait flight services, cooperate in financial services, work together to fight crime and offer judicial aid to each other.

The three pacts were sealed in Nanjing in central China April 26 by Chiang Pin- kung, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
According to the aviation service expansion pact, the number of direct cross- strait flights will be significantly increased and will cover more destinations.

However, a provision in the aviation agreement for mutual tax exemption will not take effect along with the other clauses because a relevant law revision failed to clear the legislative floor due to a boycott from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the tax exemption clause will be implemented later after the opposition has been overcome.

As to when the two sides will sign a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in financial supervision to pave the way for local banks and other financial service companies to enter the Chinese market and vice versa, Liu said that relevant negotiations are proceeding between the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission and its Chinese counterpart and may reach a conclusion soon.

Touching on cross-strait judicial aid, Liu said, local citizens intending to travel to China to visit their family members serving times at Chinese prisons are advised to seek assistance of the Ministry of Justice.
