DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 26, or the fourth day of the leap fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The U.S. Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the U.N. founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter would become effective Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to U.S. President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the Republic of China.
1992: A peoples' court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: U.S. forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former U.S. President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton begins a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
2001: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi signs an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, to help train youth from the Central American nation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor, magistrates to promote Taiwanese produce in Beijing

TEXT.P: Heads of the local governments of Taichung City, Taichung County and Changhua County departed for Beijing Friday to promote agricultural products from central Taiwan.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Changhua Magistrate Cho Poh-yuan headed for Beijing aboard a direct charter flight from Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

Cho, heading the group that also comprises members of an alliance of industrial and business associations from Taichung City and Taichung, Changhua and Nantou counties, said the group's mission in Beijing is to sell Taiwanese products and tourism to consumers in the vast markets of China's inner provinces.

Hu said that since last year, the group has traveled to Hong Kong, Macau and Xiamen to promote agricultural products from central Taiwan to great acclaim, which prompted the group to head for Beijing this time to tap China's hinterland.

After the Beijing visit, Hu will proceed to China's northeastern province of Jilin with a group of property developers and real estate brokers from Taichung to explore the real estate market in that part of the country.
The Taichung developers are expected to meet their Jilin counterparts for talks on potential joint ventures and bilateral cooperation in the trade, cultural and construction fields, Hu said.
The group took with them tons of agricultural produce, including freshly picked grapes and guavas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan signs international pact on insurance cooperation

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) has signed a new multilateral memorandum of understanding (MMOU) compiled by the International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) , making Taiwan one of the world's first signatories to the MMOU, the FSC announced Friday.

The MMOU, signed by FSC Chairman Sean Chen, offers a framework for cooperation and the exchange of information and setting up a confidentiality mechanism. With the MMOU in place, insurance supervisors will be better equipped to improve the effectiveness of cross-border supervision of insurance companies, according to the FSC.

It is the first time the FSC has signed an MMOU with an international organization and the move is expected to increase Taiwan's visibility and presence on the international stage, according to the FSC.
The IAIS holds three committee meetings every year, one of which was held in Taipei earlier in the month at which the MMOU was signed, the FSC added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday:
Apple Daily: On baby-killing by mothers

Several cases of mothers killing their newborns have been reported in Taiwan over the past year. The latest of such cases occurred Thursday, with experts speculating that the tragedy could be the result of postpartum depression.
The phenomenon is puzzling, but it is also an indication that Taiwanese society is sick.

Depression and stress experienced by mothers can be relieved through psychological or psychiatric therapy, assistance by social workers, and support from their families. However, when it comes to the traditional burdens of childbearing imposed on women and the unhealthy atmosphere of local society, it is the government that is responsible.
China Times: On the soft power of Taiwan's younger generation

Taiwan set a glorious record recently when 10 students from Shih Chien University were chosen to show their work at the Space Time Gallery of SIGGRAPH 2009 -- the world's premier forum for computer graphics and interactive techniques. One of the students, Chao Hua-chun, won third place for his project Mad Evolution, in the interactive works category of the Space Time Student Competition and Exhibition.

The brilliant performance of Taiwan's students and businesses in the fields of animation, game development and design in recent years shows that Taiwan's creativity is exploding. It also rings in the opportunity for industrial transformation in Taiwan.

Taiwan is seeking opportunities for economic breakthroughs in a "post- manufacturing age." How to build a proper connection between the talent trained in schools and the demands of business is crucial to whether Taiwan's economy can successfully reach a new climax.
United Daily News: On "economic democracy"

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) recently said that its push for a referendum on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China was aimed at establishing an "economic democracy" system. When discussing this issue, the DPP should first examine its poor performance in practicing "economic democracy" in the eight years of its administration.
The essence of "economic democracy" lies in adopting a rational approach in terms of governance, rather than engaging in political maneuvering such as promoting referendums.

With more than 10 countries having signed a free trade agreement with China and more than 20 others ready to do so, whether Taiwan should sign an ECFA with China is no longer an issue. The real issue here is how Taiwan can avoid the possible disadvantages of such an agreement. Instead of pandering to populism and making ECFA its political toy, the DPP should play its role as an opposition party properly and contribute its opinions on "how" the ECFA should be signed.
Liberty Times: On President Ma's bid for the KMT chairmanship

When registering Thursday to run in the next ruling Kuomintang chairmanship election, President Ma Ying-jeou said the bid is aimed at assuming his "new historic responsibility." This responsibility probably refers to the unification of Taiwan and China.

Upon returning to the party helm, Ma will gain full control over the tempo of cross-Taiwan Strait relations; and in his capacity as KMT chairman, he will also be able to meet his Chinese Communist Party counterpart Hu Jintao. This would increase his chances of success in promoting his "economy comes before politics" strategy for achieving unification.

Ma already proved himself incompetent during his previous KMT chairmanship. Now that he is ready to regain the leadership to realize his dream of grasping more power, not only should the Taiwanese people worry that he will bring together all government and party resources to push for unification through closer economic interaction with China, but the KMT should also begin to worry that Ma would impose a strongman leadership to again make a mess of party affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor visits Hong Kong to promote Deaflympics
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 26 (CNA) 06/26/09 15:52:56 (By Stanley Cheung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said upon his arrival in Hong Kong Friday that he wants to invite Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Chief Executive Donald Tsang to attend the 21st Deaflympic Games to be held Sept. 5-15 in Taipei.

During his two-day stay in the former British colony, Hau said he will also try to push for more exchanges between Taipei and Hong Kong, including opening direct flight services between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Hong Kong.

Soon after his arrival, Hau traveled to the Tseung Kwan O Sports Ground, where he met with Secretary for Home Affairs Tsang Tak-sing, who is also chairman of the preparatory committee for the 2009 Hong Kong East Asian Games.
Hau also invited Tsang Tak-sing to attend the Deaflympics, to which the official replied that he will attend if he can obtain permission from Donald Tsang.
In addition, Hau proposed resuming the Taipei-Hong Kong city forum that was held twice between 2000 and 2007 when President Ma Ying-jeou was mayor of Taipei.
He also expressed hope that Hong Kong's representative office in Taipei will expand its services to boost bilateral exchanges in the fields of economy, trade, tourism and culture.
He was scheduled to meet Donald Tsang later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan close to fully opening market to U.S. beef: U.S. official

TEXT.P: A long-term call from the United States asking Taiwan to fully open its market to U.S. beef will apparently be realized very soon, with Stephen M. Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), expressing confidence Friday on the issue.

Young said at his last biannual press conference before vacating the post in July that ever since he became AIT director in March 2006 he has been seeking a science-based approach to fully opening Taiwan's market to all U.S. beef by working closely with the previous Chen Shui-bian administration and the incumbent Ma Ying-jeou administration.

"As I've always said publicly, all we were asking for was a science-based determination that is grounded in the international standards set by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) , " said Young, who serves as the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Such efforts seem to have received a great response from the government, with Young pointing out that in recent days, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yeh Ching-chuan and other officials from the Council of Agriculture and the Foreign Ministry have underscored his point.
"I would be disingenuous if I didn't admit that I'm disappointed that I'm preparing to leave (Taiwan) without this agreement having been reached but I think we are very close," Young said.

Taiwan at present only allows boneless U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age to be imported, but the government is considering agreeing to a U.S. request to allow imports of U.S. beef from all cattle, regardless of age, and some beef with bones, to be imported, as long as the parts considered potentially risky are removed.

Noting that imports of U.S. beef to Taiwan amounted to a record US$136 million last year despite the restrictions on bone-in beef, Young said this indicates that Taiwanese consumers already know what the American and many other consumers around the world know about U.S. beef -- that it is safe for consumption.
"It's time for the government to move forward, " Young said, calling at the same time for the opposition parties to focus on the science and not the politics surrounding the issue.

Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts, such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines.

Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increased year-on-year. At present, the U.S. supplies around 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, with the rest coming mainly from New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urges PRC to uphold human rights after dissident's arrest

TEXT.P: Taiwan has urged China to tolerate different opinions and to uphold and realize the universal values of human rights in response to Beijing's formal arrest of prominent dissident Liu Xiaobo.

Liu, a prominent writer and pro-reform activist, was formally arrested Wednesday after being held incommunicado by police for more than six months in an unknown location on charges of suspicion of "inciting subversion of state power."
He was originally detained in early December 2008, just before the Charter 08 he co-authored was due to be released.

The charter called for democracy, protection of human rights, election of public officials, freedom of expression and religion, and an end to the Communist Party's monopoly over the military, judicial system and government.

In response to the arrest that drew global attention. Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Liu Te-shun said Thursday that all citizens should be able to present their own views on national development and the government's direction and that this is a natural phenomenon in a democratic society, one that China should face up to.
Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued a statement urging China's government to immediately release Liu.
The DPP called on China to squarely face and respond to people's calls for democratic reform instead of oppressing and even threatening pro-democracy activists.

Saying that democracy, freedom and human rights have been recognized worldwide as Taiwan's important assets, the DPP urged the Ma Ying-jeou administration to publicly appeal to Chinese authorities for Liu's release and demonstrate the country's support for China's pro-reform activists and the importance it attaches to democracy and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese music circles remember Michael Jackson

TEXT.P: News of the sudden death of America's King of Pop Michael Jackson rippled through Taiwan Friday, leaving many in the country's music community distraught and nostalgic over his many hits.
Yu Guang, a veteran music program host and concert agent said he was very sad and confused over the pop star's sudden death at the age of 50.

Yu, who invited Jackson to Taiwan in September 1993 for a concert, the third stop in the pop icon's "Dangerous" concert tour around Asia, said the Michael Jackson he knew was simple and pure and had a childlike innocence.
But Jackson, Yu said, also loved and was single-mindedly devoted to music.

Wu Chien-heng, a renowned Taipei DJ, said he had been a Jackson fan since when he was in high school and loved to mimic Jackon's signature "moonwalk, " a dance move that saw Jackson glide across the stage and set off an instant fad across the globe.
Wu said Jackson's "Thriller" in 1982 opened the door for him to Western pop music, but he picks Jackson's 1991 hit "Black or White" as his favorite.
"It was a great song with a global perspective and compassion, " Wu said.
Wu said many pop icons have visited Taiwan and given concerts here over the years, but none have been on a par with Jackson, who raised the standards of music and performance to new heights.

Jackson, whose hits also included "Billie Jean," "Off the Wall, " and "Bad, " died Thursday in Los Angeles of cardiac arrest, leaving behind an unfulfilled series of comeback concerts set for London in July and hefty debts.

He was one of the most successful entertainers of all time, with 13 Grammy Awards, 13 number one singles, several groundbreaking music videos, and sales of hundreds of millions of albums and singles during his lifetime.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese orchid enthralls Paris

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-invested company based in Normandy unveiled a new species of orchid called Mme Chirac in Paris Wednesday, with more than 80 dignitaries, including former French first lady Bernadette Chirac and her husband, in attendance.

The plant was the creation of Flossan Orchid Co., a company launched by a Taiwanese businessman in France that imports young orchids from Taiwan and grows them to maturity at its greenhouse in Normandy.

Many of the dignitaries attending the reception to introduce the new orchid, including Taiwan's representative to France Michel Lu, congratulated the company on the beauty of the new orchid and praised Taiwan's accomplishments in the field.
Mrs. Chirac voiced her appreciation for having the new strain of orchid named after her and lauded Taiwan's advanced orchid planting techniques.
Taiwan exports as many as 36 million orchids, worth over US$20 million, every year and more than half of the orchids sold in Paris are from Taiwan, Lu said.
"Taiwan's orchids have made Paris more beautiful," he observed.
Flossan's greenhouse occupies some 5,500 square meters and is capable of producing close to 20,000 orchids each month. Its products target upscale consumers in the greater Paris area.
Flossan will focus on brand building and enhancing its clientele in 2009 to better tap into the French market and boost revenues, company executives said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. not worried military secrets will leak through Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 26 (CNA) 06/26/09 17:06:05 (By Rachel Chan) (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The United States is not concerned that advanced military technologies will be leaked to China through its weapon sales to Taiwan because Taiwan is capable of protecting such technologies, the top U.S. envoy to Taiwan said Friday.

"I don't really think there is a great concern about the transfer of technology from Taiwan because I think that Taiwan has very effective means in the controlling of technology, " Stephen M. Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , said at a biannual press conference.

Young, the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries, is scheduled to leave Taiwan in July after concluding his three-year term as AIT director.

Young said that while the U.S. welcomes the reduction of tensions between Taiwan and China, it is also aware of the People's Republic of China's relentless military buildup -- much of it directed at Taiwan -- and the Ma Ying-jeou administration's interest in continuing to pursue security cooperation with the U.S.

"I think that the Obama administration will calculate the requests of our Taiwan friends in that light and act at an appropriate time when there are decisions about what types of defensive weapons might make the most sense to provide this island, " he said.

Describing the triangular relations among Taipei, Beijing and Washington, Young said there have been times in the past when one side of the triangle was stronger than others, but that one of the promising aspects at present is that all three sides are fairly strong, and improving and growing.

"An important point here is that President Ma and his government, despite its very major focus on improving relations with Beijing, continues to believe it is appropriate and necessary to have an active security cooperation relationship with the U.S.," Young said.
He added that Washington will continue to look closely at Taiwan's arms sales requests and that it will not consult with Beijing on its security cooperation or arms decisions involving Taiwan.

"That's the framework. The decision itself will be made by Washington under that framework at a time and in a nature that reflect our own national interests as well as our commitments to Taiwan," Young said.
He believes that the efforts of all three of the triangle's sides can help reduce the possibility that Taiwan might be a land mine in U.S.-China relations, as some have suggested. Enditem/ls

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.045 to close at NT$32.925.
A total of US$647 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.970 and dropped to the day's low of NT$32.848.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan stock prices edge higher

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose marginally Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging up 5.95 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 6,463.56.

In line with Wall Street's overnight gains and rallies in other Asian markets, the local bourse opened higher at 6,515.64 and reached a high of 6,527.86 before retreating to the day's low of 6,460.91. The Taiex ultimately closed higher for the third straight day.
A total of 4.08 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$106.98 billion (US$3.25 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks leading the way by advancing 1 percent. Foodstuff shares and plastics and chemicals issues gained 0.6 percent, cement shares rose 0.5 percent, and textile stocks as well as banking and financial shares added 0.1 percent.
The other two major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares and machinery and electronics issues each dropping 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,128 to 994, with 197 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$6.40 billion in shares.
Solar energy and online game shares and China-concept stocks outperformed the broad market.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games budget gap should be plugged via negotiations: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Friday requested the Kaohsiung City government and the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) to resolve an NT$200 million (US$6.06 million) budget shortage for the 2009 World Games through negotiations.

Making the appeal during a safety inspection of the World Games main stadium, Liu said that to ensure the success of the event, it should in principle be held by the local government and supported by the central government because of its importance to the country.
The city and central government should find ways to narrow the budget shortage on the basis of not wasting public funds, Liu added.
SAC Minister Tai Hsia-ling, who was with Liu in Kaohsiung, said that once the city government applies for funds legally and reasonably, the SAC will carefully review the application.

The SAC slashed an NT$845 million budget approved for the World Games by NT$230 million earlier this month because of what it described as inflated and overlapping funding requests by the city government.
After further discussion, Kaohsiung still finds itself NT$190 million short of its targeted budget.

Meanwhile, during his inspection of the World Games venues, the premier expressed his concerns over the event's safety measures, the parachuting events, and the certification of the athletes' villages and personnel and urged the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC) to pay particular attention to these areas.
The premier noted that if individuals duplicate their applications for permits, it could cause a loophole in security preparations.
Referring to the kidnapping of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, Liu asked the KOC to step up measures to ensure the safety of the hotels that athletes will use.

The premier also agreed to Kaohsiung's requests for the central government to send 600 military police to maintain security during the event and to grant visa-free treatment to Kenyan guests who will visit Taiwan during the games, slated to be held July 16-26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local government heads arrive in Beijing to promote trade

TEXT.P: Heads of three local governments from central Taiwan arrived in Beijing Friday to promote agricultural products from central Taiwan, boost trade opportunities and meet with Taiwanese businessmen operating in northern China.

Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, accompanied by Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng and Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan, said the Taiwanese delegation with nearly 200 members from four cities and counties was the biggest ever to visit Beijing.

Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching was also expected to be part of the group, but he backed out after learning tropical storm Nangka might hit Taiwan in the next few days and sent Chen Chao-wang, chief of the county's agricultural bureau, on his behalf.

Hu said the group had brought many special agricultural products to the capital city to share with the Chinese people, after similar promotional trips to Hong Kong, Macau and Xiamen had met with considerable success.

Cho, heading a group that also comprised members of an alliance of industrial and business associations from the four cities and counties, said before leaving Taiwan earlier in the day that the group's mission in Beijing is to sell Taiwanese products and tourism to consumers in the vast markets of China's inner provinces.
The group will organize a trade fair and visit city officials during its stay in Beijing before returning home June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top U.S. envoy to leave post in July

TEXT.P: Stephen M. Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), bid farewell to local media Friday before stepping down from his post in July but remained silent on the identity of his successor.

Young, who assumed his post as AIT director in March 2006, said at his last press conference with members of Taiwan's media before completing his three-year term that Taiwan and the United States were very close to working out the identity of his successor.
When a decision is made, he said, the announcement will be made in Washington.
Speculation in Washington has centered on William A. Stanton, deputy chief of mission to the Republic of Korea, as the most likely diplomat to succeed Young.

Describing his job as a relay competition, the 10th AIT director said that he has followed the steps of his nine distinguished and competent predecessors, and he would consider it a great accomplishment if he had done his job as effectively as them.
"You don't want to drop the baton. You want to pass it on. I feel that I've carried the baton now for three years and four months as the director and I'm ready to pass it on," Young said.
"I've not dropped it yet and I am almost finished," he added.
Young said he is glad that he has been able to have a good frank dialogue with Taiwan's government and its people about many areas of the very close relationship between Taiwan and the U.S.

"Our relations with Taiwan today governed by the Taiwan Relations Act and other aspects of our China policy are in good shape. They are in good shape because we have so much in common, both in values and in interests, " Young said, referring to stronger protection of intellectual property rights, a possible investment agreement, and e-commerce cooperation.
The Obama administration is also working with Taiwan to clinch an extradition pact that will enhance the already strong law enforcement cooperation between the two countries, he added.

Nearing the end of his fifth stay in Taiwan over the past 46 years, Young, who is an enthusiastic cyclist, said that he will go back to the U.S. with four Giant bicycles manufactured in Taiwan and that he would love to visit this beautiful island again in the future.
Though the exact date Young will leave Taiwan has yet to be confirmed, he will depart shortly after presiding over a function July 2 to celebrate U.S. Independence Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Patient's 576 insured doctor visits in 2007 the most in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A patient suffering from blood coagulation abnormalities and mental disorders was the most-frequent user of the National Health Insurance (NHI) system in 2007, making 576 insurance-covered medical visits during the year, the Bureau of National Health Insurance said Friday.
This means that the patient visited hospitals almost twice a day except for holidays, said Chang Shu-ling, manager of the bureau's Medical Affairs Section.
Chang mentioned the case while briefing the NHI Supervisory Committee on the bureau's measures to control abuses of the insurance program.

Chang said that at present, any person covered by the insurance system who makes more than 200 medical visits a year or more than 20 visits in a month will be monitored and offered counseling by the bureau.
There were 376 people who made more than 200 doctor visits in 2007, and 9,176 people who made more than 20 visits in a given month in 2008, she said.
According to Chang, the two most common abnormal patterns in among local patients were an unusually high frequency of medical visits and unusually high expenses.
While high visit frequencies are usually seen among patients with mental disorders, high expenses often occur in treating patients suffering from cancer or serious illnesses, she said.
Through the control measures adopted by the bureau, the average number of medical visits by high-frequency users decreased by 20 percent in 2007 and 50 percent in 2008, bureau statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity hospital to distribute organic rice worldwide

TEXT.P: The Chiayi County branch of the Tzu Chi General Hospital has reaped a greater- than-expected harvest of organic rice recently and will distribute the crop to followers of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation around the world, a hospital spokeswoman said Friday.

Ho Zi-yi, a section chief of Tzu Chi General Hospital's Dalin Branch in charge of human affairs, said a total of 840 kilograms of the rice was harvested last week from an experimental farm operated by the branch.
The organic rice will be packed into small gift bags to be distributed worldwide to enable Tzu Chi followers to share the harvest, Ho said.

She said the harvest of the Taigeng No. 2 rice strain was considered a precious gift from God, as rice farmers in eastern Taiwan lost all of the year's first harvest of the Taigeng No. 4 rice strain because of a string of cold spells that hit Taiwan in April.
The Taigeng No. 2 strain is stronger in terms of pest and cold weather resistance, Ho said.
The Dalin Branch is the only one of the Tzu Chi General Hospital's six branches in Taiwan that runs an experimental rice farm.

In addition to running health institutions in Taiwan, Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity organization, has also operates environmental protection facilities, including major recycling centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry organizes youth diplomats to expand exchanges

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday launched its first "international youth diplomats exchange project, " in which university students serve as young diplomats to help Taiwan expand cultural and educational exchanges with youth in countries with which it has diplomatic allies.

Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said at a ceremony to present flags to mark the establishment of the young diplomatic mission that the new project is aimed at passing on Taiwan's rich experience and "soft power" in culture, advanced technology and education system to its allied countries.
The program will also help strengthen relations with Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

"We hope that our allied countries will benefit from young diplomats like you, who are tasked with introducing Taiwan's development experience to your counterparts through the sharing of your knowledge and talents," Ou said.

This project will also broaden students' vision and increase understanding from home and abroad on President Ma Ying-jeou's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy, which favors a moderate and pragmatic approach to enhancing relations with diplomatic allies and expanding substantial relations with non-allied countries, he added.

According to the foreign ministry, National Taiwan University, National Chengchi University and Fu Jen Catholic University will form six student groups to visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the Pacific -- Palau, Tuvalu, Marshall Islands, Solomon Islands, Nauru and Kiribati -- during the summer vacation.
The universities will also organize activities to enable the youth to exchange culture and knowledge with youngsters from those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic indicators improve in May for second consecutive month

TEXT.P: Leading economic indicators in May pointed upwards for the second consecutive month, providing a glimmer of hope that Taiwan's economic slump could ease in the near future, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Friday.

The monitoring score for Taiwan's leading indicators was 12 in May, up one point from April, but the indicators continued to flash a "blue" signal for the ninth consecutive month, a sign that the local economy remains in recession, the CEPD said.

The Cabinet-level council uses five colors to measure domestic economic health, with "red" indicating serious overheating, "yellow-red" for light overheating, "green" for steady growth, "yellow-blue" for a slowdown, and "blue" for recession.

Most other indicators showed positive cyclical movement in May, according to the CEPD report. The composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer of the economic outlook for the coming three months -- moved higher by 3.3 percent in May from the previous month to 94.9, rising for the fourth consecutive month.
The annualized six-month rate of change of the leading indicators index rose by 7.8 percentage points from April to 3.5 percent -- the first positive figure in 16 months.
All seven leading indicator components, except for new building permits, contributed positively to the index.

Export orders, average monthly overtime in industry and services, book-to-bill ratios in the semiconductor machinery industry, monetary aggregate M1B, stock prices, and producers' inventory all showed positive movement, the report showed.

The index of coincident indicators, which represents the current economic situation, stood at 87.4 in May, up 2.7 percent from the previous month. It grew for the fourth consecutive month, the CEPD said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel agencies hit hard by economic downturn

TEXT.P: Another local travel agent announced Friday that financial woes had forced it out of business, the latest sign that the global economic recession and the recent scare over the swine flu outbreak continue to take a toll on local tour operators.
Taipei-based Long Way Travel Service Co. said Friday it was shutting down because of operating difficulties and accumulated debts of more than NT$10 million (US$300,000).

Long Way became the second industry casualty in the past month after Skylark Travel Service Co., a prominent travel agent known for organizing high-end group tours to Japan, also ended operations recently because of similar cash flow problems after a potential buyout by Tsann Kuen Trans-Nation Group fell through.
Both Long Way and Skylark enjoyed good reputations in the local tourism sector.
According to the Travel Quality Assurance Association of the Republic of China, a bad economy is the prime reason behind the difficulties facing many travel agents.

Amid a lingering economic crunch, many people have opted to cut down on travel to save money, and a full recovery for travel agents might be still some ways off, sources familiar with the business said.

A Long Way employee told the Central News Agency that the number of tours organized by the agency since the beginning of this year had fallen by 30 percent to 40 percent compared to the previous year's level.
Long Way specializes in tours to Southeast Asian countries, which normally attract large numbers of Taiwanese tourists, but have suffered this year along with most other destinations.

According to statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Taiwanese took 3.24 million trips abroad in the first five months of the year, 10 percent fewer than during the same period in 2008.
The monthly number for May also dropped by 13.28 percent year-on-year.
Travel to Japan, usually one of the most popular overseas destinations among Taiwanese tourists with more than 1 million visits a year, has been particularly hard hit.
Only 80,382 Taiwanese visited Japan in May, compared to 124,440 visits in the same month last year, a year-on-year decline of 35.41 percent.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's tourist departures to Thailand also shrank to 21,558 in May this year, from 33,896 in May 2008.
Foreign tourist arrivals to Taiwan in May, not including travelers from China, also were down, by an annual rate of 18.55 percent.

The number of tourists from Japan and South Korea visiting Taiwan last month fell by 18.46 percent and 39.1 percent, respectively, while the number from Singapore and Malaysia also declined by 28.69 percent and 39.77 percent, the statistics show.
Although more Chinese tourists came to Taiwan in March and April, business sources said the outbreak of swine flu, known officially as influenza A (H1N1) has affected their willingness to travel.
In April, an average of 3,280 Chinese tourists entered Taiwan per day, but that number fell to 1,500 per day in late May and has averaged only 950 per day so far in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to step up monitoring of oil used in fast food chains

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) sent test paper that detects the acid value of cooking oil to local fast food chains to help them monitor the quality of the oil they are using to fry foods.

The DOH said acid value is an indicator of whether the composition of the oil has changed due to repeated use, and that the maximum acceptable acid value will be adjusted downwards to 2.0 mg KOH/g from the original 2.5.
The acid value measures how many milligrams of potassium hydroxide (KOH) it takes to neutralize the fatty acids found in one gram of oil.

Hsu Ching-hsin, a senior technical specialist in the DOH's Department of Food Safety, said that virgin oil should have an acid value approaching zero but that the figure rises with repeated use as the oil rancidifies and fatty acids are created.
"Fast-food operators should use the test paper to manage and replace the oil they use," Hsu said.
Local health authorities will now list the edible oil used in fast food chains as one of the priorities when they conduct spot checks on food safety, he added.

The move comes after spot checks carried out by the Taipei County government Sunday found that some big name fast food outlets did not change their frying oil on a daily basis, prompting worries that the continued use of the oil would release carcinogenic substances and pose a health hazard to consumers.
Fast food restaurants such as McDonald's, KFC, Burger King, Pizza Hut and Napoli Pizza sent representatives Friday to listen to a briefing on the DOH's latest regulations.
Some of them, including McDonald's and KFC, said they would follow the guidelines recommended by the DOH.

Food safety officials said that restaurants are required to make improvements if the oil they are using does not meet the standard. Those failing to follow the guidelines will be fined between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's ailing Chuang happy with Mirza partnership
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 26 (CNA) 06/26/09 21:34:23 (By Jennifer Huang and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chuang Chia-jung hopes to re-establish herself as one of the world's top-ranked women's doubles players with a strong showing at Wimbledon, and she got off to a good start Thursday despite fighting pain in her lower back.

Chuang and partner Sania Mirza of India, seeded 15th in this year's women's doubles, needed only 79 minutes to finish off Americans Jill Craybas and Carly Gullickson 6-4, 6-2 in a first round match to set up a second round encounter with unseeded Alla Kudryavtseva of Russia and Monica Nicolescu of Romania.
Chuang told the Central News Agency that she had been suffering from a lower back strain in the days prior to her doubles opener, and she said the pain intensified Thursday.
She got a massage and took pain killers prior to the match, which helped to some extent, but her movement was still limited during the encounter.
After climbing as high as fifth in the women's doubles rankings in August 2008 while partnering with compatriot Chan Yung-jan, Chuang's ranking has suffered since.

The duo broke up over personal differences soon after a poor showing at the Beijing Olympics (second round) and the US Open (first round) , and with Chuang playing with six different partners since then, her ranking has plummeted to 27th.
But Chuang believes her pairing with Mirza, which began in March and has led to a WTA Tour win and three semifinal appearances, has potential.

"Our chemistry is getting better, she said.Mirza has a good forehand and is excellent from the baseline, while my strengths are my backhand and I'm pretty good at net. We complement each other well and could continue playing together in the future.

The two were eliminated in the second round of the French Open, but hope to do better at Wimbledon, where Chuang and Chan crashed out in the first round last year. The question now is how much they will be affected by Chuang's injury.
Chuang remains the last Taiwanese player remaining in a singles or doubles draw (not including the mixed doubles).

Lu Yen-hsun was ousted in the first round of the men's singles by second seed Roger Federer and in the first round of the men's doubles (paired with Bjorn Phau of Germany) by Russians Igor Andreev and Evgeny Korolev in straight sets.

Chan was crushed in the women's singles by 12th seed Marion Bartoli of France, and lost her first round doubles match, paired with Hungary's Agnes Szavay, to Russia's Vera Dushevina and Tatiana Perebiynis of the Ukraine 7-5, 3-6, 6-4.

A bigger surprise was when fifth seeds Hsieh Su-wei of Taiwan and Peng Shuai of China lost their first round match on Thursday to Sorana Cirstea of Romania and Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark 6-4, 2-6, 6-2.
Though neither Cirstea or Wozniacki are highly ranked in doubles, they both have reached the third round of the women's singles and proved to be too good for the Taiwan-China pairing.
Peng, who lost a three-hour singles match earlier in the day, said the energy- sapping singles match affected her performance in the later doubles.

Hsieh and Peng reached the quarterfinals of this year's Australian Open and the semifinals of the French Open, catapulting Hsieh to No. 11 in the world in women's doubles, above both her more storied compatriots Chuang and Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1963 death of German priest confirmed by local policeman

TEXT.P: A policeman stationed in Pingtung County recently tracked down the tomb of a Catholic missionary from Germany at the behest of his family members, who were never fully convinced by reports that the priest had died in the southern Taiwan county in 1963.

Tien-Hsiang Chen-ling, a member of the Chaojhou police department in Pingtung County, was assigned to find out the truth at the request of Father Sebastian M. Heuken's family members, who wanted any documents that could prove Heuken's death.
According to Heuken's younger brother Karl, the priest had worked at a Catholic church in Chaojhou since his arrival in Taiwan in 1960.
Karl said his brother reportedly died in a traffic accident and was buried in the small town, but he questioned the report's accuracy because he never received his brother's death certificate.
Tien-Hsiang said it was the most difficult case he had ever investigated because there were no clues indicating the priest's existence.
"I could find nothing at local household offices, other police stations and traffic police divisions," the police officer said.

After turning to local churches, he finally discovered that the missionary's remains were buried at a Chaojhou church cemetery. Heuken's tombstone was engraved with Chinese characters reading "the tomb of Father Ho Li-chien" and his German name.

Tien-Hsiang said he also visited an 86-year-old Catholic nun from Switzerland in Pingtung's Jiandong Township who had worked with Heuken to gain first-hand information about the accident that led to Heuken's death.

Sister Germana Rotzetter told him that on the day of the tragedy, she and Heuken were each riding a motorbike on Provincial Highway No. 1 when Heuken collided with an oncoming cargo truck, the police officer said.
Rotzetter recalled that she called for help, but when it came, it was too late.
Tien-Hsiang said he found out that Heuken's personal effects and his death certificate had been kept at a parish in Donggang but were eventually destroyed due to their old age.

DOC.HEADLINE: No decision yet on relaxation of U.S. beef imports: DOH

TEXT.P: The government has not yet made any decision on whether to ease restrictions on U.S. beef imports, Department of Health (DOH) Deputy Minister Sung Yen-jen said Friday.

The Consumers' Foundation argued earlier in the day that if the government opens its domestic market wider to U.S. beef imports, it would be tantamount to "selling out local people's health or putting their health at risk."

"No conclusion on the issue has been reached yet," Sung stressed. "At the moment, we only recognize that U.S. beef meets the requirements of having all specified risk materials (SRMs) taken off and discarded in the cattle slaughtering process."
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months over mad cow disease concerns.
Earlier Friday, Washington's top envoy to Taiwan, Stephen M. Young, said Taiwan was very close to fully opening its market to U.S. beef, but Sung did not agree.

"Even though officials from the U.S. Trade Representative office gave us their assurances during a visit to DOH headquarters last week, we have never promised to allow imports of beef from cattle older than 30 months," Sung elaborated.
During their visit, U.S. officials presented documents showing that all U.S. beef met safety regulations set forth by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE).

All cattle undergo health checks before and after they are slaughtered and the SRMs, including brain, skull, eyes, trigeminal ganglion, notochord, backbone, and spinal nerve root, as well as all of the cattle's tonsils and small intestines, are all removed during the slaughtering process, the officials said.

Before the arrival of the U.S. trade officials, Sung said, the DOH had sent its staff members to the United States on two separate occasions to check out animal quarantine and slaughtering operations there.
Through extensive face-to-face discussions, Sung said, DOH officials have come to the conclusion that U.S. beef met the OIE-established safety requirements.

Moreover, Sung said, the United States has imposed strict restrictions on animal feed since 1997. Against such a backdrop, U.S. beef from cattle born after that year and treated in accordance with the OIE requirements was not likely to contain mad cow disease.
Nevertheless, Sung said, the government plans to still only allow imports of de- boned beef from cattle younger than 30 months, and not of any age as the U.S. has requested.
Taiwan's quarantine officials currently conduct spot checks on two to five batches out of every 100 shipments to look for irregularities.
"We only occasionally spot some small pieces of bones in certain shipments, which are invariably denied entry. Otherwise, no other major violations have been discovered," he added.
Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle.

The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts, such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines, mixed in.

Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increasing year-by-year. The U.S. currently supplies around 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, with the rest coming mainly from New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fumigation treatment plant helps Tainan mango exports to Japan

TEXT.P: A fumigation treatment plant has played a big role in the success in a Tainan County town's efforts to export Irwin mango exports to Japan, cutting down the time it takes to process the fruit before shipping it overseas.

Mango growers in the Tainan County town of Yujing said that in the past, Taiwan had mainly exported Chin Huang mangoes, a yellow-skinned mango, because they could be stored for a longer time than the more popular Irwin mango, with its sweet fragrance and attractive red color.

They said that because the Irwin mango cannot be stored for long and its harvest time is too concentrated during a specific period of time during the summer, the price of Irwin mangoes often plunged during the harvest period.

Many Irwin mango growers wanted to give up and turn to other kinds of mangoes because of these problems, but the establishment of a fumigation treatment plant in Yujing helped turn the tide, the growers said.

Fruit exported to Japan needs to be fumigated to help tackle the fruit fly or other pest problems. Prior to the building of the NT$130 million fumigation treatment plant in Yujing in 2004, that meant that harvested mangoes had to be transported to Kaohsiung and to Fengyuan in Taichung County to be fumigated.
The time it took to transport the mangoes and their vulnerability to bruising often left the fruit damaged during the transportation process, the growers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 27, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
2001: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrats are repatrated from Fu Su Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangement by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: No decision yet on relaxation of U.S. beef imports: DOH

TEXT.P: The government has not yet made any decision on whether to ease restrictions on U.S. beef imports, Department of Health (DOH) Deputy Minister Sung Yen-jen said Friday.

The Consumers' Foundation argued earlier in the day that if the government opens its domestic market wider to U.S. beef imports, it would be tantamount to "selling out local people's health or putting their health at risk."

"No conclusion on the issue has been reached yet," Sung stressed. "At the moment, we only recognize that U.S. beef meets the requirements of having all specified risk materials (SRMs) taken off and discarded in the cattle slaughtering process."
At present, Taiwan only allows imports of boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months over mad cow disease concerns.
Earlier Friday, Washington's top envoy to Taiwan, Stephen M. Young, said Taiwan was very close to fully opening its market to U.S. beef, but Sung did not agree.

"Even though officials from the U.S. Trade Representative office gave us their assurances during a visit to DOH headquarters last week, we have never promised to allow imports of beef from cattle older than 30 months," Sung elaborated.
During their visit, U.S. officials presented documents showing that all U.S. beef met safety regulations set forth by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE).

All cattle undergo health checks before and after they are slaughtered and the SRMs, including brain, skull, eyes, trigeminal ganglion, notochord, backbone, and spinal nerve root, as well as all of the cattle's tonsils and small intestines, are all removed during the slaughtering process, the officials said.

Before the arrival of the U.S. trade officials, Sung said, the DOH had sent its staff members to the United States on two separate occasions to check out animal quarantine and slaughtering operations there.
Through extensive face-to-face discussions, Sung said, DOH officials have come to the conclusion that U.S. beef met the OIE-established safety requirements.

Moreover, Sung said, the United States has imposed strict restrictions on animal feed since 1997. Against such a backdrop, U.S. beef from cattle born after that year and treated in accordance with the OIE requirements was not likely to contain mad cow disease.
Nevertheless, Sung said, the government plans to still only allow imports of de- boned beef from cattle younger than 30 months, and not of any age as the U.S. has requested.
Taiwan's quarantine officials currently conduct spot checks on two to five batches out of every 100 shipments to look for irregularities.
"We only occasionally spot some small pieces of bones in certain shipments, which are invariably denied entry. Otherwise, no other major violations have been discovered," he added.
Taiwan banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) -- also called mad cow disease -- was diagnosed in Seattle.

The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the government reimposed the ban two months later when a second BSE case was discovered in the U.S.

In 2006, the DOH agreed to allow beef imports once again, but only boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months of age, produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any risky parts, such as brains, skulls, eyes, spinal nerve roots, tonsils and small intestines, mixed in.

Over the past three years, U.S. beef imports have been increasing year-by-year. The U.S. currently supplies around 32 percent of Taiwan's beef, with the rest coming mainly from New Zealand and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Artist Villages launches 'FunArts' workshop

TEXT.P: The Taipei Artist Village (TAV) , a non-governmental artist community run by the Taipei Culture Foundation, on Saturday launched its first "FunArts" Artist Workshop in Grass Mountain Arts Village in suburban Taipei.

The "Silk Road, Thought Road: Embroidering Workshop by Lily Huang, " which kicked off the same day, is one good reason for people to get away from the bustle of the city and visit the arts village in Yangmingshan National Park, the TAV said in a press statement. It described the art of embroidery as detailed, refined and three dimensional.
"Using needle and braid knit skills, artist Lily Huang is drawing her inspiration from the natural scenery of Grass Mountain in her new art form 'Stainless Steel Embroidery,'" said the press release.
"Leave the complex city behind, concentrate on the needles, feel the art, enjoy a moment of silence," the TAV urged the public.
According to the TAV, the embroidery workshop will be held June 26 and July 11 from 2: 30 p.m.-4: 30 p.m. at 92 Art Center, Grass Mountain Artist Village.
Discounts of 10 percent will be offered to people who hold a Children's Arts Festival Passport, the TAV said.
Established in 2001, the TAV is Taiwan's first artist village. It serves as a center for creativity, reaching out to local residents and foreign artists through a variety of activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regional parliamentarians' conference to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The 40th annual conference of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) is scheduled to take place Aug. 10-12 in Taipei, marking the first time that Taiwan will host an APPU event, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday.
APPU, which is comprised of 21 countries in the Asia-Pacific region, is the only international parliamentary organization in which Taiwan has membership.
Other members of the organization include Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Mongolia, Laos and the Solomon Islands.
According to Wang, the upcoming meeting will focus on the theme of human security and is expected to draw nearly 100 parliamentarians from the member states.
Wang said seeking membership in international parliamentary organizations is one of the ways the Legislative Yuan can help develop the country's foreign relations.
The opportunity to host the international conference will also allow Taiwan's legislators to strength their friendship and exchanges with their foreign counterparts, Wang said.

In addition, the participation of Taiwan's legislators in international events will help to expand Taiwan's presence in the international arena, giving the country an opening to free itself from the diplomatic isolation imposed by China, he said.
"Parliamentary diplomacy is a path that can lead Taiwan back to the international community," Wang said.

At present, more than 50 countries and regions have set up Taiwan friendship groups within their parliaments, while there are 34 inter-parliamentary groups in the Legislative Yuan to promote friendship with their foreign counterparts, he said.
One of these groups, the Taiwan-USA Inter-Parliamentary Amity Association, is likely to visit the United States in early September.
Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who heads the association, said the visit, if realized, would focus on lobbying for Taiwan's procurement of F-16 C/D fighters from the United States.

According to Lin, a visit to the U.S. by Taiwanese legislators in July 2008 played a crucial part in prompting the former administration of George W. Bush to approve six arms sales to Taiwan in October that year.

During the visit, the legislators discussed the arms issue with officials of the U.S. Department of State and Department of Defense as well as with leaders of the armed services committees of the Senate and the House of Representatives, which helped the U.S to resolve any doubts about Taiwan's determination to acquire the weapon systems, Lin said.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan-Japan Exchange Association is planning to visit Japan after the conclusion of Japan's parliamentary elections in September.
Lee Hung-chun, a KMT legislator who heads the group, said the association meets every year with the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council to discuss issues of bilateral concern.

He noted that Japanese parliamentarians have contributed greatly to the adoption of reciprocal measures by the two sides in recent years, including the mutual visa waiver program and mutual recognition of driver's licenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan office in New York issues 1,000th ROC e-passport
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 26 (CNA) 06/27/09 16:41:41 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York issued its 1,000th Republic of China passport embedded with an integrated circuit (IC) chip Friday, which was a milestone in a program instituted by Taiwan last year mainly to crack down on crimes involving forged passports.

Kenneth K.M. Liao, head of the TECO New York office, reiterated that objective as he handed over the 1,000th IC passport to the applicant. He also expressed the hope that the United States, which he described as one of Taiwan's best foreign friends, would allow visa-free treatment for Taiwan passport holders.

Ireland recently announced that, with effect from July 1, Taiwan citizens visiting Ireland for non-employment purposes such as tourism, business and family visits will be able to enter the country without a visa for a maximum stay of 90 days.
Liao attributed the decision, which followed a similar concession by Britain in March this year, to Taiwan's introduction on Dec. 29, 2008 of its new anti-fraud IC passport.

If Washington decides to offer visa-free treatment to the large number of Taiwan citizens who travel to the U.S. every year, this will not only allow greater convenience, but will also symbolize the close friendship and mutual trust that exist between the U.S. and Taiwan, he said.

Taiwan began issuing electronic passports late last year as part of an effort to prevent human smuggling rings from using the stolen identity of Taiwan children to apply for ROC passports through "legal channels."
Taiwan is hoping that the highly enhanced security of its passports will convince the U.S. to offer visa-free treatment to Taiwan citizens.
Taiwan passport holders are allowed visa-free entry to some countries, including Japan, South Korea, and Singapore, for visits of up to 30 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade fair opens in Beijing to promote Taiwan produce, tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 27 (CNA) 06/27/09 17:45:42 (By Chang Ming-kun and Roger Chou)

TEXT.P: Senior officials of four local governments from central Taiwan hosted a trade fair Saturday in Beijing to showcase the area's agricultural products and tourism attractions.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu said the visiting delegation, which included Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and nearly 200 representatives of four cities and counties, was the biggest contingent from central Taiwan to ever visit the Chinese capital.

The Taiwan products on display at the trade fair, which is being held at the Beijing International Conference Center, include grapes and guavas from Changhua, tea from Nantou, golden bamboo shoots from Taichung city and other local specialties.
Chen Chao-wang, director of Nantou County's agricultural affairs department, represents Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching at the Beijing event.

To create a festive atmosphere, the organizers staged a wedding of a "Prince of Taichung" and "Princess of Sun Moon Lake in Nantou" as part of the promotion of the sun cakes and black tea that are specialities of those two areas, respectively.
Hu said the agricultural and tourism display was taken to Beijing after the success of similar promotional events in Hong Kong, Macau and Xiamen in China's Fujian province.
The delegation will meet with Chinese city officials during its stay in Beijing and is scheduled to return home June 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City launches promotion of Zhongshan North Road area

TEXT.P: A series of activities aimed at revitalizing business in the historical and cultural areas along Zhongshan North Road kicked off Saturday, with the Taipei City government and hundreds of shops vowing to provide a quality shopping and recreational experience to all customers.

"This is part of the city government's efforts to transform Taipei into a city that has its own special character and atmosphere, " Liu Chug-chun, chief manager of the Taipei City Office of Commerce (TCOOC), said at a news conference.
"Hundreds of enterprises, including hotels, restaurants, wedding salons and night markets, are located along Zhongshan North Road, which makes it a good place for clients of all kinds," he added.
The promotional event, dubbed "Zhongshan North Road, I Love You," was organized by the TCOOC and the Taipei City government's Department of Economic Development.
It kicked off Saturday with a 24-hour "City Afternoon Tea Marathon" that featured 800 free afternoon teas for visitors.
Noted Taiwanese writer Wang Wen-hua said at the news conference that Zhongshan North Road offers the best atmosphere in which to have afternoon tea because of the many speciality shops in the area.
According to the organizers, the entire event will run through July 31, with shops, restaurants and hotels in the area offering discounts.
In addition, individuals who shop at the participating stores will be eligible to compete in a lucky draw for prizes that include a 32-inch LCD television, home stereo theater, and MP3 players.

The Zhongshan North Road business area, known for its boutiques, hotels and wedding salons, is also home to the historical Dalongdong Baoan Temple where the Dalongdong Cultural Festival is held each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA crucial to Taiwan's competitiveness: SEF chairman

TEXT.P: The signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is crucial to Taiwan's ability to compete with other countries on an equal basis, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Saturday.

In a keynote speech at a national leadership forum held by the Taiwan Hakka Forum Association, Chiang noted that China, which joined the World Trade Organization as a developing country, has restricted the participation of foreign businesses, including those from Taiwan, in certain of its sectors.
However, many of the restricted sectors are open to Hong Kong businesses, mainly because Hong Kong has signed a Closer Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) with China, Chiang said.
This has resulted in a phenomenon in which many Taiwanese businesses have acquired Hong Kong companies so that they could enter the Chinese market, he said.
According to Chiang, economic agreements between countries can lead to a trade diversion effect, which is usually unfavorable to those excluded from the pacts.

For example, he said, after South Korea signed a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States, some Taiwanese businesses decided to set up operations in South Korea so as to obtain tariff-free treatment for their exports to the United States.
"This shows that if Taiwan cannot sign similar agreements with other countries, Taiwanese businesses will be deprived of the opportunity to compete fairly in the world markets," Chiang said.

To date, there are more than 400 economic agreements in effect worldwide, he noted. These include the economic integration in Europe, which allows for tariff exemptions and the free flow of goods and personnel in the region, he added.
Another example is the imminent economic integration between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and China, Japan and South Korea, he said.

Under this framework, Japan will grant tariff-free treatment to 90 percent of the goods exported by ASEAN countries and will gradually increase that to 93 percent within 10 years, which will severely undermine the competitiveness of Taiwanese exports, according to Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. scholars travel to Kinmen from China via 'mini three links'

TEXT.P: A delegation of U.S. scholars arrived in the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen Saturday from Xiamen in China's Fujian province via direct ferry services, commonly known as the "mini three links," across the Taiwan Strait.

Lee told his guests that the Kinmen County government has come up with a blueprint for building a bridge between Kinmen's Wulungshan and Xiamen's Dadeng, which would require an outlay of less than US$400 million.
